0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	0	Activation of the Insulin Gene Promoter through a Direct Effect of Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4* Reut Bartoov-Shifman, Rachel Hertz , Haiyan Wang , Claes B.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Wollheim , Jacob Bar-Tana , and Michael D.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the  Department of Biological Chemistry, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot 76100, Israel, the   Department of Human Nutrition and Metabolism, Faculty of Medicine, Hebrew University, Jerusalem 91120, Israel, and the   Division of Clinical Biochemistry, Department of Internal Medicine, University Medical Center, CH-1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, February 15, 2002, and in revised form, May 1, 2002.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	4	In adult mammals, the insulin gene is expressed exclusively in the beta cells of the endocrine pancreas (1-3).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	5	 This selectivity is controlled primarily at the transcriptional level through well defined promoter elements (4-6).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Although a number of transcription factors have been defined that interact with the insulin promoter and activate it in synergistic fashion (7-10), the action of these factors alone is not sufficient to explain the remarkable degree of cell specificity observed in vivo (9).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Most likely, additional transcription factors participate in achieving specificity.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	8	MODY1 is a monogenic form of diabetes characterized by impaired glucose-dependent insulin secretion in the absence of insulin resistance in peripheral tissues (11, 12).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	9	 This indicates that a beta cell defect is the primary cause of MODY and implies that MODY genes have a role in insulin production and/or secretion.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Consistent with this is the fact that four of the five known MODY subtypes are caused by mutations in distinct transcription factors expressed in pancreatic beta cells (13).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The striking MODY phenotype caused by such single gene disorders provides clear evidence of the important role of each of these transcription factors in beta cell function.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	12	MODY1 is caused by mutation in HNF4, a transcription factor of the nuclear receptor subfamily (14).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	13	 At least eight different mutations have been identified in MODY1 patients (15).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Four mutations result in truncated HNF4 proteins, of which two are nonsense mutations (14, 16), and two are frameshift mutations (17, 18).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The other four mutations are missense mutations that affect various domains of the HNF4 protein (19-22).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	16	MODY3 is caused by mutation in the HNF1 gene encoding a transcription factor of the homeodomain family (23).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Like HNF4, HNF1 is expressed in liver and beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In fact, HNF1 was shown to be a direct transcriptional target of HNF4 in liver (24).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Furthermore, a mutation in the HNF4-binding site in the HNF1 gene promoter produces a MODY phenotype (25).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Consistent with these observations, MODY1 and MODY3 show a similar clinical phenotype.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Recent studies (26) have shown that induction of dominant negative (DN) HNF1 in beta cells leads to alterations in expression of a number of beta cell genes including the insulin gene.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Because DN-HNF4 led to reduced activity of the Hnf1 promoter and reduced insulin mRNA levels (27), it was hypothesized that HNF4 increases insulin mRNA levels indirectly by increasing HNF1 levels, which in turn activate the promoter through binding to an HNF1 consensus sequence (28).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	23	Recently, however, strong evidence has been obtained indicating that this hypothesis may be an over-simplification and that the actual relationship between HNF4 and HNF1 may be more complex; it has been shown (29, 30) that P2, the major promoter of the Hnf4 gene in beta cells, is regulated by HNF1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Therefore, activation of beta cell genes by HNF4 may involve more than a simple transcriptional regulatory cascade mediated through HNF1, as previously envisaged.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	25	293T, HeLa S3 Tet-Off (CLONTECH PT3001-1), and COS7 cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, penicillin (200 IU/ml), and streptomycin (100  microg/ml).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	26	 INS-1 DN-HNF4 26 cells (27) were cultured in RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum, 25 mM HEPES, 2 mM L-glutamine, 1 mM sodium pyruvate, 50  microM 2-mercaptoethanol, penicillin (200 IU/ml), and streptomycin (100  microg/ml) supplemented with 150  microg/ml G418 and 100  microg/ml hygromycin.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	27	LUC, a plasmid containing the luciferase (LUC) gene controlled by the rat insulin I gene promoter, was generated by replacement of the SV40 promoter of pGL3-promoter vector (Promega) with the insulin promoter fragment (410 to 1).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	28	LUC is the plasmid pGL3-promoter vector (Promega), containing the luciferase gene controlled by the SV40 early promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	29	LUC contains the luciferase gene controlled by the RSV promoter (31).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	30	LUC contains the luciferase gene controlled by -actin promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	31	LUC contains the luciferase gene controlled by CMV enhancer and herpes simplex virus-thymidine kinase (TK) promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The reporter plasmids Synt 5 LUC, Synt 6 LUC, Synt 7 LUC, and Synt 8 LUC contain the luciferase gene controlled by Synt 5-8 block replacement mutants of the rat insulin I promoter (5).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	33	LUC was generated by PCR-mediated site-directed mutagenesis of pGL3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The nucleotides mutated (57 to 69) were ACGGCAAAGTCCA to CATTACCCTGAAC.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	35	LUC was generated by subcloning of the mutated insulin promoter from 410MFInsLUC to pGL3-promoter vector (Promega).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The nucleotides mutated (222 to 218) were TTAAT to GTCCG.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The Renilla luciferase internal control plasmid pRL.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	38	RSV contains the Renilla luciferase coding sequence from pRL null vector (Promega) controlled by the RSV promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	39	HNF4 encodes rat HNF4 controlled by the SV40 early promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	40	HNF4 encodes rat HNF4 controlled by the CMV promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	41	PDX1 is a PDX1 expression vector controlled by the CMV promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	42	E2A is a mouse E2A (E47) expression vector (9) controlled by the CMV promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	43	BETA is a BETA2 expression vector encoding hemagglutinin epitope-tagged BETA2 controlled by the CMV promoter (9).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	44	Transfections of 293T, HeLa, and COS7 cells were carried out by the calcium phosphate coprecipitation technique (32).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	45	 4-7 h after addition of DNA, cells were exposed to 20% glycerol in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium for 2 min.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Cells were harvested 40-48 h after transfection, and cell extracts were assayed for reporter enzyme activity.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	47	 INS-1 DN-HNF4 26 cells (27) were transfected using electroporation as follows.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Cells were suspended in 450  microl of cold phosphate-buffered saline (calcium/magnesium-free), and plasmid DNA dissolved in 50  microl of H2O was added.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Cells were incubated on ice for 10 min, then transferred to 4-mm gap cuvettes (BTX), and pulsed for 6 ms at 320 V/cm, 975 microfarads using an ECM 830 pulse generator.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	50	 For induction of DN-HNF4, cells were incubated with 1  microg/ml doxycycline for 24 h prior to transfection.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	51	Following transfection, cell extracts were prepared by 3 cycles of freeze-thawing, followed by centrifugation to remove cell debris.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The firefly and Renilla luciferase assays were carried out as follows: extracts containing 5-50  microg (2-5  microl) of protein were added to 50  microl of firefly luciferase assay buffer (Promega E1501) or 100  microl of Renilla luciferase assay buffer (33).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The samples were placed in a luminometer (LUMAC Biocounter M2500), and light output was determined over a 10-s interval.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Statistical significance was evaluated by t test using InStat software.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	55	Oligonucleotides were synthesized corresponding to the HNF4 binding element (HBE) region (5'-gatccGCCCTTAATGGGCCAAACGGCAAAGTCCAGGGa-3') from the rat insulin I promoter (5) (positions 86 to 53) and C3P region (5'-agctGCAGGTGACCTTTGACCAGCTc-3') from the rat ApoCIII promoter (34).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Radioactive probes were generated by incubation of the appropriate annealed oligonucleotides (5 pmol) in the presence of 50  microCi of [-32P]dATP (3,000 Ci/mmol), 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	57	25 mM dCTP, dGTP, and dTTP, and 5 units of DNA polymerase I (New England Biolabs, Klenow fragment) for 40 min at room temperature.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The radiolabeled oligonucleotides were separated from free nucleotide by spin dialysis using Sephadex G-50.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Specific activity obtained was typically ~2,000 cpm/fmol.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	60	Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	61	HNF4 Can Activate the Insulin Gene Promoter-- Because HNF4 was previously shown to affect insulin mRNA levels in beta cells (27), its involvement in the direct transcriptional regulation of the insulin gene was examined.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	62	 293T cells were transfected with a reporter plasmid encoding the luciferase gene controlled by the rat insulin I gene promoter (410 to 1) in the presence or absence of an HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	63	 For comparison, cells were also transfected with luciferase reporter plasmids controlled by no promoter or by other promoters as follows: RSV, -actin, CMV.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	64	TK, and SV40 in the presence or absence of HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	65	 HNF4 activated transcription of the insulin gene promoter 9.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	66	 1) but did not activate the other promoters tested, indicating that this activation is specific.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Similar results were obtained upon transfection of HeLa cells (not shown).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	68	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	69	   Activation of the insulin gene promoter by HNF4 protein.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	70	 293T cells were transfected with 1  microg of luciferase reporter plasmid containing either no promoter (pGL3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	71	basic), the rat insulin I gene promoter (pGL3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	72	Synt), or one of the following promoters: SV40, RSV, -actin, or CMV.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	73	TK in the presence of 1  microg of HNF4 expression plasmid (pcDNA3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	74	HNF4) or empty expression plasmid control.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Results are expressed as the ratio of luciferase activity observed in the presence as compared to the absence of HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Each data point represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	77	 of at least three independent transfection experiments for each reporter plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The asterisk indicates statistical significance (p  <  0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	79	0001) in the presence compared to the absence of HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	80	Identification of the Region in the Insulin Gene Promoter Important for HNF4 Activation-- In order to characterize further this HNF4-dependent activation, the insulin gene promoter was scanned for the presence of an HNF4 consensus binding sequence using TESS software (www.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Such a consensus site was found between nucleotides 57 and 69 (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	82	 2), suggesting the presence of an HNF4-binding site in the promoter of the insulin gene.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	83	 To determine whether this putative HNF4-binding site is necessary for HNF4 activation of the insulin gene promoter, we examined the ability of HNF4 to activate the insulin gene promoter mutated at this site.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Four block replacement mutants of the insulin promoter, spanning the consensus binding sequence and designated Synt 5-8, were used (5) (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	85	 As before, 293T cells were transfected with reporter plasmids encoding the luciferase gene controlled by the wild type rat insulin I promoter or by one of its mutated variants, Synt 5-8, in the presence or absence of HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	86	 HNF4 activation of mutants Synt 5 and Synt 8, in which mutations are located outside the putative HNF4-binding site, was not reduced compared with wild type promoter activation.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	87	 In contrast, mutation Synt 6 and Synt 7, each abolishing a part of the HNF4 consensus site, showed significantly attenuated activation (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	88	 These results indicate that the nucleotides mutated in mutants Synt 6 and Synt 7 are important for HNF4 activation of the insulin gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	89	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	90	   A consensus binding site for HNF4 in the insulin gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	91	 An HNF4 consensus site (boldface letters) is located between nucleotides 57 and 69 and adjacent to PDX1-binding site (boldface letters).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Block replacement mutants of the insulin promoter, designated Synt 5-8 (5), were generated by mutation of all nucleotides of the relevant portion of the wild type sequence as follows: A  C and G  T.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The location of the HBE probe is also shown.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (42K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	95	   Block replacement mutations in the HNF4 consensus binding site in the insulin gene promoter reduce HNF4 activation of the promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	96	 293T cells were transfected with 1  microg of luciferase (LUC) reporter plasmid containing the wild type rat insulin I promoter or each of the block replacement mutants Synt 5-8 in the presence of 1  microg of HNF4 expression plasmid (pcDNA3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	97	HNF4) or empty expression plasmid control.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The nucleotides mutated in Synt 5-8 are 43 to 53, 54 to 63, 64 to 68, and 79 to 88, respectively (5).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Results are expressed as the ratio of luciferase activity observed in the presence as compared to the absence of HNF4.

0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Asterisks indicate statistical significance (p = 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	103	0006 for Synt 7) compared with the values obtained for wild type promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	104	HNF4 Can Bind the Insulin Gene Promoter-- We next tested the ability of HNF4 to bind to the putative binding sequence in the insulin gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	105	 An EMSA was performed using a probe containing the putative HNF4-binding site, designated the HBE element (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Whole cell extracts were made from HeLa cells transfected with HNF4 expression plasmid and from untransfected HeLa cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Incubation of transfected extracts with the radiolabeled HBE probe resulted in a strong band that was absent when extracts from mock-transfected cells were used (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Competition with unlabeled HBE oligonucleotide abolished this band (lane 3).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Addition of anti-HNF4 serum generated a supershifted band that was not observed with preimmune serum, confirming the presence of HNF4 in the complex (lanes 4 and 5).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Apolipoprotein C III (ApoCIII) is a well characterized target gene of HNF4 (35, 36).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Competition with unlabeled oligonucleotide containing the C3P element, an HNF4-binding site in the ApoCIII gene promoter (37), also abolished the observed band (lane 6).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Competition with increasing amounts of unlabeled HBE and C3P probes indicates that HNF4 affinity to its binding site in ApoCIII gene is higher than its affinity to the binding site in the insulin gene (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	113	View larger version (44K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	114	   HNF4 can bind the insulin gene promoter, as demonstrated in EMSA.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	115	 A, whole cell extracts from mock-transfected HeLa cells (lane 1) or HeLa cells transfected with HNF4 expression vector (lanes 2-6) were incubated with 32P-labeled HBE probe and separated on a non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Specificity of binding was analyzed by adding 100- or 60-fold molar excess of unlabeled HBE probe (lane 3) or C3P probe (lane 6), respectively.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The formation of an immune complex is shown with the addition of anti-HNF4 serum (lane 4) and compared with the addition of preimmune serum (lane 5).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	118	 B, affinity of HNF4 to HBE probe is lower than its affinity to C3P probe.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Whole cell extracts made from untransfected COS7 cells (lane 1) or COS7 cells transfected with HNF4 expression vector (lanes 2-10) were incubated with 32P-labeled HBE probe and separated on a non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Competition was performed using 10-, 20-, 50-, and 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled HBE oligonucleotide (lanes 3-6, respectively) or 3-, 10-, 20-, and 50-fold molar excess of unlabeled C3P oligonucleotide (lanes 7-10, respectively).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	121	HNF4 and Other Insulin Gene Transcription Factors-- E2A (38-40), BETA2 (NeuroD) (41, 42), and PDX1 (also known as IPF1, STF1, and IDX1) (43-45) are well characterized insulin gene transcription factors that can synergistically activate the insulin gene promoter when cotransfected to HeLa cells with a reporter gene controlled by the promoter; however, when the insulin promoter construct is transfected to beta cells, it is ~4 times more active (9).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	122	 This implies that additional factor(s), present in beta cells, may be important for insulin gene regulation.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	123	 In light of our data showing that HNF4 can bind and activate the insulin gene promoter, its possible cooperation with the other three known insulin gene transcription factors was examined.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	124	 293T cells were transfected with a luciferase reporter plasmid controlled by the rat insulin I gene promoter and with expression plasmids encoding the four transcription factors E2A, BETA2, PDX1, and HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Expression of HNF4 with E2A, BETA2, and PDX1 produced a synergistic activation of the insulin gene promoter that was ~2-fold higher than the activation generated by the three factors alone (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Similar results were obtained upon transfecting HeLa cells (not shown).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	127	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	128	   A, HNF4 enhances the insulin gene promoter activation generated by E2A, BETA2, and PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	129	 293T cells were cotransfected with 1  microg of luciferase reporter plasmid containing the rat insulin I promoter in the presence or absence of 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	130	1  microg of expression vectors encoding HNF4, E2A, BETA2, and PDX1 as indicated.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Results are expressed relative to the activity observed in the presence of E2A + BETA2 + PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Each bar represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The asterisk indicates statistical significance (p = 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	134	005) compared with the value obtained upon transfection with E2A + BETA2 + PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	135	 B, HNF4 enhances PDX1 activation of the promoter in a synergistic manner.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	136	 293T cells were cotransfected with 1  microg of luciferase reporter plasmid containing the rat insulin I gene promoter in the presence or absence of 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	137	1  microg of expression plasmids encoding the indicated transcription factors.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Results are expressed relative to the activity observed in the presence of HNF4 + PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Each data point represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	140	 of 8 independent transfection experiments.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Asterisks indicate statistical significance (p  <  0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	142	0001 for HNF4 and for PDX1) compared with HNF4 + PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	143	To investigate further this augmented activation generated by HNF4, the effect of HNF4 and PDX1 was tested in the absence of E2A and BETA2.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	144	 293T cells were cotransfected with a reporter plasmid encoding the luciferase gene controlled by the rat insulin I promoter and with expression vectors encoding PDX1 and HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Expression of HNF4 and PDX1 generated synergistic activation of the promoter (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Synergistic activation was also observed in HeLa cells (not shown).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	147	 This cooperativity of HNF4 with PDX1 is probably responsible for the synergistic activation observed previously upon coexpression of HNF4 with E2A, BETA2, and PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	148	Mechanism of Action of HNF4 in Beta Cells-- Expression of dominant negative HNF1 in the beta cell line INS-1 reduced the expression of several beta cell genes, including the insulin gene (26), and has similar effects to that of dominant negative HNF4 (27).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Furthermore, HNF4 is a transcription activator of HNF1 (24, 27), and mutations in HNF1 are responsible for MODY3 (23).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	150	 This raises the possibility that HNF4 may activate the insulin gene indirectly, through Hnf1 gene function.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In non-beta cells, the HNF4-dependent activation we observed (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	152	 1) may be mediated in part through HNF1, but the substantial reduction in the activation of promoter mutated in the HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	153	 3) indicates that a significant portion of the effect is mediated directly.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	154	To assess the significance of the HNF4 site in the insulin gene promoter in beta cells, and to test whether in beta cells HNF4 activates the insulin gene promoter directly or indirectly through HNF1, we used INS-1 DN-HNF4 26 cells, a derivative of INS-1 cells that contains a plasmid encoding doxycycline-inducible dominant negative HNF4 (27).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	155	 This dominant negative protein possesses a functional dimerization domain but lacks a DNA binding domain and therefore suppresses activity of the endogenous wild type HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Luciferase reporter plasmids controlled by wild type rat insulin I gene promoter or by promoter mutated either in HNF1- or HNF4-binding sites were electroporated into these cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	157	 In the absence of doxycycline (i.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	158	 no expression of DN-HNF4), mutations in either the HNF4 site or the HNF1 site led to reduced activity of the insulin gene promoter (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Thus both sites are important for full transcriptional activation in beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	160	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	161	   Effect of DN-HNF4 on wild type and mutated insulin gene promoter in beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	162	 A, luciferase reporter genes containing wild type insulin gene promoter (wild type, WT) and insulin gene promoter containing mutations in the HNF1 site (HNF1) or HNF4 site (HNF4) were electroporated into INS-1 DN-HNF4 26 cells in the presence (light bars) and absence (dark bars) of doxycycline (Dox.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Cells were harvested 48 h following electroporation, and normalized luciferase activity was determined.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Results are expressed relative to the activity obtained for wild type promoter in the absence of doxycycline.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Each data point represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	166	 of at least three independent electroporation experiments.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Asterisks indicate statistical significance (p = 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	168	02 for HNF1) in the presence compared to the absence of doxycycline.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	169	 B, model depicting possible effects of DN-HNF4 on insulin gene expression.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	170	Identification of HNF1 and HNF4 as the mutated genes responsible for MODY3 and MODY1, respectively, has prompted efforts to establish the precise role of these factors in health and disease.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Because the MODY phenotype involves a primary defect in beta cells, the defective function of these transcription factors must be manifested in these cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Indeed, expression of DN-HNF1 and DN-HNF4 leads to clear alterations in expression of key beta cell genes, including the insulin gene (26, 27).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Because previous studies have shown that HNF4 is an activator of HNF1 (24) and that MODY3 can be caused by mutation in an HNF4-binding site in the HNF1 promoter (25), it was proposed that the effect of HNF4 on the insulin gene promoter is indirect, mediated through activation of HNF1 (27).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	174	In this report, we have examined the above hypothesis.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Expression of DN-HNF4 in beta cells led to reduced activity of both wild type insulin gene promoter and promoter mutated in the HNF1-binding site, strongly suggesting the presence of an HNF4-binding site elsewhere in the promoter region.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Indeed, we identified such a sequence between nucleotides 57 and 69 of the promoter, and we were able to show that it is capable of binding HNF4 in vitro.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	177	 We further showed that this site is essential for full activation of the promoter in beta cells and for efficient HNF4-dependent activation in non-beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Expression of DN-HNF4 in beta cells also led to reduced activity of a promoter construct bearing mutations in the HNF4 site.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The data therefore indicate that in addition to the previously recognized indirect action of HNF4 on insulin gene expression mediated through HNF1, there is also a direct action mediated through binding to the novel HNF4 consensus sequence in the promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Gerber for assistance with plasmid construction and Dr.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Dikstein for gifts of plasmids.

0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	183	), and Swiss National Science Foundation Grant 32-49755.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	184	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	187	Holds the Marvin Meyer and Jenny Cyker Chair of Diabetes Research.
