0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Mutations in the HNF4-binding site are represented in boldface type.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Plasmids were transfected into HepG2 (B) and CV-1 (C) cells, and the normalized activity  plus or minus  S.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	109	 (n = 4) of each construct is presented as relative activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	110	View this table:    TABLE I Analysis of free bile acids in gallbladder bile of liver-specific HNF4-null and control mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	111	Amounts of - and -MCA were combined.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Data are mean  plus or minus  S.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	113	 (FLOX (n = 7 to 8) and KO (n = 6 to 8)).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Significant differences compared with FLOX mice: *, p  <  0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	115	View this table:    TABLE II Analysis of conjugated bile acids in gallbladder bile of liver-specific HNF4-null and control mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	116	Data are mean  plus or minus  S.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	117	 (FLOX (n = 7 to 8) and KO (n = 6 to 8)).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Significant differences compared with FLOX mice: *, p  <  0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	119	View larger version (95K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Northern blot analysis of VLACSR and BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Total liver RNA was isolated, and 10  microg was subjected to electrophoresis on a 1% agarose gel, transferred to a nylon membrane, and hybridized with the indicated 32P-labeled cDNA probes.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	122	 TAUT, taurine transporter; AGXT, alanine:glyoxylate aminotransferase.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	123	  Free BAs and Glycine-conjugated BAs Are Increased in Gallbladder Bile of Liver-specific HNF4-null Mice Because the expression of VLACSR and BAT was decreased in H4LivKO mice, it was expected that free BAs are increased and conjugation patterns are altered in H4LivKO mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Most BAs in the H4Flox mice are also found as conjugated derivatives in gallbladder bile because only small amounts of free BAs were detected (Table I).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	125	 However, free BAs were significantly increased in the gallbladders of H4LivKO mice (Table I), indicating that the conjugation enzymatic machinery of the BAs might be impaired by decreased expression of VLACSR in the livers of H4LivKO mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	126	The conjugation pattern of BA in gallbladder bile was further determined by LC-MS/MS (Table II).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In male H4Flox mice, taurocholic acid (TCA) and tauro--muricholic acid (T--MCA) were the predominant BAs.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The concentrations of these BAs (Table II, upper) were decreased in H4LivKO mice, but the total amounts (Table II, lower) were almost unchanged (TCA) or increased (T--MCA).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Most mammals secrete BAs conjugated with taurine and/or glycine, but mouse gallbladder bile contains only the taurine-conjugated forms (18).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	130	 However, small amounts of glycine-conjugated BAs including glycocholic acid, glycodeoxycholic acid (GDCA), and glycochenodeoxycholic acid (GCDCA) were detected in the H4Flox mice, and their levels were much lower as compared with their taurine-conjugated derivatives.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	131	 In contrast to the results with control mice, taurodeoxycholic acid (TDCA), GDCA, taurochenodeoxycholic acid (TCDCA), and glycochenodeoxycholic acid (GCDCA) were increased in H4LivKO mice with GDCA and GCDCA being markedly elevated.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	132	 These results indicate that the conjugation pattern of BAs in H4LivKO mice is significantly different from H4Flox mice because of decreased expression of BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Because glycine-conjugated BAs are increased and taurine-conjugated BAs are maintained in H4LivKO mice, an unidentified BAT that can use both glycine and taurine as substrates might play an important role in H4LivKO mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	134	Expression of the Mouse VLACSR Gene Is Directly Regulated by HNF4 To investigate why expression of VLACSR was reduced in H4LivKO mice, the promoter region of the mouse VLACSR gene was cloned (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	135	 A transcription start site was determined by 5'-rapid amplification of cDNA ends, and five major sites were identified between  to 143 and  to 85 from translation start site (+1).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	136	 A putative HNF4-binding site and a GC box were found between  to 162 and  to 150 and  to 238 and  to 229, respectively (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	137	 To determine whether HNF4 has the potential to activate the mouse VLACSR promoter, several VLACSR promoter-luciferase reporter plasmids were constructed (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	138	 When HepG2 cells, which express HNF4, were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the  to 194-bp fragment containing a putative HNF4-binding site was higher than that of the promoterless construct (pGL3/basic) and the  to 146-bp fragment (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The promoter activities of the  to 220-bp fragment was higher than  to 194-bp fragment, indicating that the nucleotide sequence between  to 220 and  to 195 bp, which are GC-rich regions similar to the GC box between  to 238 and  to 229 bp, might be important for promoter activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Furthermore, the promoter activities of the  to 256-,  to 1014-,  to 1435-, and  to 2219-bp fragments, which contain an HNF4-binding site and GC-rich sequences, were much higher than that of  to 194- and  to 220-bp fragments.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	141	 To determine whether HNF4 positively regulates the promoter activity, CV-1 cells, which do not express HNF4, were used.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The promoter activity of the  to 146-bp fragment was unchanged by cotransfection of the HNF4 expression vector, consistent with the absence of an HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	143	 However, the promoter activity of the  to 194-bp fragment was increased by cotransfection with an HNF4 expression vector.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The same results were obtained using the longer fragments, indicating that HNF4 positively regulates expression of the VLACSR gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Interestingly, the basal promoter activity of  to 220-bp fragment was increased in the absence of HNF4 expression, and the activity of  to 256-bp fragment was much higher.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Because a GC-rich sequence was observed in the region between  to 256 and  to 195 bp, the Sp1 family proteins might be important in activating maximal promoter activity in the presence of HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	147	View larger version (39K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Nucleotide sequence of the mouse VLACSR gene promoter.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	149	 A, localization of HNF4-binding site and GC box in the mouse VLACSR gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	150	 B, numbering of nucleotides is relative to the translation start site (nucleotide +1, arrow).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The asterisk marks the transcription start sites.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The putative binding site for HNF4 at  to 162 and  to 150, and GC box at  to 238 and  to 229 are indicated by boldface and underlined, respectively.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	153	  To determine whether HNF4 can bind to the HNF4-binding site in the mouse VLACSR promoter, gel shift analysis was performed (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Liver nuclear extracts from H4Flox mice contained proteins that bound to the HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Binding was diminished by the addition of excess amounts of unlabeled VLACSR probe (wild-type) but not by the mutated probe, indicating that a protein specifically bound to this site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	156	 3C, lanes 2 and 3, the lower arrow).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Furthermore, these bands were supershifted by the addition of anti-HNF4 antibody, indicating that the protein bound to this HNF4-binding site was indeed HNF4 (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	158	 However, supershifted bands were not detected using liver nuclear extracts from H4LivKO mice (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	159	 3C, lane 9) and no specific complex, indicated by the lower arrow, was detected using the labeled mutated probe (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	160	 These results indicate that the HNF4-binding site in the mouse VLACSR promoter is capable of binding HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	161	To determine whether disruption of the HNF4-binding site and GC box decreases the promoter activity, mutations were introduced into the HNF4-binding site and GC box in the mouse VLACSR ( to 1014/ to 47)-luciferase construct (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	162	 4B, when HepG2 cells were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the HNF4 mutant ( to 1014/HNF4 Mut) was decreased as compared with the wild-type construct ( to 1024/WT).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The promoter activity of the GC box mutant ( to 1014/GC box Mut) was further decreased, and the double mutants for both the HNF4-binding site and GC box ( to 1014/HNF4/GC box Mut) had almost no promoter activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	164	 When CV-1 cells were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the HNF4 mutant ( to 1014/HNF4 Mut) was decreased to 40% as compared with the wild-type fragment ( to 1014/WT) in the presence of HNF4 (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The basal activity of the GC box mutant ( to 1014/GC box Mut) was decreased to the same level as the promoterless vector, but the activity was still increased by HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Furthermore, introduction of mutations into the binding sites of both factors ( to 1014/HNF4/GC box Mut) caused a marked reduction of promoter activities even in the presence of HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	167	 These results indicate that the HNF4 and a GC box-binding protein can activate expression of the VLACSR gene, but both are needed for the maximal activation.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	168	Expression of the Mouse BAT Gene Is Directly Regulated by HNF4 In order to investigate why the expression of BAT was reduced in H4LivKO mice, the promoter region of the mouse BAT gene was cloned (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	169	 An HNF4-binding site was found between  to 68 and  to 56 from the transcription start site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	170	 However, the promoter activity of the 3078-bp fragment between the beginning of intron 1 and translation start site was not induced in HepG2 and CV-1 cells by cotransfection with HNF4 (data not shown).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	171	 To determine whether HNF4 has the potential to activate the mouse BAT promoter, several BAT promoter-luciferase reporter plasmids were constructed (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	172	 When HepG2 cells were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the  to 136-bp fragment containing a putative HNF4-binding site was higher than that of the promoterless construct (pGL3/basic) and the  to 52-bp fragment (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The promoter activities of the longer fragments were much higher than that of the  to 136-bp fragment.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	174	 To determine whether this effect was due to HNF4, CV-1 cells were used.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The promoter activity of the  to 52-bp fragment was unchanged by cotransfection of the HNF4-expression vector, consistent with the absence of an HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	176	 However, the promoter activity of the  to 136-bp fragment was increased by HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The same results were obtained from experiments using the longer fragments.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	178	View larger version (38K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Nucleotide sequence of the mouse BAT gene promoter.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	180	 A, localization of HNF4-binding site in the mouse BAT gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The asterisk marks the translation start site in exon 2.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	182	 B, numbering of nucleotides is relative to the transcription start site (+1, arrow).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The putative binding site for HNF4 at  to 68 and  to 56 is indicated by boldface and underlined.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	184	  To determine whether HNF4 can bind to the DR1-like elements in the mouse BAT promoter, gel shift analysis was performed (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Liver nuclear extracts from H4Flox mice contained proteins that bound to the HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Binding was diminished by the addition of excess amounts of unlabeled BAT probe (wild-type) but not by the mutated probe, indicating that a protein specifically bound to this site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	187	 6C, lanes 2 and 3, the lower arrow).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Furthermore, these bands were supershifted by the addition of anti-HNF4 antibody, indicating that the protein bound to this HNF4-binding site was indeed HNF4 (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Supershifted bands were not detected using liver nuclear extracts from H4LivKO mice (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	190	 6C, lane 9), and no specific complex, indicated by the lower arrow, was detected using the labeled mutated probe (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	191	 These results indicate that the HNF4-binding site in the mouse BAT promoter is capable of binding HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	192	To determine whether disruption of the HNF4-binding site decreases the promoter activity, the same mutations used in Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	193	 6C were introduced into the HNF4-binding site in the mouse BAT ( to 602/+178)-luciferase construct (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	194	 7B, when HepG2 cells were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the mutated  to 602-bp fragment ( to 602/Mut) was decreased to 25% as compared with the wild-type fragment ( to 602/WT).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	195	 When CV-1 cells were used, the promoter activity of the mutated fragment was decreased to 15% by cotransfection of HNF4 as compared with the wild-type fragment (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	196	 7C), indicating that the HNF4-binding site is important for activation of the mouse BAT promoter.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	197	Because the levels of unconjugated (free) BAs are very low in gallbladder bile (22), increased levels of unconjugated BAs in liver-specific HNF4-null mice appear to be due to decreased expression of VLACSR and BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Because VLACSR and BAT are preferentially expressed in liver (18, 19) as well as HNF4, HNF4 is a central factor in the regulation of VLACSR and BAT in vivo.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	199	 An HNF4-binding site and a GC-rich region were identified in the promoter region of the mouse VLACSR gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Indeed, HNF4 binds to this HNF4-binding site, and the promoter activities were dependent on this site and expression of HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Furthermore, a GC-rich sequence was also important for maximal activation of the VLACSR gene because the mutated GC-rich sequence reduced its basal promoter activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	202	 It was reported that HNF4 and Sp1, a prototypical GC box-binding protein, binds to promoter regions of genes, including apolipoprotein C-III and CYP27, and increases their expression (23, 24).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	203	 In the mouse VLACSR promoter, HNF4 can still activate promoter activity when mutations were introduced into the GC box, but the resultant activity was much lower when compared with that of the wild-type promoter.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	204	 This result indicates that cooperative binding of HNF4 and Sp1 to the promoter might be required for maximal induction of VLACSR expression in the liver.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Furthermore, the expression of sterol carrier protein x, which is involved in the side chain -oxidation of BA, was also reduced in liver-specific HNF4-null mice, and Sp1 was identified as a critical factor regulating the sterol carrier protein x gene in an HNF4-independent manner (data not shown).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Because expression of Sp1 and Sp3, typical GC box-binding proteins, was unchanged and VLACSR expression is markedly reduced in liver-specific HNF4-null mice (data not shown), post-transcriptional modification of Sp1 and/or Sp3 could reduce the expression of VLACSR in these null mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	207	In addition to increased unconjugated BAs in serum, glycine-conjugated BAs such as GDCA and GCDCA were significantly increased in the gallbladder of liver-specific HNF4-null mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Because mouse BAT has no glycine conjugation activity (19), expression of an unidentified BAT gene might be activated in H4LivKO mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Actually a few mouse genes that exhibit similarity to mouse BAT were cloned, but their function is still unknown.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Expression of one of these genes (GenBankTM accession number NM_145368 [GenBank] ) was found to be increased in the livers of H4LivKO mice (data not shown).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	211	 However, it remains unclear whether this gene encodes an enzyme with glycine conjugation activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Furthermore, the physiological role of increased GDCA and GCDCA in H4LivKO mice also remains unclear, but these BAs in the intestinal lumen might change many aspects of intestinal and whole body cholesterol homeostasis.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	213	Recently it was reported (25) that a mutation of the BAT coding sequence causes human familial hypercholanemia that is characterized by elevated serum BA, and serum of homozygous individuals for this mutation contains only unconjugated BAs.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Because serum unconjugated BAs are increased, but most BAs in the gallbladder are conjugated forms in liver-specific HNF4-null mice, protein and enzyme activity of VLACSR and BAT might still be active in these mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	215	 In human disease, mutations in the HNF4-binding sites were reported in HNF1, blood coagulation factor VII, and IX (9).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Because HNF4 regulates many liver-enriched genes, human diseases might be found to be caused by mutations of the HNF4-binding sites in the VLACSR and BAT genes.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	217	It was reported that the expression of BAL and BAT is induced by treatment with ligands for the farnesoid X receptor (FXR) in rat, and this induction was due to the binding of FXR to FXR-binding sites in their promoter regions (26).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Because this phenomenon was not observed in mouse, regulation of both genes by FXR exhibits a species difference between rat and mouse (26).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Actually, neither VLACSR nor BAT gene was induced in wild-type mice treated with cholic acid, a ligand for FXR (data not shown).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Unlike other nuclear receptors including FXR, HNF4 is constitutively activated in vivo and in vitro without exogenous compounds (9).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Thus, HNF4 positively regulates the basal levels of expression of the VLACSR and BAT genes.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	222	 It may also be involved in the regulation of transporters such as OATP1 and NTCP that are required for hepatocyte uptake of conjugated BAs from the portal circulation (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	223	View larger version (25K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Schematic representation of regulatory targets of HNF4 in bile acid transport and conjugation.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Bile acids, conjugated by VLACSR and BAT, are exported from hepatocytes by transporters such as bile salt export pump located at the canalicular membrane.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Most bile acids are recycled and transported from the portal circulation back into hepatocytes by transporters including NTCP and OATP1 located at the basolateral membrane.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Expression of OATP1, NTCP, VLACSR, and BAT is reduced in liver-specific HNF4-null mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Note that HNF4 directly regulates the expression of VLACSR and BAT via HNF4-binding sites in their promoters.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	229	  Many nuclear receptors including FXR are involved in regulating the BA biosynthesis pathway and transport system (6, 14, 15).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Thus, these nuclear receptors also might have important roles in inducing or repressing the expression of VLACSR and BAT to regulate the BA conjugation pathway.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	231	   FOOTNOTES   * The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	232	 This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	234	To whom correspondence should be addressed: Laboratory of Metabolism, Center for Cancer Research, NCI, National Institutes of Health, 9000 Rockville Pike, Bldg.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	235	: 301-496-9067; Fax: 301-496-8419; E-mail: fjgonz{at}helix.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	236	1 The abbreviations used are: BAs, bile acids; HNF4, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4; BAL, bile acid-CoA ligase; BAT, bile acid-CoA:amino acid N-acyltransferase; VLACSR, very long chain acyl-CoA synthase-related; NTCP, sodium taurocholate cotransporter polypeptide; OATP1, organic anion transporter polypeptide 1; LC-MS/MS, liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry/mass spectrometry; MCA, muricholic acid; GDCA, glycodeoxycholic acid; GCDCA, glycochenodeoxycholic acid; TCA, taurocholic acid; T--MCA tauro--muricholic acid; TDCA, taurodeoxycholic acid; TCDCA, taurochenodeoxycholic acid; WT, wild-type; FXR, farnesoid X receptor.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	0	Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor Is a Negative Regulator of Steroidogenesis in Bovine Adrenal Glomerulosa Cells Carine F.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Buholzer, Jean-Francois Arrighi, Shahnaz Abraham, Vincent Piguet, Alessandro M.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	2	Division of Endocrinology, Diabetology and Nutrition (C.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	3	) and Department of Dermatology and Venereology (J.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	4	), University Hospital, CH-1211 Geneva 14, Switzerland.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	5	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Professor Alessandro M.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Capponi, Division of Endocrinology, Diabetology, and Nutrition, University Hospital, 24 rue Micheli-du-Crest, CH-1211 Geneva 14, Switzerland.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	7	This crucial step of intramitochondrial cholesterol transfer is performed by the steroidogenic acute regulatory (StAR) protein (4, 5).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The ultimate demonstration of the indispensable role of the StAR protein came from congenital lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, an inherited disease that leads to a dramatic deficiency in all steroid hormones and in which loss of function mutations have been discovered in the StAR gene (6).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	9	Because the StAR protein mediates the rate-limiting step in steroidogenesis, its expression must be finely regulated.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Indeed, in human NCI-H295R adrenocortical carcinoma cells, hormone-stimulated StAR protein synthesis and steroid production are prevented by inhibition of RNA synthesis (7).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells in primary culture, mimicking the calcium signal gener ated by AngII leads to increased expression of StAR mRNA and protein (8).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Similarly, treatment of human NCI-H295R cells with AngII results in an increase in StAR mRNA levels within 30 min, with maximal levels being reached within 6 h (7, 9).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These results clearly indicate a transcriptional regulation of AngII on StAR gene expression.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Various consensus response elements have been identified in the StAR gene promoter (10).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Although promoter mapping studies have provided extensive information on activators of the StAR gene, the role of transcription factors that repress StAR protein expression has received less attention.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The best characterized repressor of the StAR gene is DAX-1 (dosage-sensitive sex reversal, adrenal hypoplasia congenita critical region on the X chromosome, gene 1), a member of the orphan nuclear receptor family (11, 12, 13).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Our laboratory has recently demonstrated that AngII powerfully represses DAX-1 expression in bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells, thus leading to increased StAR expression and aldosterone production (14).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	18	Another potential candidate for a negative regulation of the StAR gene is chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor (COUP-TF), which is usually present as two isoforms, COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII (15, 16).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	19	 These orphan members of the steroid receptor superfamily play distinct and crucial roles in fetal development of the nervous (17) and cardiovascular (18) systems.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In addition to these well-established developmental effects in fetal life, the following pieces of evidence suggest a direct or indirect interaction between COUP-TF and the promoter of the StAR gene and thus an involvement of COUP-TF in adult steroidogenic cell function.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	21	 First, COUP-TF colocalizes in the nuclei of the adrenal cells with DAX-1 and steroidogenic factor-1 (SF-1), two transcription factors involved in steroidogenesis and in StAR regulation, and its expression is modulated in adrenocortical adenomas, COUP-TFI being lower in aldosterone-producing tumors than in normal tissue (19, 20) and COUP-TFII appearing to be increased in aldosteronoma cells (21).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In normal adrenocortical tissue, COUP-TFI and -II expression levels appear to be qualitatively equivalent (20).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Second, it has been recently shown that SF-1 and COUP-TF can activate and repress, respectively, bovine CYP17 gene transcription in Y-1 mouse adrenocortical cells (22, 23).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Third, a similar competition between SF-1 and COUP-TF for a composite binding site has been demonstrated for other genes involved in steroidogenesis, including human aldosterone synthase, aromatase, and murine DAX-1 genes (23, 24, 25).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Taken together, these data raise the question of a possible negative role of COUP-TF in the regulation of StAR gene expression.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	26	In the present work, we have therefore examined whether COUP-TFs are involved in the regulation of basal and AngII- or ACTH-induced aldosterone biosynthesis in bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells in primary culture.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Our results show clearly that COUP-TF is a negative regulator of mineralocorticoid biosynthesis.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	28	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	29	 AngII Represses COUP-TF Protein Levels in a Concentration-Dependent Manner.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	30	Bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells were stimulated for 6 h with AngII at various concentrations.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	31	 COUP-TF was determined in nuclear extracts and aldosterone was measured in the incubation medium as described in Materials and Methods.

0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Each value is the mean  plus or minus  SEM of three experiments performed with separate cell preparations.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	36	  View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Time-Dependent Repression of COUP-TF Protein by AngII.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	38	Bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells were treated with AngII (10 nM) for the indicated periods of time, after which COUP-TF protein was determined in nuclear extracts as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	39	 A, Representative Western blot of COUP-TF.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	40	 B, Densitometric analysis of COUP-TF levels in AngII-stimulated cells as a function of time, expressed as percentage of control values (Ctrl) at time zero.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Each point is the mean value from two separate experiments.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	42	  AngII-Induced Repression of COUP-TF Is Independent of Protein Synthesis AngII-induced inhibition of COUP-TF protein expression was paralleled by a decrease in COUP-TF mRNA levels, an inhibition to 18  plus or minus  8.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	43	01) being reached with 10 nM AngII after 6 h, as shown in Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	44	 To determine whether de novo protein synthesis is required for AngII-mediated COUP-TF repression, we treated bovine glomerulosa cells for 6 h with 10 nM AngII in the presence of 10  microg/ml cycloheximide, a protein synthesis inhibitor.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Blockade of protein synthesis affected neither the inhibitory effect of AngII on COUP-TF mRNA expression (Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	46	 3, A and B) nor its repression of COUP-TF protein levels in glomerulosa cells (Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	47	 These observations suggest that de novo protein synthesis is not required for AngII-induced repression of COUP-TF.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	48	 In this same series of experiments, forskolin was as potent as AngII in repressing COUP-TF mRNA (data not shown) and protein levels (Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	49	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Effect of AngII and Cycloheximide (CHX) Treatment on COUP-TF mRNA and Protein Levels.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	51	Bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells were treated for 6 h with AngII (10 nM) in the absence or in the presence of 10  microg/ml cycloheximide.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	52	 COUP-TF mRNA and protein levels were determined by Northern blot and Western blot analysis, respectively, as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	53	 A, Representative Northern blot of COUP-TF mRNA.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	54	 B, Densitometric analysis of COUP-TF mRNA levels in glomerulosa cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	55	 C, Representative Western blot of COUP-TF.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	56	 D, Densitometric analysis of COUP-TF protein levels in glomerulosa cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Values are means  plus or minus  SEM from three separate experiments.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	58	  AngII Does Not Affect COUP-TF mRNA Stability To determine whether AngII affects COUP-TF mRNA stability, we incubated control and AngII-stimulated adrenal glomerulosa cells in the presence of 1  microg/ml actinomycin D, a transcription inhibitor, for various periods of time and determined COUP-TF mRNA levels by Northern blot analysis.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	59	 4, in the presence of actinomycin, COUP-TFI mRNA decayed with a half-life of approximately 8 h, and AngII did not alter COUP-TFI mRNA stability over a 24-h period.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	60	View larger version (31K):    Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Effect of Actinomycin D on COUP-TFI mRNA Levels in AngII-Treated Bovine Adrenal Glomerulosa Cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	62	Bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells were treated with 2.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	63	5  microg/ml actinomycin D in the absence or in the presence of AngII (10 nM) for the indicated periods of time.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	64	 COUP-TFI mRNA levels were determined by Northern blot analysis as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	65	 A, Representative Northern blot of COUP-TFI.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	66	 B, Densitometric analysis of COUP-TFI mRNA levels.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Values are means  plus or minus  SEM from three separate experiments.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	68	  Effect of COUP-TF Overexpression on StAR Expression and on Mineralocorticoid Production Lentiviral vectors have proven to be highly useful infection tools.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Indeed, HIV-derived lentiviral vectors efficiently integrate into nondividing cells (31, 32).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Because bovine glomerulosa cells in primary culture are practically quiescent and in view of the relatively low transfection efficacy obtained in these cells with the usual transfection reagents, we used HIV-derived vectors to overexpress COUP-TFI and -II in glomerulosa cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	71	 We first infected bovine glomerulosa cells with lentiviral vectors encoding green fluorescent protein (GFP) under control of the human phospholgycerate kinase (hPGK) promoter.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The infected cells were analyzed for GFP fluorescence by flow-cytometric analysis 5 d after infection.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Ninety-one percent of the cells infected with 500 ng p24 expressed GFP (data not shown).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Bovine glomerulosa cells in primary culture were then infected with lentiviral vectors encoding for murine COUP-TFI or COUP-TFII under control of the hPGK promoter.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Five days after infection, cells were incubated in the presence of 10 nM AngII for 6 h, and StAR, COUP-TFI, and COUP-TFII mRNA levels were determined by RT-PCR with bovine- and mouse-specific primers.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	76	 As expected, no endogenous signal was detected in noninfected and mock-infected cells because we used murine probes (Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In contrast, the infected cells displayed robust expression of mouse COUP-TFI and -II mRNA, as determined by RT-PCR with mouse-specific primers.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	78	 5B, AngII treatment for 6 h induced an increase of StAR mRNA levels in noninfected and mock-infected cells [to 172  plus or minus  14% and 165  plus or minus  10% of controls, respectively (n = 3; P  <  0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	79	 This increase was entirely blocked in cells overexpressing either COUP-TFI [104  plus or minus  12% of controls; n = 3; not significantly different (NS; P  >  0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	80	05)] or COUP-TFII (82  plus or minus  24% of controls; n = 3; NS) (Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	81	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Effect of COUP-TFI and II Overexpression on StAR mRNA Levels and Aldosterone Production in Bovine Adrenal Glomerulosa Cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	83	The COUP-TFI and -II isoforms were overexpressed in bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells using lentiviral vectors.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	84	 StAR mRNA levels and aldosterone production were determined in control (Ctrl) and AngII-stimulated (10 nM, 6 h), noninfected (NI), mock-infected (Mock), and COUP-TFI- or COUP-TFII-infected cells as described in Materials and Methods.

0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	86	 B, Densitometric analysis of StAR mRNA in control cells and in cells challenged with AngII.

0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	92	2% of controls; n = 3; NS) (Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	93	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Effect of COUP-TFI Overexpression on StAR Protein Levels in Bovine Adrenal Glomerulosa Cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	95	COUP-TFI was overexpressed in bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells using a classical transient transfection technique as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	96	 StAR protein levels were determined by Western blot after 10 nM AngII treatment of the cells for 6 h.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	97	 A, Representative Western blot.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	98	 B, Densitometric analysis of StAR protein levels.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Values are means  plus or minus  SEM from three separate experiments.

0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	101	  Basal aldosterone production rate amounted to 3.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	102	4 fmol/ microg protein/6 h in both untreated noninfected and mock-infected cells and rose to 17.

0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	104	4 fmol/ microg protein/6 h in mock-infected cells under AngII challenge (n = 3; P  <  0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	105	 In contrast, AngII only increased aldosterone production from 5.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	106	0 fmol/ microg protein/6 h in cells overexpressing COUP-TFI and from 4.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	107	7 fmol/ microg protein/6 h in cells overexpressing COUP-TFII (n = 3; P  <  0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	108	 AngII response in noninfected cells) (Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	109	Effect of COUP-TFI on StAR Promoter Activity To gain further insight into the regulation of StAR gene expression by COUP-TFs, we performed a dual luciferase reporter assay in bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells in primary culture.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	110	3-kb human StAR promoter region directing the expression of the luciferase reporter gene (Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	111	 7A) was transfected into bovine glomerulosa cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Treatment of the cells with AngII 10 to 8 M for 6 h significantly increased StAR promoter activity 2.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	113	 7B, this AngII-induced effect was completely abolished in cells that had been cotransfected with either COUP-TFI (0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	114	 mock-transfected cells for both treatments).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	115	View larger version (34K):    Fig.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	116	 COUP-TFI and -II Prevent StAR Promoter Activity by Directly Interacting with the StAR Promoter in Bovine Adrenal Glomerulosa Cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	117	A, COUP-TFI and -II were cotransfected with the StAR-luc reporter construct in bovine glomerulosa cells in primary culture as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	118	 B, Densitometric analysis of the relative StAR promoter activity in mock-transfected and COUP-TFI- and COUP-TFII-overexpressing cells, in the presence and absence of 10 nM AngII.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	119	 C, EMSA: nuclear extracts derived from control bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells or cells stimulated with 10 nM AngII were incubated with the labeled StAR promoter fragment probe (see Materials and Methods) in the absence or in the presence of a purified COUP-TFI antibody and submitted to PAGE followed by autoradiography.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The EMSA is representative of three separate experiments yielding similar results.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	121	 D, ChIP assay was performed on bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells using a purified COUP-TFI antibody for immunoprecipitation and specific primers corresponding to the StAR promoter for real-time PCR, as described in detail in Materials and Methods.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Representative agarose gel of the amplification product.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	123	 E, Densitometric analysis of the ChIP assay.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Values are means  plus or minus  SEM from three separate experiments.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	125	  Interaction of COUP-TFI with the StAR Promoter To examine whether the transcription factor COUP-TFI interacts directly with the StAR promoter for its action, we performed EMSAs.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Because direct competition between SF-1 and COUP-TF is known for binding to other gene promoters, we used a 23-bp DNA fragment containing the proximal SF-1 response element of the bovine StAR promoter as a probe.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	127	 7C, lanes 2 and 3, nuclear extracts of bovine glomerulosa cells shifted the labeled probe, generating at least two bands.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	128	 When the nuclear extracts were preincubated with a purified antibody directed against COUP-TFI, the intensity of the shifted bands was dramatically reduced, thus suggesting that COUP-TFI binds to the proximal StAR promoter in vitro (lanes 4 and 5).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	129	 No significant differences in the intensity of the shifted bands were observed with nuclear extracts from AngII-treated cells (lanes 3 and 5) in this qualitative assay.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	130	Finally, this interaction was confirmed by in vivo analysis of the physical interaction between COUP-TFI and the StAR promoter, using the chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assay.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	131	 7, D and E, immunoprecipitation with a COUP-TFI antibody of nuclear extracts of glomerulosa cells, followed by real-time PCR of the StAR promoter, yielded a band of the expected size on agarose gel, indicating that the StAR promoter was immunoprecipitated with COUP-TFI and thus strongly suggesting an interaction between COUP-TFI and the proximal StAR promoter.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Furthermore, when ChIP was performed on chromatin extracted from AngII-treated cells, a marked and significant decrease in the intensity of the StAR promoter band was observed (61.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	133	Four main conclusions can be drawn from the present work: 1) COUP-TF proteins are abundantly present in bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells in primary culture and are repressed by AngII and forskolin; 2) COUP-TFI and -II repress AngII-induced StAR mRNA and protein expression; 3) COUP-TFI and -II overexpression prevents AngII-induced mineralocorticoid biosynthesis; 4) COUP-TFI interacts directly with the proximal StAR promoter.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	134	First, in agreement with previous immunohistochemical studies performed in mice (18), we detected high basal COUP-TF protein levels in resting bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	135	 In man, recent studies have shown that COUP-TF expression is inversely correlated with steroid production in adrenocortical tumors (20).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	136	 These data suggested that this transcription factor could function as a repressor of steroidogenesis and that the mechanism of action of physiological activators of steroid production, such as AngII or ACTH (mimicked by forskolin), could operate, in part, through a reduction of COUP-TF protein levels.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Indeed, as shown in the present study, both AngII and forskolin strongly diminished COUP-TF mRNA and protein expression, over a range of concentrations similar to those used to induce aldosterone production.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	138	Second, we observed that COUP-TFI and -II repressed StAR mRNA and protein expression.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Because the StAR protein controls the rate-limiting step of steroidogenesis, we hypothesized that COUP-TF might act at this level.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	140	 COUP-TF is known to negatively regulate the transcriptional activity of SF-1 and to repress various actors in the steroidogenic cascade (23, 34), such as the gene encoding cytochrome P450 steroid 17-hydroxylase, by competing with SF-1 for the binding to repeated cAMP-responsive sequences spaced by six nucleotides (repCRS2) (35).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Furthermore, COUP-TF and SF-1 have also been shown to bind to overlapping binding sites involved in the regulation of the oxytocin gene in the bovine ovary (36).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Although multiple SF-1 binding elements required for hormonal induction have been identified in the StAR protein gene 5'-flanking promoter region (10, 37, 38), COUP-TF has not been reported, so far, to bind to the StAR promoter or to affect its activity.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Interestingly, our laboratory has demonstrated recently that the levels of another orphan nuclear receptor, DAX-1, which is known to repress StAR protein expression also by interacting negatively with SF-1 either directly or indirectly (12), are down-regulated by AngII and forskolin in bovine adrenal glomerulosa cells and that this effect is correlated inversely with StAR protein expression and aldosterone biosynthesis (14).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	144	We therefore examined whether COUP-TF could repress StAR expression levels by overexpressing the transcription factor in bovine glomerulosa cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	145	 To overcome the usually low rates of efficiency observed in these cells when utilizing classical transfection reagents, we have used an HIV-derived lentiviral system yielding high levels of gene delivery in primary cells (27, 28).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Indeed, infected bovine glomerulosa cells expressed high amounts of exogenous, murine COUP-TFI and -II mRNA that could be distinguished from endogenous COUP-TF mRNAs by using species-specific primers for the RT-PCR amplification.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Moreover, we show here that overexpression of either isoform of COUP-TF resulted in a complete suppression of AngII-induced StAR mRNA and protein induction, a finding strongly suggesting a direct or indirect repressor role for COUP-TF on StAR promoter activity.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	148	 These results were indeed confirmed by luciferase reporter gene assay of the StAR promoter in cells overexpressing COUP-TF, which showed a dramatic reduction in AngII-induced StAR promoter activity.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	149	 COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII were equally effective in repressing StAR mRNA expression, although only the latter has been shown to be expressed in the cortex of the adrenal gland during organogenesis in mice (18).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	150	 However, both COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII have been shown to be present in normal and tumoral human adrenocortical tissue in immunohistological studies (19, 21), and we observed a similar expression pattern of the mRNA of both isoforms in bovine glomerulosa cells (data not shown).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	151	Third, at the functional level, we observed an inverse relationship between mRNA COUP-TF levels and AngII-induced aldosterone output, a finding that corroborates our hypothesis that the hormone acts by lifting the repression exerted by COUP-TF on StAR gene expression.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Interestingly, overexpression of COUP-TFs did not affect either basal StAR expression or basal aldosterone production.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	153	 This result was actually expected, in view of the robust expression of endogenous COUP-TFs in bovine glomerulosa cells, which presumably already exert a maximal repressor effect on these parameters in the resting state.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Only under conditions of stimulation with AngII, when endogenous COUP-TFs are repressed, is the effect of overexpressing exogenous COUP-TF visible, preventing the normal StAR induction and steroid production elicited by the hormone.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	155	 In addition, COUP-TF is certainly not the sole regulator of StAR expression, and other factors, such as DAX-1 and SF-1 (14), most probably also contribute to basal StAR gene expression.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	156	 This finding is also in agreement with clinical observations showing that COUP-TFI and -II protein levels are markedly reduced in steroid-producing human adrenal tumors, as assessed by Western blot analysis (19), but contrasts with immunohistological observations indicating that COUP-TFII is highly expressed in nuclei of aldosteronoma cells (21).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	157	 One possible explanation for this discrepancy could be found in the different methodologies used in these studies, as immunoblotting yields more quantitative measures than immunocytochemistry.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	158	Fourth, we have shown a direct physical interaction of COUP-TF with the proximal StAR promoter both in vitro and in vivo.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	159	 In EMSAs performed with a probe corresponding to a region of the proximal StAR promoter known to be critical in the control by SF-1 of StAR gene expression, the intensity of two bands was dramatically reduced by preincubation of the nuclear extracts with the anti-COUP-TF antibody.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	160	 This finding indicated that COUP-TF can interact either directly or indirectly with the StAR promoter.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Whether the two shifted bands represent complexes of COUP-TF with other proteins remains to be elucidated.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	162	Finally, ChIP assays allowed us to clearly demonstrate and quantify a direct binding of COUP-TF with the proximal StAR promoter.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The decrease in StAR promoter yield in the ChIP assay observed after AngII treatment matches exactly the repression of COUP-TF that we have observed, thus confirming that AngII lifts a direct repression exerted by COUP-TF on the StAR promoter.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	164	In summary, the data we have presented in this work indicates that the transcription factor COUP-TF, which is essentially known to play a developmental role in the adrenal cortex, is also implicated in modulating the differentiated function of adrenal glomerulosa cells, namely aldosterone biosynthesis.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Under basal conditions, COUP-TF exerts a tonic inhibition on steroidogenesis by repressing StAR protein expression, thus preventing cholesterol substrate supply to the mitochondria.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Challenge of glomerulosa cells with physiological activators of mineralocorticoid production lifts this inhibition by reducing COUP-TF protein levels and COUP-TF binding to the StAR promoter, thus allowing the StAR protein to be expressed in higher amounts, intramitochondrial cholesterol transfer to occur and, eventually, aldosterone synthesis to proceed.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	167	Generation of Lentiviral Vectors and Infection of Bovine Adrenal Glomerulosa Cells Lentiviral vectors were generated as described previously (27, 28).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	168	5-kb fragments were excised out of the original mouse plasmids pCDNA3-COUP-TFI and pCDNA3-COUP-TFII with BamHI and XhoI restriction enzymes.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The digested fragments were separated on agarose and subsequently purified (JetQuick extraction kit, Genomed GmbH, Basel, Switzerland).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	170	 COUP-TF cDNAs were then inserted into the pRRL-sin-ppt-hPGK vector digested with BamHI and SalI.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	171	Lentiviral vectors were obtained by transient transfection of 293T human embryonic kidney cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	172	 A total of 2 x 106 293T cells were seeded in 10-cm petri dishes 24 h before transfection, in DMEM containing 10% fetal calf serum and glutamine, in the presence of chloroquine (final concentration, 25  microM) and in a 5% CO2 atmosphere.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Plasmid DNA (20  microg) was used for the transfection of one 10-cm dish using the calcium-phosphate precipitation method: 2.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	174	5  microg envelope-coding plasmid pMDG, 7.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	175	5  microg packaging plasmid pCMVR8.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	176	91 (which expresses Gag, Pol, Tat, and Rev), and 10  microg of either COUP-TFI- or COUP-TFII-expressing pRRL-sin-ppt-hPGK plasmid.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The cells were washed with PBS after 14 to 16 h and were incubated in serum-free DMEM in a 10% CO2 atmosphere.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The conditioned medium was collected after another 24 h and filtered through 0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	179	45- microm pore polyvinylidene difluoride filters.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The vectors were concentrated 100-fold by one round of centrifugation at 50 000 x g for 90 min and resuspended for 20 min at room temperature in PBS.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Titers of HIV vectors were determined by p24 antigen ELISA.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Titers were found to range from 5 x 106 to 107 infectious units/ml.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Stock of vectors was stored at  to 80 C until used for infection of the bovine glomerulosa cells.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	184	 All infections were performed in 12-well plates, with 200,000 glomerulosa cells per well and 500 ng of p24 were used for each COUP-TF.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	185	Determination of Aldosterone Production Aldosterone content in incubation media was measured by direct RIA using a commercially available kit (Diagnostic Systems Laboratories, Webster, TX).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Aldosterone production was normalized and expressed per microgram cellular protein.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	187	Western Blot Analysis For the determination of protein expression levels, bovine glomerulosa cells were washed twice in ice-cold PBS, and nuclear extracts were prepared according to the procedure of Schreiber et al.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Mitochondrial extracts were prepared as described elsewhere (30).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Proteins were quantified using a protein microassay (Bio-Rad, Munich, Germany).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Equal amounts of protein (15  microg) were resolved by 10% SDS-PAGE and transferred onto polyvinylidene difluoride membranes.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Western blot analysis was carried out with rabbit antisera directed either against COUP-TF (kindly provided by Professor Ming-Jer Tsai, Houston, TX) or against StAR (kindly provided by Professor Douglas Stocco, Lubbock, TX).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Immunoreactive proteins were visualized by the enhanced chemiluminescence method (Amersham Biosciences, Otelfingen, Switzerland).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	193	Northern Blot Analysis Glomerulosa cell total RNA was extracted using the RNAgents kit (Promega Corp.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	194	, Zurich, Switzerland) according to the instructions of the manufacturer.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	195	 For Northern blot analysis, 30  microg RNA were size fractionated on a 1% formaldehyde agarose gel, vacuum transferred onto Nytran membranes (Schleicher  and  Schuell, Dassel, Germany), and fixed by UV cross-linking.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	196	 The integrity of the 18 S and 28 S RNA was checked by ethidium bromide staining of the gel.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Hybridization was performed using the previously cloned 1.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The cDNA was labeled with [32P]dCTP using the Rediprime II random primer labeling kit from Amersham Biosciences.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Northern blots were prehybridized in Rapid Hybridization Buffer (Amersham Biosciences) at 65 C for 30 min.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The 32P-labeled probe (specific activity: 2 x 106 cpm/ng DNA) was then added, and the incubation was continued for 2.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Blots were washed for 5 min and 15 min successively at room temperature in 2x saline sodium citrate (SSC)-0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	202	1% SDS, and then for 15 min in 1x SSC-0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The final wash was performed at 65 C for 15 min in 1x SSC-0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	204	 RNA-cDNA hybrids were visualized on Hyperfilms (Amersham Biosciences) after a 12- to 14-h exposure period.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Blots were stripped and reprobed with mouse glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) cDNA (Ambion, Lugano, Switzerland) to assess RNA loading.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	206	Semiquantitative RT-PCR RT-PCR was used to evaluate StAR and COUP-TF mRNA abundance in response to various treatments.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Total RNA (100 ng) was amplified by one-step RT-PCR Access system (Promega Corp.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	208	, Madison, WI) according to the instructions of the manufacturer.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The primers were: bovine StAR 5'-TGA AGA GCT TGT GGA GCG CA-3'(forward) and 5'-TGC GAG AGG ACC TGG TTG AT-3'(reverse), corresponding to positions +538 to 557 and +902 to 921, respectively (GenBank accession no.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Y17259); mouse COUP-TFI 5'-ATG CAC TCA CAA ACG GGG AT-3' (forward) and 5'-ACT GTG CGA AGA GAG GGC AAT-3' (reverse), corresponding to positions +514 to 533 and +1121 to 1141, respectively (GenBank accession no.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	211	 U07625); mouse COUP-TFII 5'-AAG CTG TAC AGA GAG GCA GGA-3' (forward) and 5'-AGA GCT TTC CGA ACC GTG TT-3' (reverse), corresponding to positions +475 to 495 and +1106 to 1125, respectively (GenBank accession no.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	212	 X76653); GAPDH 5'-ATG GTG AAG GTC GGA GTG-3' (forward) and 5'-TGC AGA GAT GAT GAC CCT C-3' (reverse), corresponding to positions +82 to 99 and +426 to 444 (GenBank accession no.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Primers yielded products of the expected size corresponding to 362 bp for GAPDH, 383 bp for StAR, 627 bp for COUP-TFI, and 650 bp for COUP-TFII.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	214	 PCR products (10  microl) were analyzed on 1.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	215	2% agarose gel and quantified by densitometry using a Computing Densitometer (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	216	 All mRNA levels were normalized to GAPDH mRNA.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	217	Dual Luciferase Reporter Assay System The StAR-luc reporter construct was kindly provided by Dr.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	218	3-kb StAR promoter region was cloned into the plasmid vector pGL2 (Promega Corp.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	219	), which contains firefly luciferase as a reporter gene.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Other plasmids used in these experiments included the pGL2 basic vector as a negative control, which contains no promoter sequence; pGL2 control used as a positive control, which places the luciferase gene under the control of the simian virus 40 (SV40) promoter; pRL-SV40 vector, which places the Renilla luciferase under the control of the SV40 promoter was used as an internal control; and pCR3.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	221	1 vector in which murine COUP-TFI or COUP-TFII cDNA were subcloned under the control of the cytomegalovirus promoter (kindly provided by Professor Ming-Jer Tsai, Houston, TX).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Bovine glomerulosa cells were cotransfected with the various vectors according to the manufacturer s protocol (Effectene Transfection Reagent kit, QIAGEN GmbH, Hilden, Germany).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Cells were harvested 48 h after transfection, and extracts were made in Passive lysis buffer (Promega Corp.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Luciferase and Renilla activities were quantified using a Luminoskan Ascent (Labsystems, Catalys AG, Wallisellen, Switzerland).
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The luciferase assay results were normalized to Renilla activity to compensate for variations in transfection efficiency.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Each treatment group contained at least triplicate cultures.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	227	EMSA Double-stranded DNA (5'-gatCACAGCCTTCAGCTGGAGGTATTT annealed with 5'-gatcAAATACCTCCAGCTGAAGGCTGTG) corresponding to nucleotides  to 49 to  to 26 of the bovine StAR promoter according to the sequence published by Rust et al.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	228	 (39) was [-32P]dATP labeled by Klenow (Promega Corp.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Nuclear protein extracts (15  microg) were incubated for 20 min at room temperature with 30, 000 cpm/min of labeled probe and 2  microg of poly[d(IC)] in EMSA binding buffer.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The reaction mixture was loaded onto on a nondenaturing 5% polyacrylamide gel for 2 h at 200 V in a cold room.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Gels were dried and exposed to autoradiography films (Kodak Biomax MR, Sigma-Aldrich GmbH, Steinheim, Germany) for 72 h.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	232	 In supershift experiments, 1  microg purified rabbit polyclonal anti-COUP-TFI (kindly provided by Dr.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Dufau, Bethesda, MD) or anti-SF-1 (kindly provided by Professor K.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Morohashi, Okasaki, Japan) antibody was added to the mixture 30 min before the labeled probe.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	235	ChIP Assay Chromatin cross-linking was performed by adding 1% formaldehyde to bovine glomerulosa cells at room temperature for 8 min.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The reaction was stopped by adding glycine to a final concentration of 0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Cells were then washed twice with ice-cold PBS, collected in 5 ml PBS, and harvested by brief centrifugation.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Cells were resuspended in ice-cold cell lysis buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	239	5% Nonidet P-40; protease inhibitors), incubated on ice for 5 min, and briefly centrifuged.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Cells were then resuspended in nuclear lysis buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	241	0; 1 mM EDTA; 1% Triton X-100; 0.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	242	5 M NaCl; protease inhibitors), incubated at room temperature for 5 min while vortexing vigorously several times, and washed in PBS.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Sonication of the cells was performed 30 times for 30 sec in TEN buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	244	0; 1 mM EDTA; 100 mM NaCl) with a Branson 250 sonifier, followed by centrifugation for 15 min at 14,000 rpm in an Eppendorf table centrifuge.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Supernatant was collected and diluted 5-fold in dilution/incubation buffer (20 mM HEPES, pH 8.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	246	1% NaDOC; 1% Triton X-100; 100  microg/ml salmon sperm DNA; 1 mg/ml BSA; protease inhibitors) followed by immunoclearing with 20  microl protein A Sepharose CL-4B (Pharmacia Biotech AB, Uppsala, Sweden) for 30 min at room temperature, to which 5  microl of specific anti-COUP-TFI antibody were added for overnight incubation at 4 C.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The mixture was then cleared from precipitated material by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 10 min.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Supernatant was incubated with 12  microl Protein A Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences) for 1 h at room temperature.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Precipitate was recovered by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 1 min and washed seven times in RIPA buffer (50 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	250	7% NaDOC; 1% Nonidet P-40) and once in TE buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl; pH 8.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	251	0; 1 mM EDTA) and extracted twice with 100  microl elution buffer (100 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Eluates were pooled, treated with proteinase K (100  microg/ml) for 2 h at 42 C, heated at 65 C overnight to reverse the formaldehyde cross-linking, and treated by phenol extraction and ethanol precipitation.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The DNA pellet was dissolved in 15  microl of TE buffer.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	254	 DNA (5  microl) was used for real-time PCR.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The primers were located on the proximal part of the bovine StAR promoter: forward, 5'-AGA CTC CTG GTG AGG CAA TC-3'; and reverse, 5'-CTG CGG CCA GAT GAT GTG TT-3', according to the GenBank sequence (accession no.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Y17260), and yielding an amplification product of 137 bp.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	257	Analysis of Data Results are expressed as means  plus or minus  SEM.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The mean values were compared by ANOVA using Fisher s test.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	259	05 was considered as statistically significant.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Quantification of immunoblots and autoradiograms was performed using a Molecular Dynamics Computing Densitometer.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	261	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Dr.
