0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	265	) and by a grant from the Fondation Gustave Prevot (to A.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	266	First Published Online September 16, 2004.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	267	Abbreviations: AngII, Angiotensin II; ChIP, chromatin immunoprecipitation; COUP-TF, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor; DAX-1, dosage-sensitive sex reversal, adrenal hypoplasia congenita critical region on the X chromosome, gene 1; GAPDH, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase; GFP, green fluorescent protein; hPGK, human phospholgycerate kinase; SDS, sodium dodecyl sulfate; SF-1, steroidogenic factor 1; SSC, saline sodium citrate; StAR, steroidogenic acute regulatory; SV40, simian virus 40.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	268	Received for publication February 10, 2004.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Accepted for publication September 10, 2004.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	0	The embryonic expression of the tissue-specific transcription factor HNF1[alpha] in Xenopus: rapid activation by HNF4 and delayed induction by mesoderm inducers.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	1	Aristotelis Nastos, Elke Pogge von Strandmann, Heike Weber+ and Gerhart U.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	2	Universitatsklinikum Essen, Institut fur Zellbiologie (Tumorforschung), Hufelandstra&szlig;e 55, D-45122 Essen, Germany.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received September 4, 1998; Revised and Accepted October 27, 1998.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	4	The tissue-specific transcription factor HNF1[alpha] is expressed in kidney, liver, intestine and stomach of Xenopus.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We show that the HNF1[alpha] gene is transcriptionally activated at the onset of zygotic gene transcription and that this transcription is maintained throughout development.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Ectodermal explants of blastulae (animal caps) express HNF1[alpha] mRNA upon stimulation with the mesoderm inducers activin A and BMP4 as well as on overexpression of Smad2 and Smad1, the corresponding members of the intracellular TGF-[beta] signal transducers, respectively.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Beside these factors that mediate their response through serine/threonine kinase receptors, bFGF, which acts via tyrosine kinase receptors, leads to HNF1[alpha] expression, too.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	8	 These embryonic inducers result in a delayed appearance of HNF1[alpha] mRNA, excluding a direct activation of HNF1[alpha].
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In contrast, the maternally expressed nuclear receptors HNF4[alpha] and HNF4[beta] activate the initial HNF1[alpha] transcription, since overexpression of HNF4 leads to a rapid expression of HNF1[alpha] mRNA in animal caps.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Similarly, in entire neurulae HNF4 overexpression results in increased HNF1[alpha] transcription.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Therefore, we assume that the initial activation is dependent on maternal HNF4[alpha] and HNF4[beta] transcription factors whereas HNF1[alpha] induction by growth factors reflects the property of these factors to induce the differentiation of mesodermal and entodermal cell types expressing HNF1[alpha].
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	12	The differentiation of tissue-specific cell types during development of a multicellular organism is initiated in the fertilized egg by maternal components laid down during oogenesis.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Some of the most important maternal determinants regulating these early events include cell surface signalling molecules and their receptors as well as transcription factors.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The interplay of growth factors and transcription factors, which is best analyzed in Drosophila (1), is assumed to define the spatial activation of specific genes in development.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	15	In Xenopus, it is well established that maternal inductive signals emanating from the vegetal region of the cleaving embryo lead to a distinct pattern of gene expression in the equatorial region and thereby determine the prospective mesodermal tissues of the embryo (2).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	16	 These inductive factors are fibroblast growth factors (FGF) and members of the transforming growth factor [beta] (TGF-[beta]) family, with bFGF and activin A or Vg1 as the most significant members (2-6).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Whereas the FGF signal is received by membrane-bound tyrosine kinase receptors, TGF-[beta]s act exclusively through serine/threonine kinases on the cell surface (7).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Intracellular TGF-[beta] signalling involves a class of proteins referred to as Smad proteins (7-10).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In Xenopus embryos, Smad1 and Smad2 overexpression in the animal cap mimics the effect of the TGF-[beta] family members BMP4 (bone morphogenetic protein) and activin A, respectively (11,12).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In general, the Smad proteins seem to be phosphorylated at C-terminal serine residues by the activated type I receptor (13,14), form heteromeric complexes with Smad4 (15) and migrate into the nucleus, where they regulate the expression of TGF-[beta]-responsive genes by direct interaction with specific transcription factors (16).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Based on all these data Smad proteins are considered as essential intracellular components in TGF-[beta] signalling.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	22	In an approach to link maternal components with the transcriptional activation of a tissue-specific transcription factor we have investigated the expression of HNF1[alpha] in Xenopus (17-19).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	23	 This tissue-specific transcription factor found in all vertebrates is expressed in endodermal tissues such as liver, gut and stomach but also in the kidney, a mesodermal derivative (17,20).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	24	 As binding sites for HNF1[alpha] are present in several genes specifically expressed in these tissues, it is assumed that HNF1[alpha] participates in the establishment of the differentiated state.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Previously, we showed by RNase protection analysis that the first HNF1[alpha] transcripts appear at the gastrula stage and therefore HNF1[alpha] gene transcription is zygotically activated (17).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	26	 To reveal the regulatory elements involved in HNF1[alpha] gene activation we injected promoter constructs into fertilized eggs.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	27	 We identified a minimal promoter fragment of the Xenopus gene sufficient for proper activation of the reporter gene in swimming larvae (18,19).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The promoter elements mediating gene activation appear to be conserved in vertebrate evolution as the injected rat HNF1[alpha] promoter is also regulated in Xenopus.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	29	 By mutational analysis of the minimal regulatory unit of the Xenopus HNF1[alpha] promoter, an OZ element, two HNF1 binding sites and one binding site for HNF4 were characterized as regulatory elements (18,19).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The HNF4 binding site seems to play a predominant role, as it is not only sufficient but also essential for activation of the reporter gene (18).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	31	 HNF4 is encoded in a small gene family, with HNF4[alpha] and HNF4[beta] identified in Xenopus (21,22).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Both HNF4 proteins are expressed maternally and are present in a gradient from the animal to the vegetal pole (22).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Overexpression of rat HNF4[alpha] in Xenopus leads to the ectopic appearance of HNF1[alpha] protein in the head and tail of swimming larvae (18).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	34	 These data support the assumption that HNF4 resides on the top of a transcriptional cascade leading to activation of the HNF1[alpha] gene during embryogenesis.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Since ectopic HNF1[alpha] expression was analyzed only in swimming larvae, when organogenesis is already established, it is not known whether HNF4 is able to activate initial HNF1[alpha] transcription in embryogenesis.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	36	We have recently shown that activin A induces HNF1[alpha] protein expression in animal caps that differentiate into mesodermal and endodermal cell types (23).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	37	 By injecting various HNF1[alpha] promoter constructs, we could define the HNF4 binding site as an apparent activin A-responsive element in the HNF1[alpha] promoter (23).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	38	 However, since HNF1[alpha] induction in animal caps was measured at the protein level after 3 days of culture (23), it is an open question whether activin A or its related factor Vg1, both reported to be maternal components (24-26), trigger the initial HNF1[alpha] gene activation in the developing embryo.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	39	In this report we investigate the effects of embryonic mesoderm inducers known to be present as maternal components in the egg on expression of the HNF1[alpha] gene and compare their inducing potential with the transcription factors of the HNF4 family.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	40	MATERIALS AND METHODS Microinjections of synthetic capped mRNAs into Xenopus eggs.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	41	The cDNAs for Xenopus Smad1 and human Smad2, kindly provided by Gerald Thomsen and Jeff Wrana, were cloned into the pCS2+ expression vector (27) with the N-terminus fused to a Myc or a Flag epitope, respectively.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	42	 For in vitro mRNA synthesis both clones were linearized with NotI and transcribed with SP6 polymerase.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The BMP4 cDNA was a gift from Walter Knochel (28) and was cloned into the pSP64T vector.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	44	 To synthesize the BMP4 mRNA the vector was cut with BamHI and transcription was driven by SP6 polymerase (23).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The green fluorescent protein (GFP)2 cDNA cloned into the pCS2 vector was kindly provided by Enrique Amaya and synthetic mRNA transcription was driven by SP6 polymerase after linearization with PvuII.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The rat HNF4[alpha] (19) and Xenopus HNF4[beta] (22) cDNAs were cloned into the Rc/CMV vector (Invitrogen).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	47	 After linearization with NaeI we used T7 polymerase for the in vitro transcription.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Synthetic capped mRNAs were microinjected (1 ng of Smad1, Smad2, BMP4, HNF4[alpha] or HNF4[beta] and 200 pg of GFP2) into the animal pole of fertilized Xenopus eggs at the one cell stage and the embryos were allowed to develop until the late blastula or early neurula stages.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	49	Animal pole explants of non-injected and mRNA-injected stage 9 embryos were prepared as described by Weber et al.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	50	 (23) and incubated at 23 degrees C for 3, 6, 24, 48 or 72 h.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	51	 These incubation periods correspond to the developmental stages 11, 13, 27, 33 and 42, respectively.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The human recombinant activin A was kindly provided by Yuzuru Eto (Central Research Laboratory, Ajinomoto Co.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	53	, Kawasaki, Japan) and used at a concentration of 10 ng/ml.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Recombinant human bFGF was obtained from Gibco BRL and used at the given concentrations.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	55	Entire and animal cap dissected embryos were homogenized as described (18).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Aliquots of 10  microg of the protein extract were separated on a 12.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	57	5% SDS gel and transferred to nitrocellulose filters (30).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Flag tagged Smad2 was detected using the monoclonal antibody M2 (Kodak) directed against the N-terminal Flag tag according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	59	Reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	60	Total RNA was prepared using the RNA clean system (AGS, Heidelberg, Germany) following the instructions of the manufacturer.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	61	 RT-PCR of whole embryos and animal caps was performed as previously described (22).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	62	 For the detection of specific RNAs the following primers, annealing temperatures and cycle numbers were used.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	63	 HNF1[alpha]: upstream 5[prime]-CCTGAAGAGGCTGCTCATCAG-3[prime], downstream 5[prime]-GTCCTGCATGTGTGAACTCTG-3[prime], 54 degrees C, 35 cycles.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Brachyury: upstream 5[prime]-GGATCGTTATCACCTCTG-3[prime], downstream 5[prime]-GTGTAGTCTGTAGCAGCA-3[prime], 54 degrees C, 30 cycles.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Goosecoid: upstream 5[prime]-ACAACTGGAAGCACTGGA-3[prime], downstream 5[prime]-TCTTATTCCAGAGGAACC-3[prime], 54 degrees C, 30 cycles.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Globin: upstream 5[prime]-GCCTACAACCTGAGAGTGG-3[prime], downstream 5[prime]-CAGGCTGGTGAGCTGCCC-3[prime], 56 degrees C, 30 cycles.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Muscle actin: upstream 5[prime]-GCTGACAGAATGCAGAAG-3[prime], downstream 5[prime]-TTGCTTGGAGGAGTGTGT-3[prime], 48 degrees C, 30 cycles.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Ornithine decarboxylase (ODC): upstream 5[prime]-AATGGATTTCAGAGACCA-3[prime], downstream 5[prime]-CCAAGGCTAAAGTTGCAG-3[prime], 44 degrees C, 30 cycles.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	69	RESULTS HNF1[alpha] expression starts with the onset of zygotic gene transcription at the mid blastula transition (MBT).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	70	To identify the factors involved in embryonic activation of the HNF1[alpha] gene in the developing Xenopus embryo it was a prerequisite to determine the temporal expression pattern of HNF1[alpha] mRNA by a more sensitive technique than previously used (17).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	71	 1) we revealed that HNF1[alpha] transcripts are absent in the early cleaving embryo between the fertilized egg (stage 1) and the mid blastula (stage 8) stages, whereas the first transcripts are detectable at the late blastula (stage 9) stage corresponding to the initiation of zygotic gene transcription in Xenopus (31).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The amount of transcript remains constant up to the late gastrula (stage 12) stage and increases by ~100-fold during further development up to the swimming larva (stage 42) stage.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The amount of ODC mRNA, known to remain constant in Xenopus development (32), was similar in all RNA samples.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Temporal expression pattern of the HNF1[alpha] gene in Xenopus embryogenesis.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	75	 At the indicated developmental stages as defined (46) total RNA from five embryos was isolated and analyzed by RT-PCR for the presence of HNF1[alpha] and ODC transcripts.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The time point of the mid blastula transition (MBT) when zygotic gene transcription starts is indicated and hours after fertilization are given.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Control RT-PCR reactions containing embryonic RNA of stage 42 (+cont.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	78	), no RNA (H2O) or HeLa cell RNA are shown on the left.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	79	Therefore, HNF1[alpha] is zygotically expressed in Xenopus and transcription of this gene is maintained during all developmental stages.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Obviously, initial HNF1[alpha] transcription at the onset of zygotic gene transcription is initiated by regulatory components of maternal origin.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	81	The activin A signalling pathway leads to HNF1[alpha] induction.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	82	To analyze whether the maternal inducer activin A might initiate HNF1[alpha] expression we investigated at what time point activin A treatment leads to HNF1[alpha] gene transcription in explants of the animal pole of the balstula (animal caps).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Using RT-PCR we detected HNF1[alpha] mRNA in animal pole explants at 72 h after treatment with activin A (data not shown).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	84	 This late appearance of HNF1[alpha] mRNA is very similar to the induction we have seen previously when analyzing the effect at the protein level (23).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	85	 As treatment of animal pole explants with activin A in conjunction with retinoic acid enhances activin A-dependent HNF1[alpha] protein induction (23), we determined the time point of HNF1[alpha] gene activation by activin A in the presence of retinoic acid.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	86	 As indicated in Figure 2 the first HNF1[alpha] transcripts are detectable after 24 h of incubation (lane 4).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Since under these conditions both goosecoid and brachyury transcripts are visible already after 3 h of treatment (lane 2), HNF1[alpha] expression cannot be an immediate response to activin A signalling.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	88	 As Smad2 is known to be an intracellular mediator of activin A signalling (7,33), we analyzed whether the introduction of this downstream effector might also activate HNF1[alpha] gene transcription.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Using an mRNA encoding a Flag tagged Smad2 protein we could verify in a western blot using a Flag tag-specific monoclonal antibody that Smad2 protein was present in the injected embryos at the time of animal cap explantation (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	90	 To analyze expression of HNF1[alpha] mRNA in these Smad2-injected animal caps, total RNA from the explants was isolated at different time points of culturing.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Based on RT-PCR analysis HNF1[alpha] transcripts were absent in animal caps derived from Smad2 mRNA-injected embryos after 0, 3 and 6 h of incubation (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The first few HNF1[alpha] transcripts appeared after 24 h (lane 6).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Their amount rose to a maximum (lane 7, 48 h) and remained at this level after 72 h of culture (lane 8).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The same level of HNF1[alpha] induction was observed in uninjected animal caps treated with activin A for 72 h (lane 2).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Kinetics of HNF1[alpha] gene activation in animal caps treated with activin A in combination with 10-5 M retinoic acid.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	96	 For each time point total RNA from 10 animal caps was isolated and analyzed by RT-PCR for the presence of HNF1[alpha], goosecoid (gsc), brachyury (Xbra) and ODC transcripts.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Control animal caps were cultured in buffer for 24 h.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	98	 As a control RT-PCR was also done on RNA isolated from whole embryos or on an aliquot lacking RNA (H2O).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The low level of HNF1[alpha] transcript present in the 24 h control (lane 1) is most likely due to the presence of endodermal cells contaminating this sample as the mesodermal markers goosecoid and brachyury are weakly induced.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Kinetics of HNF1[alpha] gene induction by overexpression of Smad2.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Animal caps dissected from Smad2 mRNA-injected embryos were incubated for 0, 3, 6, 24, 48 and 72 h in buffer (lanes 3-8).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	102	 For comparison animal caps derived from uninjected embryos were either cultured in buffer alone (lane 1) or in the presence of 10 ng/ml activin A (lane 2).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The leftover dissected blastulae of each group were used for protein extract preparation and analyzed by western blot analysis for expression of the Flag tagged Smad2 protein.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	104	 At the indicated time points the expression of HNF1[alpha], brachyury (Xbra), goosecoid (gsc), globin, muscle actin and ODC were measured by RT-PCR.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	105	In contrast, brachyury and goosecoid, both known to be activated as an early response to activin A/Smad2 signalling (34), were expressed at the time point of dissection (lane 3), indicating a successful initial mesodermal induction caused by the translated Flag tagged Smad2 mRNA.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	106	 As expected, the expression of both marker genes declined with longer culture periods and was replaced after 24 h by expression of muscle actin (lane 6), indicating late dorsal mesoderm, and after 48 h by the late ventral mesodermal marker globin (lane 7), as reported by Graff et al.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	107	 These data show that the activated activin A/Smad2 pathway leads to a late induction of HNF1[alpha] gene expression.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	108	The BMP4/Smad1 pathway leads to HNF1[alpha] mRNA expression.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	109	Signalling by BMPs that are also members of the TGF-[beta] family is another important maternal pathway in the early Xenopus embryo leading to activation of genes involved in mesoderm induction (reviewed in 35,36).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	110	 To investigate its potential role in HNF1[alpha] induction, we injected Xenopus eggs with RNA encoding BMP4 that leads to the translation of functional BMP4 protein in the early cleavage stages (37).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	111	 To monitor successful expression of the introduced RNA we co-injected RNA encoding GFP.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	112	 At the blastula stage animal caps were explanted exclusively from GFP-positive embryos and cultured for different time periods prior to RNA extraction.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Figure 4 demonstrates that HNF1[alpha] transcripts were detectable after 48 h of culture (lane 8), whereas the brachyury gene (Xbra), an immediate response gene of BMP4 signalling (38), was transcribed already at the time of animal cap explantation (lane 4).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The late appearance of HNF1[alpha] transcripts was also confirmed in an experiment where we injected RNA encoding Smad1 (data not shown), the mediator specific for BMP4 signalling (34).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Kinetics of HNF1[alpha] gene induction by BMP4.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Animal caps dissected from GFP2 and BMP4 mRNA-injected embryos were incubated for 0, 3, 6, 24, 48 and 72 h in buffer.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	117	 For comparison animal caps derived from uninjected embryos were either cultured in buffer alone (lane 1) or in the presence of 10 ng/ml activin A (lane 3).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	118	 In addition animal caps from exclusively GFP2-injected embryos were also cultured for 72 h in buffer (lane 2).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	119	 At the indicated time points the expression of HNF1[alpha], brachyury (Xbra), globin and ODC was measured by RT-PCR.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	120	bFGF induces the appearance of HNF1[alpha] transcripts.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	121	The mesoderm inducer bFGF is another maternal component of the FGF family (39) and exerts its effect by binding to corresponding tyrosine kinase receptors (40).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	122	 To explore whether this pathway is able to activate HNF1[alpha] gene expression, we incubated animal caps in increasing concentrations of bFGF and analyzed the level of HNF1[alpha] mRNA.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	123	 After 72 h of incubation abundant HNF1[alpha] transcripts were found in caps treated with between 3 and 150 ng/ml bFGF (data not shown).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Using the highest concentration of bFGF we determined the kinetics of HNF1[alpha] mRNA appearance in explanted animal caps.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Figure 5 reveals that HNF1[alpha] mRNA was present after 48 (lane 5) and 72 h (lane 6) of bFGF treatment.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	126	 A similar late appearance was also observed for globin transcripts, whereas brachyury transcripts (Xbra) were already seen 3 h after bFGF addition (lane 2), as previously described (41).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	127	 This delayed induction of HNF1[alpha] excludes the possibility that bFGF signalling leads to direct activation of the HNF1[alpha] gene.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Kinetics of HNF1[alpha] gene induction by bFGF.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Animal caps were incubated in the presence of bFGF for the time period indicated.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Control caps were also incubated for 72 h in buffer.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Transcripts of HNF1[alpha], brachyury (Xbra), globin and ODC were measured by RT-PCR.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	132	 HNF4 overexpression in animal caps leads to rapid activation of HNF1[alpha] transcription.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	133	Since it is known that HNF4 activates HNF1[alpha] protein expression in swimming larvae and HNF4 protein is expressed maternally (18,22), we explored whether HNF4 is able to activate the initial HNF1[alpha] transcription.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Therefore, we microinjected synthetic mRNA encoding rat HNF4[alpha] into fertilized Xenopus eggs.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Animal caps of injected blastulae were explanted and total RNA was either isolated immediately or after culturing in buffer for 3-72 h.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	136	 By RT-PCR we detected HNF1[alpha] transcripts at the time of explantion of the animal caps in the HNF4[alpha]-injected embryos (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	137	 6, compare lane 3 with lane 1).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	138	 HNF1[alpha] mRNA accumulated in injected animal pole explants between 3 and 72 h of culture in the absence of any external inducer (lanes 4-6).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Neither goosecoid nor brachyury, both marker genes for early mesoderm, were activated by HNF4[alpha] overexpression (data not shown).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Analyzing older caps we found no transcripts of the dorsal or ventral mesodermal markers muscle actin or globin, respectively (data not shown).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Kinetics of HNF1[alpha] gene activation in animal caps by overexpression of rat HNF4[alpha].
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Fertilized eggs were injected with rat HNF4[alpha] mRNA and animal caps dissected from a stage 9 blastula.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	143	 After culturing for the given time period RNA was isolated from the animal caps and analyzed by RT-PCR for expression of HNF1[alpha] and ODC.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	144	 As controls animal caps of non-injected embryos were cultured for 72 h either in buffer (lane 1) or in the presence of 10 ng/ml activin A (lane 2) and analyzed as above.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	145	Our data clearly establish that the tissue-specific transcription factor HNF4 activates HNF1[alpha] gene transcription without delay in animal caps and that this event is independent of mesoderm induction, since none of the mesodermal markers analyzed was affected.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	146	HNF4 but not Smad2 increases HNF1[alpha] expression in the entire embryo.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	147	To explore whether HNF4 acts as an early activator of HNF1[alpha] gene transcription also in the entire embryo, we overexpressed HNF4 by microinjection of synthetic mRNA encoding Xenopus HNF4[beta] into fertilized eggs.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	148	 As shown in Figure 7A, there is a much higher level of HNF1[alpha] transcripts in HNF4[beta]-injected embryos (lanes 3 and 4) than in uninjected (lane 1) or GFP2 mRNA-injected control larvae (lane 2).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	149	 We conclude that overexpression of the Xenopus HNF4[beta] protein leads to increased expression of the endogenous HNF1[alpha] gene.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	150	 A similar induction was observed by injecting rat HNF4[alpha] mRNA (data not shown).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Clearly, these data establish that HNF4[alpha] as well as HNF4[beta] can dramatically up-regulate early expression of the endogenous HNF1[alpha] gene.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Overexpression of HNF4 and Smad2 in early neurula embryos.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	153	 (A) Fertilized eggs were either injected with GFP2 mRNA or co-injected with GFP2 and Xenopus HNF4[beta] mRNA.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	154	 At neurula stage 14 total RNA from uninjected (lane 1), GFP2- (lane 2) or GFP2/Xenopus HNF4[beta]-injected (lane 3-4) embryos was isolated and analyzed for the presence of HNF1[alpha] and ODC transcripts.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	155	 (B) Fertilized eggs were injected with mRNA encoding Flag tagged Smad2 and cultured up to early neurula stage 14.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Protein extracts and total RNA from uninjected (lane 1) and mRNA-injected (lanes 2 and 3) embryos were prepared.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Expression of the Flag-Smad2 protein was analyzed in a western blot.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	158	 In (A) and (B) the abundance of HNF1[alpha] mRNA was measured by RT-PCR under less sensitive conditions than shown in Figure 1 to avoid overexposure of the strong HNF1[alpha] signals in lanes 3 and 4 of (A).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	159	To investigate whether Smad2 overexpression is able to activate early HNF1[alpha] transcription in the whole embryo as shown for HNF4 overexpression, we injected Flag tagged Smad2 mRNA into fertilized eggs and prepared extracts at the neurula stage from injected and uninjected stage 14 embryos.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	160	 By western blot analysis using a monoclonal antibody directed against the Flag epitope we can detect overexpressed Flag tagged Smad2 protein in two independent batches of mRNA-injected embryos (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	161	 RT-PCR of non-injected control and Smad2-injected early neurula embryos could detect no significant difference in HNF1[alpha] transcription (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	162	 This establishes that Smad2, unlike HNF4, is not able to increase early HNF1[alpha] gene transcription in the entire embryo and this finding correlates with the late induction found in animal caps (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	163	DISCUSSION HNF1[alpha] expression during embryogenesis.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	164	Our data show that HNF1[alpha] transcripts appear at stage 9 of Xenopus development, immediately after the onset of zygotic gene transcription at the MBT (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	165	 This finding extends our previous RNase protection analysis showing transcripts of the HNF1[alpha] gene only at stage 11 (17) and reflects the higher sensitivity of the RT-PCR method.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Even using this most sensitive detection system we failed to detect any maternal HNF1[alpha] mRNA.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	167	 This establishes that HNF1[alpha] expression depends entirely on zygotic transcription and thus on activation by maternal components.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	168	Transcription of HNF1[alpha] is initiated prior to organogenesis but as the low amounts of transcripts do not yield significant protein levels (17), we doubt that HNF1[alpha] has a regulatory role in these early stages.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	169	 This is reminiscent of the early expression pattern of Xenopus MyoD, where the initial weak and unrestricted expression in the mid blastula stage is without significance for muscle differentiation (42).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	170	HNF1[alpha] is a late response gene to the mesoderm inducers.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	171	The present data show that HNF1[alpha] induction by activin A, BMP4 or bFGF is a late response and thus differs from the early responses seen for the goosecoid and brachyury genes under the same conditions.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The much delayed response of HNF1[alpha] expression upon addition of the mesoderm inducers implies that the appearance of HNF1[alpha] mRNA reflects the differentiation of mesodermal and endodermal cells that express HNF1[alpha].
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	173	 This interpretation is also valid for preloading of the animal caps with Smad2 or Smad1, essential intermediate components of TGF-[beta] signalling, that fails to produce an early response of the HNF1[alpha] gene, too (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	174	Since we have shown previously that in animal caps the activin A signal is received by the HNF4 binding site of injected HNF1[alpha] promoter constructs (23), we assume that HNF4 is the major factor acting in the mesodermal and endodermal cells differentiated upon activin A treatment.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Further evidence that activin A signalling and HNF4-induced activation of the HNF1[alpha] gene are separate events in the early embryo is provided by our observation that in gel retardation experiments using protein extracts from Xenopus gastrulae with combined overexpression of Smad2 and HNF4 proteins, no Smad2/HNF4 interaction could be identified (data not shown).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	176	 In contrast, such complexes have been found between the transcription factor FAST1 and the TGF-[beta] signalling molecule Smad2 that were bound to the activin response element of the Mix.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Consistent with this direct interaction on the induced promoter it has also been established that activin A stimulation of the Mix.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	178	2 promoter is an early response (43).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	179	HNF4 initiates HNF1[alpha] gene transcription.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	180	The main focus of our work was to analyze the mechanisms involved in the initial embryonic activation of the HNF1[alpha] gene.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	181	 We revealed that HNF4 is able to initiate HNF1[alpha] expression at the onset of zygotic gene transcription in blastula embryos whereas the mesoderm inducers activin A, BMP4 and bFGF fail to activate HNF1[alpha] gene expression in these early embryonic stages.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	182	Clearly, the HNF4[alpha] and HNF4[beta] transcription factors are good candidates for initial activators, since they are present as maternal components (18,22) and the HNF1[alpha] promoter contains a functional HNF4 binding site (18,19).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	183	 This potential link can be verified by overexpression of rat HNF4[alpha] or endogenously expressed Xenopus HNF4[beta]: in both cases we found an increase in HNF1[alpha] gene transcription at the early neurula stage (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	184	 This induction is very rapid, as animal caps injected with HNF4[alpha] mRNA contained induced HNF1[alpha] mRNA already at the blastula stage, when they were explanted (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	185	 This implies that HNF4 translated on the injected mRNA during early cleavage stages prior to the MBT had accumulated and activated HNF1[alpha] transcription rapidly at the MBT.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	186	 From this observation we conclude that the cells of the animal caps are competent for efficient HNF1[alpha] gene transcription if triggered with the appropriate signal.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The induction of HNF1[alpha] by HNF4 is a specific effect and independent of mesoderm induction, as other mesoderm markers are not expressed in HNF4-injected animal caps (data not shown).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	188	All these findings support the idea that maternal HNF4 is the initial activator of the HNF1[alpha] gene in Xenopus.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	189	 A loss-of-function study to test this assumption is difficult to perform, since HNF4 protein is already present in the egg and thus RNA depletion experiments are not possible.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Therefore, we introduced a fusion protein containing the HNF4 DNA binding domain and the putative ligand binding domain linked to the repressor domain of even-skipped of Drosophila into fertilized eggs.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Although this HNF4 repressor acted efficiently in hepatoma cells and was expressed at high levels in the injected embryos, we could not detect a significant reduction in endogenous HNF1[alpha] mRNA accumulation (data not shown).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	192	 We assume that the level of HNF4 repressor translated prior to the MBT is not sufficient to compete with the amount of maternal HNF4[alpha] and [beta] proteins (18,22) that had accumulated during several months of oocyte maturation.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	193	 In contrast, in all experiments where dominant negative variants of transcription factors have been successfully used to repress endogenous factors, e.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	194	 brachyury or eomesodermin (44,45), the inhibition involved zygotically accumulated trans-cription factors.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	195	 In these cases inhibition is probably facilitated as the embryo is preloaded with the repressors prior to expression of the zygotic factor to be inhibited.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	196	Overexpression of either rat or Xenopus HNF4 leads to increased transcription of the HNF1[alpha] gene in the early stages of embryogenesis (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	197	 This is in contrast to experiments done with the myogenic transcription factor MyoD: in this case only murine MyoD activated ectopic expression of myogenic markers in Xenopus embryos, whereas overexpressed Xenopus MyoD was hardly active (27).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Thus, in contrast to MyoD, the activity of HNF4 is species independent, indicating the high degree of functional conservation of the HNF4 family members in vertebrates (18,21,22).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	199	Our data show no differences in the activating potential between distinct HNF4 isoforms in the early stages of development, as the injected [beta] isoform increases HNF1[alpha] transcription (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	200	 7) as efficiently as the [alpha] isoform of HNF4 (Fig.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	201	 This finding possibly reflects the identical expression patterns of HNF4[alpha] and HNF4[beta] we have seen in whole-mount immunostaining in early cleavage stages (22).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Wrana for various plasmids and Y.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	203	Eto for the generous gift of recombinant human activin A.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	204	 This work was supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (Ry5/3-3).
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	205	 (1996) Development, 122, 2359-2366.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	206	 (1992) Development, 116, 783-797.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	207	 (1996) Development, 122, 1975-1984.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	208	 (1989) Development, 106, 775-785.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	209	 (1989) Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual, 2nd Edn.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	211	 (1992) Development, 114, 711-720.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	212	 (1992) Development, 115, 573-585.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	213	 (1998) Development, 125, 857-867.
0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	214	 (1996) Development, 122, 2427-2435.

0.22450218.9837989.html.plaintext.txt	219	de +Present address: The Randall Institute, Developmental Biology Research Centre, King's College, London WC2B 5RL, UK This page is run by Oxford University Press, Great Clarendon Street, Oxford OX2 6DP, as part of the OUP Journals Comments and feedback: www-admin{at}oup.

0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	0	Estrogen Receptor, a Common Interaction Partner for a Subset of Nuclear Receptors Soo-Kyung Lee, Hueng-Sik Choi, Mi-Ryoung Song, Mi-Ock Lee and Jae Woon Lee.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	1	) Chonnam National University Kwangju, 500 to 757 Korea Department of Microbiology (M-R.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	2	) College of Medicine Yonsei University Seoul, 120 to 752 Korea.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	3	While some nuclear receptors apparently bind HREs only as homodimers, TRs, vitamin D receptor, RARs, the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs), and several orphan nuclear receptors bind their specific response elements with high affinity as heterodimers with RXRs (11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Based on this high-affinity binding, such heterodimers have been considered to be the functionally active forms of these receptors in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	5	 However, RXR is not the only receptor capable of forming heterodimers with other nuclear receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	6	 TR (17, 18), COUP-TF (19, 20, 21), PPAR (22), and small heterodimer partner (SHP) (23) have been reported to form heterodimers with other receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Interestingly, although heterodimerization with RXR usually results in enhanced transactivation, COUP-TF and SHP seem to function primarily as transcriptional repressors (23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Heterodimer formation can generate many different combinations of receptors, particularly in the light of the fact that multiple genes and multiple isoforms exist for RAR, RXR, TR, COUP-TF, and PPAR.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	9	 As the expression of each isoform depends on cell type and the stage of growth and development, heterodimerization among all these receptors results in the formation of an extremely diverse group of receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In principle, the enormous number of heterodimer combinations could cover a wide range of transcriptional activities, thus generating significant diversity in gene regulation.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	11	Herein, we show that estrogen receptor (ER) directly binds, through protein-protein interactions between ligand-binding domains, to HNF4, TR, RAR, and RXR, adding a complexity to the already complicated list of the heteromeric interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	12	 We have also confirmed the results (29, 30) that newly cloned ER named ERss interacts with ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In parallel, COUP-TF (31), estrogen-related receptor 1 (ERR1) (32), and SHP (D.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Moore, personal communications) were shown to interact with ER, while this manuscript was in preparation.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	15	 We further show that coexpression of native TR, RAR, or RXR differentially regulates transactivations by ER in yeast and CV1 cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	16	 These results suggest that ER is a common interaction partner for a subset of receptors, and these interactions mediate novel signaling pathways in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	17	View larger version (25K):    Figure 1.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	18	 ER Binds to a Subset of Nuclear Receptors in Yeast.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	19	EGY48 cells, in which ss-galactosidase expression is dependent on the presence of a transcriptional activator with a LexA DNA-binding domain, were transformed with plasmids expressing the indicated LexA and B42 chimeras.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	20	 These cells were grown in liquid culture containing galactose, since expression of the B42 chimeras is under the control of the galactose-inducible GAL1 promoter (33 ).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	21	 ss-Galactosidase readings were determined and corrected for cell density and for time of development (A415/A600) x 1000/min.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The result is the average of at least three different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	23	 A, Open bars indicate no hormone added.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Light-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Thick-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA (B42/RAR and B42/RXR-LBD) or T3 (B42/TR and B42/TR-LBD).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Black bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM T3 (B42/TR and B42/TR-LBD) or 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM 9-cis-RA (B42/RAR and B42/RXR-LBD).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	27	 B, Open bars indicate no hormone added.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Light-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM T3.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Thick-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Black bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM 9-cis-RA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	31	  To confirm whether various ligand-dependent stimulations of the LacZ expressions observed reflect genuine ligand-dependent protein-protein interactions or simply ligand-dependent transactivations mediated by the AF2 domains (1), we reexamined the LacZ expressions with two previously defined AF2 mutant receptors, LexA/TR-LBD459 (33) and B42/RXR-LBDAF2 (36).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	32	 1B, the 9-cis-RA-dependent induction of the LacZ expression observed with coexpression of B42/RXR-LBD and LexA/TR-LBD was lost when B42/RXR-LBDAF2 was coexpressed instead, whereas the T3-dependent induction was specifically lost when LexA/TR-LBD459 was used.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	33	 When LexA/TR-LBD459 and B42/RXR-LBDAF2 were coexpressed, neither T3 nor 9-cis-RA-depedent induction of the LacZ expression was observed.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	34	 These results, along with our previous finding (33) in which the interactions of LexA/TR and B42/RXR were not affected by mutations into the AF2 domain of TR, clearly demonstrate that protein-protein interaction of TR and RXR are ligand independent.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Therefore, results of the yeast two-hybrid tests should be taken with caution that they may not represent true ligand-dependent interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Thus, we further characterized these interactions using two additional methods (i.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	37	 mammalian two-hybrid tests and glutathione-S-transferase (GST)-pull downs).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	38	ER Interacts with TR, RAR, and RXR in Mammalian Cells To examine whether ER binds to these receptors in mammalian cells, we employed a mammalian two-hybrid system that reproduces the heteromeric receptor-receptor interactions (37).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	39	 2, cotransfection of CV1 cells with expression vectors for VP16/TR, VP16/RAR, and VP16/RXR significantly increased the Gal4/ER-LBD-mediated induction of the Gal4-TK-Luc reporter gene activity (4-, 7.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	40	5-fold induction, respectively).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Similar results were obtained in the presence of 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	42	1  microM cognate ligand, suggesting that they interact with each other in a ligand-independent manner.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	43	 As expected, VP16 alone was ineffective.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Thus, we concluded that ER is capable of constitutively binding to TR, RAR, and RXR in mammalian cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	45	 These results suggest that the various ligand-dependent stimulations of the LacZ expression in yeast (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	46	 1A) may have reflected ligand-dependent transactivations of the AF2 domains, as suggested by the results shown in Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	47	View larger version (22K):    Figure 2.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	48	 ER Binds to a Subset of Nuclear Receptors in Mammalian Cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	49	CV1 cells were transfected with ss-galactosidase expression vector and VP16 alone, VP16/TR, VP16/RAR, or VP16/RXR-expression vectors along with a reporter gene Gal4-TK-Luc (37 ).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Open bars indicate no hormone added, whereas hatched and black bars indicate addition of 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	51	1  microM T3 and 9-cis-RA, respectively.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Normalized luciferase expressions from triplicate samples are presented relative to the ss-galactosidase expressions, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	53	  ER Binds to TR, RAR, and RXR in Vitro To further characterize these interactions in vitro, GST-fusions to full-length rat TRss, human RAR, and RXR were expressed, purified, and tested for interaction with an in vitro-translated full-length human ER or luciferase labeled with [35S]methionine.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	54	 As expected, luciferase was not able to interact with any of the GST proteins (data not shown).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	55	 However, ER readily interacted with GST/TR, GST/RAR, and GST/RXR either in the presence or absence of ligand (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	56	 ER didn t interact with GST alone or GST/GR, as expected.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	57	 In contrast, ER bound to GST fusion to the receptor-binding domain of SRC-1 (GST/SRC-R) (38) in an E2-stimulated manner (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The percentage of total [35S]ER bound by the fusion proteins were approximately 15 to 30% of the inputs (data not shown), and the E2-dependent fold-increase in the pull-down of [35S]ER by GST/SRC-R was approximately 4- to 5-fold.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	59	 From these results, we concluded that ER constitutively binds to TR, RAR, and RXR through direct protein-protein interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	60	 In particular, these results, along with the mammalian two- hybrid tests (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	61	 2), suggest that at least some of the ligand-dependent stimulation of the LacZ expression observed in the yeast two-hybrid tests (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	62	 1) should have resulted from ligand-induced transactivations rather than ligand-induced protein-protein interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	63	View larger version (20K):    Figure 3.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	64	Luciferase and ER-LBD labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation were incubated with glutathione beads containing GST alone, GST fusions to TRss (A), RAR (B), RXR (C), SRC-R and GR (D).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Beads were washed, and specifically bound material was eluted with reduced glutathione and resolved by SDS-PAGE.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	66	 (-) denotes no hormone added; 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	67	1  microM of each ligand was added as indicated.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	68	  Function of the ER Heterocomplexes We have previously shown that LexA/TR-LBD requires coexpression of native RXR for an efficient T3-dependent transactivation in yeast (33).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Similar to LexA/TR-LBD, LexA/ER-LBD alone was an inert transactivator, either in the presence or absence of E2, of the previously described LacZ reporter gene controlled by upstream LexA-binding sites in yeast (33).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	70	 To gain insights into the functional consequences of these interactions in vivo, we coexpressed holo-proteins of these ER-interacting receptors in the LexA/ER-LBD-expressing yeast cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Interestingly, RAR, RARss, RXRss, TR, or TRss dramatically enhanced the basal transcriptional activities of LexA/ER-LBD (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Coexpression of RAR led to approximately 2-fold induction in the basal transcriptional activities, which was further enhanced approximately 2-fold by addition of 1  microM 9-cis-RA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Interestingly, coexpression of RXR or RXR induced the LexA/ER-LBD-mediated LacZ expression only in the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA; i.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	74	 the basal level of expression was not affected by coexpression of these two receptors (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	75	 These results indicate that coexpression of these native receptors can differentially regulate transactivations by ER in yeast, attesting to the possible functional significance of these interactions in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	76	View larger version (34K):    Figure 4.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Modulation of LexA/ER-LBD by Coexpressed Holo-nuclear Receptors in Yeast.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	78	EGY48 cells, in which ss-galactosidase expression is dependent on the presence of a transcriptional activator with a LexA DBD, were transformed with plasmids expressing LexA/ER-LBD and the indicated holo-nuclear receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Open bars indicate no hormone added.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Light-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Thick-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA (RARs and RXRs) or T3 (TRs).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Black bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM T3 (TRs) or 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM 9-cis-RA (RARs and RXRs).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	83	 ss-Galactosidase readings were determined and corrected for cell density and for time of development (A415/A600) x 1000/min.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The result is the average of at least three different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	85	  To assess the functional consequences of these interactions in mammalian cells, TR, RAR, or RXR was cotransfected into CV1 cells along with an ER expression vector and a reporter construct controlled by ERE (ERE-TK-CAT or ERE-TK-Luc).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	86	1  microM E2 stimulated the ER-mediated reporter gene expression approximately 5- to 7-fold in the absence of cotransfected receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Coexpression of TR, however, significantly stimulated both the basal and E2-induced transactivations by ER (4- and 2-fold, respectively).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Interestingly, a weak additive effect was observed with the TR coexpression; i.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	89	 E2 plus T3 resulted in approximately 1.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	90	5-fold higher activities than E2 alone (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	91	 5A; see the results with 50 ng TR cotransfected).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Coexpression of RAR did not affect the basal level of transactivations by ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	93	 However, it repressed the E2-induced transactivation almost to the basal level (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	94	 In contrast, coexpression of RXR modestly stimulated the E2-induced transactivations by ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The basal level of transactivations by ER, however, was not affected by the RXR coexpression.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Similarly, coexpression of ER inhibited the 9-cis-RA-induced transactivations of a reporter construct controlled by ss-retinoic acid response element (data not shown).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In addition, cotransfection results varied depending on cell types and receptor isotypes, suggesting that other factors contribute to the final phenotype of each ER heterocomplex (M.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	98	 These results, along with the yeast coexpression results (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	99	 4), suggest that these ER heterocomplexes can differentially modulate the ER-mediated transcriptional activites in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	100	View larger version (20K):    Figure 5.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Differential Activites of the ER Heterocompexes in Mammalian Cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	102	CV1 cells were transfected with ss-galactosidase expression vector and increasing amounts of TR, RAR, or RXR expression vectors along with a reporter gene ERE-TK-LUC (A) or ERE-TK-CAT (B), as indicated.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Cells were unstimulated (open bars) or stimulated with 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	104	1  microM E2 (light-hatched bars), 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	105	1  microM T3 (thick-hatched bars), or 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Normalized luciferase expressions from triplicate samples are presented relative to the ss-galactosidase expressions and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	107	Even though the oligomeric status of the ER heterocomplexes are not currently known, two lines of evidence attest to the specificity of the protein-protein interactions between ER and these receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	108	 First, a series of chimeric HNF4s we recently constructed to define the HNF4 homodimeric interactions and RXR heterodimeric interactions (10) differentially interacted with ER (our unpublished results).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Second, we isolated a few mutant RXRs that show specifically impaired interactions with ER while maintaining wild-type interactions with other receptors (our unpublished results).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Similar to the chimeric HNF4s, these mutations also reside within the I-box of the RXR, which was recently found to be essential for homo- and heterodimer formations (9, 10), suggesting that HNF4 and RXR exploit the conventional dimerization domains (the I-box) to interact with ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Recently, the DNA-binding pattern of the RXR was shown to be regulated by ligand-dependent modulation of its oligomeric state (dimer vs.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	112	 tetramer), and the tetramerization domain was defined to be distinct from the dimerization domain I-box (45).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Thus, further mutational studies within this newly defined tetramerization domain of RXR, as well as mapping the regions of ER essential for these interactions, will be required to clearly decode the oligomeric status of these ER heterocomplexes.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	114	The LexA-based yeast two-hybrid system presents two possible complications to study protein-protein interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	115	 First, the full-length LexA used in this system contains its own dimerization domain, which could complicate interpretation of the interaction results, particularly where dimerization is a prerequisite for two target proteins to interact with each other.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Second, this system cannot distinguish between genuine ligand-dependent protein-protein interactions and ligand-dependent transactivations.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	117	 For instance, the ligand-induced stimulations of the LacZ expressions when LexA/TR and B42/RXR-LBD were coexpressed were shown to reflect ligand-dependent transactivations mediated by the AF2 domains of TR and RXR (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	118	 With these complications, other methods such as the GST pull-downs should be employed to probe protein-protein interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The interactions of ER with TR, RAR, and RXR were hormone-independent in both mammalian two-hybrid tests and GST pull-downs, suggesting that the seemingly hormone-dependent interactions in yeast (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	120	 1) may have been the hormone-dependent transactivations of the AF2 domains.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The T3-dependent stimulation of the LacZ expression with TR-LBD and ER-LBD coexpressed (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	122	 1A) may have also reflected the T3-dependent transactivations of the AF2 domain of TR.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The basal interactions between these proteins might have been too low to detect in the yeast system, which, however, became detectable with an aid from the activated transactivations of the AF2 domain upon T3 addition (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	124	 1A; see the results with LexA/ER-LBD and B42/TR-LBD).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	125	The physiological implications for these interactions have been accumulating.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	126	 For instance, manipulations of T3 and E2in vitro were shown to potentiate or mutually inhibit effects of gene expression (40, 46, 47).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Environmental conditions that alter levels of circulating T3, such as cold temperature, were also shown to alter E2-dependent female reproductive behavior (48, 49, 50, 51).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	128	 TR was recently shown to attenuate ER-mediated transactivations from the vit A2 consensus ERE, which is not necessarily dependent on DNA binding, as the TR DNA-binding mutant was still able to inhibit E2-dependent transactivation (52, 53).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	129	 However, under similar conditions, we observed a modest enhancement of the ERE-mediated transactivations by either liganded or unliganded ER when cotransfected with TR (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The reasons for this discrepancy are not currently known.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	131	 In addition, retinoids have been shown to inhibit the growth of hormone-dependent breast cancer cells both in vivo and in vitro (54, 55, 56).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Nonadditive inhibition has been demonstrated between retinoids and antiestrogens, suggesting that each agent may produce common antiestrogenic effects.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Recently, synergistic interactions between HNF3 and HNF4 mediating apolipoprotein AI gene expression were shown to be further potentiated by cotransfected ER (57), in which the physical association of ER and HNF4, as described in this report, may play a role.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	134	 However, the physiological implications for the ER/SHP (D.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Moore, personal communications), ER/COUP-TF (31), and ER/ERR1 (32) interactions are not currently known.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	136	In conclusion, we found that ER directly binds to a subset of nuclear receptors through protein-protein interactions between ligand-binding domains, and these ER heterocomplexes led to differential regulation of transactivations by ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	137	 From these results, we propose that ER is a common interaction partner for a subset of receptors, and these different ER heterocomplexes should mediate novel signaling pathways in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	138	Yeast ss-Galactosidase Assays The cotransformation and transactivation assays in yeast as well as quantitative liquid ss-galactosidase assays were performed with the following changes as described previously (33).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The yeast culture were initially diluted to an A600 of 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	140	05, and plated into 96-well culture dishes with the various concentrations of hormone.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The cultures were then incubated in the dark at 30 C for 16 h.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The A600 was determined, and then cells were lysed and substrate was added and A415 was read after 10 to 30 min.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The normalized galactosidase values were determined as follows: (A415/A600) x 1000/min developed.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	144	 For each experiment, at least six independently derived colonies expressing chimeric receptors were tested.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	145	Pull-Down Assays GST fusion proteins were produced in Escherichia coli and purified using glutathione-Sepharose affinity chromatography essentially as described (36).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	146	 GST proteins were bound to glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads (Pharmacia) in binding buffer (50 mM KPO4, pH 6.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	147	0, 100 mM KCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 10% glycerol, 10 mg/ml E.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Beads were washed once with binding buffer and incubated for 60 min at 4 C in the same buffer with equivalent amounts of various proteins labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Nonbound proteins were removed by three washes with binding buffer without E.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	150	 coli extract, and specifically bound proteins were eluted with 50 mM reduced glutathione in 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Eluted proteins were resolved by PAGE and visualized by fluorography.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	152	Cell Culture and Transfections CV1 cells were grown in 24-well plates with medium supplemented with 10% charcoal-stripped serum.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	153	 After 24 h incubation, cells were transfected with 150 ng of ss-galactosidase expression vector pRSV-ss-gal and 100 ng of a reporter gene ERE-TK-CAT or ERE-TK-Luc, along with 10 ng ER- and increasing amounts (50 to 100 ng) of TR, RAR, or RXR expression vector.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Total amount of expression vectors were kept constant by adding decreasing amounts of the CDM8 expression vector to transfections containing increasing amounts of the TR, RAR, or RXR vector.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	155	 For the mammalian two-hybrid tests, a reporter gene Gal4-TK-Luc, vectors expressing VP16/-, VP16/TR, VP16/RAR, or VP16/RXR, and Gal4DBD/ER-LBD expression vector were used as described (37).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	156	 After 12 h, cells were washed and refed with DMEM containing 10% charcoal-stripped FBS.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	157	 After 12 h, cells were left unstimulated or stimulated with 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Cells were harvested 24 h later, and CAT or luciferase activity was assayed as described (58), and the results were normalized to the ss-galactosidase expression.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Similar results were obtained in more than two similar experiments.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	160	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Drs.

0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Moore for valuable advice, plasmids, and communications of their results before publication.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Vincent Giguere for mERss and Dr.
