0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	0	Identification of a Novel Sonic Hedgehog Response Element in the Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor II Promoter Venkatesh Krishnan, Gerard Elberg, Ming-Jer Tsai and Sophia Y.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Cell Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas 77030.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	2	It has been reported that increased Shh expression in the notochord results in the increased expression of HNF3ss in the floor plate and the subsequent appearance of other ventral markers in the neural tube (6).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	3	 This results in the suppression of the dorsalizing signals, induced by BMP-2/4 originating from the neuroectoderm (7).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The appearance of ventral markers within the neural tube establishes a dorso-ventral boundary, which is broadly described as dorso-ventral patterning.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The induction of motor neuron markers within the ventro-lateral region is coincident with this Shh-mediated activity in the neural tube.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Jessell and co-workers (8) have demonstrated that conditioned media from COS-1 cells that overexpress and secrete Shh can mediate motor neuron differentiation in naive neural plate explants.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	7	Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factors (COUP-TFs) are members of the nuclear receptor superfamily and belong to the orphan receptor subclass (9, 10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Two genes called COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII have been identified in mammals.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	9	 COUP-TFs are capable of dimerizing with the retinoid X receptor and are known to affect the regulation of retinoic acid receptor, retinoid X receptor, and vitamin D receptor responsive genes (9).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	10	 COUP-TFs in general are expressed during embryonic development and are proposed to mediate essential mesenchymal-epithelial interactions that are crucial for proper organogenesis (10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	11	 To that effect, mRNA of COUP-TFII has been detected in the mesenchymal compartment of several developing organs such as the kidney, breast, and prostate (10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	12	COUP-TFs are expressed in the developing murine central and peripheral nervous systems.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	13	 It is hypothesized that these two genes play a role in regulating the developmental fates of diencephalic neuromeres by altering the expression of some of the key factors involved in cell fate determination (11).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Most importantly, COUP-TFII mRNA is highly expressed in differentiating motor neurons within the neural tube of a developing chick embryo.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Notochord transplantation experiments suggest that this increase in COUP-TFII mRNA within the ventro-lateral region of the chick neural tube is mediated by signals derived from the notochord (12).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Hence, we hypothesize that Shh, a secreted morphogen derived from the notochord, can elicit this increase in COUP-TFII expression in differentiating motor neurons.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	17	For our studies we used the P19 mouse embryocarcinoma cells that were previously used to study the retinoid-mediated regulation of COUP-TFs (13, 14).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Also, these cells exhibit some characteristics of neuronal cells when treated for extended periods with all-trans retinoic acid (15).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	19	 For our initial experiments, conditioned medium derived from COS-1 cells transfected with a mouse Shh expression construct was applied to P19 cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Later, an Escherichia coli-expressed N-terminal 20-kDa Shh protein fragment was used in our studies.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In this report we provide evidence that Shh can induce COUP-TFII transcripts in P19 cells and evidence to implicate a novel target element on the COUP-TFII promoter that mediates this Shh-induced activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	22	View larger version (20K):    Figure 1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Induction of COUP-TFII mRNA by Conditioned Media Containing Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	24	A, P19 cells were treated with 200  microl (lane 2) and 400  microl (lane 3) of conditioned media containing Shh N-terminal fragment (pBKCMV-Shh).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Lane 1 is the control lane, which was conditioned media from the vector-transfected COS-1 cells (pBKCMV).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Densitometric analysis reveals a 3- to 5-fold increase in COUP-TFII mRNA levels after adjusting for the GAPDH internal control.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	27	 B, COS-1 cells were transfected with pBKCMV alone (lane 1) or pBKCMV-Shh (lane 2 and 3).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The medium was concentrated to 1/20 of the volume and separated on a 12% SDS-PAGE gel.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The gel was subsequently transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane and subjected to a Western analysis as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The 20-kDa band represents the secreted form of Shh N-terminal fragment.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Lane 3 represents a membrane that contains the same media from lane 2 except that it was probed with a primary antibody that was preblocked with the specific antigen.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	32	  To ascertain the presence of secreted Shh in the conditioned media, we performed a Western blot analysis using a polyclonal antibody that specifically recognizes the secreted N-terminal 20-kDa Shh protein fragment (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Results from these experiments suggest that immunodetectable levels of the secreted 20 kDa N-terminal fragment of Shh are only present in COS-1 cell-conditioned media transfected with the pBKCMV-Shh plasmid (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The N-terminal protein was used to block this antibody to corroborate its specificity (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Since the signaling function of Shh is restricted to this N-terminal secreted fragment, we shall refer to this fragment as Shh for the remainder of this report.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	36	Induction of COUP-TFII Promoter Activity by Conditioned Media Containing Shh To identify the mechanism of this Shh-mediated increase in COUP-TFII mRNA, we analyzed the effect of the Shh-containing conditioned media on the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	37	6-kb promoter fragment that includes the transcription initiation site of COUP-TFII was cloned upstream of the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) reporter gene (p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	38	6CII-CAT) and transfected into P19 cells (13).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	39	 2 the conditioned media containing Shh (lanes 2 and 3) can increase COUP-TFII promoter activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	40	 In a separate experiment we show that this increase can be elicited by adding 1 nM N-terminal 20-kDa Shh protein directly to COS-1 cells transfected with the p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Hence, it can be inferred that P19 and COS-1 cells possess the necessary factors to transduce the Shh signal.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	42	 These results indicate that the 1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	43	6-kb fragment of the COUP-TFII promoter harbors the target element(s) that mediates Shh activation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	44	View larger version (46K):    Figure 2.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Induction of COUP-TFII Promoter Activity by Conditioned Media Containing Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	46	P19 cells were transfected with the p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Increasing amounts of conditioned media from COS-1 cells containing Shh were added to P19 cells (lane 2; 200  microl, lane 3; 400  microl).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Conditioned medium from COS-1 cells with no Shh was added separately to P19 cells (lane 1; 400  microl) transfected with the p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	49	 A 10-fold increase was observed between lanes 1 and 3.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	50	  Deletion Analysis of the COUP-TFII Promoter To further characterize the target element(s), deletion mutants of the COUP-TFII promoter with various end points were generated.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	51	 COS-1 cells were transfected with this plasmid and treated with 1 nM Shh protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	52	 3A, the Shh-mediated increase in promoter activity was restricted to the 5' -1455 to -1212 nucleotide (nt) fragment (compare lanes 3 and 4 with the other lanes).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	53	 In contrast, the p800CII-tkCAT (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	54	 3A, lanes 5 and 6), p900CII-tkCAT (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	55	 3A, lanes 7 and 8), or the tkCAT vector backbone (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	56	 3A, lanes 9 and 10) showed no increase in CAT activity in the presence of Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	57	View larger version (35K):    Figure 3.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Identification of a ShhRE on the COUP-TFII Promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	59	A, COS-1 cells were transfected with the following plasmids: p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	60	6CII-CAT, lanes 1 and 2; p240CII-tkCAT, lanes 3 and 4; p800CII-tkCAT, lanes 5 and 6; p925CII-tkCAT, lanes 7 and 8; and pBLCAT2, lanes 9 and 10.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Cells were treated with 1 nM Shh for 36 h, and cell lysate was assayed for enzyme activity as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	62	 A 4- to 6-fold increase in CAT activity was observed between lanes 1 and 3 and 2 and 4, respectively.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	63	 B, COS-1 cells were transfected as described earlier with the plasmids as indicated by their starting nucleotide on the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	64	 A 4- to 6- fold increase in CAT activity was observed between lanes 1 and 3 and 2 and 4, respectively.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	65	 C, COS-1 cells were transfected as described earlier with the plasmids as indicated by the region within the COUP-TFII promoter and described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	66	 A 3- to 4-fold increase was observed between lanes 1, 3, and 5 and 2, 4, and 6, respectively.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	67	  To further define the Shh response element (ShhRE), we used nested primers to PCR amplify specific 5' deleted fragments of this -1455 to -1212 region of the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	68	 These deletion fragments were subsequently cloned upstream of a tkCAT reporter, transfected into COS-1 cells, and treated with or without 1 nM Shh protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	69	 3B, deletion of the first 112 nt (from -1455 to -1343) has no effect on the Shh inducibility (compare lanes 2 and 4).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	70	 In contrast, deletion of the next 76 or 159 nt (from -1343 to -1267 or -1150) abolished Shh-dependent activation of the reporter gene (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	71	 3B; compare lanes 2, 6, and 8).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Also, cells transfected with the tkCAT vector backbone showed no increase in CAT enzyme activity in the presence of 1 nM Shh (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Results obtained from these studies suggest that the Shh-induced activity was mediated by a response element located between -1343 and -1267 of the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	74	Additional deletions were made within this region of the promoter to localize the target element that mediates Shh activation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	75	 These fragments were subsequently cloned upstream of a tkCAT reporter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	76	 COS-1 cells were transfected with these plasmids and treated with 1 nM Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	77	 3C, deletion of 27 nt from -1343 does not affect Shh activation (compare lanes 4 and 6).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	78	 However, additional removal of 18 nt (from -1316 to -1298) abolishes Shh activation (compare lanes 6 and 8).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	79	 These results indicate that the 19-bp region between nucleotides -1316 and -1298 harbors most of this activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Collectively, our results indicate that a region (-1316 to -1298) within the COUP-TFII promoter harbors a ShhRE that mediates the Shh-induced increase in COUP-TFII promoter activity that leads to increased steady-state levels of COUP-TFII mRNA.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	81	Characterization of the ShhRE in P19 Cells To further confirm that the region between -1316 and -1298 is sufficient to confer the Shh response, we used this sequence in a heterologous promoter function assay.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	82	 A 42-bp oligonucleotide (ShhRE) that includes this region and the flanking sequences was synthesized, and three copies of this oligo were placed upstream of a tkLUC reporter gene to determine whether this element confers Shh inducibility through a heterologous promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	83	 In addition, four specific mutations, M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5, were introduced along this element and three copies of each of these mutant oligos were cloned upstream of a tkLUC reporter (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The resulting plasmids were then transfected into P19 cells, and reporter gene activity in response to 1 nM Shh was analyzed.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	85	 4B, three copies of ShhRE can provide a 5- to 7-fold increase in reporter gene activity in response to Shh (compare C and Shh).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	86	 4B, the M2, M3, and M4 mutations abolish the Shh response (compare S and S M1, S M2, S M3).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	87	 In contrast the M1 and M5 mutants were still capable of mediating this Shh-induced reporter gene activity (compare S, S M1, and S M5).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	88	 These results indicate that the nucleotide sequences defined by the mutant oligos M2, M3, and M4 are important for mediating the Shh response.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Hence, the point mutations introduced within the ShhRE that abolish transactivation must affect the binding of a putative transcription factor to this DNA element.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	90	View larger version (27K):    Figure 4.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Characterization of the ShhRE on a Heterologous Promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	92	A, Sequence information on the wild type ShhRE and mutant oligonucleotides used in a transient transfection assay.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	93	 B, P19 cells were transfected with 3XShhRE-tkCAT (lanes 1 and 2), 3XM1-tkCAT (lanes 3 and 4), 3XM2-tkCAT (lanes 5 and 6), 3XM3-tkCAT (lanes 7 and 8), and 3XM4-tkCAT (lanes 9 and 10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Cells were treated with (S) or without (C) 1 nM Shh for 24 h, and luciferase activity was measured as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Results are expressed as mean  plus or minus  SD from three separate experiments.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	96	  Electromobility Shift Assays (EMSAs) Using P19 Nuclear Extracts and Radiolabeled ShhRE To understand the nature of the protein-DNA interaction on this element, we performed EMSAs using radiolabeled ShhRE.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The resulting autoradiograph indicates that there are two specific bands (see arrows), which are specifically enriched by Shh treatment (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Also, these bands are competed by the excess unlabeled ShhRE (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	99	 As expected, the mutant oligos M2, M3, and M4, which fail to exhibit enhancer-like activity, also fail to compete for these specific complexes when used as competitors (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Also, as expected, the oligo M1 and M5, which are functional ShhREs, could effectively compete for binding to these two specific complexes (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	101	 These results suggest that any alterations in the TACATAATGCGCCG core (residues in bold) of this ShhRE results in decreased binding, which then leads to decreased enhancer activity in transient transfection assays.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	102	View larger version (75K):    Figure 5.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	103	 EMSA Using Radiolabeled ShhRE and Nuclear Extracts from P19 Cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	104	P19 cells were treated with (lanes 2 through 8) or without (lane 1) 1 nM Shh for 36 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Later, cells were harvested and nuclear extract was obtained.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Five micrograms of this extract were used in an EMSA using radiolabeled ShhRE, which was performed as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Mutant competitor oligos at 100-fold molar excess were coincubated (lanes 3 through 8) with radiolabeled probe.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The specific bands are indicated by the arrowheads.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	109	The identification of this ShhRE provides us with a valuable tool to study the various signaling pathways that are induced by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Previously, it was reported by Ingham and his colleagues (17) that a binding site for the Ci (cubidus interruptus) protein is a consensus HhRE (GACCACCCA), since it mediates the activation of the ptc (patched) promoter by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Ptc is a downstream target gene of Hh and is part of the putative membrane-bound Shh receptor complex (18, 19, 20).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	112	 However, the exact mechanism of ptc activation via this Ci element remains to be determined.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Interestingly, the ShhRE found on the COUP-TFII promoter bears very little similarity to that of the Drosophila Ci binding site.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In our oligo competition experiments, we demonstrate that any changes in the core sequence (TACATAATGCGCCG) are deleterious to Shh-induced binding.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Also, a transcription factor data bank analysis revealed very little information as to the exact identity of the factor(s) that may bind this element.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The identification of this novel response element suggests that in higher vertebrates the pleiotropic effects of Shh can be mediated by multiple pathways, some of which may target the Gli (mammalian homolog of Ci) binding site and others may target novel elements such as the one in the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	117	 5, the DNA-binding complexes in P19 nuclear extracts are induced by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The precise mechanism for this increase in binding is not known.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	119	 It is possible that Shh may simply modulate the activity of this factor(s) that binds to the ShhRE.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	120	 In agreement with this possible modulatory role for Shh, the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A (PKA) has been implicated in the Hh-signaling pathway.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In Drosophila, it is believed that PKA agonists can suppress signaling mediated by Hh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Also, localized loss of PKA -/- activity in a Drosophila imaginal disc can mimic Hh activity even in the absence of Hh (21, 22).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Similar results have been obtained using a dominant negative form of PKA in the mouse dorsal central nervous system (23, 24).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	124	 These observations have led to the popular belief that reversal of a PKA-repressed pathway is one of the major mechanisms of Hh activity in Drosophila and in mammals.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	125	 However, we do not observe a significant decrease in our transient transfection assays when COS-1 cells are treated with both Shh and forskolin (90  microM) using the 3X ShhRE-tkCAT.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Also, forskolin fails to decrease Shh-induced binding in an EMSA using radiolabeled ShhRE (data not shown).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	127	 These results suggest that in higher vertebrates additional pathways that are independent of PKA may also be induced by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The identification of COUP-TFII as a novel target gene and the characterization of a ShhRE within its promoter may allow for the unraveling of this complex pathway.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	129	Our results provide a novel target gene for Shh, namely COUP-TFII, which can be exploited to study some of the intermediate steps in the Shh-signaling pathway.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	130	 In particular, COUP-TFII is a very well characterized transcription factor whose ability to affect the function of several other nuclear receptors provides an attractive target for the pleiotropic effects of Shh signaling.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	131	 However, the expression of COUP-TFII transcripts and areas in which Shh exerts its signaling activity may be limited to a few regions within the developing embryo (1, 10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	132	The Shh homozygous null mice display the predicted phenotype based on the expression profile of this protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The Shh null mice display a cyclopia phenotype along with a loss of maintenance and organization along the axial midline structures of the developing embryo (25).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	134	 However, in the Shh null mice we can detect some COUP-TFII transcripts (F.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	135	 This observation suggests that COUP-TFII is not exclusively regulated by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	136	 These results are not surprising since COUP-TFII is expressed throughout mouse embryonic development in a wide variety of tissues (10, 11).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Also, we and others have shown that COUP-TFs are downstream target genes of retinoic acid and that their expression is increased by treatment with both 9-cis and all-trans retinoic acid (13, 14).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	138	We have generated COUP-TFII homozygous null mice to study the possible involvement of COUP-TFII in motor-neuron differentiation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	139	 However, the COUP-TFII null mice die before 10.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Interestingly, no obvious change in the overall morphology within the ventro-lateral region of the neural tube is observed (F.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	141	 We believe that the presence of COUP-TFI transcripts in the neural tube may allow for some functional compensation of COUP-TFII, which may obscure any obvious defects in motor neuron differentiation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	142	 We are currently attempting a localized knock out of both COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII in the ventro-lateral region of the neural tube to study the possible involvement of these genes in motor neuron differentiation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	143	Our results have provided a novel target gene for Shh signaling in P19 mouse embryocarcinoma cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Activation of COUP-TFII, which is known to harbor a trans-repressor domain in its C-terminal 15 amino acids, may have important implications in neural tube patterning (26).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Shh has been implicated in enabling the notochord-derived signals to repress the dorsalizing signals induced by BMP-2/4 from the roof plate and or the neural epithelium of the neural tube (7, 27).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	146	 It has been reported that COUP-TFI can inhibit the BMP-4 promoter in fetal rat calvarial osteoblasts (28).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	147	 It is possible that temporal induction of COUP-TFII expression by Shh may serve to mediate this very repression in specific regions that are fated to become motor neurons in the ventro-lateral region of the neural tube.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In conclusion, our results provide a novel target gene (COUP-TFII) and a novel target element (ShhRE) that seem to mediate Shh-induced COUP-TFII expression in P19 mouse embryocarcinoma cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This finding will allow for the elucidation of the numerous signaling pathways induced by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	150	Oligonucleotide Sequences ShhRE: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC TAC ATA ATG CGC CCG GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	151	M1: CGGGATCC AGT GAA TTC TAC ATA ATG CGC CCG GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	152	M2: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC CGC ATA ATG CGC CCG GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	153	M3: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC TAC GTG ATG CGC CCG GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	154	M4: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC TAC ATA ATG CGC ATT GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	155	M5: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC TAC ATA ATG CGC CCG GAG AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	156	The ShhRE, M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5 oligos were cut with BamHI and BglII and ligated to generate a 3-copy insert.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Later this multimer was excised from a gel and subcloned into the BamHI site of the ptk109 plasmid, which contains a luciferase reporter gene driven by a minimal tk promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	158	PCR Primers -808 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CAG AGA GCT CAG TGA GCT.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	159	+117 reverse primer: TGA AGA TCT GAG TGT GCA GC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	160	-1343 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CGG AGA GCA TTA TTC AGT.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	161	-1267 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CAA ACC ACT GTG CCC GAT.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	162	-1150 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CAT TTA GAG GCA TCG CCA.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	163	-1316 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CGT TCT ACA TAA TGC GCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	164	-1298 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CAT GCG CCG GGA GTC CCG GGT GGA C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	165	-1070 reverse primer: GAA GAT CTT CCT GGC CAC AGA GAG G.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	166	The above mentioned primers were used to PCR amplify specific regions within the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	167	6-kb region was used as template, and 100 ng/ml of each of the forward and reverse primers were used in a 50- microl reaction along with 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	168	5 mM deoxynucleoside triphosphates (final concentration) and 1  microl of Taq polymerase.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Ten percent dimethylsulfoxide was included in some reactions when the regions to be amplified had a GC content that was greater than 50%.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The amplified DNA fragments were phenol- and chloroform-purified followed by an overnight restriction enzyme digest with the appropriate enzymes.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	171	 All forward primers were digested with XbaI, and all reverse primers were digested with BglII.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Later these fragments were subcloned into a pBluescript II KS plasmid vector at the XbaI and BglII sites.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	173	 T7 and T3 primers were used to sequence these PCR-amplified fragments and after verification, these fragments were subcloned into the pBLCAT2 (tkCAT) or pBLCAT3 (CAT alone) plasmid at the XbaI/BamHI site.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The resultant plasmids were sequenced using the PCR primers and were subsequently used in transient transfection assays.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	175	COS-1 Conditioned Media COS-1 cells were plated at a density of 2 x 106 cells per 10-cm plate.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Cells were transiently transfected using the diethylaminoethyl-Dextran method as described previously (29).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Briefly, 1  microg of pBKCMV-Shh or pBKCMV plasmid was dissolved in 60  microl Tris-borate-NaCl (TBS) buffer and was incubated along with 120  microl diethylaminoethyl-Dextran (Sigma, St.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Louis, MO; 5 mg/ml in TBS) for 30 min at room temperature.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Later, this DNA solution was mixed with 4 ml TBS buffer containing 10% NuSerum (Collaborative Biomedical Products, Bedford, MA).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	180	 This mixture was then applied to the 10-cm plate, and the cells were incubated in this mixture for 6 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Cells were shocked with 10% dimethylsulfoxide for 2 min followed by a 4-h incubation with DMEM (no serum) containing 100  microM Chloroquine (Sigma, St.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Cells were washed and fresh medium was added containing 5% FBS.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Conditioned medium was obtained after 24, 36, and 48 h and assayed by Western blot after the medium had been concentrated to 1/20 of the volume in an Amicon (Beverly, MA) concentrator.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The 48-h time point was found to be optimal for use in other assays.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	185	Northern Blot Analysis P19 cells were grown to a density of 5 x 105 cells per 10-cm plate.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Cells were used between passage numbers 5 and 20.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Late passage cells displayed significant variations in our experiments and hence were not used in these reported studies.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Conditioned media obtained from the appropriately transfected COS-1 cells were applied at a specific time point, and 40 h later total RNA was obtained using the Trizol (Life Technologies, Gaithersburg, MD) reagent.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	189	 This method is a modification of the guanidinium-HCl method of RNA isolation (30).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	190	 RNA was dissolved in 100% deionized formamide and used within a short period or stored in 70% ethanol for extended periods at -70 C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Ten micrograms of total RNA were reprecipitated and washed with 70% ethanol and redissolved in diethyl pyrocarbonate-treated water.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	192	 This RNA was heated at 55 C for 15 min in loading buffer (35% formamide, 10% formaldehyde, 20 mM Na2HPO4, pH 6.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	193	8, and loading dye containing 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	194	 RNA was quick cooled on ice and loaded onto a 1% agarose gel containing 1 M formaldehyde in an SPC buffer (20 mM Na2HPO4, pH 6.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The gel was run in 1x SPC buffer and stained with ethidium bromide (0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	196	01% solution in 1x SPC) for 20 min followed by destaining for 1 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The separated RNA was blotted onto a Hybond N nylon membrane (Amersham, Arlington Heights, IL).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	198	 A RNA ladder (6  microg) was run along with each gel and was used to estimate the size of the transcript.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The membrane was UV-cross-linked (Stratalinker, Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) for 2 min and was dried in a gel dryer at 80 C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The membrane was prehybridized using the QuikHyb solution from Stratagene for 1 h and was hybridized with a radiolabeled 500-bp 5'-untranslated region fragment (31) of COUP-TFII for 2 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Later, the membrane was washed twice with 2x saline sodium citrate (SSC) buffer and 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	202	 This was followed by two high-stringency washes using 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The residual SDS was removed using a quick 2x SSC wash, and the membrane was exposed to a XOMAT-AR film (Eastman Kodak, Rochester, NY) for 6 to 12 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The membrane was then stripped using 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	205	1x SSPE (sodium phosphate-EDTA), 1% SDS solution at 85 C for 15 min.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	206	 It was then rehybridized with a specific 5' 1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	207	Transient Transfection Assays COS-1 cells were transiently transfected as described earlier, using 1  microg reporter plasmid.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	208	 P19 cells were transfected using a replication-deficient adenovirus as described earlier (33).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Briefly, adenovirus (2 x 108 particles) and 100 ng reporter plasmid were incubated at room temperature for 30 min in a buffer containing 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	210	 This was followed by infection of P19 cells (400,000 cells per well) with this viral-DNA mixture for 2 h in a 37 C incubator in DMEM containing 5% FBS.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	211	 coli-expressed Shh (1 nM) was added along with the fresh media supplemented with 10% FBS after transfection and incubated for 24 h, before the cells were harvested for reporter gene activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	212	 A Bio-Rad (Hercules, CA) protein assay reagent was used to quantitate the amount of protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Five micrograms of cell lysate were used in a CAT assay, which was performed as described previously (34).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	214	 For the luciferase reporter gene assays, 10  microg cell lysate were incubated with the enzyme substrate in a 60- microl reaction mix according to the instructions provided in the Promega luciferase assay system kit (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Enzyme activity was measured in a Monolight analytical luminometer (Analytical/Luminescence Laboratory, Ann Arbor, MI) for 5 sec and was plotted as relative luciferase units per 20  microg lysate.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	216	 2, P19 cells were transfected using 1  microg p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	217	6CII-CAT plasmid along with 6  microg Lipofectamine (Life Technologies) reagent in 4 ml DMEM without serum for 10 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Later cells were washed and 12 ml fresh DMEM containing 10% FBS were added along with 200  microl or 400  microl concentrated COS-1-conditioned media containing Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	219	 In parallel, 400  microl concentrated COS-1-conditioned media without Shh, along with 12 ml DMEM, were also added to P19 cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	220	 After 36 h cells were harvested and cell lysate was obtained.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Protein concentration was determined using the Bio-Rad protein assay reagent.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Twenty micrograms of cell lysate were used to analyze CAT activity as described earlier.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	223	EMSAs P19 cells were seeded at 5 x 105 cells per 10-cm plate in DME-F12 media with or without 1 nM Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	224	 After 36 h cells were harvested and washed in PBS.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Cells were incubated in 200  microl hypotonic buffer containing 10 mM KCl, 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	226	1 mM EDTA, 1 mM dithiothreitol (DTT), 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	227	5 mM phenylmethylsulfonylfluoride, and 10 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Twenty-five microliters of 10% NP-40 were added, and the cells were vortexed for 30 sec.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Later these cells were centrifuged at 5000 rpm at 4 C to spin down the nuclei.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Nuclei were then incubated in 30  microl hypertonic buffer containing 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	231	4 M NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonylfluoride, 10% glycerol, and 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	232	9, for 30 min in a gentle shaker at 4 C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	233	 This mixture was centrifuged at 13,000 rpm at 4 C for 10 min, and the supernatant was immediately dialyzed for 4 h in 500 ml buffer containing 10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	234	5, 50 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, and 5% glycerol at 4 C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	235	 A 10 kDa molecular mass cut-off membrane was used for this dialysis.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	236	 A Bio-Rad protein assay reagent was used to quantitate the amount of protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Five micrograms of nuclear extract were incubated along with 50,000 cpm of radiolabeled ShhRE for 15 min, in a buffer containing 10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	238	5, 80 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	239	1 mg/ml BSA, 200 ng salmon sperm DNA, 3  microg poly dG-dC, 1  microg poly dI-dC, and 5% glycerol.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	240	 One hundred molar excess of competitor oligos were incubated in the appropriate reaction mix along with the nuclear extract.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The samples were then loaded onto a 5% native polyacrylamide gel, and the protein-DNA complexes formed were separated and analyzed by autoradiography.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	242	Western Blot Analysis Conditioned media from the appropriately transfected COS-1 cells were concentrated to 1/20 the volume using an Amicon concentrator and applied onto a 12% SDS-polyacrylamide gel.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	243	 The separating gel was immediately transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane in a buffer containing 50 mM Tris, 380 mM glycine, 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	244	1% (wt/vol) SDS, and 20% methanol.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The transfer was performed at 65 V for 16 h in a cold room.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	246	 To confirm complete transfer, the gel was stained with a Coomassie stain for 20 min followed by destaining in a 40% methanol-10% glacial acetic acid solution for 1 to 2 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The resultant membrane was subjected to the standard enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) Western blotting kit protocol (Amersham, Life Science).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	248	 A rabbit polyclonal antibody that specifically recognized the N-terminal 20 kDa Shh protein (3) was used to detect the levels of N-terminal 20-kDa protein in the conditioned media.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The primary antibody was divided into two groups and was blocked with BSA or 4  microg/ml N-terminal Shh protein fragment for 2 h at 4 C with gentle shaking.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The membrane divided into two halves and was incubated with the primary antibody or the preblocked antibody at a 1:3000 dilution in 20 mM Tris, 137 mM NaCl, 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The membrane was washed and then incubated with a horseradish peroxidase-labeled anti-rabbit secondary antibody (1:1000 dilution) for 1 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	252	 This was followed by another wash and incubation with the detection mix provided in the ECL kit, for 1 min.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The membrane was immediately drained and exposed to film for 30 sec.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	254	 A prestained marker (Bio-Rad) was used to estimate the apparent molecular masses of the resultant bands.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	255	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We are grateful to Dr.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	0	An enhancer element 6 kb upstream of the mouse HNF41 promoter is activated by glucocorticoids and liver-enriched transcription factors Alain Bailly, Maria Elena Torres-Padilla, Antoine P.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	1	Unite de Genetique de la Differenciation, FRE 2364 du CNRS, Institut Pasteur, 25 Rue du Dr Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received May 31, 2001; Revised and Accepted July 9, 2001.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	3	Relatively little information is available concerning the regulation of expression of the HNF4 gene.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	4	 A series of up to 10 DNase I hypersensitive sites (HS) in adult liver chromatin, spread out over 15 kb of DNA upstream of the start of transcription of HNF41, the initially isolated isoform (1), implies that its regulation is complex (13,14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	5	5 kb fragment of DNA upstream of the transcription start site and its 5' deletions to analyze expression in transient transfection assays in hepatoma cells as well as in transgenic mice.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	6	 While the long fragment and deletions down to  to 228 bp showed similar activity in transient expression assays, only the long fragment conferred appropriate activity to a reporter gene in transgenic mice.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	7	 These results imply that the distal HS harbor important regulatory sites for HNF41 expression.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Several splice variants of HNF4 have been described (reviewed in 12), so it is assumed that all of the HNF4 variants concern alternative splicing events within a single gene region.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, the most recently described of them, HNF47, contains a unique sequence encoding the N-terminal portion of the protein and the 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR), implying that it is transcribed from a separate promoter (15).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	10	We have analyzed the regulatory role of distal sequences upstream of the HNF41 promoter and characterized a 700 bp enhancer conferring high activity and glucocorticoid induction to both a heterologous and the HNF41 promoter.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	11	 We have found LETF binding sites and glucocorticoid-responsive sequences essential for enhancer activity in a 240 bp sub-region.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Our results are in line with the requirement for upstream sequences for tissue-specific activity of the HNF41 promoter (14) and with glucocorticoid induction of HNF41 expression (11,15) and lead us to propose a model of biphasic regulation of this enhancer involved in HNF41 expression during liver development.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	13	Cell lines and culture conditions FGC4 rat hepatoma cells (16) are well differentiated whereas H5 cells (17) are dedifferentiated variants.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Cells were grown in modified Ham s F12 medium (18) containing 5% fetal calf serum.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Human epithelial carcinoma C33 cells (19) were maintained in Dulbecco s modified Eagle s medium containing 7% fetal calf serum.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	16	 All cells were cultured under humidified 7% CO2.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	17	Transient transfections Fragments of the mouse HNF41 5'-region (see Figs 1A and 2A) derived from the SBII2.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	18	Zhong, Yale University, New Haven, CT) were cloned in front of the herpes simplex virus thymidine kinase (tk) promoter driving transcription of the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase gene (CAT) in pBLCAT5 (20).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The 700 bp enhancer was cloned in  to 34pZLUC (14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	20	8pZLUC is described in Zhong et al.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Constructs with the 700 bp enhancer and its sub-regions were checked by DNA sequencing.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Standard transfections were performed by the calcium phosphate procedure as previously described (21) using 5  microg each of reporter plasmid and internal control plasmid RSVlacZ.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Cells were harvested 64 h later.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Where indicated, 1  microM dexamethasone (Dex) was added 48 h before harvest.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	26	165  microg each and pBluescript plasmid was added to 3.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	28	2 kV), using 5  microg each of test and control plasmid.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	57	  DNase I footprinting and electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) Nuclear protein extracts from FGC4 and H5 cells, treated or not with Dex (1  microM) for 2 days, and from rat liver were prepared as described previously (27) except that (NH4)2SO4 precipitation and dialysis were omitted.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Protein concentrations were measured with the Bio-Rad protein assay.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Purified recombinant truncated rat HNF1 (HNt) and rat HNF41 were kind gifts of C.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	60	Cheret (Institut Pasteur, Paris, France) and F.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	61	Ringeisen (Institut Pasteur), respectively.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The DNase I footprinting assay was performed essentially as described previously (28), except that the binding reaction contained 85 mM NaCl and 10 mM KCl.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Proteins were incubated with labeled DNA probe (1 ng) in 12  microl for 1 h on ice before adding DNase I.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Products were analyzed on 6% polyacrylamide to 7 M urea gels.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	65	EMSA was carried out as described previously (27), with 50 mM NaCl added to the reaction mix.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Binding reactions were performed with 10  microg of nuclear protein extracted from FGC4 or H5 and 0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	67	4 ng of labeled oligonucleotide.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides used contained HNF41 upstream sequences binding to HNF1 (oligo BS1, 5'-GCAAACTCATGCCCAGTTAATTTTTTAAAGCAAGACCAACAGGCTC) or protected in DNase I footprinting experiments as well as binding sites of HNF1 in the rat albumin promoter (PE56; 27), HNF3/HNF6 in the mouse transthyretin promoter, from  to 85 to  to 110 (TTR; 29 to 31), HNF3/Oct-1 and HNF6 in the 6-phosphofructo-2-kinase promoter (PFK-III and PFK-IV, respectively; 32), Oct-1 in the mouse light chain gene promoter (Oct-Ig; 32), HNF4 in the human apolipoprotein CIII promoter, from  to 67 to  to 92 (ApoCIII; 33), and in the rat (34) and mouse (35) HNF1 promoter (H1H4, 5'-GATCGGCTGAAGTCCAAAGTTCAGTCC), C/EBP in the rat albumin promoter, from  to 86 to  to 109 (DEI; 28), and of the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) in the rat tyrosine aminotransferase gene, from  to 2491 to  to 2510 (GRE; 36).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	69	 A double-stranded oligonucleotide (oligo BS1m) containing four point mutations in the HNF1 consensus site of oligoBS1 as described in the mutant PE DS 34 of PE 56 (27) was also used.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	70	 In competition experiments, 20 ng of non-labeled double-stranded oligonucleotide was added to the reaction mix except as otherwise stated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	71	 A C/EBP-specific antibody (sc-61 X; Santa Cruz Biotechnology) and an antibody raised against the N-terminus of rat HNF41 (a kind gift of F.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	72	Sladek, University of California, Riverside, CA; 37) were used.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	73	Site-directed mutagenesis Site-directed mutagenesis of the B1E5B2 reporter was performed using the QuickChange kit (Stratagene).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	74	 All isolated clones were analyzed by DNA sequencing.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	75	 We introduced a clustered point mutation (38) (mutant F1m1, 5'-GGAGAGGCCAATGGCCTCGAAGCTTCCCCAGGAGGCCTCCTGCCC) or two point mutations (mutant F1m2, 5'-GGCCAATGGCCTCTAGAATAACCCAGGAGGCC) at the C/EBP consensus site in F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The HNF1 binding site BS1 was mutated using oligo BS1m.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Clustered point mutations according to the mutation of the HNF3 binding site in the TTR promoter (29) were introduced at a HNF3 consensus site in F3 (mutant F3mH3, 5'-GCTGCCTTTATCTCCCTGTGGTAAAGATCTGAATATACTCAGGCCCTGGAGCAGGGC).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Three point mutations were introduced at the center of a HNF4 consensus site (12) in F2 (mutant F2mH4, 5'-GCTGTTGACTCTTGAGCTCCGTCTTCCCTCCGGAGG).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	79	Since we had observed that transcription of the endogenous HNF4 gene of rat hepatoma cells is induced by Dex treatment (data not shown), each of the fragments was tested for Dex inducibility (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Dex induction was observed only in FGC4 (2 to 3-fold) and not in H5 cells and, with one exception, it was found only for the most active fragments.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The only fragment with low basal activity that showed inducibility was B1E4, which covers HS V (13).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	82	 This fragment has not yet been studied further.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	83	To test whether the 700 bp enhancer can act on the homologous promoter, we cloned it in front of the  to 34/+182 HNF41 sequence in plasmid  to 34pZLUC (14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The 5' deletion to  to 34 retained non-tissue-specific promoter activity (14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	85	 1C) the 700 bp enhancer, whatever its orientation, increased the activity of  to 34pZLUC 5-fold, while the relative activity of  to 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	86	 This last plasmid contains the 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Moreover, Dex treatment increased the activity of the 700/ to 34pZLUC constructs 2-fold, which accounts totally for the Dex induction of  to 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	88	A 240 bp region is sufficient for enhancer activity and Dex inducibility and is transactivated by HNF1 and HNF41 Deletions were performed in the 700 bp enhancer to delineate the sequences that are critical for basal and inducible expression (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Concerning the 5' and 3' deletions, in BspEI and B1E5A2 basal activity was strongly reduced compared to that of the 700 bp enhancer and hormone inducibility was abolished.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The sequences deleted between HpaI and DraI had a negative effect on both basal and induced activity because their loss led to increased activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Further deletion from DraI to AvaI caused a strong decline in both basal and hormone-induced activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	92	 An internal deletion, (BspEI to StuI), also strongly reduced both basal and induced activities compared to the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Therefore, three adjacent blocks of sequence lying between the PvuII and DraI sites are important for full basal and hormone-induced activity of the 700 bp enhancer, with the most 5' one (PvuII to BspEI) being the most critical for the Dex response.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Analysis of two central fragments, PvuII to DraI and BspEI to DraI, confirmed that an element required for hormone response is located between the PvuII and BspEI sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	95	 None of the fragments shown in Figure 2A exhibited strong enhancer activity in dedifferentiated H5 cells in the absence or presence of Dex (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	96	Because it is known that the HNF4 gene is subject to cross-regulation by HNF1 and to auto-regulation (24,39 to 42), several of the fragments were tested for transactivation by HNF1 and HNF41.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The 700 bp enhancer is transactivated by both factors in H5 (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	98	 2A) and C33 (data not shown) cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Analysis of deleted constructs in H5 cells (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	100	 2A) shows that the HNF4 response element is located between the PvuII and BspEI sites and the HNF1 element between the AvaI and DraI sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In addition, in H5 cells the 700 bp enhancer is transactivated similarly by HNF41 and HNF47 and less efficiently by HNF1ss than HNF1 (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	102	In conclusion, these results show that the 700 bp enhancer is transactivated by HNF41, HNF47, HNF1 and HNF1ss.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Furthermore, the 240 bp PvuII to DraI sequence contains HNF4 and HNF1 response elements and acts as a cell-specific enhancer whose activity is increased by glucocorticoids.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	104	Hepatoma cell nuclear proteins bind to the 240 bp enhancer DNase I footprint experiments were performed to search for binding sites of nuclear proteins in the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Figure 3A shows four footprints (F1 to F4), revealed with nuclear extract from FGC4 and H5 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Due to the location of F1 very close to the labeled end of the probe, its 3'-limit is not clearly visible.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	107	 However, using a probe labeled further downstream on the same strand we precisely located the 3'-end of F1 (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	108	 There is a surprising similarity between the footprints obtained with the two extracts.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	109	 3A and data not shown) the H5 extract is clearly less active than that of FGC4 and for F2 a greater protection by FGC4 extract is evident only at the 3'-extremity of the footprint.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	110	 As only F1 to F3 lie within the 240 bp enhancer region characterized above (see Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	111	 3C), we mapped these three footprints on the opposite strand using FGC4 extract (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The autoradiogram shows F2 and F3 at higher resolution.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	113	 In addition, Figure 3A and B shows F1 as a particularly strong footprint on both strands.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Positions and sequences of F1 to F3 are given in Figure 3C and D, along with sequences of the oligonucleotides used in the EMSA.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	115	View larger version (31K):    Figure 3.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Oligonucleotides used for further analysis are underlined.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	127	  In F1 a C/EBP binding site is essential for basal enhancer activity and overlaps with Dex-responsive sequences EMSA were performed with nuclear extracts from FGC4 and H5 cells treated or not with Dex and an oligonucleotide containing F1 (oligo F1) (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In FGC4 extracts a complex pattern of six bands was observed, two of which (designated 1 and 3) were restricted to these extracts.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The H5 extract showed strong bands corresponding to complexes 2 and 4 only after Dex treatment (even though Dex inducibility was restricted to FGC4 cells), while hormone treatment did not change the pattern in FGC4.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Interestingly, three of the six bands observed in FGC4 were strongly represented in liver extract (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Moreover, complexes 1 and 3 appeared common between liver and FGC4.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	132	 In competition experiments oligos F1 and DEI, containing the C/EBP site of the albumin promoter, displaced the bands in the three types of extracts (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	133	 In contrast, binding sites for the other LETF or GR did not compete (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Therefore, C/EBP family proteins bind to F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	135	 In agreement with this, a sequence homologous to the C/EBP binding site consensus (43) was found in the center of F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The two bands specific to FGC4 and liver extracts were shown to contain C/EBP by supershift assays: a specific antibody displaced only bands 1 and 3 in FGC4 and liver extracts and had no effect in the H5 extract (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Consequently, we conclude that C/EBP binds to F1 in FGC4 cells and the liver but not in H5 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	138	View larger version (70K):    Figure 4.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	139	 C/EBP binds to F1 in FGC4 cells and rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	140	 (A) Nuclear extracts from cells treated or not with Dex were incubated with labeled oligo F1 in EMSA as indicated.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	144	 (C) EMSA of labeled oligo F1 and FGC4 nuclear proteins without (minus) or with competitor oligo F1 or oligonucleotides containing binding sites for HNF1 (PE56), HNF4 (ApoCIII and H1H4), C/EBP (DEI) and GR (GRE).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	145	 (D) EMSA with labeled oligo F1, FGC4 and H5 nuclear extracts and increasing amounts of anti-C/EBP antibody.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Antibody (1 to 3  microl, undiluted or 10-fold diluted) was preincubated with nuclear extracts as indicated for 10 min at room temperature, then reactions were completed and incubated for 30 min on ice.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Cells were treated with Dex to observe complexes 2 and 4 in H5 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Complexes 1 and 3 were supershifted by the antibody (arrowhead).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	149	  To determine whether C/EBP plays a role in enhancer activity, critical bases were mutated in the C/EBP consensus site (38) in the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The activity of the mutant reporter plasmid (F1m1) was then tested in FGC4 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The mutant showed a low basal activity, reduced 6-fold compared to the wild-type (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In addition, Dex inducibility was entirely destroyed by the mutation (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The mutant sequence failed to bind proteins of FGC4 or H5 extracts, as shown by EMSA and DNase I footprint experiments (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	154	 However, three of the seven mutated nucleotides in the F1m1 mutant belong to a glucocorticoid response element half-site (half-GRE) consensus overlapping with the C/EBP consensus (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Consequently, the mutation could impair binding of GR linked to the hormone.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	156	 We then performed two point mutations in the C/EBP consensus site that do not affect the half-GRE consensus but impair C/EBP binding as analyzed by competition experiments in EMSA (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	157	 This mutation diminished basal activity (mutant F1m2, Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	158	 5A, left) but caused only a weak inhibition of the Dex effect (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	159	 We conclude that the C/EBP binding site is required for full basal enhancer activity and overlaps with a half-GRE consensus site involved in hormone inducibility.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	160	 These data indicate that C/EBP is involved in enhancer activity in FGC4 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (18K):    Figure 5.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The C/EBP site is required for full enhancer activity and functional GRE consensus sites overlap with the C/EBP, HNF4 and HNF3 sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	163	 (A) (Left) FGC4 cells were transfected with B1E5B2 reporter plasmids, either wild-type or bearing two different mutations in the C/EBP binding site of F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	164	 An overlapping half-GRE consensus site is affected by mutation in the F1m1 but not in the F1m2 mutant.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Activity is expressed relative to B1E5B2.
