0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	172	 In both the F2mH4 and F3mH3 mutants GRE consensus sites are affected.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	173	 For the F3mH3 mutant, the mean  plus or minus  SD of two independent experiments is shown.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	174	  F2 and F3 contain HNF4 and HNF3 binding sites, respectively, both overlapping with Dex-responsive sequences An oligonucleotide spanning the more protected part of F2 (oligo F2) was used in EMSA with FGC4 extract.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Competition experiments suggested that F2 binds HNF4 weakly (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	176	 To confirm that HNF4 binds to F2, we used purified recombinant rat HNF41 and labeled oligo F2 in EMSA.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Figure 6A shows a complex which was displaced by unlabeled ApoCIII and oligo F2 but not by unlabeled HNF1 site PE56.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Moreover, antibody against rat HNF41 supershifted nearly all the complex (compare lanes anti-HNF4 + and  to ).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	179	 This figure also shows that oligo F2 binds HNF41 with an efficiency  > 60-fold lower than ApoCIII.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	180	View larger version (47K):    Figure 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Recombinant HNF41 binds to F2 (A) and HNF3 to F3 (B).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	182	 (A) Labeled oligo F2 and recombinant rat HNF41 (0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	183	7  microg) were incubated without (minus) or with (plus) an anti-HNF41 antibody and without (minus) or with competitor oligonucleotides.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The first lane shows migration without protein.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	185	 For the reaction with the antibody and the control, 1  microl of 10-fold diluted antibody in PBS (plus) or PBS alone (minus) was added to reaction mix that had been preincubated for 15 min on ice.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Incubations were carried out for 25 min at room temperature.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Other reactions were incubated on ice for 30 min.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The arrowhead designates the ternary complex antibody to HNF4 to DNA.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Oligonucleotide amounts are given in nanograms.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Protein to DNA complexes are indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	191	 (B) Labeled oligo F3 was incubated without (minus) or with FGC4 nuclear extract and competitor oligonucleotides.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	192	 TTR and PFK-III contain binding sites for HNF3 and HNF6 and for HNF3 and Oct-1, respectively, whereas PFK-IV and Oct-Ig bind HNF6 and Oct-1, respectively.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	193	  EMSA was carried out with FGC4 extract and an oligonucleotide containing F3 (oligo F3).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	194	 One complex formed, which was competed by oligo F3 and by oligos TTR and PFK-III, containing HNF3/HNF6 (30,31) and HNF3/Oct-1 (32) binding sites, respectively (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	195	 6B, left), but not by oligos PFK-IV and Oct-Ig (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	196	 6B, right), binding to HNF6 and Oct-1, respectively (32).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	197	 This shows that HNF3 binds to F3.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In support of a functional role of HNF3 binding, HNF3 transactivates the 700 bp enhancer in co-transfection experiments in C33 cells (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	199	HNF4 and HNF3 consensus sites were found in oligos F2 and F3, respectively.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	200	 To examine the functional roles of these sites, we introduced point mutations in each of them in the 700 bp enhancer and tested the resulting plasmids for basal and Dex-induced activity in FGC4 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	201	 5B) caused a slight reduction in basal activity (left) and a significant reduction in inducibility (right).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	202	 A slight reduction in inducibility was obtained for the HNF3 mutation in F3 while the basal activity was not affected (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	203	 However, these mutations reduced but did not abolish HNF41 and HNF3 binding as analyzed by competition experiments in EMSA (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Furthermore, the HNF4 consensus site is included in a GRE consensus site which is affected by the HNF4 mutation while the HNF3 mutation touches a half-GRE consensus site.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	205	 These data show that GRE consensus sites intermingled with the LETF sites are required for maximal Dex inducibility of the 700 bp enhancer, as is the case for the C/EBP site in F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	206	A functional HNF1 binding site is essential for basal enhancer activity The 700 and 240 bp enhancers are similarly transactivated by HNF1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	207	 A computer search for putative HNF1 binding sites in the 700 bp sequence using a weighted matrix (44) revealed three sites with high scores.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The most upstream contains the DraI site and the three last bases of the consensus (15 bp) were replaced by vector sequence in cloned fragments cut by DraI.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The second HNF1 site is located a few base pairs downstream of the DraI site and the third lies 70 bp further downstream (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In DNase I footprinting experiments using purified recombinant truncated HNF1 protein (HNt) we demonstrated that the two most upstream consensus sites correspond to authentic HNF1 binding sites (BS1 and BS2, respectively; data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Then we tested the recombinant HNF1 protein by EMSA using double-stranded oligonucleotides containing BS1, wild-type (oligo BS1) or mutated (oligo BS1m) in order to abolish HNF1 binding (27).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	212	 A complex between HNt and labeled oligo BS1 formed which was competed by PE56 and oligo BS1, but not by oligo BS1m (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	213	 From these experiments we conclude that BS1 binds HNF1, but with an efficiency  > 16-fold lower than the high affinity PE56 oligonucleotide.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	214	 In the constructs 3' deleted at the DraI site, modified BS1 still binds to HNt but with a lower affinity (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	215	 In EMSA using FGC4 extracts the third consensus (BS3) proved also to bind HNF1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	216	View larger version (33K):    Figure 7.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Recombinant HNF1 binds to a site at the 3'-end of the 240 bp enhancer (A) and this site is required for HNF1 transactivation (B) and full enhancer activity (C).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	218	 (A) Purified recombinant truncated rat HNF1 was used at 0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	219	5  microg in EMSA with the labeled oligo BS1 in the absence or presence of increasing amounts (indicated in ng) of competitor oligo PE56, BS1 or BS1m (mutated in BS1).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	220	 (B) CAT activity of reporter plasmid B1E5B2, wild-type or mutated in BS1 (BS1m*, see text), in H5 co-transfected with HNF1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	221	 For the mutant reporter, the mean  plus or minus  SD of three independent experiments is shown.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Expression vector amounts are indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	223	 (C) CAT activity in FGC4 of reporter plasmid B1E5B2, wild-type or mutated in BS1 (BS1m* or BS1m).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The mean  plus or minus  SD of two independent experiments is shown.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	225	  To investigate whether BS1 could mediate transactivation by HNF1 we used oligo BS1m to mutate BS1 in the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	226	 We obtained two mutant reporter plasmids of which one (BS1m*) contains an insertion of two G residues within BS1 in addition to the expected mutation.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	227	 As shown in Figure 7B, in H5 cells this mutant plasmid exhibited the same low basal activity as the B1E5B2 reporter plasmid but transactivation by co-transfected HNF1 was severely compromised, in spite of the continued presence of intact BS2 and BS3 sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Moreover, activity of both mutant plasmids in FGC4 was strongly and similarly reduced compared to the wild-type (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	229	 These results thus show that BS1 is required not only for transactivation by HNF1, but also for enhancer activity of the 700 bp region in differentiated hepatoma cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	230	In summary, we have characterized several LETF binding sites (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	231	 8A) within the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	232	 C/EBP, HNF4 and HNF3 binding sites are located in the 240 bp minimal enhancer, PvuII to DraI, whereas an HNF1 binding site overlaps its 3'-end and two other HNF1 binding sites lie further downstream.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The C/EBP site and the first (BS1) HNF1 site are required for full basal activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Several imperfect whole and half-GRE consensus sites were found in the minimal enhancer (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Three of them, overlapping with LETF sites, are crucial for maximal hormone inducibility of the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	236	View larger version (14K):    Figure 8.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Overview of the  to 6 kb enhancer (A) and a model for HNF41 regulation (B).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	238	 (A) A restriction map is shown (P, PvuII; B, BspEI; A, AvaI; D, DraI; H, HpaI).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Positions of three imperfect whole and five imperfect half-GRE consensus sites in the minimal enhancer are indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Protein binding sites characterized using DNase I footprinting assay and EMSA with FGC4 nuclear extract or purified recombinant proteins are represented.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Footprints F1 to F3, HNF1 binding sites and LETF binding to the sites are indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	242	 (B) Schematic representation showing a model of the factors that are expressed and could bind to the HNF41  to 6 kb enhancer and promoter (14) regions, resulting in low expression during early liver development and a strong up-regulation at birth.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	243	The 700 bp enhancer contains a 240 bp core sequence sufficient for both enhancer activity and Dex induction and within which three footprints (F1 to F3) have been identified.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	244	 C/EBP binds to F1, HNF4 to F2 and HNF3 to F3.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Finally, a functional HNF1 binding site is at the 3'-end of the core sequence.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Figure 8A summarizes these data.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The sequence comprising the minimal enhancer is conserved.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Blast analysis of the mouse and human (NCBI database accession no.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	249	 AL117382) sequences showed an overall 86% identity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The F1 to F3 and HNF1 sites exhibit the highest scores (90 to 100%).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	251	 This fact implies that the HNF41 enhancer is an important element that plays a similar role in humans.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	252	The C/EBP site is the strongest footprint in the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Its mutation significantly reduces enhancer activity but only in cells that produce C/EBP, implying that this site responds specifically to binding of C/EBP.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Previously we proposed that HNF4 regulates its own expression based on studies of stable transfectants (24,42).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Our data here support such a direct auto-regulation mechanism because the enhancer core sequence contains a functional HNF4 response element.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	256	 In addition, HNF3 transactivates the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	257	 However, while mutation of the HNF4 and HNF3 sites had only small effects, the introduced mutations impaired binding of the factors only partially.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The HNF41 enhancer is strongly transactivated by HNF1 and more weakly by HNF1ss.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Transactivation by HNF1 is mediated by a weak HNF1 binding site, which is also required for high basal activity of the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	260	 A similar functional role of weak HNF1 binding sites has been reported for the mouse phenylalanine hydroxylase gene enhancer (21).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	261	 A functional HNF1 binding site in the HNF41 enhancer, in addition to the site described earlier in the promoter region (14), accords with earlier reports of cross-regulation between HNF4 and HNF1 (39 to 42).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Based on the strong response to HNF1, we propose that this factor plays a critical role in enhancer activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	263	In agreement with our observations, glucocorticoids have been shown to activate HNF4 expression in primary cultured rat hepatocytes (11).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Moreover, HNF41, but not HNF47, is induced by glucocorticoids in murine hepatic cells (15).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Maximal Dex induction of the enhancer requires the F1 to F3 region where three imperfect GRE and five imperfect half-GRE consensus sites were found, some overlapping with the F1 to F3 footprints (see Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Although competition EMSAs using GRE failed to provide evidence for binding of GR, the presence of GRE consensus sites and responsiveness to Dex imply that GR binds to the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Indeed, mutations introduced into LETF binding sites that affect GRE whole sites or half-sites compromised Dex induction, implying that these sites are functional.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Moreover, induction of the 700 bp enhancer was restricted to differentiated hepatoma cells, implying that a liver-specific protein(s) is required for the glucocorticoid effect.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Indeed, the LETF can synergize with GR to achieve glucocorticoid induction of the tyrosine aminotransferase (TAT) (45 to 47) and the phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) genes (48).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	270	 A similar situation appears to exist for the HNF41 enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	271	At first sight, it is surprising to observe that the major transactivators for the HNF41 enhancer are hormone-activated GR and LETF that are expressed late in development, such as C/EBP and HNF1, even though it is known that HNF4 transcripts are first detected very early (2).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	272	 However, probes that do not distinguish between the HNF41 and HNF47 isoforms were used for analysis of early embryos.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Recent work from our laboratory has revealed that expression of the HNF41 isoform is strong in the liver only at the end of fetal life and at birth, whereas the HNF47 isoform is the predominant form of HNF4 in embryonic liver (M.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	274	Weiss, submitted for publication).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The dramatic activation of HNF41 that occurs just before birth could be assured, on the one hand, by C/EBP, whose expression is also activated at birth (49), and, on the other, by glucocorticoids.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Indeed, the TAT and PEPCK genes, which like HNF41 have enhancers in which glucocorticoid hormone response modules overlap LETF sites (46 to 48), are strongly induced by glucocorticoids at birth.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	277	HNF41 is thus expressed at low levels in embryonic liver.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Binding sites in the HNF41 enhancer do include transcription factors that are present in the developing liver.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	279	 HNF3 and ss are among the first LETF to be expressed in this tissue (50).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	280	 HNF1ss, known to be expressed before HNF1 in the embryonic liver (4,5), is a transactivator of the enhancer, as is HNF47.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	281	Although many studies have contributed to the notion that the group of LETF is subject to cross-regulation and to auto-regulation (4,5,8,9,14,24,30,31,34,35,39 to 42,51 to 63), this is the first detailed study of an enhancer regulating expression of one of these factors.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Furthermore, this analysis concerns one of the first of these factors to be expressed, HNF4 (2).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The results of this study are entirely consistent with the observed behavior of the HNF4 gene in vivo and provide a basis to explain its expression pattern.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Indeed, binding sites for essentially all of the LETF so far identified are present, including factors expressed early during development, such as HNF3 and ss, HNF1ss and HNF47, and others that are expressed a little later, such as HNF1, and in particular those that are up-regulated at birth, including C/EBP, HNF41 and, perhaps most importantly, activated GR.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Consequently, the properties of the  to 6 kb enhancer are consistent with it being involved both in the initiation of expression of HNF41 and in its maintenance.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Figure 8B presents our model of biphasic regulation of the HNF41 enhancer during liver development.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	351	 (1998) Hepatocyte nuclear factor 6: organization and chromosomal assignment of the rat gene and characterization of its promoter.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	352	 (2000) CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein- is a component of the growth hormone-regulated network of liver transcription factors.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Endocrinology, 141, 1686 to 1692.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	354	 (1997) The cut-homeodomain transcriptional activator HNF-6 is coexpressed with its target gene HNF-3ss in the developing murine liver and pancreas.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	355	 (1999) C/EBP regulates generation of C/EBPss isoforms through activation of specific proteolytic cleavage.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	356	 (1993) Elements and factors involved in tissue-specific and embryonic expression of the liver transcription factor LFB1 in Xenopus laevis.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	0	Twin Hydroxymethyluracil-A Base Pair Steps Define the Binding Site for the DNA-bending Protein TF1*.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	1	(Received for publication, February 12, 1997).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Figueiredo  , Aldo Galeone  , Luciano Mayol   and E.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	3	The DNA-bending protein TF1 is the Bacillus subtilis bacteriophage SPO1-encoded homolog of the bacterial HU proteins and the Escherichia coli integration host factor.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	4	 We recently proposed that TF1, which binds with high affinity (Kd was ~3 nM) to preferred sites within the hydroxymethyluracil (hmU)-containing phage genome, identifies its binding sites based on sequence-dependent DNA flexibility.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Here, we show that two hmU-A base pair steps coinciding with two previously proposed sites of DNA distortion are critical for complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The affinity of TF1 is reduced 10-fold when both of these hmU-A base pair steps are replaced with A-hmU, G-C, or C-G steps; only modest changes in affinity result when substitutions are made at other base pairs of the TF1 binding site.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Replacement of all hmU residues with thymine decreases the affinity of TF1 greatly; remarkably, the high affinity is restored when the two hmU-A base pair steps corresponding to previously suggested sites of distortion are reintroduced into otherwise T-containing DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	8	 T-DNA constructs with 3-base bulges spaced apart by 9 base pairs of duplex also generate nM affinity of TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	9	 We suggest that twin hmU-A base pair steps located at the proposed sites of distortion are key to target site selection by TF1 and that recognition is based largely, if not entirely, on sequence-dependent DNA flexibility.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	10	The genome of the Bacillus subtilis bacteriophage SPO1 contains 5-hydroxymethyluracil (hmU)1 in place of thymine, and discrimination between T- and hmU-containing DNA is important during phage multiplication (1, 2).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	11	 For one phage-encoded protein, the DNA-binding and -bending protein TF1, this discrimination is essentially absolute: the high affinity of TF1 (Kd order of magnitude nM) for preferred sites within the hmU-containing phage genome is greatly reduced for the corresponding T-containing DNA (3, 4).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	12	 We recently showed that the affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA is matched in T-containing DNA constructs that contain sets of two consecutive mismatches separated by 9 bp of duplex, indicating that hmU-content and appropriately placed flexible loops contribute similarly to complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	13	 We proposed, therefore, that DNA in a complex with TF1 is distorted at two sites that are separated by 9 bp of duplex DNA, sites corresponding to two hmU-A base pair steps, and that TF1 identifies its target sites through recognition of sequence-dependent DNA flexibility (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Here we examine the requirement for hmU residues across a 37-mer DNA duplex representing a preferred binding site within the phage genome (4) and specifically evaluate sequence requirements at the two inferred sites of DNA distortion.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	15	TF1 was overexpressed in Escherichia coli DL39 (6) and purified as described (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Oligonucleotides with hmU content were synthesized as described (7) and purified by high pressure liquid chromatography.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	17	 T-containing oligonucleotides were purchased and purified by denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The top strand (shared among bulge constructs) was 32P-labeled at the 5-end with T4 polynucleotide kinase.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Complementary oligonucleotides were mixed at equimolar concentrations, heated to 90  degrees C, and slowly cooled to 4  degrees C over several hours to form duplex DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	20	Electrophoretic mobility shift experiments were carried out as described (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Experiments with perfect duplex hmU- or hybrid T/hmU-DNA were done at room temperature unless noted otherwise.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Experiments with bulge constructs were performed at 4  degrees C to prevent dissociation of duplexes.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	23	 After electrophoresis, gels were dried and protein-DNA complexes were quantified using phosphorimaging.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	24	 DNA migrating between bands corresponding to free and complexed DNA was considered as free DNA (5) in calculating equilibrium dissociation constants (Kd) (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Values of Kd are reported as the average of at least three experiments  plus or minus  S.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	26	 (for closely related DNA constructs yielding suboptimal complex formation, triplicate determinations were deemed unnecessary).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	27	The sequence of a 37-mer DNA construct corresponding to a preferred binding site within the phage SPO1 genome (4) is shown in Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Because of the ability of TF1 to form nested complexes on longer DNA fragments, the length of the DNA constructs was chosen to accommodate only one TF1 dimer (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The affinity of TF1 for the 37-mer hmU-containing duplex (Kd was ~3 nM; Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	30	 1A) was reduced 10-fold upon replacement of the two hmU-A base pair steps corresponding to the potential sites of distortion with A-hmU, G-C, or C-G steps (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Altering the sequence at the center of the binding site (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	32	 1 and 2, panels C) or on the flanks, distal to the proposed sites of bending (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	33	 1 and 2, panels D), did not significantly affect complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The observed sequence specificity at proposed sites of distortion is consistent with a direct participation of hmU-A base pair steps in complex formation and DNA bending.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Sequences of 37-mer oligonucleotides.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	36	 A, the sequence of the top strand corresponding to a preferred binding site within the SPO1 genome is shown, with hmU-A base pair steps that correspond to proposed sites of distortion in boldface.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	37	 B, a 10-fold reduction in affinity is associated with replacement of target hmU-A steps.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	38	 C and D, sequences of oligonucleotides with substitutions between (C) or distal to (D) hmU-A base pair steps (substitutions are underlined).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Substitutions on the flanks target additional hmU-A base pair steps; additional substitutions were required to prevent introduction of new hmU-A steps.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Top strands shown were annealed to complementary hmU-containing bottom strands to generate perfect duplexes.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Dissociation constants, Kd nM, are shown at the right.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	42	 [View Larger Version of this Image (36K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Electrophoretic analysis of hmU-DNA titrated with TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The affinity of TF1 for the 37-mer duplex corresponding to a preferred binding site (panel A) is reduced upon replacement of hmU-A base pair steps with A-hmU (panel B).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Altering the central base pairs (GC-rich; panel C) or the sequence distal to proposed sites of DNA distortion (wild-type (wt) + GC; panel D) has little effect on complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Protein concentrations indicated below panel D are identical for all panels.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	47	 [View Larger Version of this Image (109K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	48	To evaluate the contribution of hmU residues to the DNA binding affinity of TF1, DNA constructs were designed in which central hmU-containing blocks of 13 or 11 bp, encompassing the proposed sites of DNA distortion (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	49	 3, constructs Th2 and Th3), or of 9 or 7 bp, excluding hmU-A steps that are candidate sites of specific distortion (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	50	 3, constructs Th4 and Th5), were embedded in T-containing surrounding sequence.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Constructs in which the proposed sites of distortion lie within the hmU-containing blocks (Th2 and Th3) yielded Kd = 5-6 nM compared with 3 nM for all-hmU-DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	52	 A more than 5-fold reduction in affinity was observed for DNA with shorter hmU-containing blocks (Th4 and Th5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	53	 A DNA duplex in which a central 13-bp T-containing block is flanked by hmU-containing sequence (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	54	 3, construct Th1) bound TF1 with 10-fold lower affinity relative to all-hmU-DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	55	 DNA duplexes with T or hmU content.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Blocks of hmU content are underlined.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	57	 DNA constructs are named at the left, and dissociation constants, Kd nM, are shown at the right.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The symbol  denotes complex dissociation during electrophoresis that is too rapid to allow a reliable determination.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	59	 [View Larger Version of this Image (63K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	60	For DNA with 2 4-bp hmU-containing blocks, a significantly lower affinity was observed for DNA constructs with T-A base pair steps at the proposed sites of bending (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	61	 3, constructs Th8 and Th9) than for otherwise identical constructs with hmU-A base pair steps (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	62	 3, constructs Th6 and Th7; Kd was ~5 nM).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Remarkably, TF1 was found to have essentially undiminished affinity for DNA in which the two hmU-A base pair steps are completely surrounded by T-containing DNA (Kd = 4 nM; Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	64	 We note also that the affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA and for the Th7/Th6 construct was the same at room temperature and at 4  degrees C (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	65	 A 7-10-fold reduction in affinity was observed if only one strand contained the requisite hmU-A sequence (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	66	 3, constructs Th7/T and T/Th6, and Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Our interpretation of these observations is that hmU content affords an increased flexibility that is recognized by TF1 and that hmU-A base pair steps symmetrically disposed about the center of the binding site are targets for specific distortion in the protein-DNA complex.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Twin hmU-A base pair steps corresponding to presumptive sites of distortion are required for complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA (A) is reproduced by a DNA construct in which target hmU-A base pair steps are surrounded by T-DNA (Th7/6 in B).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Constructs in which only one strand contains the hmU-A sequence have 10-fold lower affinity (Th7/T in C).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	71	 [View Larger Version of this Image (113K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The nM affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA is reproduced by T-DNA with base bulges separated by 9 bp of duplex.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The affinity of TF1 for perfect duplex hmU-DNA is reproduced by T-DNA with a set of 4-nt loops (A).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	74	 1- or 2-base bulges (lowercase c, underlined) in combination with a mismatch reproduce the nM affinity for TF1 (B), as do 2- or 3-base bulges (C).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	75	 , the same as in the legend to Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	76	 All experiments were carried out at 4  degrees C.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	77	 [View Larger Version of this Image (33K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	78	The high affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA (Kd was ~3 nM) was reproduced in T-DNA that contains two appropriately positioned flexible sites generated by sets of tandem mismatches (Ref.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Improved complex formation relative to perfect duplex T-DNA would also be expected for T-DNA constructs in which the energetic cost of bending is lessened through the incorporation of bulge-loops, i.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	80	 with nucleotides that are formally unopposed on the complementary strand (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Constructs with sets of 1- or 2-nt bulges combined with one mismatched base pair positioned 9 bp apart indeed generated high affinity for TF1 (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	82	 5B); note that sets of 2-nt loops (one mismatch) generated suboptimal binding compared with sets of 4-nt loops (two consecutive mismatches).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The high affinity of TF1 was fully restored for DNA constructs with sets of 2- or 3-nt bulges with suboptimal binding for DNA with a pair of 1-nt bulges (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Replacing the T-containing top strand of bulge constructs with the corresponding hmU-containing strand did not affect complex formation (data not shown).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Bulge-loops are considered to generate directed kinks in the helix axis (8, 9).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Consistent with the presence of such kinks, we observed a reduction in electrophoretic mobility of bulged DNA constructs, the magnitude of which depended on the size of the bulge (data not shown).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The mobility of protein-DNA complexes was similar irrespective of the nature of the DNA construct.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	88	The TF1 double mutant protein TF1 (E15G/T32I) binds DNA with ~40-fold higher affinity than does wild-type TF1 (10) due to interactions outside the central 25-bp region of the binding site (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The presence of bulge-loops in T-DNA affected the affinity of TF1 (E15G/T32I) and wild-type TF1 in similar ways, consistent with unaltered interactions for the mutant protein with a central DNA segment that includes proposed sites of bending (data not shown).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	90	The structure of TF1 reveals the presence of flexible -ribbon arms that are directly involved in DNA binding (11),2 as does the structure of the closely related HU protein (12, 13) and the recently reported structure of integration host factor (IHF) in a complex with DNA (14).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	91	 At the tip of the DNA-binding arms, TF1 contains a Phe residue at position 61 in place of the Arg found in all other members of this protein family.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	92	 TF1(F61R) has reduced preference for hmU-DNA over T-DNA (15) but was seen to retain high affinity for hmU-DNA (Kd = 9.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Substituting Phe-61 with Tyr had little effect on affinity (Kd = 6.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Replacing Phe-61 with a polar, uncharged residue (Ser or Gln) significantly reduces both DNA binding affinity and site-selectivity (15).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Notably, the affinity for hmU-DNA of both TF1(F61S) (Kd = 236  plus or minus  19 nM) and TF1(F61Q) (Kd = 685  plus or minus  48 nM) increased more than 5-fold for T-DNA with 2 3-base bulges (Kd = 36  plus or minus  2 and 90  plus or minus  7 nM, respectively; Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	96	 This is in contrast to wild-type TF1 that bound hmU-DNA and bulge-DNA constructs (1+2, 1+3, 0+2, and 0+3) with approximately the same affinity (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	97	 T-DNA with sets of 4-nt loops, which also reproduces the affinity of wild-type TF1 for hmU-DNA (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	98	 5), did not significantly enhance complex formation by TF1(F61S) (Kd was ~200 nM) or TF1(F61Q) (Kd was ~570 nM) beyond that observed with hmU-DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Apparently hmU content and flexible loops in T-DNA contribute similarly to complex formation for these TF1 mutant proteins, which are deficient in binding and bending of hmU-DNA (15, 16), whereas DNA with a static kink generates an increase in affinity.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	100	Our previous conjecture that TF1 principally identifies its preferred binding sites through recognition of sequence-dependent DNA flexure was based on an analysis of affinities for DNA constructs with sets of 4-nt loops (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	101	 For this mode of target site selection, the prediction would be for the sequence at the sites of distortion to significantly affect complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	102	 This prediction appears to be borne out both in terms of preferred base pair steps in the context of hmU-DNA (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	103	 1 and 2) but particularly by the significant effect of hmU-A base pair steps in a T-containing surrounding sequence (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	104	 We propose that hmU content confers a site-specific flexibility on the DNA duplex that is recognized by TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	105	 hmU-A base pair steps that are situated at presumptive sites of DNA bending make the principal contributions to complex formation with TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	106	 hmU residues at other positions that generate measurable, yet suboptimal affinities, presumably do so either due to longer range effects on DNA flexure or because of alternative placement of TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	107	 An effect of hmU residues on the deformability of the double helix is corroborated by the increased affinity observed for other members of the family of type II DNA-binding proteins, HU and IHF, and for the unrelated eukaryotic protein, HMG1 (17).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Changes in complex formation by both major and minor groove-binding proteins and antibiotics induced by introduction of other modified bases have also been interpreted in terms of effects on DNA deformability by exocyclic substituents (18-20).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	109	Inferences about increased flexure of DNA containing modified bases stress the need for analysis of the associated structures and conformational energetics.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Structural nuclear magnetic resonance analysis of an A-hmU base pair flanked by G-C base pairs indicates no significant deviations from classical B-form DNA (21), although nearest neighbors do influence the structure (22).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	111	 13C or 31P nuclear magnetic resonance relaxation experiments may provide the required insights into the dynamics of duplex DNA the size of a protein binding site, features that are only poorly extractable from measurements using techniques such as fluorescence polarization and DNA cyclization (23, 24).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The suggested locations of DNA bends in the TF1 DNA complex coincide with two hmU-A base pair steps.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Considering the unique properties of the T-A step in terms of diversity of structure (25, 26), it would be of particular interest to determine whether the inherent deformability of the T-A step is accentuated in hmU-A.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	114	For a protein that bends DNA through a large angle (16), it is not surprising to find a greater affinity for DNA whose axis is kinked by unpaired bases (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Indeed, similar results have been previously reported for HU (27).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	116	 We note that T-DNA constructs with pairs of suitably placed 4-nt loops or 3-nt bulge-loops generate the same affinity for wild-type TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, different structures and energetics of deformation are indicated by the significantly higher affinity for bulge constructs of the TF1 mutant proteins TF1(F61S) and TF1(F61Q), which are impaired in DNA binding and bending.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	118	 These observations are consistent with a static kink introduced by bulge-loops compared with a looser more flexible structure imposed by symmetric loops (8, 9, 24, 28); we suggest that pre-bent DNA bulge-loop constructs also permit complex formation with certain TF1 mutant proteins, whereas binding and bending of DNA with sets of 4-nt loops (or hmU content) require a protein-mediated introduction and stabilization of DNA kinks.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	119	Replacement of Phe-61 at the tip of DNA-binding arms with a polar, uncharged residue may render TF1 mutant proteins either incapable of producing specific DNA kinks, a process which would be aided locally by the presence of DNA bulge-loops, or deficient in securing the resulting DNA conformation, demands on which would be lessened in DNA with a predisposed orientation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	120	 If TF1, like IHF, employs a totally conserved Pro residue to intercalate between specific base pairs of the binding site (14), then the deficiency of TF1(F61S) and TF1(F61Q) in DNA binding and bending may reside in their inability to stabilize a severely bent DNA conformation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Phe-61 contributes to the striking preference of TF1 for hmU-DNA over T-DNA (15).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	122	 TF1(F61R) also has high affinity for hmU-DNA but a reduced preference for hmU-DNA over T-DNA (15).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	123	 In addition, IHF (which has higher affinity for a specific binding site in hmU-DNA compared with T-DNA (17)) relies heavily on indirect readout to recognize its binding sites (14).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	124	 If TF1 and IHF engage their DNA targets in an isomorphous fashion, the preference for hmU-DNA characteristic of TF1 may not be due to specific interactions between Phe-61 and hmU residues of the TF1 binding site.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Rather, the inability of TF1 to stabilize a T-DNA duplex that is severely kinked through intercalation of Pro residues may be alleviated by the more pliable hmU-DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	126	 On the other hand, the possibility that TF1 does use Phe-61 directly for inducing DNA kinks at two hmU-A base pair steps remains to be established or disproved by direct structure determination.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	127	 139, 407-422 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Choy, H.

0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	142	 260, 120-125 [CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Diekmann, S.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	143	 84, 8257-8261 [Abstract] Bailly, C.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	144	 253, 1-7 [CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Bailly, C.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	145	 93, 13623-13628 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Mellac, S.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	146	 (1993) Biochemistry 32, 7779-7786 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Pasternack, L.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	147	 24, 2740-2745 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Millar, D.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	148	 76, 2080-2094 [CrossRef] Kahn, J.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	149	 (1994) Nature 368, 163-166 [CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Hunter, C.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	150	 230, 1025-1054 [CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Wolffe, A.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (1997) Frontiers in Molecular Biology, IRL Press, Oxford , in press Pontiggia, A.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	152	 7, 343-350 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Bhattacharyya, A.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	153	 17, 6821-6840 [Abstract]  1997 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	0	 1995 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Expression Screening Reveals an Orphan Receptor Chick Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor I as a Regulator of Neurite/Substrate-Cell Contacts and Cell Aggregation (*).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	2	Henry Connor , Howard Nornes , Toomas Neuman ( ).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	3	A rat homologue of chick ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor I (COUP-TF I) was isolated using an expression cloning method developed to iso-late neurite outgrowth inhibitors.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Overexpression of COUP-TF I in 3T3 fibroblasts resulted in reduction of stable contact formation between neurites and transfected cells.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Additionally, COUP-TF I enhanced retinoic acid response element-dependent reporter gene expression in 3T3 fibroblasts, indicating that COUP-TF I can modulate transcriptional activation in these cells.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Our data suggest that COUP-TF transcription factors are involved in the regulation of cell surface molecules during neurogenesis.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	7	Nuclear hormone receptors, which function as ligand-dependent transcription factors, have a crucial role in establishing initial cellular diversity in the nervous system.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Among the best characterized members of the superfamily of nuclear hormone receptors are the receptors for retinoids, thyroid hormones, steroid hormones, and glucocorticoids, whose importance during neurogenesis is well described (for review, see Beato(1989); Evans and Arriza(1989); McEwen et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Hormone receptors activate or repress gene transcription through binding to cis-acting hormone response elements (HRE)()(Green and Chambon, 1988; Beato, 1989).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Besides the ligand-dependent transcription factors, the hormone receptor superfamily comprises several orphan receptors for which ligands are not known (for review, see Evans(1988) and Green and Chambon(1988)).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Orphan receptors, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF) homologues, have been isolated from Drosophila (Mlodzik et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	12	, 1990), sea urchin (Chan et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1992), zebrafish (Fjose et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	14	, 1993), Xenopus (Matharu and Sweeney, 1992), chick (Lutz et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	15	, 1994), and mammals (Miyajima et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	16	, 1991; Ladias and Karathanasis, 1991).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	17	 One possible function of COUP-TF transcription factors is to regulate the activity of ligand-activated hormone receptors through heterodimer formation or competition for specific response elements (Cooney et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	18	Analyses of nuclear hormone receptors in various systems clearly demonstrate that regulation of gene expression by these transcription factors depends on the presence of different ligands and also on the interactions with activators and repressors.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The role of COUP-TF orphan receptors in neurogenesis is virtually unknown.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In Drosophila, the expression of COUP-TF homologue seven-up is required for development of specific subset of photoreceptor neurons during eye development (Mlodzik et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	21	, 1994), COUP-TFs are expressed in a complex spatial and temporal pattern during development of the nervous system.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	22	The central nervous system of most adult vertebrates is inhibitory to axonal growth.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	23	 During development, inhibitory regions regulate the formation of neuronal pathways and connections (Tosney and Landmesser, 1984; Davies et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Several factors responsible for neurite outgrowth inhibition have been characterized (Caroni and Schwab, 1988; Cox et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	25	, 1990; Raper and Kapfhammer, 1990; Luo et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We developed a screening system for cloning inhibitory molecules after transfection of a cDNA library into ``substrate'' cells, which are subsequently cocultured with neuronal cells and screened for functional expression of neurite outgrowth inhibition.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	27	 This approach allows isolation of cDNAs for surface molecules, which cause direct inhibition of neurite outgrowth, as well as cDNAs for factors involved in regulating the expression of molecules, which inhibit or facilitate neurite outgrowth.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This screening system enabled us to isolate a rat homologue of orphan receptor COUP-TF I, whose overexpression results in decreased contact stability between neurites and substrate cells.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	29	 These data suggest the possible involvement of COUP-TF I in the regulation of neurite contacts and cell aggregation.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	30	Cell Culture Mouse NIH-3T3 fibroblasts and neuroblastoma glioma hybrid NG108-15 (Hamprecht, 1977) cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	31	) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (Sigma).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Neuronal differentiation of NG108-15 cells was achieved by culture in serum-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium for 72 h.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	33	To establish cell lines overexpressing COUP-TF I, cDNA was cloned into the expression vector pRcCMV (Invitrogen) using HindIII linkers and transfected into 3T3 cells followed by selection with G418 (600  microg/ml, Life Technologies, Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	34	Generation of Subtraction cDNA Library Poly(A) RNA was isolated (FastTrack, Invitrogen) from brains and spinal cords of embryonic day 17, postnatal day 5, and adult rats and also from chronically injured spinal cords.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	35	 24  microg of Poly(A) RNA from postnatal day 5, adult, and injured spinal cord (8  microg from each) was used to synthesize first strand cDNA using oligo(dT) primer with a NotI restriction site at the 5`-end (5`-CTAGATCGCGAGCGGCCGCCCTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT) andSuperScript RNaseH-reverse transcriptase (200 units/ microg of Poly(A) RNA, Life Technologies, Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The first strand synthesis reaction was labeled using [P]dCTP (5  microCi,  > 3000 Ci/mmol, Amersham Corp.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	37	) to facilitate tracing of the DNA.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	38	 First strand cDNA was hybridized to embryonic day 17 poly(A) RNA (200  microg) in sealed ampules (total volume, 100  microl, buffer 0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	39	8, 300 mM NaCl, 2 mM EDTA, and 0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	40	2% SDS) for 18 h at 70  degrees C.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The hybridization mix was diluted to a final molarity of 0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	42	08 M sodium phosphate, loaded onto a DNA grade hydroxylapatite column (4 ml (volume), Bio-Rad), and washed extensively with 0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	43	08 M sodium phosphate buffer (pH 6.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Single-stranded cDNAs were eluted in 10 ml of 0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	45	5 ml) exhibiting radioactivity above background were pooled, and the cDNAs were concentrated by butanol extraction followed by chromatography in STE buffer (100 mM NaCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	46	4, 1 mM EDTA) on a Sephadex G-25 column (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Single-stranded cDNAs were mixed with 100  microg of poly(A) RNA from embryonic day 17 for the second cycle of hybridization.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	48	 After the second cycle, first strand cDNAs were hybridized with 5  microg of the original Poly(A) RNA isolated from postnatal day 5, adult, and injured rats nervous systems, and the resulting DNA/RNA hybrids were used as template for second strand synthesis with RNaseH and Escherichia coli DNA polymerase I (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Blunt ends were created with T4 DNA polymerase, and the HindIII adapter (5`-AGCTTGGCACGAG-3`, 3`-ACCGTGCTC-5`) was ligated to the cDNA.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Longer cDNAs ( > 700 bp) were isolated by digestion with NotI followed by size selection on a Sephacryl S 400 column (Pharmacia) and were subsequently cloned between the HindIII and NotI restriction sites of the expression vector pRcCMV (Invitrogen).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The library was divided into 20 aliquots and used to transform E.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	52	 coli DH5 cells (MAX Efficiency, Life Technologies, Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Each aliquot yielded 5-8 10 colonies, which were combined and grown for large scale plasmid isolation (plasmid maxi kit, Qiagen).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The cDNA expression library has 2 10 independent clones with an average insert size of 1.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	55	Isolation of Cell Clones and cDNA Transfection of the cDNA library into fibroblasts was performed by the calcium phosphate coprecipitation technique using 20  microg of DNA/100-mm tissue culture plates (Falcon) at a cell density of 2 10 cells per plate with an incubation time of 15-16 h.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Each aliquot of the cDNA library (n = 20) was used to transfect cells in 20 plates.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The cDNA library was transfected into NIH-3T3 fibroblast cells.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Selection of transfected cells was performed with 600  microg/ml G418 (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	59	) for 14-21 days prior to testing for neurite outgrowth inhibition.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Screening for neurite outgrowth inhibition involved coculture of transfected fibroblasts with the neuroblastoma-glioma hybrid cell line NG108-15 differentiated for 72 h in serum-free culture medium prior to coculture.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Differentiated NG108-15 cells rapidly established an extensive and robust network of contacts with control NIH-3T3 cells, indicating that fibroblasts provide a good substrate for contact formation.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Inhibitory clones were identified as those that had fewer or no contacts with surrounding neurites.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Inhibitory clones were isolated and propagated.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	64	Genomic DNA was prepared from isolated clones (TurboGen, Invitrogen) and used as a template for amplification of cDNAs by polymerase chain reaction.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Primers for cDNA amplification corresponding to flanking sequences in the pRcCMV vector (5`-primer 5`-AGCTCTCTGGCTAACTAGAGAAC, 3`-primer 5`-AGCGAGCTCTAGCATTTAGGTGA) were prepared, and 35 cycles of polymerase chain reaction were performed using the following conditions: 92  degrees C, 1.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	66	2 min; 58  degrees C, 2 min; and 72  degrees C, 4 min.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Amplified DNAs were cloned into EcoRV site of Bluescript plasmid (Stratagene) for sequencing.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Isolated cDNAs with vector (pRcCMV) sequences were subcloned into pRcCMV expression vector between HindIII and NotI sites and retested for neurite inhibition.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	69	Northern Blot Analyses Total RNA was isolated using acid guanidinium/phenol/chloroform extraction procedure (Chomczynski and Sacchi, 1987).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The RNA (25  microg/lane) was fractionated on 1.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	71	2% agarose-formaldehyde gel and transferred to a nylon membrane (Hybond N, Amersham).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Full-length COUP-TF I was radiolabeled (P) using Multiprime DNA labeling system (Amersham) and used as a probe.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The blots were washed at high stringency (0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	74	2 SSC, 65  degrees C) and exposed to x-ray film for 3 days.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Transferred RNAs were monitored by methylene blue staining of the filters before hybridization.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	76	Analyses of Contact Stability between Transfected Fibroblasts and Neurites of NG108-15 Cells Fibroblasts were plated in 12-well dishes at a density of 2 10 cells/well 72 h prior to coculture.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Differentiated NG108-15 cells were added at a density of 2 10 cells per well.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	78	 2 h after coculture initiation, fibroblast colonies were identified, and the number of contacts between fibroblasts and NG108-15 cells were recorded at three time points: 1) starting time, t = 0; 2) 0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	79	5 h after the starting time, t = 2.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The number of contacts was used to determine the direction and magnitude of any change in the dynamics of cell-cell interaction.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Analysis of the data was performed with one-tailed t test.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	82	Transfections and CAT Assays Cells (3 10) in 60-mm dishes were cotransfected overnight with a combination of plasmid DNA (total 15  microg) by the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The DNA mix consisted of expression plasmid (pRcCMV or pRc-COUP-TF I, 9  microg), CAT reporter gene construct (DR-1, -RARE, CRBP I, 3  microg), and pRcCMV-lacZ (3  microg).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The pRcCMV-lacZ construct was used to facilitate normalization of the CAT activity to transfection efficiency.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Transfections were performed in triplicate.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Transfection medium was replaced after 18 h with a control media or media supplemented with 10M retinoic acid.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Cells were harvested 48 h later and processed for CAT and lacZ assays according to the methods of Sambrook et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Protein concentration was determined with a protein assay reagent (Bio-Rad) using bovine serum albumin as a standard.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Samples from the CAT assays were resolved by thin-layer chromatography, visualized on x-ray film, and quantitated by liquid scintillation counting.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	90	For construction of reporter plasmids, oligonucleotides containing corresponding HREs were synthesized, trimerized, and cloned into the EcoRV site of Bluescript II KS (Stratagene).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Orientation of the oligonucleotides was determined by sequencing.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The Bluescript vectors containing oligonucleotides were digested (HindIII/XbaI), and the fragments were separated on a 10% polyacrylamide gel in TBE buffer, electroeluted, and ligated to the HindIII/XbaI site of pBLCAT2 (Luckow and Schutz, 1987).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	93	The following oligonucleotides, based on DR-1 (Kadowaki et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	94	, 1992), and CRBP I (Tran et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	95	, 1992), were synthesized: DR-1, 5`- GGCTTCAGGTCAGAGGTCAGAGA and 5`- GGTCTCTGACCTCTGACCTGAAG; -RARE, 5`-GGTGTAGGGTTCACCGAAAGTTCACTCA and 5`-GGTGAGTGAACTTTCGGTGAACCCTACA; and CRBP I, 5`-CCATCCAGGTCAAAAAGTCAGGA and 5`-GGTCCTGACTTTTTGACCTGGAT.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The HRE sequences are underlined.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	97	Preparation of Whole Cell Extracts and Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA) These methods were performed at 4  degrees C as previously described (Scholer et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Briefly, the extraction buffer contained 20 mM Hepes, pH 7.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	99	5 mM dithiothreitol, 25% glycerol, and protease inhibitors phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	100	7  microg/ml), aprotinin (1  microg/ml), and bestatin (40  microg/ml).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Sonicated extracts were cleared by centrifugation for 5 min.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Binding conditions for the EMSA were 10 mM Hepes, pH 7.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	103	8, 1 mM spermidine, 5 mM MgCl, 50 mM KCl, 0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	104	5 mM dithiothreitol, 9% glycerol, 0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	105	8  microg of poly(dI-dC), 50,000 cpm of the P-labeled oligonucleotide, and 10  microg of cell extract.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	106	 After incubation for 15 min at 25  degrees C, DNA-protein complexes were separated on a 5% polyacrylamide gel, followed by autoradiography.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Three different batches of extracts were used in EMSA analyses, and no batch differences were observed.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	108	Cloning of COUP-TF I Expression screening of the subtraction cDNA library was performed to isolate genes that inhibit neurite outgrowth.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The cDNA library in pRcCMV expression vector was transfected into NIH-3T3 fibroblasts, and, after 3 weeks of antibiotic selection, several clones that had less contacts with neurites were isolated.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	110	 These clones were propagated, and the transfected cDNAs were isolated using polymerase chain reaction and retested for neurite outgrowth inhibition.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Sequence analysis revealed that one cDNA is the rat homologue of human orphan receptor COUP-TF I lacking 40 amino acids of the transactivation domain localized near the amino terminus of the DNA binding domain (COUP-TF I).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Full-length COUP-TF I cDNA was isolated by high stringency screening of the brain cDNA library cloned into ZAPII vector (Stratagene).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The rCOUP-TF I cDNA encodes a protein with a predicted molecular mass of 45.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	114	8 kilodaltons (Genbank accession number, U10995) and is 98% identical to the human COUP-TF I at the amino acid level with 95% identity at the nucleotide level.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	115	COUP-TF I Interacts with HREs in Fibroblasts Expression of COUP-TF I was analyzed by Northern blot using six COUP-TF I and three pRcCMV vector-transfected clones.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Vector-transfected and -untransfected fibroblasts did not express detectable levels of COUP-TF I (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Three transfected clones expressed introduced COUP-TF I at high levels (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	118	 1A, lanes6, 7, and 9), two clones expressed at moderate levels (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	119	 1A, lanes3 and 5), while one clone did not express COUP-TF I at a detectable level (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	120	Figure 1: Expression and activity of COUP-TF I in transfected fibroblasts.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	121	 A, Northern blot analyses of COUP-TF I expression in control 3T3 fibroblasts (lane1) and fibroblast clones transfected with COUP-TF I cDNA cloned into pRcCMV expression vector (lanes2-8) or pRcCMV vector only (lanes9 and 10).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Expression of COUP-TF I was high in clones 7-9 (lanes6-8, respectively) and varied from undetectable to moderate in clones 2-5 (lanes2-5, respectively).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	123	 B, EMSA analysis of control fibroblasts (lane 1) and fibroblasts transfected with pRcCMV expression vector (lane2) and COUP-TF I cDNA in pRcCMV (lane3).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Cell extracts were analyzed by EMSA using oligonucleotides DR-1, -RARE, and CRBP I.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	125	 As a control for binding specificity, 100 times molar excess of corresponding unlabeled oligonucleotides were added to the binding reaction (lane4).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	126	 C, the transient CAT activity of DR-1-TK-CAT (DR-1), -RARE-TK-CAT (-RARE), and CRBP I-TK-CAT (CRBP) reporter constructs in the presence of pRcCMV (CMV) or COUP-TF I-expressing plasmid pRcCMV-COUP-TF I (COUP).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Subsets of each transfection group were treated with 10M retinoic acid (RA).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	128	 All cells were cotransfected with pRcCMV/lacZ constructs to facilitate normalization of CAT gene expression to transfection efficiency.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	129	 All treatments were done in triplicate, and the numbers represent values of two experiments.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Values are normalized based upon transfection efficiency and are expressed as relative to the results obtained by transfection of pRcCMV-transfected cells with corresponding reporter plasmid for which activities were set at 1.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Results were analyzed by a one-tailed t test.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	132	Since COUP-TF I can form inactive complexes with retinoid X receptors (RXR) and binds to HREs from different genes as a homodimer to repress the hormone response (Cooney et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	133	, 1992), we used EMSA analysis to examine whether the overexpression of COUP-TF I in fibroblasts affects formation of HRE binding complexes.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Since the effects of COUP-TF I depend on the HRE sequence, we analyzed two natural and one synthetic HRE: -RARE, a direct repeat with a 5-bp spacer that is activated by RAR and is not inhibited by COUP-TF I (Tran et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	135	, 1992); CRBP I-RARE, a direct repeat with a 2-bp spacer that is optimally activated by RARRXR heterodimers but not by RXR homodimers (Hermann et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	136	, 1992); and DR-1, a direct repeat that contains a 1-bp spacer and has a high affinity for COUP-TF I (Kadowaki et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	137	, 1992) and RXRs (Mangelsdorf et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Our results demonstrated that the pattern of protein-DNA complexes is changed in COUP-TF I overexpressing cells compared with controls (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	139	 A unique DNA-protein complex (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	140	 1B, arrow) was detected in extracts made from COUP-TF I overexpressing cells.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Antibodies (developed in our laboratory) against COUP-TF I supershifted the complex (data not shown), verifying the presence of COUP-TF I in the complex.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	142	The role of COUP-TF I as an activator or inhibitor of transcription in 3T3 cells was examined by transient CAT assays using the -RARE, CRBP I, and DR-1 oligonucleotides coupled to the TK promoter of the CAT reporter gene.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Results from cotransfections of reporter constructs and pRcCMV or COUP-TF I expression vectors are shown in Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Cotransfection of COUP-TF I significantly induced (p  <  0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	145	05) -RARE containing reporter construct activity (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Addition of retinoic acid-induced expression (p  <  0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	147	01) of the -RARE reporter gene construct in cells cotransfected with the pRcCMV control expression vector to levels similar (p  >  0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	148	05) to cells cotransfected with COUP-TF I in the presence or absence of retinoic acid.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	149	 No significant effects of COUP-TF I or retinoic acid treatment on reporter gene expression of other constructs was detected.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In these experiments, COUP-TF I functioned as a positive regulator of -RARE-coupled reporter gene expression in 3T3 fibroblasts.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	151	COUP-TF I Overexpression Changes Contact Stability between Transfected Fibroblasts and Neurites The growth rate of neurites from NG108-15 cells is rapid and robust, which makes them a good model for studying cell-cell interaction and contact stability.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Analyses of neurite contact stability were performed with fibroblast clones overexpressing COUP-TF I.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Fibroblasts transfected with the pRcCMV vector only and naive fibroblasts were used as controls.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	154	 There is a general increase in the number of contacts over the course of the experimental period.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	155	 This increase was not different for naive control fibroblasts or fibroblasts transfected with the expression vector (205  plus or minus  64% versus 160  plus or minus  37%, respectively, p  >  0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	156	 However, fibroblasts transfected with COUP-TF I (clones 5, 8, and 9) exhibited a significantly (p  <  0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	157	05) lower increase in contact number (51  plus or minus  14%, 18  plus or minus  20%, 38  plus or minus  27%, respectively, Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	158	 2) indicative of lower contact stability.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	159	 While differences in level of expression of COUP-TF I were apparent in clones 5, 8, and 9 (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	160	 1A, lanes5, 7, and 9, respectively), contact stability was not dependent upon the level of expression of COUP-TF I cDNA (p  >  0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Neuroblastoma-glioma NG108-15 cells have rapidly growing neurites with large growth cones and filopodia.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	162	 After contact with control fibroblasts, growth cones maintain their form (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	163	 In contrast, the processes of NG108-15 cells exhibit retraction or become very small after contact with COUP-TF I-expressing cells, indicative of growth cone collapse and contact instability (Fig.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The increased number of contacts in these cultures comes from other NG108-15 cells in the vicinity of the fibroblasts.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Since the differentiated NG108-15 cells observed have an equal probability to establish and maintain contacts with fibroblasts, the test determines the stability of cell-cell contact.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	166	Figure 2: Cells expressing COUP-TF I exhibit lower (p  <  0.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	167	05) contact stability when cocultured with NG108-15 cells.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Contact stability was assayed in three groups: 1) naive fibroblasts (control); 2) cells transfected only with pRcCMV vector (CMV 3); and 3) three clones transfected with COUP-TF I cDNA (COUP 5, COUP 8, and COUP 9).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The number of contacts between cell types at time 0 and 2.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	170	5 h was used to calculate the percentage change in the number of contacts for each colony of cells observed.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The bars represent the average percentage change in the number of contacts observed for each group and represent the data from three separate experiments.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The number of observations (n) for each group is given.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	173	Figure 3: Interactions of neurites with control and COUP-TF I overexpressing 3T3 fibroblasts.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	174	 2 h after the addition of NG108-15 cells (t = 0), fibroblast clones were identified and photographed at various times during the culture period (given below each panel).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Fibroblasts transfected with the pRcCMV control vector (F in upperCMVpanel) provide a good substrate for support of processes from NG108-15 cells (N).
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The processes are robust, and contacts (arrows) are persistent during prolonged culture.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	177	 In contrast, cells overexpressing COUP-TF I cDNA (F in lowerCOUPpanel) do not sustain significant attachment of processes from NG108-15 cells.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	178	 During the culture period, contacts (arrows) are not maintained.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	179	Members of the steroid hormone receptor superfamily interact in a complex manner and stimulate or repress gene expression, depending upon the type and number of factors present and also the context of the gene promoter (Cooney et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	180	 We have shown that overexpression of the orphan receptor, COUP-TF I, can alter cell-cell interaction in fibroblasts and block neuronal differentiation of PCC7 cells (Neuman et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Expression of COUP-TF I in fibroblasts is correlated with detectable alterations of normal cell behaviors, presumably associated with alteration or modification of the expression of cell surface proteins.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The exact nature of this change is unknown since no differences were detected in comparisons of isolated membrane proteins from control and COUP-TF I-expressing cells, nor was there any indication of involvement of secretory factors.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	183	()Discerning the mechanism by which COUP-TF I altered surface properties was further hampered due to a lack of characterization of fibroblasts with regard to members of the steroid hormone receptor superfamily, which are endogenously expressed and represent potential heterodimerization partners.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	184	 However, data from transient CAT assays indicated that COUP-TF I induced transcriptional activity of -RARE-coupled reporter gene constructs.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Together, these data are consistent with a model in which COUP-TF I interacts with other nuclear hormone receptors, causing changes in gene expression.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Several scenarios are possible, including COUP-TF I homodimers binding to retinoic acid response elements, or COUP-TF I/retinoic acid receptor heterodimer formation (Tran et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	187	, 1992) with subsequent alteration of gene expression.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Retinoic acid alters expression of genes that promote cell growth and attachment, i.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	189	, 1991), and is also important in the regulation of hox genes (Linney, 1992), which have been shown to interact with promoters of cell adhesion molecules, i.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	190	 N-CAM and cytotactin (Jones et al.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Our data are consistent with a model in which perturbation of a variety of processes, including differentiation, aggregation, and cell-cell interaction, is regulated by expression of COUP-TF I.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	192	* This work was supported by the Spinal Cord Society.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	194	 This article must therefore by hereby marked ``advertisement'' in accordance with 18 U.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	196	The nucleotide sequence(s) reported in this paper has been submitted to the GenBank/EMBL Data Bank with accession number(s) U10995.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	197	  To whom correspondence should be addressed: Dept.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	198	 of Anatomy and Neurobiology, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO 80523.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	199	: 303-491-5791; Fax: 303-491-7907; E-mail: toomas@lamar.
0.24508433.7797489.html.plaintext.txt	200	The abbreviations used are: HRE, hormone response element; COUP-TF, chick ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay; RARE, retinoic acid response element; bp, base pair(s); RAR, retinoid acid receptor; RXR, retinoid X receptor.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	0	The orphan nuclear receptor, COUP-TF II, inhibits myogenesis by post-transcriptional regulation of MyoD function: COUP-TF II directly interacts with p300 and MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	1	Peter Bailey, Vittorio Sartorelli1, Yasou Hamamori1 and George E.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	2	University of Queensland, Centre for Molecular and Cellular Biology, Ritchie Research Laboratories, B402A, St Lucia, 4072 Queensland, Australia and 1University of Southern California, Institute of Genetic Medicine #140,2250 Alcazar Street, Los Angeles, CA 90033, USA.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received June 11, 1998; Revised and Accepted October 15, 1998.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	4	COUP-TF II is an orphan nuclear receptor that has no known ligand in the `classical sense'.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	5	 COUP-TF interacts with the corepressors N-CoR, SMRT and RIP13, and silences transcription by active repression and trans-repression.
