0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Forced expression of the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TF II in mouse C2 myogenic cells has been demonstrated to inhibit morphological differentiation, and to repress the expression of: (i) the myoD gene family which encodes myogenic basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) proteins; and (ii) the cell cycle regulator, p21Waf-1/Cip-1.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In the present study, we show that COUP-TF II efficiently inhibits the myoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells by post-transcriptional mechanisms.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Furthermore, repression of MyoD-dependent transcription by COUP-TF II occurs in the absence of the nuclear receptor cognate binding motif.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The inhibition of MyoD-mediated trans-activation involves the direct binding of the DNA binding domain/C-region and hinge/D-regions [i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	10	 amino acid (aa) residues 78-213] of COUP-TF II to the N-terminal activation domain of MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Over-expression of the cofactor p300, which functions as a coactivator of myoD-mediated transcription, alleviated repression by COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Further binding analysis demonstrated that COUP-TF II interacted with the N-terminal 149 aa residues of p300 which encoded the receptor interaction domain of the coactivator.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Finally we observed that COUP-TF II, MyoD and p300 interact in a competitive manner, and that increasing amounts of COUP-TF II have the ability to reduce the interaction between myoD and p300 invitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The experiments presented herein suggest thatCOUP-TF II post-transcriptionally regulates myoD activity/function, and that crosstalk between orphan nuclear receptors and the myogenic bHLH proteins has functional consequences for differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	15	The process of skeletal muscle differentiation involves the activation and induction of a large array of muscle-specific genes, and exit from the cell cycle.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The myoD gene family encodes myogenic specific basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) proteins that activate and control this process (reviewed in 1-3).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	17	 MyoD plays a dual role during myogenesis, activating both muscle specific gene transcription and promoting cell cycle exit by inducing the expression of p21Cip-1/Waf-1, an inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases and cellular proliferation (4-6).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Transactivation by MyoD involves: (i) the bHLH domain, that is involved in both DNA binding and dimerisation; (ii) the heterodimerisation of MyoD with the ubiquitously expressed E2A gene products, E12 and E47 (7); (iii) the binding of MyoD-E2A heterodimers to specific E-box motifs (CANNTG) in muscle-specific enhancers (reviewed in 1-3); and (iv) the recruitment of the cofactors p300 and PCAF (8-10).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The cofactors p300 and PCAF are critical coactivators for MyoD during myogenic commitment and differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD directly interacts with p300 and recruits PCAF to form a ternary multimeric complex on promoter elements (8,11).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These events lead to hyper-acetylated and transcriptionally-permissive chromatin.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Moreover, p300 and PCAF coactivate myoD-mediated trans-activation of the p21 gene, and are necessary for MyoD-mediated cell cyle arrest (11).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	23	The transcriptional activity of MyoD is modulated by environmental cues related to the concentration of growth factors, receptors and oncogene products which promote cell division (reviewed in 12).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	24	 These agents inhibit the transcriptional activity of MyoD by promoting: (i) the direct phosphorylation of the bHLH region and/or the interaction with c-jun, which prevent DNA binding; (ii) the activation of inhibitor of differentiation expression (Id), a bHLH protein that lacks DNA binding ability, and functions as a dominant negative; and (iii) the suppression/sequestering of myogenic specific transcription factors and cofactors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	25	The orphan nuclear receptors COUP-TF II, Rev-erbA and RVR are members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, and are abundantly expressed in proliferating myoblasts (12-15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	26	 However, the expression of this group of receptors is repressed during differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Constitutive expression of COUP-TF II cDNA in mouse C2 myogenic cells blocks morphological differentiation by suppressing the levels of myoD mRNA, increasing cyclin D1 protein levels, and blocking the induction of myogenin and p21 mRNAs after serum withdrawal (14,16).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The molecular basis for these effects has not been elucidated.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	29	COUP-TF IIis ubiquitously expressed in adult tissues, and regulated by the morphogen, sonic hedgehog (17).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	30	 During embryogenesis, COUP-TF II is expressed in the developing CNS in a spatio-temporal manner (18,19), and in the dermatomial region of the somite at 10 days post coitum, which will give rise to the axial skeletal and tongue muscle (20).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	31	 COUP-TF proteins are highly expressed in many other developing organs and the expression level decreases with completion of differentiation, suggesting that COUP-TF is involved in organogenesis (21,22).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	32	 COUP-TF binds to direct and inverted repeats of the RGGTCA motif spaced by 0-12 nt (23-26).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	33	COUP-TF isoforms I and II have been demonstrated to: (i) repress hormonal trans-activation of target genes by the nuclear receptor family (23-26); (ii) repress trans-activation by the potent GAL4VP16 chimera (16); (iii) interact with TFIIB; and (iv) negatively regulate the transcription of many other genes(e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Apolipoprotein AI gene) (21,27-29).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Inhibition of trans-cription by COUP-TF II has been shown to be mediated by two main mechanisms, active repression and transrepression (30).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Active repression by COUP-TF involves direct binding and competition for the occupancy of a common response element (31).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Transrepression involves inhibition of transcription by COUP-TF II in the absence of its cognate binding motif, or independent of nucleic acid binding (30).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Interestingly, we (16) and Achatz et al.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	39	 (30) have demonstrated that the DNA binding domain (DBD)/C-region of COUP-TF II is necessary for transrepression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The molecular mechanism underlying COUP-TF II transrepression is unclear; however, it has been suggested that direct protein-protein interactions between COUP-TF and essential cofactors may be involved.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Whether COUP-TF II directly regulates the transcription of the bHLH regulators is unclear.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Furthermore, the fact that COUP-TF II represses transcription in the presence and absence of its cognate binding motif raises the scenario that COUP-TF II may control MyoD activity or the formation of the functional MyoD ternary complex.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	43	Active repression by COUP-TF II is mediated by the nuclear corepressors (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	44	 N-CoR/RIP13 and SMRT/TRAC-2) (16,32-35).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Corepressors actively repress transcription by: (i) interacting with Sin3A/B and recruiting histone deacetylases (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	46	 HDAc-1 or Rpd3) which actively promote chromatin condensation via hypo-acetylation of the chromatin (36-39); and (ii) binding key components of the basal transcriptional machinery (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	47	 TFIIB, TAFII32 and TAFII70) (40).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	48	 In the present study, we demonstrate that that repression of MyoD-mediated transactivation by COUP-TF II involves direct binding to MyoD and p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	49	Vectors used in transfection experiments and GST-pulldowns are described in detail elsewhere (8,16).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The construction of new plasmids is described herein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The oligonucleotides GMUQ371 5[prime]-GCGGTCGACATATGTGCCGCCTCAAAAAGTGCCTC-3[prime] and GMUQ372 5[prime]-GCGGTCGACTTATTTATTGAATTGCCATATACGG-3[prime] were synthesised to allow PCR amplification of the COUP-TF II region spanning amino acids (aa) 134-414.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The oligonucleotides GMUQ371 and GMUQ373 5[prime]-GCGGTCGACCTAGGTTTTACCTACCAAACGG-3[prime] were used to amplify the region spanning aa 134-389.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	53	 PCR amplification was performed with Pfu DNA polymerase (Stratagen, La Jolla, CA) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The resulting DNA fragments were digested with SalI and ligated to SalI-digested pNLVP16.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The plasmids are described as VP16-COUP-TF II 1/2 (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	56	 aa 134-414) and VP16-COUP-TF II 1/3 (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	57	 aa 134-389) throughout the text.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The oligonucleotides GMUQ272 and QMUQ273 (described in 16) were used to generate the COUP-TF II CD region.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The resulting product was digested with EcoRI and end-filled with Klenow DNA polymerase according to the manufacturer's directions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The COUP-TF II CD end-filled fragment was then cloned into a pNLVP16 vector which had been cleaved with NdeI and end-filled with Klenow DNA polymerase.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	61	 To generate the pSG5-COUP-TF II AB, ABCD and CDE expression vectors GAL4-COUP-TF II plasmids encoding the AB, ABCD and CDE domains were digested with EcoRI and the resulting fragments cloned into the EcoRI site of pSG5.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	62	 pSG5-COUP-TF II CD was generated by digesting the COUP-TF II CD PCR fragment with EcoRI and again directly cloning into the EcoRI site of pSG5.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	63	 To create the plasmids encoding GST-COUP-TF II AB, ABCD, CDE and DE, GAL4-COUP-TF II plasmids encoding the AB, ABCD, CDE and DE domains were digested with EcoRI and the resulting fragments cloned into the EcoRI site of pGEX-1[lambda]T.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	64	 GST-COUP-TF II CD wasgenerated by digesting the CD PCR fragment with EcoRI and cloning into the EcoRI site of pGEX-1[lambda]T.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	65	 VP16, GAL and GSTchimeras were sequenced to confirm the orientation and reading frame.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	66	JEG-3 cells were cultured for 24 h in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle's Medium (DMEM) containing 5% charcoal stripped fetal calf serum in 6% CO2 at 37 degrees C prior to transfection.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	67	 JEG-3 cells grown in 6-well dishes to 60-70% confluence were transiently transfected with 3  microg of the reporter plasmid DNA G5E1b-CAT, 1  microg of either GAL4-p300-aa 1-149, GAL4-p300-aa 595-1240, or GAL4-p300-aa 1030-2414 and 1  microg of either VP16O, VP16 COUP-TF II, VP16 COUP-TF II AB, VP16 COUP-TFII ABCD, VP16 COUP-TF II CD, VP16 COUP-TF II CDE, VP16 COUP-TF II DE, VP16 COUP-TF II 1/2 or VP16 COUP-TF II 1/3 by the DOTAP/DOSPER (Boehringer Mannheim) mediated procedure as described previously (41).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The DNA/DOTAP/DOSPER mixture was added to the cells in 3 ml of fresh medium.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The medium was replaced 24 h after transfection.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Cells were harvested and assayed for CAT enzyme activity as previously described after a further 24 h.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Each transfection experiment was performed at least three times in order to overcome the variability inherent in transfections.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	72	 NIH3T3 fibroblasts were grown to confluence (~5  x  106 cells) in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Cells were transfected by the calcium phosphate precipitation procedure as previously described.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	74	 One  microg of the 4RE-tkLUC reporter was coprecipitated with either 100 ng of EMSV, 200 ng p300 and/or 100-500 ng of the pSG5-COUP-TF II `sense'/pSG5-COUP-TF II `anti-sense'plasmid.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	75	5 mg of the CMV-LacZ plasmid was included in each transfection.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Luciferase activity was assayed as previously described (8) and corrected for with respect to the transfection efficiency by the [beta]-galactosidase assay.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Thequantitative [beta]-galactosidase assay was performed with the chlorophenol red-[beta]-d-galactopyranoside substrate (CPRG; Boehringer Mannheim) as previously described (8).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Each transfection experiment was performed at least three times in order to overcome the variability inherent in transfections.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	79	C3H10T1/2 cell myogenic conversion.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	80	For the myogenic conversion assay, C3H10T1/2 fibroblasts were grown to 60% confluence in 12-well dishes.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Cells in each well were transfected by the DOTAP/DOSPER (Boehringer Mannheim) mediated procedure, using 1  microg of EMSV-MyoD in combination with either 1  microg of pSG5-COUP-TF II, pSG5-COUP-TF II AB, pSG5-COUP-TF II ABCD, pSG5-COUP-TF II CDE or pSG5 carrier DNA so as to total 2  microg per transfection.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	82	4  microg each of EMSV-MyoD, EMSV-Myf-5, EMSV-Myogenin and EMSV-MRF4 were cotransfected with either 0.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	83	4  microg of pSG5 or pSG5-COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Twenty-four hours after transfection, cells were reefed on 10% DMEM until 100% confluent, whereupon the media was changed to DMEM plus 2% horse serum.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Cells were grown under these conditions for 6 days, with media changes occurring every 2 days.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Immunostaining was then performed using a monoclonal antibody directed towards the fast isoform of the major thick filament protein, skeletal myosin heavy chain (MHC) (Sigma; clone MY32).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	87	 This procedure is described in detail elsewhere (8).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	88	GST and GST fusion proteins were expressed in Escherichia coli (BL21) and purified using glutathione-agarose affinity chromatography as described previously (15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The GST fusion proteins were analysed on 10% SDS-PAGE gels for integrity and to normalise the amount of each protein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The Promega (Madison, WI) TNT-coupled transcription-translation system was used to produce [35S]methionine-labelled MyoD and COUP-TF II proteins that were visualised by SDS-PAGE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	91	 In vitro binding assays were performed with glutathione agarose beads (Sigma, St Louis, MO) coated with ~500 ng GST fusion protein and 2-30  microl [35S]methionine-labelled protein in 200 ml of binding buffer containing 100 mM NaCl, 20 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	92	5 % NP-40, 5  microg of ethidium bromide and 100  microg of BSA.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The reaction was allowed to proceed for 1-2 h at room temperature with rocking.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The affinity beads were then collected by centrifugation and washed five times with 1 ml of binding buffer without the ethidium bromide or BSA.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The beads were then resuspended in 20 ml of SDS-PAGE sample buffer and boiled for 5 min.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The denatured proteins were run on a 10% SDS-PAGE gel which was subsequently treated with Amersham Amplify fluor (Amersham, Arlington Heights, IL), dried and autoradiographed.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	97	RESULTS COUP-TF II inhibits myoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	98	We have previously demonstrated that proliferating C2C12 myoblasts express COUP-TF II mRNA and that constitutive expression of COUP-TF II cDNA in mouse C2 myogenic cells blocks morphological differentiation by suppressing the expression levels of the myoD gene family and critical cell cycle regulators (14,15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Moreover, preliminary evidence suggests that COUP-TF II directly regulates the transcription of the bHLH/contractile gene families and/or the cell cycle regulators (P.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	100	 However, the fact that COUP-TF II represses transcription in the presence and absence of its cognate binding motif, and interacts with the corepressors N-CoR and SMRT, raises the scenario that COUP-TF II may control MyoD activity or function by post-transcriptional mechanisms, which include transrepression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	101	We tested this hypothesis by investigating the impact of SV40-driven COUP-TF II expression on the MyoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In this system, transient transfection of an EMSV-MyoD expression vector under the control of a moloney sarcoma virus promoter leads to the phenotypic/myogenic conversion of these cells as scored by immunostaining with a monoclonal antibody directed against a muscle-specific marker.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The antibody is against the fast isoform of the major thick filament protein, skeletal MHC.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	104	 MHC is associated with the contractile phenotype and is expressed during the process of muscle differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Utilisation of an EMSV-driven MyoD expression vector, which is essentially refactory to repression by COUP-TF II, assured that any observed affects of COUP-TF II on phenotypic conversion were independent of myoD down-regulation, and mediated by post-transcriptional events.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	106	 We demonstrated that the identical moloney sarcoma virus promoter linked to the CAT reporter in the same vector was not affected/regulated by COUP-TF II expression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	107	 We cotransfected increasing amounts of either pSG5, the SV40 expression vector alone, or pSG5-COUP-TF II with EMSV-CAT.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	108	 We observed that at the concentrations of DNA transfected in this experiment, neither the vector alone nor pSG5-COUP-TF II affected the activity of the EMSV promoter (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	109	In the initial experiment, C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently transfected with EMSV-MyoD in combination with either pSG5 (vector/vehicle only) or pSG5-COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	110	 As expected, cells transfected with EMSV-MyoD and pSG5 were found to be positively stained with the MHC antibody.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	111	 In stark contrast, cells that were transfected with both MyoD and wild type COUP-TF II did not undergo myogenic conversion (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	112	To delimit the region within COUP-TF II which is involved in the ablation of the MyoD-mediated acquisition of the myogenic phenotype, we cotransfected 10T1/2 cells with EMSV-MyoD and expression vectors encoding the AB, ABCD and CDE regions of COUP-TF II (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	113	 After immunostaining, it was found that the ABCD and CDE regions were sufficient to inhibit myogenic conversion (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In contrast, the AB region of COUP-TF II failed to ablate the MyoD-mediated acquisition of the contractile phenotype (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	115	 This is in agreement with previous studies that show that the CD region of COUP-TF II (encoding the DBD and hinge domain) blocks the trans-activation of GAL4-dependent reporter genes by the potent chimeric trans-activator GAL4VP16 (16).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	116	 (A) COUP-TF II expression does not affect the activity of the EMSV promoter.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	117	 C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently co-transfected with EMSV-CAT in combination with either increasing quantities (0.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	118	0  microg) of pSG5 alone or pSG5-COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	119	 They were subsequently assayed for CAT activity; results shown are mean  plus or minus  standard deviation and were derived from three independent transfections.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	120	 (B) COUP-TF II inhibits the myoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The ABCD and CDE regions of COUP-TF II are sufficient to inhibit myogenic conversion.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	122	 C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently transfected with EMSV-MyoD in combination with either pSG5 alone (panel b), pSG5-COUP-TF II (panel c), pSG5-COUP-TF II AB (panel d), pSG5-COUP-TF II ABCD (panel e) or pSG5-COUP-TF II CDE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Myogenic conversion was then scored with respect to the untransfected control cells (panel a) by immunostaining with a monoclonal antibody directed towards the fast isoform of the major thick filament protein, skeletal [alpha]MHC after 4 daysin 2% horse serum.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (C) Diagrammatic representation of COUP-TF II, highlighting the key domains: AB domain(i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	125	 aa 79-144); D domain or Hinge (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	126	 aa 145-213); and E domain of putative LBD (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	127	 (D) Inhibition of 10T1/2 myogenic conversion by COUP-TF II is not overcome by the forced expression of the myogenic factors myoD, myogenin, myf-5 and MRF-4.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	128	 C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently transfected with expression vectors for the myogenic factors MyoD, myogenin, myf-5 and MRF-4 in the absence (panel b) and presence (panel c) of COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	129	 As before, myogenic conversion was scored with respect to the untransfected control cells (panel a) by immunostaining with an MHC antibody.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	130	 MHC-positive cells are stained red and highlighted by an arrow.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	131	We then examined whether forced expression of the myogenic factors myoD, myogenin, myf-5 and MRF-4 could overcome the block mediated by COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	132	 C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently transfected with expression vectors for the myogenic factors myoD, myogenin, myf-5 and MRF-4 in the presence and absence of COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	133	 It was found that although cotransfection of C3H10T1/2 cells with the complete repertoire of myogenic factors results in very efficient myogenic conversion, as scored by positive [alpha]MHC immunostaining, COUP-TF II still blocks the acquistion of the contractile phenotype (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	134	In summary, the experiments presented above suggest that the CDE region of COUP-TF II is involved in the inhibition of myoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Furthermore, the orphan nuclear receptor abrogates 10T1/2 myogenic conversion in the absence of its cognate binding motif.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The ability of COUP-TF II to over-ride the entire repertoire of myogenic factors also suggests that it may sequester or bind essential cofactors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	137	COUP-TF II inhibits myoD-mediated trans-activation of a reporter gene downstream from a MyoD-dependent heterologous promoter.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	138	The immunohistochemical analysis suggested that COUP-TF II acts to repress 10T1/2 myogenic conversion by a mechanism which is independent of MyoD gene expression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Hence, it was of interest to determine whether COUP-TF II could repress MyoD-dependent transcription in the absence of its cognate binding site.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	140	 To achieve this we utilised a 4RE-tkLUC reporter construct, in which four copies of the right E box (CANNTG motif) of the muscle specific MCK enhancer are placed upstream of a minimal thymidine kinase promoter linked to the LUC reporter gene.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	141	 This reporter construct does not contain a cognate binding site for COUP-TF II, and has been demonstrated to facilitate MyoD-dependent trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	142	C3H10T1/2 cells were cotransfected with the 4RE-tkLUC reporter in combination with either EMSV-MyoD and/or COUP-TF II sense and anti-sense expression vectors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	143	 As expected, co-transfection of the reporter with EMSV-MyoD alone activated the expression of the LUC reporter gene very efficiently (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	144	 However, cotransfection of 10T1/2 cells with EMSV-MyoD and increasing quantities of the pSG5 COUP-TF II expression vector (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	145	 100, 300 and 500 ng) significantly repressed MyoD-mediated trans-activation in a dose-dependent fashion (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In contrast, cotransfection of EMSV-MyoD with the anti-sense COUP-TF II construct did not have any affect on MyoD trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	147	 This result clearly shows that COUP-TF II is capable of blocking MyoD-mediated trans-activation in a dose-dependent manner via a trans-repression mechanism which is independent of COUP-TF II DNA binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	148	 (A) COUP-TF II inhibits the MyoD-dependent transactivation of a 4RE reporter construct via a mechanism that is independent of DNA binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	149	 NIH 3T3 cells were transiently transfected with the 4RE-tkLUC reporter (1  microg) in combination with either MyoD (100 ng), COUP-TF II sense `S' (100, 300 or 500 ng) or COUP-TF II anti-sense `AS' (500 ng) as indicated (+).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	150	 After 48 h, cells were harvested and assayed for luciferase activity as described in the Methods and Materials.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (B) COUP-TF II directly interacts with MyoD in vitro; the CD region of COUP-TF II alone is capable of mediating this interaction.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	152	 MyoD was radiolabelled with [35S]methionine by in vitro transcription/translation [the input (lane 1) represents ~10% of the total protein] and was assayed for its ability to interact with glutathione-immobilised GST alone (lane 2), GST-COUP-TF II (lane 3), GST-COUP-TF II AB (lane 4), GST-COUP-TF II ABCD (lane 5), GST-COUP-TF II CD (lane 6), GST-COUP-TF II CDE (lane 7) and GST-COUP-TF II DE (lane 8).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The retained proteins are shown in lanes 3-8.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	154	 COUP-TF II directly interacts with MyoD: the CD region of the nuclear receptor mediates the interaction.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	155	We postulated that COUP-TF II could be functioning to repress MyoD activity/function by directly interacting with MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	156	 To determine this we utilised the in vitro GST pulldown assay, in which glutathione agarose-immobilised GST-COUP-TF II was incubated with in vitro 35S-radiolabelled full-length MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	157	 This assay clearly showed that COUP-TF II and MyoD were indeed capable of a direct interaction in vitro (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	158	To map the region within COUP-TF II that was involved in mediating this interaction, a variety of COUP-TF II domains were sub-cloned into the GEX-1 expression vector, producing the fusion protiens GST-COUP-TF II AB, GST-COUP-TF II ABCD, GST-COUP-TF II CD, GST-COUP-TF II CDE and GST-COUP-TF II DE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The full-length and deleted GST-COUP-TF II chimeric proteins were then incubated with in vitro translated MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Interestingly, the COUP-TF II domains ABCD, CD and CDE interacted strongly with full-length MyoD (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	161	 In contrast, neither the AB region nor the DE region retained the ability to interact with full-length MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	162	 This demonstrated that the CD region of COUP-TF II, which spans aa 78-213 and encodes the DBD and hinge region, is required for MyoD binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	163	 This observation was also confirmed by examining the ability of in vitro translated full-length COUP-TF II to interact with GST-MyoD (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	164	 As expected, we observed specific binding between 35S-radiolabelled COUP-TF II and GST-MyoD in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	165	 These experiments suggested protein-protein interactions were involved in the transrepression of myoD-mediated transcription.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD mediates the interaction with COUP-TF II in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	167	 (A) GST pulldown showing an interaction between 35S-radiolabelled COUP-TF II and glutathione agarose-immobilised GST-MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The input lane represents ~10% of the total protein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	169	 (B) Diagrammatic representation of the MyoD protein, highlighting key regulatory domains.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	170	 (C) Glutathione agarose-immobilised GST and GST-COUP-TF II proteins were incubated with either 35S-radiolabelled full-length MyoD, N-terminal MyoD (aa 1-100) or C-terminal MyoD (aa 162-318).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The input lanes represent ~10% of the total protein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	172	 (D) COUP-TF II directly interacts with the N-terminal of MyoD in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The CDE domain of COUP-TF II was radiolabelled with [35S]methionine by in vitro transcription/translation [the input (lane 1) represents ~10% of the total protein] and assayed for its ability to interact with glutathione-immobilised GST alone (lane 2), GST-MyoD full-length (lane 3), GST-MyoD N-terminal (lane 4), GST-MyoD C-terminal (lane 5) and GST-MyoD bHLH (lane 6).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The retained proteins are shown in lanes 3-6.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD mediates the interaction with COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	176	To identify the domain within MyoD (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	177	 3B) which interacts with COUP-TF II, immobilised GST-COUP-TF II was incubated in combination with either 35S-radiolabelled N-terminal MyoD (aa 1-100) or C-terminal MyoD (aa 162-318).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	178	 It was found that the N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD, but not the C-terminal region, interacted with COUP-TF II (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	179	 It should be noted that the N-terminal activation domain of MyoD has also been demonstrated to interact with p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	180	To rigorously confirm that the N-terminal of MyoD interacts with COUP-TF II, we examined the ability of a number of GST-MyoD fusion chimeras containing functional subdomains of MyoD and immobilised on glutathione agrose beads [i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	181	 GST-MyoD (aa 1-318), GST-N terminal MyoD (aa 1-100), GST-bHLH (aa 102-161) and GST-C-terminal MyoD (aa 162-318)] to interact with the 35S-radiolabelled CDE region of COUP-TF II (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	182	 As expected, MyoD and the N-terminal of MyoD linked to GST interacted strongly with in vitro translated COUP-TF II-CDE (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In contrast, the GST-MyoD-C-terminal and -bHLH regions did not support any significant interaction with the CDE domain of COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	184	 These experiments suggest that the N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD, which is represented by the first 100 aa of the protein, is required for COUP-TF II binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	185	The coactivator p300 alleviates COUP-TF II-mediated repression of MyoD-dependent trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	186	Nuclear receptors have been demonstrated to inhibit AP-1 function, in the absence of any observable affects on DNA recognition, by competing for limiting amounts of p300/CBP (42).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Competition for p300 in this case involves direct binding between p300 and nuclear receptors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In the context of muscle differentiation, p300 functions as a coactivator for MyoD-mediated trans-activation, and has been demonstrated to augment the trans-activation of genes which contain E-box elements in their enhancer regions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	189	 It was therefore of some interest to determine whether COUP-TF II could be functioning to repress MyoD-dependent trans-activation by competing for limiting amounts of p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	190	 In doing so, we examined the effect of p300 over-expression on COUP-TF II-mediated repression of MyoD-dependent trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	191	 NIH 3T3 cells were cotransfected with the 4RE-tkLUC construct and COUP-TF II in the presence of either MyoD or MyoD and p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	192	 If competition for limiting quantities of p300 also accounts for the inhibitory effect of COUP-TF II on MyoD transcriptional activity, then increased levels of p300 should restore/alleviate COUP-TF II-mediated repression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	193	 We found that cotransfection of p300 with COUP-TF II and MyoD almost completely rescued myoD transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	194	 4A), suggesting that repression by COUP-TF II involves competition for limiting amounts of p300, presumably through protein-protein interactions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The coactivator p300 alleviates COUP-TF II-mediated repression of MyoD-dependent trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	196	 NIH 3T3 cells were transiently transfected with 1  microg of the 4RE-tkLUC construct, 100 ng of CMV-MyoD, 200 ng of CMV-[beta]p300 and 300 ng of COUP-TF II as indicated (+).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	197	 After 48 h, cells were harvested and assayed for luciferase activity.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	198	 COUP-TF II interacts with the N-terminal 149 aa receptor interaction domain (RID) of the cofactor p300 in vivo.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	199	Nuclear receptors have been shown to directly interact with the N-terminal RID encoded by aa residues 1-149 of p300 in vivo (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	200	 To determine if COUP-TF II also interacts with p300 in vivo, we utilised the mammalian two-hybrid assay.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In this assay, the GAL4 DBD-p300 domain fusion chimeras, GAL4-p300-aa 1-149, -p300-aa 595-1240, and -p300-aa 1030-2414 were independently cotransfected in JEG-3 cells with either full-length VP16-COUP-TF II, VP16-COUP-TF II AB or VP16-COUP-TF II CDE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The capacity of the GAL-p300 and VP16-COUP-TF II fusion products to physically interact in vivo was then assessed by their ability to trans-activate a CAT reporter gene placed downstream of GAL4 binding sites linked to the E1b promoter.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	203	 It was found that, like other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, full-length COUP-TF II strongly interacts (~20-fold) with only the N-terminal RID of p300 (aa 1-149) (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In comparison, with the nuclear receptor RXR[gamma] (in the presence of ligand), the interaction of the N-terminal region of p300 with full-length COUP-TFII, is stronger [~5-fold; data not shown, and similar to that reported by Chakravarti et al.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	205	 It was also found that the RID of p300 interacted efficiently with the C-terminal region of COUP-TF II which encodes the CD and E domains [i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	206	 DBD, hinge and putative ligand binding domain (LBD)].
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In contrast, the AB region of COUP-TF II did not interact with the RID of p300 (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	208	 (A) Diagrammatic representation of the p300 protein, highlighting regions involved in protein-protein interactions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	209	 (B) COUP-TF II interacts with the RID of p300 in vivo.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	210	 JEG-3 cells were transiently transfected with the G5e1bCAT reporter construct and expression vectors encoding either GAL4-p300-aa 1-149, GAL4-p300-aa 595-1240, GAL4-p300-aa 1030-2414, VP16-COUP-TF II full-length, VP16-COUP-TF II AB or VP16-COUP-TF II CDE as indicated (+).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	211	 After 48 h on 10% charcoal stripped medium, cells were harvested and assayed for CAT activity.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Results shown are mean  plus or minus  standard deviation and were derived from at least three independent experiments.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	213	 In each case, fold activation is relative to GAL4-p300 chimera/VP160 CAT activity, which is arbitrarily set at 1.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	214	 (C) The CD region of COUP-TF II, which spans aa 78-213, interacts with the N-terminal 149 aa of p300 in vivo.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	215	 JEG-3 cells were transiently transfected with the 3 mg G5e1bCAT reporter construct, 1 mg GAL4-p300-aa1-149 and 1 mg of the VP16-COUP-TF II chimeras as indicated (+).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The results are presented as the mean  plus or minus  standard deviation and were derived from at least three independent experiments.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	217	 In each case, fold activation is relative to GAL4-p300-aa 1-149/VP160 CAT activity, which is arbitarily set at 1.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	218	 (D) Direct binding between the CD region of COUP-TF II and full-length p300 in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	219	 p300 was radiolabelled with [35S]methionine by in vitro transcription/translation and assayed for its ability to interact with glutathione-immobilised GST, GST-COUP-TF II, GST-COUP-TF II AB, GST-COUP-TF II ABCD, GST-COUP-TF II CD, GST-COUP-TF II CDE and GST-COUP-TF II DE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The cofactor p300 directly interacts with the COUP-TF II CD region in vivo and in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	221	To delimit the region within COUP-TF II which interacts with the p300 RID in vivo, we again utilised the mammalian two-hybrid assay.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	222	 In doing so, the VP16 chimeras VP16-COUP-TF AB, ABCD, CDE, CD, DE, 1/2 and 1/3 (depicted in Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	223	 5C) were independently cotransfected with GAL RID p300 and assayed for their ability to trans-activate the G5e1bCAT reporter.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	224	 It was found that the CD region of COUP-TF II, which encodes the DBD and hinge (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	225	 aa 78-213), was sufficient to interact with the RID of p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Interestingly, the VP16-COUP-TF II chimeras 1/2 and 1/3, which contain only part of the DBD (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	227	 from aa 134), were not able to interact with the RID of p300, suggesting that the entire DBD is required for binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	228	To confirm that COUP-TF II and p300 interact directly, we used the in vitro GST pulldown assay.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Equal quantities of glutathione agarose-immobilised GST (negative control) and GST-COUP-TF II full-length and various sub-domains (GST-COUP-TF II AB, GST-COUP-TF II ABCD, GST-COUP-TF II CD, GST-COUP-TF II CDE and GST-COUP-TF II DE) were incubated with in vitro 35S-radiolabelled full-length p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The resulting pulldown clearly showed a direct interaction between full-length COUP-TF II and in vitro translated p300 (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Furthermore, the CD region of COUP-TF II, spanning aa 78-213, is required for the interaction with p300 (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Interestingly, this is the same region that interacts with MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	233	 It should be noted that the ABCD and CDE regions of COUP-TF II are also sufficient to repress the MyoD-dependent conversion of C3H10T1/2 cells and that the DBD of COUP-TF II (aa 79-144) is essential for the repression of trans-activation in the absence of the cognate binding motif and nucleic acid binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	234	COUP-TF II, p300 and MyoD interact in a competitive manner.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	235	We then embarked on experiments designed to analyse whether competitive binding between these interacting proteins was an issue with respect to the formation of a ternary complex.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	236	 We examined the ability of increasing amounts of COUP-TF II CDE to affect the efficiency of interaction between GST-MyoD and radiolabelled p300 (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	237	 We observed that increasing amounts of radiolabelled COUP-TF II CDE reduced the ability of a fixed amount of 35S-labelled p300 to interact with GST-MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Similarly, we observed that increasing amounts of myoD reduced the ability of p300 to interact with COUP-TF II (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	239	 COUP-TF II, p300 and MyoD interact in a competitive manner in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	240	 (A) Glutathione-immobilised GST-MyoD protein was incubated with 0.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	241	5  microl of 35S-radiolabelled p300 and either 2, 4 or 8  microl of radiolabelled COUP-TF II CDE as indicated.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	242	 In each pulldown, the input lanes represent ~10% of the total protein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	243	 (B) Glutathione-immobilised GST-COUP-TF II protein was incubated with 1  microl of 35S-radiolabelled p300 and either 2, 4 or 8  microl of radiolabelled MyoD as indicated.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	244	This suggested that the interaction between COUP-TF II, p300 and myoD is competitive in nature, and that COUP-TF II may be involved in the process that regulates the interaction between MyoD and its cofactor, p300, which is essential for trans-activation of gene expression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	245	The regulation of myogenesis (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	246	 muscle differentiation) is intimately controlled by a group of muscle specific bHLH proteins encoded by the myoD gene family (myoD, myogenin, myf-5, MRF-4) (reviewed in 1-3).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The products of the myoD gene family are involved in a variety of protein-protein interactions with many factors that mediate transcription [e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	248	 E12 and E47, TFIIB; 7,44], control the cell cycle (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	249	 RB; 45), and regulate chromatin accessibility and architecture (p300 and PCAF; 11).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These protein-protein interactions regulate cellular proliferation and activate myogenic specific transcription that encodes the contractile phenotype.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Insights into the process of myogenesis have been provided by the myoD gene family of transcription factors, because they function at the nexus of command circuits that control the mutually exclusive events of division and differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	252	The nuclear receptor superfamily are potent regulators of development, differentiation, homeostasis and organ physiology; however, their functional role in mammalian muscle differentiation, regulation of MyoD and myogenesis has only been resolved at a descriptive level.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The classical ligand activated nuclear receptors (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	254	 thyroid hormone receptor) promote differentiation and muscle maturation in vivo (12,46).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	255	 However, the orphan nuclear receptors including Rev-erb[alpha], RVR and COUP-TF II, which are abundantly expressed in skeletal muscle and proliferating myogenic cells, antagonistically regulate muscle differentiation and appear to be involved in the maintenance of the proliferative state (13-15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	256	This study was directed toward identifying some of the mechanistic aspects of orphan nuclear receptor-mediated repression of muscle differentiation and myogenic conversion.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Our work suggested that repression of MyoD-mediated trans-activation and myogenic conversion by COUP-TF II involves direct interactions with MyoD and its coactivator, p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Furthermore, the study provides another line of evidence in a biological context which demonstrates that COUP-TF II-mediated repression of MyoD-dependent trans-activation occurs in the absence of the orphan receptor cognate binding motif.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	259	 This observation strengthens the view that trans-repression by COUP-TF II has a functional role during mammalian muscle differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Finally, it demonstrates that direct crosstalk between the orphan nuclear receptor and bHLH pathways has functional consequences for the regulation of differentiation and phenotypic acquisition.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	261	 This mode of action and crosstalk between two central regulatory components may turn out to be utilised in other pathways of mammalian differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	262	Specifically, our study showed that COUP-TF II could repress MyoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential 10T1/2 cells, when myoD expression was driven by a viral promoter refractory to COUP-TF II action.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This immunochemical analysis suggested that the CDE region (but not the N-terminal AB region) of COUP-TF II was necessary for the repression of myoD-mediated myogenic conversion.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	264	 In particular, the C and D regions of the orphan receptor, between aa residues 78 and 213, which encode the DBD and hinge region, respectively, were specifically involved in these events.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	265	 We observed that a MyoD-dependent reporter gene driven by four multimerised MyoD binding sites (from the MCK-enhancer), cloned upstream of the herpes simplex thymidine kinase promoter, was specifically inhibited by COUP-TF II expression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Our study suggested that one of the mechanisms involved in this process of repression was the direct interaction between MyoD and COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Additional in vitro experiments demonstrated that the interaction was mediated by the acid-rich N-terminal activation domain of MyoD (which also mediates p300 binding) and the CD region of COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Furthermore, COUP-TF II interacted with the N-terminal RID (aa 1-149) of the cofactor p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	269	 This is perhaps not surprising, since many other classical ligand activated nuclear receptors (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	270	) interact with the coactivator p300 (42).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	271	 However, the fact that the DBD (C-region) and hinge/D-region of COUP-TF II mediate the interaction to p300 and MyoD is novel, and perhaps suprising.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	272	 With respect to the in vitro and in vivo requirement of the COUP-TF II DBD and hinge region (aa 79-213) as a dimerisation interface for myoD and p300, it should be mentioned that this domain contains the DR and T box motifs, which have been implicated as dimerisation interfaces in RXR (and other nuclear receptors).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Furthermore, they are highly homologous to the similar motifs found in RXR, which is expected, since COUP-TF II and RXR belong to the same nuclear receptor sub-family (47,48).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The DR box has been strongly implicated in the heterodimerisation of TR and RAR with RXR.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The DR boxes in RXR[gamma] and COUP-TF II are highly homologous.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Similarly, the T-box sequence that forms a third helix in RXR, and is implicated in homo- and heterodimerisation, is very similar in COUP-TF II and RXR (49-53).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Recently, COUP-TF II and SpI have been demonstrated to synergistically regulate the transcription of the HIV type I LTR (54).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	278	 In support of our observations, they demonstrated that the in vitro and in vivo physical interaction with SpI is mediated by the DBD of COUP-TF.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Furthermore, the Octamer transcription factors are recruited by the C-region (DBD) of the glucocorticoid receptor (55).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	280	COUP-TF II-mediated repression of trans-activation involves the cofactor p300, since co-expression with p300 alleviates the silencing of transcription.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Our study suggested that repression may involve sequestration of this vital cofactor for myoD-mediated trans-activation, since COUP-TF II directly interacts with p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Whether inhibition of MyoD-dependent trans-activation by COUP-TF II binding is a result of: (i) a conformational change in MyoD (which is detrimental to function); (ii) a prevention of p300/cofactor/coactivator binding; (iii) and/or sequestering of cofactors (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	283	 p300) by COUP-TF II is unclear at present.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	284	 However, the in vitro GST-pulldown data does suggest that MyoD, COUP-TF II and p300 interact in a competitive manner, and that increasing amounts of COUP-TF II have the ability to reduce the interaction between myoD and p300 in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	285	Achatz and colleagues have demonstrated that repression of transcription by COUP-TF II activity is dependent on the DBD and a segment spanning aa residues 193-399 (30).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Single point mutations in the DBD that ablated sequence-specific binding did not affect the silencing of transcription.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	287	 (16) demonstrated that the repression of GAL4VP16-mediated trans-activation involves the DBD of COUP-TF II in the absence of its cognate binding motif.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Achatz suggested that the regions critical for repression of trans-activation by COUP-TF II were involved in mediating protein-protein interactions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	289	 In the present study, we show that the DBD and hinge region of COUP-TF II alone are sufficient to bind either MyoD or p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Deletions of COUP-TF II that contain only part of the DBD (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	291	 from aa 134), however, are not able to interact with the RID of p300, suggesting that the entire DBD is required for binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Although the DBD and hinge region functions as a dimerisation interface in COUP-TF II, we also observed that the presence of the E-region strengthens the specificity of the interaction (G.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	293	 While this manuscript was being reviewed, it was demonstrated by Froeschle et al.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	294	 (56) that the DBD of the retinoic acid receptor also directly interacts with MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Our data and the above data suggested that the DBD of the nuclear receptors may also encode a dimerisation interface for the bHLH family of proteins.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	296	Forced expression of COUP-TF II in C2 myogenic cells blocks differentiation and in particular ablates the induction of p21 mRNA expression (14).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Moreover, in normal proliferating C2 cells, COUP-TF II mRNA is expressed, however, during cell cycle withdrawal and differentiation, the mRNA levels are repressed (15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Transcription of the p21 gene is specifically stimulated by MyoD during myogenic differentiation, and is coactivated by a transcriptional complex that contains both p300 and PCAF (11).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	299	 In the present study, we show that MyoD-mediated transcription is significantly repressed by COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	300	 This suggests that COUP-TF II is involved in the maintenance of the proliferative state, by controlling the trans-activation of the p21 gene.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	301	Nuclear receptors have also been shown to interact with a growing family of PAS/bHLH domain coactivators (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	302	 SRC1/N-CoA-1, TIF-2/GRIP-1, ACTR/RAC-3/pCIP) (57-59).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	303	 However, the N-terminal bHLH/PAS domains in these coactivators function as activation domains, interact with other proteins or are involved in target gene specificity.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	304	 There has been no documented interactions between these regions of the cofactors and the nuclear receptors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	305	In conclusion, the present study provides evidence that suggests that one of the mechanisms that mediates repression of muscle differentiation and myogenic conversion by COUP-TF II involves direct interactions with MyoD and its coactivator, p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Whether the direct crosstalk between the orphan nuclear receptor and bHLH pathways has target gene specificity in a developmental context remains to be elucidated, and will be a focus of future studies in the context of mammalian differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	307	This investigation was supported by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) of Australia, and the University of Queensland Enabling Fund.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	308	 is an NHMRC Supported Senior Research Fellow.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	309	 The Centre for Molecular and Cellular Biology is the recipient of an Australia Research Council (ARC) special research grant.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	310	 (1995) Science, 267, 1018-1021.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	311	 (1995) Science, 267, 1024-1027.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	312	 (1997) Science, 278, 1947-1950.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	313	 (1994) Development, 120, 25-36.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	314	 (1993) Science, 260, 1117-1121.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	315	 (1998) Oncogene, 16, 3369-3378.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	316	 (1995) Science, 270, 1354-1357.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	317	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Tel: + 61 7 3365 4492; Fax: +61 7 3365 4388; Email: g.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	319	au This page is run by Oxford University Press, Great Clarendon Street, Oxford OX2 6DP, as part of the OUP Journals Comments and feedback: www-admin{at}oup.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	320	uk' + u + '@' + d + ''//--> Last modification: 21 Nov 1998 Copyright Oxford University Press, 1998.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	0	COUP-TFII is essential for radial and anteroposterior patterning of the stomach Norio Takamoto1, Li-Ru You1, Kelvin Moses1, Chin Chiang2, Warren E.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	1	 DeMayo1,4, Ming-Jer Tsai1,4,* and Sophia Y.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Department of Molecular and Cellular Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX 77030, USA 2 Department of Cell Biology and Neurosciences, University of South Alabama, Mobile, AL 36688, USA 3 Department of Cell and Developmental Biology, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, TN 37232,USA 4 Developmental Biological Program, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX 77030, USA.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	3	* Authors for correspondence (e-mail: stsai{at}bcm.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	4	edu' + u + '@' + d + ''//-->; mtsai{at}bcm.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	5	Key words: Nuclear orphan receptor, Sonic hedgehog, Organogenesis, Stomach, Mouse, Nr2f1, Nr2f2.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	6	Sonic hedgehog (Shh) patterns a variety of embryonic tissues, including the fore-stomach epithelium by signaling to the mesenchyme prior to organ regionalization (Chiang et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Shh-null mice exhibit inappropriate expression of alkaline-phosphatase (EAP) in the epithelium of the hind-stomach (Ramalho-Santos et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	8	, 2000), which is consistent with the stomach epithelium acquiring an intestinal or `posteriorized' character.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Conversely, the stomach of the activin receptor IIA and B compound mutant (ActRIIA/B mutant; Acvr2a/Acvr2b to Mouse Genome Informatics) exhibits posterior extension of the fore-stomach epithelium with expansion of Shh expression (Kim et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	10	, 2000), a process referred to as `anteriorization'.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These data suggest that Shh expression in the fore-stomach acts to induce and/or maintain non-intestinal character, resulting in the development of gastric epithelium (Ramalho-Santos et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	12	COUP-TF proteins are nuclear orphan receptors, highly conserved across species.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Two members have been identified in mice, COUP-TFI (Nr2f1 to Mouse Genome Informatics) and COUP-TFII (Nr2f2 to Mouse Genome Informatics).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The temporal and spatial expression pattern of COUP-TFII in mesenchyme led us to hypothesize that COUP-TFII plays a role in mesenchymal-epithelial interactions during organogenesis (Tsai and Tsai, 1997).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In the developing neural tube, Shh has been shown to regulate COUP-TFII expression during the differentiation of motoneurons (Lutz et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	16	 We have also identified a 5'-regulatory element that mediates Shh stimulation of COUP-TFII expression (Krishnan et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	17	 COUP-TFII is likely to be a downstream target of Shh signaling, and the requirement for Shh in gastric organogenesis led us to infer that COUP-TFII may play a role in stomach development.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	18	To circumvent the early embryonic lethality of the COUP-TFII-null mutation and to investigate its function during gastric organogenesis, we generated a conditional null mutant of COUP-TFII using the Cre/LoxP system.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Nkx3-2 (Bapx1) is a homeobox-containing gene (Tribioli et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	20	, 1997) that is coexpressed with COUP-TFII in the stomach primordium; thus, Nkx3-2Cre knock-in recombinase was used to ablate COUP-TFII in the gastric mesenchyme.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The stomachs of conditional mutant mice exhibited dysmorphogenesis accompanied by abnormalities of both compartmentalization and radial patterning, demonstrating a functional link between Shh and COUP-TFII.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	22	Nkx3-2Cre knock-in animal was generated by homologous recombination in ES cells (K.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Cre recombinase was inserted in-frame into the exon1 of Nkx3-2 locus.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	24	 No overt phenotype was found in heterozygous animals.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	25	X-gal staining X-gal staining was performed according to the published methods (Hogan et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	26	 For whole-mount staining, embryos (up to E10.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	27	5) were dissected and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, then stained in X-gal staining solution at room temperature.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Histological sections of whole-mount stained embryos were processed in Histoclear, embedded in paraffin, and sectioned at 10-12  microm.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Sections were cleared with Histoclear, rehydrated and counterstained with Eosin, and mounted with Permount.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	30	5 or later) and postnatal samples were cryoprotected with 20% sucrose/PBS solution after fixation with 2% paraformaldehyde and embedded in OCT compound.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Cryostat sections (16  microm) were briefly fixed in 2% paraformaldehyde, stained in X-gal staining solution and counterstained with Eosin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	32	Histological analysis Tissues were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, embedded in paraffin and sectioned at 5 or 7  microm.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Hematoxylin and Eosin staining was carried out according to the regular protocol.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	34	 For immunohistochemistry, paraffin sections were dewaxed, rehydrated and incubated with primary antibodies.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Antibodies against human CK14 (1:500) was a gift from Dr Roop (Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Polyclonal anti-serum against PGP9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Antibodies against TUJ1 (Convance, 1:1000), GATA4 (Santa Crutz, 1:400), H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit (Affinity BioReagents, 1:500) were used in immunostaining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Texas Red-tagged Griffonia simplicifolia II (GSII) lectin was used to stain the stomach tissue.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Positive staining for CK14 and PGP9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	40	5 was visualized by using biotinylated secondary antibody and streptavidin-horseraddish peroxidase conjugate, and NovaRed (Vector) as a chromogen.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	41	 SMA-, TUJ1, GATA4 and H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit were visualized by using biotinylated secondary antibody and streptavidin-horseraddish peroxidase conjugate, and DAB (Vector) as a chromogen.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Monoclonal anti--smooth muscle actin (SMA-, 1A4, 1:1000) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and immunostaining was performed using Mouse-On-Mouse kit (Vector) according to manufacturers instruction, and detected with AlxaFluor488 (Molecular Probes).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	43	 For ultrastructural study of the disorganized smooth muscle layer, 0.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	44	5  microm semi-thin sections were stained with Toluidine Blue.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Endogenous alkaline-phosphatase staining was performed as previously described (Ramalho-Santos et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	46	, 2002) and counterstained with Methyl Green.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The glycoconjugated production in parietal cells of the stomach was marked by DBA lectin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Whole-mount in situ hybridization for COUP-TFII was carried out as described (Qiu et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Probe for Shh was a gift from Dr M.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Scott (Stanford University, CA).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	51	 For section in situ hybridization of Shh, E11.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	52	5 embryos were cross-sectioned and Shh expressions in the fore-stomach were detected using 35S-UTP labeled probes.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Positive signals were pseudo-colored (red) and overlaid on bright field image of Hematoxylin staining as described (Pereira et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	54	Explants culture of embryonic foregut Foreguts were dissected from E10.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	55	5 lacZ knock-in heterozygous embryos and cultured on tissue-culture insert (Corning) with defined serum-free medium (Opti-MEMI, Invitrogen Life Technologies).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Explants were incubated with vehicle (DMSO), 1, 5 and 10  microM of cyclopamine (Toronto Research Chemicals) for 48 hours, and fixed with 2% paraformaldehyde for whole-mount lacZ staining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Explants from wild-type embryos were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde and used for whole-mount in situ hybridization.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	58	View larger version (57K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Expression of COUP-TFII in the stomach using lacZ knock-in model.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Generation of the lacZ knock-in allele and generation of floxed COUP-TFII allele.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Using homologous recombination, a targeting construct containing nuclear lacZ, Neo/TK and LoxP sites were inserted into the genomic COUP-TFII locus, generating a targeted allele in ES cells.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Treatment with Cre recombinase and FIAU selection resulted in a lacZ knock-in allele in which lacZ gene expression was controlled by the endogenous COUP-TFII promoter when recombination took place between the first and the third loxP sites of the targeted allele.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	63	 In addition, floxed COUP-TFII ES clones that retains COUP-TFII locus but lacks selection markers were generated when recombination took place between the second and the third loxP sites.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	64	 B, BamHI; H, HindIII; S, SalI; X, XbaI.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	65	5 heterozygous COUP-TFII/lacZ knock-in embryo were stained (for 2 hours) for lacZ activity.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	66	 There is relatively high expression in the mesenchymal cells just adjacent to the epithelium.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The stomach from a 3-day-old heterozygous knock-in animal was dissected and whole-mount X-gal staining was performed.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The boundary between stomach and duodenum is indicated by arrowhead.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	69	 (D) A cryostat section of stomach from adult heterozygous knock-in animal was stained for lacZ activity (blue) and counterstained with propidium iodide (red).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	70	 DBA lectin immunostaining denotes the parietal cells (green).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	71	 There is strong X-gal staining in the base layer and negligible staining in the surface pit layer of the adult Zymogenic unit.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	72	 m, mesenchyme; e, epithelium; fs, fore-stomach; hs, hind-stomach; d, duodenum; oe, esophagus.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	73	5, X-gal staining was detected in both the epithelium and mesenchyme of the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Brief staining of cryostat sections revealed that mesenchymal cells adjacent to the endoderm had higher expression of COUP-TFII than did distal mesenchymal cells, suggesting that a potential diffusible molecule, secreted from the epithelium might regulate COUP-TFII expression in the mesenchyme (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	75	 At postnatal day 3, COUP-TFII/lacZ was detected throughout the stomach (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	76	 1C), and was sharply downregulated in duodenum (red arrowhead indicates junction between stomach and duodenum).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	77	 COUP-TFII/lacZ was also expressed in the glandular epithelium of adult stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Adult glandular epithelium forms tubular structures, each of which is referred to as a zymogenic unit, which can be subdivided into four regions; a surface pit, an isthmus, a neck and a base that is located proximal to the sub mucosa (Karam and Leblond, 1993).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Strong lacZ staining was evident at the base, and much lower at surface pit layer (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	80	 To ensure COUP-TFII is also expressed in the parietal cells, we used DBA lectin for immunostaining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	81	 1D, X-gal and lectin-positive green cells colocalized, indicating that COUP-TFII is expressed in the parietal cells of the Zymogenic unit.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The expression pattern of COUP-TFII in the Zymogenic unit mimics the reported expression pattern of Shh in mouse stomach (van den Brink et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Thus, COUP-TFII is abundantly expressed from an early developmental stage in both epithelium and mesenchyme of the stomach in parallel with Shh.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	84	Nkx3-2Cre recombinase ablates COUP-TFII in the gastric mesenchyme To examine the role of COUP-TFII in gastric development, we chose to ablate the COUP-TFII gene in a tissue-specific manner using the Cre/LoxP system.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The targeting vector depicted in Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	86	 1A, was introduced into ES cells.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	87	 After excision of the Neo-TK cassette by Cre-based recombination, ES cells harboring the conditional allele were generated as depicted in Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	88	 1A and used to generate floxed COUP-TFII mice.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	89	 An Nkx3-2Cre mouse line was also generated (K.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	90	, unpublished), which was crossed with the floxed COUP-TFII mice.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	91	 As lacZ is only turned on in cells with COUP-TFII locus recombined or deleted, X-gal staining can be used as a marker for successful COUP-TFII recombined or deleted cells.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	92	5 stomach from Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/+ embryo demonstrates that COUP-TFII was ablated specifically in the gastric mesenchyme (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	93	 This is expected because X-gal staining of lacZ knock-in mice is detected only in the stomach primordium (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	94	 2A) which is similar to Nkx3-2-Cre expression at E9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	95	5, as demonstrated by the product of intercrossing the Nkx3-2Cre with ROSA26 reporter strain (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	96	View larger version (74K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Ablation of COUP-TFII in the mesenchyme of the developing stomach using Nkx3-2Cre and COUP-TFII floxed mice.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	98	 (A) Whole-mount X-gal staining of Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/+ embryo, demonstrating the ablation of COUP-TFII by Nkx3-2Cre at E9.

0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	105	 X-gal staining indicates Cre-mediated recombination and was detected throughout the gastric mesenchyme, but not in the epithelium, demonstrating the ablation of COUP-TFII in the gastric mesenchyme at E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Scale bars: in B, 100  microm for A,B; in C, 100  microm for C.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	107	  Conditional ablation of COUP-TFII in the gastric mesenchyme results in dysmorphogenesis and radial patterning defects of the developing stomach The size of the mutant stomach is slightly smaller when compared with the control littermate at E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Histological analysis of Hematoxylin and Eosin-stained sagittal sections of the mutant stomach showed that the epithelium is considerably thicker than the controls at E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	109	 In addition, the circular smooth layer, which is stained with -smooth muscle actin antibody, is disorganized in comparison with the controls at E13.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	110	 These abnormal morphological changes were again seen at E14.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	111	5 (data not shown), suggesting radial patterning of the stomach might be perturbed.

0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	115	 COUP-TFII floxed homozygote served as controls, and Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/flox were designated as conditional mutants.
