0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Bone morphogenetic protein-4 is required for mesoderm formation and patterning in the mouse.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	0	The Integrase of the Long Terminal Repeat-Retrotransposon Tf1 Has a Chromodomain That Modulates Integrase Activities* Amnon Hizi1 and Henry L.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Section on Eukaryotic Transposable Elements, Laboratory of Gene Regulation and Development, NICHD, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, June 10, 2005 , and in revised form, August 11, 2005.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	3	LTR-retrotransposons are closely related to retroviruses.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Both types of elements encode Gag, protease, reverse transcriptase, and IN proteins and both depend on IN to insert their cDNA into the genome of a host cell.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The LTRs, positioned at the ends of the cDNA, are subdivided into an upstream segment, U3, a central region, R, and a downstream segment, U5.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	6	 A large number of biochemical studies with purified IN have characterized the chemistry of insertion (10-12).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The INs of retroviruses have two activities that are necessary for the integration of the viral cDNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	8	 At first, 2 or 3 nucleotides are removed from the 3' ends of the LTRs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	9	 This site-specific nucleolytic cleavage or "3' processing reaction" is required to position the "CA" dinucleotides at the 3' ends of the cDNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The CA dinucleotides are conserved among all retroviruses and their position at the 3' ends of the cDNA is required for the second step of retrovirus integration, the "strand transfer reaction.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	11	" During this second step, the 3' hydroxyls of the terminal "A" act as nucleophiles in a pair of transesterification reactions that cleave the phosphodiester bonds in the target DNA and simultaneously make a covalent bond between the 3' ends of the viral DNA and the 5' ends of the target DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	12	In retroviruses, the minus strand primers initiate reverse transcription 2 or 3 nucleotides from the LTR and this results in additional nucleotides at the cDNA termini that IN removes during the processing reaction.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In the case of most LTR-retrotransposons the minus strand primers initiate reverse transcription with no added nucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	14	 As a result, these LTR-retrotransposons are thought to proceed to the strand transfer reaction without a processing step (13).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	15	The INs of retroviruses have three protease-resistant domains and the functions of these domains have been studied extensively (12, 14, 15).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The NH2-terminal domain contains a conserved motif similar to zinc fingers.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Although this domain does bind zinc, little else is known about its function.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The central domain is the catalytic core that contains highly conserved acidic residues, Asp, Asp, and Glu, that are juxtaposed on an RNase H-like fold.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	19	 These three amino acids are conserved in all the INs of retroviruses, LTR-retrotransposons, and DNA transposons (16).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The central domain of HIV-1 IN was shown to be sufficient for catalytic activity in in vitro assays for the reverse reaction of strand transfer known as disintegration (17).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The COOH-terminal domain is less well conserved but has nonspecific binding activity to DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Although the structure of individual domains has been determined for several INs, no single structure yet contains all three domains (18).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	23	Tf1 of Schizosaccharomyces pombe is one of the LTR-retrotransposons that contains a chromodomain at the COOH terminus of IN (8).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Its high level of transposition activity allows Tf1 to be studied as a model for reverse transcription and integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Expression of Tf1 from a high copy plasmid results in the formation of virus-like particles, the reverse transcription of the Tf1 mRNA, and the integration of the cDNA into intergenic sequences (19-21).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A novel mechanism of self-priming initiates minus strand reverse transcription from the upstream LTR (22).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	27	 After initiation, reverse transcription proceeds through the same intermediates typical of other LTR elements.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The IN of Tf1 that inserts this cDNA into the genome of S.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	29	 pombe contains putative zinc binding, catalytic core, and COOH-terminal domains that are necessary for integration (23).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Mutation analysis indicated that its high level of activity and the tools available to study it make Tf1 uniquely suited for examining the function of the chromodomain in integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	31	In this report the activities of Tf1 IN and the function of its chromodomain were studied.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	32	 IN and IN without the chromodomain (CH-) were expressed in bacteria and purified.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Biochemical assays for disintegration and strand transfer showed that IN possessed substantial activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Because Tf1 cDNA was predicted to terminate with CA, it was surprising that IN also had strong 3' processing activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	35	 This indicates that the position of the minus strand primer relative to the LTR is not sufficient to predict the presence of processing activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The most unexpected result was that CH- had significantly higher specific activity than IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	37	 In addition, CH- was much less dependent on specific sequences at the termini of the donor DNA than was IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	38	 These results reveal that the chromodomain in the Tf1 IN modulates both the level and specificity of integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	39	Purification of the Recombinant Full-length IN and CH- Proteins All steps were performed at 4  degrees C, unless otherwise stated.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	40	Lysis of the Bacteria The bacterial pellets were brought up in 50 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 8.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	41	1 M NaCl, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	42	 After a thorough mixing, the solutions were kept for 15 min on ice followed by the addition of more NaCl to a final concentration of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Then, the solutions were sonicated on ice, followed by the addition of Triton X-100 to a final concentration of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	44	 We have found that the presence of this detergent is critical to dissociate the recombinant INs off the bacterial DNA (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The insoluble material was removed by ultracentrifugation for 1 h in the Beckman SW28 rotor at 26,000 rpm and the clear yellowish supernatants were subjected to affinity purification.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	46	Affinity Purification on Sepharose-Co2+ Columns Sepharose-Co2+ columns (BD Talon, BD Biosciences) with bed volumes of 5 ml were equilibrated with 50 mM sodium phosphate, pH 8.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	47	5 M NaCl, 10% (v/v) glycerol, and 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	48	1% Triton X-100, and then loaded with the supernatant from the ultracentrifugation.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The column was then washed twice, once with 50 mM sodium phosphate, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	50	1% Triton X-100, and the second with the same buffer, supplemented with 20 mM imidazole.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Elution was performed with the same buffer but with a final concentration of 50 mM imidazole.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The fractions were all analyzed by SDS-PAGE, and the peak IN protein fractions were pooled and dialyzed against 50 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	53	5, 10% glycerol, 10 mM MgSO4, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM dithiothreitol, and 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The proteins were fully soluble after this dialysis.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	55	Heparin-Sepharose Column Purification Five-ml heparin-Sepharose (6, Fast Flow, Amersham Biosciences) columns were pre-washed with about 100 ml of the same buffer used for dialysis, and then loaded with the dialyzed protein solution.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The same buffer was also used for extensive washing (about 500 ml) of the column after loading was completed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Finally, the proteins were eluted off the affinity resin with a similar buffer, supplemented with NaCl at a final concentration of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The recombinant INs emerged off the columns at sharp peaks with protein concentrations as high as 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The proteins were stored at -80  degrees C in small aliquots.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Each aliquot was thawed only once for conducting the enzymatic assays.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	61	Oligonucleotides All oligonucleotides were gel purified.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Their sequences and designations are presented in the supplemental material.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	63	Substrates Used in IN Assays The appropriate DNA oligonucleotides were 5' end-labeled.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	64	4  microg of each oligo were 32P end-labeled using 20 units of T4 polynucleotide kinase (New England Biolabs), and 100  microCi of [-32P]ATP in a final volume of 20  microl using the buffer supplied.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	65	 After an incubation of 1 h at 37 degrees C, 1  microl of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	66	25 M EDTA was added to each sample and the mixtures were treated for 5 min at 95  degrees C to inactivate the enzyme.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	67	 After adding NaCl to a final concentration of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	68	1 M and increasing the volume to 40  microl, the labeled DNA was annealed to three times the equimolar ratio of the appropriate non-labeled DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	69	 After 5 min at 95  degrees C, the mixtures were allowed to cool slowly to room temperature for about 2 h.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The duplexes generated were then stored at -20  degrees C and were used after freezing and thawing for up to 1 month.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	71	Assays for IN Activities Unless otherwise stated, assays of IN and CH- were performed in final volumes of 20  microl containing 25 mM MOPS-NaOH, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	72	2, 4% (w/v) polyethylene glycol 8000, 10% (v/v) glycerol, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 6.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	73	25% (v/v) of freshly prepared dimethyl sulfoxide, and 1 mM MnCl2.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Each reaction mixture contained between 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	75	2 and 1  microg of the enzymes and 1 pmol of the labeled DNA substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Incubations were performed for 1 h at 37  degrees C, and reactions were stopped by adding 10  microl of formamide loading buffer (95% formamide, 20 mM EDTA, 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	77	5 mg/ml xylene cyanole FF) to each sample.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The samples were then treated for 3 min at 95  degrees C, quickly cooled on ice and loaded on an 8 M urea, 13.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	79	5% (w/v) polyacrylamide sequencing gel in Tris borate/EDTA buffer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	80	 After electrophoresis, the wet gels were subjected to phosphorimaging, using an Amersham Biosciences Storm 840 instrument.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	81	View larger version (26K):    FIGURE 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	82	 SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis of the purified recombinant Tf1 proteins.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The purification of the Tf1 IN and CH- proteins was performed as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	84	" One  microg of each purified protein and a mixture of size markers (M) containing 1  microg of protein in each band were loaded onto a 10% polyacrylamide-urea gel.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Following electrophoresis the proteins were stained with Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	86	  Purified recombinant HIV-1 IN (a generous gift of R.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Craigie) was assayed with the specified substrates under the optimal conditions of this enzyme that differ from those suitable to the Tf1 enzymes.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Reactions were performed each in 20  microl of 25 mM MOPS-NaOH, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	89	1 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, 10% glycerol, 10 mM -mercaptoethanol, 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	90	 All other steps, including preparation of the substrates, incubation times, and analyses of the reaction products were performed as described for the Tf1 INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	91	Under in vitro conditions INs can catalyze the reverse of DNA strand transfer in a reaction designated disintegration (10).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	92	 This activity can be assayed using oligonucleotides that mimic a single ended insertion (25-27).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The disintegration activity of Tf1 IN was studied first because the substrate sequence and structural requirements for this reaction are less stringent than those for the forward reactions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	94	The model substrate designed to measure disintegration activity is shown in Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The 5' end of the target DNA was labeled with 32P.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The reaction results in a concerted cleavage-ligation where the donor DNA is excised and the disrupted target is repaired.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	97	 This results in the production of a 63-nt product labeled with 32P at its 5' end.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Because of its size, the 63-nt product could be readily distinguished from the initial species labeled with 32P, the 20-nt substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Separate substrates were designed that mimicked either the U3 or U5 ends of the Tf1 LTR.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The IN and CH- proteins produced substantial amounts of the 63-nt product using either the U3 or U5 substrates (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	101	 We tested whether the disintegration substrates as designed for Tf1 IN could be recognized by another IN, that of HIV-1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Interestingly, HIV-1 IN is at least as active with the U3 and U5 substrates as the two Tf1 INs (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	103	 This is despite the low homology between the Tf1 and HIV-1 sequences at the ends of their donor DNAs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	104	View larger version (39K):    FIGURE 2.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The disintegration assay of Tf1 IN and CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	106	 A, schematic of the disintegration reaction.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The substrates for disintegration were oligonucleotides that mimicked one end of the Tf1 DNA inserted into a target.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The 5' end of the target DNA, indicated with an asterisk, was labeled with 32P.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The disintegration reaction results in the cleavage of the phosphodiester bond 3' to the terminal sequence, ACA, and the ligation of the labeled oligonucleotide to the remainder of the target molecule.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	110	 This led to an increase in the length of the 5' end-labeled oligonucleotide from 20 to 63 nt.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	111	 B, the disintegration activity of Tf1 IN, CH-, and HIV-1 IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Enzymatic reactions were conducted with equal amounts of the U3 or U5 substrates and 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The reaction products were resolved by electrophoresis on a urea-polyacrylamide sequencing gel.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The control lane shows a reaction mixture incubated with no enzyme and the U3 substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The control with the U5 substrate looked the same as the U3 (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The molecular weight markers (M) were HinFI fragments of X174 that were labeled on their 5' ends.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	117	  To optimize the reaction conditions we measured the influence of NaCl, MnCl2, and MgCl2 on the activities of IN and CH- (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	118	 NaCl greatly inhibited the activities of both proteins and a strong preference for MnCl2 over MgCl2 was observed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The highest disintegration activity was obtained with 25 mM MOPS-NaOH, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	120	2, 4% polyethylene glycol 8000, 10% glycerol, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 6.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Other additives, often used to enhance IN activities, such as, bovine serum albumin, spermidine, Triton X-100, or Me2SO at final concentrations above 6.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	122	25% were all found to inhibit the Tf1 INs (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	123	Having established the assay conditions for the Tf1 IN and the CH enzymes, dose-dependent reactions were performed with increasing amounts of each protein.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The quantitative data presented in Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	125	 4 show that for the U3 substrate the activity of IN increased with protein content up to 275 ng, whereas no maximum was observed with the U5 substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The data with CH- revealed the surprising result that the CH- protein was substantially more active than the full-length IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Although this was true for both the U3 and U5 substrates, it was with the U3 substrate that CH- exhibited the greatest increase in activity over that of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	128	Recombinant IN and CH- Possess Strand Transfer Activities Strand transfer assays are a more relevant measure of IN activities because they represent the forward reaction of integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The strand transfer activities of IN and CH- were assayed to determine whether these proteins were capable of mediating integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The substrates for these assays were double-stranded oligonucleotides designated to mimic either the U3 or U5 ends of Tf1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Initially, we used double-stranded oligonucleotides with blunt ends that terminated with the CA dinucleotide (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The oligonucleotide with the 3' CA was labeled at its 5' end with 32P.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Strand transfer results in the insertion of the oligonucleotides into other identical molecules and as a result oligonucleotides are created that are both bigger and smaller than their original size (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	134	 We found that the conditions established for the disintegration reaction are also optimal for the strand transfer activity of the Tf1 enzymes (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	135	View larger version (17K):    FIGURE 3.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The effect of NaCl and divalent cations on the disintegration activities of IN and CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	137	 These assays were performed with the U3 substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The reaction products were subjected to electrophoresis and the gels were scanned with a phosphorimager.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	139	 A, the dependence of disintegration activity on NaCl.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Increasing amounts of NaCl were added to the reaction mixtures.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Reactions were performed with 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The disintegration activity is expressed for each point as a percentage of the maximal activity observed at the lowest NaCl concentration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	143	 B, the effects of divalent cations on the disintegration activity of Tf1 IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The disintegration activity of 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	145	1  microg of Tf1 IN was measured with increasing concentrations of either MnCl2 or MgCl2.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The levels of conversion were calculated as described in A.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The activity for each divalent cation is expressed as a percentage of maximal activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	148	 C, the effects of divalent cations on the disintegration activity of CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	149	 The disintegration activity was assayed and quantified as described in B, except that each reaction contained 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	150	 5B shows that relative to protein dose, both the IN and CH- generated oligonucleotide products longer than the original U3 and U5 substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The lengths of these products varied because the integration into the acceptor DNA was relatively random.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	152	 However, it was apparent for both IN and CH- that with the U5 substrate there were preferred positions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Interestingly, a significant fraction of the extended products were longer than twice the size of the 24-nt substrate and products as long as 70-mers were observed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	154	 This indicates that both versions of Tf1 INs were capable of three or more integration events in which products of the first round of integration served as substrates for further integration events.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	155	 To our knowledge, such multiple round integrations have not been reported for other INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	156	We tested whether the chromodomain played a role in strand transfer by comparing the activity of IN to CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	157	 To evaluate the levels of strand transfer activity we calculated the amount of the oligonucleotide species longer than 24 nt as a percentage of the total amount of the labeled oligonucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	158	 5C shows that CH- was substantially more active than IN with both the U3 and U5 ends.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The elevated activity of CH- correlated well with the results of the disintegration assays.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	160	 However, the difference between the strand transfer activity of CH- and IN was more pronounced than observed for disintegration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The maximal differences in activity between CH- and IN were approximately 7- and 4-fold when observed with the U3 and U5 end-derived substrates, respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	162	 These results indicate that the presence of the chromodomain inhibits both the disintegration and strand transfer activities of Tf1 IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	163	View larger version (18K):    FIGURE 4.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The disintegration activities of IN and CH- in assays with increasing amounts of protein.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The reactions were conducted with either the U3 or U5 substrates and increasing amounts of Tf1 IN or CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The proteins were diluted in the buffer used to store the proteins (50 mM HEPES-NaOH, 10% glycerol, 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	167	05% Me2SO, 2 mM dithiothreitol, and 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	168	2) and equal volumes of the protein samples were added to each reaction.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	169	 After the reaction, products were subjected to electrophoresis and the gels were scanned with a phosphorimager.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	170	  CH- and IN Possess 3' End Processing Activity It is currently thought that the role of the 3' end processing activity of INs is solely to remove the 2 or 3 nucleotides 3' of the CA that result from the position of the minus strand primer 2 or 3 nucleotides downstream of the first LTR.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The primer for the minus strand of Tf1 is positioned adjacent to the LTR so it is predicted that no processing activity is required (28, 29).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	172	 However, sequences of Tf1 cDNA extracted from particles revealed the surprising result that 85% of the 3' ends had one or more untemplated nucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	173	4 Because these nucleotides are added to the 3' ends after the CA dinucleotide, they are expected to block integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	174	 We therefore speculated that Tf1 IN would have a processing activity that would remove these nucleotides to expose the CA dinucleotides and allow integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	175	We tested IN and CH- for the 3' processing activity using the assay already described for the strand transfer activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	176	 In this case, the 5' end-labeled substrates contained nucleotides positioned 3' to the critical CA (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Processing activity would cause a reduction in length of the labeled substrate after the extra sequences are removed from the 3' end.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	178	Processing the U5 End of the LTR The IN and CH- enzymes were tested for processing activity using a set of substrates that mimicked the U5 end of the LTR with sequences that extended past the conserved CA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Each of the oligonucleotide pairs were designed such that processing activity that removes nucleotides 3' of the CA would produce the same 24-nt product.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The 3' end extensions were either in the form of a single-stranded overhang (Ov) beyond the CA or they were base paired in the form of a blunt end (Bl).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The sequences of the extensions were chosen based on their presence at the 3' ends of the DNAs that were isolated in vivo from particles.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	182	 For example, the most prominent sequences observed after the U3 and U5 ends were "TT" and "AT," respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	183	4 In addition, longer stretches of "T"s were observed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	184	As indicated by the 24-nt product, both IN and CH- exhibited processing activity that specifically removed the nucleotides 3' of the CA (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The processing activity of IN produced the 24-nt sequence as the dominant product from the substrates with "tt," "at," "ttt," and "ttttt" as single-stranded extensions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In the one case of a substrate with a Bl end ("at"), IN generated the 24-nt species along with several other smaller products.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	187	 These additional products are seen to a lesser extent with the other substrates and are likely because of nonspecific nuclease activity of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	188	 This type of nonspecific activity is observed with other INs (30).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	189	 It is reported that a variety of INs possess an intrinsic DNA hydrolysis or alcoholysis activity that is responsible for nonspecific nuclease activity similar to what we observed (31).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	190	View larger version (41K):    FIGURE 5.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The strand transfer activities of IN and CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	192	 A, a schematic diagram of the strand transfer assay of the Tf1 IN and CH- enzymes with pre-processed substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	193	 B, the electrophoretic analyses of the products of the strand transfer reactions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	194	 For the U3 end, oligonucleotide HL1034 was 5' end-labeled and annealed to oligonucleotide HL1033.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	195	 For the U5 end, oligonucleotide HL1039 was 5' end-labeled and annealed to oligonucleotide HL1040.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Decreasing amounts of each enzyme were incubated with either substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The products were resolved electrophoretically.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The lanes marked 0 contained a reaction incubated with no enzyme.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The following are the lane numbers and the amounts of protein, expressed in  microg, used for each reaction: for IN: 1, 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The protein dilutions were done as described in the legend to Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The size markers included a disintegration reaction performed with U5 substrate and Tf1 IN, as described in the legend to Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Also included as markers was the X174 DNA cleaved with HinFI and 5' end-labeled.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	203	 C, quantitative analyses of strand transfer activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The radioactivity in the gel shown in B was scanned with a phosphorimager.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The radioactivity in all the bands larger than 24 nt was calculated as the percentage of the total radioactivity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The activities are expressed as the percent of conversion.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	207	  For retrovirus INs, the product of the processing activity is the only substrate suitable for strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Therefore, reactions with efficient processing activity also exhibit strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The processing activity of Tf1 IN with either the "at " or "tt" extensions was high and strand transfer was detected (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The processing activity with the 3- and 5-nucleotide extensions was less efficient and no strand transfer was observed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Thus, the IN of Tf1 was similar to INs of retroviruses in that processing was required for strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	212	The amounts of processed products accumulated by CH- were similar to that of IN (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	213	 However, CH- generated substantially more products of strand transfer than IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The levels of these strand transfer products greater than 24 nt were quantified.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The activity of CH- with all substrates was significantly higher than that of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	216	 For example, the activities with the tt-Ov was 57% and with at-Ov was 38% relative to that produced with the pre-processed substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The comparable figures for IN were 11 and 15%, respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Because the increase in strand transfer requires enhanced 3' end processing, these data indicate that the 3' end processing activity of CH- is higher than that of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	219	The efficient processing of the U5 substrates suggested that the Tf1 proteins specifically recognized and removed the extensions beyond the CA dinucleotide.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	220	 To test whether other sequences in the substrate were recognized, IN and CH- were assayed for activity using a substrate with the U5 sequence of HIV-1 (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The HIV-1 substrate was 21 nt long and had the physiological GT extension 3' of the CA dinucleotide.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Processing activity would reduce the 21-nt species to 19 nt.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Compared with the processing activity of HIV-1 IN with this substrate, the Tf1 proteins exhibited very little activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	224	 This indicates that in addition to the CA dinucleotide, the Tf1 proteins recognize sequence in the U5 substrate specific for Tf1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	225	 It was also seen that HIV-1 IN did not utilize the Tf1 pre-processed substrates (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	226	Processing the U3 End of the LTR Retroviral INs have processing activities that remove extensions 3' of the CA from both the U5 and U3 ends of the cDNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Because the Tf1 proteins were found to have processing activity on the U5 end, we tested whether they could also process extensions from the U3 end of Tf1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The results show that both CH- and IN can remove nucleotides 3' of the CA in the U3 sequence (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	229	 As seen with the U5 substrates, the shorter extensions on the U3 substrates were processed more efficiently than those with longer extensions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The cleavages of the Ov versions were somewhat more efficient than the Bl counterparts.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	231	The processing activity of CH- with 3-, 5-, and 6-nucleotide extensions was significantly greater than that of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	232	 However, comparing the activities of the proteins with the shorter extensions was complex because the strong strand transfer activity of CH- reduced the accumulation of the processed species.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	233	 To approximate the processing activities of IN and CH-, the levels of strand transfer were quantified.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	234	 As found above for the U5 substrates, CH- exhibited substantially higher levels of activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	235	 For example, the activities with tt-Ov was 88%, with tt-Bl was 32%, and with ttt-Ov was 19% of that produced with the pre-processed substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The comparable figures for IN were 11 and 4%, and not detectable, respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	237	Strand Transfer Activities Require Pre-processing of the Extensions 3' to CA The processing activities of IN and CH- were estimated by measuring the products of the subsequent strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	238	 This was done because the products of processing can be readily converted by strand transfer activity into larger oligonucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	239	 However, the accumulated products of strand transfer would be an overestimate of processing if the Tf1 proteins could mediate strand transfer with substrates that retained nucleotide extensions 3' to the CA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	240	 To test this possibility, strand transfer reactions were conducted with substrates that possessed a2',3'-dideoxynucleotide at their 3' end.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Unless removed by processing, this substrate would lack the necessary 3' hydroxyl and as a result it would block strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	242	View larger version (49K):    FIGURE 6.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	243	 The 3' end processing and strand transfer activities with the U5 substrates of Tf1 and with an HIV-1 substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	244	 A, a schematic diagram of the 3' processing assay shows the oligonucleotides annealed to mimic the U5 and U3 ends of Tf1 DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The asterisk indicates the 5' end of the oligonucleotide with the conserved CA labeled with 32P.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	246	 B, the electrophoretic analyses of the reaction products of the 3' processing assays.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Reactions were conducted with equal amounts of the specified substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	248	 The sequence from the 3' end of the substrates are shown above the lanes and extensions 3' to the conserved ACA are indicated in lowercase.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The substrate with the pre-processed end (ACA) was blunt ended and was the same one used in Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Substrates marked with Bl are double-stranded oligonucleotides with blunt ends.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Those marked Ov have 3' overhangs corresponding to the sequence in lowercase.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Other reactions were performed with a blunt ended substrate that mimics the U5 end of HIV-1 DNA with the additional two nucleotides, gt, 3' to the conserved CA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	253	 To generate this substrate the oligonucleotide RZ132 was 5' end-labeled and annealed to oligonucleotide RZ61.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The enzymatic reactions performed with Tf1 IN, Tf1 CH-, and HIV-1 IN were marked with a +, and those without enzyme were marked with a -.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The positions of the labeled oligonucleotides are indicated as 24 or 21 nt for the Tf1 or HIV-1 substrates, respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	256	  The experiment described in Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	257	 8 tested the U3 substrate of Tf1 that had 3' ends with the sequence "-ACA-tt(dd)c.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	258	" This substrate was compared with the control substrate that ended with a "c" instead of (dd)c.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Two variants of each DNA, one with a single-stranded Ov and the other with the Bl configuration were tested.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	260	 The CH- protein exhibited high levels of strand transfer with the blocked substrate ACA(t)2ddc-Ov, which were not significantly different from that with the unblocked DNA, ACA(t)2c-Ov.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	261	 This indicated that the strand transfer occurred only after an efficient removal of the blocking sequence.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	262	 The strand transfer activity with the Ov substrates was substantially greater than seen with the Bl versions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	263	 The full-length IN did not show significant activity with either the modified or unmodified substrates (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	264	The Strand Transfer Activity of Tf1 IN but Not CH- Specifically Requires That "ACA" Be Present at the 3' End of the Substrate The strand transfer activities of retrovirus and retrotransposon INs require that the highly conserved CA dinucleotide be present at the 3' end of the donor substrate (30).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	265	 We tested whether the IN of Tf1 had this same requirement for CA and whether the chromodomain contributed to this specificity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	266	 IN and CH- were tested for whether each of the last three nucleotides of the LTRs, ACA was necessary for strand transfer (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The substrates were based on the U3 double-stranded donor used in Figs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	268	 7 and 8 that lacked extensions 3' of the ACA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Thus, no 3' processing was required.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Single, double, and triple substitutions were made in the ACA to test the dependence on this triplet.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	271	 All the modifications introduced in the sequence led to a dramatic reduction of the strand transfer activity of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	272	 In sharp contrast to IN, CH- was capable of strand transfer with most of the substituted substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Except for the substrate in which all three terminal nucleotides were flipped (tgt), CH- had greater than 10% of the activity observed with the unsubstituted substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The most striking difference between CH- and IN was with the substrate with a -1 transition (AtA).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	275	 CH- retained 50% of the activity observed with the ACA terminus, whereas the full-length IN had just 1% activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	276	 This large difference in the specificity of the two related proteins shows that IN was far more stringent than the CH- counterpart in selecting the DNA donor with the correct 3' end.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	277	View larger version (83K):    FIGURE 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The 3' processing and strand transfer activities of Tf1 IN and CH- with U3 substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	279	 The reactions were conducted with equal amounts of the specified substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	280	 The labeling of the substrates above each lane is as described in the legend to Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The reactions performed with the specified enzymes are marked with + and those without enzyme are marked with -.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	282	The full-length version of Tf1 IN was found to have substantial levels of strand transfer activity with both the U3 and U5 substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The genomes of eukaryotes accumulate large numbers of inactive retrotransposons.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The strand transfer assay is a stringent test of IN function, and the activity of Tf1 IN detected here indicates that this protein was fully active.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Strand transfer assays with substrates containing nucleotides 3' to the CA revealed that the Tf1 IN also had 3' processing activity (Figs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	286	 This was observed with U3 and U5 substrates and with single and double-stranded extensions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	287	 As is the case with the 3' end processing activity of HIV-1 IN, extensions longer than 2 nucleotides were more readily removed when they were single-stranded than when double-stranded (37).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	288	View larger version (88K):    FIGURE 8.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The 3' end processing and strand transfer activities of Tf1 IN and CH- with substrates that contained blocked 3' ends.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Substrates ending with a 3'-terminal dideoxy C are indicated by ddc.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The experiment was performed and the annotations are as described in the legend to Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	292	  In one respect, the processing activity was quite unexpected.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	293	 It was thought that the 3' end processing activity of retroviruses and LTR-retrotransposons is required only in the cases where the priming of minus strand reverse transcription adds nucleotides beyond the conserved CA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	294	 For Tf1, the 3' end of the minus strand primer is immediately adjacent to the U5 sequence of the upstream LTR (28, 29).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	295	 As a result, no extensions and no processing were thought to occur.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	296	 However, recent analyses of Tf1 cDNA extracted from particles revealed that 85% of the U3 and U5 ends terminated with nontemplated nucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	297	4 The processing activity of IN observed here could in theory remove these 3' extensions and allow the bulk of the cDNA to participate in integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	298	 This model raises the question why would nontemplated nucleotides be added just so they could be removed by IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	299	 One possibility is that the nontemplated nucleotides could prevent aberrant annealing of the 3' end to sequences in the opposite LTR and its subsequent extension.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	300	 As a result, the nontemplated nucleotides would protect the completed cDNA until IN initiates 3' processing.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Another possibility is that the nontemplated nucleotides could protect the conserved CA from attack by nonspecific 3' exonucleases.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	302	View larger version (64K):    FIGURE 9.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The strand transfer activities of Tf1 IN and CH- with U3 substrates that contained sequence modifications of the terminal ACA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	304	 The modifications were marked by lowercase letters.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	305	 The activities with the modified substrates were compared with that of the pre-processed substrate (ACA).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	306	 All substrates tested possessed blunt ends and were used in equal amounts.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The reactions were conducted either in the presence of the specified enzyme (+) or in the absence of enzyme (-).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	308	  The LTR-retrotransposon Ty3 of Saccharomyces cerevisiae does contain an IN with 3' processing activity and this was predicted based on the position of its minus strand primer (38).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Nevertheless, most other LTR-retrotransposons such as Ty1 have minus strand primers immediately adjacent to the U5 sequence of their LTR and are not thought to have processing (39).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	310	 The finding that Tf1 IN has processing activity brings into question the predicted lack of processing activity in the INs of the other LTR-retrotransposons.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Approximately 25% of Ty1 cDNA terminates with nontemplated nucleotides (40).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The cDNA with the nontemplated additions could participate in integration only if the IN has processing activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	313	 However, analyses of Ty1 IN failed to detect processing activity (41, 42).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	314	The removal of nontemplated nucleotides by IN may also occur with retroviral cDNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	315	 In vitro experiments show that HIV-1 reverse transcriptase possesses terminal transferase activity that adds nontemplated nucleotides to the 3' end of the nascent DNA (43-45).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	316	 A time course of reverse transcription during HIV-1 infection identified a prominent species of cDNA that had one nucleotide extra on the 3' end of the plus strand (46).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	317	 This led the authors to propose that the extra nucleotide was the result of nontemplated addition and that the 3' processing activity of IN removed it.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	318	Perhaps the most striking results presented in this report indicate a role for the chromodomain in modulating integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Although removing 15% of IN might be expected to reduce activity substantially, the deletion of the chromodomain resulted in a intriguing increase in the disintegration and strand transfer activities.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	320	 CH- also had greater 3' processing activity than IN, assuming that the greater amounts of strand transfer products generated were all derived from processed oligonucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Evidence supporting this assumption was that oligonucleotides with the blocking nucleotide (dd)c 3' of the CA were just as efficiently converted into products of strand transfer by CH- as oligonucleotides without the (dd)c block (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	322	 These data indicate that the chromodomain of Tf1 IN negatively modulates the IN activities.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	323	In addition to its role in limiting integration activity, the chromodomain had a significant impact in restricting the sequence at the 3' end of the donor DNA that could function in strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Only when the chromodomain was present was there a strict requirement for the ACA at the 3' end of the donor DNA (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	325	 The strong specificity of the intact IN is in contrast to the IN of Ty1, which in similar types of assays can tolerate many alterations in the 3' end of the donor DNA (42).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	326	 However, INs of retroviruses, such as HIV-1, lack chromodomains and yet exhibit strict requirements for the sequences at the 3' end of the donor DNA (35, 37).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Thus, the chromodomain is not the only means for INs to achieve this strict requirement for the CA at the 3' end of donor oligonucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Therefore, it appears that in the case of Tf1 IN, the chromodomain evolved independently as a means of restricting donor sequences.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	329	Both contributions of the chromodomain, limiting IN activity and increasing sequence specificity, may result from a single mechanism that restricts access to the active site of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Although there are several examples of chromodomains that interact directly with histone H3, the lack of histone proteins in our assays indicates such an interaction is not required for the restrictive properties of the Tf1 chromodomain.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Functional analyses of several chromodomains recently revealed an unexpected diversity of interaction targets such as DNA and RNA (7).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	332	 It is possible that the chromodomain of Tf1 restricts IN activity through interactions with the donor DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Regardless of the mode of inhibition, there is the interesting possibility that in vivo, the inhibition is regulated.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	334	 One intriguing hypothesis is that the chromodomain does interact with histone H3 and it is this interaction at the target site that relieves the inhibitory function of the chromodomain.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	335	 The chromodomain of HP1 forms an organized cluster of strands and helices in response to its interaction with the NH2 terminus of H3 (32, 47).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	336	 This dramatic reorganization is consistent with a role in regulating integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	337	Although chromodomains are known to exist in many INs of LTR-retrotransposons (8, 9), the results reported here are the first direct effort to identify the function of the chromodomain in IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	338	 The restrictive role of the chromodomain identified here may very well be true for the other chromodomain containing INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	339	 In addition to INs, chromodomains have been identified in several other enzymes.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	340	 The H3 lysine 9-specific histone methyltransferase Su(var)3-9, the ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling factors, CHD, the DNA methyltransferase CMT, and the histone acetylase CDY, are all enzymes that contain chromodomains (7).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	341	 In light of the restrictive function of the chromodomain in Tf1 IN, it will be interesting to test how the chromodomains in these other proteins affect their enzymatic activities.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	342	The poor solubility of the recombinant INs studied thus far has been a major obstacle in producing high resolution structures.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	343	 High concentrations of salt or the introduction of amino acid substitutions have been necessary to solubilize individual domains of INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	344	 A number of structures have been determined for each of the three domains of the INs from the retroviruses HIV-1, simian immunodeficiency virus, avian sarcoma virus, and Rous sarcoma virus (18).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	345	 However, the lack of a structure for an intact IN makes it difficult to model the spatial relationships between the three domains.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	346	 During the purification of Tf1 IN it became clear that this IN was substantially more soluble than other integrases previously studied.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	347	 It is possible that this solubility will lead to the first crystal structure of a full-length IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	348	 This would serve as a significant leap in understanding the structures of INs in general and more specifically, of HIV-1 IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	349	 A structure of an intact IN would substantially facilitate the design and development of new drugs against HIV IN and, thus, contribute to the ongoing fight against AIDS.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	350	   FOOTNOTES   We dedicate this article to the memory of our colleague and good friend, Dr.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	0	Multiple Phosphorylation Events Control Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor I Orphan Nuclear Receptor Activity Frederique Gay1, Peter Barath, Christine Desbois-Le Peron, Raphael Metivier2, Remy Le Guevel, Darcy Birse and Gilles Salbert.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	1	Equipe Information et Programmation Cellulaire (F.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	2	) et Equipe Endocrinologie Moleculaire de la Reproduction (R.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	3	), Unite Mixte de Recherche 6026 Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Universite de Rennes I, Campus de Beaulieu, 35042 Rennes Cedex, France; Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics (P.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	4	), Arrhenius Laboratories for Natural Sciences, Stockholm University, Stockholm SE-106 91, Sweden.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	5	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Dr.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Gilles Salbert, Equipe Information et Programmation Cellulaire, Unite Mixte de Recherche 6026 Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Universite de Rennes I, Campus de Beaulieu, 35042 Rennes cedex, France.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	7	Initial studies identified COUP-TFs as transcriptional activators (19, 20, 21, 22); nevertheless, COUP-TFs can repress the transcriptional activation mediated by a number of ligand-bound nuclear receptors, including VDR, TRs, RXRs, and RARs (23, 24, 25, 26).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	8	 A functional cross-talk between COUP-TFs and retinoid-signaling pathways during development has been proposed, based on the comprehensively documented antagonistic effects of COUP-TFs on retinoid-dependent gene expression, and the observation that COUP-TF genes are themselves targeted by retinoids (7, 8, 15, 27, 28).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, recent data indicate that the orphan receptors can also serve as accessory factors for some ligand-bound nuclear receptors such as GR, ER, and RAR (29, 30, 31).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In some specific promoter contexts, COUP-TFs are thus able to enhance the ligand-induced transactivation function of these various receptors, suggesting that COUP-TFs may be required for effectively establishing the cues for certain genetic responses after exposure of the cell to a ligand.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In this respect, it is not surprising that common phenotypes, such as similar bone fusions, are generated in COUP-TFI-/- and RAR1-/-/RARss-/- independent knockout experiments (16, 32).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The recent finding that COUP-TFI is required for the induction of growth inhibition and apoptosis by retinoic acid in cancer cells further substantiates a positive interaction between COUP-TFs and retinoid receptors in vivo (31).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	13	With very few exceptions, most ligand-dependent nuclear receptors can be activated in a ligand-independent manner through phosphorylation events (33).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	14	 As an example, ER can activate transcription after phosphorylation, independent of supplemented E2 (33, 34, 35, 36, 37).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In a similar manner, many other ligand-regulated nuclear receptors are either activated or repressed through phosphorylation events (33, 34), and these regulatory mechanisms seem relevant also to the orphan receptors such as Nur77/NGFI-B, HNF-4 or ROR (38, 39, 40, 41).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Although COUP-TFs were cloned more than 10 yr ago, a ligand has yet to be elucidated or characterized, suggesting that COUP-TFs could be true orphan nuclear receptors.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The presence of several putative phosphorylation sites for MAPKs, PKC, and casein kinase II (CKII), within its sequence led us to postulate that COUP-TFI could be targeted by cellular kinases.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In this report, we demonstrate that COUP-TFI can be directly phosphorylated by PKC and MAPK, these phosphorylation events differently modulating COUP-TFI functions.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	19	 COUP-TFI is thus likely to be regulated by extracellular signals transduced through distinct phosphorylation pathways.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	20	View larger version (49K):    Figure 1.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The COUP-TFI Orphan Receptor Activates the Mouse Vn Gene Promoter through Direct Binding to a Consensus Half-Site.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The induction obtained with the wt promoter in the presence vs.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Results are shown as the mean  plus or minus  SEM of 12 (COS-7 cells) or 6 (P19 cells) values obtained in three and two independent experiments, respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	34	 EMSA analysis of COUP-TFI binding to the NR1 element is shown in panel D.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	35	 WCEs from COS-7 cells transfected with empty pcDNA3 (first lane) or pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI (other lanes) were incubated with the 32P-labeled double-stranded NR1 oligonucleotide and the complexes were resolved by nondenaturing electrophoresis.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The position of the specific COUP-TFI/NR1 complex, as assessed by supershifting analysis with the anti-hCOUP-TFI antibody (Ab), is indicated by an arrowhead.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Nonspecific bands are indicated by asterisks.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	38	 To estimate the affinity of COUP-TFI for the NR1 sequence, increasing amounts (2- to 10-fold molar excess) of NR1, DR1, and AP1 cold competitor oligonucleotides were added.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	39	  Prediction of Multiple Putative Phosphorylation Sites for Distinct Signaling Pathways within the Human COUP-TFI Sequence and in Vivo Phosphorylation of COUP-TFI As shown in Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	40	 2A, in silico analysis of the human COUP-TFI protein sequence revealed several putative phosphorylation sites targeted by distinct cellular kinases, namely CKII, PKC, and proline-directed kinases such as MAPKs.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The consensus phosphorylation sites were defined as S/TXXD/E for CKII (44), S/TXR/K for PKC (45), and PX1-2S/TP for the three distinct MAPK pathways identified in mammalian cells (46).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	42	 These pathways include members of the extracellular signal-regulated kinases ERK1/p44MAPK and ERK2/p42MAPK, the Jun NH2-terminal kinase and the p38 kinase (47, 48, 49).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The three putative MAPK phosphorylation sites identified within the human COUP-TFI sequence were found to be highly conserved throughout evolution (8), and were clustered in the amino-terminal A/B domain (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The putative CKII and PKC phosphorylation sites, some of which were also evolutionarily conserved (8), were in contrast distributed throughout the COUP-TFI sequence (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The DNA binding domain (DBD) contained exclusively PKC target sites, whereas the A/B and the putative ligand binding domain (LBD) of the receptor displayed both CKII and PKC potential target sequences (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The presence of several putative phosphorylation sites for various cellular kinases in the human COUP-TFI sequence raises the possibility that, similar to posttranslational modifications described for several nuclear receptors, COUP-TFI could be a phosphoprotein in vivo, whose activity may be regulated by specific phosphorylation events.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	47	 To test this hypothesis, we cloned the human COUP-TFI cDNA encoding residues 57 to 423 in frame with the glutathione-S-transferase (GST) coding sequence of the mammalian expression vector pBC/GST.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	48	 After mutation of the PKA site present in the GST sequence, the recombinant vector was transfected in COS-7 cells.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	49	 32P-Labeled orthophosphate was then added to label phosphoproteins in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Cell extracts were purified on glutathione-agarose beads and analyzed in SDS-PAGE.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The positions of GST and GST::COUP-TFI were determined by western blotting with an anti-GST antibody (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Results indicate that both GST and GST::COUP-TFI had been labeled in vivo (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Although a slight incorporation of 32P was observed for GST, the GST::COUP-TFI fusion protein was approximately 90 times more radioactive than free GST, indicating that COUP-TFI is indeed a phosphoprotein in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	54	View larger version (29K):    Figure 2.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The Human COUP-TFI Sequence Contains Multiple Putative Phosphorylation Sites and Is Phosphorylated in Vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	56	A, Positions of potential target sites for CKII (black arrowheads), PKC (open arrowheads), and MAPK (gray arrowheads) identified within the sequence of the human COUP-TFI receptor.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	57	 B, In vivo phosphorylation of COUP-TFI.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	58	 COS-7 cells were transfected with pBC/GST or pBC/GST-COUP-TFI 57 to 423 and treated with 32P orthophosphate.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Proteins were extracted and purified on glutathione-agarose beads before SDS-PAGE.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	60	 a, Autoradiogram; b, Coomassie Brilliant blue staining of the gel.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The positions of GST and GST::COUP-TFI were assessed by Western blot with anti-GST antibodies (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The autoradiographic signals as well as the protein levels were quantified to estimate the relative specific activity of the labeled proteins.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	63	 These activities are expressed as OD arbitrary unit per picomole of protein.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	64	  Multiple Phosphorylation Pathways Regulate COUP-TFI-Mediated Transcriptional Activation of the Vn Gene Promoter The functional relevance of phosphorylation events for the regulation of COUP-TFI activity was first assessed by using specific inhibitors for the three above described kinases in transfection experiments (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	65	 COS-7 cells were cotransfected with the COUP-TFI-dependent reporter gene Vn-luciferase (Luc) (containing the wt Vn gene promoter sequence, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	66	 1), in the presence or absence of increasing amounts of human COUP-TFI expression vector.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Cells were treated, or not treated, with DRB (5-6-dichloro-1-ss-D ribofuranosyl benzimidazole), a CKII inhibitor (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	68	 3A), or the p42MAPK/p44MAPK signaling pathway-specific inhibitor PD980059, or the PKC inhibitor GF 109203X (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Consistent with our previous results, cotransfection with increasing amounts of COUP-TFI expression plasmid led to a dose-dependent induction of reporter gene activity.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Neither the basal nor the stimulated transcriptional activity of the reporter gene was modified by treatment of the cells with DRB (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The expression level of COUP-TFI was also unaffected by this treatment (data not shown, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Based on these experiments defining that inhibition of the CKII pathway in vivo does not affect COUP-TFI-mediated transcriptional activation, it seems unlikely that this kinase regulates COUP-TFI function.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Whereas basal activity was not altered, treatment of the cells with PD980059 led to a significant decrease (76% inhibition of the activation) in reporter gene activity observed in the presence of 50 ng of COUP-TFI expression vector (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	74	 As assessed by Western blotting, this inhibition was not due to a decrease in nuclear receptor expression (data not shown, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The inhibitory effect of the specific MAPK inhibitor on the induction of the Vn gene promoter by COUP-TFI was not restricted to COS-7 cells as similar results were obtained in experiments utilizing P19 cells (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	76	 3B, treating cotransfected COS-7 cells with GF 109203X in the absence of expression vector did not influence basal activity.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In contrast, GF 109203X induced a marked reduction (60% inhibition of the activation) in the reporter gene activity observed in the presence of 50 ng of COUP-TFI expression vector (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Concurrent with the previous observation, the inhibition of COUP-TFI- induced reporter gene activity was not due to a reduced expression of COUP-TFI in COS-7 cells treated with GF 109203X (data not shown, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Thus, the blocking of either the p42MAPK/p44MAPK or the PKC signaling pathway results in a strong inhibition of the COUP-TFI-dependent transcription, suggesting that COUP-TFI function may be positively regulated by these kinases in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	80	View larger version (33K):    Figure 3.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Specific Inhibitors of MAPK and PKC Decrease COUP-TFI-Mediated Transcription.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The Selective Inhibitor of PKC Specifically Decreases COUP-TFI Binding to DNA in a Dose-Dependent Manner.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The position of COUP-TFI receptor is indicated by an arrowhead, whereas nonspecific bands are indicated by asterisks.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	98	  To determine the functional requirement of the phosphorylation-mediated regulation of COUP-TFI activity, similar cotransfection experiments were performed using expression vectors encoding truncated COUP-TFI receptors (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The COUP-TFI 57 to 423 protein is truncated at the amino-terminal region of the A/B domain, lacking a putative CKII and PKC phosphorylation sequence (S7), as well as two amino-terminal (T51 and T54) MAPK phosphorylation sites.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	100	 In addition to these four sites, the COUP-TFI 84 to 423 protein, which is deleted of almost the entire A/B domain (86 first amino acids), is devoid of the third putative MAPK phosphorylation site (T63) and of a CKII phosphorylation site (T66).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Western blotting showed that all the three constructs were efficiently expressed in COS-7 and displayed similar expression levels (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Independent of the amount of expression vector used, COUP-TFI 57 to 423 was able to stimulate the reporter gene activity to a similar extent to that observed with the equivalent dose of wild-type (wt) COUP-TFI expression vector (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Moreover, both PD980059 and GF 109203X efficiently counteracted the reporter gene activation mediated by 50 ng of COUP-TFI 57 to 423 expression vector.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	104	 This observation suggests that the region spanning residues 1 to 56 of COUP-TFI, including one PKC and two MAPK potential phosphorylation sites, is dispensable for transactivation and is not involved in the regulation of COUP-TFI activity by the PKC and MAPK pathways.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Cotransfection of COS-7 cells with increasing amounts of COUP-TFI 84 to 423 expression vector resulted in a weak stimulation of the reporter gene (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Experiments run in P19 cells gave similar results (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	107	 These data suggest that residues 57 to 83 play a crucial role, directly or indirectly, in the COUP-TFI-mediated transactivation, and raise the possibility that the third (T63) MAPK phosphorylation site could be a hierarchal requisite for COUP-TFI activity and for the MAPK-mediated regulation of the nuclear receptor functions.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	108	 This was, to some extent, confirmed by the observation that PD980059 is significantly less efficient in inhibiting the COUP-TFI 84 to 423-mediated transcriptional activation than it is in decreasing COUP-TFI 57 to 423-induced activation (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Indeed, the inhibition of COUP-TFI 84 to 423 and COUP-TFI 57 to 423 activity due to PD980059 was 58% and 89%, respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The residual effect of PD980059 on COUP-TFI 84 to 423-mediated transactivation suggests the involvement of an additional nonconsensus MAPK phosphorylation site located between residues 84 to 423, or that MAPK indirectly modulates COUP-TFI activity.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Finally, in cells cotransfected with 50 ng of COUP-TFI 84 to 423 expression vector, treatment with GF 109203X reduced the reporter gene activity to the basal level (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This last result implies that the potential phosphorylation site(s) targeted by PKC are located outside of the A/B domain (i.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	113	 All together, these findings strongly suggest that COUP-TFI activity is positively regulated by phosphorylation events in vivo, events that may be mediated by the p42MAPK/p44MAPK and PKC pathways.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	114	In Vitro Dephosphorylation Inhibits COUP-TFI Binding to Its DNA Target Sequences In an attempt to identify the functions of COUP-TFI that are controlled by phosphorylation events, we first focused on DNA binding activity, and investigated whether in vitro dephosphorylation of COUP-TFI could affect its ability to bind DNA elements (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	115	 In this study, COUP-TFI was expressed in COS-7 cells and whole-cell extracts (WCEs) from either untransfected or COUP-TFI-expressing cells were treated in vitro with calf intestinal phosphatase (CIP).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	116	 4A, incubation of untreated WCEs from COUP-TFI-expressing cells with labeled double-stranded DR1 oligonucleotide led to the formation of a complex species shifted in EMSA experiments as a single band (indicated by an arrowhead).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Supershifting experiments with anti-COUP-TFI antibody reduced the electrophoretic mobility of the retarded complex, confirming the presence of COUP-TFI in this complex.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	118	 In vitro treatment of the WCEs prepared from COUP-TFI-expressing cells with CIP buffer alone or CIP buffer and phosphate had no effect on the intensity of the shifted band, showing that neither of the compounds affected the binding of COUP-TFI to DNA elements.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	119	 In contrast, treatment of WCEs with CIP strongly decreased the intensity of the shifted band, providing evidence for a CIP-mediated decrease in the formation of the COUP-TFI/DR1 complex.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The hypothesis that CIP-mediated dephosphorylation of COUP-TFI inhibited nuclear receptor binding to specific DNA elements was further substantiated by the observation that addition of phosphate to the dephosphorylation mixture abolished the effect of the CIP.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	121	View larger version (29K):    Figure 4.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Dephosphorylation of COUP-TFI Inhibits Its Ability to Bind DNA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	123	Effects of the in vitro treatment with CIP on COUP-TFI binding to DNA were assessed by EMSA.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	125	5 U) and of a competitive inhibitor of CIP (NaPO4, lanes 5 and 7).
