0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 The Journal of Experimental Medicine, Volume 197, Number 6, 763-775 Detection of a Functional Hybrid Receptor c/GM-CSFRss in Human Hematopoietic CD34+ Cells J.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 U 506 Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale (INSERM), Hopital Paul Brousse, 94807 Villejuif, France 2 Istituto Gaslini, Largo Gerolamo Gaslini 516147 Genoa, Italy 3 Istituto Nazionale per la Ricerca sul Cancro, IST, Largo Rosanna Benzi 16132 Genoa, Italy 4 U 487 INSERM, IGR, 94800 Villejuif, France 5 U 268 INSERM, Hopital Paul Brousse, 94807 Villejuif, France 6 GenMab B.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	3	 University Medical Center Immunotherapy Laboratory, KC02.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	4	2 Lundlaan 6 3584 EA Utrecht, Netherlands 7 Forshungzentrum Borstel, Parkallee 22, D-23845 Borstel, Germany 8 INSERM E-0109, Bicetre, France 9 U 542 INSERM, Hopital Paul Brousse, 94807 Villejuif, France.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Bruno Azzarone, INSERM U542, Batiment Lavoisier, Hopital Paul Brousse, 94807 Villejuif, France.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Phone: 00-33-145595344; Fax: 00-33-145595343; E-mail: bazzarone{at}hotmail.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	7	Key Words: IL-15   GM-CSF   IL-15R   signal transduction   CD34+ cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	8	In this study, we demonstrate that normal CD34+ cells, but not nonhematopoietic cells, express a novel functional hybrid receptor composed of the c and GM-CSFRss chains, in which the GM-CSFRss chain may inhibit c/JAK3 signaling.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	9	 This complex is maintained in CD34+ myeloid and cord blood (CB)Pr CD34+/CD56- cells, but not in mature NK cells, suggesting that it is involved in controlling hematopoietic differentiation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	10	Isolation and Culture of Normal Polyclonal NK Cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Non-adherent PBMCs from healthy volunteers were isolated by centrifugation on a Ficoll gradient.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	12	 CD3-/CD4-/CD8- cells were purified by negative depletion and cultured with 100 U/ml rIL-2 (Proleukin; Chiron Corp.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	13	) in the presence of 105 irradiated allogenic PBMCs/well and 104 221 lymphoblastoid cells/well.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	14	 By day 15, almost all the proliferating cells expressed CD16 and CD56 antigens.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Human TF1ss (IL-15R/ss/c) and M07sb (IL-15Rss/c) are two IL-15 to dependent leukemic cell lines, whereas TF1 (IL-15R/c) is a GM-CSF to dependent cell line.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	16	 TF1 and TF1ss cells have the potential to display proerythroid differentiation whereas M07Sb cells display promegakaryocytic differentiation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	17	 NK-L is a functional human cytolytic NK cell line that is dependent on rIL-2.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Raji is a B cell line (IL-15R/c) that does not depend on growth factors for its proliferation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The growth characteristics and phenotypes of these cells have been reported elsewhere (21 to 25).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Cells were maintained in RPMI medium (Eurobio) supplemented with 10% FCS (ATGC Biotechnologie), 2 mM glutamine, 1% antibiotics (GIBCO BRL), 10 ng/ml rIL-15, or rGM-CSF (R and D Systems) at 37 degrees C, under an atmosphere of 5% CO2/95% air.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Cells were subcultured twice per week by seeding fresh culture medium with 105 cells/ml.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The human stromal fibroblast MS9 strain, isolated in culture from the spleen of a patient with a myeloproliferative syndrome, was used as a feeder layer for hematopoietic cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	23	 MS9 fibroblasts express a bioactive membrane-bound IL-15 that induces the NK cell differentiation of CD34+ cells; they also secrete GM-CSF (26, 27).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	24	 MS9 cells between passages 5 and 10 were cultured for 72 h at a density of 2 x 105 cells/ml in RPMI medium supplemented with 10% FCS in 6-well plates before being brought into contact with hematopoietic cells (5 x 105 cells/well).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	25	 TF1ss and NK-L cells were kindly provided by Drs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	26	 of Human Oncology, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI) and Alessandro Moretta (Department of Experimental Medicine, University of Genoa, Genoa, Italy), respectively.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	27	 TF1ss cells and Raji cells (3 x 105 cells/ml) were cultured for 4 d in complete growth medium supplemented with rIL-15 or rGM-CSF (10 ng/ml).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Sister cultures were treated with neutralizing anti to IL-15R M162 (developed by Immunex Corp.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	29	, provided by Genmab A/S, Copenhagen, Denmark), rat anti-c (TUGh4), and anti-GM-CSFRss (BD Biosciences/Becton Dickinson) mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	30	TF1ss cells (3 x 105 cells/ml) were also cultured for 4 d with MS9 stromal cells as the feeder layer.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Sister cultures were treated with anti to IL-15 (R and D Systems), anti to IL-15R M162, anti to IL-15Rss (CF-1; a gift from Dr.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Jacques, U463 INSERM, Nantes, France), anti-c (TUGh4), anti-GM-CSFRss, or anti-GM-CSFR (S-20; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In some inhibition experiments, we used low concentrations of anti to IL-15Rss and anti-c mAbs, because a combination of 1  microg/ml of each mAb is more efficient than a single dose of 10  microg/ml of each mAb at inhibiting IL-15 effects (23).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Cells were counted in triplicate.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The statistical significance of differences was determined using Student's t test, with P 0.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	36	Analysis of IL-15 Signal Transduction in the Human Hematopoietic TF1ss Cell Line and in CBPr CD34+/CD56- Precursors.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	37	 For signal transduction analysis, cells were incubated overnight with a low concentration of rIL-15 (0.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	38	5 ng/ml) and were then deprived of growth factors for 3 h at 37 degrees C.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Cells were then stimulated by incubation with 10 ng/ml rIL-15 for 5 to 15 min.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	40	 In some experiments, cells were initially treated for 1 h with either 10  microg/ml neutralizing antibody against IL-15, IL-15Rss, c, or GM-CSFRss chains or with the JAK3-specific inhibitor, WHI-P131 (Calbiochem), which has no effect on JAK1 and JAK2.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	41	Immunoblotting: Western Blotting.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Experiments were performed as described previously (12, 14, 28, 29).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Briefly, cultures were serum-starved to reduce basal phosphorylation levels.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Cells were then washed twice and suspended in lysis buffer supplemented with 0.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	45	 For immunoprecipitation, lysates were incubated with anti-c (TUGh4), anti-JAK3 (Upstate Biotechnology) or polyclonal anti-TRAF2 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	46	) antibody and immune complexes were captured by incubation with protein G-Sepharose beads (Amersham Biosciences) overnight at 4 degrees C.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The captured immune complexes were washed twice with lysis buffer.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Complexes or lysates (for Western blotting) were then dissolved in Laemmli buffer, boiled, and separated by SDS-PAGE (7.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The protein bands were transferred to PVDF membranes (NEN Life Science Products).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Membranes were blocked by incubation with 5% BSA and probed with the following antibodies: anti-JAK1, anti-JAK2, and 4G10 anti-phosphotyrosine (Upstate Biotechnology/USA Euromodex), anti-pJAK1 (Tyr 1022/1023), anti-pJAK2 (Tyr 1007/Tyr 1008), anti-STAT3, anti-pSTAT3 (Tyr705), and anti-STAT6 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	51	), anti-STAT5 (Transduction Laboratories/Becton Dickinson), anti-pSTAT5 (Tyr694), anti-pSTAT6 (Tyr641; Cell Signaling/New England Biolabs, Inc.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	52	Primary antibody binding to the membrane was detected by incubation with peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies, followed by the enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) system (Amersham Biosciences).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The membrane was then subjected to densitometry, including correction for background, with analysis using NIH Image software.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	54	 To correct for possible variations in the amount of protein loaded, values are expressed as pSTAT/STAT ratios.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Results are expressed as increases (e.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	56	, three times) with respect to the results obtained for untreated cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	57	 For the double staining of c and GM-CSFRss chains, human MPB and CB CD34+ cells, the leukemic cell lines (TF1, TF1ss, and M07sb), and MS9 cells were washed and permeabilized by incubation with ORTHOpermeafix (Ortho Diagnostic Systems Inc.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	58	) for 45 min at room temperature.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Cells were then stained with anti-c (TUGh4) mAb and with the biotinylated anti to GM-CSFRss secondary mAb, and were then incubated at room temperature with Alexa Fluor594-GAR and streptavidin-Alexa Fluor594 (Molecular Probes).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The extent of association between the two chains was assessed using the colocalization option of Methamorphe Software (Universal Imagine).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	61	 We also used confocal microscopy to evaluate production of the activated transcription factor, pSTAT5, in TF1ss and M07sb cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Cells were starved of growth factors overnight and were then stimulated with rGM-CSF, as described above.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Some samples were pretreated with anti to IL-15ss/c or anti to GM-CSFRss mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Cells were then permeabilized and indirect immunofluorescence assessed by means of antibodies recognizing the phosphorylated form of the transcription factor STAT5 (pSTAT5).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Samples were washed and incubated with Alexa Fluor488-GARa antibody.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Nuclei were stained with 2  microg/ml propidium iodide (PI, red staining).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	67	 All antibodies were dissolved in PBS supplemented with 10 mg/ml BSA to block nonspecific binding.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The stained cells were washed with PBS, centrifuged in a Cytospin 3 (Shandon) onto glass slides, and mounted under a coverslip in Prolong Antifade (Molecular Probes) mounting medium.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The slides were analyzed by laser scanning confocal microscopy, using a Leica TCS Confocal System.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	70	View larger version (60K):    Figure 1.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	71	 c/GM-CSFRss interaction in human hematopoietic and nonhematopoietic cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	72	 (A) Western blots of total lysates.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	73	 MPB CD34+ cells, TF1, and M07Sb promyeloid CD34+ cell lines were analyzed for the expression for c and GM-CSFRss chains.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Briefly, cell lysates were subjected to electrophoresis and the protein bands were transferred to PVDF membranes.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The total lysate membranes (Tot.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	76	lys) were then probed with anti-c or anti to GM-CSFRss mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The data shown are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	78	 (B) Coimmunoprecipitation MPB CD34+ cells, CBPr CD34+/CD56- and normal polyclonal NK cells (panel a), TF1, TF1ss, MO7sb promyeloid CD34+and NK-L cell lines (panel b) and human skin myofibroblasts (panel c) were analyzed for c/GM-CSFRss interactions.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Briefly, total lysates were subjected to immunoprecipitation (IP) with an anti-c antibody.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Immunoprecipitates were subjected to electrophoresis and the protein bands were transferred to PVDF membranes.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Membranes corresponding to the c immunoprecipitate and to total lysates (Tot.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	82	lys) were probed with anti-c or anti-GM-CSFRss mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Analysis by confocal microscopy of the interactions between the c chain (green staining) and GM-CSFRss (red staining) in MPB CD34+ cells (panel a1), CBPr CD34+ cells (panel a2), TF1 cells (panel b1), TF1ss cells (panel b2), M07Sb (panel b3), and MS9 spleen myofibroblasts (panel c).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	85	 As specificity controls, we analyzed the interactions between the c chain (green staining) and IL-6R gp130 (red staining, panel d) or between the c chain (green staining) and ss1 integrin (red staining, panel e) in CB CD34+ cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The images presented are compacted overlay pictures from serial optical sections, 1  microm thick, from the outside to the inner compartments of the cell.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The yellow staining indicates colocalization of the various molecules.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	89	  Human MPB CD34+ cells, CBPr CD34+/CD56- progenitors and normal polyclonal NK cells were immunoprecipitated with anti-c mAb, and the c membranes were reprobed with mAbs recognizing the c and GM-CSFRss chains.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Reprobing with the anti-c mAb confirmed the presence of a specific 64 kD band, whereas reprobing with anti to GM-CSFRss mAb resulted in detection of the specific 130 kD band in MPB CD34+ and CBPr CD34+/CD56- cells, but not in polyclonal NK cells from normal donors (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Thus, normal human CD34+ cells express a c/GM-CSFRss complex, which is not detectable in mature NK cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	92	The c/GM-CSFRss association was also detected both in the proerythroid TF1 and TF1ss cell lines, which expressed IL-15R/c and IL-15R/ss/c, respectively, and in the promegakaryocytic (M07sb) cells expressing IL-15Rss/c, whereas it was not detected in the cytolytic NK-L cell line (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	93	 In addition, the c/GM-CSFRss complex was not found in human skin myofibroblasts despite the presence of the c and GM-CSFRss chains in these cells (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Reprobing the c membrane with anti-GM-CSFR or anti-gp130 mAbs did not give a specific signal (unpublished data).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	95	We demonstrated, by confocal microscopy, the colocalization of the c (green staining) and GM-CSFRss (red staining) chains in MPB and CB CD34+ progenitors, as well as in the TF1, TF1ss and M07sb cell lines (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The images presented are overlay-compacted images from confocal analysis of 1  microm serial optical sections from the cell surface to the inner compartment.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	97	In MPB CD34+ and unprimed CB CD34+ cells (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	98	 1 C, panels a1 and a2), all cells displayed strong colocalization of the two molecules (yellow staining), restricted to the membrane/submembrane compartment.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	99	 1 C, panels b1 and b2), we observed similar yellow staining of the membrane/submembrane compartment and spotted yellow staining in the cytoplasm, suggesting that the hybrid receptor was taken up by some of the cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	100	 This punctate distribution of the c/GM-CSFRss complex in the cytoplasms was the predominant staining pattern in M07sb cells (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	101	 No colocalization was observed in human MS9 myofibroblasts (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The specificity of c and GM-CSFRss chain colocalization was further confirmed by the lack of colocalization of the c chain and the IL-6R subunit gp130 (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	103	 1 C, panel d) or the ss1 integrin (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	104	 1 C, panel e) in normal CB CD34+ cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Computerized quantification of the extent to which the c chain and the GM-CSFRss chain were colocalized in normal and leukemic CD34+ cells showed that 74.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	106	3% (M07sb) of the GM-CSFRss chain colocalized with the c chain, whereas 94.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	107	6% (M07sb) of the c chain colocalized with the GM-CSFRss chain.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Our results indicate that the c chain is almost completely associated with the GM-CSFRss chain, with 30 to 40% of the GM-CSFRss chain left free.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	109	The expression of this hybrid receptor is constitutive and does not seem to be influenced by cytokine stimulation, as it is observed in CB hematopoietic progenitors, whether unprimed or treated with SCF/Flt3-L, in MPB CD34+ cells, and in CD34+ myeloid cell lines, which are dependent on GM-CSF (TF1) or IL-15 (TF1ss, M07sb) for growth.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	110	IL-15 to  and GM-CSF to dependent Proliferation in TF1ss Cells Is Modified by Anti to GM-CSFRss and Anti-c mAbs, Respectively.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The presence of the hybrid receptor on CD34+ cells dependent on IL-15 or GM-CSF led us to investigate the role of this receptor in cell proliferation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	112	 2 A, TF1ss cells proliferated in the presence of rIL-15 (+200%) or rGM-CSF (+300%).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	113	 IL-15 to dependent proliferation was inhibited by anti to IL-15R, but not by anti-c mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Anti-GM-CSFRss mAb slightly, but significantly increased (+20 to 25%, P  <  0.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	115	001) the rate of cell proliferation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	116	View larger version (26K):    Figure 2.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Proliferation induced by rIL-15 and rGM-CSF: IL-15R/GM-CSFR cross talk in TF1ss cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	118	 (A) Proliferative response of TF1ss cells to recombinant IL-15 and GM-CSF.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	119	 TF1ss (IL-15R/ss/c) CD34+ cells were cultured for 4 d with rIL-15 or rGM-CSF (10 ng/ml) and their proliferation potential was then analyzed.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Sister cultures were continuously incubated with neutralizing mAbs recognizing the IL-15R, c, and GM-CSFRss chains.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In TF1ss cells cultured with rIL-15, the proliferation rates of samples treated with an anti to GM-CSFRss mAb were significantly higher (+25%; P  <  0.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	122	001) than those of samples incubated with rIL-15 alone or with rIL-15 plus an anti-c mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	123	 (B) Proliferative response of Raji cells to rIL-15.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Raji cells (IL-15R/c) were cultured for 4 d with rIL-15 (10 ng/ml) and analyzed for proliferation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Sister cultures were continuously incubated with neutralizing mAbs recognizing the IL-15R, c, and GM-CSFRss chains.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	126	 (C) Proliferative response of TF1ss cells to MS9 cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	127	 TF1ss cells were cocultured for 4 d with MS9 cells and analyzed for proliferation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Sister cultures were continuously incubated with neutralizing mAbs recognizing the GM-CSFR, GM-CSFRss, IL-15Rss/c, IL-15R chains, and IL-15.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Cells were counted in an electronic Coulter counter and the data are expressed as % difference in proliferative potential with respect to control untreated samples.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	131	  In contrast, GM-CSF to dependent proliferation was totally inhibited not only by anti to GM-CSFRss mAb, but also by anti-c mAb, further suggesting that there is cross talk between these two cytokine receptors in these cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	132	 As a control, we used the Raji cell line, the growth of which is not dependent on IL-15, and which expresses IL-15R and c, but not IL-15Rss chains (reference 30; Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	133	 After 4 d in culture, Raji cells fed with DMEM supplemented with 10% FCS proliferated, resulting in a 200% increase in cell density.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The addition of 10 ng/ml of rIL-15 increased the proliferation of these cells (+30%).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	135	 This effect was inhibited by anti-IL-15R mAb, but not by anti-c or anti-GM-CSFRss mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Anti to IL-15 and anti to IL-15R mAbs have been shown to have similar effects on Raji cells (25).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	137	We investigated whether the growth of TF1ss cells could be stimulated by contact with human stromal MS9 cells, which have been shown to secrete several hematopoietic growth factors (26), and whether the hybrid receptor was involved in these interactions.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	138	 TF1ss cells proliferated when cultured in contact with MS9 cells, doubling in number after 4 d (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The proliferation induced by MS9 cells was totally inhibited by neutralizing mAbs against the GM-CSFR and GM-CSFRss chains.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Neutralizing mAbs directed against IL-15 or the IL-15R chain had no effect whereas anti to IL-15Rss/c mAbs inhibited the proliferation of TF1ss cells by 60%.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Thus, TF1ss cell proliferation is completely dependent on GM-CSF produced by MS9 cells (26) and can be efficiently inhibited by anti to IL-15Rss/c mAbs, consistent with the existence of cross talk between the two cytokine receptors.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	142	IL-15 to induced JAK/STAT Signaling Is Inhibited by Anti to GM-CSFRss mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The inability of the anti-c mAb to block IL-15 to dependent proliferation in TF1ss cells suggests that the c chain cannot mediate the effects of IL-15 in these cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	144	 We investigated the signal transduction triggered by IL-15 and the involvement of the various subunits of the IL-15R, in TF1ss cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	145	Densitometric analysis revealed that rIL-15 (10 ng/ml) caused the levels of phosphorylation of JAK1 and STAT3 to increase by a factor of seven within 15 min (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Neutralizing anti to IL-15Rss mAb totally inhibited the phosphorylation of JAK1 and inhibited that of STAT3 by 50%.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In contrast, anti-c mAb had no effect on either pathway.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	148	 These data confirm the results of the proliferation assays, demonstrating the incapacity of the c chain to mediate IL-15 to dependent functions in TF1ss cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	149	View larger version (43K):    Figure 3.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	150	 IL-15 signal transduction: IL-15R/GM-CSFR cross talk in TF1ss cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Analysis of JAK/STAT signal transduction by Western blotting.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	152	 TF1ss cells were incubated with 10 ng/ml rIL-15 for 15 min at 37 degrees C.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Sister cultures were pretreated for 1 h with neutralizing anti to IL-15Rss/c, anti-GM-CSFRss, or anti-IL-6R gp130 mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Cell extracts were analyzed by Western blotting using anti-phospho-JAK1 (pJAK1), anti-phospho-JAK2 (pJAK2), anti-phospho-TYK2 (pTYK2), anti-phospho-STAT5 (pSTAT5), and anti-phospho-STAT6 (pSTAT6) antibodies.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Membranes were then reprobed with antibodies recognizing the native proteins.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	156	 To correct for possible variations in the amount of protein loaded, values are expressed as pJAK/JAK or pSTAT/STAT ratios.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	157	 pJAK/JAK and pSTAT/STAT levels were determined by densitometry including correction for background (NIH Image software).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Results are expressed as increases (e.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	159	, two times) with respect to untreated cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	161	  We then investigated whether the GM-CSFRss chain interfered with c chain activity, as suggested by the results of the proliferation assays.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Constitutive levels of JAK1, JAK2, STAT5, and STAT6 phosphorylation were low in TF1ss cells (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Densitometric analysis showed that rIL-15 (10 ng/ml) induced an increase by a factor of at least two in the level of phosphorylation of all of these molecules, within 15 min.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The phosphorylation of JAK1, STAT5, and STAT6 was totally inhibited not only by the synergistic combination of anti to IL-15Rss and anti-c mAbs, but also by neutralizing anti to GM-CSFRss mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	165	In contrast, JAK2 phosphorylation was totally inhibited by anti to IL-15Rss/c mAb but was only inhibited by 30% with the anti-GM-CSFRss mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The use of an isotype-matched anti-gp130 mAb had no significant effect on the level of phosphorylation of the various molecules.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	167	 In contrast to what was observed in TF1ss cells, anti to GM-CSFRss mAb did not affect IL-15 signaling in CD34+ promegakaryocytic M07sb cells expressing a low-affinity IL-15Rss/c receptor (unpublished data).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	168	GM-CSF to induced pSTAT5 Nuclear Translocation Is Inhibited by Anti to IL-15Rss/c mAbs in TF1ss Cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	169	 We analyzed the effects of anti to IL-15Rss/c mAbs on the signal transduction activated by rGM-CSF (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Densitometric analysis revealed that rGM-CSF (at a concentration of 10 ng/ml) doubled the phosphorylation of JAK2 and quadrupled that of STAT5 in TF1ss cells in a 15-min period.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	171	 In experiments with anti to IL-15Rss/c mAbs, the specific JAK3 inhibitor WHI-P31 or the irrelevant anti-gp130 mAb, we observed no significant inhibition of either pathway, which demonstrated that neither of the two chains of the IL-15R affected these steps of GM-CSF signaling.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The effects of rGM-CSF and IL-15Rss/c mAbs on the localization of pSTAT5 were analyzed by confocal microscopy (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Cells were stained for pSTAT5 (green staining) and with propidium iodide (specific for nuclei; red staining); superimposition of the two stains gave a yellow coloration.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	174	 In basal culture conditions, all cells displayed green staining of the cytoplasm, indicating the presence of pSTAT5 protein in this compartment.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The intensity of the green staining increased after GM-CSF stimulation suggesting that the level of STAT5 phosphorylation increased.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	176	 No inhibition was observed in the presence of neutralizing anti-IL-15Rss/c mAbs, or of the specific JAK3 inhibitor WHI-P31 (unpublished data), confirming the results obtained by Western blotting.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	177	View larger version (50K):    Figure 4.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	178	 GM-CSF signal transduction: IL-15R/GM-CSFR cross talk in TF1ss cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	179	 (A) Analysis of JAK2/STAT5 signal transduction by Western blotting.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	180	 TF1ss cells were incubated with 10 ng/ml rGM-CSF for 15 min at 37 degrees C.
