0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Membranes were then reprobed with antibodies recognizing the native proteins.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	184	 To correct for possible variations in the amount of protein loaded, values are expressed as pJAK/JAK or pSTAT/STAT ratios.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	185	 pJAK/JAK and pSTAT/STAT levels were determined by densitometry, including correction for background (NIH Image software).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Results are expressed as an increase (e.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	187	, two times) with respect to untreated cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	189	 (B) Analysis of pSTAT5 nuclear localization by confocal microscopy.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	190	 TF1ss cells were incubated with 10 ng/ml rGM-CSF for 15 min at 37 degrees C.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Sister cultures were pretreated for 1 h with neutralizing anti-IL-15Rss/c mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Control (basal) and treated cultures were analyzed by confocal microscopy for pSTAT5 distribution in the cell, focusing particularly on whether this protein was present in the nucleus.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Propidium iodide stains nuclei red whereas pSTAT5 is stained green.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Yellow staining indicates the presence of pSTAT5 in the nucleus.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	195	  In basal culture conditions, only a few cells displayed yellow staining indicating the presence of pSTAT5 in the nucleus.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Control cultures displayed only red nuclear staining when treated with PI and the second reagent.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Short-term stimulation with rGM-CSF (15 min) induced the massive nuclear translocation of pSTAT5 in 30% of the cells, as demonstrated by intense yellow staining of the nucleus.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Finally, anti to IL-15Rss/c mAbs efficiently inhibited the effects of rGM-CSF on pSTAT5 nuclear translocation, as shown by a loss of the yellow staining, whereas the isotype-matched anti-gp130 mAb had no effect (unpublished data).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The effects on STAT5 of anti-IL-15Rss/c mAbs and of the specific JAK3 inhibitor WHI-P31 were also observed in M07Sb cells (unpublished data).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	200	TF1 Cells Express Functional IL-15R/c Complex, the Formation of which Is Controlled by the Hybrid c/GM-CSFRss Receptor.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The absence of proliferation in IL-15R/c-positive TF1 cells in response to IL-15 has been attributed to the lack of the IL-15Rss subunit (23), which is indispensable for IL-15 binding and c chain signaling (7).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	202	 However, it has recently been reported that the IL-15R chain may transduce a signal in the absence of links with any other receptor subunit (12), leading to NF-B activation via the cytoplasmic interaction of this molecule with the signaling molecule TRAF2.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	203	 We therefore investigated the possible presence of a functional IL-15R/c receptor in TF1 cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Analysis of total lysates showed that the TF1 and TF1ss cell lines expressed the c chain (64 kD) and at least two IL-15R isoforms, 58 and 38 kD in size (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The two cell lines were then incubated with an anti-c mAb for immunoprecipitation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The c membrane was reprobed with the anti-c mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	207	 A strong specific signal was identified at 64 kD.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In contrast, two major bands, 58 and 38 kD in size, were identified if the membrane was reprobed with anti to IL-15R mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Thus, in both TF1 and TF1ss cells, the c chain is physically associated with the two IL-15R isoforms.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	210	View larger version (42K):    Figure 5.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	211	 IL-15R/c interaction in TF1 and TF1ss cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	212	 TF1 and TF1ss cells were analyzed for IL-15R/c interactions.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Briefly, lysates were subjected to immunoprecipitation (IP) with an anti-c antibody.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Immunoprecipitates were subjected to electrophoresis and the protein bands were transferred to PVDF membranes.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Membranes corresponding to immunoprecipitated c and total lysates (Tot.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	216	) were probed with anti-c or anti to IL-15R mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	218	 (B) Analysis of JAK3 phosphorylation by Western blotting.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	219	 TF1 and TF1ss cells were incubated with 10 ng/ml rIL-15 for 15 min at 37 degrees C.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Sister cultures were pretreated for 1 h with neutralizing anti to IL-15R, anti to GM-CSFRss, and anti-gp130 mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Cell extracts were subjected to immunoprecipitation with an anti-JAK3 mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	222	 JAK3 membranes were then re-probed with anti-phosphotyrosine 4G10 or anti-JAK3 mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	223	 To correct for possible variations in the amount of protein loaded, values are expressed as pJAK3/JAK3 ratios.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	224	 pJAK3/JAK3 levels were determined by densitometry, including correction for background (NIH Image software).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Results are expressed as increases (e.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	226	, two times) with respect to untreated cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	228	 TF1 cells were analyzed for interactions between TRAF2, IL-15R, and c.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Briefly, lysates were subjected to immunoprecipitation (IP) with an anti-TRAF2 antibody.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Immunoprecipitates were subjected to electrophoresis and the protein bands were transferred to PVDF membranes.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Membranes corresponding to immunoprecipitated TRAF2 and total lysates (Tot.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	232	) were probed with anti-TRAF2, anti-c, or anti-IL-15R mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	234	 (D) Analysis of IB phosphorylation by Western blotting.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	235	 TF1 and TF1ss cells were incubated with 10 ng/ml rIL-15 or rIL-7 for 15 min at 37 degrees C.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Cell extracts were analyzed by Western blotting with anti-phospho-IB (pIB) antibody.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Membranes were then reprobed with an antibody recognizing ss-actin.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	238	 To correct for possible variations in the amount of protein loaded, values are expressed as pIB/ss actin ratios.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	239	 pIB/ss actin levels were determined by densitometry, including correction for background (NIH Image software).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Results are expressed as increases with respect to untreated cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The data presented are representative of three independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	242	  Stimulation with rIL-15 induced JAK3 phosphorylation (increase by a factor of 15) only in the presence of anti to GM-CSFRss mAb, indicating that the IL-15R/c receptor is potentially functional in TF1 cells (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	243	 A similar result was also obtained with TF1ss cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	244	Total lysates of the TF1 and TF1ss cell lines were subjected to immunoprecipitation with an anti-JAK3 mAb, and the JAK3 membranes were probed with the anti-phosphotyrosine mAb 4G10.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	245	 A single phosphorylated band was detected for the samples treated with an anti-GM-CSFRss mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Reprobing of the membrane with an anti-JAK3 mAb resulted in the detection of a single protein with migration characteristics identical to those of the phosphorylated band detected on the 4G10 Western blot, indicating that the phosphorylated protein is, indeed, JAK3.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	247	 These data indicate that the c subunit of the IL-15R/c receptor is functional in TF1 cells, even in the absence of the IL-15Rss chain, but that signaling is controlled by GM-CSFRss.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	248	 The hybrid receptor is, therefore, functional in these cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	249	We analyzed whether the IL-15R/c complex was associated with the signaling molecule TRAF2 (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Analysis of total lysates with anti-TRAF2, anti-c, or anti to IL-15R mAbs showed that TF1 cells expressed TRAF2 (55 kD), the 58 kD IL-15R isoform and the c chain (64 kD).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	251	 After immunoprecipitation with an anti-TRAF2 antibody, reprobing of the TRAF2 membranes with mAbs recognizing the IL-15R and c chains resulted in the detection of specific 58 and 64 kD bands, respectively, indicating that TRAF2 is physically associated with the IL-15R 58 kD standard isoform and the c chain.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	252	We also showed that rIL-15, but not rIL-7, triggered phosphorylation of the p65 NF-B subunit inhibitor IB (42 kD) within 15 min in TF1 and TF1ss cells (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Reprobing the membranes with an anti to ss-actin mAb identified a band of similar intensity at 42 kD in each sample, indicating that the gel had been evenly loaded in terms of amount of protein.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	254	 We also showed by confocal microscopy that rIL-15, but not rIL-7, induced the translocation to the nucleus of the p65 NF-B subunit (unpublished data).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	255	 These data indicate that, in TF1 cells, the IL-15R chain is functional and able to activate the NF-B factor.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Moreover, not only does its association with the c chain not interfere with NF-B activation, it also probably renders the c chain functional even in the absence of the IL-15Rss chain, as shown by the induction of JAK3 phosphorylation by rIL-15.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	257	IL-15 to induced STAT5 Signaling Is Inhibited by Anti to GM-CSFRss mAb in Normal CBPr CD34+/CD56- Cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Finally, we investigated the functional significance of the hybrid receptor in normal CB hematopoietic progenitors and the properties of this receptor in these cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	259	 We used populations of CB progenitors that had been expanded for 5 d in the presence of SCF and Flt3-L (CBPr CD34+/CD56-).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	260	 This facilitates proliferation of the hematopoietic progenitors, which maintain a CD34+/CD56- phenotype with no expression of lineage-specific markers (7).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	261	 We found that rIL-15 quadrupled levels of STAT3 phosphorylation, which was not significantly affected by anti to GM-CSFRss or isotype-matched control anti-gp130 mAbs (Fig.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	262	 As expected, rGM-CSF did not induce STAT3 phosphorylation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	263	 In contrast, anti-c, but not anti-gp130 mAbs inhibited constitutive STAT3 phosphorylation, suggesting interference with an autocrine IL-15 to dependent loop.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Indeed, unprimed hematopoietic precursors secrete several hematopoietic cytokines that regulate normal hematopoiesis (3) by autocrine/paracrine loops, and IL-15 belongs to this group (20).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	265	View larger version (51K):    Figure 6.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	266	 IL-15 signal transduction: IL-15R/GM-CSFR cross talk in CBPr CD34+/CD56- cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Analysis of STAT signal transduction by Western blotting.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	268	 CB CD34+ cell populations were expanded by incubation for 5 d in the presence of SCF and Flt3-L.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	269	 These cells displayed a CD34+/CD56- phenotype with no expression of lineage-specific markers.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	270	 These CBPr CD34+/CD56- progenitors were incubated with 10 ng/ml rIL-15 or rGM-CSF for 15 min at 37 degrees C.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Sister cultures were pretreated for 1 h with neutralizing anti-IL-15Rss/c, anti-GM-CSFRss, or anti-IL-6R gp130 mAbs.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Cell extracts were analyzed by Western blotting with anti-phospho-STAT3 (pSTAT3), anti-phospho-STAT5 (pSTAT5), and anti-phospho-STAT6 (pSTAT6) antibodies.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Membranes were then reprobed with antibodies recognizing the native proteins.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	274	 To correct for possible variations in the amount of protein loaded, values are expressed as pSTAT/STAT ratios.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	275	 pSTAT/STAT levels were determined by densitometry, including correction for background (NIH Image software).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Results are expressed as increases with respect to untreated cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	277	 The data presented are representative of two independent experiments.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	278	  Both rIL-15 and rGM-CSF induced STAT5 phosphorylation (increases by factors of 10 and 7, respectively).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Anti to GM-CSFRss mAb totally abolished the effect of rIL-15 whereas the action of rGM-CSF action was inhibited by only 35% with an anti-c mAb.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	280	 No significant inhibition was observed if an anti-gp130 mAb was used.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Finally, CBPr CD34+/CD56- progenitors displayed discrete constitutive STAT6 phosphorylation, with an 80% increase in phosphorylation in response to rIL-15, but no effect of rGM-CSF.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The various neutralizing mAbs had no significant effect on STAT6 phosphorylation.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	283	On the basis of these results, we propose a model for the activation of STAT5 by rGM-CSF via the hybrid receptor c/GM-CSFRss.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	284	 We suggest that STAT5 tyrosine phosphorylation and nuclear translocation are regulated independently and that the translocation pathway is controlled by the c/JAK3 complex, which, in cells with type I IL-4R, is necessary for the translocation of STAT5 to the nucleus (35).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	285	The hybrid receptor is functional not only in leukemic cell precursors, but also in normal progenitors, although its functions appear more limited in normal cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Indeed, in normal CBPr CD34+/CD56- progenitors, the hybrid receptor controls the IL-15 to dependent phosphorylation of STAT5 but not of STAT3 and STAT6.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Moreover, levels of GM-CSF to dependent STAT5 phosphorylation are decreased by anti-c mAb in CBPr CD34+/CD56- progenitors, but not in TF1ss cells.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	288	 These differences may be due to differences in origin (normal versus pathological) and/or degree of primitiveness of the two types of CD34+ cell.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	289	 In any case, our results emphasize the involvement of the hybrid receptor in the control of normal and pathological hematopoiesis, with this receptor probably displaying various functions during hematopoietic development.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	290	The absence of the hybrid receptor on nonhematopoietic cells strengthens the evidence for its "specific" involvement in hematopoiesis.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The distribution of this receptor in cells of various lineages and functions suggests that it is involved in the development of hematopoiesis, probably affecting engagement in myeloid, rather than lymphoid, lineages.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Indeed, the inhibition of c/JAK3 signaling by the GM-CSFRss chain should be interpreted in light of the inhibition of lymphocyte maturation and myelopoiesis dysregulation observed in mice and humans bearing c or JAK3 deletions or mutations (9 to 11).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	293	In erythrocytic TF1 cells, we describe, for the first time, a novel IL-15R/c/TRAF2 complex that triggers specific IL-15 signaling, even though these cells do not express the IL-15Rss chain23, a subunit indispensable for the c chain functions (7).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Both subunits of the IL-15R/c heterodimer are functional, although they behave differently from what would be expected based on the results obtained for other cell types.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	295	 It has been reported that IL-15R, associating with the signaling molecule TRAF2, activates the transcription factor NF-B, in the absence of a link with the c chain (12, 24).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	296	 In contrast, in TF1 cells, IL-15R and c are associated but we nevertheless observed the phosphorylation, not only of IB, but also of JAK3 factors.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	297	 However, the phosphorylation of JAK3 factor was only observed in samples treated with rIL-15 and anti to GM-CSFRss mAb, indicating that the c/JAK3 pathway is functional in the absence of the IL-15Rss chain but is controlled by the hybrid receptor.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	298	The association of IL-15R/c/TRAF2 may play a regulatory role at certain stages of hematopoiesis, associating NF-B activation, which is involved in the control of erythropoiesis (15), with the conditional activation of JAK3-dependent pathways.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	299	Finally, we showed that rIL-15 induced the phosphorylation of STAT6 both in leukemic TF1ss proerythroid precursors, and in normal CBPr CD34+/CD56- progenitors.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Our data suggest that this unusual IL-15 to dependent pathway, the activation of which in mast cells was attributed to the high-affinity p65 IL-15RX receptor (28, 29), is also triggered in other types of CD34+ precursor.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	301	 However, in TF1ss cells, this pathway is controlled by the classical IL-15R/ss/c receptor and/or by the c/GM-CSFRss hybrid receptor, whereas in normal CBPr, CD34+/CD56- IL-15 to dependent STAT6 phosphorylation is not controlled by the hybrid receptor.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Overall, these results suggest the possible and complex involvement of STAT6 in the control of hematopoiesis (36) and provide further evidence that IL-15/GM-CSF are involved in cross talk.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	303	Recent data have shown that unprimed hematopoietic progenitors secrete several mediators activating autocrine/paracrine regulatory loops (3).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	304	 For instance, CD34+ cells may express GM-CSF transcripts (3) and a biologically active IL-15 that controls expression of the c chain, but is not competent for inducing the spontaneous differentiation of these cells into NK cells (20).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Thus, IL-15 and GM-CSF may contribute, by means of the hybrid receptor, to the autocrine/paracrine cross talk that controls the development of hematopoietic cells (3), perhaps by inhibiting the spontaneous engagement of these cells in the lymphoid lineage.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	306	 In contrast, in leukemic hematopoiesis, the action of the hybrid receptor is probably irreversible and may be involved in the molecular mechanisms responsible for the inhibition of differentiation in certain leukemic clones.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	307	   Acknowledgments   This work was supported by grants from the Association pour la Recherche sur le Cancer (ARC, N degrees  5801), NRB-Vaincre le Cancer, FE.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	308	FLUC, Fondation de France (N degrees  99-003929), Italian Association for Cancer Research (AIRC), and the Italian National Council for Research (CNR).
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	309	Submitted: January 29, 2002 Revised: January 27, 2003 Accepted: January 28, 2003.
0.26340848.12642604.html.plaintext.txt	310	   Footnotes   * Abbreviations used in this paper: BM, bone marrow; CB, cord blood; MPB, mobilized peripheral blood.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	0	Gene Silencing by Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor I (COUP-TFI) Is Mediated by Transcriptional Corepressors, Nuclear Receptor-Corepressor (N-CoR) and Silencing Mediator for Retinoic Acid Receptor and Thyroid Hormone Receptor (SMRT) Hirotaka Shibata, Zafar Nawaz, Sophia Y.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Cell Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas 77030.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	2	Silencing activity of unliganded TR and RAR requires limiting factors termed corepressors (5).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Recently, two corepressors that bind to unliganded TR and RAR have been cloned using a yeast two-hybrid screen: N-CoR (nuclear receptor-corepressor) (10, 11) and SMRT (silencing mediator for RAR and TR) (12, 13, 14, 15).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Binding of these corepressors is necessary for unliganded receptors to silence the activity of target promoters.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Prevailing evidence suggests that binding of hormone changes the conformation of the receptors, which results in the release of the corepressor and recruitment of coactivators, thereby abolishing their silencing activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	6	 These two corepressors exhibit significant sequence homologies in their receptor-interacting domains, suggesting the existence of a corepressor gene family.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	7	 COUP-TFs (chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factors) belong to the steroid receptor superfamily and are classified as orphan receptors because their ligand has yet to be defined.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	8	 There are two COUP-TF genes in mammals, COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	9	 COUP-TFs have been implicated in neurogenesis, organogenesis, and cell fate determination (16, 17, 18, 19).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	10	 COUP-TFs can form stable homodimers and bind to a variety of hormone response elements recognized by other members of the steroid receptor superfamily, such as RAR, retinoid X receptor (RXR), TR, vitamin D receptor (VDR), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor, and hepatocyte nuclear factor 4.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	11	 COUP-TFs can thereby inhibit transcriptional activities of these receptors on both consensus and natural response elements (17, 20).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Four mechanisms have been proposed to address COUP-TF s ability to inhibit the transactivation function of other members of the steroid receptor superfamily.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	13	 First, COUP-TFs repress the hormone-dependent transactivation of target genes by VDR, TR, and RAR through direct competition for occupancy of their response elements (21, 22, 23).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Second, COUP-TFs heterodimerize with RXR to reduce the available concentration of RXR for heterodimerization with TR, VDR, RAR, and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor and thus indirectly interfere with these receptors to transactivate their target genes (21, 22, 24, 25, 26, 27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Third, COUP-TFs can tether to DNA via LBD-LBD interactions with TR, RAR, and RXR to transrepress their activities (27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Finally, COUP-TFs have been shown to repress basal and activator-dependent transcriptional activities of various promoters when their binding site is placed upstream or downstream of these promoters (27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The silencing domain in COUP-TFs was localized to the C terminus of the putative LBD, which can be transferred to the heterologous Gal4 DNA-binding domain (DBD).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Activators that can be repressed by COUP-TFs include acidic (Gal4-RII), glutamine-rich (Gal4-ftzQ), proline-rich (Gal4-CTF1P), and Ser/Thr-rich (Gal4-ZenST) transactivators (27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Because COUP-TF can repress such a diverse group of transactivators, it is unlikely that COUP-TF s repression is through direct quenching of these transactivators or by interfering with their respective targets.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	20	 It is rather likely that COUP-TFs interact with a common target, a putative corepressor(s) that mediates their repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	21	To substantiate this hypothesis, we address two major questions in this paper; 1) Does COUP-TFI-mediated repression require corepressors? and 2) If it does, does COUP-TFI share corepressors with other receptors, such as TR and RAR? To answer these questions, we first examined whether cofactors are involved in COUP-TFI-mediated repression using either self-squelching or TR/COUP-TF-mediated mutual squelching experiments.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Next, we examined whether COUP-TFI can interact with N-CoR or SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Finally, we examined whether N-CoR or SMRT can function as a corepressor in COUP-TFI-mediated repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Results from these experiments indicate that both N-CoR and SMRT can function as corepressors for COUP-TFI-mediated repression of target genes.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	25	View larger version (14K):    Figure 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	26	 COUP-TFI Is Able to Squelch the Repressor Activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	27	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	28	1  microg Gal4-COUP-TFI cDNA, 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	29	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, and increasing amounts of COUP-TFI or COUP-TFI35 expression plasmid (0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	30	1  microg) was transfected instead of Gal4-COUP-TFI in lane 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	31	  COUP-TFI Shares Common Corepressor(s) with TRss To elucidate whether COUP-TFI shares common corepressors with TRss, squelching experiments were performed.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Overexpression of TRss in the absence of T3 can reverse the basal repression activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI by squelching endogenous corepressors in a dose-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In contrast, the liganded TRss cannot squelch the repression (lines 3 to 8, Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Similarly, overexpression of TR mutant, TR168 to 456(V174A/D177A), which loses its silencing activity but retains hormone-dependent transactivation (28), cannot relieve the basal repression activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI (lines 9 to 11, Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	35	 These findings strongly suggest that TRss- and COUP-TFI-mediated repression share the same corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	36	View larger version (17K):    Figure 2.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Unliganded TRss, but Not Liganded TRss or TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A), Is Able to Squelch Repressor Activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	38	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	39	1  microg Gal4-COUP-TFI cDNA, 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	40	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, and increasing amounts of TRss or TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A) expression plasmids (0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Cells were treated with 10-7 M T3 for 24 h in lanes 6 to 8.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	42	1  microg) was transfected instead of Gal4-COUP-TFI in lane 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	43	  In a reverse experiment, we examined whether COUP-TFI can squelch the repression activity of Gal4-TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	44	 3, transfection of Gal4-TRss into HeLa cells significantly repressed the basal promoter activity of the reporter construct.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Overexpression of COUP-TFI can reverse this repression in a dose-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	46	 As expected, we observe no reversal of TRss-mediated repression by overexpression of the repression-defective COUP-TFI mutant, COUP-TFI35.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	47	 These results further suggest that common corepressors are shared by COUP-TFI and TRss for their repression activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	48	View larger version (14K):    Figure 3.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	49	 COUP-TFI, but Not COUP-TFI35, Is Able to Squelch the Repressor Activity of Gal4-TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	50	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	51	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, and increasing amounts of COUP-TFI or COUP-TFI35 (0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	52	1  microg) was transfected instead of Gal4-COUP-TFI in lane 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	53	  Both N-CoR and SMRT Interact with COUP-TFI Using the LBD of TRss as a bait in a yeast two-hybrid screen, the TR-interacting protein, SMRT, has been cloned (12, 14, 15).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	54	 (10) have cloned another TR-interacting protein, N-CoR, which has sequence similarity to SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Both N-CoR and SMRT have been identified as corepressors for TR and RAR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	56	 We asked whether these two corepressors can function as corepressors for COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	57	 First, we examined whether COUP-TFI can interact specifically with these authentic corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Using a yeast two-hybrid assay, we confirmed that these corepressors can interact with TRss in a hormone-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	59	 4, A and B, a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 921-2453 and fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 565-1495 and 1192 to 1495 can interact with TRss in a hormone-dependent manner as previously described (10, 12, 14).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	60	 It should be pointed out that, to our surprise, a larger fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453, which contains a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 921-2453, cannot interact with TRss in a yeast two-hybrid assay.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Although the reason for this discrepancy is not clear at present, it is possible that the N-terminal repression domain of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190 to 920 is very potent and overrides the activation function of Gal4 in a yeast two-hybrid assay.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	62	 This notion is further supported by our observation that a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 can interact with TRss in vitro (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	63	View larger version (34K):    Figure 4.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Interaction of TRss or COUP-TFI with N-CoR or SMRT in Yeast Two-Hybrid Assays.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	65	A, Various fragments of SMRT and N-CoR constructs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 29 to 564, 565-1289, 565-1495, and 1192 to 1495 were constructed.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The fragment of SMRT encoding amino acids 1192 to 1495 was obtained by yeast two-hybrid screen as a bait of the LBD of TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The fragments of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 and 921-2453 were constructed.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In N-CoR, there are two repression domains (RD1 and RD2) as shown in the N-terminal region.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The acidic-basic motif (AB) and the serine-glycine-rich domain (SG) in the central region are indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Glutamine-rich regions (Q) and predicted amphipathic -helix (H) regions are also indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The most N-terminal region of SMRT (amino acids 1 to 483) contains four putative repeated motifs, and it has 44% identity with N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	73	 A series of deletion mutants of N-CoR or SMRT (illustrated in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	74	 4A) were created and tested for interaction in the yeast two-hybrid system with TRss (B) or COUP-TFI (C).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	75	 For the experiments presented here, Gal4 DBD-TR168 to 456 or Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI constructs were coexpressed with Gal4 AD-N-CoR or SMRT deletion mutants.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Each two-hybrid pair was transformed into the yeast y190, the transformants were propagated, and the ss-galactosidase activity was determined.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The effects of T3 on the TR/N-CoR or SMRT interaction in the presence of 1  microM T3 in the culture medium was also tested.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Cotransformation of Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI and Gal4 AD-TFIIB was used as a positive control.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	79	 At least two independent yeast transformants were analyzed, and the results were determined as mean  plus or minus  SEM.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	80	  Next, we examined the interaction between COUP-TFI and N-CoR or SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	81	 We first demonstrated that no interaction between Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI (amino acids 184 to 423) fusion and Gal4 activation domain (AD) (empty vector) was shown as a negative control (lane 1 in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	82	 In contrast, as a positive control, we showed a strong interaction between Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI and Gal4 AD-TFIIB (lane 7 in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	83	 We then examined the interaction of various deletion fragments of N-CoR or SMRT with COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	84	 In a yeast two-hybrid assay system, the interaction of COUP-TFI with N-CoR or SMRT was detected when COUP-TFI was bound to DNA response element.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	85	 In the absence of DNA response element, no interaction was observed (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	86	 A fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 921-2453 strongly interacts with COUP-TFI; however, a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 does not interact with COUP-TFI in a yeast two-hybrid assay.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Similar to the TRss interaction study (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	88	 4B), the repression domains of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190 to 920 may interfere with the Gal4 activation domain function in a yeast two-hybrid assay; thus, a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 is not able to activate ss-galactosidase activity of the reporter.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	89	 However, both N-CoR fragments encoding amino acids 190-2453 and 921-2453 were found to interact with COUP-TFI in an in vitro glutathione S-transferase (GST) pull-down assay because these in vitro interactions are presumably not influenced by the repressor function of N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Thus, a fragment of COUP-TFI encoding amino acids 56 to 423 can interact specifically with N-CoR in yeast and in vitro.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	91	 On the other hand, fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 29 to 564 and 565-1495 strongly interact with COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In contrast, a fragment of SMRT encoding amino acids 1192 to 1495, which interacts well with TR, interacts only weakly with COUP-TFI in a yeast two-hybrid assay (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	93	 These results suggest that the COUP-TFI-interacting domain of SMRT is located mainly at amino acids 29 to 564 and 565-1191.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	94	 These interaction data in yeast are further supported by the in vitro protein-protein interactions as shown in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Both fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 29 to 564 and 565-1289 are able to interact with GST-COUP-TFI, whereas a fragment of SMRT encoding amino acids 1192 to 1495 fails to interact with GST-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	96	View larger version (39K):    Figure 5.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Interaction between COUP-TFI and N-CoR or SMRT in in Vitro GST Pull-Down Assays.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	98	Radiolabeled N-CoR, SMRT, or TFIIB were tested for their abilities to bind to an immobilized GST-COUP-TFI fusion protein or to GST control protein.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	99	 GST or GST-COUP-TFI fusion protein were expressed in yeast and purified by adsorption to a glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	100	 A, The fragments of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 and 921-2453 and TFIIB, translated in vitro, were incubated with the GST control protein (lanes 2, 5, and 8) or GST-COUP-TFI (lanes 3, 6, and 9) for 30 to 60 min at 4 C with rocking.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The GST or GST-COUP-TFI Sepharose beads were then extensively washed, and radiolabeled corepressor proteins (lanes 3 and 6) or TFIIB (lane 9) bound to the matrix were eluted with SDS loading buffer and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Lanes 1, 4, and 7 represent each input protein.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	103	 B, The fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 29 to 564 (lanes 1 to 3), 565-1285 (lanes 4 to 6), and 1192 to 1495 (lanes 7 to 9) were radiolabeled and tested for their abilities to bind to an immobilized GST-COUP-TFI (lanes 3, 6, and 9 or to GST control protein (lanes 2, 5, and 8), while Lanes 1, 4, and 7 represent each input protein.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The molecular weight of each protein is indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	105	  N-CoR and SMRT Potentiate the Basal Repression by Gal4-COUP-TFI From the above studies, we have shown that N-CoR and SMRT can interact with COUP-TFI specifically.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	106	 We then asked whether these two corepressors are required to mediate COUP-TFI repression activity in mammalian cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	107	 6, neither N-CoR nor SMRT have a significant effect on transcription activity of the reporter construct in the absence of cotransfected Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	108	 However, both N-CoR and SMRT can potentiate the repressor function of Gal4-COUP-TFI in a dose-dependent manner in HeLa cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	109	 These data suggest that both N-CoR and SMRT can function as corepressors of COUP-TFI in HeLa cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Thus, it is likely that they are the endogenous corepressors of COUP-TFI in HeLa cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	111	View larger version (9K):    Figure 6.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	112	 N-CoR and SMRT Can Potentiate Basal Repression Activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	113	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	114	1  microg Gal4 or Gal4-COUP-TFI cDNA, 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	115	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, and increasing amounts of N-CoR or SMRT expression plasmid (0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	116	  N-CoR and SMRT Can Reverse the Squelching of COUP-TFI-Mediated Repression As shown earlier (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	117	 1), overexpression of COUP-TFI can squelch the repressor activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	118	 If N-CoR and SMRT are the limiting factors required for COUP-TFI-mediated repression, we expect that overexpression of N-CoR or SMRT should reverse this squelching activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	119	 7, overexpression of N-CoR or SMRT was able to relieve the squelching effects of COUP-TFI on Gal4-COUP-TFI repression function in a dose-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	120	 On the other hand, overexpression of N-CoR or SMRT had no significant effect on transcription activity of the reporter construct in the absence of cotransfected Gal4-COUP-TFI (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Therefore, both N-CoR and SMRT can substitute for the endogenous corepressor(s) in mediating COUP-TFI s repressor function.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	122	View larger version (17K):    Figure 7.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Reversal of COUP-TFI-Mediated Squelching of Basal Repression Activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	124	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	125	1  microg Gal4 or Gal4-COUP-TFI cDNA, 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	126	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	127	0  microg COUP-TFI cDNA, and increasing amounts of N-CoR or SMRT expression plasmid (50, 100, and 200 ng).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	128	To examine whether a corepressor(s) can be shared between TRss and COUP-TFI, squelching experiments were performed.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	129	 2, unliganded but not liganded TRss can squelch the basal repression of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The evidence that the TR mutant, TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A) (28), which does not interact with the putative corepressors, cannot squelch the basal repression of Gal4-COUP-TFI further supports the notion that common corepressors may be involved in basal repression between TRss and COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Furthermore, overexpression of COUP-TFI, but not COUP-TFI35, can squelch the basal repression activity of Gal4-TRss, also suggesting that common corepressors can function for both COUP-TFI and TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Theoretically, the target of transcriptional interference may be either a basal transcription factor(s) or a corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Transfection of COUP-TFI or TRss did not change the basal transcription of a PRE-tk-luciferase reporter lacking a proper response element (data not shown), suggesting that squelchers are unlikely to interfere directly with the function of any basal transcriptional machinery.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Therefore, the target(s) of interference between COUP-TF and TRss is likely to be one or more transcriptional corepressor protein(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	135	Because COUP-TFI can form homodimers by itself or form heterodimers with TRss (27), it is possible that the squelchers can form non-DNA-binding heterodimers with the repressors used in Figs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	136	 1, 2, and 3 (Gal4-COUP-TFI/COUP-TFI for Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	137	 2, and Gal4-TRss/COUP-TFI for Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	138	 If this is the case, inhibition of repressor activity may be due to inhibition of DNA binding rather than to squelching of a limiting corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	139	 However, several lines of evidence suggest that this is not the case.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	140	 First, both COUP-TFI and TRss have the ability to bind specifically to corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Second, a mutant form of TRss (TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A)), which loses its ability to interact with corepressor but retains its intact dimerization domain, is not able to inhibit the repression activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Third, COUP-TF mutant (COUP-TFI35), which loses its ability in silencing, also loses its ability to squelch repressor activity of TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Finally and most importantly, we have demonstrated directly that both N-CoR and SMRT can mediate repressor activity of COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	144	 6) and reverse the self-squelching activity (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Therefore, inhibition of repression activity by squelchers in Figs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	146	 1, 2, and 3 indeed results from squelching of a limiting corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	147	Because squelching experiments showed that COUP-TFI may share a corepressor(s) with TRss, we examined protein-protein interaction between COUP-TFI and N-CoR or SMRT in a yeast two-hybrid assay and in in vitro GST pull-down assays as shown in Figs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The amino acid 921-2453 fragment of N-CoR interacts with COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This result is consistent with what has been observed in TR interaction studies (10, 33).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Interaction between COUP-TFI and the amino acid 190-2453 fragment of N-CoR was not detected in a yeast two-hybrid assay, but was detected in an in vitro GST pull-down assay.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	151	 This discrepancy is likely due to the potent repressor domain of the N-terminal portion of N-CoR, which suppresses the Gal4 activation function, resulting in interference with ss-galactosidase expression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Consistent with this interpretation, Seol et al.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	153	 (33) also recently demonstrated that the repressor domain of N-CoR strongly interferes with the mammalian two-hybrid assay to study the protein-protein interaction between N-CoR and TR or RAR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	154	 On the other hand, the amino acid 29 to 564 and amino acid 565-1289, but not amino acid 1192 to 1495, fragments of SMRT strongly interact with COUP-TF in yeast and in vitro assays.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Based on these data, we concluded that there are at least two COUP-TFI-interacting domains within the SMRT molecules.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The lack of interaction between COUP-TFI and SMRT (1192 to 1495) is surprising because this region interacts very strongly with TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Thus, different repressors may interact differentially with SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Finally, the corepressor-interacting region in COUP-TFI is localized in the extreme C terminus, which is quite different from the region of TR and RAR where hinge and N-terminal portions of LBD are involved in this interaction.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Thus, repression function of COUP-TFs may act in a different way from that of TR and RAR (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	160	View larger version (27K):    Figure 8.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Structure Domains of Repressors and Corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	162	A, Functional domains of COUP-TFI, TRss, and RevErb A.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	163	 A/B, C, D, E/F are functional domains of receptors (3).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	164	 CID (corepressor-interacting domain) is a sequence important for repressor function and contains a region that interacts with corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The CoR box is a conserved region of human TR, TRss, RAR, and RevErb A.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The CoR box of TRss is a repressor domain that interacts with corepressors; however, CIDs of RevErb A are different from the region of CoR box.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	167	 B, Receptor-interacting domains of SMRT and N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Receptor-interacting domains of corepressors are indicated below each scheme of SMRT and N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In N-CoR, there are two repression domains (RD1 and RD2) as shown in the N-terminal region.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The most N-terminal region of SMRT (amino acids 1 to 483) contains four putative repeated motifs and it has 44% identity with N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The acidic-basic motif () and the serine-glycine-rich domain (SG) in the central region are indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Glutamine-rich regions (Q) and predicted amphipathic -helix (H) regions are also indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	173	  In support of this observation, N-CoR has been shown to function as a corepressor for RevErb A (34).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	174	 However, a region homologous to the CoR box in the RevErb A, which is necessary for TR and RAR to interact with N-CoR, is not required for RevErb A-mediated repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	175	 N-CoR contains two adjacent but distinct interaction domains, amino acids 2040 to 2239 and 2239 to 2296.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The former fragment of N-CoR strongly interacts with both TR and RevErb A; however, the latter fragment of N-CoR interacts weakly and preferentially with RevErb A.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Taken together, these data suggest that different nuclear receptors, utilizing different amino acid sequences, repress transcription by interacting with different region of N-CoR or SMRT as shown in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	178	Recently, an activator for COUP-TFII has been identified using a yeast two-hybrid screen, designated ORCA (orphan receptor coactivator) (35), and this factor is identical to a recently described ligand (p62) of tyrosine kinase- signaling molecule p56lck, suggesting that ORCA may link COUP-TFII and cell surface signal transduction pathways.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	179	 This integrating role may be similar to what is observed with cAMP response element-binding protein CBP and the related protein p300.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	180	 CBP plays a role in integrating cAMP second messenger and nuclear hormone receptor signal transduction pathways.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Of interest, ORCA/p62 shares a small region of homology with CBP, suggesting a potential similarity in their mechanism of action.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	182	 However, based on their data, ORCA/p62 does not bind directly to COUP-TFII-binding sites and COUP-TFII/ORCA complex is not detected in gel retardation assays.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Therefore, it is possible that ORCA/p62 may function directly or indirectly by phosphorylating COUP-TFII or ORCA/p62 may overcome the function of a specific COUP-TFII-associated corepressor.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Because ORCA/p62 can convert COUP-TFII into a transcriptional activator in a ligand-independent manner in mammalian cells, it is possible that COUP-TFI can also be activated by a coactivator(s) in a ligand-independent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Our preliminary data showed that overexpression of hSRC-1a (36), which is a general coactivator for members of steroid receptors, cannot relieve the repressor activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI in HeLa cells (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	186	In conclusion, we demonstrated that corepressors are involved in the mechanisms of COUP-TFI-mediated gene silencing, and that both N-CoR and SMRT can function as corepressors for COUP-TFI in mammalian cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Therefore, orphan receptors such as COUP-TFI and RevErb A can function as a repressor in vivo by utilizing corepressors that are common for members of the TR and RAR subfamily.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	188	Cloning of SMRT by Yeast Two-Hybrid System Yeast strains used are as follows.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	189	 y190: MATa, leu2 to 3, 112, ura3 to 52, trp1 to 901, his2-D200, ade2 to 101, gal4gal180URA3 GAL-lacZ, LYS GAL-HIS3, cyhr.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	190	 y187: MAT, gal4, gal80, his3, trp1 to 901, ade2 to 101, ura3 to 52, leu2 to 3, -112, URA3 GAL-lacZ met-.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	191	 BJ2168: MATa, prc1 to 407, Prb1 to 1122, pep4 to 3, leu2, trp1, ura 3 to 52.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Yeast-selective media and plates were prepared according to Guthrie and Fink (37).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The yeast strain y190 containing pAS1cyh2-TR168 to 456 was transformed with a human brain cDNA library in pGAD10 (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) and plated on synthetic complete medium lacking tryptophan, leucine, and histidine (containing 25 mM 3-aminotriazole) as described by Durfee et al.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	194	 His+ colonies exhibiting ss-galactosidase activity using the filter lift assay were further characterized.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	195	 ss-Galactosidase activity was determined using chlorophenol red ss-D galactopyranoside as described (38).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	196	 To recover the library plasmids, total DNA from yeast was isolated and used to transform Escherichia coli (HB101) which lacks leu2 gene.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Transformants were identified on minimal medium lacking leucine and containing ampicillin.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	198	 To ensure that the correct cDNAs were identified, library plasmids isolated were retransformed into y190 containing pAS1cyh2-TR168 to 456, and ss-galactosidase activity was determined.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The specificity of the interaction of cor 10.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	200	1 (SMRT 1192 to 1495), one of the 12 positive clones, with TR was determined by mating y190 containing pGAD10-cor 10.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	201	1 with the strain y187 containing either pAS1-SNF, pAS1-cdk2, pAS1-p53, or pAS1-lamin.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The ss-galactosidase activity of these diploids was examined using the filter lift and chlorophenyl red ss-D galactopyranoside methods.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	203	1 clone was identical to recently identified corepressor SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The yeast two-hybrid system was also used to determine protein-protein interaction between COUP-TFI and SMRT or N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	205	Protein-Protein Interaction by GST-Pulldown Assay GST-COUP-TFI (pCBGST1-COUP-TFI) fusion protein was expressed and extracted in yeast strain BJ2168 as described previously (39).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	206	 GST-pulldown assay was performed as described with modifications (4, 39): 30  microl glutathione-Sepharose beads stored in NENT buffer (500 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 20 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	207	5% NP-40, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 6 mM MgCl2, and 8% glycerol) were incubated with yeast extracts containing GST-fusion proteins in a 1:1 vol ratio together with NENT buffer for 30 to 60 min at 4 C.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Preparation of yeast extracts containing GST-fusion protein was described previously (39).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Subsequently, the supernatant was removed and the beads were washed twice with 1 ml NENT buffer and twice with 1 ml transcription washing buffer (60 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 20 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	210	05% NP-40, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 6 mM MgCl2, and 8% glycerol).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	211	 In vitro-translated and -radiolabeled proteins were obtained using TNT Coupled Reticulocyte Lysate Systems (Promega).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Five to 10  microl crude lysate were incubated with the beads in 200  microl transcription washing buffer for 2 h at 4 C.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Finally, the beads were washed five times with 1 ml NENT buffer and proteins were solubilized in SDS loading buffer and analyzed on SDS-PAGE.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The input lane contains 10% of the labeled protein used for binding.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	215	Plasmids Mammalian Expression Vectors The expression plasmids pABgal147, pABgal, pABgalTRss, pABgalTRss, pABgal-TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A), pRSV-COUP-TFI, pRSV-COUP-TFI35, and pRSVgalCOUP-TFI were described previously (5, 20, 21, 27, 28, 40).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	216	 pCMX-N-CoR (10) and pCMX-SMRT (12) were generous gifts from Dr.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The 17 mer x 4-tk-LUC reporter gene contains four copies of a 17-mer upstream activating sequence located upstream of the thymidine kinase promoter and luciferase gene.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	218	 pCR3-SMRT565 to 1289 was constructed by TA Cloning (Invitrogen) of PCR-amplified product with primers 5'-AGCTGACGTCGACGCCTCGTG-3' and 5'-CTGCACCGCCTGGCTTCTAT-3' in which template cDNA was made by reverse transcription of human skeletal muscle mRNA (Clontech) with primer 5'-GCTGGCATGTTCCTGCACCG-3'.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	219	 pCR3-SMRT565 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the EcoRI (filled)-BglII fragment of pGAD10-SMRT1192 to 1495 into the BglII-EcoRV site of pCR3-SMRT565 to 1289.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	220	 pCR3-SMRT29 to 564 was constructed by TA Cloning (Invitrogen) of PCR-amplified product with primers 5'-AAGATTCCGAGCTCTGCTAC-3' and 5'-CACGAGGCGTCGACGTCAGC-3' in which template cDNA was made by reverse transcription of human skeletal muscle mRNA (Clontech) with primer 5'-GTGCGGGGACTTGGCGATCT-3'.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	221	 pCR3-SMRT29 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the SalI fragment of pCR3-SMRT29 to 564 into the SalI site of pCR3-SMRT565 to 1495.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	222	 pABgalSMRT29 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the SalI (partial)-XbaI fragment into the PvuII site of pABgal.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	223	 All PCR generates clones were sequenced to ensure that no mutation occurred during PCR reactions.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	224	Yeast Vectors The Gal4 DBD-TRss168 to 456 yeast expression plasmid (pAS1cyh2-TR168 to 456) was constructed by inserting the HindIII-SmaI blunt-ended fragment of pABgalTR168 to 456 into the SmaI site of pAS1cyh2 (38).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI56 to 423 yeast expression plasmid (pAS1cyh2-COUP-TFI) was constructed by inserting the EcoRI-SmaI (filled) fragment of pGEM7Zf(+)-COUP-TFI into the SmaI site of pAS1cyh2.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Yeast expression plasmid, pCBGST1-COUP-TFI56 to 423, was constructed by inserting the EcoRI-SmaI (filled) fragment (amino acids 56 to 423) of pGEM7Zf(+)-COUP-TFI into the SmaI site of pCBGST1 (39).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Yeast expression plasmid, pACTII-N-CoR190 to 2453, was constructed by inserting the PvuI-SalI (filled) fragment of pCMX-N-CoR into the NcoI-XhoI site (filled) of pACTII (38).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Yeast expression plasmid, pACTII-N-CoR921 to 2453, was constructed by inserting the HincII-SalI (filled) fragment of pCMX-N-CoR into the SmaI site of pACTII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	229	 pACTII-SMRT29 to 564 was constructed by inserting the SalI fragment (filled) of pCR3-SMRT29 to 564 into the NcoI (filled) site of pACTII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	230	 pACTII-SMRT565 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the SalI-XhoI fragment of pCR3-SMRT565 to 1495 into the NcoI (filled) site of pACTII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Yeast expression plasmid, pGAD10-SMRT1192 to 1495, was recovered from a yeast two-hybrid screen using pAS1cyh2-TR168 to 456 as a bait.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Yeast expression plasmid, pACTII-TFIIB, was constructed by inserting the NcoI (partial)-EcoRI fragment of pGST-TFIIB (4) into the NcoI-EcoRI sites of pACTII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	233	In Vitro Transcription and Translation Vectors pT7-N-CoR190 to 2453 was constructed by inserting the PvuI-SalI fragment of pCMX-N-CoR into the NcoI site (filled) of pT7ssSal (41).

0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	236	 pT7-SMRT565 to 1289 was constructed by inserting the SalI-EcoRV fragment of pCR3-SMRT565 to 1289 into the NcoI-EcoRI (filled) site of pT7ssSal.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	237	 PT7-SMRT1192 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the EcoRI fragment (filled) of pGAD10-SMRT1192 to 1495 into the HincII site of pT7ssSal.

0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	239	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank members of our laboratories for critically reading this manuscript.

0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	0	Haploinsufficiency of Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor II in Female Reproduction Norio Takamoto, Isao Kurihara, Kevin Lee, Francesco J.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	1	 DeMayo, Ming-Jer Tsai and Sophia Y.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	2	Department of Molecular and Cellular Biology and Program of Development, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas 77030.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	3	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Sophia Y.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	4	, Department of Molecular and Cellular Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, Texas 77030.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	5	edu' + u + '@' + d + ''//--> or mtsai{at}bcm.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	6	Haploinsufficiency that is caused by heterozygosity of a targeted null allele occasionally reveals the overall impact of a gene dosage effect as a traceable trait.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Many COUP-TFII +/ to  mutants die before weaning suggesting a haploinsufficiency phenotype of the COUP-TFII gene (7).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Upon analyzing the mating patterns of COUP-TFII +/ to  mice, we found that the COUP-TFII +/ to  females have reduced reproductive function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	9	 COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice exhibited reduced fecundity characterized by reduced litter size, and genotype-dependent reduction in growth in the progeny.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Because normal female reproduction requires functional coordination throughout female hypothalamo-hypophyeal-ovarian endocrine axis, as well as an endocrinological link between ovary and uterus, subtle defects in multiple organs of this axis, could significantly alter the normal reproduction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Therefore, we investigated the ovarian and uterine physiology of the COUP-TFII +/ to  mice to determine the cause of this reduction in female fecundity.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	12	Here, we report on the phenotypic analysis of the COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse, specifically related to female ovarian and uterine function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Analysis of ovarian function was conducted by challenging COUP-TFII +/ to  and control mice with a superovulatory regimen of gonadotropins and assaying the ability of the ovary to ovulate and produce ovarian steroids.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse showed normal ovulation of oocytes but demonstrated a reduced capability for synthesizing sex steroid hormones.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This reduction is due to the reduction of the expression of steroidogenic enzymes important for P4 synthesis and the reduction of vascularization in COUP-TFII heterozygotes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Analysis of uterine function in the COUP-TFII +/ to  mice was accomplished by assaying the response of the uterus to an endocrine induction of the decidual reaction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	17	 COUP-TFII +/ to  showed a reduced decidual cell reaction in response to the artificial stimulation, indicating a defect in endometrial function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Analysis of the expression of COUP-TFII +/ to  in the endometrium demonstrated steroid hormone-dependent changes in expression of COUP-TFII in the uterine endometrial stroma.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	19	 This analysis demonstrates that COUP-TFII is important in the regulation of ovarian and uterine function and indicates that COUP-TFII is required for normal female reproductive functions.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Overall Reproductive Performance of COUP-TFII Heterozygous Female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	21	  Delayed Puberty and Growth Retardation and Abnormal Estrus Cycles in COUP-TFII +/ to  Female Mice To further ascertain the underlying cause of reduced fertility of COUP-TFII +/ to  females, we examined the timing of vaginal openings as an indication of onset of puberty.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The results of this analysis are shown in Table 2.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	23	 COUP-TFII +/ to  females exhibited slightly delayed vaginal opening at 30.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	24	6 d after birth, as compared with 27.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	25	9 d after birth in wild-type females (Table 2).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The delay in puberty may be a result of delayed growth of the COUP-TFII +/ to mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The postnatal growth of COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  pups nursed by COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  mothers was measured.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The results of this analysis are shown in Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Significant growth retardation of COUP-TFII +/ to  was clearly shown in mutants as compared with the wild-type controls nursed by either COUP-TFII +/+ or COUP-TFII +/ to  mothers (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	30	 However, growth of COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  were both significantly lower when nursed by COUP-TFII +/ to  as compared with COUP-TFII +/+ moms.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Therefore, the growth retardation is a consequence of both the genotype of the pup, as well as the ability of the mother to nurture the development of the pup.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Delayed Onset of Puberty in COUP-TFII Heterozygous Female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	33	  View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Growth Retardation and Delayed Onset of Puberty in COUP-TFII Heterozygotes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	35	A, Gene dosage effect of COUP-TFII on postnatal growth rate was assessed by daily monitoring of body weight of progeny from wild-type male X heterozygote female (for wild-type or heterozygous pups nursed by heterozygous mother) or heterozygous female X wild-type female (for wild-type or heterozygous pups nursed by wild-type mother).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Normal growth was assumed in wild-type pups nursed by wild-type female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Significantly retarded growth rate was seen in heterozygous pups nursed by wild-type mother, but better than wild-type pups nursed by heterozygous mother.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Most severe growth defect was seen in heterozygous pups nursed by heterozygous mother.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	39	 B, Estrus cyclicity was assessed by daily inspection of vaginal smear of 20-wk-old virgin females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Wild-type female shows regular cyclicity, but heterozygous female showed irregular estrus cycles.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	41	 P, Proestrus; E, estrus; M, metestrus; D, diestrus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	42	  In the analysis of the fecundity of the COUP-TFII +/ to  mice, the ability of the females to have normal reproductive cycles were monitored by recording the estrus cycles of 3-month-old females through daily inspection of vaginal smears.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The diagnostic difference was facilitated by modified Papanicolou staining.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	44	 A representative estrus cycle was schematized in Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	45	 COUP-TFII +/+ females showed regular cyclicity, whereas COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice showed prolonged diestrus or metestrus, or lack of obvious estrus phase.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Thus, estrus cycles of female heterozygote were found to be irregular.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	47	To ensure the expression of COUP-TFII expression is reduced in the heterozygote, we isolated protein extracts from ovariectomized wild-type and COUP-TFII+/ to  uteri and performed Western blot analysis using COUP-TFII-specific antibodies.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Figure 2 shows that the expression of COUP-TFII is greatly reduced in comparison to the control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The bar graph indicates that the expression levels of COUP-TFII are reduced approximately 2-fold in COUP-TFII+/ to  mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Similar level of reduction in COUP-TFII expression was also shown in the ovaries of COUP-TFII +/ to  in comparison to the controls (data not shown).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The above results indicate that COUP-TFII expression correlates with the loss a single allele in the COUP-TFII+/ to  mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	52	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Western Blot Analysis of COUP-TFII Expression Level in the Uteri of COUP-TF Heterozygous and Wild-Type Mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	54	A, Representative data of COUP-TFII and ss-actin expression in the uterus of wild-type and COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice 2 wk after ovariectomized are shown.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	55	 B, COUP-TFII expression level was normalized by ss-actin.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Bar height represents the ratio of COUP-TFII heterozygote to control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	57	 COUP-TFII expression was reduced to about half in COUP-TFII +/ to  mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	58	  Expression of COUP-TFII in Female Reproductive Axis The above analysis demonstrates that COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice shows abnormal reproductive cycles and delayed puberty.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Part of this phenotype may be due to expression of COUP-TFII in the uterus because previous analysis has shown COUP-TFII is expressed in the adult female endometrium (8).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	60	 However, to determine where else COUP-TFII may be acting, the expression of COUP-TFII in the female reproductive axis was assessed.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	61	 This was accomplished using a genetically engineered mouse in which the LacZ reporter had been knocked into the COUP-TFII gene (9).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	62	 This mouse allows for the rapid and sensitive assay of the expression pattern of COUP-TFII.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Histological sections from hypothalamus, pituitaries, ovaries, and uteri from COUP-TFII-LacZ mice were analyzed by X-gal staining.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The results of this analysis are shown in Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	65	 COUP-TFII expression, as seen by X-gal staining, was found in the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH) (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	66	 3A), whereas no specific staining was detected in the pituitary gland (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	67	 In the adult ovary, strong staining was found in the theca cells, the layer surrounding the granulosa cells of ovarian follicles, but not detected in the granulosa cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Weaker staining was detected in mesenchymal cells surrounding the corpus luteum (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	69	 To ensure that the X-gal staining faithfully recapitulated the endogenous COUP-TFII expression, we used COUP-TFII-specific antibody in immunostaining to assess the expression of COUP-TFII in the ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Again, strong staining was found in the theca cells, weak staining in the corpus luteum, and no detectable staining in the granulosa cells (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The patterns of COUP-TFII expression using immunostaining are virtually identical with that shown using X-gal staining.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Thus, X-gal staining could be used as an alternative assays to assess endogenous COUP-TFII expression patterns.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	73	View larger version (130K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Expression of COUP-TFII in Female Reproductive Tract.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	75	Expression of COUP-TFII in female reproductive tract was assessed with LacZ knock-in mice or assessed by immuohistochemical staining using COUP-TFII-specific antibodies.

0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	84	 E, Sagittal section of uterus from 8-wk-old randomly cycling female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	85	 High expression in both longitudinal and circular smooth muscle cells was evident, and scattered staining was seen in endometrial stromal cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Glandular and luminal epithelial cells also showed weak staining.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	87	 AM, Antimesometrium; Mes, mesometrium; arrowheads, luminal epithelium; arrows, glandular epithelial cells; smc, smooth muscle cells.

0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	89	  In the uterus of randomly cycling females, strong staining was evident in the myometrium, weaker staining was seen in endometrial stromal cells, and very weak positive staining was shown in glandular and luminal epithelial cells (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	90	 There was no significant difference in COUP-TFII expression between mesometrium and anti-mesometrium portions of the uterus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	91	 COUP-TFII expression was assessed by LacZ activity during decidualization using gestational d 8 uteri, and the decidualized cells in antimesometrium stained strongly positive (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	92	Because uterine gene expression is regulated by steroid hormones, we also examined the effects of exogenous steroid hormones and exogenous gonadotropins on COUP-TFII expression in the uterine endometrium (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	93	 In ovariectomized females, COUP-TFII expression was high in endometrial stroma (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	94	 4A), whereas treatment with 17ss-estradiol (E2) for 48 h drastically reduced COUP-TFII expression (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Treatment with P4 prevented the reduction of COUP-TFII expression by E2 in the endometrial stroma (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Note that COUP-TFII expression in the myometrium was not obviously altered by exogenous steroid treatment.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The expression of COUP-TFII after E2 and P4 treatment was similar to that observed in the nonpregnant uterine horn of a gestational d 10 pregnant female mouse (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	98	 We also examined COUP-TFII expression after the administration of exogenous gonadotropins (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Twenty-four hours after pregnant mare s serum gonadotropin (PMSG) injection, COUP-TFII expression in endometrial stroma was obviously decreased (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	100	 4E), whereas 48 h after PMSG injection, COUP-TFII expression in the endometrium recovered partially (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	101	 A further increase of COUP-TFII expression in the endometrial stroma was found 24 and 48 h after human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) injection (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	102	View larger version (138K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Hormonal Regulation of COUP-TFII Expression in Endometrial Stroma.
