0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	115	 I, Expression of COUP-TFII was examined by immunohistochemical staining in wild-type uterus 2 wk after ovariectomy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	116	 COUP-TFII was highly expressed in endometrial stroma and myometrium but very low in grandular and luminal epithelial cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	117	  The expression pattern of COUP-TFII in the uteri was further confirmed by immunostaining using COUP-TFII-specific antibodies.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Strong staining was found in endometrial stromal cells as well as myometrium, whereas weaker staining was seen in glandular and luminal epithelial cells of the ovariectomized COUP-TFII+/ to  uteri (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The endogenous COUP-TFII expression patterns are indistinguishable from the X-gal expression pattern shown in Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	120	Normal Ovarian Function but Reduced Progesterone Levels Are Found in COUP-TFII +/ to  Females The above analysis determined that COUP-TFII is expressed in the hypothalamus, ovary, and uterus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Therefore, the reduction in fertility in the COUP-TFII +/ to  may be due to deficiencies in any of these three organs.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	122	 To determine whether the cause of the reduced fertilely may be due to a reduction in ovarian function, ovarian function was assayed by determining the ability of the ovaries to respond to a superovulatory regimen of hormones and determining the number of oocytes ovulated, as well as the production of progesterone after superovulation, as well as during pregnancy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The results of this analysis are shown in Tables 3 and 4, respectively.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	124	 There was no significant difference between COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ in the number of oocytes ovulated in response to gonadotropins.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Although the ability of the COUP-TFII +/ to  mice to ovulate is normal, perturbation in the level of progesterone, P4, production may contribute to the reduced fertility.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	126	 As shown in Table 4, P4 levels were significantly decreased in COUP-TFII +/ to  females subsequent to exogenous hCG stimulation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Measurement of P4 and pregnenolone (P5) levels in pregnant (gestational d 15) females, were shown to be lower in heterozygous females, although statistically not significant.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Therefore, the ovaries of COUP-TFII +/ to females are able to undergo normal ovulation, but the reduction in fertility may be due to impairment of the corpus luteum of COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse ovaries to produce P4 in early pregnancy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Normal Ovulation in Response to Exogenous Gonadotropins.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Circulating Ovarian Steroids in COUP-TFII Heterozygous Females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	131	  Reduction of Expression Levels of Steroidogenic Components Critical to P4 Synthesis We showed that the predominant site of expression of COUP-TFII in the ovary is the theca interna, but not in the granulosa cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Theca cells are responsible for synthesizing precursor C19 steroids in the preovulatory follicle in response to LH, and granulosa cells aromatize the precursor steroids in vivo under the regulation of FSH (10).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	133	 In the corpus luteum, however, large luteal cells that are believed to be derived from the granulosa cells are capable of synthesizing P4 from circulating low-density lipoprotein (LDL) (10).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Thus, vascularization of corpus luteum upon ovulation is considered to be important to supply the luteal cells with the substrates to synthesize P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	135	Considering the importance of COUP-TFII in angiogenesis (7), we conducted microscopic examination of COUP-TFII+/ to  and wild-type super ovulated ovaries to determine whether vascularization is perturbed.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Although no obvious microscopic abnormality could be detected in the COUP-TFII+/ to  ovaries, we noted the lumen of vessels in COUP-TFII +/ to  ovaries is not as dilated as the COUP-TFII +/+ control, suggesting that COUP-TFII +/ to  ovaries might not be well supplied with blood (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	137	 We then used an endothelial-specific marker, platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM), in immunostaining to examine the vessel more closely.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	138	 A considerable reduction in CD31 (PECAM-1)-positive stained vessels was seen in the COUP-TFII +/ to  corpus luteum (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	139	 5, B and C), suggesting that vascularization is compromised in COUP-TFII +/ to  ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	140	 This could contribute at least partly to the reduction of observable progesterone levels in super ovulated COUP-TF +/ to  female mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	141	View larger version (49K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Defective Vascularization of Corpus Luteum and Reduced Expression of Cyp11a1, Hsd3b1, and StAR in COUP-TFII +/ to  ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	143	A to C, Microscopic evaluation of vascularization in superovulated COUP-TFII heterozygous and wild-type ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Dilated vessels were not seen in COUP-TFII heterozygous ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	145	 B, Vascularization as assessed by immunofluorescent signal using CD31 (PECAM-1-specific antibody).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Reduced vascularization was seen in COUP-TFII +/ to  corpus luteum.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	147	 C, Nuclear staining with DAPI on the same slide as B.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	148	 D, The mRNA for COUP-TFII, CYP11a1, HSD3b1 and StAR were quantified with TaqMan-based RT-PCR.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	149	 All mRNA quantities were normalized against 18S RNA using ABI rRNA control reagents.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	150	 All experiments were performed in triplicate and verified with a duplicate set of mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Means for mRNA expression between WT and COUP-TFII +/ to  mice were compared using a Student s t test, and the P values are present in the figure.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	152	  The impaired steroid production in the COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice could also be due to alteration in the expression levels of steroidogenic components critical for P4 biosynthesis.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The impact of COUP-TFII haploinsufficiency on the expression levels of genes involved in steroid hormone biosynthesis in the ovaries of COUP-TFII+/ to  and wild-type ovaries administered a superovulatory regimen of gonadotropin was assayed by quantitative RT-PCR assays.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	154	 As a control, we first examined the mRNA expression levels of COUP-TFII and showed that COUP-TFII mRNA level was reduced to 30% in the heterozygote in compared with the wild-type controls (Fig 5D).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Similarly, a significant reduction (40%) of cytochrome P450, family 11, subfamily a, polypeptide 1 (Cyp11a1), mRNA levels was detected (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	156	 In addition, steroidogenic acute regulatory protein (StAR), hydroxy--5-steroid dehydrogenase, 3ss- and steroid -isomerase 1 (Hsd3b1) mRNA levels were also greatly reduced in COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice to less than 30% of the controls (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The reduction of mRNA expression of all these components important for P4 biosynthesis will no doubt also contribute to the observed reduction of P4 levels in the COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	158	Defective Uterine Function in COUP-TFII +/ to  Females COUP-TFII is expressed in the endometrium of the uterus, as well as the endometrial decidual cells during pregnancy (Figs.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	159	 A defect in the ability of the endometrium to undergo decidualization may greatly affect reproductive performance.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	160	 To assay the ability of the uterus to undergo decidualization, independent of hypothalamus and ovarian function, COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ mice were challenged with artificial decidual stimulus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	161	 This stimulus consisted of administering a mechanical trauma, a burred needle scratch, to the uterus of ovariectomized mice treated with exogenous E2 and P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In each animal, the left horn was given the mechanical trauma after hormonal treatment, whereas the right horn was not traumatized and could serve as a control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	163	 After the experiments, wet weight of each horn was determined and the ratio of scratched vs.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	164	 6, uterus from COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice exhibited significantly reduced decidual cell reaction when compared with COUP-TFII +/+ mouse uteri.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	165	 This above analysis indicates that the reduced fertility in COUP-TFII +/ to  mice may be in part due to a reduced ability of the endometrial stroma to undergo the necessary differentiation to support embryo implantation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	166	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Reduced Decidual Cell Reaction in COUP-TFII Heterozygote.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	168	Decidual cell reaction was induced by traumatizing left uterine horn (L) after hormonal treatment of ovariectomized wild-type or heterozygous females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Right horn (R) was left intact for control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	170	 A, Typical deciduoma formation in the left uterine horn of wild-type female is shown on the top panel, whereas limited decidual cell reaction was seen in the left uterine horn of heterozygous female shown in the bottom panel.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	171	 B, Wet weight of left horn and right horn from each animal was weighted and ratio between left stimulated horn and right control horn (L/R ratio) were calculated.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	172	 There was significant decrease (P = 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	173	018) in L/R ratio for COUP-TFII heterozygous females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	174	There is abundant expression of COUP-TFII in the VMH of the central nervous system.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Although the significance of VMH expression is not clear, several of the observed haploinsufficiency phenotypes (e.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	176	 growth retardation and delayed puberty) are consistent with the idea that the COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse may suffer from mild hypopituitarism.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	177	 However, there was no significant decrease in IGF-I in heterozygotes (data not shown), which is indicative of other potential growth perturbation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	178	 COUP-TFII has been implicated to interfere with the function of the orphan nuclear receptor steroidogenic factor 1 (SF1) (11).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	179	 SF1 null mice resulted in defective development of VMH (12).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Rescue experiments using SF1 null mutants indicated SF1 functions in VMH to regulate late onset obesity (13).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Thus, it might be interesting to speculate that COUP-TFII and SF1 reciprocally regulate growth in VMH.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Future specific deletion of COUP-TFII could elucidate this aspect of COUP-TFII function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	183	Although the role of COUP-TFII in the VMH is speculative, the role of COUP-TFII in the ovary was investigated.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	184	 COUP-TFII mice did not demonstrate impairment in ovulation but did show impairment in the ability of P4 production.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The reduced capability to synthesize P4 in response to exogenous gonadotropin suggests potential defects in the ovarian function of COUP-TFII +/ to .
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Theca cells in the ovaries are responsible for synthesizing precursor C19 steroids in the preovulatory follicle in response to LH, and granulosa cells aromatize the precursor steroids in vivo under the regulation of FSH (11).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In the corpus luteum, however, large luteal cells that are believed to be derived from the granulosa cells are capable of synthesizing P4 from circulating LDL (11).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Thus, vascularization of corpus luteum upon ovulation is considered to be important to supply the luteal cells with the substrates to synthesize P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The high expression of COUP-TFII in the theca cells, but not in granulosa cells, suggests COUP-TFII might be involved in a steroidogenic pathway, or it might have a significant role during vascularization of the corpus luteum.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Here, we showed that vascularization as measured by PECAM immunostaining is perturbed in COUP-TFII +/ to  mice as compared with the controls.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	191	 This might lead to inefficient delivery of LDL to the large luteal cells resulting in the reduced ability of the corpus luteum to synthesize P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	192	 In addition, we also show that the expression levels of mRNA of CYP11a1, HSD3b1, and StAR are significantly reduced in the COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	193	 All of these genes are important for the biosynthesis of P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Thus, the reduction in the expression of these genes will directly contribute to the observable reduced P4 levels in the COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice, and the decrease in circulating P4 in pregnant COUP-TFII +/ to  females might result in the reduced ability of the uterus to support pregnancy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	195	The reduced levels of P4 in early pregnancy may impact on COUP-TFII expression in the uterus during early pregnancy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Analysis of the expression of COUP-TFII in the uterus shows that E2 treatment caused drastic decrease of COUP-TFII expression in the endometrial stroma, whereas P4 treatment with E2 attenuates E2 action, restoring COUP-TFII expression in the stroma.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	197	 COUP-TFII expression was low after treatment with PMSG, which induces ovarian E2 synthesis, and COUP-TFII expression in the endometrial stroma increased expression after hCG, which induces ovarian P4, are consistent with steroid hormone regulation in hormone-treated ovariectomized females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The lower levels of P4 in the COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse combined with the loss of one COUP-TFII allele in the uterine stromal cell may be the partial cause of the haploinsufficient decrease in uterine function in these mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	199	 However, reduced uterine stromal cell function was still observed after exogenous administration of P4 indicating that part of the haploinsufficient phenotype is specific to the uterus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	200	During implantation, the endometrial stromal cells undergo a series of complex processes called decidualization (14, 15).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The process of decidualization involves concurrent cell proliferation, differentiation, as well as angiogenesis.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Based on our findings, it is evident that uterine function is significantly affected in COUP-TFII heterozygous females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The relatively high expression of COUP-TFII in endometrial stromal cells, the steroid regulation of COUP-TFII expression in the endometrial stroma, and the reduced decidual cell reaction all support this notion.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Identification of the role of COUP-TFII in the process of decidualization may be discerned from the analysis of what other genes have been shown to regulate this process.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	205	Several targeted null mutant mice, including progesterone receptor (PR) (16), Hoxa-10 (17), and 11 (18) exhibited defects in decidual cell reaction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Consistent with the notion that P4 is required for decidualization in human endometrium, decidual cell reaction was absent in PRKO female mice (16).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	207	 One of the potential key genes that are regulated by P4 is Indian hedgehog (IHH) (8), a well-known morphogen.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Hedgehog signaling is known to regulate cell proliferation and differentiation during embryonic development (19).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The fact that IHH is expressed at preimplantation endometrial epithelial cells and its expression is rapidly induced by P4 (8) further implicates its role in mediating PR function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Importantly, it has been demonstrated that COUP-TFII is regulated by hedgehog signaling (20).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	211	 One of the intriguing possibilities is that P4 regulates IHH in the luminal epithelium, priming stroma cells for decidualization.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	212	 COUP-TFII, a downstream target of IHH could mediate IHH signaling in the endometrium during periimplantation (8).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Importantly, both IHH and COUP-TFII had been implicated in angiogenesis (7, 21).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	214	 It is our speculation that during artificially induced decidualization or repeated remodeling of endometrium after first conception, normal vascularization is moderately, but functionally significantly affected by COUP-TFII.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	215	Taken together, phenotypic analysis using the haploinsufficiency model of COUP-TFII indicated several functions of this gene in the female reproductive tract.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Combination of those haploinsufficiency phenotypes throughout the female reproductive axis might additively affect female reproductive function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Although use of this model might be limited for overall phenotypic analysis, it, perhaps, could reveal the global impact of a gene dosage effect (as in human genetic conditions) on female reproduction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	218	 We propose that COUP-TFII plays an important role in the endometrial stroma during the periimplantation period.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Detailed molecular and cellular mechanisms could be elucidated by conditional gene targeting approaches, such as using endometrial-specific Cre recombinase.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	220	LacZ Staining LacZ staining of various tissues from LacZ knock-in mice were performed as described previously (23).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Tissues from heterozygous for COUP-TFII-LacZ knock-in were dissected and fixed in 2% paraformaldehyde for 30 min at room temperature.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	222	 After washing in PBS, embryos were cryopreserved in 30% sucrose, and then embedded in OCT compound (Sakura Finetek USA, Torrance, CA).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Cryostat sections (20  microm) were incubated at room temperature for 2 h with staining solution containing 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	224	02% Nonidet P-40, 5 mM potassium ferricyanide, 5 mM potassium ferrocyanide, and 1 mg/ml X-gal.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Sections were counterstained with Eosin Y (Sigma, St.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Nuclear localization signal used for LacZ localization in the nucleus facilitated identification of specific staining in all the tissues except for neural tissues, and control sections from wild-type mice did not show any specific staining with the condition used in this study.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	227	Superovulation, Artificial Decidual Cell Reaction, and Steroid Hormone Induction Superovulation was achieved by treating 21-d-old female virgin mice with PMSG (5 IU, ip) (Sigma) followed 48 h later with hCG (5 IU, ip) (Sigma).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The mice were euthanized and ova were harvested from the oviducts 24 h after hCG administration.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Induction of the artificial decidual cell reaction was induced as described previously (16).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Briefly, 8-wk-old COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ females were ovariectomized on d 0, treated with E2 (0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	231	1  microg per mouse per day) from d 10 to 12, and treated with P4 (1 mg per mouse per day) and E2 (6.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	232	7 ng per mouse per day) from d 16 to 23.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Mechanical decidualization in the left uterine horn was performed 6 h after hormone injection on d 18.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The whole uterus was dissected 6 h after hormone injection on d 23.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The ratio of the weights of the stimulated to the unstimulated (control) horns was calculated.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Steroid hormone regulation of COUP-TFII in the mouse uterus was analyzed by administering steroid hormones to COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ female mice as follows.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Hormone treatment was conducted on 6-wk-old COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ female mice after bilateral ovariectomy 2 wk before the commencement of the hormone treatment.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Mice were then treated with E2, 5 ng sc, P4 1 mg, sc, or 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Animals were anesthetized with Avertin (2,2,2-tribromoethyl alcohol; Sigma) and killed by cervical dislocation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	240	Immunohistochemical Staining Tissues from COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  mice were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 1 h at 4 C, cryopreserved in 30% sucrose, then embedded in OCT compound (Sakura Finetek USA).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Cryostat sections (7  microm) were incubated in blocking buffer [PBS, 1% BSA, 5% normal donkey serum, 10  microg of Fab fragment donkey antimouse IgG (heavy and light chains) per ml, 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	242	02% Triton X-100] for 1 h at room temperature followed by incubation with the primary antibody [monoclonal anti-COUP-TFII (1:100,000)] overnight at 4 C.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	243	 After incubation with primary antibody, slides were incubated with biotin-SP-conjugated donkey antimouse IgG (heavy and light chains; Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories) for 1 h at room temperature, then with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated strepavidin (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR) for 1 h at room temperature.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Signals were visualized using DAB Kit (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA) and counterstained with hematoxylin.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	245	 For immunofluorescence, cryosections were incubated with biotin-conjugated polyclonal rat anti-CD31 (PECAM-1) antibody (BD Biosciences Pharmingen, San Diego, CA) [1:1000] for 2 h and signals were developed using TSA kit no.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	246	 22 (Molecular Probes) in accordance with the manufacturer s instruction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	247	Western Blot Analysis Isolated tissues were homogenized in buffer composed of 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	248	25 M sucrose, 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	249	5), 25 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, and 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	250	5 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Protein concentrations were determined by the BCA protein assay system (Pierce, Rockford, IL).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Ten micrograms of protein were mixed with 2x Laemmli Sample Buffer (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) and separated on 7.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	253	5% polyacrylamide gels, then electroblotted onto nitrocellulose membranes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Membranes were incubated with the primary antibody followed by incubation with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated antimouse IgG antibody.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Signals were visualized with ECL plus Western Blotting Detection System (Amersham Biosciences, Amersham, Buckinghamshire, UK).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Intensities of the bands were analyzed with National Institutes of Health Image software and normalized by ss-actin expression level.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	257	Quantitative RT-PCR Assays Total mRNA was isolated from snap frozen superovulated ovarian samples using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) according to manufacturer s instructions.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The mRNA for genes of interest were quantitated with TaqMan-based RT-PCR using the ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	259	 RT-PCRs were performed using One-step RT-PCR Universal Master Mix reagent and TaqMan Gene Expression Assays (Applied Biosystems) according to the manufacturer s instructions.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Cycling conditions were 95 C for 1 min, followed by 40 cycles at 95 C for 15 sec and 60 C for 1 min.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	261	 All mRNA quantities were normalized against 18S RNA using ABI rRNA control reagents.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	262	 The TaqMan Gene Expression Assays used include: Mm00490735_m1 (Cyp11a1); Mm00441558_m1 (StAR); Mm00476184_g1 (Hsd3b1); Mm00772789_m1 (Nr2f2, COUP-TFII), and Eukaryotic 18S rRNA (4319413E).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	263	 All experiments were performed in triplicate and verified with a duplicate set of mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Means for mRNA expression between WT and COUP-TFII +/ to  mice were compared using a Student s t test.

0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	269	Abbreviations: COUP-TFII, Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor II; Cyp11a1, cytochrome P450, family 11, subfamily a, polypeptide 1; E2, 17ss-estradiol; hCG, human chorionic gonadotropin; Hsd3b1, hydroxy--5-steroid dehydrogenase, 3ss- and steroid -isomerase 1; IHH, Indian hedgehog; LDL, low-density lipoprotein; P4, progesterone; PECAM, platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule; PMSG, pregnant mare s serum gonadotropin; PR, progesterone receptor; SF1, steroidogenic factor 1; StAR, steroidogenic acute regulatory protein; VMH, ventromedial hypothalamus.

0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	0	ACCELERATED PUBLICATION Crystal Structure of the HNF4 Ligand Binding Domain in Complex with Endogenous Fatty Acid Ligand* Sirano Dhe-Paganon , Karen Duda  , Melanie Iwamoto, Young-In Chi, and Steven E.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Joslin Diabetes Center  and  Department of Medicine, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts 02215.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, July 23, 2002, and in revised form, August 20, 2002.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	3	Nuclear receptors are ligand-activated transcription factors that regulate such diverse physiological processes as reproduction, development, and metabolism.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Ligand binding induces conformational changes that coordinately dissociates corepressors and recruits coactivators to enhance transcriptional activity (1, 2).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Physiologically relevant ligands, which are known for less than half of the 48 nuclear receptors encoded by the human genome, include the steroid hormones, retinoids, thyroid hormone, vitamin D3, and fatty acids.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	6	 HNF4 is considered to be an orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily because its endogenous ligand is not known (3).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Originally identified in liver, HNF4 is also present in kidney, gut, and pancreatic islets.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	8	 It functions in transcriptional cascades, downstream of TGF--activated SMAD signaling and GATA and HNF3/forkhead family transcription factors and upstream of the HNF1/POU homeodomain transcription factor.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In addition to HNF1, the many target genes for HNF4 in liver include coagulation factors and proteins involved in lipid and cholesterol metabolism and transport.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Selective targets present in kidney and intestine include erythropoietin and intestinal fatty acid binding protein, respectively.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Targeted disruption of Hnf4 in mice leads to defective gastrulation, underscoring an important role for HNF4 in the developing gut (4).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In humans, the clinically apparent phenotype associated with Hnf4 mutations is a Mendelian form of diabetes mellitus associated with abnormalities in lipoprotein and lipid concentrations (5, 6).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	13	Protein Production and Crystallization-- DNA encoding the LBD of rat HNF4 (residues 133-382) was subcloned into the pET 28a vector (Novagen) by PCR.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Protein was expressed in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3) (Invitrogen), grown either in LB or synthetic medium containing L-selenomethionine (SeMet), and isolated from bacterial lysates using Talon cobalt affinity resin (Clontech).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The His6 affinity tag was removed with bovine thrombin (10 units/ml), and the protein was further purified by ion exchange chromatography (Mono Q fast protein liquid chromatography).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Crystals were obtained at room temperature by the vapor diffusion method in 10  microl of sitting drops containing equal volumes of protein (25 mg/ml) and crystallization buffer (0.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	17	7 M ammonium acetate, 16% MPD (2-methyl-2,4-pentanediol), and 10 mM dithiothreitol).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	18	Data Collection and Structure Determination-- Diffraction data were collected at 100 K at the National Synchotron Light Source, Brookhaven, NY (beamline X12C).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Oscillation images were collected every 1 degrees , and the data were integrated and scaled using the DENZO HKL software package (10).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The structure was determined using MAD phasing of SeMet-substituted protein.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The expected bijvoet and dispersive differences (11) based on six bound seleniums in a monomer (250 residues) were 5.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The program SOLVE (12) found 20 of 24 possible selenium sites.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The phases were improved by 4-fold averaging and solvent flattening utilizing the programs MLPHARE and DM in the CCP4 suite (13).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The model was built using O (14) and refined with CNS (15), applying restrained 4-fold non-crystallographic symmetry, overall B-factor corrections, and bulk solvent corrections (Table I).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	25	Domain Architecture and Structural Homology-- The amino- and carboxyl-terminal boundaries of the LBD of HNF4 were delineated from sequence comparisons with other members of the nuclear receptor family.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Although we attempted to express longer versions, including the entire LBD plus F-domain (133-455), these degraded to shorter fragments.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Since susceptibility to proteolysis suggested that the F-domain is at least partially disordered, we expressed and crystallized the LBD domain (133-382) by itself.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Crystals belonging to the tetragonal space group P41212 (unit cell: a = b = 102.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	29	7 A) reached maximal dimensions of 0.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	30	2 mm in sitting drops within 5 days.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The structure was solved using MAD phasing of selenomethionine-substituted protein (Table I).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	32	                              View this table:    Table I Data and refinement statistics.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	33	Four protein molecules are assembled in the asymmetric unit as a pair of identical homodimers.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Each LBD of HNF4 contains 9-10  helices and two  strands that adopt the helical sandwich motif common to the LBDs of nuclear receptors (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	35	 194 core  carbons of the ligand binding domains from HNF4 and RXR (Protein Data Bank number 1FBY) (16), a close structural relative, superimpose with a root mean square deviation of 1.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Following conventional nomenclature,  helix 2 (2), which is variably present in nuclear receptor LBDs, is absent in HNF4, 6 consists of a single  helical turn, and 10 and 11 are contiguous.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Acidic residues Glu261 and Asp262 create a bulge in 5 that may be important for dimerization (17).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Electron density is apparent for all residues except those at the amino (133-140) and carboxyl (368-382) termini of the domain and within the loop between  helices 1 and 3 (the 1/3 loop, residues 157-165).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	39	View larger version (38K):    Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	40	   Structure of the HNF4 ligand binding domain.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	41	 A, a ribbon diagram of the homodimer reveals a "LBD" fold.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Helices, shaded turquoise (1-9), yellow (10), or red (12), reveal two distinct conformations: open on the left and closed on the right.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	43	  Strands are colored green, and the fatty acids in the ligand binding pockets are colored magenta.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	44	 B, the ligand and elements of secondary structure are colored similarly in the schematic representations, with open and closed conformations in the same orientations for comparison.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	45	Fatty Acids in the Ligand Binding Pocket of HNF4-- Although we did not add potential ligands to our crystallization trials, the initial electron density maps showed density in the ligand binding pocket of the domain that was not accounted for by the protein.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The excess electron density, present in all molecules of the asymmetric unit, resembled a small molecule associated with the guanidinium group of Arg226.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization and time of flight mass spectrometric analyses of HNF4 revealed, in addition to the expected parent ion for the expressed protein, the presence of non-covalently associated saturated and monounsaturated fatty acids (data not shown).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	48	 To confirm the identities of the lipids and quantify relative amounts, purified HNF4 solutions were submitted for fatty acid analysis by GC.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Recombinant rat HNF4-(133-382) contained a mixture of fatty acids, including 16:0, 17:0 cyclo, 18:17c, and 14:0 (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Similar sets of fatty acids bound a longer form of rat HNF4 containing the entire carboxyl-terminal F domain (residues 133-455, data not shown) and the LBD of human HNF4 (residues 140-382), which differs from the rat domain at seven positions (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	51	 These findings demonstrate that both human and rat proteins associate spontaneously with endogenous fatty acids and that the F domain does not influence binding.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	52	View larger version (19K):    Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	53	   Fatty acids bound to the HNF4 LBD.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Fatty acids were extracted from rat HNF4-(133-385), human HNF4-(140-385), and E.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	55	 coli BL21 cells, converted to the corresponding methyl esters, and analyzed by GC.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The results are plotted as percentages of total and sorted according to relative abundance in bacteria.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	57	 12:0, 14:0, and 16:0 are saturated lauric, myristic, and palmitic acids, respectively; 16:17c is monounsaturated palmitoleic acid, cyclo refers to a cyclopropyl group, 2OH and 3OH have hydroxyl groups at the 2 or 3 positions, respectively, and iso has an extra methyl group on the penultimate carbon.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Both fatty acids are listed when mixtures could not be resolved.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	59	To determine whether the LBDs select specific fatty acids from the larger pool, we subjected E.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	60	 coli BL21 cells to similar GC analyses (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The bacterial fatty acids present in greatest abundance also bound HNF4, although there appears to be a degree of selectivity.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	62	 For example, the fatty acids 16:0, 18:17c, 16:1 iso/14:0 3OH, and 19:0 cyclo 8c are present in greater relative abundance in the bacteria than associated with human or rat HNF4 (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	63	 2) (16:1 iso and 14:0 3OH are not distinguished by GC).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	64	 In contrast, fatty acids 17:0 cyclo, 16:1 7c/15 iso 2OH, 15 iso 3OH, and 10:0 were bound to the protein in higher relative abundance than their presence in E.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Other fatty acids such as 18:17c and 14:0 were neither selected for nor against (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Therefore, although a wide range of fatty acids were found within its ligand binding pocket, HNF4 appears to exhibit selectivity toward a subset of those found in bacteria.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Future experiments with mammalian tissues are required to determine which fatty acids bind under relevant conditions and whether the capacity of HNF4 to serve as a fatty acid sensor has physiological or pathological ramifications.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	68	The fact that the fatty acids were persistently bound even after a multistep purification indicated that they were tightly associated.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	69	 This was borne out by additional attempts to strip the lipids from the protein, as the fatty acids remained associated after dialysis and gel-filtration chromatography (data not shown).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	70	The serendipitous presence of fatty acids provided an opportunity to analyze how ligands bind to HNF4.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The lipid carboxyl group was readily identified next to the side chain of Arg226 and the methylene chain could be built to C12.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Density beyond that point was weak, indicating that the remainder of the chain is either flexible or occupies multiple conformations.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The cavity has an internal volume of 370 A3, calculated by the program Voidoo (18), which is almost entirely occupied by fatty acid.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	74	 While this volume is within the normal range for nuclear receptor LBDs, the elongated, relatively linear shape of the pocket is atypical.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Both oxygens of the fatty acid head group are ion-paired with the guanidinium group of Arg226, and one oxygen forms additional hydrogen bonds with the backbone NH of Gly237 and side chain OH of Ser181 (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Residues that line the internal surface of the ligand binding pocket are largely hydrophobic, including those arising from 3 (Ile175, Val178, Cys179, Met182), 5 (Leu219, Leu220, Ala223), 1 (Leu234, Leu236), 2 (Val242), loop 2/7 (Leu249), 7 (Met252, Val255, Ser256, Ile259), and 10 (Met342, Gln345, Ile346, Ile349) (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In the "closed" conformation 12 of HNF4 does not contact the ligand, in contrast with other nuclear receptors where 12 in the canonical agonist-bound conformation often does contact the agonist.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	78	View larger version (67K):    Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	79	   Ligand binding and the dimer interface.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	80	 A, stereo diagram of the ligand binding pocket of HNF4, with structural elements colored as described in the legend to Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	81	 B, schematic representation of interactions within the ligand binding pocket of HNF4.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Residues that interact in both open and closed forms are labeled black in a gray box, residues that interact in the closed form only are white in a gray box, and interactions found in the open form only are white in a black box.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	83	 C, interactions at the homodimer interface.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	84	Although HNF4 and RXR are similar in terms of amino acid sequence, their ligand binding specificities are distinct.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	85	 This is due in part to Phe313 in RXR, which points inward and directs bound 9-cis-retinoic acid upward toward 5 (19).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The corresponding residue in HNF4 is Ala223, which, presumably because of the decreased bulk of the side chain, allows the fatty acid ligand to curl downwards toward 7.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	87	 It is thus particularly interesting to note that F313A substitution in RXR leads to constitutive activation, due to the spontaneous binding of an endogenous fatty acid as we have seen for wild-type HNF4 (19).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The fatty acid in the binding pocket of RXR F313A adopts a U shape, and density is interpretable out to the C18 position.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In contrast, the side chains from residues Met182 and Met342 fill the upper portion of the HNF4 ligand binding pocket to prevent the fatty acid from looping around to form a U, and we don't see density past the C12 position.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	90	 These two methionine residues of HNF4 are unique among nuclear receptors.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	91	Helix 12 Adopts Two Conformations-- The two molecules within each dimer adopt distinct conformations.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In the first, referred to as the open state, 12 is fully extended and contiguous and collinear with 10 (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The second molecule of each homodimer adopts a closed conformation, with 12 situated against the body of the LBD.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The conformation of the "open" state is fixed by crystal packing between two open forms at an axis of symmetry.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In the closed state, residues Leu360, Leu361, Met364, and Leu365 form a hydrophobic face on 12 that interacts with a corresponding hydrophobic surface on the body of the domain created by residues from 3 (Met182, Lys183, Leu186, Leu187, Leu189, and Val190) and 4 (Leu211, Ala215, Gly216, and Leu219).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Residues Gln362 and Glu363 help to anchor 12 through hydrogen bonds with Lys350 in 10 and Arg212 in 4, respectively.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Since fatty acid ligands similarly occupy the ligand binding pockets of molecules in open and closed conformations, the structural rearrangement does not appear to be required for ligand-mediated activation as has been proposed for other nuclear receptors (17, 20, 21).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	98	 It is possible that to lock the domain in its closed and active state, both ligand and coactivator must be bound, but since our structure lacks coactivator, it does not test this hypothesis.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	99	The Dimer Interface-- As opposed to many nuclear receptors that form heterodimers, HNF4 functions primarily as a homodimer (22).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Consistent with this, the LBD of HNF4 crystallizes as a canonical homodimer with near-perfect 2-fold symmetry about the interface (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	101	 A 1156-A2 surface of each monomer is buried at the dimer interface.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	102	 A coiled coil interaction between 10 from each molecule dominates the interface, with hydrophobic side chain-side chain interactions (Phe325:Phe325, Leu329:Leu329, Leu330:Ile283, Leu332:Leu330, Pro333:Pro333 and Trp340:Trp340) along its length (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Intermolecular salt bridges (Glu269:Lys300, Arg303:Glu327, and Arg322:Asp312) and hydrogen bonds (Gln307:Glu327, Glu311:Gly323, and Gln336:Gln336) appear to contribute to the stability of the interface.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	104	MODY1 Mutations-- Of 14 mutations in HNF4 that have been found in patients with the MODY1 form of diabetes (5, 8, 9, 23), three encode substitutions within the LBD (V255M, E276Q, R324H).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The side chain of Val255 (in 7) points into the ligand binding cavity where it participates in ligand recognition.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	106	 While questions have been raised about functional consequences of the V255M substitution (24), the structure suggests that a methionine side chain at this position would partially occlude the ligand binding cavity and potentially alter binding affinity or specificity.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Contact between Val255 and backbone atoms of 10 in the vicinity of Met342 is also predicted to stabilize the protein fold.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Therefore, the V255M substitution might also decrease protein stability and reduce its concentration in cells or ability to homodimerize.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Side chains from the other two MODY1-associated residues, Glu276 (amino terminus of 8) and Arg324 (9/10 loop), form an ionic interaction, and Glu276 forms a second ionic interaction with Arg317 (also in the 9/10 loop).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Neither of these residues is involved directly in ligand binding, but mutations in them may influence dimerization.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	111	 While the residues themselves are not at the dimer interface, the 9/10 loops of two molecules interact with each other.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Since the residues help tether the 9/10 loops, it is likely that loss of interactions between Glu276 and Arg324 would destabilize dimerization.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Saxena of beamline X12C at the National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, for valuable assistance.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	114	* This work was supported in part by National Institutes of Health Grant R01 DK43123 (to S.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	115	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	118	The atomic coordinates and the structure factors (code 1M7W) have been deposited in the Protein Data Bank, Research Collaboratory for Structural Bioinformatics, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ (http://www.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	119	Both authors were supported by Mary K.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	120	  These authors contributed equally to this work.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	121	  Supported by National Institutes of Health Training Grant T32 DK07260.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	122	To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	123	Published, JBC Papers in Press, August 21, 2002, DOI 10.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	124	The abbreviations used are: LBD, ligand binding domain; SeMet, L-selenomethionine; MAD, multiwavelength anomalous diffraction; GC, gas chromatography; RXR, retinoid X receptor.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	125	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	0	COUP-TF interacting protein 2 represses the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription in human microglial cells Celine Marban1, Laetitia Redel1, Stella Suzanne1, Carine Van Lint2, Dominique Lecestre1, Sylvette Chasserot-Golaz3, Mark Leid4, Dominique Aunis1, Evelyne Schaeffer1 and Olivier Rohr1,5,*.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	1	1INSERM unite 575 Pathophysiology of Nervous System, Centre de Neurochimie 5 rue Blaise Pascal, 67084 Strasbourg, France 2Institute for Molecular Biology and Medicine, Laboratory of Molecular Virology 12 rue des Professeurs Jeener et Brachet, 6041 Gosselies, Belgium 3Unite CNRS UPR 2356 5, rue Blaise Pascal, 67084 Strasbourg, France 4Laboratory of Molecular Pharmacology, College of Pharmacy and Environmental Health Sciences Center, Oregon State University Corvallis, Oregon 97331-3507, France 5IUT Louis Pasteur de Schiltigheim, 1 Allee d'Athenes 67300 Schiltigheim, France.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	2	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Tel: +33 388 45 66 01; Fax: +33 388 60 08 06; Email: rohr{at}neurochem.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	4	HIV-1 gene transcription is a key step in the control of the virus life cycle [reviewed in (7)].
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Viral gene transcription is characterized by two temporally distinct phases.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The initial phase occurs immediately after integration and relies solely on cellular transcription factors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Most of the transcripts cannot elongate efficiently and terminate rapidly after initiation.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	8	 However, a few transcripts elongate throughout the genome, resulting in transcription and expression of the viral transactivator Tat.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The subsequent phase of transcription occurs when enough Tat protein has accumulated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Tat binds to TAR, recruits pTEFb complex and dramatically stimulates HIV-1 gene transcription [reviewed in (8,9)].
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	11	We have previously studied some of the cellular transcription factors that impact HIV-1 gene transcription in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor I (COUP-TFI)/Ear3, Arp1/COUP-TFII and Ear2/COUP-TFIII proteins are the three members of the COUP-TF orphan nuclear receptors superfamily.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	13	 We have described that the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TFI/Ear3 (10,11) is expressed in numerous human CNS cell lineages, including microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	14	 COUP-TFI is an activator of HIV-1 gene transcription in oligodendrocytes (12), microglia (13) and T lymphocytes (14).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Moreover, we have revealed the importance of functional interactions between the nuclear factor for interleukin 6 (NF-Il6), Sp1 and COUP-TFI in the regulation of the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription in brain cells (15).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The transcription factor Sp1 is one of the crucial cellular proteins for efficient HIV-1 gene transcription (16 to 18).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	17	 A number of studies have reported that Sp1 can serve as an anchor for indirect binding of other transcription factors to the HIV-1 long terminal repeat (LTR) region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In all cell types, an interaction between Sp1 and Tat is required for optimal HIV-enhancer activation (19).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Moreover, Sp1 is able to recruit the Cyclin T1 subunit of P-TEFb to the LTR, which helps to bypass a requirement for TAR/Tat and promotes processive transcription without Tat (20).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In microglial cells, the main HIV-1 target cells in the brain (6), Sp1 anchors COUP-TF (13) and NF-IL6 (15) to the three GC-boxes adjacent to the viral CATA box.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The CATA box is used instead of the TATAA box for optimal HIV-1 gene transcription and replication (21).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	22	 We have shown that Sp1 and COUP-TF interact and cooperate in the transcriptional activation of HIV-1 gene transcription (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Moreover, COUP-TF can substitute to Sp1 association with the viral Tat protein to restore Tat function and HIV-1 replication in microglial cells (22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	24	 These results highlight the key roles of Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins in HIV-1 expression in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	25	Members of the COUP-TF family have been shown to bind related zinc finger proteins named COUP-TF-interacting protein 1 (CTIP1) and 2 (CTIP2) that are highly expressed in brain and immune systems (23,24).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Recent results support the selective contribution of these proteins in the development and function of the nervous and immune systems (24).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	27	 We recently described that the nuclear cofactor CTIP2 inhibits the subsequent phase of HIV-1 gene transcription and viral replication by relocating the viral transactivator Tat protein to transcriptionally inactive regions of chromatin via Hp1 (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In the present work, CTIP2 overexpression leads to the repression of HIV-1 replication.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In contrast, CTIP1 was unable to affect Tat function.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Using confocal microscopy to visualize Tat subcellular distribution in the presence of each CTIP proteins, we found that CTIP2, but not CTIP1, leads to the disruption of Tat nuclear localization and to its recruitment within CTIP2-induced nuclear ball-like structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In addition, we showed that CTIP2 and Hp1 associate with Tat to form a three-protein complex.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	32	 These findings suggest that the inhibition of HIV-1 expression by CTIP2 correlates with the recruitment of Tat within CTIP2-induced structures and its relocalization within inactive regions of chromatin.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	33	On line with this study, we noticed that CTIP proteins also affect HIV-1 gene transcription in the absence of Tat, which means that CTIP proteins may also impair endogenous cellular transcription factor functions of importance for the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	34	Here, we report that CTIP proteins repress HIV-1 gene transcription via the proximal LTR region which binds Sp1 and COUP-TF transactivators.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Since COUP-TF and Sp1 cellular transcription factors are two of the major contributors to HIV-1 gene transcription in microglial cells, we have postulated that Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated LTR-driven activation may be impaired by CTIP1 and CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	36	 We report here that both CTIP1 and CTIP2 repress Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated stimulation of HIV-1 gene expression.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Since the CTIP2 repressive activity is much stronger than the CTIP1-mediated inhibition of HIV-1 replication, we focused our study on CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	38	 CTIP2-mediated repression of Sp1 and COUP-TF functions results from direct physical interactions of these cellular transcription factors with CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Association with CTIP2 forces Sp1 and COUP-TF relocation to CTIP2-induced subnuclear structures containing the heterochromatin-associated protein Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Moreover, CTIP2 can be recruited to the HIV-1 promoter by a physical association with Sp1 bound to the GC-box regions of the LTR.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Since Sp1 or COUP-TF transcription factors are necessary for the Tat function in microglial cells (22), CTIP2-mediated repression of COUP-TF and Sp1 functions may largely contribute to the previously described CTIP2-mediated impairment of Tat activity and viral replication in microglial cells (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	42	Several plasmids were kindly provided by the following investigators: GST-Sp1 constructs were provided by H.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Rotheneder (Vienna, Austria) (27) and pLTR-LUC by C.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	44	 pNL4-3 (28) was obtained through the AIDS Research and Reference Reagent Program, division of AIDS, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), NIH.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	45	To construct RFP-CTIP2, the expression vector Flag-CTIP2 was digested with EcoRI and the CTIP2 insert was subcloned into the EcoRI site of the pDSRed vector (Clontech).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The GFP-Sp1 was constructed by isolating the XhoI to HindIII Sp1 insert from the GST-Sp1 expression vector and subcloned into the XhoI to HindIII sites of the pEGFP-C1 vector (Clontech).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	47	Cell culture The human microglial (provided by M.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Tardieu, Paris, France) (29), the TZM-bl (30 to 32) and the HEK 293T cell lines were maintained in DMEM containing 10% fetal calf serum and 100 U/ml penicillin to streptomycin.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	49	Viral replication Microglial cells cultured in 12-well plates were transfected using the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method with HIV-1 pNL4-3 (1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	50	5  microg), CMV-Sp1 (1  microg) or RSV-COUP-TF (1  microg) plasmids and the indicated HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2 expression vectors (0.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Total amounts of DNA were identical in each experiment.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Compensations were made by adding the corresponding empty vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Each transfection was carried out in duplicate and repeated a minimum of three separate times with two different plasmid preparations.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	54	 HIV-1 replication was monitored as described previously (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	55	CAT assays Microglial cells cultured in 12-well plates were transfected using the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method with pLTR-CAT (3  microg), pGC-WAP-CAT (3  microg) or pLTR-CAT GC (3  microg), CMV-Sp1 (1  microg) or RSV-COUP-TF (1  microg) plasmids and the indicated HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2 (0.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	56	5 or 1  microg) expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Total amounts of DNA were identical in each experiments.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Compensations were made by adding the corresponding empty vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Each transfection was carried out in duplicate and repeated a minimum of three separate times with two different plasmid preparations.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	60	 CAT assays were carried out using standard techniques.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	61	Co-immunoprecipitation assays Microglial cells cultured in 100 mm diameter dishes were transfected using LipofectamineTM 2000 Reagent (Invitrogen) with the indicated Flag-CTIP2 (30  microg).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Twenty four hours post-transfection, the cells were washed twice with cold phosphate-buffered saline, harvested and prepared for nuclear extracts (12).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Nuclear proteins were first diluted in TNE buffer [50 mM Tris, pH 8, 1% Nonidet, 2 mM EDTA, protease inhibitors cocktail (Roche)], cleared with Protein A/G Plus-Agarose (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) and finally incubated overnight with primary antibodies: anti-Sp1 (Sigma), anti-COUP-TF (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Mertz, Madison, WI) or anti-Hp1 (kindly provided by R.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Losson, IGBMC, Strasbourg, France).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The extracts were then immunoprecipitated by the addition of Protein A/G Plus-Agarose (Santa Cruz Biotechnology).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	67	 After extensive washing with TNE buffer, the immunoprecipitates were processed for SDS to PAGE and western blot analysis.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	68	Glutathione S-transferase (GST) pull-down assays Production of GST fusion proteins was described previously (13) and visualized by Coomassie blue staining.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The 35S-labeled proteins were prepared by in vitro transcription and translation using the TNT  T7 Coupled Wheat Germ Extract System (Promega).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	70	 GST pull-down assays were performed as described previously (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	71	SDS to PAGE and western blot analysis SDS to PAGE was performed using standard techniques.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Proteins were detected using antibodies directed against the Flag epitope (M2 mouse monoclonal; Sigma), against the COUP-TF protein (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Mertz) and against the Sp1 protein (Sigma).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Proteins were visualized by chemiluminescence using the Super Signal Chemiluminescence Detection System (Pierce).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	75	Electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) The probe used in our experiments has been described previously (13) and corresponds to the three Sp1 binding sites of the HIV-1 proximal LTR region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Once produced, GST fusion proteins were eluted in glutathione buffer (50 mM Tris, pH 8, 20 mM reduced glutathione).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Purified Sp1 (Promega) and GST fusion proteins were then incubated with the 32P-labeled probe in binding buffer (20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	78	5 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT and 10% glycerol) at 4 degrees C for 15 min.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For supershift experiments, GST fusion proteins were incubated with the primary antibodies: anti-COUP-TF (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Mertz), anti-CTIP2 and anti-Sp1 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) for 16 h before adding the probe.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	81	 EMSA assays were performed as described previously (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	82	Indirect immunofluorescence and confocal microscopy Microglial cells cultured in 48-well plates were transfected or not using LipofectamineTM 2000 Reagent (Invitrogen) with Flag-CTIP2, RFP-CTIP2 and/or GFP-Sp1 expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Cells were fixed and permeabilized as described previously (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The coverslips were then incubated for 1 h at room temperature with primary antibodies directed against COUP-TF (Santa Cruz Biotechnology or kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Mertz), Sp1 (sigma) and Hp1 proteins and/or against the Flag epitope (M2 mouse monoclonal; Sigma).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The primary immunocomplexes were revealed by CY2- or CY3-labeled secondary anti-species antibodies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The stained cells were analyzed by confocal microscopy using a Zeiss laser scanning microscope (model 510 invert) equipped with a Planapo oil (63x) immersion lens (numerical aperture = 1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	88	Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays TZM-bl and HEK 293T cells cultured in 100 mm diameter dishes were transfected using the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method with the indicated pLTR-LUC, pLTR-CAT mutGC and Flag-CTIP2 (30  microg) expression vector.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	89	 ChIP assays were performed using the ChIP Assay Kit (Upstate) 48 h post-transfection.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The primary antibodies used for the ChIP were anti-Sp1 (Upstate), anti-Hp1 (Upstate), anti-COUP-TF (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) and anti-Flag M2 mouse monoclonal (Sigma).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	91	 DNA was subjected to PCR amplification using a 5' primer (5'-GATAAGGTAGAAGAGGCC-3') corresponding to the LTR sequence located 293 nt downstream of the transcriptional start site and a 3' primer (5'-CTAACCAGAGAGACCCAGTAC-3') corresponding to a region just upstream of the transcriptional start site.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The resulting PCR product (307 bp) was analyzed by agarose gel electrophoresis and ethidium bromide staining.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Three separate experiments were performed.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (12K):    Figure 1 CTIP1 and CTIP2 proteins repress HIV-1 gene transcription via the proximal LTR region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Microglial cells were transfected with 3  microg of pLTR-CAT or 3  microg of pLTR-CAT (287 to 535) in the presence or absence of 1  microg of HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Two days post-transfection, CAT activities were measured and expressed relative to the CAT activity obtained with pLTR-CAT alone with the standard deviations indicated (values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments performed in duplicate).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	97	  CTIP1 and CTIP2 cofactors inhibit Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated activation of HIV-1 gene transcription and related viral replication To decipher the mechanism whereby CTIP proteins affect the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription, we investigated the impacts of CTIP proteins on Sp1 and COUP-TF functions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Microglial cells were transfected with pLTR-CAT plasmid together with the vectors expressing COUP-TF (Figure 2A) or Sp1 (Figure 2B) proteins and with increasing amounts of HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2 expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The two proteins were able to repress COUP-TF- and Sp1-mediated stimulations of CAT activity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	100	 As a control, we performed western blot experiments, indicating that COUP-TF and Sp1 expressions were not downregulated but slightly upregulated by the cofactors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Since overexpression of COUP-TF and Sp1 stimulates HIV-1 gene expression, this modest upregulation could not be responsible for the CTIPs repressive function.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	102	 To correlate CTIP1 and CTIP2 repressive activity on LTR-driven transcription to the level of HIV-1 replication, we studied their impacts on Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated stimulations of viral replication.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Cells were transfected with HIV-1 pNL4-3 and COUP-TF (Figure 2C) or Sp1 (Figure 2D) expression vectors in the presence of increasing amounts of CTIP1 or CTIP2 expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The level of viral replication was investigated by quantifying p24 Gag expression in the culture supernatants 2 days after transfection.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	105	 While both CTIP1 and CTIP2 inhibited COUP-TF (Figure 2C) and Sp1 (Figure 2D) activation of HIV-1 NL4-3 replication, the strongest repression was observed with CTIP2 (Figure 2C and D, lanes 6 to 8), indicating that the repressing activity of CTIP2 on HIV-1 replication cannot be explained only by its previously described capacity to repress the viral Tat protein (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	106	 These results strongly suggest that CTIP1 and CTIP2 repress the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription through direct or indirect interactions with endogenous Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	107	View larger version (32K):    Figure 2 CTIP1 and CTIP2 inhibit Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated activation of HIV-1 gene transcription and related viral replication.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Microglial cells were cotransfected with 3  microg of pLTR-CAT (A and B) or 3  microg of pNL4-3 (C and D), 1  microg of RSV-COUP-TF (A and C) or CMV-Sp1 (B and D) expression vectors and increasing amounts of HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2 (0.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	109	 (A and B) Two days post-transfection, CAT activities were measured and expressed relative to the value obtained with pLTR-CAT alone with the standard deviation indicated (values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments performed in duplicate).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Western blot experiments were performed on nuclear extracts with antibodies directed against COUP-TF or Sp1 proteins as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	111	 (C and D) Two days post-transfection, culture supernatants were analyzed for p24 Gag contents and expressed relative to the value obtained with pNL4-3 alone taken as 1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Depending on the cell confluency, this value varied between 500 and 5000 pg/ml.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments performed in duplicate.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	114	  The HIV-1 Tat function and the subsequent phase of the HIV-1 gene transcription also depend on Tat association with Sp1 or COUP-TF in microglial cells (22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Since CTIP2-mediated repressive activities are much stronger than those observed for CTIP1 and since CTIP2, but not CTIP1, inhibits the subsequent phase of the HIV-1 gene transcription, we focused our mechanistic investigation on CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	116	CTIP2 interacts with COUP-TF and Sp1 in vitro by two interfaces To decipher the mechanism whereby CTIP2 represses COUP-TF and Sp1 stimulatory activities, we first examined whether these proteins were able to interact in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	117	 GST pull-down assays were performed with in vitro translated 35S-labeled CTIP2 and equal amounts of full-length or truncated GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1 fusion proteins (Figure 3A).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Results show that CTIP2 bound specifically to GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1 (Figure 3A, lanes 3 and 8, respectively) but not to the control GST protein (Figure 3A, lanes 2 and 7, respectively).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Approximately 2 to 5% and 1 to 2% of the 35S-labeled CTIP2 interacted with GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1, respectively.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Moreover, the 49 to 148 region of COUP-TF (Figure 3A, lane 5) and the 622 to 788 region of Sp1 (Figure 3A, lane 11) were still able to mediate association with CTIP2, indicating that CTIP2 interacted with the N-terminal region of COUP-TF and the C-terminal region of Sp1, both of which include zinc finger domains.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	121	View larger version (22K):    Figure 3 CTIP2 interacts in vitro with COUP-TF and Sp1 by two interfaces.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	122	 (A) Upper panels: schematic representation of the COUP-TF and Sp1 proteins; lower panels: GST pull-down assays were performed with 35S-labeled CTIP2 incubated with GST (lanes 2 and 7) or GST fusion proteins of the indicated COUP-TF domains (lanes 3 to 5) or Sp1 domains (lanes 8 to 11).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Approximately 1% of the total 35S-labeled CTIP2 obtained was loaded as input control (lanes 1 and 6).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (B) GST pull-down assays were performed with 35S-labeled full-length or truncated CTIP2 proteins incubated with GST (lanes 2 and 5), GST-COUP-TF (lane 6) or GST-Sp1 (lane 3) fusion proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Approximately 1% of the total 35S-labeled proteins used were loaded as input control (lanes 1 and 4).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Representative Coomassie stainings of GST, GST-Sp1 and GST-COUP-TF proteins were presented (B lower panels).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	127	  To precisely delineate the region of CTIP2 protein that associates with Sp1 and COUP-TF, GST pull-down assays were performed with full-length GST-COUP-TF or GST-Sp1 fusion proteins and a series of in vitro-translated 35S-labeled full-length and deletion mutants of CTIP2 (Figure 3B).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The full-length as well as deletion mutants starting at position 350, 610 and 717 did mediate interaction with GST-COUP-TF (Figure 3B, lane 6) and GST-Sp1 (Figure 3B, lane 3) but not with the control GST protein (Figure 3B, lanes 2 and 5).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	129	 These results show that CTIP2 is able to interact with Sp1 and COUP-TF via its C-terminal zinc finger domain region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	130	 We have previously shown that CTIP2 harbors two independent interaction domains with the viral Tat protein (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	131	 This prompted us to determine whether an additional interaction interface was located in the N-terminal or the central region of CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	132	 To this end, GST pull-down experiments were performed with additional deletion constructs.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	133	 As expected, the deletion mutant 350 to 716 was not able to interact with COUP-TF and Sp1, confirming that the C-terminal region of CTIP2 containing residues 717 to 813 mediates binding to these transcription factors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	134	 However, the 1 to 354 and the 145 to 434 constructs appeared to be able to restore interactions, suggesting that the central region of CTIP2 located between the residues 145 and 354 might be sufficient for COUP-TF and Sp1 association.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	135	Thus, these findings indicate that CTIP2 interacts in vitro with the zinc finger domains of COUP-TF and Sp1 by two interfaces located in the central region (residues 145 to 354) and the C-terminal region (residues 717 to 813).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	136	CTIP2 colocalizes with Sp1 and COUP-TF within Hp1-associated structures To visualize the association of CTIP2 with Sp1 and COUP-TF within the nucleus, Flag-CTIP2 transfected microglial cells were observed by immunofluorescence confocal laser microscopy (Figure 4A).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	137	 As previously described (25), anti-Flag immunostaining of Flag-CTIP2 revealed the formation of CTIP2-induced nuclear ball-like structures in microglial cells nuclei (Figure 4A, images 3, 8 and 13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Flag-CTIP2 appeared as concentrated at the periphery but absent within the structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Interestingly, observations of RFP-CTIP2 (Figure 4B, images 1 and 5) fusion protein revealed the presence of CTIP2 at the periphery but also within the previously described nuclear structures, suggesting that the Flag epitopes within these ball-like structures were probably not accessible to the anti-Flag antibodies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	140	 To control the nuclear location of RFP-CTIP2 expression, cells were transfected with RFP-CTIP2 and GFP-Lamin B expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	141	 As previously described (25), CTIP2-induced nuclear structures were located in the nucleus of microglial cells (C.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In the absence of CTIP2, endogenous COUP-TF and Sp1 proteins were expressed in the nucleoplasm with a speckled and diffused staining pattern (images 1 and 6).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Moreover, in the presence of Flag-CTIP2, these transcription factors were at least partially located to CTIP2-induced nuclear structures (Figure 4A, images 2 and 7).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Endogenous Sp1 (Figure 4A, images 9 and 10) and COUP-TF (Figure 4A, images 4 and 5) proteins colocalized with CTIP2 at the periphery of the immunostained structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Up to 87 and 70% of endogenous COUP-TF and Sp1 proteins colocalized with CTIP2, respectively.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	146	 No staining was observed inside the ball-like structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	147	 We have reported that CTIP2 relocates the viral Tat transactivator to the heterochromatin-associated protein Hp1 (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Endogenous Hp1 exhibited a diffused and speckled nuclear distribution in the absence of CTIP2 (Figure 4A, image 11).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	149	 To visualize the presence of Hp1 in CTIP2-induced structures in the absence of Tat, we performed immunodetection of endogenous Hp1 in microglial cells expressing Flag-CTIP2.
