0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	150	 As shown in Figure 4A (images 14 and 15), endogenous Hp1 colocalized with CTIP2, suggesting that endogenous COUP-TF, Sp1 and Hp1 proteins are relocated to the same CTIP2-induced nuclear structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	151	 To address whether COUP-TF and Sp1 also colocalized with CTIP2 inside the ball-like structures, we performed immunodetection of the endogenous COUP-TF protein with other different polyclonal antibodies (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Mertz) in the presence of RFP-CTIP2 and GFP-Sp1 fusion proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	153	 As shown in Figure 4B (image 2), endogenous COUP-TF was observed inside the structures, confirming that the epitope accessibility to the antibodies is determinant to COUP-TF immunodetection.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Since RFP-CTIP2 was expressed in ball-like structures (Figure 4B, images 1 and 5), GFP-Sp1 expressed alone was localized in the nucleoplasm with a diffused staining pattern (Figure 4B, image 6).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Moreover, in the presence of RFP-CTIP2, GFP-Sp1 is relocated to CTIP2-induced structures (Figure 4B, image 3).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	156	 COUP-TF and GFP-Sp1 relocation was not restricted to the periphery of the CTIP2-induced nuclear structures, since they were also detected inside the structures as shown by the presence of white staining resulting from colocalized red, blue and green staining (Figure 4B, image 4).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Thus, endogenous Sp1 proteins were probably relocated within the heterochromatic structures too.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	158	 However, they remained unaccessible to the currently used antibodies (Figure 4A, images 7 and 9).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	159	 These results strongly suggest that the cellular transcription factors, Sp1 and COUP-TF, associate with CTIP2 in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	160	View larger version (37K):    Figure 4 CTIP2 colocalizes with Sp1 and COUP-TF within Hp1-associated structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	161	 (A) Microglial cells were transfected or not with Flag-CTIP2 as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	162	 After being treated, endogenous Sp1, COUP-TF and Hp1 proteins were immunodetected with primary anti-COUP-TF (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) (images 1 and 2), anti-Sp1 (images 6 and 7) and anti-Hp1 antibodies (images 11 and 12).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Overexpressed Flag-CTIP2 was detected with antibodies directed against the Flag epitope (images 3, 8 and 13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The primary immunocomplexes were revealed by CY2- or CY3-labeled anti-species secondary antibodies (green or red staining).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Mask column (images 5, 10 and 15) shows the colocalized CY2 and CY3 stainings.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	166	 (B) Microglial cells expressing RFP-CTIP2 (image 1) and GFP-Sp1 (image 3) were subjected to endogenous COUP-TF immunodetection with anti-COUP-TF antibodies (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	167	 COUP-TF immunocomplexes were stained by CY5- (blue staining) labeled anti-species secondary antibodies (image 2).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Pattern of RFP-CTIP2 and GFP-Sp1 expressed alone are presented on images 5 and 6, respectively.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	169	 (A and B) Coverslips were subjected to confocal microscopy analysis.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	170	  CTIP2 interacts with Sp1, COUP-TF and Hp1 in microglial cells We have observed that CTIP2 colocalizes with Sp1, COUP-TF and the heterochromatin-associated protein HP1 in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	171	 To test whether Sp1, COUP-TF, CTIP2 and Hp1 are present in the same complex, we performed co-immunoprecipitation experiments on microglial nuclear extracts expressing or not the Flag-CTIP2 protein (Figure 5A).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Anti-Flag western blot immunodetections performed on anti-COUP-TF (lanes 3 and 4), anti-Sp1 (lanes 6 and 7) and anti-Hp1 (lanes 9 and 10) immunoprecipitated nuclear extracts indicated that CTIP2 interacted with COUP-TF (lane 4), Sp1 (lane 7) and Hp1 (lane 10) in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	173	 As a control, experiments performed on CTIP2 non-expressing extracts (lanes 3, 6 and 9) or on non-immune serum (NIS) immunoprecipitated nuclear extracts (lanes 2, 5 and 8) confirmed the specificity of the Flag immunodetection and the specificity of the COUP-TF, Sp1 and Hp1 immunoprecipitation experiments, respectively.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Thus, CTIP2 may be able to recruit a protein complex, including the three proteins in the nucleus of microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	175	 To address how CTIP2 links COUP-TF and Sp1 to Hp1, we performed competition pull-down assays (Figure 5B).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	176	 GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1 fusion proteins were incubated with both 35S-labeled CTIP2 145 to 434 and CTIP2 717 to 813 in the presence of increasing amounts of 35S-Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Results clearly show that CTIP2 145 to 434 remained bound to GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1, while CTIP2 717 to 813 was displaced by Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	178	 This displacement increased the amount of GST fusion proteins available for the CTIP2 145 to 434 binding.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Hp1 competed for COUP-TF and Sp1 binding to the C-terminal domain of CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	180	 These findings indicate that the 145 to 434 region of CTIP2 has a stronger binding affinity for COUP-TF and Sp1 than the 717 to 813 domain, which preferentially binds Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Thus, CTIP2 may link COUP-TF and Sp1 bound to the 145 to 434 domain and Hp1 bound to the 717 to 813 domain.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	182	 To precisely examine the formation of a ternary complex between Sp1, COUP-TF and CTIP2, we performed GST pull-down experiments of mixed 35S-labeled-Sp1 and -COUP-TF proteins with GST-CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	183	 As shown in Figure 5C, Sp1 and COUP-TF interacted together with CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Moreover, addition of increasing amounts of 145 to 434 CTIP2 or COUP-TF proteins did not compete each other for Sp1 binding (Figure 5D).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Thus, COUP-TF and CTIP2 do not compete for Sp1 binding in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Taken together, those findings strongly suggest the formation of a ternary complex occurring between Sp1, COUP-TF and CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	187	View larger version (22K):    Figure 5 CTIP2 interacts with COUP-TF, Sp1 and Hp1 in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	188	 (A) Nuclear extracts of microglial cells expressing (lanes 2, 4, 5, 7, 8 and 10) or not (lanes 3, 6 and 9) Flag-CTIP2 were immunoprecipitated with antibodies directed against COUP-TF (lanes 3 and 4), Sp1 (lanes 6 and 7) or Hp1 (lanes 9 and 10) proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Proteins were separated by SDS to PAGE and western blot analysis with anti-Flag antibodies were performed.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	190	 (B) GST pull-down competition assays were performed with equal amounts of 35S-labeled 145 to 434 and 717 to 813 CTIP2 proteins and increasing amounts of 35S-labeled Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Proteins were incubated with GST-COUP-TF or GST-Sp1 fusion proteins as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	192	 (C) GST pull-down assays were performed with equal amounts of 35S-labeled Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins and GST or GST-CTIP2 fusion proteins as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	193	 (D) GST pull-down competition assays were performed with the indicated amounts of 35S-labeled 145 to 434 CTIP2 and COUP-TF proteins and GST-Sp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	194	 (A to D) Approximately 1% of the total 35S-labeled proteins used were loaded as input control.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	195	  CTIP2 is anchored to the HIV-1 LTR by direct interactions with Sp1 bound to the LTR proximal region CTIP proteins are DNA-binding proteins, which bind a consensus sequence related to the canonical GC-box (33).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Moreover, we have previously described that COUP-TF activates HIV-1 transcription by direct protein to protein interactions with Sp1 bound to the proximal region of HIV-1 LTR (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The association of CTIP2 with Sp1 and COUP-TF (Figure 5) led us to examine how CTIP2 interacts with the HIV-1 LTR to promote viral repression.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	198	 To do that, we performed EMSA experiments with pure Sp1 proteins and bacterially produced GST-CTIP2 and GST-COUP-TF proteins that were incubated with a 32P-labeled probe corresponding to the three Sp1 binding sites (GC-box) of the HIV-1 LTR proximal region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	199	 As expected, Sp1 bound to the probe to form a shifted nucleoproteic complex (Figure 6A, lanes 1 and 7).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Interestingly, addition of GST-CTIP2 (lane 2) or GST-COUP (lane 3) but not GST (lane 4) separately promoted the formation of supershifted complexes, indicating that, as previously reported for COUP-TF (13), CTIP2 was anchored to the LTR by a physical interaction with Sp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	201	 As a control, GST-COUP-TF and GST-CTIP2 proteins, incubated alone, were unable to directly interact with the probe (lanes 5 and 6).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	202	 To confirm whether COUP-TF, CTIP2 and Sp1 form a ternary complex, we performed additional gel shift experiments in which increasing amounts of CTIP2 proteins were added to the binary Sp1/COUP-TF complex (lanes 9 and 10).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	203	 As shown, the shifted complex formed by COUP-TF and Sp1 bound to the template (lane 8) was supershifted by increasing the amount of CTIP2 in a dose-dependent manner.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Moreover, the intensity of the supershifted complexes also increased with CTIP2 quantity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Those findings are in favor of the formation of a ternary complex anchored to the HIV-1 Sp1 binding sites.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	206	 To precisely examine this complex, the mixed three proteins were incubated with their respective antibody.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	207	 EMSA experiments demonstrated that the complex observed in the presence of the three proteins (Figure 6A, lane 10 and Figure 6B, lane 1) was supershifted by the antibodies directed against CTIP2 (Figure 6B, lane 2) and COUP-TF (Figure 6B, lane 3) but not by non-immune serum (Figure 6B, lane 5) confirming the presence of the two proteins in the complex.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Moreover, incubation of the mixed three proteins with the anti-Sp1 antibodies (Figure 6B, lane 4) inhibited the formation of the nucleoprotein complex.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Thus, impairing Sp1 binding to the proxixmal region of the HIV-1 LTR results in the total abolition of the CTIP2 and COUP-TF ability to bind this region of the viral promoter.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	210	 These results confirm that both CTIP2 and COUP-TF interact with Sp1 bound to the LTR in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Previously published EMSA experiments performed with nuclear extracts of microglial cells have revealed that this region of the viral promoter binds the cellular transcription factors, Sp1 and Sp3, in microglial cells (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	212	 EMSA experiments performed with nuclear extracts of microglial cells expressing CTIP2 could not allow us to observe CTIP2 indirect binding to the LTR (C.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	213	 To bypass this technical issue and to address whether CTIP2 interacts with the viral promoter in vivo, ChIP assays were conducted on TZM-bl cells, which contain a chromatin-integrated LTR, and on transiently transfected HEK 293T cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Although the nature and/or the extent of chromatin formation on transiently transfected templates likely differ from that of chromosomal genes, previous reports have validated ChIP studies in transiently transfected cells (34,35).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The amplified proximal LTR region includes the three Sp1 binding sites but not the previously described COUP-TF binding site (12).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	216	 As expected, in the absence of CTIP2, both endogenous Sp1 and COUP-TF interact with the proximal LTR region in chromatin-integrated (Figure 6C) and transiently transfected contexts (Figure 6D, left panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Moreover, the presence of CTIP2 did not abolish Sp1 and COUP-TF recruitment (Figure 6C, row 2 and Figure 6D, left panel row 3) in agreement with the in vitro results described above.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	218	 However, in the presence of CTIP2, a lesser extent of template was immunoprecipitated with the antibodies directed against Sp1 and COUP-TF in the context of the integrated LTR (Figure 6C, row 2).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The same observations were made with the antibodies directed against Sp1 in the transiently transfected LTR context (Figure 6D, left panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	220	 As shown in Figure 6C and D (left panel), CTIP2 interacted with the proximal region of the viral promoter.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	221	 In addition, mutation of the Sp1 binding sites abolished the interaction of Sp1, COUP-TF and CTIP2 with this region of the viral LTR (Figure 6D, right panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Taken together, our in vitro and in vivo findings suggest that the Sp1-mediated recruitment of CTIP2 to the LTR occurs in a cellular context.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	223	 We could not detect Hp1 interactions with the proximal region of the LTR in the absence of CTIP2, suggesting that CTIP2 significantly increase the recruitment of Hp1 to the HIV-1 proximal promoter (Figure 6D, left panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	224	 In addition, mutation of the Sp1 binding sites also abolished CTIP2-mediated recruitment of Hp1 (Figure 6D, right panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Since Hp1 associates with heterochromatic regions, it is likely that CTIP2 promotes transcriptionally repressed heterochromatic environment to the viral LTR region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	226	View larger version (31K):    Figure 6 CTIP2 is anchored to the HIV-1 LTR by direct interactions with Sp1 bound to the LTR proximal region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	227	 (A and B) EMSA experiments were performed using purified Sp1, GST, GST-COUP-TF and GST-CTIP2 fusion proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Proteins were incubated with a 32P-labeled probe corresponding to the three Sp1 binding sites located downstream of the LTR (LAI) TATAA sequence.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	229	 (A) Increasing amounts of GST-CTIP2 proteins correspond to 5  microl (lane 9) and 10  microl (lane 10) of the used GST-CTIP2 preparation.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Supershift experiments performed in (B) were carried out with non-immune serum (lane 5) and with antibodies directed against CTIP2 (lane 2), COUP-TF (lane 3), and Sp1 (lane 4).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The specific shifted and supershifted complexes are presented.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	232	 (C) The TZM-bl cells, which contain a stably integrated LTR, were transfected or not with 30  microg of the indicated Flag-CTIP2 expression vector.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (D) HEK 293T cells were transfected with 5  microg of the indicated pLTR (left panel) or pLTR mutGC (right panel) constructs and 10  microg of Flag-CTIP2 expression vector if indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	234	 (C and D) Input lanes correspond to positive controls conduced with a fraction of the lysates used for the immunoprecipitation.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Control lanes correspond to negative controls, in which immunoprecipitation reactions were performed without antibodies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Anti-Flag, anti-Sp1, anti-COUP-TF and anti-Hp1 lanes represent amplification reactions from samples immunoprecipitated with the indicated antibodies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Results are representative of three independent experiments.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	238	  Sp1 binding sites are dominant and sufficient but not absolutely necessary for transcriptional repression mediated by CTIP2 To address the importance of the HIV-1 LTR GC-box sequence for CTIP2 repressive function, we have transfected microglial cells with the pGC-WAP-CAT reporter plasmid in the presence of Sp1 and CTIP2 expression vectors (Figure 7A).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	239	 As expected, this heterologous promoter, containing three consensus binding sites for Sp1, was highly inducible by ectopic Sp1 overexpression (lane 3).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Interestingly, overexpression of CTIP2 also repressed Sp1-mediated transcriptional stimulation in the context of the GC-WAP promoter (lane 4), indicating that Sp1 binding sites were sufficient for CTIP2 activity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	241	 These results also suggest that CTIP2 may be able to repress transcription of other Sp1-sensitive cellular genes.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	242	View larger version (12K):    Figure 7 Sp1 binding sites are dominant and sufficient but not absolutely necessary for transcriptional repression mediated by CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	243	 (A) Microglial cells were transfected with 3  microg of pGC-WAP-CAT reporter vector and 1  microg of expression vectors as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	244	 (B) Microglial cells were transfected with 3  microg of pLTR-CAT, pLTR-CAT mutGC or pLTR-CAT GC and 1  microg of the indicated Flag-CTIP2 vector.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Two days post-transfection, CAT activities were measured and expressed relative to the value obtained with the reporter plasmids pGC-WAP-CAT or pLTR-CAT alone with the standard deviations indicated (values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments carried out in duplicate).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	246	  To decipher whether CTIP2 repressive function is exclusively mediated by the Sp1 binding sites, we have further examined the LTR sequences responsible for CTIP2-mediated transcriptional repression.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	247	 To do that, we have transfected microglial cells with pLTR-CAT vectors containing mutated or deleted GC-boxes in the presence or absence of CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	248	 As previously shown, CTIP2 expression resulted in a strong repression of the basal LTR-driven CAT activity (Figure 7B, lane 2).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Mutation (lane 3) or deletion (lane 5) of the Sp1 binding sites resulted in a  > 90% impairment of the LTR transcriptional activity, confirming the importance of endogenous Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins, which bind to this region and stimulate the initial phase of LTR-driven transcription in microglial cells (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Surprisingly, CTIP2 was still able to repress the low remaining transcriptional activity of the mutated (lane 4) and of the deleted (lane 6) LTR, suggesting that CTIP2 may also affect HIV-1 gene transcription via association with some other cellular transcription factors yet to be characterized.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	251	Here, we addressed the mechanism whereby CTIP2 impairs the initial phase (prior to Tat expression) of HIV-1 gene transcription in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	252	We report that CTIP proteins inhibit Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated activation of HIV-1 gene transcription and replication in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	253	 To decipher the mechanism whereby CTIP2 alters COUP-TF and Sp1 functions, we examined whether these proteins interact in vitro and in cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	254	 GST pull-down experiments revealed that CTIP2 associates with the N-terminal region of COUP-TF and with the C-terminal region of Sp1 in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	255	 In this way, CTIP2 presents two interfaces for Sp1 and COUP-TF interactions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	256	 COUP-TF and Sp1 proteins bind the central and the C-terminal region of CTIP2 in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	257	 These results are consistent with the previously reported interface domains of Arp1 (COUP-TFII) with CTIP1 (23).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Confocal microscopy observations of COUP-TF and Sp1 location in the presence or absence of CTIP2 reveal that CTIP2 colocalizes with COUP-TF and Sp1 within nuclear ball-like structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Moreover, the heterochromatin-associated protein Hp1 is also present in these structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	260	 There are three Hp1 protein family members in mammals, Hp1, Hp1ss and Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The Hp1 isoform is mainly detected in transcriptionally repressed heterochromatic region (36).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Thus, the colocalization of CTIP2 with endogenous Sp1, COUP-TF and Hp1 proteins as reported here strongly suggests that these proteins are relocated to transcriptionally inactive regions of heterochromatin in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Those CTIP2-induced structures may represent a new class of nuclear structures (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Moreover, our observations may favor the hypothesis, suggesting that the formation of nuclear bodies inhibits HIV-1 gene transcription by sequestering a variety of factors required for transcriptional activation [reviewed in (37)].
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	265	Co-immunoprecipitation data indicate that the described subnuclear colocalization results from physical interactions between Sp1, COUP-TF, Hp1 and CTIP2 in the nucleus of microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Since Hp1, Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins associate with CTIP2 in microglial cells, we address their respective interaction interfaces in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Our findings show that the central zinc finger domain of CTIP2 may preferentially bind Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins, while the C-terminal region may bind to Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	268	 In the presence of the viral Tat transactivator, CTIP2 also associates with Hp1 via its C-terminal region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Taken together, these findings suggest a permanent association of CTIP2 with Hp1 via its C-terminal region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	270	 The central domain of CTIP2 may be reserved for the interactions with the functionally repressed transcription factors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Our observations indicate that COUP-TF and Sp1 could bind together to CTIP2 and that COUP-TF and CTIP2 do not compete for Sp1 binding.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Those findings suggest the formation of a ternary complex, including COUP-TF, Sp1 and CTIP2 proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Thereby, CTIP2 links these transcriptional activators to transcriptionally repressed heterochromatic region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	274	 CTIP1 and CTIP2 proteins have been described as sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins (33).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The core-binding site identified in this study is highly related to the canonical GC-box sequence.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Since Sp1 anchors COUP-TF to the GC-box sequence of the viral LTR region (12), we addressed how CTIP2 interacts with the HIV-1 promoter.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Our findings demonstrate that CTIP2 is not able to directly bind the three viral GC-box sequences in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	278	 CTIP2 is recruited to the HIV-1 LTR via its association with Sp1 bound to this region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Moreover, CTIP2 is not in competition with COUP-TF for Sp1-mediated anchorage to the viral promoter, indicating that the three proteins are linked together to the LTR in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	280	 The ChIP experiments conducted in a cellular context confirm that CTIP2, Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins do bind the proximal region of the HIV-1 promoter in chromatin-integrated and non-integrated contexts.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	281	The surprising reduction of Sp1 or COUP-TF binding to the viral promoter in the presence of CTIP2 apparently does not agree with the in vitro observations.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	282	 We show that Sp1 anchors CTIP2 and COUP-TF to the HIV-1 LTR and that Sp1 binding to the GC-box sequence is necessary for CTIP2 recruitment to this region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Nevertheless, since Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins are not accessible to their related antibodies in the CTIP2-induced nuclear structures, one wonders whether the observation of reduced binding to the LTR may result from protein sequestration and/or chromatin environment.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	284	 ChIP experiments also indicate that CTIP2 promotes Hp1 recruitment to the LTR encompassing the Sp1 binding sequences.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Mutation of the Sp1 binding sites abolished this recruitment.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Taken together, these results suggest that the Sp1-mediated anchorage of CTIP2 to the HIV-1 LTR region may recruit a large complex that promotes Hp1 association, heterochromatin environment and viral gene transcriptional silencing.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	287	 In Jurkat cells, CTIP2 associates with the histone deacetylase SirT1 in a large complex.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	288	 CTIP2-mediated recruitment of SirT1 to promoter template results in a deacetylation of the bound histones H3 and H4 and in a transcriptional repression (35).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The chromatin structure close to the HIV-1 gene promoter is involved in viral post-integration latency phenomenon (38).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Further studies will be necessary to examine the CTIP2-recruited complex that promotes HIV-1 gene silencing.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	291	To control whether the CTIP2 repressive function is mediated by Sp1 binding sites, we have examined its ability to repress a heterologous promoter containing three consensus GC-boxes.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Our findings reveal that GC-box sequences are sufficient for CTIP2-mediated repression of Sp1 stimulation, suggesting that CTIP2 may impact the transcriptional activity of other GC-box containing promoters.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	293	 In agreement with these observations, CTIP2 is still able to repress LTR-driven transcriptional activity of a LTR deleted downstream of the GC-box sequences.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Recruitment of CTIP1 to the template by a COUP-TF family member has been found to result in a transcriptional repression of a reporter gene harboring a COUP-TF binding site (23).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	295	 In the context of the HIV-1 promoter, deletion of the previously described COUP-TF binding site did not impact CTIP2 repressive function.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Moreover, EMSA and ChIP experiments demonstrate that CTIP2 interacts with the proximal region of the LTR excluding the COUP-TF binding sequence.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Taken together, these findings indicate that the COUP-TF binding sequence, located downstream to the GC-box region, might not be implicated in the CTIP2 repressive functions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	298	 As widely reported, deletion of the LTR GC-box region results in a drastic ( > 90%) reduction of the LTR-driven transcriptional activity (13 to 15,22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	299	 These observations confirm the crucial contribution of Sp1 and COUP-TF transcription factors to support viral gene transcription in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Moreover, they highlight the importance of CTIP2-mediated repression of Sp1 and COUP-TF protein functions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Most of the 80% CTIP2-mediated reduction of the basal transcriptional level may be charged on to this repressive activity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Surprisingly, CTIP2 is still able to repress the 10% remaining transcriptional activity driven by a GC-box deleted LTR, suggesting that CTIP2 may also be able to repress the expression of mutated strains of virus.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	303	 This remaining activity represents  < 10% of the global CTIP2-mediated repressive activity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	304	Nevertheless, we have previously suggested that COUP-TF restores the viral Tat function in the context of a GC-box mutated LTR by anchoring Tat to the basal transcriptional machinery (22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Interestingly, we observed that CTIP2 is also able to repress this functional cooperation (C.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	306	 These results suggest that, in this context, COUP-TF may bind CTIP2 via its N-terminal region and the general transcription factor TFIIB via its C-terminal part as described previously (39).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Thus, in the absence of Sp1-mediated linkage to the GC-box region of the HIV-1 LTR, CTIP2 may bypass Sp1 association by a COUP-TF-mediated linkage to the basal transcriptional machinery.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Moreover, this proposed indirect linkage might be weak since it appeared undetectable by ChIP experiments.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Along this line, CTIP2 might also associate to some other cellular transcription factors yet to be characterized.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	310	These studies fully complete those reporting CTIP2-mediated repression of the viral Tat function (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Since Sp1 or COUP-TF association is necessary for Tat function in microglial cells (22), it can be postulated that CTIP2-mediated impairment of Sp1 and COUP-TF function contributes to the previously observed repression of Tat function.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	312	The chromatin structure at the site of provirus integration is reminiscent to post-integration latency phenomenon (38).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	313	 In vitro, latent T-cell clones frequently contain HIV-1 genome integrated in heterochromatin structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	314	 This is in contrast to a productive infection where integration in or near heterochromatin is disfavored (40).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	315	 No antiretroviral drugs that are currently available can inhibit transcription of HIV RNA from the integrated HIV proviral DNA in infected cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Nevertheless, HDAC inhibitors are able to induce quiescent provirus, suggesting that derepression of heterochromatin structures may force viral expression from latently infected reservoirs (41,42).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Thus, investigation on factors that may promote heterochromatin structures to the viral gene promoter, such as CTIP2, appears crucial for understanding these phenomena and for the development of new anti-HIV strategies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	318	 At this stage, further studies will be necessary to precisely examine the CTIP2-associated enzymatic activities that promote transcriptional silencing.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	319	 In addition, since our investigations were restricted to the transcriptional step of the viral life cycle, it cannot be excluded that CTIP2 also counteracts other critical steps necessary to optimal viral replication.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	320	 This possibility needs further clarification.

0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	322	 (1997) Central nervous system as a sanctuary for HIV-1 infection despite treatment with zidovudine, lamivudine and indinavir AIDS, 11, 1302 to 1303[ISI][Medline] .

0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	342	 (2000) Functional interactions between C/EBP, Sp1, and COUP-TF regulate human immunodeficiency virus type 1 gene transcription in human brain cells J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	343	, 74, 65 to 73[Abstract/Free Full Text] .
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	344	 (1986) Activation of the AIDS retrovirus promoter by the cellular transcription factor, Sp1 Science, 232, 755 to 759[ISI][Medline] .
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	345	 (1989) Role of SP1-binding domains in in vivo transcriptional regulation of the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 long terminal repeat J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	346	, 63, 2585 to 2591[ISI][Medline] .
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	347	 (1995) Transcriptional trans activation by human immunodeficiency virus type 1 Tat requires specific coactivators that are not basal factors J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	348	 (1993) A cooperative interaction between NF-kappa B and Sp1 is required for HIV-1 enhancer activation EMBO J.

0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	351	 (2004) The human immunodeficiency virus type 1 promoter contains a CATA box instead of a TATA box for optimal transcription and replication J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	352	, 78, 6883 to 6890[Abstract/Free Full Text] .
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	353	 (2000) The nuclear receptor chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor interacts with HIV-1 Tat and stimulates viral replication in human microglial cells J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	354	, 275, 2654 to 2660[Abstract/Free Full Text] .
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	355	 (2000) Isolation of a novel family of C(2)H(2) zinc finger proteins implicated in transcriptional repression mediated by chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF) orphan nuclear receptors J.

0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	357	 (2004) CTIP1 and CTIP2 are differentially expressed during mouse embryogenesis Gene Expr.

0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	0	AMP-activated Protein Kinase Regulates HNF4 Transcriptional Activity by Inhibiting Dimer Formation and Decreasing Protein Stability* Yu Holly Hong  , Usha S.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Varanasi  , Wenbo Yang  and Todd Leff   ||.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the  Department of Pathology and the Center for Integrative Metabolic and Endocrine Research, Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, Michigan 48201 and the Department of Molecular Science, Pfizer Global Research and Development, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48105.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, April 18, 2003 , and in revised form, May 1, 2003.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	4	HNF4 has also been shown recently to play an important role in the regulation of hepatic glucose output, a key component of the maintenance of plasma glucose levels.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	5	 (10) recently demonstrated that the transcriptional regulation of gene for the key gluconeogenic enzyme phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase by cAMP was mediated by the transcriptional co-activator PGC-1 acting through HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	6	 These findings suggest that HNF4 may play a role in the transcriptional response of the liver to metabolic hormones and that factors regulating the activity of HNF4 could have an effect on hepatic glucose output.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	7	AMPK is the mammalian homolog of the yeast SNF1 protein kinase (11).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In yeast, the SNF1 complex is a nuclear protein that regulates expression of genes involved in glucose metabolism and is activated by phosphorylation when glucose is removed from the growth medium (12).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In mammalian cells, AMPK acts as a fuel sensor that monitors AMP and ATP levels.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	10	 It is activated by high AMP:ATP ratios during states of low energy charge.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Once activated, the enzyme reduces the activity of ATP-consuming anabolic pathways and increases the activity of catabolic ATP-producing pathways, acting to reestablish normal cellular energy balance (for review see Ref.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Depending on the tissue, a variety of physiological circumstances can cause AMPK activation including hypoglycemia (14), ischemia (15), heat shock (16), and exercise (17 to 19).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	13	 AMPK activation has been associated with several key aspects of metabolism including exercise-induced glucose uptake and fatty acid oxidation in muscle (17, 20, 21), reduced lipid (22, 23) and glucose synthesis in liver (12, 24), and altered glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in the endocrine pancreas (14, 25).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	14	AMPK is a heterotrimer consisting of a catalytic subunit and two non-catalytic and subunits (26, 27) that exist in multiple isoforms (28 to 30).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Kinase activity is regulated allosterically by AMP binding and also by direct phosphorylation mediated by an uncharacterized AMP-sensitive protein kinase.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	16	 A potential role of AMPK in the nucleus is suggested by several observations.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The first is the similarity of the mammalian kinase to the yeast SNF1 transcriptional regulator, as described above.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Second, AMPK heterotrimers containing the 2 subunit isoform are preferentially found in the nucleus (31).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In addition, AMPK has been shown to phosphorylate the transcriptional coactivator p300 and to regulate its ability to mediate nuclear receptor transcriptional activity (32).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	20	It has been reported previously (33) that AMPK activation reduces HNF4 target gene transcription.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These findings, together with the fact that both proteins participate in the regulation of similar metabolic pathways, raise the possibility that HNF4 is directly regulated by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The experiments described here examine the possibility that AMPK phosphorylates HNF4 and regulates its transcriptional activity.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	23	View larger version (31K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	24	 HNF4 is phosphorylated by AMPK in vitro.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	25	 A, autoradiogram of full-length human HNF4 phosphorylated by AMPK in an in vitro kinase reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	26	 HNF4 protein produced in an in vitro transcription/translation system was incubated with purified rat liver AMPK and [-32P]ATP.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	27	 For comparison, the same quantity of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL), a known substrate of the kinase, was phosphorylated in a parallel reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	28	 B, amino acid sequence of the consensus phosphorylation site for AMPK (53), showing the three best matches in the human HNF4 sequence (bottom).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Potential phosphorylation residues are shown in boldface.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The amino acid numbers are based on GenBankTM entry XM029795.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	31	 C, schematic map of the HNF4 protein showing the location of the DNA binding domain (DBD) and ligand binding domain (LBD) and the location of the serine 304 residue.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The four sub-fragments of the receptor that were used in phosphorylation studies are shown.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	33	 D, in vitro phosphorylation of each of the four HNF4 subfragments shown in C, in the presence or absence of AMP as indicated.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Lower panels are Western blots (WB) showing total protein amounts in the reactions.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	35	  View larger version (25K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	36	 AMPK phosphorylates HNF4 at serine 304.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	37	 A, autoradiogram of the HNF4 C fragment phosphorylated in vitro by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Wild-type and Ser-304 mutant C fragments of HNF4 produced in an in vitro transcription/translation system were incubated with purified rat liver AMPK and [-32P]ATP, in the presence or absence of AMP as indicated.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Lower panels are Western blots (WB) showing total protein amounts in the reactions.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	40	 B, phosphorylation of full-length wild-type and Ser-304 mutant HNF4 by AMPK in vitro as in A.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Numbers below each lane indicate the degree of phosphorylation relative to the wild-type protein in the absence of kinase and AMP.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The degree of phosphorylation was calculated from quantified autoradiograph and Western blot bands as the ratio of phosphorylated to total protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	43	 C, in vivo phosphorylation of the HNF4 C fragment by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	44	 BHK cells were transfected with either vector (Vec) alone or constructions producing FLAG-tagged wild-type or S304A mutant HNF4 C protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Transfected cells were treated with the AMPK activator AICAR as indicated and [32P]orthophosphate.

0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	47	  View larger version (69K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Phosphorylation at Ser-304 blocks dimerization and DNA binding.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	49	 A, the phosphomimetic HNF4 S304D mutation is defective in its ability to bind DNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	50	 In vitro transcription/translation reactions were programmed with plasmids producing full-length wild-type, S304A, or S304D HNF4 proteins (pH4c series plasmids) or with empty vector (Vec).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The DNA binding activities of the three HNF4 proteins were analyzed in a gel mobility shift assay using the proximal HNF4-binding site of the apoCIII promoter as labeled probe.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The lower panel is a Western blot showing the input amount of HNF4 protein used in the DNA binding reactions.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	53	 B, the S304D mutant HNF4 protein is defective in its ability to form HNF4 homodimers.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	54	 A GST pull-down assay was performed with in vitro produced GST-HNF4 fusion protein (wild-type, full-length).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The plasmid producing the 78-kDa GST fusion protein was co-translated with plasmids producing 52 kDa wild-type, S304A, or S304D as indicated in the presence of [35S]methionine.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Lanes 1 to 3 were subjected to GST pull-down procedure using glutathione beads, whereas lanes 4 to 6 were loaded directly on the gel without pull-down.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Lanes 7 and 8 are translations of the two input plasmids alone.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	58	 C, gel mobility shift assay showing that the phosphomimetic HNF4 S304D mutation is defective in forming functional dimers.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	59	 In vitro translated GFP-HNF4 fusion protein (81 kDa) and 52-kDa wild-type, S304A, and S304D mutants were co-translated as indicated and analyzed in a gel mobility shift assay.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The DNA-protein complexes with each of the possible dimer combinations is indicated on the right.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Equivalent amounts of each protein were used the DNA binding reactions as determined by Western blot analysis (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	62	 D, gel shift analysis of wild-type and mutant HNF4 proteins produced in vivo.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	63	 CHO cells were transfected with the indicated plasmids, treated with the AMPK activator AICAR as indicated, and nuclear extracts were prepared and subjected to gel mobility shift analysis using the apoCIII promoter proximal HNF4-binding site as a probe.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Equivalent amounts of nuclear extract were loaded on each lane.
