0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	66	  View larger version (26K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Phosphorylation of HNF4 on Ser-304 reduces protein stability.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	68	 A, Western blot showing the effect of AMPK activation on the appearance of proteolytic degradation fragments of HNF4 from CHO cells transiently transfected with the indicated pH4c series construction (W, wild type; A, S304A; D, S304D).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	69	 These construct(ion)s produce C-terminal FLAG-tagged HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	70	 AICAR (500  microM) was present as indicated during the last 24 h of the transfection, with a second addition 2 h before the cells were harvested.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Upper panel, anti-FLAG antibody, showing full-length HNF4 and smaller molecular weight fragments.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Lower panel is the same membrane reprobed with anti--actin antibodies as loading control.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	73	 B, Western blot showing the effect of S304 mutations on the rate of HNF4 protein degradation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	74	 CHO cells transiently transfected with pH4i plasmids (pH4i-WT, pH4i-304A, and pH4i-304D) producing N-terminal FLAG-tagged HNF4 protein under the control of a tetracycline-regulated promoter.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Cells were treated with doxycycline 18 h post-transfection to shut off expression of HNF4 protein and harvested at the indicated times thereafter.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Western analysis was performed using an anti-FLAG antibody to detect HNF4 and reprobed with anti-GFP antibody to detect the amount of EGFP protein produced from a co-transfected pEGFP-N1 reference plasmid.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	77	 C, results from a densitometric analysis of the blots in B.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The HNF4:GFP ratio was calculated for each lane, and the data for each construction was normalized to the 2-h time point that was set to 100.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The data are plotted as the log values of the relative HNF4 protein amount.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The calculated half-life values from regression lines are shown in hours.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	81	  View larger version (15K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Phosphomimetic S304D mutation reduces transcriptional activity of HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	83	 CHO cells were transfected with an HNF4-responsive luciferase reporter and increasing amounts (in micrograms) of either wild-type, S304A, or S304D HNF4 producing plasmids as indicated.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Relative transcription was calculated as the ratio of luciferase to -galactosidase activity (from a cotransfected reference plasmid) normalized to the activity of the vector control.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Values are the means of three replicates, and error bars represent standard deviation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	86	Cell Culture, Transfection, and Reporter Assay Transient transfections for in vivo labeling were conducted in a baby hamster kidney cell line, BHK-21, which was cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells were used in transfection for transcription assays and nuclear extract preparation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	88	 CHO cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/F-12 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	89	 All transfections were carried out with LipofectAMINE 2000 (Invitrogen).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Transfections for reporter assays were conducted in 24-well plates in triplicate for each condition.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Cells were harvested at 20 h post-transfection using lysis buffer (Promega, Madison, WI), and the lysates were analyzed with Tropix Dual Light Luciferase and -galactosidase assay kit (Tropix, Inc.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	92	, Bedford, MA) using an EG and G Berthold Microlumat 96P luminometer.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	93	In Vitro and in Vivo Phosphorylation In vitro phosphorylation assays were conducted with in vitro translated proteins produced using the TNT Quick-Coupled transcription/translation system (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	94	 TNT reactions were carried out for 60 min at 30  degrees C and then immunoprecipitated by anti-FLAG (Sigma) or anti-T7 (Novagen Inc.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	95	, Madison, WI) antibodies, and protein A/G-agarose beads (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	96	 After washing five times with HNTG buffer (20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	97	5, 50 mM NaCl, 5% glycerol, 1% Triton, 1.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	98	5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA), the purified beads were subjected to an in vitro phosphorylation reaction using 100 milliunits of purified rat liver AMPK (Upstate Inc.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	99	, Lake Placid, NY) per reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Reactions were carried out in a buffer containing 5 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	101	5 mM MgCl2,50  microM ATP, 10  microCi of [-32P]ATP, and a mixture of protein kinase C/protein kinase A inhibitors, with or without of 300  microM AMP, and incubated at 30  degrees C for 30 min.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The reactions were stopped by washing the beads three times with HNTG buffer and adding 30  microl of 2x SDS loading buffer (Invitrogen).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The protein products were separated on SDS-PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose membranes, which were then subjected to autoradiography and Western blot analysis using an anti-FLAG antibody conjugated with horseradish peroxidase (Sigma), and detected with the SuperSignal West Pico chemiluminescent system (Pierce).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	104	In vivo phosphorylation labeling was conducted in BHK cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	105	S304A mutant, along with the control vector, were transfected in 100-mm plates.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Each plate was split into two 60-mm plates 16 h post-transfection.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	107	 In vivo labeling was conducted with 1 mCi (37 MBq) of [32P]orthophosphate per plate for 1 h at 40 h post-transfection, with or without of 500  microM 5'-aminoimidazol-4-carboxoxamide 1--D-ribofuranoside (AICAR).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Cells were harvested in 600  microl of HNTG buffer and mixed for 30 min at 4  degrees C.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The cell lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-FLAG monoclonal antibody (Sigma) and 50  microl of protein A/G-agarose beads for 2 h at 4  degrees C.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The beads were washed five times with same buffer.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Bound proteins were eluted in 30  microl of 2x SDS loading buffer at 95  degrees C for 5 min, separated on 4 to 12% gradient SDS-PAGE gel, transferred to nitrocellulose membrane, and detected by autoradiography or Western blot using anti-FLAG antibody conjugated with horseradish peroxidase as described above.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	112	Gel Mobility Shift and Pull-down Assays CHO cells transfected with full-length, wild-type, or mutant HNF4 were harvested at 20 h post-transfection, with or without 12 h treatment of AICAR.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Nuclear extracts were prepared essentially as described (34).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The recombinant HNF4 proteins were produced in vitro using TNT Quik-Coupled transcription/translation system as described by the manufacturer (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	115	 For dimerization experiments, where different HNF4 proteins were produced from two plasmids, templates producing wild-type or mutant HNF4 proteins were used in the co-translation reactions at ratios determined in pilot translations to produce equal amounts of protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	116	 For GST pull-down assays, 25  microl of translation reactions were incubated with 15  microl of glutathione-Sepharose 4B (Amersham Biosciences) in BC-150 buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	117	5 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 1x protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Diagnostics)) for 30 min at room temperature on a rotary platform.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The beads were washed five times with BC-150 buffer, boiled in 25  microl of SDS sample buffer, and resolved on 4 to 20% gradient gels (Invitrogen).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Gels were stained with Coomassie Blue, incubated in Amplify (Amersham Biosciences) for 30 min, dried, and fluorographed.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	120	The synthetic double-stranded oligonucleotides used in DNA binding reaction were labeled with [-32P]dCTP using the Rediprime-II random labeling system (Amersham Biosciences).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The double-stranded DNA binding probe contains the proximal HNF4-binding site from the human apoCIII gene (35).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	122	 DNA binding reactions were carried out in 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	123	06% Nonidet P-40, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 1  microg of double-stranded poly(dI-dC), with 20,000 cpm of labeled probe (0.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	124	25 ng), and either with 2 to 5  microg of nuclear extract or 1  microl of TNT reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Reactions were incubated for 20 min at room temperature and then analyzed on precast 6% DNA retardation gels (Invitrogen) in 0.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	126	5x TBE at 125 V for 45 min at room temperature.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	127	Protein Stability Experiments For the experiments shown in Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	128	 4, B and C, CHO cells were transfected in 12-well plates as described above but using LipofectAMINE Plus (Invitrogen) with 1 ng of the tetracycline-regulated HNF4 expressing plasmids (pH4i-WT, pH4i-304A, and pH4i-304D) together with 20 ng of pTET-OFF and 40 ng of pEGFP-N1 (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) per well.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	129	 18 h after transfection doxycycline was added (1  microg/ml) to the culture media to stop transcription of recombinant HNF4 and cells were harvested 2, 4, 6, and 8 h later by lysis in HNTG buffer.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Gel electrophoresis and Western blot analysis to detect FLAG-HNF4 and GFP protein were carried out as described above.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	131	Mapping AMPK Phosphorylation Site on HNF4 When the HNF4 amino acid sequence was screened for the consensus target sequence for AMPK phosphorylation, three potential sites were found (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	132	 1B) with the best match to a site surrounding serine 304.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	133	 To determine whether any of these sites were targets for AMPK phosphorylation, they were each mutated to alanine and examined in an in vitro phosphorylation assay.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	134	 None of the mutants abolished phosphorylation by AMPK (data not shown), indicating that there are multiple AMPK phosphorylation sites on HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	135	 To examine phosphorylation of individual segments of the protein independently, four overlapping fragments of HNF4 were generated from subclones of the HNF4 cDNA (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	136	 When in vitro AMPK assays were conducted, all four subfragments were phosphorylated to some degree (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	137	 1D) and showed the expected enhancement of phosphorylation in the presence of AMP (an allosteric activator of the kinase).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	138	 However, when the results were normalized to the total amount of protein in the assay, the HNF4/C fragment (containing the Ser-304 site) showed the highest degree of AMP-dependent phosphorylation (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	139	 A significant amount of phosphorylation was also observed with the HNF4/A fragment.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The HNF4/A fragment contains one of the three potential consensus sites for AMPK (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	141	 However, mutation of threonine 15 to alanine in this sequence did not reduce the phosphorylation of the HNF4/A fragment, suggesting the presence of one or more cryptic AMPK sites in this part of the protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	142	To determine whether the C fragment is phosphorylated at the Ser-304 residue, the S304A mutant was transferred to the C fragment and examined in an in vitro phosphorylation assay.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	143	 2A, mutation of serine 304 completely abolished phosphorylation of the C fragment.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Although the Ser-304 site is also present in the D fragment (Fig 1C), it does not appear to be a good substrate for the kinase in this context as this fragment is phosphorylated to a much lower degree than the C fragment (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	145	 When the S304A mutation was examined quantitatively in the context of the full-length protein, it reduced phosphorylation by 50% (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Together, these results suggest that S304A is a phosphorylation site for AMPK in vitro and that additional sites are present in both the N and C termini of protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	147	In vivo, HNF4 is a phosphoprotein and is a substrate for multiple kinases (36, 37).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	148	 To explore the phosphorylation of HNF4 by AMPK in vivo, wild-type and S304A versions of the HNF4/C fragment were cloned into a eukaryotic expression vector and transfected into baby hamster kidney (BHK) cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In vivo phosphorylation labeling was carried out with these transfected cells in the presence or absence of AICAR.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	150	 AICAR is converted in cells to the AMP analog ZMP (5'-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide-1-E-D-ribofuranotide), which activates the kinase (38).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The wild-type HNF4/C fragment was phosphorylated during the labeling reaction, and the treatment of the cells with AICAR caused an 2-fold increase of phosphorylation (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	152	 This phosphorylation was completely absent when the S304A version of the fragment was used, indicating that Ser-304 is phosphorylated in vivo by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	153	 In vivo phosphorylation experiments using the full-length HNF4 protein showed the same degree of phosphorylation for the wild-type and Ser-304 mutant protein (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	154	 This may be due to a combination of high basal phosphorylation of HNF4 by multiple kinases in vivo (36, 37) and the likelihood that there are additional AMPK phosphorylation sites on HNF4 (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	155	Functional Effects of HNF4 Phosphorylation To explore potential functional effects of phosphorylation of HNF4 at serine 304, an aspartic acid residue was introduced at this site by in vitro mutagenesis to generate a charge mimic of the phosphoserine residue.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The effect of phosphorylation at Ser-304 on the ability of HNF4 to form functional homodimers and bind to DNA was examined in a gel mobility shift assay with wild-type and the phosphomimetic S304D versions of HNF4 proteins synthesized by in vitro translation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Both the wild-type and S304A version of HNF4 bound to an HNF4-response element derived from the human apoCIII promoter (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	158	 However, the S304D mutant HNF4 showed a dramatically reduced ability to bind to DNA despite similar amounts of protein present in the reaction (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Gel mobility shift experiments using HNF4 protein that was phosphorylated by AMPK in vitro showed only a mild reduction in DNA binding activity (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The effect of phosphorylation on the ability of HNF4 to bind DNA would be less pronounced than the S304D mutation if less than 100% of the HNF4 protein is phosphorylated in the in vitro kinase reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Although the efficiency of these reactions is unknown, it is likely that only a fraction of the HNF4 molecules become phosphorylated at Ser-304 leaving the non-phosphorylated protein free to form dimers and bind DNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In addition, it is also possible that dimers composed of one phosphorylated and one non-phosphorylated HNF4 molecule are competent to bind DNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	163	Because HNF4 binds DNA as a homodimer, the defective DNA binding of the S304D mutant could be due either to reduced dimer formation or to a diminished affinity of mutant dimers for DNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	164	 To examine directly the effect of the mutant on dimerization, in the absence of DNA, an in vitro association assay using 35S-labeled HNF4 monomers of different sizes was carried out.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	165	 A fusion protein of GST and wild-type HNF4 (protein size 78 kDa) was co-translated with either wild-type or mutant full-length HNF4 protein (52 kDa).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The GST-HNF4 fusion protein was purified out of the reaction with a glutathione resin together with dimerized 52-kDa wild-type or mutant HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	167	 3B) demonstrated that wild-type and S304A HNF4 readily formed dimers with the wild-type GST-HNF4 protein (arrow, lanes 1 and 2).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	168	 In contrast, the S304D protein showed a reduced ability to interact with the wild-type GST-HNF4 (compare lane 3 to lanes 1 and 2).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Densitometry analysis of the Western blot demonstrated that the lower input amount of S304D protein (lane 6) did not account for the reduction in the amount of S304D bound to wild-type GST-HNF4 protein (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	170	To examine further the ability of dimers composed of one unphosphorylated monomer and one phosphorylated monomer to form and bind to DNA, wild-type and S304D mutant HNF4 proteins of different sizes were mixed together and the resulting dimers analyzed by gel mobility shift.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	171	 3C) demonstrate that dimers composed of one wild-type GFP-HNF4 molecule (81 kDa) and one S304D molecule (52 kDa) can form and are competent to bind DNA (lane 6) but with less efficiency than dimers of wild-type GFP-HNF4 and either wild-type or S304A HNF4 proteins (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	172	 3C, compare lane 6 to lanes 3 and 9).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	173	 3A, homodimers of S304D HNF4 failed to form (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	174	 3C, compare lane 4 to lanes 1 and 7).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Taken together, these results demonstrate that, in vitro, a negative charge on serine 304 inhibits dimer formation and that the effect is more pronounced when both monomers contain the additional negative charge.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	176	To examine the effects of Ser-304 phosphorylation on dimer formation and DNA binding in vivo, wild-type, S304A, and S304D expression constructs were transfected into CHO cells (which have very low amounts of endogenous HNF4).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	177	 After transfection, AMPK was activated by AICAR treatment, and nuclear extracts were prepared for gel mobility shift assays.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	178	 As observed in vitro the S304D phosphomimetic mutant showed reduced DNA binding activity (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In addition there is a mild reduction in DNA binding of the wild-type protein upon AICAR treatment (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	180	 3D, compare lanes 4 and 5) that did not occur in the phosphorylation-defective S304A protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	181	 However, much of this reduction in DNA binding activity correlates with changes in the amount of HNF4 present in the various transfections (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	182	 For example, the amount of S304D protein is significantly lower than the wild-type protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	183	 3D, compare lane 8 to lane 4, lower panel).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Likewise, the amount of wild-type HNF4 is reduced after AMPK activation (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	185	 3D, compare lanes 4 and 5, lower panel).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The reduction of HNF4 amounts after AICAR treatment did not occur with the phosphorylation-defective S304A mutation (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	187	 3D, compare lanes 6 and 7, lower panel) suggesting that the effect is due to phosphorylation at serine 304.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	188	 These changes in HNF4 protein amounts suggest that addition of a negative charge to serine 304 reduces the stability of the HNF4 protein in these cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	189	Potential effects of AMPK activation on HNF4 protein stability were further explored by examining the appearance of proteolytic products of wild-type and mutant HNF4 proteins in transiently transfected CHO cells treated with AICAR.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Western blot analysis shows that in the absence of AICAR detectable amounts of degradation fragments appear in only lysates from cells transfected with the phosphomimetic S304D HNF4 (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The activation of AMPK by AICAR addition induced the appearance of degradation fragments from the wild-type but not the phosphorylation-defective S304A protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	192	 These findings indicate that phosphorylation of HNF4 on serine 304 increased the proteolytic degradation of the protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	193	 In addition, these results strongly support the conclusion that AMPK phosphorylates HNF4 on serine 304 in vivo.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	194	 To measure the rate of degradation of wild-type and mutant HNF4 proteins, a tetracycline-regulated expression system was used to transiently express wild-type and 304 mutant HNF4 in transfected CHO cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	195	 18 h post-transfection, HNF4 expression was specifically extinguished by the addition of doxycycline, and the amount of HNF4 protein remaining in the cells was determined at regular intervals over the following 8 h.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	196	 4, B and C) demonstrate that the phosphomimetic S304D mutant protein was degraded more rapidly then either the wild-type or S304A proteins.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Taken together, the in vitro and in vivo results suggest that phosphorylation of HNF4 at Ser-304 has two effects on HNF4: to reduce its ability to form functional dimers, and to reduce the stability of HNF4 in vivo.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	198	The HNF4 dimerization and DNA binding results presented above predict that the AMPK-mediated phosphorylation of HNF4 on serine 304 would have a negative effect on its transcriptional activity.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	199	 To determine whether this is the case, plasmids expressing wild-type and Ser-304 mutant proteins were transfected into CHO cells together with an HNF4-responsive reporter plasmid.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	200	 As predicted from the DNA binding studies, the S304D mutant showed significantly less transcriptional activity than the wild-type HNF4 protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The S304A mutant was slightly more active than the wild-type protein suggesting the possibility that there is a basal level of phosphorylation that reduces the activity of the wild-type protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	202	 These results indicate AMPK-negative regulates HNF4 activity by phosphorylation of serine 304 and suggest that AMPK activity could influence the expression of HNF4 target genes.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	203	In addition to the effects on HNF4 dimerization and DNA binding, phosphorylation of HNF4 on Ser-304, or conversion of Ser-304 to an aspartic acid, also caused an increase in the degradation rate and a reduction in the amount of HNF4 protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Our results are consistent with previous findings showing that activation of AMPK in primary hepatocytes resulted in a reduction in the amount of endogenous HNF4 (33).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Taken together, our findings suggest a model in which one of the branches of the AMPK signaling pathway results in the phosphorylation of HNF4 on serine 304, leading to both a reduction in the amount and activity of HNF4 and a subsequent reduction in the expression of HNF4 target genes.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	206	Although the work reported here is focused on the phosphorylation of the serine 304 residue in HNF4, it is clear that this is not the only site on HNF4 that is phosphorylated by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The HNF4/A fragment from the N-terminal half of the protein was strongly phosphorylated in vitro on a site that we were not able to map.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	208	 This site (or sites) may be responsible for the remaining phosphorylation of the full-length protein that occurs when the Ser-304 residue is mutated to alanine (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	209	 We are currently mapping the AMPK site in the N terminus of HNF4 so that we can determine their functional significance.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In addition to the regulation of HNF4 activity that we describe here, it has been reported previously that HNF4 DNA binding activity is repressed by protein kinase A-mediated phosphorylation of residues in the DNA binding domain (37).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	211	 It has also been reported that phosphorylation of HNF4 on tyrosine residues affected its transcriptional activity and sub-nuclear localization (39).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	212	 These findings, together with those reported here, suggest that that HNF4 is a highly regulated transcription factor and that multiple signaling pathways influence its activity.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	213	An interesting question concerning the phosphorylation of HNF4 by AMPK in vivo is the cellular location in which it occurs.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	214	 HNF4 is strongly associated with the nucleus, whereas most of the known AMPK substrates are cytoplasmic enzymes.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Although it is possible that HNF4 is also phosphorylated by in the cytoplasm, the most appealing compartment for the interaction would be the nucleus.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Several observations support this possibility.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	217	 First, specific isoforms of the kinase have been reported to be present in the nucleus (31, 40).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Second, other transcriptional components have been reported to be potential substrates of the kinase; the co-activator p300 (32) and the carbohydrate-response transcription factor ChREBP (41).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Finally, the yeast homolog of mammalian AMPK, SNF-1, is present in the nucleus (for review see Ref.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	220	 13) and is associated with chromatin, possibly in a gene-specific pattern (42).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Together these observations suggest the intriguing possibility that at least some version of mammalian AMPK may be a component of the transcriptional complex on specific genes that are regulated by cellular energy balance.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	222	What would be the physiological outcome of reduced HNF4 target gene expression? The answer to this question depends on the tissue being considered.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	223	 In the endocrine pancreas, reduction of HNF4 activity would be predicted to have significant effect on the ability of the islet to secrete the appropriate amount of insulin.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	224	 This possibility is illustrated by the phenotype of MODY1 patients who have only one normal allele of the HNF4 gene and presumably a reduced amount of active HNF4 protein (3).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	225	 These patients have a defective insulin secretion in response that appears to be a primary effect of reduced HNF4 levels in pancreatic -cells (4, 43).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Consistent with the apparent role of HNF4 in pancreatic physiology are the observations that HNF4 regulates a variety of -cell genes involved in glucose sensing and insulin secretion (6 to 8).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	227	Like HNF4, AMPK also clearly plays a role in the physiology of the endocrine pancreas.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	228	 It is likely that the -cell senses glucose concentration as fluctuations in the amount of intracellular ATP generated by glucose oxidation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The insulin secretory machinery gauges the amount of insulin to secrete by sensing these ATP level fluctuations (for review see Ref.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	230	 It is possible that the changes in cellular energy balance in -cells that occur in normal physiology have an effect on HNF4 phosphorylation and activity and that fluctuation in HNF4 activity are part of the normal physiological regulation of the islet.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Consistent with this possibility is the observation that low glucose levels induce AMPK activity in cell lines derived from pancreatic -cells and the suggestion that changes in kinase activity are involved in insulin secretion (25).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Alternatively, it is possible that AMPK-mediated changes in HNF4 activity are relevant in pathological conditions where AMPK is aberrantly activated and HNF4 activity is suppressed below normal levels.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	233	 This situation could potentially result in a physiological circumstance analogous to the MODY1 phenotype.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	234	Another tissue where AMPK-mediated changes in HNF4 target gene expression could have a significant metabolic effect is the liver.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	235	 It has been understood for many years that HNF4 plays an important role in the liver, regulating genes involved in lipid (45), amino acid (46, 47), and glucose metabolism (48, 49) and the coagulation cascade (50).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	236	 It has been reported recently that HNF4 plays a key role in the induction of hepatic gluconeogenesis by mediating the transcriptional effects of the co-activator PGC1 (10).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	237	 On the other hand, the reduction of HNF4 levels due to haploinsufficiency in MODY1 patients did not cause major liver abnormalities (5, 51), although changes in amounts of some liver-derived serum proteins were observed (52).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	238	It is clear that an AMPK-mediated phosphorylation of HNF4 could potentially have important effects on liver and pancreatic islet physiology.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	239	 We are currently examining HNF4 phosphorylation in hepatic and pancreatic cell lines to determine whether AMPK-dependent phosphorylation of Ser-304 occurs under more physiological conditions and to ascertain the potential metabolic role of the phosphorylation events described here.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	240	   FOOTNOTES   * The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	241	 This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	243	 of Pediatrics, University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI 48109.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	244	|| To whom correspondence should be addressed: Dept.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	245	 of Pathology/CIMER, Wayne State University Medical School, 540 E.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	246	: 313-577-3006; Fax: 313-577-0057; E-mail: tleff{at}med.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	247	1 The abbreviations used are: HNF4, hepatic nuclear factor 4; AMPK, AMP-activated protein kinase; GST, glutathione S-transferase; CMV, cytomegalovirus; CHO, Chinese hamster ovary; MODY, maturity onset diabetes of the young; AICAR, 5'-aminoimidazol-4-carboxoxamide 1--D-ribofuranoside; BHK, baby hamster kidney; GFP, green fluorescent protein; EGFP, enhanced GFP.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	248	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Satya Reddy, Galina Malkin, and Neelam Srivastava for expert technical assistance and Dr.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	249	 David Taylor for providing an HNF4-GST construction.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	0	Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 Isoforms Originated from the P1 Promoter Are Expressed in Human Pancreatic ss-Cells and Exhibit Stronger Transcriptional Potentials than P2 Promoter-Driven Isoforms J.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	1	Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale Unit 459 (J.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	2	); and Diabetes Cell Therapy Unit, ERIM 106 Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale (T.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Warembourg, Lille F 59045, France.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	4	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: B.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Laine, Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale Unit 459, Laboratoire de Biologie Cellulaire, Universite H.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Warembourg, 1 Place de Verdun, F 59045 Lille, France.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	7	In mammals, HNF4 is encoded by two different genes: HNF4 and HNF4 (10).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The HNF4 gene potentially encodes nine distinct isoforms.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Their structure and nomenclature are presented in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	10	 HNF4 isoforms result from both alternate promoter usage and alternative splicing.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	11	 1A, promoter P1 initiates transcripts that contain exon 1A (isoforms 1 to 6), whereas promoter P2 initiates transcripts that contain exon 1D (isoforms 7 to 9; Refs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Isoforms 2 and 8 are the alternatively spliced variants of isoforms 1 and 7, respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	13	 They contain a 30-bp insert in their 3' sequence (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Compared with these four isoforms, isoforms 3 and 9, which have a completely different 3' sequence, are much less expressed, whereas isoforms 4 to 6 are very poorly expressed or have not yet been identified in vivo (1, 13).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The expression of HNF4 isoforms varies with development, differentiation, and tissue origin (1, 14, 15, 16).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The expression of HNF4 mainly initiates at the P1 promoter in adult liver and kidney (15).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Recently, two different groups documented the expression of transcripts of the P2 promoter in insulinoma INS-1 cells, as well as in mouse and human pancreatic islets, but did not detect transcripts of the P1 promoter, leading to the conclusion that HNF4 transcription is driven almost exclusively by the P2 promoter in the endocrine pancreas (11, 12, 17).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Strongly contrasting with these data, we observed that HNF4 transcripts initiated at the P1 promoter are substantially expressed, alongside P2 promoter transcripts, in human pancreatic ss-cells and in the rodent pancreatic ss-cell lines RIN m5F and HIT-T15.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Only HNF4 isoforms initiated at the P1 promoter contain the activation function module AF-1, which is encoded by exon 1A.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The AF-1 plays a key role in HNF4 transcriptional potential and in the recruitment of coactivators that are essential for HNF4 function (18, 19, 20).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	21	 We show that lack of the AF-1 in HNF4 isoforms initiated at the P2 promoter markedly decreases both the transcriptional potential and interaction with several coactivators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Conversely, lack of the AF-1 does not affect the repression of HNF4 activity by small heterodimer partner (SHP).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	23	 This finding highlights the functional consequences of expression of the HNF4 P1 promoter transcripts in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	24	View larger version (20K):    Figure 1.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Expression of HNF4 transcripts in human pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A, Schematic representation of the HNF4 gene showing promoters P1 and P2 (black boxes) with their respective first exon named 1A and 1D (hatched boxes).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Lines linking exons indicate splicing events; splicing of exon 1A to exon 2 yields isoforms 1 to 3, whereas splicing resulting in insertion of exon 1B (dotted lines) yields isoforms 4 to 6.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Use of exon 1C, which has not been demonstrated, is not presented.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Splicing of exon 1D to exon 2 yields isoforms 7 to 9.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Use of a second donor site at the 3' end of exon 9 yields a 30-bp insert (squares in exon 9) in isoforms 2 and 8.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	31	 B, Schematic representation of mature transcripts of the HNF4 isoforms 1, 2, 7, and 8 showing the 30-bp insert in isoforms 2 and 8.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	32	 For clarity s sake, isoforms 3 to 6 and 9, which are expressed at low levels, are not shown.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Positions of primers used in RT-PCR are indicated.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	34	 C, RT-PCR analysis of HNF4 transcripts containing exon 1D, using primers d and b.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	35	 D, RT-PCR analysis of HNF4 transcripts containing exon 1A, using primers a and b.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	36	 E, Determination of the relative amounts of isoforms 1 and/or 7 vs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	37	 isoforms 2 and/or 8 transcripts, using primers e and f.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	38	 F, RT-PCR analysis of HNF4 transcript.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	39	 G, RT-PCR of the control ss-actin.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	40	 C to G, Lane 1, molecular mass markers (in base pairs); lane 2, human pancreatic islets; lane 3, isolated human pancreatic ss-cells; lane 4, human exocrine pancreas; lane 5, rat insulinoma RIN m5F cells; lane 6, hamster insulinoma HIT-T15 cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	41	 For all RT-PCR analyses, a negative control is shown (lane 7).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	42	 H, Lack of cross-amplification of P2 promoter transcripts by primers a+b (1 and 2, PCR was performed with cloned HNF42 and -8, respectively).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	43	 I, Control of the specificity of amplification of reverse-transcribed RNAs from human pancreatic islets by primers a+b.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	44	 1, RT-PCR was performed as in D; 2, RT-PCR was performed as in D except that the step of reverse transcription was carried out in the absence of Moloney murine leukemia virus reverse transcriptase.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	45	 RNA from three donors yielded identical results.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	46	 J, Expression of P1 promoter transcripts using primers h and g designed to specifically amplify exons 1A and 2.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	47	 1, Reverse-transcribed RNA; 2, non-reverse-transcribed RNA from human pancreatic islets.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	48	Human pancreas processing Human pancreases (n = 5) were harvested from adult brain-dead donors in accord with French Regulations and with the local Institutional Ethical Committee.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Pancreatic islets were isolated after ductal distension of the pancreas and digestion of the tissue with liberase (Roche Molecular Biochemicals, Mannheim, Germany) as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Exocrine fraction was obtained as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	51	Islet enrichment and single ss-cell preparation Pancreatic islet-enriched fractions (purity 90  plus or minus  5%) were obtained from semipurified preparations by "handpicking" the dithizone-stained islets under a binocular microscope.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Single ss-cell suspensions were obtained by gentle pipetting of islets for 4 to 6 min in an enzymatic dissociation buffer containing 3.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	53	6 g/liter papain (Splittix, Bio Media, Boussens, France).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	54	2 vol of the enzyme-inhibiting solution consisting of Splitstop (Bio Media) plus fetal calf serum (3/1 vol/vol, respectively), when about 80% of islet cells appeared as single cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Cell sorting was then achieved as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	56	Semiquantitative RT-PCR Total RNA was prepared using the Macherey Nagel (Duren, Germany) RNA extraction kit according to manufacturer s protocol.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Reverse transcription and PCR were performed as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	58	 21 in conditions that were adjusted to maintain the amplification within the exponential range.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Primers used for HNF4 transcripts are shown in Table 1, and primers for the coactivator peroxisome proliferator activated receptor coactivator (PGC)-1 transcripts have the following sequences: sense, 5'-gtggatgaagacggattgcc-3'; antisense, 5'-ttctagttgtctagagtcttgg-3'.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	60	 PCR products were electrophoresed in 2% agarose gel, and band intensity was analyzed on a Kaiser camera equipped with the Gel Analyst 3.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	61	01 software (both provided by Vasse SARL, Templemars, France).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	62	  Plasmid constructs Plasmid pcDNA3 human HNF42 was described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Plasmid pcDNA3 human HNF42 Y6D/F19D was obtained by site-directed mutagenesis from pcDNA3 human HNF42 F19D (20).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The human HNF48 cDNA was obtained by PCR using human HNF42 cDNA as PCR matrix.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The sense primer encompassed the sequence +1/+49 of exon 1D (11) and a sequence hybridizing to the first 23 nucleotides of exon 2, which is common to both 2 and 8 HNF4 isoforms.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The antisense primer hybridized to sequence 1412 to 1433 of HNF42 cDNA, taking adenosine of the ATG codon of initiation methionine as position 1 (27).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	67	 This cDNA was introduced in the EcoRI and XbaI sites of pcDNA3 to generate the expression plasmid pcDNA3 human HNF48.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Constructs were verified by DNA sequencing.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The human HNF1 promoter cloned in pGL3 was a gift from Dr.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Bell (Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Chicago, IL).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Plasmids expressing the fusion proteins glutathione-S-transferase (GST)-PGC-1 (36 to 797), GST-p300 (340 to 528), GST-glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein (GRIP)-1(1122 to 1462), and GST-full-length SHP were gifts from Drs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Spiegelman (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA), Grossman (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute), Stallcup (University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA), and Gustafsson (Karolinska Institute, Huddinge, Sweden), respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The expression plasmids pCMVss-NHA p300, its pCMVss control vector, and pSG5 SHP were gifts from Drs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Grossman and Gustafsson, respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	75	EMSAs When used for control of specificity, HNF42 and -8 were synthesized in vitro as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	76	 EMSAs were performed as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	77	 28 using the 32P-labeled HNF4 response element of the HNF1 promoter and either in vitro-synthesized proteins or nuclear extracts of HIT-T15 and HepG2 cells prepared as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Supershifts were performed by incubating proteins with either the 455 antiserum (1) or the H4/55 monoclonal antibody (15) before addition of the labeled probe.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	79	Transient transfections RIN m5F cells were transiently transfected with the LipofectAmine reagent (3  microl/ microg of DNA) according to Invitrogen (SARL, Cergy Pontoise, France) recommendations.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	80	 HIT-T15 and HeLa cells were transiently transfected with the polyethylenimine reagent (4  microl/ microg of DNA) according to Euromedex (Souffelweyersheim, France) recommendations.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Normalization for differences in transfection efficiencies was performed as previously described using either the Renilla luciferase reporter plasmid in RIN m5F and HeLa cells (29) or the ss-galactosidase reporter plasmid in HIT-T15 cells (30).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Luciferase assays were performed with the Dual Luciferase kit (Promega Corp.
