0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	85	Western blot analysis Western assays were performed as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	86	 26 and revealed with the 455 antiserum (1).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	87	In vitro protein-protein interaction assays GST pull-down assays were performed as described previously (26) using 35S-methionine-labeled in vitro-synthesized HNF4 and bacterially expressed GST fusion proteins.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Interactions were quantified using the ImageQuant software on a PhosphorImager apparatus (both from Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	89	Human pancreatic ss-cells express HNF4 isoforms 1, 2, 7, 8, and HNF4 HNF4 transcripts from promoter P1 mainly represent isoforms 1 and 2, and transcripts from promoter P2 mainly represent isoforms 7 and 8, because we determined that very low levels of isoforms 3 to 6 and 9 were expressed in the cells tested.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Indeed, when using primers that specifically amplify isoforms 3 + 6 + 9 or isoforms 4 + 5 + 6 (couples of primers P6 + P7 and P9 + P10, respectively, described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	91	 14), only very faint bands could be detected (data not shown).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In addition, when analyzing transcripts from the P1 promoter, we failed to detect a band of 612 bp, the expected size of amplicons of transcripts containing exon 1B (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	93	 This result confirms the very low, if any, expression of isoforms 4 to 6.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	94	Because the insertion of 10 amino acid residues in the carboxy-terminal sequence of HNF42 was shown to facilitate recruitment of coactivators (31), we analyzed the expression of isoforms containing the 30-bp insert in ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Primers e and f, hybridizing to exons 9 and 10, respectively, were designed to amplify two fragments, the larger one containing the 30-bp insert of isoforms 2 and 8 (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The levels of expression of isoforms 2 and/or 8 were equivalent to those of isoforms 1 and/or 7 in human pancreatic islets and isolated human pancreatic ss-cells (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Similar results were obtained with RIN m5F and HIT-T15 RNA (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	98	Next we analyzed HNF4 expression using primers that specifically amplify the carboxy-terminal domain of this isoform (Table 1).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	99	 1F show that HNF4 is well expressed in human pancreatic islets, isolated human pancreatic ss-cells, and RIN m5F and HIT-T15 cells but is poorly expressed in human exocrine pancreas.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	100	Immunodetection of HNF4 proteins originated from the P1 promoter in pancreatic ss-cells To ascertain the expression of HNF4 proteins encoded by the P1 promoter transcripts containing exon 1A, we used the monoclonal antibody H4/55, which specifically recognizes the amino-terminal sequence of isoforms 1 and 2 but not isoforms 7 and 8 (15).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Because this antibody is not suitable in Western blot assays (Ryffel, G.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	102	, personal communication), HNF4 expression was studied in EMSA performed with the HNF4 response element of the HNF1 promoter (HNF1 probe).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The specificity of the H4/55 monoclonal antibody was confirmed using in vitro-synthesized HNF42 and HNF48: it supershifted the complex formed with HNF42 but not that formed with HNF48 (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Conversely, complexes formed with both HNF4 isoforms could be supershifted by the 455 antiserum raised against their identical carboxy-terminal sequence (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Nuclear extracts of HepG2 cells, which predominantly express HNF41 and 2, yielded a complex that could be supershifted by both the 455 antiserum and the H4/55 monoclonal antibody (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Pancreatic ss-cells express much lower amounts of HNF4 than HepG2 cells (32), which compelled us to use 4-fold higher amounts of HIT-T15 nuclear proteins than HepG2 nuclear proteins.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	107	 This accounts for the unspecific background observed when analyzing the former material (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Nevertheless, with HIT-T15 nuclear extracts, we could easily detect a retarded band (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	109	 2B, lane 1) corresponding to a complex mainly formed with HNF4: this complex exhibited the same electrophoretic mobility as that yielded by HNF4 proteins from HepG2 cells; it could be supershifted by the 455 antiserum (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	110	 2B, lane 2) but could not be obtained using a mutated HNF1 probe that is unable to bind HNF4 (data not shown).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Addition of the H4/55 monoclonal antibody resulted in a concomitant decrease in the retarded band and formation of a strong supershifted band that could not be obtained by an antibody raised against an irrelevant peptide sequence, the Xpress tag (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This result unambiguously shows endogenous expression of HNF41 and/or -2 proteins and confirms that HNF4 P1 promoter transcripts are readily expressed in the pancreatic ss-cell line HIT-T15.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	113	 This cell line also expresses HNF4, which, when complexed with DNA, comigrates with complexes formed between DNA and HNF41 and -2 (33).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	114	 HNF4 is not recognized by the 455 and H4/55 antibodies; this could account for the partial supershift observed in lanes 2 and 3, as previously observed with nuclear extracts of intestinal villi and crypts (33).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	115	View larger version (47K):    Figure 2.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Immunodetection of HNF4 isoforms derived from the P1 promoter in the pancreatic ss-cell line HIT-T15.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	117	 EMSAs were performed with the HNF4 response element of the HNF1 promoter and either in vitro-synthesized HNF42 and HNF48 (A) or nuclear extracts of HIT-T15 (20  microg) and HepG2 (5  microg) cells (B).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	118	 DNA-protein complexes were incubated with either the 455 antiserum, which recognizes the common C-terminal end of isoforms 1, 2, 7, and 8, or the monoclonal H4/55 antibody, which recognizes the N-terminal sequence of isoforms 1 and 2, or the unrelated Xpress antibody.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Arrow and arrowhead denote DNA-HNF4 shifted complexes and supershifted complexes, respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	120	  Weak transcriptional potentials of HNF48 produced from the P2 promoter in pancreatic ss-cells HNF41 and -2, whose transcripts include exon 1A, contain the activation function AF-1 module at their amino-terminal end (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	121	 This module includes structural motifs characteristic of acidic activators and plays a key role in the transcriptional potential of HNF4 isoforms 1 and 2 (18;19).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The amino-terminal sequence of HNF47 and -8, encoded by exon 1D, does not contain these motifs and seems to lack an activation function AF-1 module.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	123	 We addressed the consequences of this sequence difference on the HNF4 transcriptional potential in pancreatic ss-cell lines, by comparing the transcriptional activities of HNF4 isoforms 2 and 8 in RIN m5F and HIT-T15 insulinoma cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	124	 To better define the effect of lack of the AF-1 on the HNF4 transcriptional potential in these cells, we also analyzed the activity of HNF42 Y6D/F19D, which has a mutated AF-1 module (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The mutated residues are crucial for the AF-1 function in hepatoma HepG2 cells (18) and in embryonal kidney HEK 293T cells (Eeckhoute, J.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	126	 In RIN m5F cells, the HNF1 promoter was activated 6.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In HIT-T15 cells, only HNF42 activated the HNF1 promoter (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The differences in transactivation were not due to low expression of HNF48 or HNF42 Y6D/F19D (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	129	 These results support the hypothesis that the lower transcriptional activity of HNF48 is due to lack of a AF-1 module.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	130	View larger version (14K):    Figure 3.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Lack or mutation of the AF-1 activation function decreased HNF4 transcriptional potential in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	132	 A, Schematic representation of HNF42 with its AF-1 module (black box), HNF42 Y6D/F19D with the mutated AF-1 (black box with white diamonds), and HNF48 lacking the AF-1.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The sequence 1 to 16 of isoform 8 (hatched box) does not share any homology with sequence 1 to 29 of isoform 2 (11 ).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	134	 RIN m5F and HIT-T15 cells (B and C, respectively) were transiently transfected with 300 ng of human HNF1 promoter-Firefly luciferase-reporter plasmid, 25 ng of the indicated HNF4 expression plasmids, and 10 ng of either pGL3-Renilla luciferase (in RIN m5F) or pCMV-ss-galactosidase (in HIT-T15).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Fold induction refers to activities without any HNF4 derivative (empty expression vector).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Error bars indicate SD values of Renilla luciferase or ss-galactosidase-normalized Firefly luciferase activities from three experiments performed in quadruplicate.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Significance of the difference with values obtained for HNF42 is indicated: ***, P  <  0.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	138	 D, Western blotting of overexpressed HNF4 proteins revealed with the 455 antiserum.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	139	  HNF48 driven from the P2 promoter exhibits reduced interaction and cooperation with several coactivators As for other nuclear hormone receptors, the HNF4 transcriptional potential is modulated by coactivators or corepressors.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The HNF4 AF-1 interacts with the coactivator p300 (18, 19, 20), as do the AF-1 of other nuclear receptors with p300 and GRIP-1 (34).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	141	 We therefore investigated the effects of lack of the AF-1 in HNF48 and mutation of this module in HNF42 Y6D/F19D on the interaction with coregulators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In this study, we included p300, GRIP-1, and PGC-1, which are HNF4 coactivators (31, 35, 36, 37), and SHP, a HNF4 corepressor (38).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	143	 GRIP-1, p300, and SHP were reported to be expressed in the endocrine pancreas (7, 39, 40), and PGC-1 expression in human pancreatic ss-cells and in insulinoma cell lines was evidenced by RT-PCR (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	144	 HNF48 interacted much less efficiently than HNF42 with p300 and GRIP-1 (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Conversely, no difference between both isoforms was observed when studying physical interaction with PGC-1 and SHP (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Results obtained with HNF42 Y6D/F19D support that the lower interaction of isoform 8 with p300 and GRIP-1 is due to the lack of AF-1 in this isoform.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	147	View larger version (35K):    Figure 4.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Effects of lack of the AF-1 activation function or of AF-1 mutation on physical interaction between HNF4 and coregulators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	149	 A, PGC-1 expression analyzed by RT-PCR.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Lane 1, Human pancreatic islets; lane 2, human exocrine pancreas; lane 3, isolated human pancreatic ss-cells; lane 4, rat insulinoma RIN m5F cells; lane 5, hamster insulinoma HIT-T15 cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	151	 B, Physical interactions with coregulators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In vitro-synthesized 35S-methionine-labeled HNF42, HNF48, or HNF42 Y6D/F19D were incubated with immobilized GST-PGC-1 (36 to 797), GST-p300 (340 to 528), GST-GRIP-1 (1122 to 1462), or GST-full-length SHP.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	153	 After extensive washing, proteins were eluted with sodium dodecyl sulfate loading buffer and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Values under photographs indicate binding of HNF42 Y6D/F19D and HNF48, relative to that of HNF42 from three independent experiments.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Inputs, corresponding to 10% of amounts of labeled proteins used in the assays, were taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	156	  Next we studied the effect of lack of the AF-1 on the cooperation between HNF4 and p300 that is required for activation of transcription (35).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	157	 To circumvent technical difficulties due to cotransfection of multiple expression plasmids in pancreatic cells and to avoid interference with endogenous HNF4 and HNF4, this study was carried out in HeLa cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	158	 When p300 was not overexpressed, the HNF1 promoter was activated 5.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	159	6-fold by HNF48 and HNF42 Y6D/F19D (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The marked difference in transactivation potentials of HNF4 isoforms 2 and 8 was not due to a difference in expression of the proteins (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The coactivator p300 had no effect on the activity of the HNF1 promoter in the absence of HNF4 but enhanced the transcriptional potential of HNF42 2-fold vs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	162	2-fold for HNF48 and HNF42 Y6D/F19D, respectively (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Therefore, when the AF-1 module was either lacking or mutated, both the physical interaction and the functional cooperation between p300 and HNF4 were decreased.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	164	 As expected from results obtained in pull-down assays, the transcriptional activities of isoforms 2 and 8 were repressed to similar extents by SHP (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	165	View larger version (16K):    Figure 5.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The transcriptional potentials of HNF42 and -8 are differently enhanced by the coactivator p300 but similarly repressed by the corepressor SHP.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	167	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of human HNF1 promoter-Firefly luciferase-reporter plasmid, 10 ng of Renilla luciferase expression plasmid, and either 12.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	168	5 ng of the indicated HNF4 expression plasmids together with 250 ng of p300 expression plasmid (A) or 25 ng of the indicated HNF4 expression plasmids together with 250 ng of SHP expression plasmid (B).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The total amounts of transfected DNA was equalized with the corresponding empty vectors (-).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Fold induction refers to the activity with no HNF4 and mediator.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Error bars indicate SD values of Renilla luciferase normalized Firefly luciferase activities from three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The extent of activation or repression is presented (values above each bar) relative to activity of each isoform or mutant (set to 100) without cotransfected mediator.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	173	 C, Western blotting of overexpressed HNF4 proteins revealed with the 455 antiserum.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	174	A mutation in the HNF4 P1 promoter significantly decreasing the promoter s activity is associated with diabetes (41).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	175	 This suggests that promoter P1 transcription may be important for normal pancreatic ss-cell function.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	176	 In addition, a HNF42 clone was isolated from a human pancreatic islet cDNA library, also arguing for the expression of HNF4 P1 promoter transcripts in endocrine pancreas (Furuta, H.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	177	Controversial results were obtained concerning HNF4 expression in exocrine pancreas (12, 32).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	178	 We confirmed results described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	179	 32 stating that HNF4 was poorly expressed in the exocrine pancreas.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	180	Compared with isoform 7, isoform 1 is a stronger transcriptional activator in nonpancreatic ss-cells except on promoters of genes that are expressed early in liver (15, 16, 42).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Our functional studies showed that the transcriptional potential of HNF42 was significantly stronger than that of isoform 8 in models of pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Interestingly, these results were obtained on the promoter of HNF1, which plays a crucial role in these cells (7, 9, 43, 44).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Because HNF1 expression is regulated by HNF4 in pancreatic ss-cells (5, 45), we suggest that expression of the HNF4 P1 promoter producing isoforms 1 and 2 is most probably of major importance in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	184	 From our data obtained with HNF42 containing a mutated AF-1, we can infer that the difference in transcriptional potential between isoforms 2 and 8 was due to the lack of the AF-1 module in the latter isoform.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	185	Furthermore, lack of AF-1 in HNF4 resulted in a decreased interaction with p300 and GRIP-1 coactivators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Interaction with p300 was studied using a fragment (amino acids 340 to 528) that interacts with both the HNF4 AF-1 and AF-2 (20).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Despite interaction through the AF-2, we observed a marked decrease in binding of HNF4 lacking the AF-1, thus highlighting the substantial contribution of AF-1 to the interaction with p300.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Consistent with this result, we observed that p300 enhanced the transcriptional potential of isoform 2 more efficiently than that of isoform 8 and HNF42 with a mutated AF-1.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Interestingly, the AF-1 module is also required for the synergistic action of p300 and GRIP-1 to enhance the HNF4 transcriptional activity (42).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	190	In contrast to these coactivators, the corepressor SHP interacted similarly with HNF42 and 8 and repressed their transcriptional activity to similar extents.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	191	 This strongly suggests that SHP-mediated recruitment of transcriptional inhibitor(s) is not AF-1 dependent.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Silencing mediator of retinoic acid and thyroid hormone receptors (SMRT), another HNF4 corepressor (46), was shown to interact similarly with HNF41 and HNF47 (42).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	193	 It appears therefore that the HNF4 AF-1 interacts only with coactivators whereas the AF-2 interacts with both coactivators and corepressors in a mutually exclusive fashion.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Because the balance between coactivators and corepressors is crucial for HNF4 transcriptional activity (38, 46), lack of the AF-1 in isoforms 7 and 8 most probably results in a shift toward a lower ability to recruit coactivators and a subsequent lower coactivator-mediated enhancement of HNF4 transcriptional potential.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	195	 SHP is highly expressed in human pancreatic islets (Moerman, E.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	196	, unpublished results) and may serve as an important checkpoint to balance the activity of the transcriptional network of pancreatic ss-cells (7, 8).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	197	 In these cells in which the HNF4 AF-2 has a high probability to be occupied by SHP, the transcriptional activity of isoforms containing the AF-1 may be more efficiently enhanced by coactivators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Thus, even if the AF-1-dependent cofactor-mediated modulations of HNF4 transcriptional activity observed in this study and in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	199	 42 remain to be shown in pancreatic ss-cells, our results strongly argue for an essential role of the promoter P1-driven HNF4 isoforms in these cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	200	A cross-regulatory loop between HNF1 and HNF4 has been evidenced in pancreatic ss-cells, as reviewed in Refs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In the model proposed by Ferrer (9), activation of the HNF1 promoter by HNF4 is crucial to maintain HNF1 expression above the threshold level required to hold the HNF1/HNF4 circuit in the switch-ON state and, consequently, to avoid ss-cell dysfunction and development of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (9).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Expression of the HNF4 P1 promoter transcripts in pancreatic ss-cells is probably crucial to maintain this circuit in the switch-ON state.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Indeed, HNF4 is expressed at a limiting amount in ss-cells, and, among isoforms 1, 2, 7, 8, and , only the first two contain the AF-1 module, which confers a stronger transcriptional potential and leads to a more efficient recruitment of coactivators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Thus, expression of isoforms 1 and 2 is likely of crucial importance in the transcriptional network controlling pancreatic islet function.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	205	   Acknowledgments   Professors Ryffel, Spiegelman, Gustafsson, Stallcup, Bell, and Grossman are acknowledged for providing the H4/55 monoclonal antibody, pGEX-PGC1, pGEX-SHP, pGEX-GRIP-1, pGL3-HNF1, and pCMCss and pGEX-p300 plasmids, respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Brand for helpful discussion and to L.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	207	   Footnotes   This work was supported by a grant from the European Foundation for the Study of Diabetes.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	208	 contributed equally to this work.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	209	Abbreviations: AF, Activation function; GRIP, glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein; GST, glutathione-S-transferase; HNF, hepatocyte nuclear factor; PGC, peroxisome proliferator activated receptor coactivator; SHP, small heterodimer partner.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	210	Accepted for publication December 24, 2002.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	0	Polyamines Modulate the Interaction between Nuclear Receptors and Vitamin D Receptor-Interacting Protein 205 Yutaka Maeda, Christophe Rachez1, Leo Hawel, III, Craig V.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	1	Environmental Toxicology Graduate Program (Y.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	2	), Departments of Cell Biology and Neuroscience (F.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	3	), University of California, Riverside, California 92521; and Cell Biology Program (C.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	4	), Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, New York 10021.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	5	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Frances M.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	6	, Department of Cell Biology and Neuroscience, University of California, Riverside, Riverside, California 92521.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	7	An increasing amount of evidence indicates that both types of coactivators interact with the activation function-2 (AF-2) region of the ligand binding domain (LBD) of the NRs via LXXLL motifs (NR interaction regions or NR boxes).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	8	 p160 family members glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein 1 (GRIP1) and steroid receptor coactivator-1 (SRC1) bind the AF-2 and help recruit p300/CBP, which has also been found to bind via the AF-2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	9	 DRIP205 (also known as TRAP220, RB18A, PBP, TRIP2), a component of the DRIP/TRAP complex, also interacts with the AF-2 via LXXLL motifs (6, 7, 8).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	10	 However, what is not clear is how a given nuclear receptor makes the switch from the p160/p300 complex to the DRIP complex.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Whereas the switch from corepressor to coactivator binding is apparently made by a conformational change in the receptor upon ligand binding, both types of coactivators bind liganded receptor and bind principally via the AF-2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This suggests that perhaps a change not in the receptor but in the coactivators is required to make the switch from one complex to another.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	13	 However, what might cause that switch is completely unknown at this point.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	14	In an attempt to answer some of these questions, we examined the interaction between an orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4, NR2A1) and the DRIP complex.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	15	 HNF4 is a somewhat unusual receptor in that it activates transcription in a constitutive fashion (i.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	16	 in the absence of exogenously added ligand).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	17	 HNF4, a highly conserved member of the superfamily, is critical to early development and is directly linked to several human diseases including diabetes and hemophilia (reviewed in Ref.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Whereas an endogenous ligand has not yet been definitively identified for HNF4 (10, 11), we and others (12, 13, 14, 15, 16) have shown that HNF4 interacts with coactivators GRIP1 and p300/CBP in the absence of added ligand and that transactivation by HNF4 is completely dependent upon the AF-2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	19	In this study, we show that the HNF4 LBD also interacts with a complex containing DRIP proteins in the absence of exogenously added ligand.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In investigating this interaction, we found that the polyamine spermine enhanced the interaction between DRIP205 and not only the HNF4 but also the VDR LBD.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In contrast, spermine decreased the interaction of both receptors with p160 family member GRIP1.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	22	 These and other results lead us to propose a model in which polyamines such as spermine help promote the switch from the p160/p300 complex to the DRIP complex.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	23	View larger version (25K):    Figure 1.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	24	Top, wt rat HNF41, from which all HNF4 constructs were derived.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Numbering indicates aa residues; A to F, conventional nomenclature for NR domains; DBD, DBD consisting of the zinc fingers (Zn2+) and hinge region (domain D).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	26	wt is the full-length, wt human DRIP205 sequence.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	27	mut contains double mutations in the two NR boxes.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	28	box encompasses aa 527 to 714 and contains the two wt NR boxes.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	29	  View larger version (22K):    Figure 2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	30	 HNF4 Interacts with the DRIP Complex in the Absence of Exogenously Added Ligand.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	31	5 mg of Namalwa B cell nuclear extracts in the presence or absence of 1  microM 1,25-(OH)2D3 (+D3) and the indicated GST fusion proteins (VDR LBD, HNF4 DBD and LBD, GST control; see Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	32	 1) as described in Materials and Methods.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Bottom, Immunoblot analysis (Western blots) of a gel done in parallel with antisera to DRIP205 (1:100), DRIP150 (1:500), or DRIP130 (1:500) as indicated (37 ).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	34	 B, Transient transfection assay as described in Materials and Methods into Saos2 cells with 2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	35	0  microg reporter construct ApoB.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	36	1  microg of the indicated HNF4 expression vector (see Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Shown is the mean luciferase activity in relative light units (RLU)  plus or minus SD of triplicates from one representative experiment of three.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	38	wt also stimulated HNF4-mediated transcription in the absence of added ligand in 293T and CV-1 cells (data not shown).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Stimulation was also observed when normalized to a ss-galactosidase control, although it was not as great because DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	40	wt also enhanced the expression from the ss-galactosidase vector (data not shown).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	41	  Polyamines Enhance the Interaction between HNF4 LBD and DRIP205 in Vitro To determine whether DRIP205 interacts directly with the LBD of HNF4, as it does with other nuclear receptors (17, 19, 20, 21, 22), GST pull-down assays were performed using in vitro-translated DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	42	wt interacted only modestly with the HNF4 LBD construct (2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	43	2%) just as it did with the VDR LBD in the absence of ligand (1.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	44	 In contrast, addition of 1,25-(OH)2D3 significantly enhanced binding to the VDR LBD (21.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	45	5%; lane 5) and served as a positive control.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	46	View larger version (42K):    Figure 3.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The Polyamine Spermine Enhances Binding of DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	48	A, Pull-down assay as described in Materials and Methods with in vitro-synthesized 35S-labeled DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	49	wt and immobilized GST fusion proteins of the HNF4 and VDR LBD (see Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	50	 1) in the absence and presence of 4  microM 1,25-(OH)2D3 (+D3) dissolved in ethanol (EtOH) as indicated.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Shown is an autoradiograph of SDS-PAGE quantified by phosphor imaging.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	52	 10% input, 10% of amount of lysate used in the reaction; % bound, percentage of total input bound normalized to binding to the GST control (GST).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	53	 B, Pull-down assay as in A with 35S-labeled DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Brackets, Partial translation products of DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	55	 10% input, 10% of amount of lysate used in the reaction; % bound, percentage of input of full-length DRIP205 bound, normalized to GST control (GST).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	56	  To resolve the apparent discrepancy between the ability of the HNF4 LBD to bring down the DRIP complex from cell extracts and the relative inability of the LBD to interact with in vitro-translated DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	57	wt, we incubated the 35S-labeled DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	58	wt with cell extracts and repeated the pull-down assay.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	59	 We found that under these conditions the DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	60	wt could indeed interact with the HNF4 LBD but that the addition of the cell extracts was not required for the effect, only the addition of the extract buffer (data not shown).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Because the most unusual components of the nuclear extraction buffer were the positively charged polyamines spermine and spermidine, we tested them in the pull-down assay.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	62	 We found that physiological concentrations of spermine (1 mM) markedly enhanced the interaction between 35S-labeled DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	63	5% to 22%, but had only a negligible affect on background binding to the GST control (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	64	 3B, compare arrow in lane 5 with lane 3, and lane 4 with lane 2).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	65	1 mM) resulted in less binding (3.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	66	5%), indicating a dose effect (lane 7).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Interestingly, truncated 35S-labeled DRIP205 products present in the lysate bound relatively well to the HNF4 LBD, irrespective of the addition of spermine (lanes 3, 5, 7, 9, bracket).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Similar effects were observed with spermidine although to a lesser degree (data not shown).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	69	In investigating the nature of the effect of spermine on the HNF4-DRIP205 interaction, we found several properties that suggest that the effect is a specific one.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	70	 For example, spermine did not enhance binding of DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	71	wt to a GST HNF4 fusion construct lacking the AF-2 (C360), indicating that the AF-2 is required (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	72	 4A, top panel, compare lane 6 with lane 3).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Spermine also only marginally affected the ability of the HNF4 LBD to interact with another protein, namely 35S-labeled HNF41 (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	74	 4A, bottom panel, compare lane 7 with lane 4; 1.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	75	3-fold effect on binding DRIP205), and this effect did not require the presence of the AF-2 (compare lane 6 with lane 3).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The effect of spermine also required the presence of the NR boxes of DRIP205 as pull-downs with the full-length DRIP205 containing mutations in the two NR boxes (DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	77	mut) were not affected by the addition of spermine (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	78	 4B, middle panel, compare lane 7 with lane 4).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Likewise, interaction with a small region of DRIP205, which encompasses just the NR boxes (DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	80	box), was not greatly affected by the addition of spermine (compare lane 7 with lane 4, bottom panel).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	81	 These results indicate that whereas the effect of spermine was dependent on the presence of the AF-2 and the NR boxes, it was not due to an increased interaction between just these two regions.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	82	 This is not surprising in that spermine is a charged molecule and the AF-2-NR box interaction is primarily a hydrophobic one.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	83	View larger version (34K):    Figure 4.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Spermine Enhances Binding of DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	85	wt to NR LBDs in an AF-2- and NR Box-Dependent Manner.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	86	wt or HNF41 (full length) and immobilized GST fusion proteins (C360, GST.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	87	 1) in the absence and presence of 1 mM spermine as indicated.

0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	91	 1) in the absence and presence of 1 mM spermine as indicated.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	92	 10% input, 10% of amount of lysate used in the reaction; % bound, percentage of total input bound normalized to binding to the GST control (GST).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	93	 C, Pull-down assay as in B with 35S-labeled DRIP205 constructs (DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	94	LBD) in the absence and presence of 1 mM spermine and 1,25-(OH)2D3 (+D3) or ethanol control (EtOH) as indicated.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	95	 10% input, 10% of amount of lysate used in the reaction; % bound, percentage of total input bound normalized to binding to the GST control (GST).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	96	  Additional studies support the notion that the effect of the spermine may be due to more than simply an enhancement of the AF-2-NR box interaction and may in fact involve the entire DRIP205 molecule.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Because other coactivators have been found to interact with the DNA binding domain (DBD) of nuclear receptors (23, 24), we sought to determine whether DRIP205 might also interact with the HNF4 DBD and whether that interaction was affected by the addition of spermine.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Whereas the HNF4 DBD bound remarkably well to both the wt DRIP205 (67%) and the DRIP205 containing the mutated NR boxes (54.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	99	 4B, top and middle panels, lane 3), spermine greatly decreased both of those interactions (lane 6).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	100	 In contrast, the isolated DRIP205 NR box did not bind well to the HNF4 DBD either in the absence or presence of spermine (bottom panel, lanes 3 and 6).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Whereas it is possible that the decrease in binding of the full-length DRIP205 to the HNF4 DBD is not related to the increased in binding to the LBD, it is equally possible that the two effects are related.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	102	 For example, spermine could induce a conformational change in DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	103	wt that causes a decrease in the interaction with the HNF4 DBD and an increase in the interaction with the LBD, perhaps as a result of increased access to the NR boxes.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Such a conformational change could also explain why the HNF4 LBD binds the truncated DRIP205 products better than the full-length DRIP205 and why that binding is not affected by spermine to in the truncated products, the NR boxes may already be fully accessible (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	105	If spermine is primarily affecting DRIP205 and not HNF4, then one might expect to see a similar affect on the interaction with other nuclear receptors.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	106	 This is exactly what we found with the VDR LBD: the presence of spermine enhanced the interaction with DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	107	4% binding in the presence of 1,25-(OH)2D3 (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	108	 4C, top panel, compare lane 7 with lane 4).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	109	 It also enhanced binding to the unliganded VDR, although that binding was still considerably less than in the presence of ligand (Fig, 4C, top panel, lane 6 vs.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Once again, the affect of spermine was evident only on the full-length DRIP205, as there was no appreciable effect on the isolated NR boxes (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	111	GRIP1: Decreased Binding in the Presence of Polyamines and Synergy with DRIP205 To determine whether polyamines could increase the interaction between nuclear receptors and any NR box containing protein, we examined the effect of spermine on binding to p160 family member GRIP1.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Much to our surprise, addition of spermine to the pull-down reaction reproducibly decreased the interaction of 35S-labeled GRIP1 with both the HNF4 and the VDR LBD (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	113	 5A, top and bottom panels, compare lane 7 with lane 4).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (28K):    Figure 5.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Spermine as a Switch between the p160 Family and the DRIP Complex: Spermine Decreases Binding of GRIP to NR LBDs and GRIP1 Synergizes with DRIP205 to Activate HNF4-Mediated Transcription.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	116	 3 but with in vitro-translated 35S-labeled GRIP1 and GST.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	117	 HNF4 (DBD or LBD; top panel) and GST.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	118	LBD (bottom panel) in the absence and presence of 1 mM spermine as indicated.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	119	 +D3, Reaction performed in the presence of 4  microM 1,25-(OH)2D3 dissolved in ethanol (lanes 4 and 7).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	120	 An equivalent amount of ethanol was added to the reactions in lanes 3 and 6.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	121	 B, Transient transfection assay into 293T cells as described in Materials and Methods with 2  microg of a Gal4 luciferase reporter construct (pFR-luc, Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) and 0.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	122	1  microg of expression plasmids containing a Gal4.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	123	DBD fusion to the HNF4 LBD (Gal4.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	124	LBD) in the absence or presence of 5  microg pSG5.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Shown is the mean luciferase activity in relative light units (RLU)  plus or minus SD of triplicates from one representative experiment of three.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	126	  Because spermine decreased the interaction with GRIP1 but increased the interaction with DRIP205, this suggested that the two coactivator complexes could act together in a single pathway with spermine acting as a switch between the two complexes.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	127	 If this is the case, then one might expect to see a synergistic effect between the two coactivators.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In contrast, if GRIP1 and DRIP205 act independently in two parallel pathways, then one would expect to see only an additive effect.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Transient cotransfection analysis showed that DRIP205 activated a Gal4 fusion construct containing the HNF4 LBD approximately 2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	130	 5B, compare lane 6 with lane 5) and that GRIP1 activated it 2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	131	6-fold (compare lane 7 with lane 5).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	132	 In contrast, when both GRIP1 and DRIP205 were present, the activation was more than additive (8.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	133	LBD alone; compare lane 8 with lane 5), indicating a synergistic effect of these coactivators and supporting the notion that they act on the same pathway.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	134	In Vivo Evidence of a Role for Polyamines in Activated Transcription To determine whether the effects of spermine seen in vitro also played a role in vivo, the transient transfection assay was performed in the presence of a specific inhibitor of polyamine biosynthesis, -difluoromethylornithine (DFMO), which is known to decrease the levels of intracellular polyamines such as spermidine and spermine by blocking the activity of ornithine decarboxylase (Ref.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	135	 A 24-h treatment with DFMO reduced the intracellular levels of both spermidine and spermine in the 293T cells (to 37% and 77%, respectively; Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	136	 6B), and decreased the HNF41-mediated transcription by nearly 50% (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	137	 6C, top, compare lane 3 with lane 1 and lane 4 with lane 2).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The effect on the HNF41-mediated transcription appeared to be specific in that DFMO slightly increased the level of background transcription from the reporter construct but did not decrease the HNF41 protein levels as evidenced by immunoblot analysis (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	139	 6C, bottom, compare lane 3 with lane 2).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Because the addition of polyamines to a gel shift reaction decreased the ability of HNF41 to bind DNA in vitro (Seidel, S.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Sladek, unpublished data), it is unlikely that the decrease in HNF4-mediated transcription in the DFMO-treated cells is due to a decrease in DNA binding.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Rather, the results suggest that blocking synthesis of polyamines such as spermine specifically decreased the ability of HNF41 to activate transcription.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	143	View larger version (19K):    Figure 6.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Polyamines Modulate Transcriptional Activation in Vivo.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	145	A, Pathway of polyamine biosynthesis in mammalian cells.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	146	 ODC, Ornithine decarboxylase (25 ).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	147	 B, Intracellular polyamine concentrations in duplicate samples of 293T cells in the absence (control 1 and 2, DMEM alone) and presence of 1 mM DFMO in DMEM (DFMO 1 and 2) were measured as described in Materials and Methods.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Results are given in nanomoles of polyamine per milligram of total protein.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Intracellular putrescine levels were less than 0.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The effect of the DFMO was comparable to that observed by others in another cell line (38 ), although the starting levels of spermine were somewhat higher for the 293T cells.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	151	 C, Transient transfection into 293T cells performed as described in Materials and Methods with 2  microg of the reporter construct (ApoB.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	152	HNF41 (HNF4) in the absence or presence of 1 mM DFMO added 24 h before harvesting as indicated and as in B.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Fold Induction, Luciferase activity normalized to ss-gal activity.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The experiment was repeated twice with similar results.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The data are presented as the mean  plus or minus  SD of the triplicate.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Bottom, Immunoblot analysis of the transfected 293T cells to detect the HNF41 protein using the 445 antibody (39 ) and goat antirabbit antisera conjugated to alkaline phosphatase.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	157	View larger version (21K):    Figure 7.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Proposed Model for a Role of Polyamines in Transcriptional Activation.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	159	Polyamines such as spermine may decrease the binding of activators such as HNF4 and VDR to coactivators such as GRIP1 (a p160 family member) but increase the binding to DRIP205 (shaded molecules).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	160	 This would allow for a switch between the p160/p300 complex and the DRIP complex, both of which interact with nuclear receptors via a common docking surface, the AF-2 (black dot).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	161	 As described in the text, one potential source of the polyamines could be the chromatin.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	162	  Polyamines are small, ubiquitous, organic polycations found at relatively high concentrations in the cell, approximately 1 to 2 mM.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	163	 They have been implicated in a wide variety of physiological functions and have been found to bind proteins as well as nucleic acids (reviewed in Refs.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Perhaps one of the most intriguing, if elusive, roles of polyamines is in the regulation of gene expression.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Polyamines are implicated in the formation of higher order chromosomal fibers, facilitating condensation of chromatin fragments and interacting specifically with nucleosome core particles and DNA (31).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Whereas this would suggest that an increase in polyamine levels would globally repress transcription, in fact it results in an increase in expression of many genes (32), suggesting that polyamines regulate gene expression by additional mechanisms.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	167	 One such mechanism could be via affecting the interaction of transcriptional activators, such as HNF4, with coactivators, such as the DRIP complex.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	168	The data presented in this study indicate that p160 family member GRIP1 and DRIP205 can synergistically activate transcription (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	169	 5B), suggesting that they act in a single pathway but raising the question of how the switch is made from one coactivator to the other.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Our data also show that the polyamine spermine can decrease the binding of at least two different nuclear receptors to GRIP1 (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	171	 5A) and can increase the binding to DRIP205 (Figs.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	172	 3 and 4), suggesting that polyamines may play a role in that switch.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Support for that role in vivo is observed when blocking the biosynthesis of polyamines resulted in a decrease in HNF4-mediated transcription (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	174	 If polyamines were acting at the level of chromatin only, and not at the level of coactivators, then one would expect a decrease in polyamine levels to decondense the chromatin and result in an increase, not a decrease, in transcription.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Therefore, the in vivo as well as the in vitro results suggest that polyamines may play a role in transcription activation other than altering the state of the chromatin.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	176	 However, it must be noted that other interpretations of the in vivo data are possible and that additional experiments are required to definitively prove that polyamines modulate the synergy between GRIP1 and DRIP205 in vivo.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	177	The model of polyamines playing a role in the switch between different coactivator complexes is intriguing but provocative, and raises several important questions.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	178	 One is how do polyamines affect binding of coactivators to activators? Whereas the mechanism is not known, our results suggest that it is not due to a simple enhancement of the interaction between the AF-2 of the nuclear receptors and the NR boxes of DRIP205 (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Rather, because truncated DRIP205 products bound the HNF4 LBD equally well in the presence and absence of spermine (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	180	 3), we favor a model in which polyamines induce a conformational change in DRIP205 that exposes otherwise buried NR boxes.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	181	 There is at least one example already of a conformational change in a coactivator that is important for its function (33).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Another important question is where do the polyamines come from? Most of the polyamines in the cell are not free but are bound to negatively charged molecules such as chromatin (28, 29, 30).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Because others have shown that the hyperacetylation of histones inhibits the ability of polyamines to condense the chromatin (31), it is possible that acetylation of histones by coactivators such as p300 or p300/CBP-associated factor may also cause a release of polyamines from the chromatin.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	184	 If this were the case, then upon activator binding DNA and recruiting a HAT-containing coactivator complex, there would be an increase in the local polyamine concentration that could then mediate the switch from the HAT-containing complex to the DRIP complex.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Some evidence already exists that polyamine levels can affect histone acetylation by influencing the action of histone acetyltransferases and deacetylases (32).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Finally, an attractive feature of the model is that it could apply not only to nuclear receptors but to any transcriptional activator that recruits both HAT-containing coactivators and the DRIP/TRAP/ARC/mediator complex, of which there are several examples (4, 7).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	187	Plasmids and Transient Transfection Assays The following constructs have been previously described: pMT7 expression vectors containing full-length rat HNF41 (pMT7.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	188	HNF41) and amino acids (aa) 1 to 374 (HNF4.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	189	1 vector containing aa 1 to 360 of HNF41 (HNF4.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	190	N1C360) (12); HNF4 GST fusion constructs containing aa 127 to 374 (GST.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	191	DBD); the reporter construct ApoB.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	192	Luc; a Gal4 DBD fusion construct containing the HNF4 LBD (Gal4.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	193	LBD) (34); the GST fusion construct containing aa 110 to 427 of the human VDR (GST.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	194	1 expression vectors containing the full-length wt human DRIP205 cDNA (DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	195	wt), a small region spanning the two NR boxes of DRIP205 (aa 527 to 714) (DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	196	box), and a full-length DRIP205 with two mutated NR boxes (LXXLL to LXXAA; DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	197	GRIP1 containing full-length mouse GRIP1 kindly provided by M.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Stallcup (University of Southern California) (Ref.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Human embryonic kidney 293T and Saos-2 cells were maintained and transfected with Lipofectin (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	200	, Gaithersburg, MD) as previously described (34).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	201	 DNA mixtures typically contained 2  microg luciferase reporter; 0.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	202	0  microg of the DRIP expression vectors, pSG5.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	203	GRIP1, or appropriate empty vector; and 2  microg RSV.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	204	GST Pull-Down Assay In vitro protein-protein interaction assays were performed using GST fusion proteins as previously described (34).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	205	 In general, 20  microl of beads containing 10 to 20  microg protein were incubated at 4 C with 2 to 5  microl in vitro-translated [35S] methionine-labeled protein in rabbit reticulocyte lysate (TNT, Promega Corp.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	206	, Madison, WI) for 1 h with gentle agitation before extensive washing and elution with SDS buffer and analysis by 10% SDS-PAGE followed by autoradiography and phosphor imaging.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	207	DBD beads were prewashed in buffer containing 1 M NaCl to remove contaminating DNA.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Pull-downs with Namalwa B cell nuclear extracts were performed as previously described (17).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	209	 For pull-downs with ligand or polyamines, 1,25-(OH)2D3 or spermine was added to 1 to 4  microM or 1 mM, respectively, to the GST beads at the same time as the lysate or extract.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The concentration of Tris-HCl was increased from 20 mM to 50 mM for experiments with polyamines to maintain the pH at 8.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	211	Measurement of Intracellular Polyamine Levels Intracellular polyamine levels were measured by ion-exchange chromatography followed by reverse-phase HPLC as previously described (36).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Briefly, 3 x 106 293T cells plated in a 100-mm plate 1 d in advance were treated with 1 mM DFMO in DMEM when the cells were approximately70% confluent.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Twenty-four hours later, the cells were washed extensively with PBS and lysed in 400  microl 0.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	214	2 N perchloric acid followed by sonication.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The extracted material was then subjected to chromatography.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	216	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank E.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Martinez for critical reading of the manuscript and S.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	218	   FOOTNOTES   This work was supported by NIH Grants CA-79909 (to C.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	219	 from the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science and University of California Toxic Substances Research and Teaching Program.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	220	1 Current address: Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale Unite 459, Faculte de Medicine H.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Warembourg, 1 Place de Verdun, 59045 Lille cedex, France.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	222	Abbreviations: aa, Amino acids; AF-2, activation function 2; ARC, activator recruited cofactor; CBP, cAMP response element binding protein-binding protein; DBD, DNA binding domain; DFMO, -difluoromethylornithine; 1,25-(OH)2D3, 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D3; DRIP, VDR-interacting protein; GRIP1, glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein 1; GST, glutathione S-transferase; HAT, histone acetyl transferase; HNF4, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4; LBD, ligand binding domain; NR, nuclear receptor; PCAF, p300/CBP associated factor; SRC1, steroid receptor coactivator; TRAP, thyroid hormone receptor associated protein; VDR, vitamin D receptor; wt, wild-type.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	223	Received for publication October 5, 2001.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Accepted for publication March 14, 2002.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	0	The activation function 2 domain of hepatic nuclear factor 4 is regulated by a short C-terminal proline-rich repressor domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	1	Chemical Pathology Unit, Sir William Dunn School of Pathology, University of Oxford, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3RE, UK.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received January 26, 1998; Revised and Accepted March 19, 1998.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	3	Hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) is a transcription factor whose expression is crucial for mouse embryonic development, for liver-specific gene expression and for the prevention of one form of maturity-onset diabetes of the young.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Its domain structure has been defined previously and is similar to other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	5	 A repressor domain has now been localised to a region of 14 amino acids (residues 428-441) near the C-terminus of HNF4 and is sufficient by itself to repress the activity of the activation function 2 (AF2) domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Multiple mutations within this repressor domain enhance activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Interestingly, this repressor domain shares homology with a repressor domain in the progesterone receptor.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In a detailed mutagenesis study of the AF2 core, we demonstrate that L 366, which is conserved in the AF2 core between HNF4 and a number of orphan nuclear receptors, is essential for the full activity of the AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Furthermore, a double mutation of E 363 and L 366 suggests that these residues might act in a cooperative manner.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	10	Hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) was first isolated as a protein involved in regulating a number of liver-specific genes (1).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	11	 It shares amino acid sequence homology with the nuclear receptor superfamily.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Since no ligand has yet been found for HNF4, it is classified as an orphan nuclear receptor.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	13	Extensive work carried out on nuclear receptors (e.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	14	 oestrogen and retinoic acid receptors) has shown that they have a modular structure, with distinct regions carrying out specific functions (2).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The N-terminal region (A/B) contains an activation function 1 (AF1) whose activity can be cell-type as well as promoter-context specific (3).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	16	 A highly conserved zinc finger domain, required for DNA binding, is present in region C, with region D acting as a hinge (2).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The C-terminal half of these receptors contains a long hydrophobic domain (region E), which encodes various functions.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	18	 These include receptor dimerisation, ligand binding and a ligand-dependent activation function 2 (AF2) (2).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The AF2 domain contains a core region of seven amino acids [Phi][Phi][KHgr]a[Phi][Phi]a/L (where `[Phi]' is a hydrophobic residue, `[KHgr]' any residue, `a' an acidic residue and L = leucine) which is critical for activation and is conserved in many nuclear receptors (4).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The extreme C-terminal region of these receptors (region F) varies in length between receptors and its function is unknown.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In HNF4, this region is extended and contains a proline-rich domain (1).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	22	HNF4 is expressed in many tissues including liver, kidney, pancreas and intestine (1,5,10).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	23	 There are a number of isoforms generated by alternative splicing (5).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	24	 For example, the HNF4[alpha] gene in humans encodes three isoforms, [alpha]1, [alpha] 2 and [alpha]4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	25	 There is, in addition, a distinct [gamma] subtype encoded by the HNF4[gamma] gene (5).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The rat HNF4 isoforms 1-455 and 1-465 are equivalent to human [alpha]1 and [alpha]2 respectively (1,6).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In Xenopus laevis, HNF4 is encoded by two distinct ([alpha] and [beta]) genes (7).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	28	Deletion of HNF4 is embryonic lethal in mice, since it resulted in the induction of cell death in embryonic ectoderm and impairment of gastrulation of mouse embryos carrying a homozygous (-/-) knockout of the HNF4[alpha] gene (8).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In the regulation of the factor IX gene, point mutations which disrupt an HNF4 binding site result in haemophilia B (9,10).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Recently, heterozygotes carrying mutations in the HNF4[alpha] allele were linked to one form of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY1) (11).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	31	 HNF4 is also involved in the regulation of a number of genes required for both carbohydrate and lipid metabolism as well as erythropoiesis (1,12).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	32	 These genes include apolipoprotein CIII, pyruvate kinase, [alpha]1-antitrypsin and erythropoietin.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	33	Previous work aimed at investigating the C-terminal activation domain of HNF4 in transcription showed that large deletions in the C-terminal region abolished transactivation (12,13).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	34	 HNF4 was also shown to interact with the basal transcription factor TFIIB (13).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Recent evidence has suggested that E363 and L366 of the AF2 core are important for the activity of the AF2 domain (14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	36	 However, this study was limited to single mutations at either position in the context of GAL4-HNF4 deletion fusion constructs (amino acids 128-370) which lacked other essential domains (the N-terminal AF1 domain, the DNA binding domain, and the repressor domain in the extended C-terminal region which is characterised in this report).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	37	In this report, we demonstrate by extensive mutagenesis in the context of both full-length HNF4 and full-length HNF4 fused to the GAL4 DNA binding domain that Leu 366 of the AF2 core is essential for full AF2 activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	38	 By investigating the effect of a double mutation involving both E363 and L366, we show that these residues may act cooperatively.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In addition, we have precisely mapped the location of a repressor domain (initially described in ref.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	40	 14 and postulated to lie between residues 371 and 455) to amino acids 428-441 and have defined amino acid residues within this domain which are required for its activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	41	MATERIALS AND METHODS Reporter plasmids and GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	42	Reporter plasmids pCAT4 and pAPF1-HIV-CAT (1,15) were used to determine the transactivation activities of GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs and native HNF4 constructs, respectively.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	43	 pCAT4 is a reporter plasmid with four GAL4 response elements, an inverted CCAAT box, and a TATA element controlling the CAT reporter gene in the pBluescript backbone; pAPF1-HIV-CAT contains two HNF4 response elements in a direct repeat, and the -57 to +80 of the HIV LTR controlling the CAT reporter gene.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	44	 To monitor transfection efficiency, the internal control plasmid pGLtkLUC (16) was used.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The plasmid pGAL4 1-147 (17) contains the DNA-binding domain (DBD) of the yeast GAL4 protein driven by the immediate-early human cytomegalovirus (CMV) promoter.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The GAL4-HNF4 full-length fusion constructs, and all C-terminal deletion constructs of HNF4 were constructed by PCR amplification of the appropriate fragment of HNF4 derived from the plasmid, pCB6HNF4 (16), using Pfu polymerase (Stratagene).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	47	 After purification of the PCR products, a BamHI/KpnI restriction digest was carried out, followed by an in-frame ligation with the GAL4-DBD using the BamHI/KpnI restriction sites in pGAL4 1-147.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	48	All GAL4-HNF4 full-length fusion proteins carrying a point mutation at E 363 or L 366, and the repressor domain mutants, were constructed by PCR-based mutagenesis using Pfu polymerase (Pritlove, unpublished data).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Native (as opposed to GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs) full-length HNF4 constructs with point mutations at E 363 or L 366 were constructed by removing the GAL4-DBD (GAL4 1-147) from the appropriate GAL4-HNF4 fusion construct by a HindIII/BamHI restriction digest.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The fusion construct GAL4-HNF4 1-372+428-441 was made by first amplifying the pGAL4-HNF4 1-372 fragment, followed by a ligation step to insert a double-stranded oligonucleotide of the repressor domain of HNF4 (residues 428-441).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The sequence of all constructs were verified by fluorescent dideoxy sequencing.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	52	Cell culture, transient transfections, enzymatic and gel mobility shift assays.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	53	HeLa and HepG2 cells were cultured using 60 mm dishes in minimal essential medium (MEM) supplemented with 10% foetal calf serum.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Transient transfections were carried out using the standard calcium-phosphate precipitation method (10).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Briefly, a total of 15  microg of DNA was transfected, consisting of 10  microg of the reporter plasmid, 2  microg of the expression plasmid, 2  microg of the internal control plasmid and 1  microg of salmon sperm DNA (Sigma).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Sixteen hours after transfection, the cells were washed twice with PBS and fresh medium added.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Cells were harvested 48 h post-transfection.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Luciferase assays were carried out according to the manufacturer using a luciferase assay kit (Promega) and quantitated using a Wallac LKB 1250 luminometer.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Chloramphenicol acetyl transferase assays were performed by standard methods (10) to determine the reporter activity of each construct.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	60	TLC plates were quantitated using a Storm phosphorimager and analysed using the Image Quant software.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Gel mobility shift assays were performed essentially as described (17) using a DNA probe containing a single GAL4 binding site, and the same HeLa cell extracts that were used to determine the relative transactivation activities of the constructs in Figure 2.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	62	P values were calculated using student's t-test when comparing the mean and standard deviation of mutants.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	63	 When comparing mutants with the full-length fusion protein or native wild-type full-length HNF4 protein, P values were calculated from z values.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	64	RESULTS Mapping the C-terminal activation function 2 (AF2) of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	65	Analysis of the amino acid sequence of rat HNF4 identified a consensus amino acid sequence ([Phi][Phi][KHgr]a[Phi][Phi]a/L, amino acid residues 360-366) found in a number of orphan and ligand nuclear receptors (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	66	 This conserved sequence, known as the activation function 2 (AF2) core, is known to form an amphipathic [alpha]-helix required for ligand-dependent activation of nuclear receptors, e.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	67	 1) revealed that the Leu at position 366 (the last residue in the AF2 core) in HNF4 is conserved in a number of orphan receptors (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	68	 1, underlined L), whereas an acidic residue (an E or D) is found at the corresponding position in a number of nuclear receptors with known ligands.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In addition, the extreme C-terminal region of HNF4, specifically amino acids 400-447, is rich in proline residues and was previously proposed to contain a proline-rich activation domain (1).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Alignment of the amino acid sequence around the activation function 2 (AF2) core of HNF4 from different species with a number of orphan nuclear receptors (above) and receptors with known ligands (below).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	71	 `[Phi]' represents a hydrophobic residue, `[KHgr]' any amino acid residue and `a' an acidic residue.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The invariant glutamic acid (E) conserved between all nuclear receptors with known ligands and HNF4 is highlighted in bold.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The leucine (L) conserved between HNF4 and a number of orphan nuclear receptors is underlined.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	74	laevis; d, Drosophila; h, human; m, mouse.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The definitions of the symbols, ARP1, EAR, COUP-TF1, Svp, TR, VDR, RAR, RXR and their accession numbers can be found in ref.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Mapping the C-terminal activation function 2 (AF2) of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	77	 (A) Schematic representation of the GAL4 DBD, the full-length HNF4 fusion and HNF4 C-terminal deletion fusions from 366 to 455 at 15 amino acids intervals.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	78	 (B) Transactivation in HeLa (dotted histogram) and HepG2 (blank histogram) cells, relative to the full-length HNF4 fusion (which is set at 100% in all experiments).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The mean of three independent transfection experiments is shown,  plus or minus  standard deviation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In the context of GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs, `F' is used to represent GAL4 1-147.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	81	 pCAT4 (see Materials and Methods) is a transfection control.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	82	In order to determine if the proline-rich region contained an activation domain, and establish the role of the conserved amino acid sequence between 360 and 366, GAL4-HNF4 fusion proteins were constructed with successive 15 amino acid deletions from the C-terminus of HNF4 up to residue 366 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Unexpectedly, deletions up to residue 381 produced fusion proteins with higher activities than the full-length fusion protein in both HeLa and HepG2 cells (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	84	 For example, the activity of deletion F 1-410 was three and half times that of the full-length fusion protein in HeLa cells.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	85	 However, when amino acids 366-380 were deleted (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	86	 2B, F 1-365) the activity decreased to 12% of full-length fusion protein.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	87	 These results suggested there was a repressor domain spanning residues 380-455.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	88	 However, there was no evidence of a proline-rich activation domain between residues 400 and 447 as previously suggested (1).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The fact that transactivation was reduced to near background level when residues 366-380 were deleted suggested that Leu 366, conserved in a number of orphan receptors and the last residue in the consensus sequence [Phi][Phi][KHgr]a[Phi][Phi]a/L (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	90	 To exclude the possibility that the increased activities of the C-terminal deletion fusions was due to higher levels of protein expression in some constructs than others, a gel mobility shift assay was carried out as described in Materials and Methods.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	91	 As shown in Figure 3, gel shifted fusion complexes of all constructs were present in comparable amounts, with insufficient variation in yield to account for the difference in activity observed in Figure 2.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Thus, no further gel shift analysis of protein levels was carried out on further constructs in this report.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	93	 A gel mobility shift assay using HeLa cell extracts to determine the protein expression levels of the full-length and C-terminal deletion fusion constructs shown (except F 1-425) in Figure 2.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Lane 1, HeLa cell extract from cells transfected with the reporter (pCAT4) and internal control (pGLtkLUC) plasmids; lane 2, GAL 1-147; lane 3, F 1-455; lane 4, F 1-365; lane 5, F 1-380; lane 6, F 1-395; lane 7, F 1-410; lane 8, F 1-440.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The position of the gel shifted `fusion complexes' is shown, free probe and the position of a presumptive degradation products comigrating with the GAL4 1-147 (the DNA binding domain of GAL4) are indicated by arrows.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	96	To identify the critical residue(s) in the region between residues 359 and 380, fusion proteins with deletions at three amino acid intervals between residues 359 and 380 were constructed and tested in the transient transfection assay in HeLa cells (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Deleting amino acids 369-380 had no effect on the activity of the C-terminal activation domain (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	98	 4B, compare F 1-380 and F 1-368).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Deleting the next three amino acids, 366-368, resulted in a significant decrease in activity to background level (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Two further deletions, F 1-362 and F 1-359, also had background activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	101	 We conclude that the region between amino acids 365 and 368 is critical for transactivation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Leu (L) 366 is the last amino acid residue in the proposed amphipathic [alpha]-helix formed by the AF2 core (Fig, 1; 18) and thus may be an important residue.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Determining the critical amino acid residues in the AF2 core of HNF4 in HeLa cells.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	104	 (A) Schematic representation of the GAL4 DBD, the full-length HNF4 fusion and C-terminal deletion fusions from 359 to 380 at three amino acid intervals.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Intermediate constructs between 368 and 380 are not shown since the activities of these constructs were not significantly different to fusion F 1-368 (results not shown).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	106	 (B) Transactivation relative to the full-length HNF4 fusion set at 100% (see legend to Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	107	To investigate the significance of L366 in more detail, point mutations of L 366 to A, D, Q and I were made both in the context of GAL4-DBD full-length HNF4 fusion proteins (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	108	 5A) and in the context of native full-length HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	109	 All mutations at L366 resulted in decreased activity compared to wild type GAL4-DBD-HNF4 fusion protein or native HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	110	 In the context of native HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	111	 5D), the activity of mutant L 366 I (which of all the mutants differed least in activity from the wild-type), was still statistically significantly different (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	112	01) from wild-type in a z value test (Materials and Methods).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	113	 When the activities of mutants 366 A and Q were compared to that of mutant 366 I, they were also found to be statistically significantly different(P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	114	 However, the transactivation activities of mutants 366 D and I were not statistically significantly different (P > 0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Comparing the activities of the same set of point mutants at L 366 in the context of the GAL4-HNF4 fusion (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	116	 5B) shows that mutants 366 Q and D were statistically significantly different from I (P  <  0.
