0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	117	01 in both cases), although no significant difference was seen between 366 I and A (P > 0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	118	05) or between mutants 366 A, D and Q.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	119	 These results show that L 366 is critical for full transactivation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The roles of L366 and E363 in the activity of the C-terminal AF2 domain of HNF4 in HeLa cells.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	121	 (A) Schematic representation of the GAL4 DBD, the wild-type GAL4-HNF4 full-length fusion construct with arrows showing the point mutations of L366->A, D, Q or I.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	122	 F E363->A shows the GAL4-HNF4 full-length construct with the bolded 363E->A mutation of the AF2 core.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	123	 F E363A/L366A shows the double mutant (B) Relative transactivation (see legend to Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (C) Schematic representation of the native full-length HNF4 and mutants studied as in (A) above.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	125	 (D) Transactivation relative to wild-type native full-length HNF4 set at 100%.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	126	 APF1-HIV-CAT is a transfection control (see Materials and Methods).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	127	Position 4 (E 363 in HNF4) of the consensus AF2 core is an acidic residue in both orphan and nuclear receptors with known ligands (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	128	 From the crystal structure of the ligand binding domain of RAR[gamma] bound to all-trans retinoic acid, this position is critical for the formation of a salt bridge between helix 4 and 12 (18), essential for AF2 activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Thus, we investigated the point mutant 363 E->A in HNF4 in the context of both a GAL4-HNF4 fusion protein (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Transactivation was statistically significantly lower than that of the wild-type fusion protein in both cases (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	131	 These results indicate that the E at 363 is also important for full transactivation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	132	We next determined the effect of a double mutation of E363A/L366A in the context of a GAL4 full-length HNF4 fusion (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Unexpectedly, the activity of the double mutant was comparable to that of the single mutants at either position (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	134	 5B, F E363A/L366A compared to F L366A or F E363A), suggesting that E363 and L366 may act cooperatively in regulating the activity of the AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The AF2 activity of HNF4 is regulated by a repressor domain near the C-terminus.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	136	A repressor domain near the C-terminus of the progesterone receptor (PR) was recently shown to inhibit the activity of PR in the absence of progesterone (19).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Alignment of the PR repressor domain sequence (residues 917-928) with the entire HNF4 protein sequence identified a potential 12 amino acid long sequence homology (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	138	 6A, boxed region) near the C-terminus of HNF4 (residues 430-441).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	139	 This potential repressor region showed 40% identity to the sequence of the repressor domain of PR, which is also near its C-terminus.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	140	 This homology and our previous results defining a repressor domain between residues 380 and 455 (see above), prompted us to investigate the effect of fusing a short region of HNF4 containing residues 430-441 downstream of a high activity C-terminal deletion mutant.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Thus, when a 14-long peptide (residues 428-441) of HNF4 was fused in-frame downstream of GAL4-HNF4 1-372 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	142	 6B), its activity was reduced from 300 to 22% of the full-length fusion protein [Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	143	 6C, compare F 1-372+428-441 to F 1-455 (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This suggested the peptide 428-441 may function as a repressor domain in isolation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	145	 A study of the C-terminal repressor of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	146	 (A) Homology (boxed) between the C-terminal repressor domain of PR and a potential repressor domain in the extended C-terminal region of HNF4 (see text).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	147	 * indicates the C-terminus of PR.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Amino acids are numbered in HNF4 above and PR below.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	149	 (B) Schematic representation of the GAL DBD, the full-length fusion (F 1-455), the 1-371 C-terminal deletion fusion and a 1-372 C-terminal deletion fusion containing an in-frame fusion with the proposed repressor domain (428-441) of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	150	 (C) Transactivation in HeLa cells relative to the full-length fusion set at 100% (see legend to Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	151	The role of this repressor domain was further investigated by mutagenesis in the context of the full-length HNF4 fusion protein.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Two constructs with multiple point mutations (a run of five or six alanine residues) in the proposed repressor domain (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The activity of the N-terminal mutant [YKLLPG->AAAAAA, (427-432)] increased 2.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	154	3 times when compared to the wild-type full-length fusion (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The C-terminal mutation [ITTIV->AAAAA, (434-438)] showed an increase in activity which was 3.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	156	5 times that of the wild-type full-length fusion protein (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Both mutants are significantly different from wild-type (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	158	 These results confirm the presence of a repressor domain between amino acids 428 and 441.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Mutation of amino acids in the repressor domain of HNF4 enhances activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	160	 (A) Schematic representation of the GAL 4 DBD, the full-length HNF4 fusion (F 1-455) and two full-length HNF4 fusions with multiple mutations to alanine (as shown) in the repressor domain of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	161	 (B) Transactivation in HeLa cells relative to the wild-type full-length HNF4 fusion.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	162	 (For further details see legend to Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	163	In this report we have studied the C-terminal activation region of HNF4, concentrating our attention on two short regions.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	164	 These are firstly, the well-known AF2 core, which is conserved in nuclear receptors (4) and secondly, a novel short repressor domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	165	 These regions were studied either by deletion analysis or by site-directed mutagenesis of HNF4 fused to the GAL4 DNA binding domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Cotransfection of such fusion constructs with a chloramphenicol acetyl transferase reporter plasmid containing upstream GAL4 binding sites into either HeLa or HepG2 cells transiently, was used to study the activities of the deleted or mutated constructs (Materials and Methods).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	167	Previous studies of the C-terminal activation domain of HNF4 suggested that the AF2 core (residues 360-366) was important for activity (12-14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Furthermore, a mutation of L366->E, in an HNF4 deletion fusion construct (amino acids 128-370) suggested that residue 366 was important for the activity of the AF2 domain (14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	169	 However, this result is preliminary because it was studied on a HNF4 deletion construct which lacked three essential domains, the N-terminal AF1 domain, the DNA binding domain and the C-terminal repressor domain (see below).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	170	 It is arguable that the results might not be typical of intact HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Another potential criticism of a previous study (14) is that the conclusions as to the importance of particular amino acid residues of the AF2 core particular were based on studies of a single point mutant at each position, 363 and 366, which might not be representative had other mutants been studied.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Here we set out to study multiple mutations at position 366 of the AF2 core and to study a double mutant involving both positions 363 and 366 to gain further insight into the role of the AF2 core.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	173	The results of successive C-terminal deletions (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	174	 2) and fine deletion mapping (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	175	 4) initially suggested that L366 might be important for the activity of the C-terminal AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Therefore, four different point mutations (L->A, D, Q or I) were constructed to definitively assess the role of L 366 in both full-length HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	177	 5C and D) and GAL4 full-length HNF4 fusion constructs (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	178	 All mutations decreased the transactivation activity, indicating that Leu 366 is required for full activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	179	 However, in contrast to a previous report where the activity of a mutant at 366 was reduced to [sim]5% of wild-type, we detected activities varying from [sim]35 to 75% of wild-type.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	180	 This suggested, surprisingly, that transactivation activity is not absolutely dependent on Leu 366, even although it is conserved in a number of orphan receptors (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	181	 A, D, Q and I were clearly functional at least in our transient transactivation assay.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	182	 This result is not an artefact of the fusion of intact HNF4 to the GAL4 DNA binding domain, since essentially similar quantitative results were obtained irrespective of whether full-length HNF4, or full-length HNF4 fused to GAL4 DNA binding domain, were studied (compare Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	183	 However, the fact that a conservative amino acid substitution 366 (L->I) showed the highest activity in our assay ([sim]60-70%), whereas non-conservative amino acid substitutions 366 (L->A, D, Q) showed lower activities (35-60%) still argues for the functional importance of Leu at 366 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	184	E363 is also highly conserved between HNF4 and all nuclear receptors with known ligands, although it is substituted by a D in some orphan receptors (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	185	 E363 was selected for mutation because it is known to be involved in the formation of a salt-bridge and is critical for transactivation in RAR[gamma] (18).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Mutation of E363->A in HNF4 here (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	187	 5) indicated that this residue, like residue 366, was required for full activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Our result at this position differed from a previous report (where activity was reduced to  < 5% of wild-type; 14) in that significant residual activity was observed (between 50 and 70% of wild-type; Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	189	 5C and D) depending on whether with the full-length HNF4 construct or the GAL4 full-length HNF4 fusion construct was used in the transactivation assay.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	190	 We attribute this difference to the fact that full-length HNF4 was used in our studies, whereas HNF4 deletion constructs were used in the previous report (14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	191	It is significant that a double mutant of 363 and 366 also retained [sim]50% activity in our assay (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The fact that the double mutant failed to demonstrate an additive effect over and above that of the two point mutants assayed separately is consistent with E363 and L366 cooperating to regulate the activity of the AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	193	 These experiments illustrates both the importance of E363 and L366 of the AF2 core, yet also demonstrate the core is partly redundant at least in our transactivation assay.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	194	 It remains possible that the redundancy observed in the mutations studied here results from a compensatory effect of the AF1 domain, which is known to transactivate (14) and is present in our full-length HNF4 constructs.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	195	Our initial C-terminal deletion experiments suggested the presence of a repressor activity within residues 380-455 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	196	 2B, and previously proposed to lie between residues 371 and 455; 14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	197	 By aligning the amino acid sequence of the PR repressor domain (19) with the entire HNF4 sequence, a short region (residues 430-441) showing 40% identity to a previously characterised repressor domain in PR was localised in HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	198	 This presumptive repressor domain was first shown to confer repressor activity by itself (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Thus, when a short peptide from amino acid 428 to 441 containing the HNF4 repressor domain was fused in-frame downstream of a high activity C-terminal deletion fusion construct, transactivation was severely inhibited, decreasing from >300 to 22%.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	200	 This is unlikely to be the result of decreased protein expression of this particular fusion construct, since a gel shift analysis of a panel of deletion constructs all showed reasonably similar levels of protein expression (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	201	 3) This implied that the peptide containing amino acids 428-441 was sufficient, by itself, to act as a repressor.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Further evidence for this repressor domain came from a study of two constructs with multiple point mutations (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	203	It is interesting to note that in the experiment where the isolated repressor domain was fused to F 1-372 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	204	 6B), the AF2 core was intact; hence an activity closer to the that of the full-length fusion (100%) might have been expected, whereas an activity of 22% was observed (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	205	 This suggests the repressor domain had a more potent inhibitory effect when fused closer to the AF2 core, than if it were in its normal location.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Perhaps the close proximity of the repressor domain to the AF2 core may restrict the accessibility of potential coactivator proteins to the AF2 core, either by binding a corepressor protein or simply by masking critical residues in the AF2 core.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In the case of the PR repressor domain, the repressor domain was shown to mediate its function through an unknown corepressor (19).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Experiments in an attempt to determine if the HNF4 repressor domain functioned through a corepressor were unfortunately inconclusive (data not shown).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	209	It is obviously interesting to know how the repressor domain in HNF4 functions and if it is required to regulate the activity of HNF4 in vivo.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	210	 An attractive, but speculative mechanism might involve the phosphorylation of threonine residues in the sequence ITTI (residues 434-437).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	211	 A corepressor might bind to the repressor domain in the phosphorylated state and dissociate in the dephosphorylated state.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Thus mutations which disrupt these threonine residues would prevent phosphorylation, thus preventing repression and thereby enhancing the activity of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	213	In summary, our characterisation of the AF2 domain in the C-terminal region of HNF4 has given new insights into the function of residues 363 and 366.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	214	 By extensive mutagenesis we have shown that L366 is essential for full AF2 activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	215	 An E363A/L366A double mutant suggested that E363 and L366 may act cooperatively to regulate the activity of the AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	216	 We have also shown that the activity of the AF2 domain is regulated by a repressor domain located within a proline-rich region.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	217	 We have localised this repressor domain to within amino acid residues 428-441 of HNF4, and showed it was necessary and sufficient for repressor activity in transient transfection studies in HeLa cells.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Furthermore, multiple point mutations within this repressor domain in the context of the full-length HNF4 fusion construct abolished repressor activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The repressor domain shares homology with a recently reported C-terminal repressor domain in the progesterone receptor (19).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	220	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Tel: +44 1865 275559; Fax: +44 1865 275556; Email: george.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	222	uk This page is run by Oxford University Press, Great Clarendon Street, Oxford OX2 6DP, as part of the OUP Journals Comments and feedback: www-admin{at}oup.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	223	uk' + u + '@' + d + ''//--> Last modification: 17 Apr 1998 Copyright Oxford University Press, 1998.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	0	The COUP-TF nuclear receptors regulate cell migration in the mammalian basal forebrain Marco Tripodi*, Alessandro Filosa*, Maria Armentano and Michele Studer.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	1	TIGEM (Telethon Institute of Genetics and Medicine), Via P.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Castellino 111, 80131 Napoli, Italy.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	3	Author for correspondence (e-mail: studer{at}tigem.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	4	Key words: COUP-TFs, Cell migration, Forebrain, Mouse.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	5	As suggested by various studies, directional migration can be achieved by short-range guidance cues and by long-range diffusible gradients (Tessier-Lavigne and Goodman, 1996).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Contact guidance relies on a permissive environment, on which gradients of diffusible guidance molecules can be superimposed, to achieve directional migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, the distribution and molecular nature of short- and long-range molecules, and the substratum that interneurons use in their migration towards the cortex, are poorly understood.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Motogenic factors, such as hepatocyte growth factor and the neurotrophin molecules BDNF and NT4, have been shown to influence the numbers of cells migrating away from the subpallium (Polleux et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Guidance molecules with repulsive and attractive activities are likely to be involved in guiding migrating cells from the subpallium to the pallium, and within the subpallium (Marin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	10	 For the substratum, one report has shown that blocking the function of the TAG1 adhesion molecule results in a marked reduction in GABAergic neurons in the cortex (Denaxa et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	11	 However, in Tag1 mutant mice, there is no major alteration in the tangential migration of interneurons (Marin and Rubenstein, 2003), and treatment of cortical slices with phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C (PI-PLC), an enzyme that cleaves GPI-anchored proteins, such as TAG1, does not alter interneuron migration (Tanaka et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Therefore, nothing is known about the nature of short-range guidance contact cues involved in tangential migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	13	The nuclear orphan receptor COUP-TFI favours migration of neurons through an integrin-dependent mechanism in cell cultures (Adam et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Overexpression of COUP-TFI in retinoic-acid-treated neuronal aggregates coated with different cell substrata, such as polylysine, laminin or fibronectin, results in a higher rate of migration compared with controls, whereas overexpression of a mutated form of COUP-TFI has no effects on cell migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Moreover, increased levels of vitronectin, an extracellular matrix (ECM) molecule involved in neurite extension, motor neuron differentiation and possibly neuronal migration, are detected both in aggregate and monolayer cell cultures after overexpression of COUP-TFI.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	16	 This, and the data that show that COUP-TFI stimulates transcription from the vitronectin promoter in vitro, strongly suggests a role of COUP-TFI in the regulation of ECM synthesis during the process of neuronal migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Although COUP-TFI has been shown to be involved in cortical regionalization and axon pathfinding in the developing telencephalon (Zhou et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	18	, 2001), its role in promoting cell migration in vivo has not been established so far.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	19	Here, we show that COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII are expressed in migrating cells in specific pathways in the basal telencephalon of mouse embryos at a stage when interneuron migration is robust.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Moreover, expression of COUP-TFI in the cortex co-localizes with the GABAergic marker calbindin, suggesting that a subpopulation of COUP-TFI-positive cells in the cortex are GABAergic interneurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	21	 With the help of transplantation and tracing techniques in organotypic slice cultures, we first show the presence of a dorsal-to-ventral migratory pathway that originates in the region of the interganglionic sulcus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	22	 We then demonstrate that COUP-TFI is expressed in the basal telencephalon in neurons not only migrating dorsally towards the cortex, but also ventrally towards the pre-optic area (POa) and the hypothalamus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Finally, by ectopic expression of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII in the GEs, we show an increased rate of migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	24	 While COUP-TFI appears to control dorsal and ventral migration in the basal telencephalon, COUP-TFII is more specific in modulating tangential migration into the intermediate zone of the cortex, suggesting distinct functions of COUP-TFs in regulating cell migration in the developing forebrain.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	25	Slice culture experiments Organotypic slice cultures of embryonic mouse telencephalon were prepared as previously described (Anderson et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Brain slices 250  microm thick were used for the grafting experiments (see below), for tracing with the fluorescent carbocyanide dye 1,1'-dioctadecyl 3,3,3',3'-tetramethylindocarbocyanine perchlorate (DiI; Molecular Probes), and for electroporation and lipofectamine injections (see below).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	27	Grafting experiments For the grafting experiments, the MGE, the LGE, or the region at the MGE/LGE border (MLGE) were removed from the donor brain slices derived from a green fluorescent protein (GFP)-expressing transgenic embryo (Hadjantonakis et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	28	, 1998) and transferred to the same position in a host wild-type brain slice.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The chimaeric slices were examined 1 hour after the transplant under a stereoscope with a GFP filter, to confirm that the transplants were successfully and correctly integrated into the host; slices where the grafts did not integrate, or integrated in an incorrect location, were not used for this study.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The medium was changed every day, and after about 60 hours the slices were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	31	Electroporation and lipofectamine-mediated injection For the fate map, a GFP-expressing vector was electroporated into the GEs of embryonic day (E) 13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	32	5 brain slices using the same method and conditions as described previously (Stuhmer et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	33	 For the gain-of-function approach, we used the PolyFect Transfection Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany), containing 250 ng/ microl of the expression vectors (CMV-GFP or CMV-COUP-TFs-IRES-GFP).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Full-length mouse COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII (kindly donated by M.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Tsai, Baylor College, USA) were cloned into the BamHI-XhoI sites of the pIRES-hrGFP-2a expression vector (Stratagene, California, USA).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	36	 We injected the constructs into the desired region of the brain slices, under microscopic guidance with a micro-syringe (Hamilton, Reno, Nevada, USA) held by a micromanipulator system using a 33-gauge blunt-ended needle (Hamilton).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The slices were then cultured for 60 hours, fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, and either observed by confocal microscopy (Leica DMIRE2) or embedded in OCT for further sectioning in a cryostat.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	38	Immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence The brains were sectioned and treated for immunostaining according to standard procedures.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Combined immunohistochemistry and in-situ hybridization on cryosections were carried out as described previously (Hirsch et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The times of incubation with the primary antibodies ranged from 90 minutes (anti-COUP-TFs, anti-reelin) to overnight.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The following antibodies were used: rabbit -COUP-TFI (1:500), rabbit -COUP-TFII (1:1000), mouse -reelin (clone G10, 1:500; kind gift of A.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Goffinet), mouse -calbindin (clone CB-955, Sigma, 1:500), mouse -GABA (clone GB-69, Sigma, 1:1000) and mouse -ss-tubulin type III (clone SDL.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Sections were alternatively incubated in a biotinylated secondary antibody (Vector, 1:200) and processed by the ABC histochemical method (Vector) or with a fluorescent secondary antibody (Molecular probes 1:400; Alexafluor 488 -rabbit, Alexafluor 594 -rabbit, Alexafluor 594 -mouse) for 1 hour at room temperature.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The immunohistochemistry-treated sections were dried, dehydrated and mounted on a coverslip with Permount (Fisher); the immunofluorescence-treated sections were mounted with Vectashield (Vector).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The GFP was detected by its endogenous fluorescence.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	46	Cell counting In the grafting experiments, the cells were counted on images obtained from 6  microm sections of the slices that were acquired with a CCD camera attached to a conventional microscope.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	47	 To count the cells, a standardized box (a 40x enlargement of the slice) was used; for each transplant, three sections were evaluated, and for each section, the cells in two different regions were counted.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	48	 In the gain-of-function experiments, an image of the whole slice was obtained by confocal microscopy, after reconstruction of all of the confocal planes.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The GFP-positive cells that migrated towards the cortex or towards the POa were counted on this reconstructed image, and normalized for the total number of GFP-positive cells [e.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	50	 cortex/(cortex + basal ganglia), or POa/(POa + basal ganglia)].
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The data from control and overexpressing cells within the same slice were compared, and paired Student's t-tests were used for the analysis.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	52	To study the expression profile of both COUP-TFs during the period of neural migration, we performed immunohistochemistry on E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	53	5 mouse forebrains, when tangential migration is well pronounced.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	54	 At this stage, COUP-TFI expression was localized to all layers of the neocortex, to the piriform cortex, to the ventricular and subventricular zones of the LGE, to the ventricular zone of the MGE, to the POa, and in scattered cells in various regions of the basal telencephalon (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	55	 By contrast, COUP-TFII expression was mainly restricted to the marginal zone of the neocortex and to the piriform cortex and POa of the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Scattered COUP-TFII-positive cells were also identified in the LGE, at the cortico-striatal boundary, and in the intermediate zone of the neocortex (arrowheads in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Expression of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII was also seen in the interganglionic region where the MGE and LGE are fused, but before the appearance of the CGE (asterisk in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	58	 For convenience, we will define this area as the `MLGE border' henceforth.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Double labelling for COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII and COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII highlighted an increased expression of COUP-TFs in this region (insets in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	60	View larger version (87K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	61	 COUP-TFs are expressed in migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Adjacent coronal sections of an E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	63	5 mouse brain at a medio-caudal level immunostained with anti-COUP-TFI (A) and COUP-TFII antibodies (A').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The asterisks in A and A' indicate expression in the interganglionic region (the `MLGE').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The insets show an enlargement of this region after double labelling of COUP-TFs (COUP-TFI mRNA/COUP-TFII antibody in A; COUP-TFI antibody/COUP-TFII mRNA in A').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The arrow in A indicates the expression boundary of COUP-TFI at the level of the medial cortex, whereas in the same region COUP-TFII is expressed in the putative cortical hem region (ch in A').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	67	 An arrow in A' indicates expression in the marginal zone of the ncx, and the arrowheads show expression at the cortico-striatal boundary and in the intermediate zone of the ncx.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	68	 (B-B''') Two different enlargements of the regions indicated in A and A'.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Most COUP-TF-positive cells show a polarized soma (arrows in B-B'''), indicative of migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	70	 (C-C') Expression of COUP-TFs in the POa region.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Note that COUP-TFI is mostly restricted in the ventricular zone and in two streams of migrating cells, as indicated by the arrows.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	72	 High expression of COUP-TFII is mainly localized in the mantle zone and in a dorsally migrating stream (arrow in C').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	73	 ch, cortical hem region; cp, choroid plexus; LGE, lateral ganglionic eminence; MGE, medial ganglionic eminence; mz, mantle zone; ncx, neocortex; pcx, piriform cortex; POa, pre-optic area; VZ, ventricular zone.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	74	  Higher magnifications of the region between the MLGE border and POa showed that the scattered COUP-TF-positive cells were grouped into streams of cells with polarized bodies, indicative of migrating neurons (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Although both proteins were localized in the same area, double detection of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII indicated that expression in these populations overlapped only partially (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	76	 In the POa region, COUP-TFs presented complementary expression (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	77	 While COUP-TFI was expressed at high levels in the ventricular zone and in streams of cells oriented dorsally and ventrally (arrows in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	78	 1C), COUP-TFII was mainly expressed in the mantle zone and in cells dorsal to the POa region (arrow in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	79	 An additional complementary expression was evident at the level of the caudomedial wall of the telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	80	 While cortical COUP-TFI expression stopped abruptly at the level of the hem region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	81	 1A), COUP-TFII was specifically expressed in this region and in the choroid plexus (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	82	In summary, COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII showed distinct and mostly non-overlapping expression profiles in the developing telencephalon at E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Furthermore, COUP-TFs appeared to be expressed in migrating cells at the stages in which several tangential migratory pathways within the developing telencephalon are well pronounced.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	84	COUP-TFs are detected in specific and non-overlapping cellular populations in the developing cortex To characterize the types of cells in which COUP-TFs are expressed, we performed a series of double immunofluorescence studies for both COUP-TFs and cell-type-specific markers (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	85	View larger version (130K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	86	 COUP-TFI is expressed in GABAergic interneurons, while COUP-TFII is expressed in Cajal-Retzius cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Double immunofluorescence of COUP-TFs (green) and cell-type-specific markers (red) in coronal sections of E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	88	 COUP-TFI (A,B), but not COUP-TFII (D,E), co-labels with calbindin in the MZ of the ncx (A,D) and of the pcx (B,E).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	89	 COUP-TFII (F,G,H), but not COUP-TFI (C,I) co-labels with reelin in the MZ of the neocortex (C,F) and in the caudomedial cortical wall (G-I).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The inset in G is a schematic diagram of the section, and indicates the position of panels (G-I).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The arrows indicate double-positive cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Note that in H, all the cells are double positive, while in I none of the cells are double positive.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	93	 MZ, marginal zone; ncx, neocortex; pcx, piriform cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	94	  The expression data described previously suggested that COUP-TFs are expressed in migrating neurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	95	 To test this hypothesis, we used an antibody against calbindin that labels a subpopulation of GABAergic interneurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	96	5, the majority of calbindin-positive cells co-labelled with COUP-TFI-positive cells in the neocortex and piriform cortex (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	97	 2A,B), but not with COUP-TFII-positive cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Similar results were obtained with an anti-GABA antibody (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Thus, in the marginal zone of the cortex, GABAergic neurons are positive for COUP-TFI and negative for COUP-TFII.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	100	 To assess whether COUP-TFII-positive cells in the marginal zone were rather Cajal-Retzius cells, we used an antibody against reelin.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	101	 All COUP-TFII-positive cells co-expressed reelin (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	102	 2F), whereas no COUP-TFI-positive cells were positive for reelin in the cortex (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	103	5 co-localization of COUP-TFII and reelin was also detected in the caudomedial wall of the telencephalic vesicles (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	104	 2G,H), which has been recently described as one of the sources of Cajal-Retzius cells (Takiguchi-Hayashi et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	105	 This is not the case for COUP-TFI, in which no co-expression of COUP-TFI and reelin has ever been detected in this region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	106	Taken together, these data strongly suggest that in the cortex COUP-TFI is expressed in GABAergic interneurons, whereas COUP-TFII is expressed in Cajal-Retzius cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	107	COUP-TFI, and not COUP-TFII, is expressed in neurons migrating tangentially from the basal telencephalon to the cortex We have previously shown that some COUP-TFI-positive cells in the cortex are GABAergic interneurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	108	 It is now well established that the GEs are the major source of most neocortical interneurons (reviewed by Corbin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	109	, 2001; Marin and Rubenstein, 2001).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Therefore, to assess whether COUP-TFI-positive cells located in the basal telencephalon are interneurons migrating to the cortex, a series of grafts from the GEs of E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	111	5 GFP-expressing transgenic brain slices were homotopically transplanted into wild-type E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	112	 3A); expression of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII was subsequently monitored in adjacent sections of the same slices.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	113	 An example of an MLGE graft is shown in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	114	 3B, which demonstrates the fate of fluorescent cells after 60 hours of incubation, at which point GFP-positive cells were distributed in the mantle layer of the basal telencephalon and in various layers of the cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	115	 High magnification of the lateral and medial cortex showed that GFP-positive cells were present in the marginal and intermediate zones (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Interestingly, some GFP-positive cells were also present in deeper layers, with a radial orientation towards the surface of the cortex (arrows in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	117	 These cells were previously reported to migrate from the marginal zone to the ventricular zone before moving radially, to take up their positions in the cortical anlage (Nadarajah et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	118	 After double labelling with anti-COUP-TFI, 75% of the GFP-positive cells (n=250) were also positive for COUP-TFI, including the ventricle-directed cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Adjacent sections of the same grafted brain slices showed no co-localization of COUP-TFII and GFP (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	120	 This is in agreement with the observation that COUP-TFII-positive cells in the cortex are non-GABAergic, and therefore do not originate from the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Thus, our data confirm that COUP-TFI in the cortex is expressed in GABAergic interneurons originating from the subpallium, whereas COUP-TFII expression has a pallial origin.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	122	View larger version (113K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	123	 COUP-TFI-positive cells in the MZ of the cortex originate from the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (A) A grafting experiment performed at E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	125	5, in which dorsally migrating cells are analysed.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The box delineates the area shown in C-H.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	127	 (B) Example of an MLGE transplant that shows GFP-positive cells migrating dorsally into the ctx, laterally into the pcx, and ventrally into the POa/hypo.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	128	 (C-H) Double immunofluorescence for GFP (green) and COUP-TFs (red) shows that GFP-positive cells originating from the graft are double positive for COUP-TFI in the MZ (arrowheads in C-E) and in the ventricle-oriented cells deriving from the MZ (arrows in C-E).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Arrows in insets show labelling of cells in the intermediate zone (IZ).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	130	 (F-H) Double immunofluorescence of GFP (green) and COUP-TFII (red) shows no co-localization of these two proteins.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	131	 ctx, cortex; MZ, marginal zone; pcx, piriform cortex; POa/hypo, pre-opic area/anterior hypothalamus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	132	  COUP-TFI is expressed in neurons migrating tangentially towards ventral regions of the telencephalon In the transplantation experiments described above, we observed that when the grafted region included the MLGE region, a significant number of neurons also migrated towards the piriform cortex and towards more ventral regions, such as the POa and the anterior hypothalamus (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	133	 In some grafts, GFP-positive cells were also identified in the POa (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	134	 4B), suggesting that cells deriving from the interganglionic region migrate in various directions: dorsally, laterally and ventrally.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	135	 By double labelling GFP-positive cells with anti-COUP-TFI and anti-COUP-TFII antibodies, we found double-positive cells for COUP-TFI, but not for COUP-TFII, in this ventral migratory path (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	136	 This suggests that a subpopulation of COUP-TFI-positive cells located in the POa/anterior hypothalamus might originate from the GEs.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Furthermore, some of these migrating cells were neurons, as demonstrated by the double staining of GFP with the neuronal marker Tuj1 (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Finally, a subpopulation of COUP-TFI-positive cells in the ventral stream was positive for GABA (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	139	 4F), suggesting that some ventrally migrating cells are GABAergic interneurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	140	View larger version (111K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Dorsal-to-ventral migration within the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	142	 (A) A grafting experiment performed at E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	143	5, in which ventrally migrating cells are analysed.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The box delineates the area shown in C-E''.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	145	 (B) Example of a graft in which GFP-positive cells have reached the POa.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Arrows in C show co-localization of COUP-TFI (red) with GFP (green), whereas no co-labelling with COUP-TFII (red) has been identified (D) within the migratory cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	147	 (E-E'') Arrows in (E'') indicate that migrating cells are neurons by double labelling of GFP (green) with Tuj1 (red).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	148	 (E'') is a merge of panels (E) and (E').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	149	 (F) Double immunofluorescence of COUP-TFI (green) and GABA (red) shows that some COUP-TFI-positive cells (arrows) are GABAergic in the ventral migratory stream.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	150	 (G) By electroporation of a GFP-expressing construct into the MLGE region, GFP-positive cells migrate ventrally, and these cells express COUP-TFI (arrows in H).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Similarly, by inserting a DiI crystal into the MLGE region, fluorescent cells are detected ventrally, in the POa/hypothalamic region (I).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	152	 These cells co-express COUP-TFI (J).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The arrow indicates a leading process.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Note that the diffuse red signal in J is the result of the DiI signal after fixation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	155	  To validate the origin of this ventral stream, we used two further experimental approaches.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	156	 We first electroporated a GFP expression vector into the MLGE region of E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	157	5 brain slices and followed the fate of the electroporated cells after 60 hours of incubation (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	158	 GFP-positive cells located ventrally with respect to the injected side showed a leading process and co-labelled with COUP-TFI, but not with COUP-TFII (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Similarly, upon placing a crystal of DiI in the MLGE region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	160	 4I), fluorescent cells were subsequently identified in more ventral regions, and these cells were positive for COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The morphology of the DiI/COUP-TFI-positive cells fits well with the morphology of tangentially migrating cells observed by other authors (Nadarajah and Parnavelas, 2002).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Indeed, the nuclei of these cells were oriented in the sense of the migration and had a process lagging behind the soma (arrow in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	163	Finally, to assess whether ventrally directed migration also originates from more caudal levels, we grafted the CGE of a GFP E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	164	5 mouse brain to a wild-type brain of the same stage (n=5) (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	165	 After 60 hours of incubation, GFP-positive cells migrated out of the graft into two main streams: a medial stream directed towards the third ventricle, and a lateral stream directed laterally and ventrally into the hypothalamic region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Both streams contained single neurons with short and polarized leading processes indicative of migrating cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Adjacent sections of the same brain slices showed co-labelling of GFP with COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	168	 5C,D), whereas no COUP-TFII-positive cells were co-localized with GFP-positive cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	169	View larger version (121K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Cells originating from the caudal ganglionic eminence can migrate ventrally.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	171	 (A) Summary of the type of graft and the results obtained after 60 hours of incubation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	172	 (B) A caudal ganglionic eminence (CGE) transplant shows GFP-positive cells migrating ventrally in two streams: a medial stream and a lateral stream.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The arrows indicate that a few cells have reached the anterior hypothalamus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	174	 (C-F) Double immunofluorescence of GFP (green) and COUP-TFI (C,D) or COUP-TFII (red); E,F) on adjacent sections of the graft shown in B.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Note that all GFP-positive cells have a leading process oriented ventrally (arrows), but that only COUP-TFI is double positive for GFP (insets in C,D).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	176	 ant hypo, anterior hypothalamus; LS, lateral stream; MS, medial stream.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	177	  Taken together, these data show that cells located in the basal telencephalon migrate tangentially not only dorsally into the developing neocortex, as previously described, but also ventrally into the basal diencephalon, including the pre-optic and hypothalamic regions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Furthermore, our results show that COUP-TFI, but not COUP-TFII, is expressed in these populations of migrating neurons, suggesting a functional role of COUP-TFI in the patterning of tangential migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	179	Ectopic expression of COUP-TFI in the basal telencephalon promotes cells to migrate in both dorsal and ventral directions At this stage, we have demonstrated that a subpopulation of COUP-TFI-positive cells in the basal telencephalon are cells that are in the process of migrating; however, this does not demonstrate that COUP-TFI is directly involved in migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	180	 To address this issue, we set up a functional assay in E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	181	5 brain slice cultures, in which we ectopically expressed COUP-TFI in the GEs at different dorso-ventral and antero-posterior locations.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The migrating cells were followed after 60 hours of incubation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	183	 On one side, and as a control, we injected a construct expressing GFP under the control of a CMV promoter, while on the contralateral side, we injected a construct expressing COUP-TFI followed by an IRES-GFP sequence.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In this way, we could follow the fate of the injected cells by following GFP fluorescence in the same slices (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	185	 6B shows the average value of GFP-positive cells in the cortex and POa, expressed as a percentage of the total number of positive cells (for control 2838 cells, and for COUP-TFI 2318 cells; n=25; see also Materials and methods for details).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In all the cases examined, the COUP-TFI-injected sides showed a statistically significant increase in the number of cells in the cortex, compared with the control side (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Ventral migration was observed only in caudal sections in which the constructs were focally injected into the subventricular zone of the MLGE region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In controls, 24% and 17% of GFP-positive cells were scored on average in the cortex and in the POa, respectively (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	189	 6B), whereas the non-migrating cells were maintained in compact clusters next to the injection site.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The injection of a CMV-COUP-TFI-IRES-GFP construct into the contralateral side of the same slices resulted in GFP-positive cells that were more dispersed in the mantle layer (arrowheads in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	191	 6D), and that were still in the process of migrating dorsally towards the marginal zone of the cortex and ventrally towards the POa (arrows in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Moreover, a higher number of GFP-positive cells were scored in the cortex and in the POa (72% and 46%, respectively), compared with the control side.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Thus, in the presence of higher levels of COUP-TFI, injected cells showed significantly increased spreading and migrating, compared with the normal situation (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	194	 6B), suggesting that COUP-TFI modulates cell migration in the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	195	View larger version (73K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	196	 COUP-TFI modulates dorsal and ventral migration in brain slices.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	197	 (A) Summary of the type of experiments performed on E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	198	 On one side, a GFP-expressing vector is injected as a control, while on the contralateral side an injection of a COUP-TFI-IRES-GFP expressing vector shows an increased rate of migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	199	 (B) The average value of the GFP/GFPtot ratio (black columns) or the GFP-COUP-TFI/GFPtot ratio (white columns) of all of the injected slices, calculated independently in the cortex or ventrally in the POa (see also Materials and methods).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Bars indicate standard errors of the mean.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In the COUP-TFI injected side, 72 plus or minus 4% of the GFP-positive cells migrate into the cortex, versus 24 plus or minus 4% of the GFP-positive cells in the control side.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	202	 For the POa ectopic expression of COUP-TFI, 46 plus or minus 3% of the GFP-positive cells were induced to migrate, versus 17 plus or minus 3% in the control situation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Significant P-values are indicated (for the cortex P=0.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Example of a control (C) and a COUP-TFI overexpressing (D) brain slice after 60 hours of incubation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The vectors were focally injected into the MLGE region.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Note that in the control situation (C), a few cells were found in the cortex (C'), while the majority remain compacted in the injection point.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	207	 (D) After injection of high levels of COUP-TFI into the MLGE region, the GFP-positive cells are more dispersed (arrowheads) around the injection point, and a more pronounced contingent of cells migrates in the dorsal and ventral directions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	208	  Ectopic expression of COUP-TFII in the ganglionic eminences induces a higher rate of migration into the intermediate zone of the cortex Next, we tested whether COUP-TFII was also able to promote cell migration in the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	209	 We generated an additional construct in which the COUP-TFII-IRES-GFP cassette was under the regulation of the CMV promoter.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The control CMV-GFP- and CMV-COUP-TFII-IRES-GFP-expressing constructs were injected into the subventricular zone of the striatum on opposite sides of E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	211	 7B shows that in the presence of ectopic expression of COUP-TFII, the average number of GFP-positive cells found in the cortex (60%, of a total number of 467 cells) was significantly higher than in the control situation (32%, of a total number of 875 cells).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	212	 An example of an injection performed in the whole striatum is shown in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	213	 As expected, a high number of GFP-positive cells migrated out of the injection point into the marginal and intermediate zones of the neocortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	214	 After injection of the COUP-TFII-expressing construct, a statistically significant increase in the GFP-positive cells was found uniquely in the intermediate layer of the neocortex, and no GFP-positive cells were ever identified in the marginal zone (arrowheads and asterisk in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	215	 However, and by contrast to previous experiments, no GFP-positive cells were ever located ventrally in the POa region, even if we focally injected the construct into the MLGE region (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Thus, ectopic expression of COUP-TFII in the basal telencephalon promotes migrating neurons to undertake a preferential route into the intermediate zone of the neocortex by avoiding the marginal zone, suggesting a cell-autonomous property of COUP-TFII in guiding cortical neurons into a specific layer of the cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	217	View larger version (83K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	218	 COUP-TFII regulates migration into the intermediate zone of the neocortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	219	 (A) Summary of the type of experiments performed on E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The respective vectors are depicted to the left of each part of the diagram.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	221	 (B) The average values of the GFP/GFPtot ratio (black column) and the COUP-TFII-GFP/GFPtot ratio (white column) in the cortex of all of the injected slices.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Bars indicate standard errors of the mean.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	223	 In the COUP-TFII injected side, 60 plus or minus 4% of the injected cells migrate into the cortex, versus 25 plus or minus 5% of the GFP-positive cells in the control side.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Examples of control (C) and COUP-TFII mis-expressing (D) brain slices in which the vectors have been injected into the Str.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	225	 (C) Arrows indicate GFP-positive cells in the MZ, whereas arrowheads indicate the IZ migratory stream.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	226	 (D) Arrowheads indicate a higher amount of GFP-positive migrating cells in the IZ of the neocortex, whereas no cells are seen in the MZ (asterisk).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Dotted line shows the putative boundary between neocortex and striatum.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	228	 All the cells external to the dotted line have been counted as cells located in the cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	229	 IZ, intermediate zone; MZ, marginal zone; Str, striatum.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	230	In this report, we have identified a novel migratory path, which to our knowledge has never been reported before.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Using grafting experiments, DNA electroporation and tracer injections, we have shown that cells located in the interganglionic region, where the MGE and LGE fuse together, have the capability of migrating ventrally towards the pre-optic and hypothalamic regions of the diencephalon (Figs 3, 4, 5).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	232	 As this path originates from the interganglionic region at specific caudal levels, it is very likely that it has been missed in other studies using similar approaches (Anderson et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The novelty of this path is twofold: first, cells migrate tangentially from dorsal to ventral, along the subventricular zone of the MGE, i.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	234	 in opposite directions with respect to the MGE-derived cortical interneurons; and second, these cells exit the basal telencephalon and migrate into the basal diencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	235	 These cells are different from the gonadotropin-releasing hormone neurons, which originate in the olfactory placode and migrate along the vomeronasal nerve fibres until they reach the POa and hypothalamus (Wray et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Migration of GABAergic neurons from the GEs to the dorsal thalamus has been observed in human brains; however, rodent embryos did not reveal a similar migratory pathway (Letinic and Rakic, 2001).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	237	 With the help of retroviral cell tracing, Marin and collaborators (Marin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	238	, 2000) have shown that cells emanating from the MGE and the adjacent POa/anterior entopeduncular area express the transcription factor Nkx2.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	239	1 and migrate to the developing striatum, where they differentiate into local circuit neurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	240	 It would be interesting to find out whether Nkx2.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	241	1 is also involved in the opposite migratory path described in this report.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	242	Furthermore, we have shown that cells originating from the CGE migrate via different streams into the basal diencephalon, and in particular into the hypothalamus (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	243	 As opposed to the MLGE transplant, in which the stream of ventrally migrating cells is quite compact, cells migrating out of the CGE take a medial and latero-ventral route.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	244	 We do not know the fate of these ventrally migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In-vivo ultrasound-guided labelling or transplantation (Nery et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	246	, 2001), in which total cortices are manipulated in toto and characterized at later stages, would help us to understand the final destinies of these migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	247	Is the basal telencephalon only chemorepulsive? Transplantation experiments and co-culture assays have shown that the POa and hypothalamic regions prevent interneurons from migrating in a ventral direction by secreting repulsive molecules that are responsible for the dorsal migration of interneurons towards the cortex (Marin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	248	 However, the cues mediating this action have not been identified yet.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Here, we show that cells originating from more dorsal and caudal regions are capable of migrating ventrally towards the POa/anterior hypothalamus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	250	 How do we reconcile these different results? First, the previous studies showed that the majority of interneurons that originated from the MGE avoided migrating in ventral directions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	251	 This is what is expected for a circumscribed graft in a section where the two GEs are well separated (Marin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	252	 However, the dorsal-to-ventral cell migration that we describe in this report originates from a restricted region, the interganglionic sulcus, at more caudal levels.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	253	 It is plausible that in order to follow the migration that originates in the MGE and LGE, this region was not included in other studies.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Therefore, we hypothesize that cells originating from different rostrocaudal levels can have different responses to the same environment by expressing position-dependent receptors.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Accordingly, COUP-TFs are not expressed in ventrally migrating cells at more rostral levels, where the two GEs are well separated (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Thus, the POa and hypothalamus can have different roles, repulsion versus attraction, according to the type of cells they encounter.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	257	A novel role for COUP-TFs in neuronal migration in the developing forebrain COUP-TFs are orphan nuclear receptors of the steroid/thyroid superfamily shown to be involved in neurogenesis, axogenesis and neural differentiation (Park et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	258	 In the cortex, COUP-TFI is mainly known for its role in regionalization and in guidance of thalamocortical projections (Zhou et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	259	, 2001), whereas COUP-TFII is a fundamental player in angiogenesis and heart development (Pereira et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	260	 In this report, we have provided the first insights into the functional roles of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII in neuronal migration in vivo.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	261	 In a previous report, it was shown that COUP-TFI could regulate cell adhesion mechanisms required for the differentiation of embryonal carcinoma cells (Adam et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Because of the substrates on which cells were plated, it was suggested that COUP-TFI could modify the synthesis of ECM molecules, making cells autonomous for migration and spreading.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Our expression data in vivo and our functional data in organotypic cultures support these results in a context in which cell migration assumes a fundamental role in achieving neuronal diversity.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	264	 By using these different approaches, we have first shown expression of COUP-TFs in highly motile neurons, such as GABAergic and reelin-positive cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	265	 2); we have then confirmed the co-localization of COUP-TFI in migrating neurons in a series of grafting experiments (Figs 3, 4, 5); and finally, we have directly demonstrated a role of COUP-TFs in modulating cell migration in a gain-of-function approach (Figs 6, 7).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Our data also demonstrate that COUP-TFs can control directional migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Indeed, cells expressing higher levels of COUP-TFs (and thus GFP) not only tend to spread and lose their aspect of aggregates, but also follow specific migratory pathways (dorsal and/or ventral) that are intrinsic to cells expressing COUP-TFs (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	268	Therefore, we hypothesize a dual role for COUP-TFs.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	269	 First, they should regulate short-range cues, such as ECM and/or adhesive molecules, and in this way modulate the neighbouring environment.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Changes in a permissive environment would allow random dispersion of migratory cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Indeed, in the absence of COUP-TFI, GABAergic cells do migrate into the cortex, although in a less organised fashion than in the normal situation (M.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Therefore, we favour the hypothesis that COUP-TFI is involved in modulating cell migration, more than inducing cells to initiate migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	273	Second, we propose that COUP-TFs control diffusible guidance molecules, and/or their receptors, involved in cell migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Indeed, ectopic expression of COUP-TFI led to the correct directional migration of the targeted cells, i.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	275	 dorsal into the cortex and ventral into the POa (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	276	 6D), suggesting that cells over- or mis-expressing COUP-TFI were able to respond to COUP-TFI-dependent guidance cues.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	277	 More striking is the behaviour of MGE-migrating cells after mis-expression of COUP-TFII.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	278	 In this case, neurons that were committed to migrate into the marginal and intermediate layers of the neocortex (see control in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	279	 7C) migrated at higher rates solely into the intermediate layer, avoiding specifically the marginal layer (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	280	 7D), suggesting that COUP-TFII regulates guidance cues required for migration into the intermediate zone of the neocortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	281	 This behaviour is in accordance with the COUP-TFII expression pattern and the grafting experiments described in this study.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Indeed, COUP-TFII-positive cells in the marginal zone are Cajal-Retzius cells, as seen by the co-expression with reelin, and it is now well established that Cajal-Retzius cells originate exclusively from the pallium (Hevner et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	283	, 1999; Takiguchi-Hayashi et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	284	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank A.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Nagy for the GFP-expressing mice, A.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Goffinet for the anti-reelin antibody and M.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Tsai for the COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII full-length cDNAs.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Fishell for helpful comments on the manuscript, and to the whole Studer laboratory for fruitful discussions.

0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	313	 What is a Cajal-Retzius cell? A reassessment of a classical cell type based on recent observations in the developing neocortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Modes of neuronal migration in the developing cerebral cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Ventricle-directed migration in the developing cerebral cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	316	 The caudal ganglionic eminence is a source of distinct cortical and subcortical cell populations.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Molecular mechanism of chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor (COUP-TF) actions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	318	 The orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TFII is required for angiogenesis and heart development.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Control of cortical interneuron migration by neurotrophins and PI3-kinase signaling.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor is a motogen for interneurons migrating from the ventral to dorsal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Null mutation of mCOUP-TFI results in defects in morphogenesis of the glossopharyngeal ganglion, axonal projection, and arborization.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Principles of neural cell migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Telencephalic origin of pulvinar neurons in the fetal human brain.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Ectopic expression of the Dlx genes induces glutamic acid decarboxylase and Dlx expression.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Generation of reelin-positive marginal zone cells from the caudomedial wall of telencephalic vesicles.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Multimodal tangential migration of neocortical GABAergic neurons independent of GPI-anchored proteins.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The molecular biology of axon guidance.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	328	 In utero fate mapping reveals distinct migratory pathways and fates of neurons born in the mammalian basal forebrain.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Permissive corridor and diffusible gradients direct medial ganglionic eminence cell migration to the neocortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	330	 A subset of peripherin positive olfactory axons delineates the luteinizing hormone releasing hormone neuronal migratory pathway in developing mouse.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	331	 The migration of luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone neurons in the developing rat is associated with a transient, caudal projection of the vomeronasal nerve.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	332	 The nuclear orphan receptor COUP-TFI is required for differentiation of subplate neurons and guidance of thalamocortical axons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	333	 COUP-TFI: an intrinsic factor for early regionalization of the neocortex.
