0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	0	Characterization of the Human PPAR Promoter: Identification of a Functional Nuclear Receptor Response Element Ines Pineda Torra, Yalda Jamshidi, David M.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Flavell, Jean-Charles Fruchart and Bart Staels.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	2	545 Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale (I.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	3	), Departement d Atherosclerose, Institut Pasteur de Lille, 59019 Lille, and the Faculte de Pharmacie, Universite de Lille II, 59006 Lille, France; and Centre for Cardiovascular Genetics (Y.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	4	), Department of Medicine, Royal Free and University College London Medical School, The Rayne Institute, London WC1E 6JJ, United Kingdom.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	5	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Bart Staels, U.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	6	545 INSERM, Institut Pasteur de Lille, 1 Rue Calmette BP245, 59019 Lille, France.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	7	PPAR-mediated transcriptional regulation of target genes is tightly controlled by ligand activation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Fatty acid (FA) derivatives and the hypolipidemic fibrates are natural and synthetic PPAR ligands, respectively (3).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	9	 PPAR mediates the action of fibrates on plasma lipid levels by regulating the transcription of genes controlling lipoprotein metabolism (4).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Moreover, PPAR is a pivotal modulator of intracellular lipid metabolism by regulating the gene expression of proteins involved in FA uptake, FA esterification, FA entry into the mitochondria, peroxisomal and mitochondrial FA catabolism, and ketone body synthesis (1).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In addition to intra- and extracellular lipid metabolism, glucose and energy homeostasis as well as body weight were also reported to be influenced by PPAR activators (5, 6).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Furthermore, PPAR is an important regulator of vascular inflammation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	13	 PPAR inhibits the expression of various inducible factors implicated in the promotion of a local inflammatory response within the developing atherosclerotic plaque (2).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In addition, PPAR regulates the expression of lipoprotein receptors and cholesterol transporters involved in the reverse cholesterol transport pathway in macrophages (7, 8).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	15	 PPAR activators reduce plasma concentrations of inflammatory cytokines in vivo (9, 10) and reduce the progression of coronary atherosclerosis in humans (11, 12, 13, 14).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	16	In addition to ligand activation, transcriptional control of PPAR target genes depends on its expression levels.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	17	 High levels of PPAR expression are observed in tissues with elevated FA catabolic rates, such as liver, heart, kidney, muscle, and the large intestine (15, 16, 17).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In rodents, PPAR is regulated by stress (18) and by different hormones, such as GH, glucocorticoids, insulin, and leptin (19, 20, 21, 22).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	19	 PPAR expression oscillates diurnally (18), is diminished with age (23), and is induced during brown adipocyte differentiation (24).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Furthermore, starvation increases PPAR expression levels in liver leading to changes in mRNA levels of PPAR target genes (25).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Low PPAR mRNA levels result in decreased PPAR activity in pancreatic islets of obese Zucker diabetic (fa/fa) rats (22), in rat cardiomyocytes during cardiac hypertrophy (26), in livers of male Syrian hamsters upon lipopolysaccharide administration (27), and in intestinal epithelial cells during hypoxia (28).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Moreover, PPAR expression levels correlate with human apo AI gene induction in response to fibrate treatment as demonstrated in human apo AI transgenic mice crossed with PPAR-deficient mice (29).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	23	However, to date, studies addressing the regulation of PPAR gene expression have been largely performed either in rodent cells or in animal models.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Although the regulation of PPAR expression in humans remains largely unknown, the observation that hepatic PPAR mRNA levels vary significantly among individuals (30, 31) suggests that PPAR is also regulated at the transcriptional level in humans.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Indeed, hPPAR mRNA levels are induced during monocyte differentiation into macrophages (32), and high glucose concentrations up-regulate PPAR gene expression in human macrophages from healthy control subjects as well as from type 2 diabetic patients (33).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	26	To understand the molecular mechanisms governing PPAR regulation, we decided to identify and functionally characterize the 5'-flanking region of the hPPAR gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In the present manuscript the transcription start site was determined, and the upstream 5'-flanking region of the hPPAR gene was identified and cloned and its transcriptional activity was examined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	28	1 In the course of these studies the sequence of the 5'-untranslated region (UTR) of the hPPAR gene was completed and an alternatively spliced exon within the 5'-UTR of the gene was identified.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Finally, hPPAR promoter activity was shown to be regulated by the nuclear receptors hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4), chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II (COUP-TFII), and PPAR itself.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	30	View larger version (29K):    Figure 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Intron-Exon Structure of the 5'-UTR of the hPPAR Gene and Identification of an Alternative Spliced 5'-UTR Variant.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	32	A, Schematic representation of the 5'-UTR of the hPPAR gene and the identified spliced variants.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The first coding exon (filled box) and the 5'-noncoding exons (hatched boxes) are depicted.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Numbers over the boxes represent the exon length in base pairs.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Oligonucleotides used for RT-PCR analysis are indicated by arrows.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	36	 B, RT-PCR analysis on human liver RNA isolated from two different subjects.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Total RNA was extracted, reverse transcribed, and amplified using primers 15C and 13 (left) or 15C and IP13 (right).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	38	 -PCR corresponds to a PCR carried in the absence of RT product.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	39	 C, Genomic sequence corresponding to the alternatively spliced exon 1b.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Oligonucleotides IP3 and IP7 used for 5'-RACE analysis are indicated by arrows.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The acceptor and donor splice sites are depicted in bold.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Nucleotides in uppercase and lowercase letters correspond to exon and intron sequences, respectively.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	43	  Determination of the Transcription Start Site To determine the hPPAR transcription start site, 5'RACE-PCR analysis was performed.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Genomic sequence upstream of the previously reported exon 1a sequence (37) was obtained by primer walking the BAC clone containing the hPPAR gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Despite the overall low degree of homology shown by the PPAR 5'-UTRs among different species, a sequence of around 60 bp was found to be 88% homologous to a region close to the transcription start site in the mouse PPAR 5'-UTR (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	46	 This prompted us to examine whether the transcription start site in the human gene could also be upstream of this region.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Accordingly, a primer close to that sequence (primer IP18, Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	48	 2A) was used as gene-specific primer in a 5'-RACE-PCR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	49	 A 213-bp DNA fragment was amplified from human liver RNA (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	50	 2B) and subsequently sequenced.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The most 5'-nucleotide before the poly-dC tail introduced by the 5'-RACE procedure mapped to a T and was designated as nucleotide +1 (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Similar results were obtained when a different gene-specific primer (primer 5-GSP) was used in the 5'-RACE-PCR (data not shown).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	53	 To confirm the results of the 5'-RACE experiments, ribonuclease (RNase) protection analysis was performed.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	54	 RNase mapping with a 337-nucleotide labeled cRNA probe complementary to bp -22 to +213 (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	55	 2C) gave a major protected band of 213 bp (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	56	 2D), thus confirming the transcription start site that had been identified by 5'-RACE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	57	 These data indicate that exon 1a is considerably longer than the partially sequenced exon 1 that had been previously reported (34, 35, 37) and than the exon 1a identified in the mouse PPAR gene (36).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	58	View larger version (64K):    Figure 2.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Mapping of the Transcription Start Site of the hPPAR Gene by 5'-RACE and RNase Protection Analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	60	A, Sequence corresponding to exon 1a in the 5'-UTR region.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The oligonucleotides YGSP1, IP24, IP18, and 5-GSP used for 5'-RACE, RNase protection analysis, and cloning are indicated by arrows.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The donor splice site is depicted in bold lowercase.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The previously reported 5'-UTR sequence (37 ) is indicated in italics.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Transcription start site (+1) is shown by an arrow.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The sequence in bold uppercase represents a region showing 88% homology with both rat and mouse 5'-UTRs (see text for of the 5'-RACE products on an agarose gel.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Total RNA from human liver was reverse transcribed and the cDNA was poly-(dC) tailed with terminal deoxynucleotide transferase (TdT) as described in Materials and Methods.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	67	 dC-tailed cDNA (TdT+) or untailed cDNA (TdT-) were amplified using an universal primer (AAP) and a gene-specific primer (IP18).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	68	 C, Schematic representation of the probe used for RNase protection analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	69	 A genomic DNA fragment (-22 to +213) was amplified with oligonucleotides IP24 and IP18 (depicted in panel A) and cloned into pBluescript SK+.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Subsequently an antisense RNA probe was transcribed.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The size of the protected fragment, as predicted by the 5'-RACE experiment shown in panel B, is indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	72	 D, Mapping of the transcription start site by RNase protection analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Autoradiograph of RNase protection analysis carried out on 20  microg of human liver total RNA extracted from two different subjects.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The protected probe fragments (indicated by an arrow) correspond to those predicted in panel B.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	75	  Cloning and Analysis of the 5'-Flanking Region of the hPPAR Gene To identify potential binding sites for transcription factors that may be important in the regulation of hPPAR gene expression, 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	76	6 kb of hPPAR sequence upstream of the transcription start site were cloned.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	77	 No consensus TATA or CCAAT boxes were found within the first 100 bp, although a CCAAT box was observed at -472 bp (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Furthermore, this region possesses the characteristics of a TATA-less promoter, namely, GC-rich sequences and multiple putative Sp1 binding sites.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Computer-assisted analysis (38) revealed several potential transcription factor binding sites including AP2, Egr-1, Egr-2, E box, NFB, and MZF-1 among others (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	80	View larger version (57K):    Figure 3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Nucleotide Sequence of the 5'-Flanking Region of the hPPAR Gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	82	Numbers are relative to the transcription start site (+1).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The putative HNF4-RE is underlined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Putative transcription factor binding sites are indicated by open boxes.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	85	  Functional Characterization of the hPPAR Promoter To determine the ability of hPPAR 5'-flanking region to drive basal transcriptional activity, sequences were fused to a luciferase reporter gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Because hPPAR is highly expressed in liver (17), the 1,664-bp promoter-containing plasmid, p(H-H)-pGL3, was transiently transfected into human HepG2 hepatoma cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Activity of this construct was about 8-fold the activity of the parental promoterless construct (pGL3 basic) in these cells (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Next, the promoter activity of different 5'-deletion constructs was evaluated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Deletion from -1,664 to -1,206 did not significantly affect the promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Truncation to -648 significantly reduced the luciferase activity in HepG2 cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	91	 By contrast, in agreement with hPPAR tissue-selective expression, luciferase activities of the p(H-H)-pGL3 construct and its 5'-deletion mutants were only 2-fold higher than pGL3 basic in Cos-1 cells, a cell line that does not express PPAR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	92	 These experiments suggest that these cells are devoid of the factors driving basal hPPAR expression compared with HepG2 cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The shortest construct, p(P-H)-pGL3, containing the GC-rich proximal promoter was only 2-fold more active relative to pGL3 basic vector in both cell lines compared with the 6-fold activity shown by the p(E-H)-pGL3 construct, which suggests that sequences between -536 and -1,664 may contain binding sites for key transcription factors driving basal hPPAR gene expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (11K):    Figure 4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Functional Analysis of hPPAR Promoter 5'-Deletion Mutants.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	96	The region spanning 1,664 bp of promoter and the first 83 bp of exon 1a was progressively deleted from its 5'-end, fused to the pGL3 basic vector, and transfected into the indicated cell types as described in Materials and Methods.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Values (mean  plus or minus  SD) represent firefly luciferase activity normalized relative to a Renilla luciferase transfection internal control.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Luciferase activities are shown relative to the activity of the pGL3 basic vector, which was arbitrarily set to 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	99	  Identification of a Functional HNF4 Regulatory Element (HNF4-RE) in the hPPAR Promoter Because hPPAR is highly expressed in liver and the hPPAR 5'-flanking region shows significant promoter activity in HepG2 cells, the regulation of hPPAR promoter activity by HNF4, a nuclear receptor that is abundantly expressed in liver, was examined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	100	 To this purpose, transient transfection studies were performed with the p(H-H)-pGL3 construct in HepG2 cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In the presence of increasing concentrations of HNF4, hPPAR promoter activity was induced in a dose-dependent fashion (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	102	 To localize the region that confers HNF4 responsiveness within the hPPAR promoter, cotransfection assays were repeated with a series of 5'-deletion hPPAR promoter constructs (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	103	 These experiments revealed that the HNF4 responsive region resides within the fragment flanked by HindIII and XhoI sites.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Analysis of the sequence in this region of the hPPAR promoter revealed two potential hexamer binding sites separated by a single nucleotide between nucleotide -1,492 to -1,483 (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	105	 3), conforming to the DR1 response elements for HNF4 (HNF4-RE).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	106	 To unequivocally characterize the imperfect DR1 as an HNF4 response element, HepG2 and Cos cells were transfected with a hPPAR promoter construct bearing two nucleotide mutations in the 5'-hexamer of the DR1 element, p(H-H)HNF4-REmut-pGL3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	107	 In contrast to the wild-type promoter construct p(H-H)-pGL3, the mutated promoter was not influenced by HNF4 cotransfection in both cell lines (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	108	 5C), thus demonstrating that the hPPAR HNF4-RE (HNF4-RE) indeed confers HNF4 response to the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	109	View larger version (17K):    Figure 5.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	110	 HNF4-Mediated Transcriptional Regulation of hPPAR via a DR1 Element.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	111	A, HNF4 increases hPPAR promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	112	 HepG2 cells were transfected with the indicated reporter construct in the presence or absence of increasing amounts (3, 10, and 30 ng) of the HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	113	 When the hPPAR promoter plasmid was not cotransfected, pGL3 basic empty vector was added to the transfection mixture.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Relative luciferase activities are shown as described in Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	115	 B, Deletion analysis of the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	116	 HepG2 cells were transfected with the indicated reporter constructs in the presence or absence of 30 ng of HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Relative luciferase activities in the presence of HNF4 are shown as fold induction of the activity of the reporter constructs in the absence of HNF4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	118	 C, Schematic representation of the constructs p(H-H)-pGL3 and p(H-H)HNF4-REmut-pGL3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The bases mutated in p(H-H)HNF4-REmut-pGL3 are underlined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	120	 D, Localization of a functional HNF4-RE in the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	121	 HepG2 and Cos cells were transfected with the indicated reporter constructs in the presence or absence of the HNF4 expression plasmid (50 ng).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Relative luciferase activities are shown as fold induction of the activity of the p(H-H)-pGL3 reporter construct in the absence of HNF4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The data presented in panels A, B, and D represent the mean  plus or minus  SD of the firefly luciferase activity normalized relative to a Renilla luciferase transfection internal control.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	124	  Binding Analysis of HNF4 to the DR1 Element To demonstrate direct binding of HNF4 to the HNF4-RE, EMSAs were performed with a radiolabeled DR1 oligonucleotide probe and in vitro translated HNF4 proteins.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	125	 6, HNF4 bound the HNF4-RE (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	126	 6A, lane 4) and the well characterized C3P site present in the apo CIII promoter (39) with similar efficacy (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	127	 DNA binding was almost completely abolished when two-point mutations were introduced into the HNF4-RE-labeled oligonucleotide (GCAGCAAAGTTCA instead of GGGGCAAAGTTCA where the underlined letters indicate the mutated nucleotides) (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Furthermore, the specificity of the HNF4-DR1 interaction was demonstrated by competition studies.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Inhibition of formation of the complex was shown by the addition of increasing concentrations of either the unlabeled HNF4-RE (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	130	 6B, lanes 9 to 11) oligonucleotides, whereas competition with an equivalent amount of unlabeled mutated HNF4-RE did not significantly displace the labeled wild-type element (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	131	View larger version (69K):    Figure 6.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	132	A, HNF4 binds the HNF4-RE and C3P oligonucleotide probes with similar efficacy.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Autoradiograph of EMSA performed on end-labeled oligonucleotides (probe) using in vitro translated HNF4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	134	 B, Competition experiments were performed in the presence of 1-, 10-, and 100-fold molar excess of the indicated unlabeled oligonucleotides on a HNF4-RE radiolabeled probe.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	135	  The HNF4-RE Confers HNF4 Responsiveness to a Heterologous Promoter To explore the activation of the HNF4-RE by HNF4 in the context of a heterologous promoter, cotransfection studies were performed with the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 construct, which contains two copies of the DR1 in the sense orientation in front of the thymidine kinase (TK) promoter (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Upon cotransfection of HNF4 into both HepG2 and RK13 cells, the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 transcriptional activity was significantly enhanced (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	137	 By contrast, the reporter activity of a similar heterologous promoter construct containing two copies of the mutated HNF4-RE was not influenced by HNF4 cotransfection (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Taken together, these data show that the DR1 site is a bona fide HNF4-RE that mediates HNF4 induction of hPPAR promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	139	View larger version (17K):    Figure 7.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The HNF4-RE Confers HNF4 Responsiveness to a Heterologous Promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	141	A, Schematic representation of the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 and the HNF4-REmutx2S-TKpGL3 constructs.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The bases mutated in HNF4-REmutx2S-TKpGL3 are underlined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	143	 B, The HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 construct was transfected in either HepG2 or RK13 cells in the presence or absence of HNF4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	144	 When the HNF4-RE heterologous construct was not cotransfected, TK-pGL3 empty vector was added to the transfection mixture (-).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Data represent the mean  plus or minus  SD of the firefly luciferase activity normalized relative to a Renilla luciferase transfection internal control.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Relative luciferase activities are shown as fold induction of the activity of TK-pGL3 in the absence of HNF4, which was arbitrarily set to 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	147	 C, HepG2 cells were transfected with either the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 or the HNF4-REmutx2S-TKpGL3 constructs in the presence or absence of HNF4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The data represent the mean  plus or minus  SD of the firefly luciferase activity normalized relative to a Renilla luciferase transfection internal control and are shown as described in Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	149	  COUP-TFII Binds the HNF4-RE and Represses Basal and HNF4-Induced hPPAR Promoter Activity DR1 elements can be recognized not only by HNF4, but also by other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, including the transcription factor COUP-TFII, also known as apo A-1 regulatory protein 1 or ARP1 (40).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In addition, COUP-TFII has been shown to actively repress or modulate the effects of HNF4 on the transcription of several genes in liver (39, 41, 42, 43, 44).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Therefore, the ability of COUP-TFII to bind the HNF4-RE was evaluated by gel shift analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	152	 COUP-TFII proteins bound to the radiolabeled HNF4-RE probe, and competition with 50-fold molar excess of unlabeled HNF4-RE oligonucleotide completely inhibited the formation of the COUP-TFII -DNA complex (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	153	View larger version (29K):    Figure 8.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	154	 COUP-TFII Binds the DR1 and Modulates Basal and HNF4-Induced hPPAR Promoter Activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	155	A, EMSA performed on end-labeled HNF4-RE oligonucleotide in the presence of in vitro translated COUP-TFII.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The unlabeled oligonucleotide (50-fold molar excess) was added to the binding reactions when indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	157	 B, The indicated reporter constructs were cotransfected into either HepG2 or Cos cells with or without HNF4 and COUP-TFII as indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	158	 When either the HNF4 or COUP-TFII expression plasmids were not cotransfected, pSG5 or pCDNA3 empty vectors, respectively, were added to the transfection mixture.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Relative luciferase activities (mean  plus or minus  SD) are shown as fold induction of the activity of the p(H-H)-pGL3 reporter construct in the absence of both HNF4 and COUP-TFII.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	160	  The influence of COUP-TFII on the hPPAR promoter activity was then investigated by cotransfection experiments in HepG2 and Cos cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Transient transfection of COUP-TFII alone decreased the activity of the hPPAR promoter construct containing the HNF4-RE site in both HepG2 and Cos cells (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	162	 As previously observed, upon cotransfection of HNF4, hPPAR promoter activity was induced in both cell lines.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	163	 However, overexpression of COUP-TFII in the presence of HNF4 abrogated the HNF4-induced transcriptional activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	164	 On the contrary, when identical experiments were performed with a promoter construct bearing a mutation in the HNF4-RE, promoter activity was not affected by cotransfection of either COUP-TFII or HNF4 alone or added together (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	165	 These data demonstrate that the repression of the PPAR promoter by COUP-TFII and the antagonism of the HNF4 induction are dependent on the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Altogether these results indicate that COUP-TFII negatively regulates PPAR gene transcription.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	167	hPPAR Binds the HNF4-RE and Regulates Its Own Expression Next, direct binding of PPAR/RXR heterodimers to the hPPAR HNF4-RE was examined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	168	 To this purpose, gel shift analysis was performed with the radiolabeled HNF4-RE probe and in vitro translated PPAR and RXR proteins.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	169	 PPAR/RXR heterodimers bound the HNF4-RE oligonucleotide (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	170	 DNA binding could be competed with increasing amounts of unlabeled HNF4-RE oligonucleotide (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	171	 9A, lanes 3 to 5), whereas incubation with a mutated HNF4-RE oligonucleotide did not compete for binding (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	172	View larger version (28K):    Figure 9.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	173	 PPAR Positively Regulates Its Own Expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	174	 EMSA performed on end-labeled HNF4-RE oligonucleotide in the presence of in vitro translated PPAR and RXR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Competition experiments were performed in the presence of 10-, 25-, and 50-fold molar excess of the indicated unlabeled oligonucleotides.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	176	 B, PPAR modulates hPPAR promoter activity via the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Cos cells were transfected with either the p(H-H)-pGL3 hPPAR or the p(H-H) HNF4-REmut-pGL3 hPPAR promoter construct, with or without a PPAR expression plasmid in the presence or absence of 100  microM Wy 14,643 as indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Relative luciferase activities (mean  plus or minus  SD) for each construct are shown relative to the promoter activity in the absence of PPAR and activator, which was arbitrarily set to 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	179	 C, The HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 plasmid was transfected in Cos cells with or without PPAR in the presence or absence of 50  microM Wy 14,643 as indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Relative luciferase activities (mean  plus or minus  SD) are shown as in panel B.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	181	 D, Fenofibric acid enhances hPPAR mRNA levels in primary cultures of human hepatocytes.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Human hepatocytes were isolated and treated for 24 h with (FF) or without (CON) 250  microM fenofibric acid.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	183	 One microgram of total RNA was reversed transcribed and subjected to Real Time PCR analysis as described in Materials and Methods.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Specific hPPAR mRNA normalized to 28S content is expressed relative to untreated cells (mean  plus or minus  SD, n = 3).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	185	  To determine the effect of PPAR on hPPAR promoter activity, transient transfection assays were performed using the hPPAR promoter construct containing the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Cotransfection of PPAR induced hPPAR reporter activity approximately 2-fold, an effect that was enhanced in the presence of Wy 14,643.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	187	 By contrast, no effect by either PPAR or its ligand could be observed when a construct containing the mutated HNF4-RE was employed, indicating that an intact HNF4-RE site is required for the PPAR-mediated induction.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	188	 To investigate whether the HNF4-RE could function as a PPRE in front of a heterologous promoter, transient transfection assays were performed using the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 construct (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Incubation of cells with Wy 14,643 in the presence of cotransfected PPAR resulted in a 5-fold activation of the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 construct, indicating that the HNF4-RE site is a functional PPRE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	190	Finally, to analyze whether hPPAR mRNA expression is regulated by PPAR agonists, primary hepatocytes isolated from human liver were cultured for 24 h in medium containing fenofibric acid.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	191	 hPPAR mRNA levels were markedly up-regulated upon treatment with fenofibric acid (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Taken together, these data show that PPAR positively autoregulates its expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	193	To study PPAR regulation in humans, we characterized the 5'-flanking region of the hPPAR gene and identified the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The genomic organization of hPPAR was recently reported (34, 35).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The hPPAR gene contains at least eight exons in which exons 1 and 2, the 5'-end of exon 3, and the 3'-end of exon 8 are not translated (34, 35).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	196	 As an initial step in our study, the 5'-UTR of the hPPAR gene was further characterized, resulting in the completion of the 5'-end sequence of exon 1, renamed exon 1a, and in the identification of an alternatively spliced 5'-variant.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	197	 An alternatively spliced exon in the mouse PPAR 5'-UTR has been previously reported (36).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	198	 However, alignment of both mouse and human 5'-UTR sequences revealed no significant degree of homology between them despite the coding exons being very similar between species.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	199	The transcription start site of the hPPAR gene was mapped.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The proximal promoter of the hPPAR gene contains no typical TATA or CCAAT boxes and has a high GC content, including several consensus Sp1 sites, features that are also present in the mouse PPAR promoter (36).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Excluding the proximal GC-rich region, both promoters do not show a high degree in sequence homology (40%).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	202	 However, only a small fragment of the mouse PPAR promoter has been sequenced to date (36).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	203	 This sequence disparity in both the 5'-UTR and the promoter regions may indicate that PPAR gene expression among species could be regulated in a different manner although sufficient data to establish a thorough comparison between species are lacking at this stage.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	204	Computer-assisted analysis of the hPPAR promoter sequence identified various putative transcription factor binding sites, such as sites for members of the early growth response (Egr) gene family, which are involved in the induction of monocytic differentiation (45).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Egr proteins could thus be involved in the up-regulation of hPPAR expression upon monocyte differentiation into macrophages (32) although further studies are needed to confirm this hypothesis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Furthermore, potential sites for NFB and AP1, factors involved in the transduction of several cytokine and proinflammatory signals, as well as for the myeloid zinc finger gene, MZF-1, were found in the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	207	 PPAR inhibition of NFB- and AP1-induced expression of inflammatory response genes (46) lies at the basis of its antiinflammatory activities.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	208	 It is tempting to speculate that hPPAR expression, in its turn, is controlled by inflammatory cytokines.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Because rodent PPAR mRNA levels are increased by glucocorticoids (20, 21), putative GR response elements were searched for.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	210	 No obvious GR response element could be detected within the hPPAR regulatory region analyzed; however, regulation studies in human tissues or cell lines would be necessary to determine whether hPPAR expression is also modulated by glucocorticoids in humans.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	211	HNF4 is a nuclear receptor that plays a key role in liver-specific gene expression (47) and is required for mammalian hepatocyte differentiation and for normal metabolic regulation in liver (48).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	212	 HNF4 is expressed at high levels in liver, kidney, and intestine (47).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	213	 It binds as homodimers to DR1-like response elements, thereby modulating the expression of several liver-enriched genes encoding apolipoproteins, coagulation factors, serum proteins, proteins of the cytochrome P450 family, and genes involved in FA and glucose metabolism (49).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Regulation of hPPAR by HNF4 is consistent with the tissue-expression pattern shown by PPAR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	215	 In the present study induction of hPPAR promoter activity by HNF4 is reported.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	216	 A HNF4-RE was identified at nt -1,492 to -1,483 within the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	217	 This element closely resembles several HNF4-REs found in other genes and the GGGGCA A AGGTCA consensus HNF4 binding site (50).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Moreover, the regulation of PPAR gene expression by HNF4 in vivo in mice was recently demonstrated using HNF4-deficient mice (51).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	219	 These mice display significantly lower PPAR mRNA levels compared with the wild-type mice, thus demonstrating that PPAR expression is regulated by HNF4 also in mice.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Nevertheless, the promoter experiments performed with the hPPAR promoter indicate that the HNF4 site identified is not responsible for the activity of the hPPAR promoter in liver because the promoter construct lacking this site still possesses a significant activity in HepG2 cells (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	221	 This may suggest that this site binds as well other factors, such as COUP-TF, present in these cells that negatively regulate the hPPAR promoter either as a result of a direct repression of the promoter or due to competition with factors, such as HNF4, for binding to the site.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	222	 In addition, negative factors may bind to sites located between -1,664 and -1,206 bp in the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Future studies on the regulation of this promoter will be required to elucidate the factors governing hPPAR gene expression in liver.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	224	Members of the COUP-TF family of orphan nuclear receptors have been reported to bind DR1 sites that are also recognized by HNF4 (52).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	225	 COUP-TF actively represses or antagonizes HNF4-mediated transcriptional activation of several genes (39, 41, 42, 43, 44).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	226	 COUP-TF II has been shown to play a role in cardiac energy metabolism and heart development (53, 54).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	227	 In this study, COUP-TFII was also shown to bind the HNF4-RE within the hPPAR regulatory region and to repress both basal and HNF4-induced hPPAR promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The COUP-TFII antagonism may finely tune HNF4-dependent gene expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The expression level of a COUP-TFII/HNF4 target gene would therefore depend on the relative concentrations of both transcription factors in a given cell type or during a certain condition.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	230	 For instance, the age-dependent diminution of apo AI gene expression has been shown to occur at the transcriptional level and to be associated with a decrease in the binding capacity and expression of HNF4 and a parallel increase in COUP-TFII binding and concentration levels (55).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Interestingly, PPAR gene expression is also diminished in aged rats (23).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Further studies are required to demonstrate whether the molecular mechanisms described for the age-dependent decline of apo AI can also explain the decreased expression of PPAR with age.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	233	Finally, PPAR is also capable of binding to the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Induction of PPAR gene expression by PPAR agonists has been reported in different rodent cell lines (22, 24, 56).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Our data indicate that PPAR agonists, such as fenofibrate, induce hPPAR mRNA levels in primary cultures of human hepatocytes as well as hPPAR promoter activity, suggesting that these effects are exerted at the transcriptional level.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Furthermore, induction of hPPAR promoter activity is dependent on the identified HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Autoregulation is a common feature among nuclear receptors.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	238	 For instance, GRs are regulated by glucocorticoids, and glucocorticoids exert these actions mainly at the level of transcription (57).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	239	 AR is another nuclear receptor that is autoregulated (58), and three different ER promoters have been shown to be regulated by estrogens (59).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	240	The coding exons of the hPPAR gene have been screened for polymorphisms.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	241	 A leucine-to-valine missense mutation at codon 162 in exon 5 of the hPPAR gene (L162V) was recently identified (34, 35).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	242	 This polymorphism shows an enhanced transactivation activity (34) and has been associated with altered plasma lipid and lipoprotein concentrations in type 2 diabetic subjects (34), supporting a role for PPAR in dyslipidemia and diabetes in humans also.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Variants have been identified in other exons and introns of the hPPAR gene (Ref.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Staels, unpublished observations).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	245	 However, these polymorphisms either show low frequency in the populations studied or they do not directly affect PPAR activity due to their location in intronic sequences of the gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Thus, it will be interesting to search for polymorphisms in the promoter sequences of the gene that may affect PPAR expression and function.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	247	Taken together, the 5'-flanking region of the hPPAR gene has been characterized, cloned, and functionally studied.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	248	 HNF4 induces hPPAR expression via a DR1 element present in the hPPAR promoter, whereas this effect is antagonized by the orphan receptor COUP-TFII.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In addition, PPAR itself modulates its own expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Knowledge of the hPPAR promoter structure will allow further studies of the molecular mechanisms governing hPPAR gene regulation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	251	Rapid Amplification of cDNA Ends (5'-RACE) PCR and RT-PCR Analysis Total human liver RNA was isolated using the guanidinium isothiocyanate method (61).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	252	 5'-RACE was performed on 1  microg total RNA using the 5' RACE-System for Rapid Amplification of cDNA Ends kit (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	253	, Gaithersburg, MD) according to the manufacturer s instructions.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	254	 For the determination of the 5'-end of exon 1a, first-strand synthesis of hPPAR cDNA was carried out using the IP7 oligonucleotide (5'-CAAGCAGTCCTCCTACCTCAGCCTTCCAAG-3') located in exon 1b (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	255	 After RNase H treatment and poly(dC)-tailing of the cDNA with a terminal deoxynucleotide transferase, the resulting cDNA (5  microl) was amplified in a PCR using the Abridged Anchor Primer (AAP) and the internal gene-specific primer YGSP1 (5'-AGTTCTGAGCTTCTCTTGCCACAAACAGTTGAGTCC-3') located in exon 1a (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	256	 PCR cycling parameters were as follows: initial denaturation at 95 C for 5 min followed by 35 cycles of 1 min at 95 C, 40 sec at 57 C, and 40 sec at 72 C with a final elongation at 72 C for 3 min.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The PCR product was then diluted 100-fold, and the diluted PCR (5  microl) was used for a nested PCR under the same conditions described above with the Abridged Universal Amplification Primer (AUAP) (nested to AAP) and oligonucleotide IP18 (5'-AGAGTCGCTGCGGTCCCCAGAC-3') (nested to YGSP1).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Oligonucleotides AUAP and AAP were provided in the 5'-RACE kit.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	259	 PCR products were visualized on a 2% agarose gel and sequenced as described above.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	260	 RT-PCR amplification of the hPPAR 5'-UTR was performed as described (31) using oligonucleotides 15C (5'-CAGGGCCCTGTCTGCTCTGTGCA-3'), 13 (5'-CTCTTATCTATGAAGCAGGAAGCACG-3'), and IP3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	261	RNase Protection Analysis The RNase protection probe used to map the transcription initiation site of the hPPAR gene was amplified by PCR from the BAC-hPPAR clone using oligonucleotides IP24 (5'-CGCGGGGCCCGGGGTCTCGGGGTCTCCG-3') and IP18 and cloned into the EcoRV site of pBluescript SK+ (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	262	 After linearizing with XhoI, antisense RNA was transcribed with T3 polymerase using the Maxiscript Kit (Ambion, Inc.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	263	, Austin, TX) as described by the manufacturer.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	264	 This 337-nucleotide probe contains cRNA complementary to the hPPAR 5'-flanking region (bp -22 to +213) and to the polylinker of the pBluescript SK+ vector (102 bp).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	265	 RNase protection analysis was carried out using the Hybspeed RNase protection Kit (Ambion, Inc.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	266	Real-Time PCR mRNA Quantification PPAR and 28S mRNAs were quantified by reverse transcription followed by Real-Time PCR using a LightCycler (Roche Diagnostics, Meylan, France) with oligonucleotide primers specific for hPPAR (5'-ATATCTCCCTTTTTGTGGCTGCTA-3' and 5'-TCCGACTCCGTCTTCTYGATGA-3') and 28S (62).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Reactions were carried out in a 20- microl reaction containing a 500-nM concentration of each primer, 4 mM MgCl2, and the LightCycler-FastStart DNA Master SYBR Green I mix as recommended by the manufacturer with the following conditions: 95 C for 8 min, followed by 40 cycles of 10 sec at 95 C, 10 sec at 55 C and 14 sec (for hPPAR) or 15 sec (for 28S) at 72 C.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	268	 hPPAR mRNA levels were normalized to 28S mRNA.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	269	Cloning of the hPPAR Promoter and Construction of Reporter Plasmids Genomic sequences between -3,593 and +83 (numbered on the basis of the distance from the transcription initiation site) obtained by direct sequencing of the BAC-hPPAR clone were amplified by PCR using oligonucleotides IP34 (5'-GCCAGGAGCAGCCACCAGGGAAATC-3') and 5-GSP (5'-AGTCCTCGGTGTGTGTCCTCGCTCCTC-3') from BAC clone DNA.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	270	 The resulting product was cloned blunt into the EcoRV site of pBluescript SK+ (Stratagene).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Reporter constructs were generated thereafter by digestion using restriction sites within the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The pBS(IP34 to 5GSP) construct was digested with HindIII or both HindIII and XhoI, and the resulting promoter digestion products were gel purified and cloned into a HindIII or XhoI plus HindIII-digested pGL3 basic plasmid (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	273	, Madison, WI), creating the reporter vectors p(H-H)-pGL3 and p(X-H)-pGL3, respectively.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Plasmids p(E-H)-pGL3 and p(P-H)-pGL3 were generated by digestion of p(X-H)-pGL3 with EcoRI plus XhoI or PstI plus XhoI, Klenow fill in of cohesive ends, and subsequent ligation of the obtained blunt ends.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	275	 HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 and HNF4-REmutx2S-TKpGL3 were created by ligating two copies of the corresponding double-stranded oligonucleotides (5'-GATCCTGGAGGGTGGGGCAAAGTTCACCATAGGTA-3' for HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 and 5'-GATCCTGGAGGGTGCAGCAAAGTTCACCATAGGTA-3' for HNF4-REmutx2S-TKpGL3) in the sense orientation into the BamHI site of TK-pGL3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	276	 All constructs were verified by restriction site digestion and sequence analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Transcription factor analysis of the promoter was performed using the MatInspector program (http://genomatix.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	278	de/cgi-bin/matinspector/matinspector.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	279	Site-Directed Mutagenesis To create p(H-H)HNF4-REmut-pGL3, mutation of the HNF4-RE was generated using the QuikChange Site-Directed Mutagenesis Kit (Stratagene) and oligonucleotide (5'-GGTGTCTGGAGGCTGCAGCAAAGTTCACCATAG-3') and its complementary oligonucleotide according to the manufacturer s recommendations.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	280	Cell Culture and Transient Transfection Assays Human liver specimens were collected for transplantation at the Moscow Center, and hepatocytes were obtained by a two-step collagenase perfusion as previously described (63).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Donors were physically healthy subjects who died after traumatic brain injury.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Permission to use the remaining untransplanted donor liver for scientific research purposes was obtained from the Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	283	 After 20 h of culture the medium was discarded and 250  microM fenofibric acid (Laboratories Fournier, Daix, France) or vehicle was added at the indicated concentration in serum-free medium for 24 h.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	284	 HepG2 (human hepatoblastoma), RK13 (rabbit kidney), and Cos cells were cultured as previously described (31).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	285	 HepG2 (105), RK13 (8 x 104), and Cos (4 x 104) cells were transfected using the cationic lipid RPR 120535B (kind gift of Aventis, Vitry, France) as described previously (64).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	286	 One hundred nanograms of the indicated pGL3 basic firefly luciferase reporter constructs or 10 ng of the TK-pGL3 reporters were cotransfected with or without 30 to 50 ng of pSG5-hHNF41 (termed HNF4 throughout this manuscript, kindly provided by B.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Laine), pcDNA3-COUP-TFII [subcloned from pMT2-COUP-TFII (65) into pcDNA3] or pSG5-hPPAR, and either 20 ng or 5 ng of the internal control Renilla luciferase reporter plasmids, pRL-Null (when basal promoter activities of the different deletion constructs were examined) (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	288	) and pRL-C+ (for the remaining transfection experiments), respectively.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	289	 pRL-C+ was obtained by replacing the luc + cassette in pGL3-C+ (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	290	 When either HNF4 or COUP-TFII plasmid was not cotransfected, pSG5 (Stratagene) or pcDNA3 (Invitrogen) empty vectors were added to the transfection mixture.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Luciferase activity was assayed 36 h later using the Dual-Luciferase Reporter Assay System (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Transfections were carried out in triplicate, and each experiment was repeated at least twice.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	293	EMSAs HNF4, COUP-TFII, PPAR, and RXR were synthesized in vitro using the TNT Quick Coupled Transcription/Translation System (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides were end-labeled with [-32P]ATP by using T4-polynucleotide kinase.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Proteins (2  microl) were incubated for 15 min at room temperature in a total volume of 20  microl with 2.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	296	5  microg poly (dI-dC) and 1  microg herring sperm DNA in binding buffer (10 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	297	1 mM EDTA; 10% glycerol; 1 mg/ml BSA; and 0.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	298	5 mM dithiothreitol) before the radiolabeled probe (0.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Binding reactions were further incubated for 15 min and resolved by 4% nondenaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in 0.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	300	25x Tris-borate-EDTA buffer at room temperature.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	301	 For competition experiments, increasing amounts of unlabeled oligonucleotide HNF4-RE, HNF4-REmut, or C3P (39) were included in the binding reaction just before addition of the labeled oligonucleotide.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	302	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Christian Duhem, Odile Vidal, and Eric Raspe for their expert technical assistance.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	303	 We are grateful to Lluis Fajas, Raphael Darteil, and Olivier Barbier for their helpful advice and discussions.

0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	307	Abbreviations: AP1 or 2, Activating protein 1 or 2; AAP, abridged anchor primer; BAC, bacterial chromosomal clone, COUP-TFII, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II; DR1, direct repeat-1, FA, fatty acid; HNF4, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4; HNF4-RE, HNF4 regulatory element; NFB, nuclear factor B; PPRE, PPAR response element; RACE, rapid amplification of cDNA ends; RNase, ribonuclease; TK, thymidine kinase; UTR, untranslated region.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	308	1 The sequence data for the hPPAR exon 1a, 1b, and promoter have been submitted to the GenBank database under GenBank accession numbers AF323915, AF323916, and AF323917, respectively.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	309	Received for publication August 31, 2001.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Accepted for publication January 17, 2001.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	0	Regulation of Retinoic Acid-induced Inhibition of AP-1 Activity by Orphan Receptor Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor* Feng Lin, Siva Kumar Kolluri, Guo-quan Chen, and Xiao-kun Zhang.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Burnham Institute, Cancer Center, La Jolla, California 92037.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, February 25, 2002, and in revised form, April 2, 2002.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	3	Retinoids, the natural and synthetic vitamin A analogs, exert profound effects on many biological processes, including cell proliferation and differentiation (1, 2), and are recognized as promising agents for the prevention and treatment of various cancers.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The effects of retinoids are mainly mediated by two nuclear receptor classes, the retinoic acid receptor (RAR)1 and retinoid X receptor (RXR) (3-5).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Both are encoded by three different genes (, , and ) and function as ligand-inducible transcription factors in vivo mainly as RXR/RAR heterodimers.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	6	 trans-Retinoic acid (trans-RA) binds RARs, whereas 9-cis-RA binds both RARs and RXRs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Binding of retinoids to their receptors induces receptor conformational changes that switch on transcription of genes containing RA response elements (RAREs) (3-5).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In addition to their positive regulation of RARE-containing genes, retinoid receptors, in response to their ligands, can inhibit effects induced by the tumor promoter 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate (TPA) and the transcriptional activity of the proto-oncogenes c-Jun and c-Fos (6), which are components of the AP-1 complex, which often has a role in cancer cell proliferation (7).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The activation of AP-1-responsive genes by TPA or c-Jun/c-Fos through TPA response elements (TREs) is repressed by retinoid receptors in a ligand-dependent manner (8-10).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Conversely, AP-1 represses transactivation of retinoid receptors (8, 9).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	11	 This mutual antagonism appears to play a critical role in regulating cell growth and differentiation (6).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	12	 For example, overexpression of c-Jun conferred retinoid resistance to breast cancer cells (11), while overexpression of retinoid receptors enabled trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 activity in ovarian cancer cells and their growth (12).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The functional interaction between AP-1 and retinoid receptors is also observed for other nuclear receptors, including glucocorticoid receptor (13-16), thyroid hormone receptor (17), vitamin D receptor, estrogen receptor (18, 19), and androgen receptor (AR) (18).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	14	The anti-AP-1 activities shown by liganded retinoid receptors appear to contribute significantly to the therapeutic efficacy of retinoids against hyperproliferative diseases (6).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Transcription of various AP-1-responsive genes, such as collagenase and stromelysin, which have roles in tumor progression and invasiveness (20), is inhibited by retinoids (8-10) and has been reported to contribute to their reversal of human bronchial epithelial squamous differentiation (21).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Retinyl methyl ether, which effectively prevents mammary cancer in animals, strongly suppressed AP-1 activity in breast cancer cell (22).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Interestingly, RAR, a negative regulator of cancer cell growth (23), potently inhibits AP-1 activity and collagenase expression in both breast and lung cancer cells (24).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Recent studies demonstrate that retinoids that specifically inhibit AP-1 activity but antagonize RAR transactivation on RAREs inhibited the growth of many different types of cancer cells (25-27).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Anti-AP-1 retinoids inhibited squamous differentiation of human bronchial epithelial cells (21), TPA-induced transformation and the clonal growth of the promotion-sensitive JB6 mouse epidermal cell line (28), and papilloma formation in animals (29).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Thus, anti-AP-1 activity of retinoids contributes to their chemopreventive and chemotherapeutic effects, presumably by blocking the processes of tumor promotion and cell transformation.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	21	The mechanism by which retinoids inhibit AP-1 activity remains largely unclear.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Unlike the effect of retinoid receptors on RAREs, inhibition of AP-1 activity by retinoid receptors is independent of retinoid receptor-RARE interaction (8-10).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Previous studies suggested several possible mechanisms for AP-1 inhibition by retinoid receptors.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	24	 First, retinoid receptors are reported to physically interact with c-Jun and/or c-Fos (8, 9).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	25	 This interaction results in the mutual inhibition of their DNA binding and transactivation functions and could explain the cross-talk occurring between AP-1 and retinoid signaling.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	26	 However, a large excess of either retinoid receptor protein or c-Jun and c-Fos proteins was required to inhibit in vitro binding to the TRE or RARE, respectively (8, 9).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Because the in vivo footprint assay for glucocorticoid receptor and AP-1 interaction did not reveal any effect on DNA binding (30), whether RAR and AP-1 directly interact in vivo remains to be established.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Subsequently, it was suggested that blocking activation of the Jun N-terminal kinase signaling pathway that activates AP-1 might be responsible for AP-1 inhibition by retinoid and other nuclear receptors (31).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Although this mechanism may explain how retinoids inhibit AP-1 activity under some conditions, it does not address how mutual inhibition occurs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Recent results suggest that the molecular basis of receptor-mediated inhibition of AP-1 transcriptional activation might be due to competition for a common coactivator, such as the cAMP-response element-binding protein (CBP), which is required for transcriptional activation by both the AP-1 complex and RARs (32).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	31	 However, a domain of RAR capable of inhibiting AP-1 activity, such as the DNA-binding domain (33), does not interact with CBP (32).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The development of retinoids that specifically inhibit AP-1 activity without transactivating RARs (25, 26) also argues against the involvement of RAR coactivators in RARs-AP-1 cross-talk.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Thus, the availability of CBP is unlikely to be the sole modulator of RAR and AP-1-signaling pathways, and other adapter proteins may be involved in the antagonism of AP-1 activity by RARs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	34	Recent studies demonstrate that orphan receptor COUP-TF is involved in regulation retinoid responses (34, 35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	35	 COUP-TF is encoded by two distinct genes, COUP-TFI (EAR-3) (36, 37) and COUP-TFII (ARP-1) (38).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Both show exceptional homology and overlapping expression patterns, suggesting their redundant functions (39).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	37	 COUP-TF can modulate retinoid responses through either its high affinity binding to various RAREs or its heterodimerization with RXR (40-43).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	38	 We previously reported that COUP-TF expression was required for cancer cell growth inhibition by trans-RA (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	39	 We further demonstrated that the effect of COUP-TF is partly due to its induction of RAR that mediates growth inhibition by retinoids in various cancer cells (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	40	Cell Culture-- HeLa ovarian and MDA-MB231 breast cancer cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (FCS); Calu-6 lung cancer and HT-1376 bladder cancer cells were grown in MEM containing 10% FCS; and T-47D and ZR-75-1 breast cancer and H292 lung cancer cells were grown in RPMI-1460 medium with 10% FCS.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	41	Plasmid Construction-- CAT reporter constructs TRE-tk-CAT and 73Col-CAT have been described (8, 17, 22, 24), as have expression vectors for RAR, COUP-TF, c-Jun, and c-Fos (8, 17, 22, 24, 44).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	42	 pcDNA3-COUP-TFII C-terminal deletion mutants pcDNA3-COUP-TFII7, pcDNA3-COUP-TFII30, and pcDNA3-COUP-TFII108 were generated as described (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	43	 pcDNA3-COUP-TFII N-terminal deletion mutants were constructed by cloning PCR products from COUP-TFII into pcDNA3 (Stratagene) using the following forward primers: TATAGGTACCATGGCGCCGCCCGTGCCC for pcDNA3-COUP-TFIIN25; ATATGGTACCATGACGCCAGCCCAGACG for pcDNA3-COUP-TFIIN50; AATTGGTACCATGCACATCGAGTGCGTG for pcDNA3-COUP-TFIIN75; and ATTAGGTACCATGCACCATCGCAACCAG for pcDNA3COUPTFIIN125.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The oligonucleotide GTGGCAGTTGAGGGGATCC was used as the reverse primer for these mutants.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	45	Transient and Stable Transfection Assays-- HeLa cells (1  x  105 cells/well) were plated in 24-well plates for 16-24 h before transfection as described (34, 35, 45), and other cancer cells (5  x  105 cell/well) were seeded in six-well plates.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	46	 A modified calcium phosphate precipitation procedure was used for transient transfections (34, 35, 45).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Briefly, 200 ng of reporter plasmid, 100 ng of -galactosidase of expression vector (pCH 110; Amersham Biosciences), and various amounts of each expression vector were mixed with carrier DNA (pBluescript) to give 1000 ng of total DNA/well.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	48	 CAT activity was normalized for transfection efficiency to the responding -Gal activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	49	 For stable transfections, the pRC/CMV-COUP-TF recombinant was transfected into MDA-MB231 and HT-1376 cells by the calcium phosphate precipitation method, and the stable clones were screened with G418 (Invitrogen) as described (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Integration and expression of transfected cDNA were determined by Southern blotting and Northern blotting, respectively.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	51	Preparation of Receptor Proteins-- Receptor proteins for RAR, TR3, COUP-TF, and its mutants were synthesized by in vitro transcription-translation using rabbit reticulocyte lysates (Promega) as described previously (34).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Amounts of translated proteins were determined by [35S]methionine incorporation and SDS-PAGE with quantitation by incorporated radioactivity after normalization relative to methionine content.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	53	Gel Retardation Assay-- A fragment of the collagenase promoter region 73 to +63 containing one AP-1-binding site (TRE) was excised from a collagenase-CAT construct (8).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	54	 In addition, the AP-1 binding sequence 5'-GATCCGGATGAGTCACCA-3' was synthesized.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Two fragments were labeled with [32P]dCTP for use as probes for protein-DNA interaction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	56	 In vitro translated protein was incubated with the probe in a 20- microl reaction mixture containing 10 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	57	9, 50 mM KCl, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 2.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	58	5 mM MgCl2, 10% glycerol, and 1  microg of poly(dI-dC) at 25  degrees C for 15 min.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	59	 DNA-protein complexes were resolved on 5% nondenaturing polyacrylamide gels, and then gels were dried and analyzed by autoradiography.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	60	GST Pull-down Assay-- To prepare glutathione S-transferase (GST)-c-Jun or GST-c-Jun mutant fusion proteins, each c-Jun DNA or c-Jun mutant fragment was cloned in frame into the expression vector pGEX-3X (Amersham Biosciences).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Fusion proteins were expressed in bacteria using the manufacturer's procedure and analyzed by gel retardation assays and Western blotting (data not shown).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	62	 To determine the interaction between COUP-TF and c-Jun, the fusion proteins were immobilized on glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The vector protein (GST), prepared under the same conditions as a control, was also immobilized.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Beads were preincubated with bovine serum albumin (1 mg/ml) at room temperature for 5 min.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	65	 35S-labeled in vitro translated COUP-TF proteins (2-5  microl, depending on translation efficiency) were then added to the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The beads in 200  microl in EBC buffer (140 mM NaCl, 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	67	5% Nonidet P-40, 100 mM NaF, 200 mM sodium orthovanadate, and 50 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	68	0) were rocked continuously for 1 h at 4  degrees C.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	69	 After washing 5 times with NETN buffer (100 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 20 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	70	5% Nonidet P-40), bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	71	Correlation between COUP-TF Expression and Inhibition of AP-1 Activity by trans-RA-- We recently reported that expression of COUP-TF is required for growth inhibition and apoptosis induction by trans-RA in various cancer cells (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Since inhibition of AP-1 activity by retinoids is known to contribute to their anticancer effects, we studied whether COUP-TF expression was involved in the process.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The effect of trans-RA on inhibiting AP-1 activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	74	 1A) was evaluated in COUP-TF-positive T-47D and ZR-75-1 breast cancer and Calu-6 lung cancer cell lines and in COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231 breast cancer, H292 lung cancer, and HT-1376 bladder cancer cell lines (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	75	 AP-1 activity induced by TPA was determined by transient transfection using the reporter 73Col-CAT, which contains a TRE that binds AP-1 (8).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	76	 TPA-induced reporter activity was strongly inhibited in a trans-RA-dependent manner in the COUP-TF-positive ZR-75-1, T-47D, and Calu-6 cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In contrast, trans-RA showed very little effect on TPA-induced 73Col-CAT activity in the COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231, H292, and HT-1376 cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Thus, COUP-TF expression correlates positively with the ability of trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 transcriptional activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	79	View larger version (40K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	80	   COUP-TF expression and trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity correlate in cancer cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	81	 A, inhibition of TPA-induced collagenase promoter activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was transfected into the indicated cancer cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	83	 After transfection, the cells were incubated in DMEM medium containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	84	5% FCS for 24 h and treated with either TPA (100 ng/ml) alone or with the indicated concentrations of trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	85	 After 12 h, the cells were harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The activities of cotransfected -galactosidase were used as controls for transfection efficiency.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	87	 B, effect of COUP-TF expression in COUP-TF-negative cancer cell lines on inhibition of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was transfected with or without COUP-TF into COUP-TF-negative cancer cell lines (MDA-MB231, H292, and HT-1376).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Cells were incubated in medium (see "Experimental Procedures") containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	90	5% FCS for 24 h and then treated with either TPA (100 ng/ml) alone or with 106 M trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	91	 After 12 h, cells were harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The activities of cotransfected -galactosidase were used as reference values.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	93	Trans-RA-dependent and -independent Antagonism of AP-1 Activity by COUP-TF-- The positive association between COUP-TF expression and trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity suggested that COUP-TF was required for trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 activity and that the absence of COUP-TF expression in MDA-MB231, H292, and HT-1376 cells might be responsible for the lack of trans-RA activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Therefore, we transiently transfected the COUP-TF expression vector and the 73Col-CAT reporter into the COUP-TF-negative cell lines, in which trans-RA did not inhibit AP-1 transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Upon COUP-TF transfection, trans-RA inhibited TPA-induced reporter activity in both MDA-MB231 and H292 cells in a COUP-TF concentration-dependent manner.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Interestingly, COUP-TF transfection alone produced some inhibition of AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	97	 This observation suggested that COUP-TF inhibited AP-1 activity in both trans-RA-dependent and -independent manners in MDA-MB231 and H292 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	98	 When evaluated in HT-1376 cells, COUP-TF expression was able to inhibit AP-1 activity independently of trans-RA (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	99	 However, it failed to confer the ability of trans-RA to inhibit TPA-induced reporter activity, even at high transfection levels, suggesting that trans-RA-dependent inhibition of AP-1 activity by COUP-TF is impaired in this cell line.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	100	The above results suggested that COUP-TF alone inhibited AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	101	 We then examined the anti-AP-1 activity of COUP-TF in HeLa cells, in which TPA strongly induced the transcription of the transfected 73Col-CAT reporter.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Similar to that observed in other cancer cell lines (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	103	 1B), COUP-TFI cotransfection inhibited TPA-induced reporter activity in a COUP-TFI concentration-dependent manner (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Cotransfection of COUP-TFII produced almost identical results (data not shown).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Activation of collagenase promoter by TPA occurs mainly through induction of AP-1 activity that activates the TRE in the promoter (7).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	106	 We therefore examined whether COUP-TF expression also interfered with transactivation activity of c-Jun homodimer and c-Jun/c-Fos heterodimer.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Cotransfection of 73Col-CAT with the c-Jun expression vector into HeLa cells led to about 5-fold induction of reporter expression (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	108	 2B), presumably due to activation of the collagenase promoter by the c-Jun homodimer.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The c-Jun-induced 73Col-CAT reporter activity was repressed when COUP-TFI expression vector was cotransfected.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Similarly, 73Col-CAT reporter activity induced by c-Jun/c-Fos heterodimers was inhibited by COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	111	 To determine that inhibition of collagenase promoter activity by COUP-TF was mediated by the TRE, we evaluated how COUP-TFI affected the TRE-tk-CAT reporter, which has a TRE sequence fused to the thymidine kinase promoter (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Our result showed that cotransfection of COUP-TFI significantly inhibited c-Jun-induced TRE-tk-CAT activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	113	 These results clearly demonstrate that COUP-TF inhibits transcriptional activity of c-Jun homodimer and c-Jun/c-Fos heterodimer and that the inhibition of AP-1 activity by COUP-TF on the TRE is responsible for its antagonism of TPA activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	115	   Inhibition of AP-1 activity by COUP-TF.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	116	 A, inhibition of TPA-induced collagenase promoter activity by COUP-TF in HeLa cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was cotransfected without or with COUP-TFI expression vector (10, 20, or 50 ng) or the control pcDNA3 vector into cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	118	 After transfection, cells were incubated in DMEM medium containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	119	5% FCS for 24 h and then treated with or without TPA (100 ng/ml).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	120	 After 12 h, the cells were harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	121	 B, inhibition of c-Jun-induced 73Col-CAT and TRE-tk-CAT activity by COUP-TF in HeLa cells.
