0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	123	 After transfection, cells were incubated in DMEM medium containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	124	5% FCS for 24 h, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	125	 C, inhibition of c-Jun and c-Fos activities by COUP-TF in HeLa cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was cotransfected with/without c-Jun (50 ng) and/or c-Fos (50 ng) expression vectors either in the presence or absence of COUP-TFI or COUP-TFII expression vector (10, 20, and 50 ng) into HeLa cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The cells were then harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	128	Inhibition of c-Jun Binding to DNA by COUP-TF-- Inhibition of AP-1 activity by several nuclear receptors has been shown to be due to their inhibition of AP-1 binding to DNA (8, 9, 13-15, 17, 22, 47).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	129	 To study whether inhibition of AP-1 DNA binding by COUP-TF was involved in its inhibition of AP-1 activity, the purified collagenase promoter fragment was used as a probe in gel shift assays for binding of in vitro synthesized c-Jun protein in the absence or presence of COUP-TF protein (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	130	 c-Jun alone formed a strong complex with the promoter.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	131	 However, upon preincubation with COUP-TF protein, c-Jun binding was significantly inhibited.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The addition of COUP-TF protein did not show any new complex formed with the collagenase promoter, indicating that the inhibitory effect of COUP-TF is not due to its direct binding to the collagenase promoter.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	133	 We also studied the effect of COUP-TF on binding of c-Jun to the TRE.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Preincubation with COUP-TF protein similarly inhibited c-Jun binding to the TRE derived from the collagenase promoter (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	135	 As a comparison, preincubation of c-Jun with TR3 orphan receptor (34) that could not antagonize c-Jun transactivation (data not shown) did not inhibit c-Jun binding to the TRE.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	136	 This result demonstrated that the inhibitory effect of COUP-TF on c-Jun binding to the collagenase promoter is not due to regions other than the TRE in the promoter.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Next, we compared the inhibitory effect of COUP-TF with that of RAR that is known to repress AP-1 activity and inhibit c-Jun binding to TRE (8).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Whereas an equal amount of COUP-TF significantly inhibited c-Jun binding to the collagenase promoter, an equal amount of RAR did not show any detectable inhibition (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Inhibition of c-Jun binding required a 5-fold excess of RAR, similar to that observed before (8).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The addition of trans-RA did not enhance the inhibitory effect of RAR (Ref.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Together, these results demonstrate that the inhibition of c-Jun binding to the TRE contributes to its suppression of AP-1 transcriptional activity by COUP-TF and that COUP-TF is a more effective inhibitor than RAR.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	142	View larger version (44K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	143	   Inhibition of c-Jun binding to DNA by COUP-TF.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	144	 In vitro synthesized c-Jun was preincubated with the indicated molar excess of COUP-TF, RAR, or TR3.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Unprogrammed reticulocyte lysate was added to maintain an equal protein concentration in each reaction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Following preincubation, the reaction mixtures were incubated with 32P-labeled collagenase promoter (A) or the TRE (B) and analyzed by gel retardation.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The arrowhead indicates the c-Jun-binding complex.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	148	Interaction of c-Jun and COUP-TF-- Our observation that COUP-TF inhibits transactivation and DNA binding by c-Jun prompted us to examine whether COUP-TF and c-Jun interact directly using GST pull-down assay (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In vitro synthesized radiolabeled COUP-TFII was specifically pulled down by bacterially expressed GST-c-Jun hybrid protein but not by GST protein (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	150	 4B), demonstrating that COUP-TF and c-Jun interact in solution.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	151	 To identify the domain of COUP-TFII responsible for interacting with c-Jun, COUP-TFII deletion mutants (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	152	 4A) were constructed and analyzed on the 73Col-CAT reporter for antagonism of AP-1 activity in HeLa cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	153	 4A) and for their interaction with c-Jun using the GST pull-down assay (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Cotransfection of the c-Jun expression vector alone induced reporter transcription (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	155	 4A), whereas cotransfection with one of the C-terminal deletion mutants COUP-TFII7, COUP-TFII30, or COUP-TFII108 strongly inhibited c-Jun-induced reporter activity, as was observed using the wild-type COUP-TFII.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	156	 N-terminal domain deletion mutants, such as COUP-TFIIN25, COUP-TFIIN50, and COUP-TFIIN75, also retained the inhibitory effect on AP-1 activity by COUP-TFII.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	157	 In contrast, partial (COUP-TFIIN125) or complete deletion of the DNA-binding domain (COUP-TFIIDBD) abrogated anti-c-Jun activity completely.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	158	 In the GST pull-down assay, COUP-TFII mutants that effectively suppressed AP-1 activity, such as COUP-TFII7, COUP-TFII30, COUP-TFII108, COUP-TFIIN25, COUP-TFIIN50, and COUP-TFIIN75, were pulled down by GST-c-Jun protein, whereas COUP-TFIIDBD, which failed to suppress AP-1 activity, was not (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Thus, inhibition of AP-1 transcriptional activity by the COUP-TFII mutants correlated with their ability to interact with c-Jun.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	160	 These observations further suggest that a direct c-Jun/COUP-TF interaction accounts for the inhibition of AP-1 activity by COUP-TF and that the DBD of COUP-TF is essential.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (44K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	162	   Interaction of c-Jun and COUP-TF and their domain requirements.

0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	171	 B, interaction between c-Jun and COUP-TFs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	172	 c-Jun was synthesized in bacteria using pGEX-3X expression vector.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	173	 GST-c-Jun fusion protein was immobilized on the glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	174	 As a control, the same amount of glutathione S-transferase was also immobilized on the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	175	 In vitro translated 35S-labeled COUP-TF and its mutant proteins were then mixed with the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	176	 After extensive washing, the bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The input proteins are shown for comparison.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	178	We also identified the region of c-Jun required for COUP-TF interaction (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Deletion of amino acids 73-232 from c-Jun (c-JunAvaI) did not affect its ability to pull down COUP-TFII.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	180	 In contrast, deletion of the C-terminal domain of c-Jun from amino acid 191 to 331 (c-JunbZIP), which encompasses the leucine-zipper region and basic region, completely abolished its ability to pull down COUP-TFII.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Thus, the C-terminal domain, but not the N-terminal domain, of c-Jun is responsible for COUP-TF interaction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	182	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	183	   The domain of c-Jun required for interaction with COUP-TF.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	184	 A, schematic representation of c-Jun and its mutants.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The amino terminus (NH2), the basic region, the leucine zipper (bZIP), and the carboxyl terminus (C) are indicated.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	186	 B, interaction between COUP-TF and c-Jun mutants.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	187	 c-Jun and its mutant proteins were synthesized in bacteria using the pGEX-3X expression vector (Amersham Biosciences).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	188	 GST-c-Jun and the mutant fusion proteins (GST-c-JunAvaI and GST-c-JunbZIP) were immobilized on the glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	189	 As a control, the same amount of glutathione transferase was immobilized on the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	190	 In vitro translated 35S-labeled COUP-TFII was then mixed with the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	191	 After extensive washing, bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Input proteins are shown for comparison.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	193	Stable Expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231 Cells Restores the Ability of trans-RA to Inhibit AP-1 Activity-- To further examine the role of COUP-TF in trans-RA-induced inhibition of AP-1 activity, we analyzed the effect of trans-RA on TPA-induced c-Jun expression in MDA-MB231 breast cancer cells and MDA-MB231 cells stably transfected with COUP-TF (MB231/COUP#16) (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Treatment of both cell lines with TPA strongly induced c-Jun expression as determined by Northern blotting (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Induction of c-Jun expression by TPA was probably due to an AP-1-binding site in the c-Jun promoter (7).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Treatment with trans-RA did not affect basal c-Jun expression in both lines and did not inhibit TPA-induced c-Jun expression in MDA-MB231 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	197	 However, pretreatment of MB231/COUP#16 cells with trans-RA completely abolished TPA-induced c-Jun expression.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	198	 These results demonstrate that COUP-TF expression is required for inhibition of AP-1 activity in MDA-MB231 cells by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	199	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	200	   Stable expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative, RAR-positive MDA-MB231 cells restores the ability of trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Total RNAs prepared from MDA-MB-231 or MDA-MB231 cells stably expressing COUP-TF (MB231/COUP#16) (35) treated with or without the indicated agents were analyzed for the expression of c-Jun.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The expression of -actin is shown to confirm the similar loading of RNA in each lane.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	203	Stable Expression of COUP-TF Does Not Lead to trans-RA-dependent Inhibition of AP-1 Activity in HT-1376 Cells Lacking RAR/ Expression-- We also evaluated whether stable expression of COUP-TF affected TPA-induced c-Jun expression in HT-1376 bladder cancer cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The stable clone, HT-1376/COUP#7, which expresses high levels of COUP-TF, was analyzed for the effect of trans-RA on TPA activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	205	 About a 4-fold induction of c-Jun expression by TPA was observed in HT-1376 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	206	 However, the induction of c-Jun expression was largely reduced in HT-1376/COUP#7 cells, with only about a 2-fold induction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Interestingly, the basal level of c-Jun expression was also slightly reduced in HT-1376/COUP#7 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Despite the reduction of c-Jun expression in the absence or presence of TPA, trans-RA failed to inhibit basal and TPA-induced c-Jun expression in both wild-type and COUP-TF-expressing cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Thus, COUP-TF expression is not sufficient to confer trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity in HT-1376 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	210	View larger version (80K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	211	   Stable expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF and RAR-negative HT-1376 cells does not lead to trans-RA-dependent inhibition of AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Total RNAs prepared from HT-1376 or HT-1376 cells stably expressing COUP-TF (HT-1376/COUP 7) treated with or without the indicated agents were analyzed for the expression of c-Jun, RAR, and RAR.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	213	 The expression of -actin is shown to confirm similar loading of RNA in each lane.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	214	RAR Expression Is Required for COUP-TF to Facilitate Antagonism of AP-1 Activity by trans-RA-- Our observations that transient (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	215	 7) expression of COUP-TF in HT-1376 cells failed to modulate antagonism of AP-1 activity by trans-RA led us to investigate RAR expression.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Unlike MDA-MB231 cells that express RAR (48) and RAR when COUP-TF is expressed (35), HT-1376 cells did not express detectable RAR or RAR (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	217	 7), although RAR was expressed (data not shown).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	218	 This result suggested that modulation of trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity by COUP-TF might require RAR or RAR.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The effect of RAR expression on the ability of COUP-TF to regulate trans-RA activity was then examined using transient transfection in HT-1376 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was transfected into HT-1376 cells with or without c-Jun and COUP-TF and/or RAR vector.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Transfected cells were treated with or without trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	222	 8A, transfected COUP-TF repressed AP-1 activity in the absence of trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	223	 In contrast, transfected RAR (10 ng) led to inhibition of AP-1 activity in a trans-RA dependent manner.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The addition of COUP-TF significantly enhanced the trans-RA-induced inhibition of AP-1 activity by RAR (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Similar results were observed using HeLa cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Thus, efficient inhibition of AP-1 activity by trans-RA activity by COUP-TF requires both COUP-TF and RAR.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	227	Retinoids are effective growth inhibitors of cancer cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Inhibition of AP-1 activity has been proposed as one mechanism by which retinoids exert their anticancer effects (6).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Despite extensive studies in the last few years, how retinoids specifically antagonize AP-1 activity remains largely unknown.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Here, we provide evidence that COUP-TF is involved in regulating the antagonism of AP-1 transactivational activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	231	 COUP-TF, by physically interacting with c-Jun, inhibits AP-1 DNA binding and transactivation and is required for efficient inhibition of AP-1 activity by liganded RARs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Our results suggest that COUP-TF plays a role in the cross-talk between retinoid and AP-1 signaling pathways.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	233	We recently reported that the expression of COUP-TF positively correlates with the inhibition of the growth of various cancer cell lines by trans-RA and that COUP-TF is underexpressed in many trans-RA-resistant cancer cell lines (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Stable expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative cancer cells restores their sensitivity to trans-RA, demonstrating that COUP-TF can mediate anticancer effects of trans-RA (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	235	 By studying anti-AP-1 activity of trans-RA in various cancer cell lines, we found a close correlation between COUP-TF expression and the anti-AP-1 activity of trans-RA (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In COUP-TF-positive ZR-75-1, T-47D, and Calu-6 cancer cell lines (35), trans-RA strongly inhibited the ability of TPA to activate transcription of the collagenase promoter, whereas in COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231, H292, and HT-1376 cell lines, trans-RA failed to suppress TPA activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	237	 This finding is consistent with a previous study showing that trans-RA effectively inhibited AP-1 activity in ZR-75-1 and T-47D cells but not in MDA-MB231 cells (49).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The requirement of COUP-TF in trans-RA-mediated AP-1 inhibition was further demonstrated by our findings that transient expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	239	 1B) restored the ability of trans-RA to inhibit TPA-induced AP-1 transactivation and that stable expression of COUP-TF in MBA-MB231 cells enabled trans-RA to inhibit TPA-induced c-Jun expression (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	240	We have reported that COUP-TF expression contributes to growth inhibition by trans-RA in cancer cells because COUP-TF on binding to the RAR promoter induces RAR expression (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	241	 RAR is reported to be a potent AP-1 inhibitor (24), suggesting that COUP-TF-induced RAR probably contributes to the inhibition of AP-1 activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Our observations that COUP-TF can effectively interact with c-Jun in vitro (Figs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	243	 3 and 4) and inhibit AP-1 transcriptional activity on transient transfection (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	244	 2) also suggest that COUP-TF is directly involved in antagonizing AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	245	Inhibition of AP-1 activity appears to be a common characteristic of nuclear receptors, as has been demonstrated for the progesterone, estrogen, androgen, thyroid hormone, glucocorticoid, and retinoid receptors, which can functionally interact with the AP-1 complex.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	246	 This study reveals that the orphan receptor COUP-TF behaves similarly.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The molecular basis of the interaction between nuclear receptors and AP-1 pathways remains largely unknown.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Models proposed include direct protein-protein interaction (8, 9, 13-15), inhibition of Jun N-terminal kinase activity (31), and competition for CBP (32).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Our results of GST pull-down assays (Figs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	250	 4B and 5) and mutation analysis (Figs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	251	 4 and 5) support the first model.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The requirement for the COUP-TF DBD for c-Jun binding is similar to observations that the DBDs of glucocorticoid receptor (14, 15) and RAR (47) are essential for their interaction with AP-1.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Interestingly, the in vitro DNA-binding study showed that COUP-TF is a more effective inhibitor of AP-1 binding than RAR (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	254	 3) on the basis of the levels of each receptor to exert this effect.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	255	In contrast to inhibition of AP-1 activity by other receptors that require their respective ligands, COUP-TF effectively inhibited AP-1 transactivation in the absence of any ligand (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Such a ligand-independent inhibition of AP-1 activity may restrict expression levels of AP-1-responsive genes in cancer cells (Figs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Interestingly, we observed that COUP-TF expression potentiates antagonism of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	258	 However, regulation of trans-RA activity by COUP-TF appears to require RAR or RAR, because transiently transfected COUP-TF was unable to confer anti-AP-1 activity to trans-RA in HT-1376 cells lacking RAR or - (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	259	 8B) unless RAR was cotransfected.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	260	 In addition, stable expression of COUP-TF restored trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity in MDA-MB231 cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	261	 6) having RARs (48) but not in HT-1376 cells lacking RAR and - (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Thus, expression of both RAR/ and COUP-TF is required for optimal inhibition of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Dawson for reviewing the manuscript.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	264	* This work is supported in part by grants from the National Institutes of Health and the United States Army Medical Research and Material Command (to X.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	265	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	266	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	268	To whom correspondence should be addressed: Burnham Institute, Cancer Center, 10901 North Torrey Pines Rd.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	269	: 858-646-3141; Fax: 858-646-3195; E-mail: xzhang@burnham.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	270	Published, JBC Papers in Press, April 4, 2002, DOI 10.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	271	The abbreviations used are: RAR, retinoic acid receptor; RXR, retinoid X receptor; RA, retinoic acid; RARE, RA response element; TPA, 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate; TRE, TPA response element; CBP, cAMP-response element-binding protein; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; FCS, fetal calf serum; GST, glutathione S-transferase.

0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	275	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS  All ASBMB Journals   Molecular and Cellular Proteomics   Journal of Lipid Research   Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Education  Copyright   2002 by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	0	Suppression of Hepatitis B Virus Core Promoter by the Nuclear Orphan Receptor TR4* Wen-Jye Lin , Jie Li  , Yi-Fen Lee, Shauh-Der Yeh, Saleh Altuwaijri, Jing-Hsiung Ou , and Chawnshang Chang.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the  George Whipple Lab for Cancer Research, Departments of Pathology, Urology, Radiation Oncology, and the Cancer Center, University of Rochester Medical Center, Rochester, New York 14642 and the   Department of Molecular Microbiology and Immunology, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, California 90033.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, June 14, 2002, and in revised form, January 8, 2003.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	3	Hepatitis B virus (HBV)1 is a small virus with a 3.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	4	2-kb partially double-stranded DNA genome, containing four open reading frames: the surface antigen, the core antigen, the polymerase, and the X protein (1, 2).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	5	 HBV is a major pathogen causing acute and chronic liver diseases, such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (3, 4).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	6	 HBV transcripts are regulated by the transcriptional control of four different promoters and two enhancer elements (5).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	7	 HBV is replicated from a RNA intermediate as a template for reverse transcription (1).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The core promoter controls the expression of the 3.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	9	5-kb core mRNA (C mRNA) as the template for replication, and the expression of the pre-core mRNA (pre-C mRNA) for the translation of the HBeAg precursor (6).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Recently, multiple binding sites for liver-specific or ubiquitous transcription factors and several hormone response elements (HRE) have been identified in the core promoter region, including Sp1 (7, 8), TATA-binding protein (9), HNF3 (10), HNF4 (11), C/EBP (12), and other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, such as the retinoid X receptor (RXR), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR), COUP-TF1, and ARP1 (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	11	 For example, HNF4 and RXR/PPAR can stimulate the expression of the 3.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	12	5-kb core RNA, COUP-TF1 suppresses the expression of both the pre-C RNA and C RNA, and TR2 preferentially represses the expression of the pre-C RNA (14).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These findings suggest that these nuclear receptors may play important roles in viral transcription.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The detailed mechanisms of how the core promoter is differentially regulated by these nuclear receptors remain unclear.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	15	The testicular orphan receptor 4 (TR4) (NR2C2) is an orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily (15-17).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	16	 This family includes classic steroid hormone receptors, the thyroid hormone receptor, the retinoid receptors, and many nuclear orphan receptors whose physiological ligands have not been identified (18).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Members of this superfamily typically contain two major conserved domains, the DNA-binding domain (DBD) and the ligand-binding domain (LBD) (18).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Most nuclear receptors bind to their cognate ligands, translocate into the nucleus, and bind to the specific HREs to turn on their downstream target genes.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	19	 TR4 was isolated from human prostate and testis cDNA libraries and is considered to be an orphan receptor, because its ligand has not been found (15).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Our previous data showed that TR4 recognizes different AGGTCA direct repeat (DR) sequences either inducing or suppressing its target genes.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	21	 For example, TR4 induces reporters containing the DR1 site of human ciliary neurotrophic factor  receptor promoter and the DR4 site of the -myosin heavy chain promoter (19, 20).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In contrast, TR4 suppresses RXR/retinoic acid receptor (DR1), vitamin D3 receptor (DR3), and RXR/PPAR (DR1)-mediated transactivation as shown by the reporter assay (21-23).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These results suggest that TR4 may act as a negative regulator of its target genes containing hormone response elements (HREs) by competition with other nuclear receptors for binding to the HREs (21, 23).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In addition, our previous data showed that TR4 could also suppress androgen receptor-mediated transactivation via protein-protein interaction (22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	25	The distribution of TR4 expression is ubiquitous in many tissues, including the central nervous system, adrenal gland, spleen, thyroid gland, and liver (16, 19, 23).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Also, there are many other nuclear receptors expressed in the liver, such as HNF4 (24) and RXR/PPAR (25, 26).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	27	 These findings suggest that these nuclear receptors in the liver can coordinately regulate gene expression by interacting with HRE sequences in the promoters of their target genes.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Our data show that TR4 can interfere with a number of other nuclear receptors by competing for binding to the same HREs (21, 22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	29	Plasmids-- The plasmids CpFL(4)LUC, CpLUC, XpHNF4LUC, and CpM2LUC were gifts from Dr.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	30	 McLachlan (The Scripps Research Institute) and were described previously (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The plasmid pCDNAI-HNF4 was a gift from Dr.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Hadzopoulou-Cladaras (Boston University, Boston, MA).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Guan (University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The pCMX-TR4, pET14b-TR4, pSG5-VDR, and pCMV-TR2 plasmids were constructed as described previously (27, 28).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	35	 pWTDHBV contains the head-to-tail dimer of the wild type HBV genome DNA (adw2) (8).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The GST-TR4, TR4-N-DBD, and TR4-LBD fusion constructs were described in our previous study (29).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The GAL4-HNF4 expression plasmid for one-hybrid assay was made by inserting the PCR-generated BamHI/XbaI fragment (amino acids 1-465) of HNF4 from pCDNAI-HNF4 into pM containing the GAL4 DBD-(1-147) (Invitrogen).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	38	Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay-- The EMSA reaction was performed as described previously (20).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Briefly, TR4 and HNF4 proteins for EMSA were transcribed and translated in TNT reticulocyte lysates (Promega), according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The oligonucleotide probes for EMSA were end-labeled with [-32P]ATP by T4 polynucleotide kinase (New England BioLabs).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	41	 HepG2 cell nuclear extracts were prepared according to the procedure of Andrew and Faller (30).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The EMSA reactions were performed with 10  microg of nuclear extracts or 2  microl of TNT lysates in an EMSA buffer containing 10 mM Hepes (pH 7.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	43	9), 6% (v/v) glycerol, 2% (v/v) Ficoll, 100 mM KCl, 0.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	44	5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM dithiothreitol.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The reaction mixtures of the proteins and DNA were incubated for 15 min at room temperature.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	46	 For the antibody supershift assay, the mixtures were incubated for another 15 min in the presence or absence of mouse anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody (#15).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The protein DNA complexes were analyzed on a 5% native polyacrylamide gel.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	48	Cell Culture, Transfections, and Luciferase Assays-- HepG2 cells, Huh7 (human differentiated hepatoma cells), H1299 cells, or HepG2.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	49	1 cells (human de-differentiated hepatoma cells) were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium or RPMI supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 2 mM glutamine, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100  microg/ml streptomycin (31).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The cells were plated at 105/well in 12-well dishes (Falcon) and transfected with 1.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	51	2  microg of DNA/well using SuperFect according to the manufacturer's protocol (Qiagen).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The internal control plasmid pRL-TK (Promega) was co-transfected in all transfection experiments.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	53	 After 48 h of transfection, the cells were harvested, and luciferase assays were performed using the Dual-Luciferase kit (Promega).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The HBV transfection experiment was carried out as described previously (8).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	55	Primer Extension Assay-- The primer to map the C gene transcripts was 5'-GGTGAGCAATGCTCAGGAGACTCTAAGG-3', which corresponds to coordinates 2024-2051 of the HBV genomic sequence.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The reaction was performed as previously described (32).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Briefly, The HBV DNA pWTD containing the wild type HBV genome (adw2) was co-transfected with the nuclear receptors into Huh7 hepatoma cells using the calcium phosphate precipitation method.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The pXGH vector served as an internal control for the normalization of transfection efficiency.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	59	 After 48 h of transfection, the RNA was isolated for the primer extension assay (32).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	60	GST Pull-down Assay-- The GST-TR4 fusion protein and GST protein were purified by glutathione-Sepharose beads according to the manufacturer's instructions (Amersham Biosciences).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	61	 HNF4 was synthesized using the in vitro TNT translation system (Promega) in the presence of [35S]methionine, and 5  microl of HNF4 protein was incubated with GST-TR4, TR4-N-DBD, TR4-LBD, or GST beads for the GST pull-down assay as described previously (22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	62	TR4 Protein Binds Specifically to the TR4RE-HBV Consensus Site of the HBV Core Promoter-- Previous studies showed that the activity of the HBV core promoter could be differentially regulated by RXR or PPAR via recognizing consensus binding sites on the HBV core promoter (13, 14).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Our previous data also showed that the TR4 has a better affinity than RXR to recognize the DR1-HRE in the promoter of the cellular retinol-binding protein II gene (21).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	64	 To examine whether TR4 can bind to the potential DR1-HRE (named TR4RE-HBV, nucleotide coordinates 1751-1778 of the HBV ayw DNA sequence) on the HBV core promoter (13), the electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) was performed with in vitro translated TR4 protein, using radiolabeled TR4RE-HBV oligonucleotides as probes.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	65	 1, no specific supershift complex was seen with an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody when using mock lysates (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	66	 In contrast, the TR4-CpFL supershift complex was observed in the presence of an anti-TR4 antibody using in vitro translated TR4 lysates (lanes 3 and 4).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Moreover, when we replaced wild type TR4RE-HBV with various mutants, we found that TR4 could only bind specifically to the wild type TR4RE-HBV, but not to other mutated TR4RE-HBVs, except for the M3 mutant, which has marginal binding (lanes 5-10).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The M1 double mutant with nucleotides changed from A to T (1765) and G to A (1767) represents the HBV mutant frequently found in the patients with chronic hepatitis (33).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	69	 TR4 was not able to bind to the M1 and M2 mutants (lanes 5 and 6), indicating that the second mutated nucleotide of the DR1-AGGTCA motif is essential for TR4 binding to the TR4RE-HBV.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	70	 In addition, a TR4-specific antibody can supershift the TR4 TR4RE-HBV complex (lane 4), and this binding can be reduced in the presence of 100-fold unlabeled TR4RE-HBV probe but not the probe with an androgen response element probes or TR4RE-HBV mutant probes (lanes 11-15), suggesting that the binding between TR4 and TR4RE-HBV is specific.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	71	View larger version (65K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	72	   TR4 binds to the CpFL element of the HBV core promoter in vitro.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	73	 TR4 proteins were in vitro synthesized in TNT reticulocyte lysates (Promega) and then incubated with CpFL or CpFL mutant probes for 30 min in the presence or absence of an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody or various 100-fold unlabeled probes as indicated.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The reaction mixtures were resolved on a 5% acrylamide native gel, and results were visualized by autoradiography.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	75	 ARE denotes the androgen response element.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	76	To further examine whether endogenous TR4 protein can interact with the TR4RE-HBV, nuclear extracts isolated from human HepG2 cells were used in the same EMSA.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	77	 2, no supershift complex was seen when the nuclear extracts were incubated with the double-mutant M1 probe in the presence of an anti-TR4 antibody (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The wild type TR4RE-HBV probe clearly binds with TR4 as indicated by the TR4 TR4RE-HBV antibody supershift complex (lanes 3 and 4).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	79	 This result shows that TR4 protein is present in liver cells and interacts with TR4RE-HBV, suggesting that this interaction may play a role in regulating HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	80	View larger version (34K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	81	   The nuclear orphan receptor TR4 is an endogenous DR-1 binding protein in HepG2 cells.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The CpFL probe containing the DR-1 site (nucleotide coordinates 1751-1780) or the M1 mutant probe were incubated with 10  microg of protein of nuclear extracts isolated from HepG2 cells.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The EMSA reaction was carried out at room temperature for 30 min in the presence or absence of anti-TR4 or anti-HNF4 antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The reaction complexes were analyzed on 5% acrylamide with 0.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	85	25 x  TBE gels, and the results were visualized by autoradiography.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	86	TR4 Enhances the Activity of a Luciferase Reporter Linked to TR4RE-HBV in Liver HepG2 and Non-liver H1299 Cells-- Our previous data showed that the DR1 consensus sequence (RXRE) from the promoter of cellular retinol-binding protein II could be recognized and suppressed by TR4 (21).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	87	 We were interested in determining whether the binding of TR4 to the TR4RE-HBV could also allow TR4 to regulate HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	88	 A reporter construct containing four synthetic copies of the TR4RE-HBV, CpFL(4)Luc, including the HNF4 consensus binding site, was used to determine the role of TR4 (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	89	 CpFL(4) plasmids were co-transfected with either the parental vector or a TR4 expression vector in liver HepG2, HepG2.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	90	 TR4 can transactivate CpFL(4)Luc activity in a dose-dependent fashion in HepG2, HepG2.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	91	 To confirm that the increase in reporter activity is not due to nonspecific activation by TR4, we also used the TR4 deletion mutants and VDR in this reporter assay.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	92	 3 (A-C) the activity of the reporter was only induced in the presence of full-length functional TR4, but not in VDR or the presence of TR4 mutants lacking the C terminus or N terminus, suggesting that the CpFL (TR4RE-HBV) elements of the core HBV promoter may be sufficient for TR4 to regulate HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	93	View larger version (25K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	94	   Effects of TR4 on a reporter containing the CpFL(DR1) element of the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	95	 A, HepG2 cells were co-transfected with 500 ng of CpFL(4)Luc reporter and increasing amounts of TR4 or VDR (100, 200, and 400 ng).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The cells with VDR transfection were treated with 100 nM vitamin D for 24 h, then harvested for the luciferase assay.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The luciferase assay was performed as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	98	1 cells were transfected with CpFL(4)Luc and TR4 or VDR, treated, and harvested as in A.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	99	 C and D, HepG2 cells and H1299 cells were co-transfected with CpFL(4)-Luc and the full-length TR4, N/C-terminal deletion of TR4 (TR4/delN and TR4/delC).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The reporter assay was carried out as described in A.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Data represent the means  plus or minus  S.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	102	 of three independent experiments.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	103	TR4 Directly Suppresses HBV Core Promoter Activity through the TR4RE-HBV Site-- The EMSA and reporter assay with CpFL(4)Luc suggest that TR4 may have a significant role in the transcriptional regulation of the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	104	 However, the functional role of TR4 in a synthetic promoter context does not necessarily reveal TR4 action in the natural HBV core promoter context.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	105	 We therefore examined the effects of TR4 on a reporter construct containing the whole context of the HBV genome sequence (CpLuc) (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Unexpectedly, TR4 suppressed CpLuc reporter activity in HepG2 cells (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	107	 In contrast, co-transfection of another nuclear receptor, HNF4, induced CpLuc reporter activity, consistent with an earlier report (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	108	 To confirm that the suppression was mediated by TR4 through binding to the TR4RE-HBV of the HBV core promoter, we also used CpM2Luc containing the mutated TR4RE-HBV to analyze TR4 suppression (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	109	 4B, TR4 suppression of the reporter activity was abolished by mutation of the TR4RE-HBV site.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	110	 In contrast, HNF4 was able to induce mutant CpM2Luc reporter activity, possibly due to the presence of another functionally intact HNF4-binding site (lane 4 versus 6) (13, 34).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	111	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	112	   TR4 represses HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	113	 A, HepG2 cells were co-transfected with 750 ng of CpLuc and 250 ng of TR4 or HNF4 vectors or the combination of these two nuclear receptors.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The luciferase activity was measured 48 h after the transfection.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	115	 B, the reporters CpLuc (750 ng) or CpM2Luc were co-transfected with TR4 (250 ng) or HNF4 (250 ng) as indicated, then harvested for the luciferase activity 48 h after the transfection.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Data represent the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	117	 of three independent experiments.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	118	 PSp, Sp, Xp, and Cp represent the promoters of the genes encoding the HBV surface antigen, X protein, and core/e antigens, respectively.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	119	Because the responsiveness of the HBV core promoter to TR4 was abrogated by this mutation, it is possible that the TR4-mediated suppression of the HBV core promoter is mainly dependent upon the binding between TR4 and the TR4RE-HBV.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Because earlier reports and our current data show that both TR4 and HNF4 can bind to the TR4RE-HBV site, which is overlapped with the HNF4 consensus binding site (13), we postulated that TR4 may exert its repressive effects on the core promoter through competition with other nuclear receptors such as HNF4 for binding to TR4RE-HBV.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	121	 We therefore examined their potential mutual influence on the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	122	 When we co-transfected equal amounts of HNF4 and TR4 with the CpLuc reporter in HepG2 hepatoma cells, TR4 repressed HNF4-induced HBV core promoter activity (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	123	 4A, column 3 versus 4), suggesting that HNF4 and TR4 may compete for the same consensus binding site on the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Similar suppression of HNF4-mediated transactivation also occurred when we used another reporter containing the HNF4 binding site found in the HBV enhancer I/X promoter overlapped with enhancer I (XpHNF4Luc, HBV coordinates 1133-1159, data not shown) (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	125	Using EMSA with in vitro translated TR4 and HNF4 in the presence of [32P]TR4RE-HBV, we also found that the binding between [32P]TR4RE-HBV and TR4 protein was suppressed by the addition of HNF4 (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	126	 5 demonstrates that TR4 and HNF4 can both bind to the TR4RE-HBV site, and the DNA binding activity of TR4 was markedly reduced in the presence of HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In contrast, we did not observe any change in HNF4 binding when we added TR4, implying that the simple competition may not fully account for TR4-mediated repression of HNF4 function.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	128	 This raises the possibility that TR4 may directly block HNF4 transactivation through protein-protein interactions with HNF4 instead of competing for DNA binding sites.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	129	 4 and 5 suggest that TR4 can bind to the same TR4RE-HBV site as well as interact with HNF4 to influence HBV core promoter expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	130	View larger version (57K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	131	   HNF4 suppresses TR4 binding to the CpFL element of the HBV core promoter in vitro.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	132	 TR4 and HNF4 proteins were in vitro synthesized in TNT reticulocyte lysates (Promega).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	133	 1  microl of TR4 protein was then incubated with CpFL probes for 15 min in EMSA reaction buffer (10 mM Hepes, pH 7.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	134	9/6% (v/v) glycerol, 2% (v/v) Ficoll, 100 mM KCl, 0.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	135	5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM dithiothreitol) in the presence or absence of the HNF4 protein.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The reaction mixtures were resolved on a 5% acrylamide native gel, and results were visualized by autoradiography.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The double asterisks indicate that the repression of TR4 DNA by HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	138	Interaction between HNF4 and TR4-- The data shown above suggest that TR4 may regulate the transcriptional activity of HNF4 by a mechanism that is independent from the competition for DNA binding.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	139	 To prove this hypothesis, we constructed a plasmid encoding GAL4-HNF4 fusion protein and examined the effect of TR4 expression on HNF4-mediated transactivation in the GAL4 one-hybrid system (35).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	140	 In this assay, the transcriptional activity of GAL4-HNF4 is independent of the binding of HNF4 and TR4 to their cognate binding site, DR1-HRE.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	141	 If TR4 can directly regulate HNF4 transcriptional activity, we should see the activity of GAL4-HNF4 would be significantly changed in the presence of TR4 expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	142	 HepG2 cells were co-transfected with GAL4-HN4 and the pG4LUC reporter in the presence or absence of the expression of the TR4 N- or C-terminal deletion of TR4 mutants.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	143	 6A, the reporter activity with GAL-HNF4 alone was increased about 3-fold, which was similarly shown by the previous study (35).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Interestingly, the expression of TR4 significantly increased the GAL4-HNF4-mediated transcriptional activation (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	145	 6A), indicating that TR4 can directly regulate the transcriptional activity of HNF4, which is independent of the event of the DNA binding and possibly mediated by protein-protein interactions.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	146	 As expected, the PG4LUC reporter activity with the GAL4 and TR4 was not increased at any significant level (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	147	 6A, columns 1 versus 6), suggesting TR4 influences HNF4 transcriptional activity in a specific manner.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Nevertheless, it is not clear how this regulation involving the interaction between TR4 and HNF4 would result in either activation or suppression of HNF4 function.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In contrast, the N- or C-terminal deletion of TR4 mutants did not show any effects on the GAL4-HNF4-mediated transactivation, suggesting that these two regions of TR4 protein may be required for TR4 action in this regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	150	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	151	   Interaction between TR4 and HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	152	 A, diagrammatic representation of the GAL4 hybrid assay.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	153	 This assay was used to test the effect of TR4 on HNF4-mediated transcriptional activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	154	 HepG2 cells were co-transfected PG4LUC, which contains four tandem repeats of the GAL4-binding sites, with GAL4-HNF4, TR4, or TR4 deletion mutants.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	155	 B, in vitro synthesized [35S]methionine-labeled HNF4 protein was incubated with GST, GST-TR4, GST-TR4-N-DBD, and GST-TR4-LBD fusion protein bound to glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The beads were extensively washed after the reaction and applied to 12% SDS-PAGE followed by autoradiography.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	157	 C, COS1 cells were transfected pCMX-TR4 with either parental vector or pCDNAI-HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	158	 After the transfection, the cells were cultured for 48 h, lysed for the immunoprecipitation assay, and the HNF4 signal was detected by Western blotting with a goat anti-HNF4 antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The results were visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Then, the same blot was stripped and blotted with an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	161	 D, HepG2 cells were transfected CpLUC with HNF4, TR4, or TR4 deletion mutants as described in Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	162	Next, we hypothesized that TR4 may directly regulate HNF4 transcriptional activity through interacting with HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	163	 To test this hypothesis, we applied the GST pull-down assay to determine the potential interaction between HNF4 and TR4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	164	 6B, HNF4 protein was pulled down and detected by SDS-PAGE from the mixture of 35S-labeled in vitro translated HNF4 protein incubated with GST-TR4, GST-TR4-N-DBD, or GST-TR4-LBD fusion protein immobilized on glutathione-linked Sepharose beads.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	165	 6B (lane 3) clearly demonstrated that HNF4 interacts with TR4 in vitro.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	166	 However, the interaction of the deletion mutants of GST-TR4 fusion protein with HNF4 is much weaker, suggesting that instead of direct competition for binding to the TR4RE-HBV, TR4 may interact with HNF4, which could possibly result in the repression of HNF4 function.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	167	 To further confirm this interaction in liver cells, we co-transfected TR4 and HNF4 into COS1 cells and used a co-immunoprecipitation assay to immunoprecipitate the TR4 and HNF4 complex by an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	168	 6C (lane 4), we can clearly observe HNF4 bands in the precipitated complex by Western blotting when co-expressing TR4 and HNF4 proteins in COS1 cells.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	169	 This result suggests that TR4 can bind to HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	170	In summary, the results presented above demonstrate that TR4 is capable of regulating HNF4 transcriptional activity by interacting with HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Also, the full-length of TR4 is essential for this regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	172	 We further compared the effects of TR4 on HNF4-mediated transactivation on the CpLUC reporter with deletion mutants of TR4 in HepG2 cells using transient transfection assay (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	173	 As expected and similar to the result shown in Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	174	 4A, TR4 suppresses HNF4-mediated transactivation (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	175	 However, the N- or C-terminal deletion of TR4 did not exhibit similarly suppressive effects as those of the full-length TR4 did (column 4 versus 7 and 8), implying that these two domains are essential in the protein-protein interaction of TR4 and HNF4, and this interaction is required for the repressive action of TR4 on the transcriptional activity of HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	176	Suppression of HBV Pre-core and Core mRNA Expression by TR4-- To further confirm the suppression of HBV core promoter activity by TR4, we applied a primer extension assay to see if TR4 can also influence mRNA expression of two HBV transcripts from the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The first transcript is pre-C mRNA, which is the precursor of HBeAg; the other transcript is C mRNA, serving as the template for reverse transcription (6, 36).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	178	 HBV RNA extracted from Huh-7 after the co-transfection of TR4 and HBV vectors was mapped with radiolabeled HBV primer at position 2024-2051 of the HBV genome (8).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	179	 7, the expression of both pre-C and C mRNAs was decreased in the presence of TR4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	180	 This result therefore confirms the reporter assays showing that TR4 can suppress HBV core promoter transcription via binding to the TR4RE-HBV site on the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	181	Earlier studies have identified two consensus DR1 binding sites for nuclear receptors in the HBV promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	182	 One such site (TGAACCTTTACCC, nucleotide coordinates 1138-1150), is located in the core domain of enhancer I and is recognized by HNF4, COUP-TF1, and RXR-PPAR (37).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The other site (AGGTTAAAGGTCT, nucleotide coordinates 1757-1769) is located in the core promoter that can be recognized by HNF4 and TR4 as described in current studies (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The detailed mechanisms of how these nuclear receptors modulate HBV gene expression via these two DR1 sites remain unclear.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Our data strongly suggest that TR4 preferentially binds the DR1 site of the core promoter, because TR4 suppression is abrogated if this site is mutated (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The selective binding of TR4 to the 2nd DR1 site may be a key step for TR4 to prevent other nuclear receptors from binding to this site, thereby repressing transcription.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	187	 However, we cannot rule out the possibility that TR4 may also regulate HBV gene expression through the DR1 site of enhancer I, because our data indicate that TR4 can recognize this site (data not shown).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Moreover, because TR4 binding to the 2nd DR1 site is prevented by two mutations ((1756 (A to T) and 1767 (G to A)), which are frequently found in patients with chronic hepatitis, one may speculate that HBV may utilize these two mutations to escape suppression mediated by TR4 and/or other transcriptional repressors.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Alternatively, creation of new mutations at these consensus DR1 sites may be able to increase the opportunity for other modulators to regulate HBV expression via these mutated DR1 sites (32).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	190	TR4 is highly homologous with another orphan receptor, TR2 (15).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Earlier studies indicated that TR2 and TR4 could modulate the expression of a set of genes through binding to the same HREs (19, 38).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	192	 (14) reported that TR2 could only repress pre-C RNA, but not C RNA expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Our current data show that TR4 can repress both pre-C RNA and C RNA expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Moreover, compared with the marginal suppression of TR2 on CpLuc reporter activity, TR4 has a much stronger suppressive effect on CpLuc reporter activity (data not shown), suggesting that TR4 may play a significant role in this regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Also, our data suggest that simple competition for binding to the DR1 site by these two nuclear receptors may not fully account for their distinct regulation of HBV core gene expression, because both nuclear receptors regulate target genes through binding to the DR sites (19, 38).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	196	 The detailed mechanisms underlying the distinct regulation of HBV gene expression by these two closely related orphan receptors remain unclear.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The interaction of TR4 and HNF4 suggests that the TR4 affects HBV gene expression at multiple levels, most importantly, including the DNA binding and protein-protein interactions.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Nevertheless, previous reports also suggested that COUP-TF could differentially modulate target gene expression via similar HREs.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	199	 For example, COUP-TF1 can induce the 7-hydroxylase promoter activity via the DR4 binding site and repress myosin heavy chain promoter activity via a similar DR4 binding site (39).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Similar differential modulation of target gene expression also occurred with TR4, via binding to similar DR1 binding sites (21, 23).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	201	The contrasting effects of TR4 on the synthetic TR4RE-HBV versus the entire HBV promoter (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	202	 3 versus 4) suggest that promoter context, especially sequences other than the TR4RE-HBV, may also play important roles for TR4 to modulate HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	203	 It is possible that sequences flanking the TR4RE-HBV may recruit one or more repressors that can cooperate with TR4 to form a protein complex to repress HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In addition, we have examined the effects of TR4 on HBV core promoter activity in non-liver cells and found that TR4 was able to induce the luciferase activity of the Cpluc reporter in H1299 cells (data not shown).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	205	 This interesting finding implies that some cellular factors in liver cells may modulate the transcriptional activity of TR4 in the regulation of the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	206	 However, the detailed mechanisms of this distinct regulation by TR4 remain unclear.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	207	TR4 may modulate its target gene expression via two distinct mechanisms.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	208	 First, TR4 can suppress target gene expression via competition with other nuclear receptors, such as RXR (DR1), VDR (DR3), and retinoic acid receptor  (DR5), for the same consensus HRE sites (21, 22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Previous studies showed that ligand-activated RXR/PPAR or PPAR can increase HBV core promoter activity through the TR4RE-HBV site (DR1) (13, 14).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Therefore, it appears that TR4 may compete for the same binding site with these nuclear receptors resulting in repression of HBV core promoter activity, which this regulation does not involve in any interaction between TR4 and other nuclear receptors (21, 22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Second, TR4 can also modulate gene expression via protein-protein interactions with other nuclear receptors.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	212	 For example, TR4 can suppress androgen target genes through interactions with the androgen receptor (40).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	213	 In the current study, we found TR4 cannot only bind to the same DR1 site on HBV core promoter as HNF4 (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	214	 5), but also interact with HNF4 (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The TR4-mediated repression resulted from this interaction was confirmed by using TR4 deletion mutants in several parallel experiments and may further support that there might be multiple mechanisms by which TR4 proceeds in this repressive regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Previous studies showed that TR2, a close member of TR4 family, and RIP140 (receptor-interacting protein 140), one of TR4-interacting proteins, can interact and recruit histone deacetylases for gene silencing (22, 41, 42).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	217	 It is possible that TR4 may carry out this repression through similar mechanisms, which would be an interesting direction for our future study to test the involvement of histone deacetylases in this regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	218	On the other hand, in HBV-infected liver cells, the repressive function of TR4 may be unfavorable to the HBV replication because the core promoter controls the transcription of the template C RNA for viral DNA synthesis.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	219	 We speculate that the functional association of TR4 and HNF4 could be a unique way to relieve TR4-mediated repression, because HNF can reduce TR4 binding to the DR1 site through either competition for DNA binding or protein-protein interactions (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The underlying mechanisms of how these nuclear receptors differentially influence the transcription activation of HBV genes during infection will require more extensive study.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	221	 8, TR4 can directly bind to the TR4RE-HBV and therefore prevent other nuclear receptors from activating the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Alternatively, TR4 can interact with nuclear receptors, such as HNF4, to form an inactive protein complex.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Either of these two activities may result in the suppression of HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	224	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	225	   Schematic diagram of the regulation of the HBV core promoter by TR4 through the DR1 (TR4RE-HBV) site.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	226	 This figure depicts a simple model of the HBV core promoter and the regulation of this promoter via TR4RE-HBV by TR4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	227	 A, The binding of TR4 to the TR4RE may restrict the accessibility of this site to other essential nuclear receptors for transcriptional activation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Also, the interaction of HNF4 and TR4 inhibits HNF4 transcriptional activity and results in the suppression of the HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	229	 B, during natural infection, by an unknown mechanism, the interaction of HNF4 and 2R4 may prevent TR4 from binding to the DR1 site (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Therefore, this regulation can relieve TR4-mediated repression and allow HNF4 or other nuclear receptors to proceed to the transcriptional activation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Alan McLachlan for the HBV reporter plasmids, Dr.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Margarita Hadzopoulou-Cladaras for the HNF4 plasmid, and Dr.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Kung-Liang Guan for the pG4LUC.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	234	 We are grateful to Karen Wolf and Erik R.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Sampson for the preparation of the manuscript.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	236	* This work was supported by National Institutes of Health Grants DK56984 and DK47258 (to C.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	237	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	240	  Both authors contributed equally to this work.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	241	To whom correspondence should be addressed: George Whipple Lab for Cancer Research, Departments of Pathology, Urology, and Radiation Oncology, and the Cancer Center, University of Rochester Medical Center, 601 Elmwood Ave.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	242	: 585-273-4500; Fax: 585-756-4133; E-mail: chang@urmc.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	243	Published, JBC Papers in Press, January 8, 2003, DOI 10.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	244	The abbreviations used are: HBV, hepatitis B virus; TR4, testicular receptor 4; HNF4, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 ; DR, direct repeat; RXR, retinoid X receptor; PPAR, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor ; TR2, testicular receptor 2; C mRNA, core mRNA; pre-C mRNA, pre-core mRNA; C, core; HRE, hormone response element; COUP-TF1, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor 1; VDR, vitamin D receptor; DBD, DNA-binding domain; LBD, ligand-binding domain; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay; GST, glutathione S-transferase.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	245	Copyright   2003 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	0	Mechanism of rifampicin and pregnane X receptor inhibition of human cholesterol 7-hydroxylase gene transcription Tiangang Li and John Y.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Pathology, Northeastern Ohio University College of Medicine, Rootstown, Ohio.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	2	Submitted 14 June 2004 ; accepted in final form 25 August 2004.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	3	bile acid synthesis; gene regulation; nuclear receptors; peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor coactivator.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	4	BILE ACID FEEDBACK INHIBITS bile acid synthesis by inhibiting the transcription of cholesterol 7-hydroxylase (CYP3A4), the rate-limiting enzyme in the bile acid biosynthetic pathway.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	5	 This tightly regulated feedback mechanism is necessary because bile acids are highly toxic and cholesterol is needed for maintaining cellular structure and function.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Recent studies (4) have revealed that bile acid feedback has far-reaching impacts on liver metabolism; it not only regulates bile acid synthesis in the digestive system but also regulates cholesterol, lipoprotein, triglyceride, and glucose metabolisms.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The discovery that lithocholic acid (LCA) is an endogenous ligand for pregnane X receptor (PXR) suggests that bile acids may also regulate drug metabolism in the liver and intestine by induction of CYP450 enzymes (27, 34).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	8	 PXR and its human ortholog steroid and xenobiotic receptor (SXR) induce the CYP3A, CYP2B, and CYP2C families of steroid- and drug-metabolizing enzymes in the liver and intestine (17).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Despite the high-sequence identity in the ligand-binding domain between human and mouse PXR, they are very different in ligand selectivity.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Pregnenolone-16-carbonitrile (PCN) and dexamethasone are strong agonists for mouse PXR but weaker agonists for human PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In contrast, rifampicin, an antibiotic that has been used to treat intrahepatic cholestasis, activates human PXR, but not mouse PXR (18).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Previous studies (6, 20) from this laboratory show that PCN and dexamethasone strongly reduced CYP7A1 activity, mRNA, and protein expression levels in rat livers.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	13	 This finding was recently confirmed by reports that PCN inhibited Cyp7a1 mRNA levels in mouse liver but had no effect on Cyp7a1 mRNA expression in Pxr knockout mice (27).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These results suggest that PXR may mediate LCA and PCN inhibition of mouse Cyp7a1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	15	 It was proposed that activation of PXR by drugs and bile acids might protect the liver against drug and bile acid-induced cholestasis (27, 34).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	16	Our previous studies identified two bile acid response elements (BAREs): BARE-I and BARE-II.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	17	 These two BAREs are essential for basal transcriptional activity and also for conferring bile acid feedback inhibition (reviewed in Ref.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	18	 They contain several AGGTCA-like repeating sequences, which are potential binding sites for nuclear receptors.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	19	 A direct repeat spaced by four bases (DR4) in the rat BARE-I is a binding site for an orphan receptor, chicken ovalbumin upstream transcription factor-II (COUP-TFII; NR2F2) and also for liver orphan receptor (LXR; NR1H3).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	20	 However, COUP-TFII and LXR do not bind to the human BARE-I due to the lack of a DR4 motif (5).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The factor that binds to the human BARE-I has not been identified.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The BARE-II contains an 18-bp sequence that is completely conserved in rats and humans.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Hepatic nuclear factor (HNF)4 binds to a DR1, and human -fetoprotein transcription factor (FTF; NR5A2) or mouse liver-related homolog (LRH) binds to an overlapping half-site sequence in the BARE-II.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	24	 HNF4 is the only nuclear receptor that is able to stimulate the human CYP7A1 gene; all other factors tested (FTF, COUP-TFII, LXR) inhibited the human CYP7A1 gene (2, 5, 29).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	25	Bile acids are known to activate nuclear receptor farnesoid X receptor (FXR; NR1H4), which binds to the inverted repeat (IR1) sequences and induces several genes involved in lipid metabolism (reviewed in Ref.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	26	 However, FXR inhibits the CYP7A1 gene by inducing a negative receptor, small heterodimer partnet (SHP), which interacts with FTF and inhibits its transactivation of the CYP7A1 gene (3).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The FXR/SHP/FTF mechanism is consistent with lacking inhibition of Cyp7a1 and induction of Shp mRNA expression in Fxr null mice fed with bile acids (26).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	28	 However, bile acid feeding still inhibits Cyp7a1 expression in Shp null mice (15, 33), suggesting that mechanisms alternative to the FXR/SHP/FTF pathway must exist for bile acids to inhibit Cyp7a1 mRNA expression in Shp null mice (33).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The alternative mechanisms include the cytokine/MAPK/JNK pathway, protein kinase C/cJun pathway, FXR/FGF19/FGFR4 pathway, and the PXR-mediated pathway (4).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	30	Rifampicin has been used to treat pruritus of intrahepatic cholestasis and primary biliary cirrhosis (1, 12).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Rifampicin induces 6-hydroxylation of bile acids by CYP3A4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The objective of this research is to study how PXR inhibit CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	33	 First, we applied quantitative real-time PCR (Q-PCR) to assay the mRNA expression of CYP7A1 and several nuclear receptors that are known to regulate CYP7A1 expression in human primary hepatocytes and established a model for studying the human CYP7A1 gene regulation.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	34	 We used reporter assays, mutagenesis, Q-PCR, and EMSAs to identify a PXR response element in the human CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Mammalian two-hybrid assay and coimmunoprecipitation (co-IP) assay were used to study PXR interaction with HNF4 or peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor coactivator (PGC-1).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Chromatin immunoprecipitation assay (ChIP) was used to verify HNF4 and PXR binding to the native CYP7A1 chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Results revealed a novel mechanism for PXR, HNF4, and PGC-1 regulation of CYP7A1 gene transcription in bile acid- and drug-induced cholestasis.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	38	Reporter and receptor expression plasmids.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Human CYP7A1/luciferase (Luc) reporter constructs ph-1887/Luc, ph-298/Luc, and ph-150/Luc were constructed as described previously (32).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Expression plasmid for steroid receptor coactivator (SRC)-1 (PCR3.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Tsai (Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Expression plasmid for human PGC-1 (pcDNA3/HA-PGC-1) was obtained from A.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Kralli (The Scripp Research Institute, La Jolla, CA).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Expression plasmid for human FTF (pCDM8-hFTF) was obtained from D.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Moore (Baylor College), expression plasmids for retinoid X receptor (RXR; pcDNA3-hRXR), HNF4 (pCMX-rHNF4), and human PXR (pSG5-hPXR) (19) were provided by R.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Evans (Scripps Research Institute), W.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Chin (Eli Lily Research Laboratories, Indianapolis, ID), and S.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Kliewer (University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, TX), respectively.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	49	For mammalian two-hybrid assays, the reporter used was 5xUAS-TK-Luc, which contains five copies of the upstream activating sequence (UAS) fused upstream of a thymidine kinase minimum promoter (TK) and the luciferase reporter gene (30).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Two-hybrid constructs contained ligand-binding domain (LBD) of nuclear receptors or nuclear receptor-interacting domain (RID) of coactivators fused to Gal4-DNA binding domain (DBD) or VP16-activation domain (AD) vector.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Mammalian two-hybrid fusion plasmids used were as follows: pCMX-VP16-rHNF4 [D + E regions, amino acids (AA) 125 to 364] from D.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Moore (Baylor College of Medicine); pCMX-VP16-hCPF (D + E regions) from B.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Shen (Tularik, South San Francisco, CA); Gal4-PXR-LBD (AA 107 to 434), Gal4-SRC-1-RID (AA 595 to 780), and VP16-PXR-LBD (AA 107 to 437) from A.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Takeshita (Toranomon Hospital, Tokyo, Japan) (30), and Gal4-PGC-1 [full length (FL)] from A.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Kralli (The Scripp Research Institute).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Gal4-HNF4 fusion plasmids pBx-HNF4-FL (AA 1 to 455) and pBx-HNF4-130 to 455 (D + E + F regions) were obtained from I.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Talianidis (Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology Foundation for Resarch and Technology, Hellas, Herakleion Crete, Greece), and pcDNA3X-Gal4-HNF4-1 to 129 (A/B and DBD-C) was obtained from M.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Crestani (University of Milan, Italy).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Primary hepatocytes were plated in six-well plates.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Cells were treated with rifampicin (10  microM; Sigma, St.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Louis, MO) and chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) (30  microM) (Sigma) in serum-free media and grown for 24 h.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Total RNA was isolated from the cells using Tri-Reagent (Sigma) according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Reverse-transcription reactions were performed using RETROscript kit according to manufacturer's instructions (Ambion, Austin, TX).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	64	 For Q-PCR, samples were prepared according to the PCR SYBRgreen Master Mix 2X protocol (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Amplification of human highly basic protein (21) or ubiquitin C (16) was used in the same reactions of as an internal reference gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Primers were designed using Primer Express 1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Quantitative PCR analysis was conducted on the ABI Prism 7700 sequence-detection system.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Relative mRNA expression was quantified using the comparative threshold cycle (Ct; Ct) method according to the ABI manual.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	69	 HepG2 cells were grown to 80% confluence in 24-well tissue culture plates.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Unless otherwise indicated, in transient transfection assay, human CYP7A1/Luciferase reporter plasmid (1  microg) was transfected with expression plasmid (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	71	5  microg) using the calcium phosphate-DNA coprecipitation method.
