0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The pCMV-galactosidase plasmid (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	73	1  microg) was transfected as an internal standard for normalizing the transfection efficiency in each assay.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	74	 In some samples, empty expression vectors were added to equalize the total amounts of plasmid DNA transfected in each assay.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Four hours after transfection, cells were incubated in serum-free media and treated with LCA (Steraloids, Newport, RI) or rifampicin in the concentrations indicated in each experiment for 40 h.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Cells were harvested for assay of luciferase reporter activity using Luciferase Assay System (Promega).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Luciferase activity was determined using a Lumat LB 9501 luminometer (Berthold Systems, Pittsburgh, PA) and normalized by dividing the relative light units by -galactosidase activity.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Each assay was done in triplicate, and individual experiments were repeated at least three times.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Data are plotted as means  plus or minus  SD.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Statistical analyses of treated vs.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	81	 untreated controls (vehicle or empty plasmids) were performed using Student's t-test.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	82	05 is considered statistically significant.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Cell viability assays were performed using TOX1 kit (Sigma).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	84	 HepG2 cells or human primary hepatocytes (HH1165) were cultured in 48-well plates and treated with increasing amounts of LCA (1 to 15  microM), CDCA (10 to 50  microM) or rifampicin (5 to 20  microM) for 48 h.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	85	 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) was added to the media and incubated for an additional 2 h.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The resulting purple crystals from MTT were dissolved in MTT dissolving solution, and absorbance was measured at 570 nm using a spectrophotometer.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Mutations were introduced into ph-298/Luc plasmid using PCR-based QuikChange Site-directed Mutagenesis Kit (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Two complementary oligonucleotides containing the mutations (see Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	89	 PCR reactions were set up according to the manufacturer's instruction using 50 ng of template DNA and 125 ng of primers.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	90	 PCR cycling parameters were set as follows: denaturing at 95 degrees C for 2 min, followed by 18 cycles at 95 degrees C for 30 s, 55 degrees C for 1 min, and 68 degrees C for 18 min.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The reaction mixture was digested by Dpn I for 2 h to remove the template DNA and transformed into XL1-Blue super competent cells (Stratagene) for selection of mutant clones.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Mutations in each clone were confirmed by DNA sequencing.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	93	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Effects of hepatocyte nuclear factor (HNF)4, PXR/RXR, and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor coactivator (PGC-1) on human CYP7A1 promoter activities.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	95	 HepG2 cells were cultured to 80% confluence.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Human CYP7A1/luciferase reporter (ph-298/Luc; 1  microg) was transiently transfected into HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	97	5  microg) was cotransfected as indicated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Cells were incubated in serum-free media for 40 h and harvested for luciferase activity assays as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The error bars represent the SD from the mean of triplicate assays of an individual experiment; n = 3, *P  <  0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Reporter plasmid 5x UAS-TK-LUC (1  microg) was transfected with various two-hybrid plasmids (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	101	5  microg each) and CMV--gal plasmid (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Cells were treated with rifampicin (10  microM), LCA (10  microM), or vehicle (DMSO).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Luciferase activity was assayed as described in Transient transfection assay.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Nuclear receptors were synthesized in vitro using Quick-coupled Transcription/Translation Systems (Promega) programmed with receptor expression plasmids according to the manufacturer's instruction.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Double-stranded synthetic probes for the PXR binding site of CYP3A4, BARE-I and BARE-II of the human CYP7A1 gene were prepared by heating equal molar amounts of complementary oligonucleotides to 95 degrees C in 2x SSC (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	106	5 M NaCl, 15 mM sodium citrate, pH 7.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	107	0) and then slowly cooled to room temperature.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The resulting double-stranded fragments were labeled with [32P]dCTP by filling in reaction using the Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Labeled double-stranded probes were purified through G-50 spin columns.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	110	 For each binding reaction, 50,000 counts/min (cpm) of labeled probe and 5 l of in vitro translated protein were incubated at room temperature for 20 min in 20  microl of binding buffer containing 12 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	111	9, 50 mM KCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 15% glycerol, and 2  microg of poly (dI-dC).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Samples were loaded on a 5% polyacrylamine gel, and electrophoresis was performed at room temperature at constant 200 V for 1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The gel was dried and autoradiographed using Phosphor Imager 445Si (Molecular Dynamics, Sunnyvale, CA).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Primary human hepatocytes were obtained in T75 culture flasks, and ChIP assays were performed on the same day the cells were received.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	115	 HepG2 cells were grown in 100-mm culture dishes to 80% confluence.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Ten micrograms of PXR, RXR, FTF, HNF4, and HA tagged-PGC-1 expression plasmids were transfected using the calcium phosphate-DNA coprecipitation method as described in Transient transfection assay.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Four hours after transfection, cells were incubated in serum-free media containing vehicle (DMSO) or 10  microM rifampicin for 40 h.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	118	 ChIP assays were performed using ChIP assay kit (Upstate Biotec, NY) according to manufacturer's protocol.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Briefly, cells were cross-linked in 1% formaldehyde for 10 min and washed with ice-cold PBS containing protease inhibitors (1 mM PMSF, 1  microg/ml aprotinin, and 1  microg/ml pepstanin A, Sigma) twice.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Cells were scraped and incubated in 1% SDS lysis buffer (1% SDS, 10 mM EDTA, 50 mM Tris HCl, pH 8.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	121	1) for 30 min on ice and sonicated using a Branson sonifier 250 with a microtip setting 6 for 15-s pulses at 40% output for a total of 1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Cell lysates were collected by centrifugation and diluted 10-fold in ChIP dilution buffer (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Ten percent of the cell lysates were saved and used as the "input" for immunoprecipitation.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	124	 After the diluted cell lysate was precleared with protein A-agarose, DNA-protein complexes were precipitated by incubating the cell lysates with 10  microg of antibodies (goat HNF4, #6556; goat PXR, #7737; goat PGC-1, #5815; goat CPF, #5995, from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA) against target proteins overnight followed by a 3-h incubation with protein A or G-agarose beads for each treatment.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Protein A or G was added as a nonimmunoprecipitation control.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The beads were washed with low-salt wash buffer (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	127	1% SDS, 1% Triton X-100, 2 mM EDTA, 20 mM Tris HCl, pH 8.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	128	1, 150 mM NaCl) once, high-salt wash buffer (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	129	1% SDS, 1% Triton X-100, 2 mM EDTA, 20 mM Tris HCl, pH 8.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	130	1, 500 mM NaCl) once, LiCl wash buffer [0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	131	25 M LiCl, 1% Nonidet P-40 (NP-40), 1% deoxycholate, 1 mM EDTA, and 10 mM Tris HCl, pH 8.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	132	1] once, and buffer with 10 mM Tris HCl and 1 mM EDTA, pH 8.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Samples were eluted twice with 250  microl of ChIP elution buffer (1% SDS, 0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	134	1 M NaHCO3), and the eluates were combined.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The cross-links were reversed by adjusting NaCl concentration to 200 mM and incubating the eluates at 65 degrees C for 4 h followed by a 1-h incubation in 0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	136	04  microg/ microl proteinase K.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	137	 DNA was extracted using phenol/chloroform and precipitated using isopropanol.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	138	 A 391-bp DNA fragment containing BARE-I and BARE-II was PCR amplified for 45 cycles and analyzed on a 2% agarose gel.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The PCR primers used were as follows: forward primer: 5'- ATCACCGTCTCTCTGGCAAAGCAC; reverse primer: 5'-CCATTAACTTGAGCTTGGTTGACAAAG.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The amplified fragment of 391 bp is from  to 432 to  to 41 containing the BARE-I and BARE-II.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	141	 HepG2 cells were cultured in T150 flasks and transfected with 10 g of PXR expression plasmid using Ca+2-phosphate coimmunoprecipitation method.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Human primary hepatocytes (#HH1148) in T75 flasks were treated with either vehicle (DMSO) or rifampicin (10  microM) for 24 h, collected, and incubated in modified RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, 1% NP-40, 0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	143	25%-deoxycholate, 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA) containing protease inhibitors (1 mM PMSF, 1  microg/ml aprotinin, 1  microg/ml pepstanin, Sigma) for 30 min.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Clear cell lyates were collected by centrifugation at 10,000 g at 4 degrees C for 15 min.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Clear lysates were precleared with protein G beads and incubated with 15  microg of rabbit anti-HNF4 antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) at 4 degrees C with rotation overnight, followed by an additional incubation for 2 h with protein G beads.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The beads were then washed three times with RIPA buffer and were boiled in 2x protein loading buffer for 5 min.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Samples were divided into equal amounts and_loaded on SDS PAGE gels for Western immunoblot analysis using goat antibodies against HNF4 (#6556, Santa Cruz Biotechnology), PGC-1 (#5815), and PXR (#7737).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	148	Rifampicin and CDCA reduce CYP7A1 mRNA expression in human primary hepatocytes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Q-PCR was then used to assay the effect of CDCA, an FXR ligand, and rifampicin, a human PXR ligand, on CYP7A1 mRNA expression levels in human primary hepatocytes (HH1106).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Comparative Ct ( to Ct) method was used to quantify the change of mRNA expression levels by CDCA and rifampicin (Table 1).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	151	 CDCA (30  microM) markedly reduced CYP7A1 mRNA expression by 95%, and rifampicin (10  microM) reduced CYP7A1 mRNA expression by 80%.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	152	 As a positive control for CDCA induction, SHP mRNA levels were determined.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	153	 As expected, CDCA induced SHP mRNA by sixfold.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The observed inverse relationship of CYP7A1 and SHP mRNA expression levels by bile acid is consistent with the hypothesis that SHP mechanism mediates bile acid inhibition of CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Interestingly, rifampicin completely abolished SHP mRNA expression.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	156	 As a positive control of PXR induction, CYP3A4 mRNA expression levels were measured in human primary hepatocytes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The CYP3A4 mRNA levels were too low to be detected in vehicle and CDCA-treated human hepatocytes (Ct = 40).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Rifampicin remarkably induced CYP3A4 mRNA levels by more than 50-fold, consistent with a previous report (9).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The strong induction of SHP by CDCA and CYP3A4 by rifampicin indicates that these compounds at the concentrations tested did not cause toxic effect on human primary hepatocytes as demonstrated by MTT assays.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The lack of an inverse relationship between CYP7A1 and SHP mRNA expression by rifampicin provides strong evidence that SHP is not involved in PXR inhibition of CYP7A1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	161	 These results may suggest that ligand-activated PXR reduced SHP gene transcription in human livers.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Quantitative PCR analysis of CYP7A1 mRNA expression in human primary hepatocytes (HH1106).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	163	  Human PXR and rifampicin inhibit CYP7A1 reporter activity in HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	164	 We then studied the effect of human PXR and rifampicin on human CYP7A1 gene transcription by transient transfection assay in HepG2 cells using a human CYP7A1/luciferase reporter construct (ph-298/Luc).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	165	 MTT assays revealed that LCA (1 to 15  microM), CDCA (10 to 50  microM), and rifampicin (5 to 20  microM) did not reduce HepG2 cell viability in the concentration range tested.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Rifampicin (10  microM) slightly inhibited CYP7A1 reporter activity assayed in HepG2 cells (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Because HepG2 cells express very low levels of PXR that are barely detectable by Western blot analysis and Q-PCR (data not shown), we overexpressed human PXR and RXR in HepG2 cells for reporter assays.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	168	 1B, rifampicin strongly reduced the reporter activity by 80% in PXR-expressing HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	169	 These results suggest that PXR is involved in rifampicin inhibition of the CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	170	View larger version (19K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Rifampicin-activated pregnane X receptor (PXR) suppresses the cholesterol 7-hydroxylase (CYP7A1) reporter activity in transient transfection assays in HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	172	 HepG2 cells were cultured to 80% confluence.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Human CYP7A1/luciferase reporter (ph-298/Luc; 1  microg) was transiently transfected into HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Cells were treated with vehicle (DMSO) or rifampicin for 40 h and harvested for luciferase activity assays as described under MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	175	 A: effect of rifampicin (10  microM) on human CYP7A1/Luc reporter activity in HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Data are plotted as means  plus or minus  SD, n = 3.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	177	 B: effects of PXR ligands (10  microM) on human CYP7A1/Luc reporter activity in HepG2 cells transfected with PXR/retinoid X receptor (RXR) expression plasmids (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	178	5  microg) or empty vector, pcDNA3, and PXR ligands were added as indicated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The error bars represent the SD from the mean of triplicate assays of an individual experiment, n = 3.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	180	  Identification of a negative PXR response element.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	181	 To localize the promoter region that confers negative rifampicin and PXR effect in the human CYP7A1 gene, 5'-deletion constructs of human CYP7A1/Luc reporter containing sequences from  to 1887/+24,  to 298/+24, and  to 150/+24 were assayed in HepG2 cells transfected with PXR and RXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Reporter activities of all three constructs were inhibited 80% by rifampicin (data not shown).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	183	 It is concluded that the PXR response element is located in the region downstream of  to 150, which contains both BARE-I and BARE-II.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	184	 We thus performed EMSA using oligonucleotide probes designed based on the nucleotide sequences in the BARE-I and BARE-II.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	185	 When the human BARE-I probe was used for EMSA (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	186	 2A), a mixture of in vitro synthesized PXR and RXR shifted a single band (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Neither PXR nor RXR alone bound the BARE-I probe (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	188	 A probe that contains a strong PXR binding site in the human CYP3A4 gene (ER6; Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	189	 2A) was used as a positive control for PXR binding (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Excess unlabeled BARE-I or unlabeled CYP3A4 oligonucleotide completely abolished the shifted band.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	191	 A mutant BARE-I probe, which has mutations introduced to alter the AGCTCA half-site sequence, did not bind PXR/RXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Figure 2C shows that unlabeled CYP3A4 oligonucleotide could completely compete out PXR binding to the labeled BARE-I probe at 100-fold excess.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	193	 On the other hand, 200-fold excess of unlabeled BARE-I was required to completely complete out PXR binding to the labeled 3A4 probe.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	194	 PXR is known to bind various motifs including DR3, DR4, and ER6 (11).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Analysis of the nucleotide sequences of human BARE-I revealed a putative DR3 motif (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	196	 2A) that is known to bind human PXR (17).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	197	View larger version (46K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	198	 EMSA of PXR/RXR binding to human and rat bile acid response element (BARE)-I probes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	199	 A: nucleotide sequences of the probes used in the EMSA.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Rat BARE-I sequence is shown for comparison.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Arrows above sequences indicate hormone response element half-site.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Lower case letters indicate mutations.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	203	 DR, direct repeat; ER, everted repeat.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	204	 B: PXR/RXR binding to human BARE-I probes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	205	 -P32-labeled probes [5 x 104 cycles/min (cpm)] and 5  microl of in vitro synthesized proteins (TNT lysate) were mixed and applied to each lane as indicated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Excess (100-fold) of unlabeled probes was used as cold competitor.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Probe CYP3A4 contains a PXR/RXR binding site (ER6) of human CYP3A4 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Probe Mut contains a mutant human BARE-I as shown in A.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	209	 C: cold competition of PXR/RXR binding to human BARE-I probe and CYP3A4 probe.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Increasing amount of excess unlabeled probes and 1  microl -P32-labeled probes (5 x 104 cpm) were incubated with 5  microl of in vitro synthesized proteins (TNT lysate) for 20 min and applied to each lane as indicated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	211	  We then introduced the same mutations into a human CYP7A1/Luc reporter to test whether the PXR binding site is functional.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Mutation of the AGCTCA sequence in the_BARE-I markedly reduced reporter activity by 90% (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	213	 This hormone-response element half-site apparently is essential for basal human CYP7A1 gene transcriptional activity.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	214	 When transfection assays were performed in HepG2 cells cotransfected with PXR/RXR, rifampicin did not significantly inhibit the mutant reporter activity (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	215	 These results confirmed that the BARE-I was a functional negative PXR response element.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	216	 It was also concluded that the BARE-II was not a PXR response element, because PXR did not bind to the BARE-II (data not shown) and rifampicin did not inhibit the mutant reporter that had an intact BARE-II (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	217	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Mutation in the BARE-I of human CYP7A1 gene abolished PXR inhibition.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	219	 A: wild-type human CYP7A1/Luc reporter (ph-298)/Luc or mutant reporter with mutations in the BARE-I region introduced by site-directed mutagenesis (shown in Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	220	 2) was transfected into HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Basal reporter activity was assayed; n = 3, mutant vs.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	222	 B: mutant reporter plasmid was transfected into HepG2 cells cotransfected with PXR/RXR expression plasmids.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	223	 **Not significant for rifampicin vs.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Cells were treated with vehicle (DMSO) or 10  microM rifampicin as indicated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	225	  Rifampicin inhibits HNF4 and PGC-1 stimulation of human CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	226	 We then studied the effect of rifampicin on CYP7A1 reporter activity affected by HNF4, PXR, and PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	227	 4, HNF4 stimulated human CYP7A1 reporter activity by fivefold (lane 2).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	228	 PGC-1 alone stimulated human CYP7A1 reporter activity by threefold (lane 3).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Combination of HNF4 and PGC-1 stimulated activity by eightfold (lane 5).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	230	 It is remarkable that addition of rifampicin almost completely abolished reporter activity in PXR expression HepG2 cells (lanes 4 and 6 to 8).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	231	 These data revealed that PXR was a strong repressor of the CYP7A1 gene when activated by a ligand, whereas HNF4 and PGC-1 are positive regulators of the human CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	232	PXR interacts with HNF4 and PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	233	 We reported previously that HNF4 bound to the BARE-II and COUP-TFII bound to the BARE-I synergistically stimulated rat CYP7A1 gene transcription (29).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	234	 We proposed a model that factors bound to the BARE-I and BARE-II interact and regulate CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	235	 We therefore wanted to test the hypothesis that PXR, which binds to the BARE-I, might also interact with HNF4 to regulate the human CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	236	 We used mammalian two-hybrid assay to study the interaction between Gal4-PXR-LBD fusion and VP16-HNF4 fusion in HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	237	 In this assay, Gal4-PXR-LBD fusion protein binds to the Gal4-DBD (DNA binding site or UAS) in a luciferase reporter (Gal4 to 5XUAS-TK-Luc), which has a TK minimal promoter, and expresses low basal activity in mammalian cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	238	 If Gal4-PXR fusion protein interacts with VP16-HNF4 fusion protein, then the Gal4 reporter activity should be stimulated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The effect of a PXR ligand on the interaction also can be tested in this assay.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	240	 5A show that Gal4-PXR-LBD (AA 107 to 434) interacts strongly with VP16-HNF4 (D + BD, AA 125 to 364) only in the presence of rifampicin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	241	 As a control for specificity of interaction, Gal4-PXR interacts very weakly with VP16-FTF.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	242	 It should be noted that the FTF binding site overlaps with the HNF4 binding site in the BARE-II.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	243	 We then used Gal4-HNF4 and VP16-PXR hybrids in two-hybrid assays.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Figure 5B shows that Gal4-HNF4 full-length and VP16-PXR-LBD interact without addition of a HNF4 ligand (4-fold of the background).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	245	 It should be noted that HNF4 has intrinsic activity, and the endogenous HNF4 ligand is not known for certain.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Addition of rifampicin somewhat enhanced the interaction.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The interactions between Gal4-HNF4 and VP16-PXR fusion proteins were much weaker than between Gal4-PXR/VP16-HNF4 hybrids (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	248	 5A), as indicated by much lower reporter activities.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The NH2-terminal region (A/B + DBD; AA 1 to 129) of HNF4 did not_interact with PXR, whereas the COOH-terminal region (LBD; AA 130 to 455) of HNF4 did.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These data revealed that the LBD of HNF4 interacts with LBD of PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	251	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Mammalian 2-hybrid assays of PXR interaction with HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	253	 A: mammalian 2-hybrid assay of ligand-dependent interaction between PXR and HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	254	5  microg) Gal4-PXR-ligand binding domain (LBD), VP16-empty vector, VP16--fetoprotein transcription factor (FTF)-LBD, or VP16-HNF4 (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	255	5  microg) were cotransfected with 5x upstream activating sequence (UAS)-thymidine kinase (TK)-LUC reporter plasmid (1  microg) into HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Cells were treated with vehicle (DMSO) or 10  microM rifampicin for 40 h and harvested for luciferase activity assays as described under MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The error bars represent the SD from the mean of triplicate assays of an individual experiment; n = 3, *P  <  0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	258	 B: mammalian 2-hybrid assay of ligand-dependent interaction between PXR and HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	259	5  microg) containing a full-length, NH2-terminal A/B + C [1 to 129 amino acid (AA)], and COOH-terminal D + E + F (130 to 455 AA) of HNF4, and VP16-PXR-LBD (0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	260	5  microg) were cotransfected with 5x UAS-TK-LUC reporter plasmid (1  microg) into HepG2 cells as indicated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Empty vector VP16 was used as a negative control.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Cells were treated with vehicle (DMSA) or 10  microM rifampicin for 40 h and harvested for luciferase activity assays as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	263	 The error bars represent the SE of the mean of triplicate assays of an individual experiment; n = 3, *P  <  0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	264	  PXR interacts with PGC-1 and rifampicin attenuates the PGC-1 interaction with HNF4 and PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	265	 PGC-1 was originally identified as a coactivator of PPAR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Since then, several other nuclear receptors including HNF4, LXR, RXR, and Estrogen receptor (ER), and ER-related receptor were found to interact with PGC-1 and regulate gluconeogenesis and energy metabolism (23, 25).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	267	 It is not known whether PGC-1 interacts with PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	268	 We therefore performed mammalian two-hybrid assays to study PXR interaction with PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Figure 6A shows that Gal4-PGC-1 strongly interacts with VP16-PXR as indicated by a 400-fold stimulation of Gal4 reporter activity over Gal4 basal activity.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	270	 A ubiquitous steroid receptor coactivator, SRC-1, interacts much weaker (20-fold) with VP16-PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Because coactivator is known to interact with nuclear receptor by binding to the LBD and ligand enhances the interaction, we then studied the effect of rifampicin on PXR interaction with HNF4 and PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Figure 6B shows that rifampicin induced a fourfold stimulation of PXR and PGC-1 interaction.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Interestingly, overexpression of HNF4 strongly inhibited PXR and PGC-1 interaction only when a PXR ligand was added.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	274	 This indicates that rifampicin promotes PXR and HNF4 interaction and excludes PGC-1 from interaction with PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Figure 6C shows that Gal4-PGC-1 interacts strongly with VP-16-HNF4 (500-fold), and rifampicin did not have any effect on the interaction.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	276	 This is expected because rifampicin is not a ligand of HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	277	 When PXR expression plasmid was cotransfected, addition of rifampicin strongly inhibited HNF4 and PGC-1 interaction.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	278	 These results also suggest that rifampicin promotes PXR interaction with HNF4 and prevents PGC-1 interaction with HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	279	 These results reveal for the first time that PGC-1 is a strong coactivator of PXR and rifampicin promotes PXR interaction with HNF4 and blocks PGC-1 from interaction with HNF4 or PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	280	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Mammalian 2-hybrid assay of PXR and HNF4 interaction with PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	282	 A: mammalian 2-hybrid assay of PXR interaction with PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	283	5  microg) VP16-PXR-LBD, Gal4-empty vector, Gal4-SRC-1-RID, and Gal4-PGC-1 were cotransfected with 5x UAS-TK-LUC reporter plasmid (1  microg) into HepG2 cells as indicated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Cells were incubated for 40 h and harvested for luciferase activity assay as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The error bars represent the SD from the mean of triplicate assays of an individual experiment; n = 3, *P  <  0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	286	 B: HNF4 disrupts PGC-1 and PXR interaction.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	287	 VP16-PXR-LBD, Gal4-empty vector, or Gal4-PGC-1 and expression plasmid pCMX-HNF4 were cotransfected with 5x UAS-TK-LUC reporter plasmid (1  microg) into HepG2 cells as indicated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Cells were treated with vehicle (DMSO) or 10  microM rifampicin as indicated for 40 h and harvested for luciferase activity assay; n = 3, *P  <  0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	289	 C: PGC-1 interacts with HNF4, and rifampicin-activated PXR disrupts HNF4 interaction with PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	290	5  microg) VP16-PXR-LBD, Gal4-empty vector, or Gal4-PGC-1 and expression plasimd pSG5-hPXR were cotransfected with 5x UAS-TK-Luc reporter plasmid into HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The error bars represent the SD from the mean of triplicate assays of an individual experiment; n = 3, *P  <  0.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	292	  HNF4 and PXR bind to the CYP7A1 gene and interact with PGC-1 in the native CYP7A1 chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	293	 To further test the binding and interaction of HNF4, PXR, and PGC-1 to the CYP7A1 gene in vivo, we performed ChIP assays using human primary hepatocytes and HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	294	 PCR primers were designed to amplify a 391-bp fragment that contains both BARE-I and BARE-II sequences.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Figure 7A shows that an antibody against PXR or HNF4 precipitated the CYP7A1 chromatins in primary human hepatocytes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	296	 For ChIP assay using HepG2 cells, PGC-1, HNF4, and PXR/RXR were overexpressed to increase receptor expression levels.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Figure 7B shows that anti-PXR or HNF4 antibody precipitates CYP7A1 chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	298	 These results confirmed that PXR and HNF4 bound to the native CYP7A1 chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	299	 PGC-1 antibody also precipitated the CYP7A1 chromatin (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Because PGC-1 is a coactivator that lacks a DBD, PGC-1 must interact with either HNF4 and/or PXR in the CYP7A1 chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	301	 We also did ChIP assay using an antibody against FTF and confirmed that FTF bound to the BARE-II.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	302	 We then studied the effect of rifampicin on the binding of these transcription factors to the CYP7A1 chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Rifampicin treatments did not affect the binding of HNF4 and PXR to the CYP7A1 chromatin, but PGC-1 was absent from the chromatin (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	304	 As a control, ChIP assays showed that rifampicin did not alter FTF binding to the chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	305	 These data are consistent with our mammalian two-hybrid assay data, which suggest that rifampicin disrupts PGC-1 interaction with HNF4 or PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	306	View larger version (25K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	307	 rifampicin impairs the recruitment of PGC-1 to CYP7A1 chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	308	 A: chromatin immunoprecipitation assay (ChIP) of PXR and HNF4 binding to human CYP7A1 gene in primary human hepatocytes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Anti-PXR or anti-HNF4 antibody (Ab) was used to precipitate the DNA-protein complex in primary human hepatocytes (HH1119).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	310	 A 391-bp fragment containing BARE-I and BARE-II was PCR amplified and analyzed on a 2% agarose gel.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Protein G was used alone as nonimmunoprecipitation control.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	312	 Ten percent of the total cell lysate was used as the "input.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	313	" B: ChIP assay of HNF4, PXR, FTF, and PGC-1 binding to human CYP7A1 chromatin using HepG2 cells.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	314	 HepG2 cells were transfected with 10  microg of PXR, RXR, HNF4, HA-PGC-1, or FTF expression plasmids and treated with vehicle (DMSO) or 10  microM rifampicin for 40 h.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	315	 ChIP assays were performed as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Anti-PXR, anti-HNF4, anti-HA, or anti-FTF antibodies were used to precipitate the DNA-protein complexes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	317	 A 391-bp fragment containing BARE-I and BARE-II was PCR amplified and analyzed on a 2% agarose gel.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Protein G was used alone as nonimmunocontrol (not shown).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	319	  Co-IP assay of HNF interaction with PXR and PGC-12.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	320	 To further confirm the physical interaction between HNF4 and PXR in cells, anti-HNF4 antibody was used to immunoprecipitate HNF4 from cell extracts isolated from HepG2 and human primary hepatocytes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	321	 If PXR interacts with HNF4 in these cells, PXR should be co-IP by anti-HNF4 antibody and detected by Western immunoblot analysis using antibody against PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Because PXR protein levels are very low in HepG2 cells, HepG2 cells were transfected with PXR expression plasmid.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	323	 8A shows that antibody against PXR detected small amounts of PXR in HepG2 cell extracts precipitated by anti-HNF4 antibody.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Rifampicin treatment markedly increased PXR protein in the IP.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Anti-HNF4 antibody detected similar amounts of HNF4 in vehicle and rifampicin-treated cell extracts.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	326	 We also did co-IP assay using human primary hepatocytes (no overexpression of PXR).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Figure 8B shows co-IP assay using anti-HNF4 antibody to precipitate cell extracts from human primary hepatocytes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Anti-PXR antibody detected a small amount of PXR protein in the IP.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Rifampicin pretreatment of hepatocytes markedly increased the amounts of PXR co-IP with the HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Anti-PGC-1 antibody detected PGC-1 protein in the IP, and rifampicin pretreatment markedly reduced the amounts of PGC-1 protein in the IP.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	331	 These data confirmed that rifampicin enhanced PXR interaction with HNF4 as revealed by mammalian two-hybrid assays shown in Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Rifampicin reduced PGC-1 co-IP with HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	333	 These results are consistent with the finding from two-hybrid assays (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	334	 6, B and C) and ChIP assays (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	335	 7B) that rifampicin promoted PXR interaction with HNF4 and excluded PGC-1 from interaction with HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	336	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	337	 Coimmunoprecipitation assay of HNF4 interaction with PXR and PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	338	 A: coimmunoprecipitation assay using HepG2 cell extracts.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	339	 HepG2 cells were transfected with PXR expression plasmid and treated with either vehicle (DMSO) or 10  microM rifampicin for 40 h.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Rabbit anti-HNF4 antibody (ab) was added to immunoprecipitate the cell lysates as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Western immunoblot analyses were performed using goat anti-PXR or anti-HNF4 antibody to detect PXR and HNF4 in the precipitates.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	342	 B: coimmunoprecipitation assay using human primary hepatocytes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	343	 Human primary hepatoctyes (HH1148) were treated with DMSO or 10  microM rifampicin for 40 h.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	344	 Rabbit anti-HNF4 antibody was added to cells lysates as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Western immunoblot analyses were performed using goat anti-HNF4, PXR or PGC-1 antibody to detect these proteins in the immunoprecipitates.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Protein G was added as a negative control.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	347	In bile acid or drug-induced cholestasis, PXR may be activated to induce CYP3A4, which catalyzes 6-hydroxylation of bile acids for renal excretion.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	348	 PXR also induces dehydroepiandrosterone sulfotransferase that excretes sulfate-conjugated bile acids.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	349	 Our findings suggest that PXR inhibition of CYP7A1 gene transcription may be an additional mechanism for reducing intrahepatic bile acid concentrations and further protect the liver from toxic effects of bile acids and xenobiotics.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	350	 PXR inhibition of SHP may also be a part of the PXR protection mechanism, because SHP could interact with PXR to inhibit CYP3A4 induction (22).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	351	Our cell-based mammalian two-hybrid assay, co-IP, and ChIP assays all confirm the interactions of PXR with HNF4 and PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	352	 The interaction between PXR and HNF4 is novel and is consistent with our model that factors bound to the BARE-I and BARE-II interact and coordinately regulate basal transcription of the CYP7A1 gene (8).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	353	 HNF4 is known to play a central role in regulation of bile acid synthesis (3).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	354	 There are reports that HNF4 is required for PXR-mediated xenobiotic induction of CYP3A4 in mice (31) and that HNF4 regulates PXR expression and xenobiotic response during fetal liver development (14).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Therefore, the PXR and HNF4 interaction may be physiologically important in the coordinated regulation of xenobiotic and bile acid metabolisms.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Both two-hybrid assay and co-IP assay using HepG2 and primary hepatocyte extracts show that rifampicin markedly enhances PXR interaction with HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	357	 The interaction between PXR and PGC-1 is as strong as between HNF4 and PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	358	 This is the first report that PXR is a target of PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Rifampicin is not required for PXR to interact with PGC-1 and does not affect HNF4 and PXR binding to CYP7A1 chromatin.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	360	 On the other hand, rifampicin dissociates PGC-1 from CYP7A1 chromatin likely due to enhancing PXR interaction with HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	361	Our results suggest a model for PXR, HNF4, and PGC-1 regulation of the CYP7A1 gene (Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	362	 HNF4 and PGC-1 are the most important transactivators of the human CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	363	 PGC-1 interacts with HNF4, which binds to the BARE-II and activates human CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	364	 According to this study, PXR binds to the BARE-I and interacts with PGC-1 but may not be important in basal transcription of the CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	365	 It should be noted that our model does not suggest a ternary complex formation among PXR, HNF4, and PGC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	366	 PGC-1 is a coactivator that binds to the LBD of both PXR and HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Therefore, it is not likely that PGC-1 interacts simultaneously with both nuclear receptors.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Ubiquitous coactivators, SRC-1 and CBP, are known to interact with PXR and HNF4; however, our data show a much stronger interaction of PXR with PGC-1 than SRC-1.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Nuclear receptor/coactivator complexes may facilitate the recruitment of histone acetytransferase to remodel the chromatin to allow recruitment of other coactivator/mediator complexes and assemble the general transcriptional machinery that regulates RNA polymerase II activity (10).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	370	 On the basis of our results, we propose a model that activation of PXR by rifampicin would allow PXR to interact directly with HNF4 and exclude PGC-1 from interacting with HNF4, resulting in suppression of the CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Corepressors, such as SMRT and NCoR1, have been shown to inhibit nuclear receptor activity (7).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Our preliminary results show that the interaction of SMRT and NCoR1 with HNF4 and PXR is very weak.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	373	 It is also possible that rifampicin-activated PXR may compete with HNF4 for PGC-1, thus inhibiting CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	374	 This mechanism of PXR inhibition of gene transcription is not likely because PGC-1 interaction with PXR or HNF4 does not require a ligand and rifampicin-activated PXR and HNF4 is known to strongly induce, not inhibit, CYP3A4 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	375	View larger version (35K):    Fig.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	376	 A model for rifampicin and PXR regulation of CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Top: HNF4 and PGC-1 are the most important activators of human CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	378	 PGC-1 interacts with HNF4, which binds to the BARE-II and transactivates the human CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	379	 According to this study, PXR is able to bind to the BARE-I.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	380	 Coactivators SRC-1 and cAMP response element binding protein binding protein (CBP) and histone acetytransferase (HAT) may be also recruited to remodel chromatin and recruit other coactivator complexes to induce the basal transcription of the CYP7A1 gene by RNA polymerase II.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	381	 Bottom: rifampicin activates PXR to promote its interaction with HNF4.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	382	 This interaction may disrupt the interaction between PGC-1 and HNF4 (and may be also PXR) and result in suppression of CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Corepressors and histone deacetylase (HDAC) may be also recruited to inhibit CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	384	  Very recently, a homeobox transcription factor, Prox1, has been shown to interact specifically with FTF and inhibits the CYP7A1 gene (24).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	385	 Prox1 is expressed in the liver and intestine and may play an important role not only in liver development, but also in regulation of bile acid synthesis.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Our Q-PCR analysis detects very high levels of Prox1 mRNA in human primary hepatocytes, indicating that Prox1 might be the dominant repressor of CYP7A1 gene expression in human livers.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	387	 However, it is not known whether bile acids or drugs affect Prox1 interaction with FTF, HNF4, or PXR.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	388	 Another recent report (28) shows that Prox1 interacts with FTF and inhibits SHP gene expression and that Prox1 specifically interacts with histone deacetylase (HDAC)3.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	389	 HDACs are known to form complexes with nuclear receptors and corepressors and inhibit gene transcription (13).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	390	 The roles of these transcriptional repressors in mediating bile acid inhibition of CYP7A1 gene transcription remain to be elucidated.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	391	In summary, this study provides the first evidence that PXR is able to interact with HNF4 and PGC-1 and plays a role in mediating rifampicin and bile acid inhibition of CYP7A1 gene transcription.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	392	 On ligand binding, PXR interacts with HNF4, blocks PGC-1 interaction with HNF4, and results in inhibition of the CYP7A1 gene.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	393	 The PXR pathway may be important for preventing bile acid and drug-induced cholestasis by inhibiting bile acid synthesis as well as stimulating bile acid transport, excretion, and detoxification.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	394	 Thus PXR plays a central role in coordinated regulation of bile acid homeostasis and drug metabolism.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	395	 This may be the mechanism for using rifampicin and steroids to treat pruritus of intrahepatic cholestasis and primary biliary cirrhosis (1, 12).
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	396	 Efficacious PXR agonists may be developed for treating these chronic liver diseases.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	397	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Dr.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Strom for providing human primary hepatocytes.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	399	 Spalding-Yoder is gratefully acknowledged.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	400	   FOOTNOTES   Address correspondence: J.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	401	 of Biochemistry and Molecular Pathology, Northeastern Ohio Univ.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	402	 College of Medicine, 4209 State Route 44, P.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Box 95, Rootstown, OH 44272 (E-mail: jchiang{at}neoucom.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	404	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	405	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.40663978.15331348.html.plaintext.txt	406	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	0	Essential Role of Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor II in Insulin Secretion and Insulin Sensitivity Revealed by Conditional Gene Knockout Pascale Bardoux1, Pili Zhang1, Daisy Flamez2, Anais Perilhou1, Tiphaine Aguirre Lavin1, Jean-Francois Tanti3, Karine Hellemans4, Emmanuel Gomas1, Cecile Godard1, Fabrizio Andreelli5, Maria Antonietta Buccheri1, Axel Kahn1, Yannick Le Marchand-Brustel3, Remy Burcelin6, Frans Schuit4, and Mireille Vasseur-Cognet1.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Department of Genetic Development and Molecular Biology, Universite Rene Descartes, Institut Cochin, INSERM U567 (Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale), Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique-UMR 8104, Paris, France 2 Diabetes Research Center, Faculty of Medicine, Vrije Universiteit Brussel Laarbeeklaan, Brussels, Belgium 3 Faculte de Medecine, INSERM U568, Nice, France 4 Gene Expression Unit, Afdeling Biochemie, Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Leuven, Belgium 5 Service de Diabetologie-Nutrition, Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Bichat-Claude Bernard, Paris, France 6 Unite Mixte de Recherche 5018, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique-UPS, IFR 31, Paul Sabatier University, Toulouse, France.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	2	The function of differentiated ss-cells is dependent upon a network of transcription factors that are required for the expression of key genes involved in glucose sensing, insulin biosynthesis, and regulated exocytosis (1 to 4).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Disturbance of this network, even by mutations causing a modest decrease in the protein level, has been shown to lead to important clinical manifestations such as diabetes and/or obesity.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	4	Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II (COUP-TFII; also called NR2F and ARP-1) is an orphan member of the steroid/thyroid hormone receptor superfamily that binds DNA by a Zn-finger DNA binding domain (5).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	5	 COUP-TFII is generally considered to be a functional transcriptional repressor of genes controlled by nuclear hormone receptors such as peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors and hepatocyte nuclear factor (HNF)-4, which are well known to play important roles in the glucose-responsive phenotype of ss-cells (6,7).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The possibility that COUP-TFII might play a role in glucose homeostasis is supported by in vitro studies suggesting that this protein is involved in regulating insulin gene expression in pancreatic ss-cells (8) but also in the expression of several other genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism (9,10).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	7	 It has been shown that COUP-TFII is expressed in the early developing endocrine pancreas and in mature differentiated islet cells (11).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	8	 However, until now the potential function of COUP-TFII in pancreatic ss-cells remains unknown.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	9	 One way to address this issue is to generate COUP-TFII-deficient mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Since global COUP-TFII deficiency results in embryonic lethality (12), we generated in this study a conditional knockout of the COUP-TFII gene using the Cre-loxP system.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Our data show that inactivation of one COUP-TFII allele in ss-cells results in disturbed insulin secretion and peripheral insulin resistance.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	12	View larger version (30K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Assessment of COUP-TFII deletion in pancreatic ss-cell and extrapancreatic cells of Rip2-Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	14	 A: Schematic representation of the genomic structure of COUP-TFII: (a) shows the genomic map of the wt COUP-TFII allele.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The lower panels show the targeted locus before (b) and after (c) excision of the neomycin selection cassette (Neo) that is flanked by one loxP upstream and two loxP sites downstream of exon 1 and also shows the position of the different primers used in the PCR analysis.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Individual letters represent restriction sites.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	17	 B: One representative PCR analysis of DNA samples.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	18	 B, brain; L, liver; H, hypothalamus; P, pancreatic islet; and SC, spinal cord and hep: HepCre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	19	 COUP-TFII fl/fl hepatocytes as control of the profile-excised fragment.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	20	 C: Western blot analysis of islet nuclear extracts of wild-type (lane 1) and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The lower panel represents the blot stained by red Ponceau, and the upper panel is the same blot hybridized with COUP-TF antibody.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	22	  View larger version (15K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	23	COUP-TFII fl/fl embryos produced by breedings between COUP-TFII fl/fl and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	24	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice or COUP-TFII fl/wt and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	25	5 days post coitum and after birth.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Values in parentheses indicate the Mendelian frequencies expected from these breedings.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	27	  Mice carrying COUP-TFII gene inactivation in the pancreatic ss-cells were generated by breeding homozygous COUP-TFII fl/fl mice with transgenic mice expressing Cre driven by the rat insulin II promoter (Rip2-Cre) generated by Magnuson and colleagues (13,14).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	28	COUP-TFII fl/wt females were mated to COUP-TFII fl/wt males to generate mice with different genotypes.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	29	COUP-TFII fl/fl mice were embryonic lethal.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Since there are no precedents for embryonic lethal phenotypes resulting from ss-cell-specific gene deletions, this lethality, together with the observations of Magnuson and colleagues (14), led us to examine possible Cre-induced deletion of the floxed COUP-TFII allele in other tissues than endocrine pancreas.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Multiplex PCR analysis was performed on DNA prepared from liver, hypothalamus, brain, and spinal cord (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	32	 We detected gene deletion in the spinal cord from the Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	33	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice, while we previously demonstrated that the COUP-TFII gene is expressed in the ventral neural tube at 9.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Therefore, extrapancreatic COUP-TFII gene knockout could contribute in the observed lethality of homozygous Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	35	Multiplex PCR analysis of DNA prepared from islets isolated from Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	36	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice confirmed that one floxed allele was deleted (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	37	 As judged by immunoblotting, COUP-TF levels were decreased by 45% in nuclear extracts prepared from islets from Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	38	 1C, lane 2) compared with wt mice (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	39	 These results indicate that Cre-induced recombination in heterozygous Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	40	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice leads to an efficient inactivation of the COUP-TFII gene in ss-cells.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The expression of COUP-TFI, a closely related family member, was not altered, suggesting that adaptative upregulation of this isoform does not occur (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	42	View larger version (12K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Steady-state mRNA levels of target genes in Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	44	COUP-TFII fl/wt and COUP-TFII fl/wt pancreatic islets of 3- to 4-month-old mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	45	 RT-PCR analysis for islet glucose-sensing proteins and COUP-TFI transcription factor in isolated islets.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Eight different animals for each genotype we used for RT-PCR using [-32P] dCTP.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Mutant/Cre+/ to  and COUP-TFII fl/wt/Cre+/ to  indicate the ratio of expression levels of the mean values of Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	48	COUP-TFII fl/wt (mutant) and COUP-TFII fl/wt to controls (Cre+/ to  or wt).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	49	  Finally, to understand the lethality of some COUP-TFII fl/fl pups, we examined whether inclusion of the loxP sites might interfere with COUP-TFII gene expression.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Semiquantitative RT-PCR analysis using the A5HF and R5HF primers showed that liver and kidney mRNA was decreased by 20% in heterozygous floxed mice with respect to normal animals (data not shown).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Accordingly, COUP-TFII protein analyzed by Western blot was also slightly decreased (by 10 to 20%) in hepatocyte nuclear extracts of heterozygous floxed mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Therefore, the floxed COUP-TFII allele is hypomorphic, which could explain the death of some homozygous floxed COUP-TFII pups.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	53	The present study was carried out in the Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	54	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice, in which the floxed allele is inactivated in the Cre-expressing cells and shows to be hypomorphic only in other tissues.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Therefore, the COUP-TFII protein is expected to be decreased by half in the former cells and by 10 to 20% in the latter ones.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	56	 All results obtained from the mutant Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	57	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice were compared with both control (Cre+/ to  or wt) and COUP-TFII fl/wt mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	58	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice exhibit altered insulin secretion after glucose challenge.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Body weight, food intake, and body composition, as assessed by biphotonic absorptiometry, in Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	60	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice were comparable to the three groups of mice, suggesting that energy metabolism in these animals is not grossly abnormal (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	61	 However, a more detailed analysis of metabolic parameters in fasted and fed states revealed differences as shown in Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	62	 In the fasted state, Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	63	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice exhibited slightly lower plasma glucose (P  <  0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	64	01) and free fatty acids (but do not reach statistical significance) and higher plasma insulin (P  <  0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	65	01) than control and COUP-TFII fl/wt mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Despite the observed hypoglycemia, the plasma insulin-to-glucagon ratio was increased twofold in Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	67	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice compared with COUP-TFII fl/wt or wt mice (a ratio of 3 in Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	68	 In the fed state, plasma glucose was normal in Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	69	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice, while plasma insulin (P  <  0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	70	01) levels remain higher than in COUP-TFII fl/wt and control mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	71	 No difference was found in plasma leptin, total and HDL cholesterol, glycerol, and albumin levels among the three groups of mice (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	72	View larger version (44K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Plasma hormones and fuels, body composition, and food intake in wt, COUP-TFII fl/wt, and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	74	 ABody composition was assessed by biphotonic absorptiometry.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	75	 All data are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE (n = 12 mice/group).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	76	 COUP-TFII fl/wt and control mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	77	  Intraperitoneal glucose tolerance tests in overnight-fasted Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	78	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice showed pronounced glucose intolerance with markedly increased blood glucose levels during the first minutes following the glucose challenge (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Moreover, the plasma insulin levels at 20 min after glucose administration were found to be lower in the mutant mice (44  plus or minus  10  microU/ml) than in control mice (132  plus or minus  27  microU/ml) (P  <  0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	80	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice showed elevated basal plasma insulin levels during fasted and random-fed periods and reduced acute glucose-stimulated insulin secretion during intraperitoneal glucose tolerance tests.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	81	 To determine the role played by this intrinsic defect of glucose-dependent insulin secretion, the insulin secretion in isolated islets of Langerhans from Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	82	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice was investigated.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	83	View larger version (25K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Glucose intolerance and insulin sensitivity.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	85	 A: Glucose tolerance tests were performed on 16-week-old male wt, COUP-TFII fl/wt, and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	86	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice that had been fasted for 14 h.
