0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Values are expressed as nanomoles glucose incorporated into glycogen per milligram muscle protein per hour and are presented as means  plus or minus  SE of four (female) and three (male) muscles.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	96	  COUP-TFII haploinsufficiency leads to impaired insulin secretion in isolated islets.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	97	 To identify the consequence of COUP-TFII haploinsufficiency at the level of the ss-cell secretory function, we studied glucose- and L-arginine-induced insulin release in an islet perifusion protocol (15).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In the basal state, measured in 3 mmol/l glucose, Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	99	COUP-TFII fl/wt islets showed a trend (not significant) to release more insulin than the COUP-TFII fl/wt islets, especially at early time points in the perifusion protocol (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Upon glucose challenge, a profound defect in insulin release was observed.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In COUP-TFII fl/wt islets, glucose induced insulin release in a concentration-dependent manner between 5 and 10 mmol/l glucose; whereas, Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	102	COUP-TFII fl/wt islets showed virtually no response to 7.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	103	5 mmol/l glucose, while their response to 10 and 20 mmol/l glucose was only one-third of that seen in the control islets (Figs.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Finally, the insulin secretion in response to the combined stimulation of 20 mmol/l arginine with 10 mmol/l glucose was also significantly lower in the Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	105	 As the stimulation by arginine was similar in COUP-TFII fl/wt and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	106	 5B), we conclude that in Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	107	COUP-TFII fl/wt islets, the glucose-induced insulin secretion is specifically affected.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	108	View larger version (36K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Blunted glucose- and L-arginine-stimulated (Arg) insulin secretion in isolated Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	110	COUP-TFII fl/wt pancreatic islets.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	111	 A: Dynamic insulin secretory response to four successive nutrient stimulations (10 min each) alternating with basal (3 mmol/l) glucose.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	112	 B: Integrated insulin release above basal following each stimulation.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Results are expressed as mean insulin release (percent of islet insulin content)  plus or minus  SE (n = 4).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	114	  These abnormalities of the insulin secretion by COUP-TFII-deficient islets were not associated with altered islet morphology (data not shown).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Intensity of insulin and glucagon immunostaining appeared normal, as was the estimated size of the insulin storage pool (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	116	 In addition, the insulin and glucagon mRNA concentrations, assessed by semiquantitative RT-PCR (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	117	 7), were not changed in mutant mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	118	 This suggests that the reduced insulin release from Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	119	COUP-TFII fl/wt islets is unlikely to be caused by abnormalities in insulin or glucagon gene expression.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The ss-cell mass, estimated by quantitative morphometric analysis, showed no differences between wt, COUP-TFII fl/wt, and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	121	View larger version (10K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Pancreatic insulin content, ss-cell mass, and ss-cell density in 14-week-old mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Results are the mean values  plus or minus  SE for three to five animals per genotype.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	124	  The effects of COUP-TFII haploinsufficiency in ss-cells on the expression of genes critical for glucose sensing and insulin secretion were examined by semiquantitative RT-PCR experiments.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	125	 All the transcripts studied were similarly abundant in controls (wt and COUP-TFII fl/wt mice) and heterozygous mice, except the glucose-responsive gene encoding GLUT2, whose mRNA abundance was significantly increased (by 60%) in the islet cells of knockout animals (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The GLUT2 transporter has been shown to play a key role in murine ss-cells for glucose signaling to insulin secretion (16) but is not rate limiting for glucose entry to ss-cells (17).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Nevertheless, increased abundance of the GLUT2 mRNA in the islets of the Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	128	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice could result from a decreased repression by COUP-TFII, maybe acting as a hepatocyte nuclear factor (HNF)-4 competitor (7).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	129	 More biology of the ss-cell and genomewide expression analysis in purified pancreatic ss-cells will be necessary to enable us to further define more systematically potential mediators of glucose recognition in our model.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	130	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice exhibit altered insulin sensitivity in vivo.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Since altered insulin secretion can modify insulin sensitivity in vivo, an insulin tolerance test was performed showing that Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	132	COUP-TFII fl/wt animals were resistant to the glucose-lowering effect of exogenous insulin (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The normal insulin sensitivity of the COUP-TFII fl/wt mice allowed us to rule out a role of the hypomorphic floxed allele by itself.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Interestingly, in isolated soleus muscle, basal and insulin-stimulated glycogen synthesis is similar when wt is compared with COUP-TFII fl/wt or Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	135	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice, indicating that insulin resistance is unlikely a primary defect in skeletal muscle (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	136	 In addition, primary abnormalities in hepatocytes can be ruled out, since mice with the hepatocyte-specific conditional COUP-TFII gene inactivation exhibit normal insulin sensitivity (M.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	137	In conclusion, the observed insulin resistance in heterozygous mice could be, at least in part, the consequence of persistent higher insulin levels.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	138	 In some mice models and in humans, chronic hyperinsulinemia was shown to be a self-perpetuating cause of the defects in insulin action and not only a compensatory response to insulin resistance (18 to 21).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Our results demonstrate that a heterozygous COUP-TFII deletion in islet ss-cells leads to an impaired glucose sensitivity and then to an abnormal insulin secretion and secondary insulin resistance.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The results obtained in vivo and in isolated islets allow us to exclude any participation of the autonomic nervous system in the alteration of insulin secretion.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In addition, pleiotropic effects of reduced intracellular COUP-TFII activity on ss-cell metabolism, which may be detrimental to the generation of ATP, seem to be excluded since genes analyzed by RT-PCR show no major change in expression level.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Moreover, as COUP-TFII deficiency is genetically imposed upon ss-cells, we interpret the lack of -cell response to hypoglycemia as secondary e.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	143	, caused by a high rate of insulin release.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	144	 It is well known that ss-cells can suppress -cell function (22).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Tissue-specific deletion of HNF-3ss in pancreatic ss-cells in mice suggested in vivo coupling of -cell function to ss-cells (23).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	146	 It is worthy of note that the abnormalities due to a partial COUP-TFII deficiency in pancreatic ss-cells mimic some of the disorders observed in type 2 diabetic patients.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	147	Rip-Cre-mediated recombination of the COUP-TFII gene.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Transgenic mice expressing Cre recombinase under the control of rat insulin II promoter (Rip-Cre transgenic line [13,14]) were used to produce COUP-TFII ss-cell-specific inactivation.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	149	 The intercrossing COUP-TFII fl mice and Rip2-Cre mice were genotyped by PCR using the primers described above and primers against the Cre transgene and an internal upstream stimulatory factor 1 control as described previously (26).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Cre recombination efficiency was assessed on liver, brain, spinal cord, hypothalamus, and islet DNA prepared from isolated islets, as described below, and by PCR.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The first one, 5' to the loxP site (1), was located in the 5' noncoding region with the sequence TGA TTT CGA TGG CTT TCC TG, while the second primer (3) was located in exon 1 with the sequence CGG AGG AAC CTG AGC TAC AC.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The third primer in intron 1 (2) was located at the 3' of the loxP site with the sequence TGC CCA CAC TTT CCT ACT CC (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	153	 An 850 bp indicated an intact exon 1 from the fl allele, an 810 bp an intact exon 1 from the wt allele, while a 500 bp indicated Cre-mediated recombination.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	154	Analysis of COUP-TFII expression by Western blotting.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	155	 A total of 1,000 islets were cultured for 16 h in Ham s F10 medium containing 10 mmol/l glucose and 10% FCS.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Nuclear proteins were prepared as described (27), and 20  microg were subjected to a standard Western blot protocol using our COUP-TF-specific antibodies at a 1:1,000 dilution (11).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Control animals used in this study were either wt or Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Adult male mice were studied at 14 to 16 weeks of age.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Animals had free access to water and standard mouse diet.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	160	 All procedures were performed in accordance with the principles and guidelines established by the European Convention for the Protection of Laboratory Animals.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	161	 For glucagon, blood samples obtained by retroorbital phlebotomy were collected in tubes containing aprotinin, and radioimmunoassay was performed (Biochem ImmunoSystems-Pharmacia and Upjohn-France).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In a fed state, blood was collected at 9:30 P.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	163	 For fasting experiments, food was removed at 9:00 A.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	164	 and the mice were kept for 4 h before blood sampling.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Plasma insulin and leptin concentrations were assessed using a rat insulin enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kit (Crystal Chem, Chicago, IL) and a mouse leptin enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kit (Crystal Chem), respectively.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Plasma concentrations of triglycerides, free fatty acids, glycerol, total and HDL cholesterol, and albumin were determined using an automated Monarch device (Instrumentation Laboratory, Lexington, MA).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	167	Measurement of insulin release from perifused islets.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Isolation of islets of Langerhans, overnight culture, and measurement of insulin release were carried out as described previously (15).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Approximately 200 islets were loaded onto a Biogel P2 column and preperifused for 20 min in Ham s F10 medium, supplemented with 0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	170	5% BSA, 2 mmol/l glutamine, 2 mmol/l CaCl2, and 3 mmol/l glucose equilibrated with 95% air/5% CO2.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	171	5 ml/min, pulses of 10 min were given with 7.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	172	5, 10, and 20 mmol/l glucose and 10 mmol/l glucose with 20 mmol/l L-arginine.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Samples were collected every minute and assayed for immunoreactive insulin with guinea pig anti-insulin serum (Linco Research, St.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	174	 As islet insulin contents between models were similar, results were expressed as percentage of islet insulin content.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Insulin was extracted by sonicating the Biogel P2 containing the islets in 5 ml of 2 mmol/l acetic acid/0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	176	Immunohistochemistry, quantification of ss-cell mass, and ss-cell density.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	177	 ss-Cell mass was determined as described previously (28) by insulin immunostaining (Dako) on 10 subsequent sections of pancreas tissue separated by  > 50  microm followed by measurement of the surface area of the sections using Biocom VisioL@b 1000 software.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	178	 ss-Cell mass was calculated by multiplying the pancreatic weight by the relative ss-cell volume.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	179	 ss-Cell density was assessed by counting the number of nuclei in a 30,000- microm2 islet total area that contained only insulin-positive cells.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Values are the means  plus or minus  SE in five mice of each genotype.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Total pancreatic islet RNA isolated using Trizol (Gibco-BRL) were treated with RNase-free DNase-I before use for semiquantitative RT-PCR.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The PCR cycle numbers were estimated for each primer pair to assure linear range amplification.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	183	 All results were verified in seven control COUP-TFII fl/wt and mutant mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	184	 We quantified bands using a STORM850 PhosphoImager and Image-Quant 5.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	185	Determination of glycogen synthesis in isolated muscle.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The two soleus muscles were isolated as described previously (29) and incubated with or without 10 nmol/l insulin for 60 min at 37 degrees C in 1 ml of Krebs-Ringer bicarbonate buffer (pH 7.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	187	3) supplemented with 1% BSA and with 3-[3H] glucose (5 mmol/l, 1  microCi/ml).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Muscles were dissolved in 1 N NaOH, aliquots were spotted onto Whatmann paper, and the filters were washed three times in ice-cold 60% ethanol before counting.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Data are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE.

0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	208	Received for publication August 16, 2004 and accepted in revised form February 15, 2005.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	0	Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 enhances the Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1-mediated activation of transcription J.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	1	INSERM Unit 459, Laboratoire de Biologie Cellulaire, Faculte de Medecine H.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Warembourg, 1 Place de Verdun, F 59045 Lille, France.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	3	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Tel: +33 3 20 62 69 51; Fax: +33 3 20 62 68 84; Email: blaine{at}lille.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	5	Received March 2, 2004; Revised April 2, 2004; Accepted April 13, 2004.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	6	HNF1 contains two domains involved in DNA binding (an atypical homeodomain and a POU-like domain), an N-terminal dimerization domain and a C-terminal transactivation domain (1).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Several proteins interact with various HNF1 domains and play crucial roles in HNF1 function.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	8	 DcoH (Dimerization Cofactor of HNF1), is a small protein, which binds to the HNF1 dimerization domain and is involved in dimer stabilization (19).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The ability of various HNF1 domains to interact with multiple coactivators allows formation of a platform for recruitment of a transcriptional complex, leading to a strong enhancement of transcription.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	10	 CBP/p300 interacts with both the DNA binding domain and the activation domain of HNF1 while P/CAF, SRC-1 and RAC3 interact with the HNF1 activation domain (20,21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Each of these coactivators can independently increase activation of transcription by HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In addition, they cooperate with each other to further enhance the HNF1-mediated activation of transcription (21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	13	 HNF1 can also interact with GATA 4, GATA 5 and Cdx-2 transcription factors (22).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The interactions between HNF1, GATA5 and Cdx-2 lead to a cooperative enhancement of HNF1-mediated activation of transcription (22).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	15	 A synergy between HNF1 and neurogenin 3 was also recently reported (23).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	16	 HNF1 down regulates HNF4-mediated activation of transcription via a direct interaction of these transcription factors (8,9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	17	In this work, we show that HNF4 enhances the transcriptional activity of HNF1, and that the cooperation between both factors can be further enhanced by p300 recruitment.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	18	GST pull-down assays GST pull-down assays were performed as described previously (24) using [35S]methionine-labelled in vitro synthesized HNF1 or HNF4 and bacterially expressed GST-fusion proteins indicated in legends to figures.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	19	Cell culture and transient transfection assays HeLa cells (5.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	20	5 x 104 cells per 24-well dish) were grown and transfected as described by Eeckhoute et al.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	21	 (30) with plasmid amounts indicated in figure legends.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Luciferase activities were measured using the Bright-Glo Luciferase assay system (Promega).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	23	Western blotting Western blotting performed from whole-cell extracts and using the 455 HNF4 antiserum was carried out as indicated by Eeckhoute et al.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	24	Data analysis Statistical analyses were based on Student s t-test for unpaired data using Prism software.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Statistical significance was set at ***P  <  0.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	26	View larger version (20K):    Figure 1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	27	 HNF4 enhanced the HNF1-dependent activation of transcription.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	28	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of the HNF1-TATA promoter (A) or the ( to 96/+11) LPK promoter (B), 15 ng of HNF1 and 20 ng of HNF4 or RXRss expression plasmids, as indicated.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	29	 (C) HNF4 was unable to cooperate with the VP16 activation domain.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	30	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of the (GAL4)x5 TATA promoter, 5 ng of GAL4-VP16 and 20 ng of HNF4 expression vectors, as indicated.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In (A), (B) and (C), the total amounts of transfected DNA were equalized with the empty expression plasmids ( to ).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Fold induction refers to the basal activities of promoters (left columns).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	34	 of three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The extent of HNF4-mediated enhancement of HNF1-dependent activation of transcription is indicated (values above bars).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	36	 (D) In vitro interaction between HNF1 and HNF4 analysed by pull-down assays.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	37	 A schematic representation of the HNF1 and HNF1-AD proteins is presented, AD denotes activation domain.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	38	 [35S]methionine-labelled HNF1 or HNF1-AD was incubated with immobilized GST or GST-HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Bound proteins were analysed by SDS to PAGE and PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Inputs correspond to 10% of amounts of labelled proteins used in the assays.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	41	 (E) Requirement of the activation domains of HNF1 for the cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	42	 HeLa cells were transfected as in (A) with the indicated HNF1 constructs.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Fold induction refers to the basal activity of the promoter (left column).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	45	 of three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	46	  To control the possibility that HNF4 does not act as a transcriptional partner of another transcription factor, we analysed the effect of HNF4 on the VP16 activation domain fused to the GAL4 DBD (construct GAL4-VP16).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	47	 HNF4 was unable to enhance the VP16-mediated activation of transcription (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	48	 1C), thus indicating the selectivity of the cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	49	As predicted from the results of Ktistaki and Talianidis (9), we observed that full-length HNF1 and HNF4 physically interact (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Interestingly, pull-down experiments also showed that HNF1 lacking its activation domain (HNF1-AD) efficiently interacted with HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	51	 This result indicates that the sequence 1 to 291 of HNF1, containing the dimerization and DNA binding domains, is able to interact with HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	52	 This prompted us to investigate whether coexpression of HNF4 and HNF1-AD could activate the HNF1-TATA promoter.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Despite their efficient interaction, HNF1-AD and HNF4 were unable to activate transcription (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	54	 1E), thus indicating that cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4 requires the HNF1 activation domain.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	55	AF2 is not the only sequence within the HNF4 LBD required for interaction and cooperation with HNF1 The repressive action of HNF1 on HNF4 was unambiguously shown to require the HNF4 LBD (9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	56	 However, using truncated fragments of HNF4, Ktistaki and Talianidis mapped the sequence involved in the interaction with HNF1 between residues 337 and 368, leading to the conclusion that the HNF4 AF2 activation function is necessary and sufficient for interaction with HNF1 (9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	57	 In fact, this sequence does not contain solely the AF2 (sequence 358 to 366 corresponding to helix 12 of the LBD), but also a fragment forming part of the large helix termed H10 to H11, according to conventional nomenclature (31).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Indeed, H10 and H11 are contiguous in HNF4 and form a helix that plays a key role in HNF4 function (31).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Furthermore, the integrity of this helix is crucial for protein conformation (32).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	60	 These recent findings begged a re-evaluation of the HNF4 sequence involved in interaction with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Using full-length HNF4, we analysed the effects of point mutations located in the HNF4 LBD (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	62	 2A) on the interaction and cooperation with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The E262A mutation was shown to affect HNF4 dimerization (26).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The E276Q mutation does not alter the intrinsic HNF4 transcriptional activity but impairs recruitment of HNF4 transcriptional partners (24,33).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Owing to the bulky side chain of phenylalanine, the A223F mutation was hypothesized to affect occupancy of the ligand binding pocket by fatty acids that act as structural cofactors rather than as conventional ligands (31).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Accord ingly, A223F mutation mildly impaired HNF4 transcriptional activity and interaction with coactivators (data not shown).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	67	 In the AF2 module, the acidic group of the amino acid residue side chain at position 363 and the hydrophobic nature of the amino acid residue side chain at position 365 are strictly conserved and play a key role in nuclear receptor function (34).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Residue L366 is also important since the L366Q mutation alters HNF4 transcriptional activity (35).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Pull-down assays showed that introducing three mutations E363K, L365Q and L366Q in the AF2 (HNF4-AF2mut construct) altered interaction between HNF4 and HNF1 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Note however that the decrease in interaction was mild.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	71	 This result confirms the involvement of the AF2 in the interaction between HNF1 and HNF4 but indicates that this module is not the unique sequence required for interaction between these proteins.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Interaction with HNF1 was also significantly decreased by the A223F and E276Q mutations while mutation E262A had no effect (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Consistent with data from pull-down assays, the HNF4-mediated enhancement of HNF1-dependent transcriptional activation of the ( to 96/+11) LPK promoter was not impaired by the E262A mutation but was significantly decreased with the mutants A223F, E276Q and HNF4-AF2mut (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	74	 We controlled so that mutant and wild-type HNF4 were expressed at a similar level in transfected cells as shown in Figure 2D for mutants A223F and HNF4-AF2mut and in (24,26) for the mutant E276Q and E262A, respectively.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	75	 It appears therefore that the interaction and cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1 depend on both the AF2 module (helix 12) and the integrity of the HNF4 LBD.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	76	View larger version (23K):    Figure 2.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The AF2 is not the only sequence within the HNF4 LBD required for interaction and cooperation with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	78	 (A) Positions of mutations used in this study.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	79	 A scheme of HNF4 structure with the various domains is given: DBD, DNA binding domain; LBD, ligand binding domain; AF2, activation function 2 module.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	80	 (B) Effects of HNF4 mutations on the physical interaction with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	81	 [35S]methionine-labelled wild-type or mutated HNF4 were incubated with immobilized GST-HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Bound proteins were analysed by SDS to PAGE and PhosphorImager.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Values under photographs indicate binding of HNF4 mutants relative to that of wild-type HNF4 from three independent experiments.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Inputs, corresponding to 5% of amounts of labelled proteins used in the assays, were taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	85	 (C) Effects of HNF4 mutations on the cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1 on the ( to 96/+11) LPK promoter.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	86	 HeLa cells were transfected as in Figure 1B.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Fold induction refers to the basal activity of the promoter (left column).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	89	 of three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Statistical significance of differences with values obtained with wild-type HNF42 is indicated by stars (P  <  0.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	91	 (D) Western blotting of wild-type (WT), A223F and AF2mut HNF4 expressed in HeLa cells using the 455 HNF4 antiserum (43).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The star denotes a non-specific band obtained from HeLa cells transfected with the empty vector ( to ).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The number on the left indicates the molecular mass of a marker size in kDa.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	94	  HNF4 cooperates with the coactivator p300 to enhance HNF1 transcriptional activity Because CBP/p300 are key coactivators of HNF1, we hypothesized that cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1 could involve p300.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In the absence of HNF1, the coactivator p300 alone or coexpressed with HNF4 was unable to activate the HNF1-TATA promoter (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	96	 On this promoter, p300 slightly enhanced HNF1 transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Note that this moderate increase is due at least in part to the low ratio of p300/HNF1 expression vectors used in our experiments (3:1) compared to that used in other studies performed on other promoters [e.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	98	 We have verified that by using a higher ratio, we could obtain a stronger enhancement of HNF1 activity by p300 alone (data not shown).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Interestingly, in the presence of HNF4, p300 synergistically enhanced HNF1-mediated activation of transcription: the activity of the promoter was increased 18.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	100	7-fold higher than the additive value for the induction of HNF1 activity by p300 and HNF4 alone (1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The marked p300-mediated enhancement of cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4 could also be observed on the ( to 96/+11) LPK promoter (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	102	 On both promoters, the enhanced cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4 was significantly impaired by mutations in the HNF4 AF2 module (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	103	 These results strongly argue for the involvement of HNF4 in the p300-mediated activation of these promoters despite the absence of HNF4 response element in their sequences.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The result obtained with the HNF4-AF2mut led us to investigate whether mutations in AF2 affect p300 binding.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Pull-down experiments clearly showed a much weaker interaction of p300 with HNF4-AF2mut than with wild-type HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	106	 This result is in line with our previous observation that deletion of the AF2 resulted in a decrease in interaction (about 70%) between HNF4 and p300 (33).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Therefore, we cannot exclude that the impaired cooperativity of HNF4-AF2mut was also due to reduced p300 recruitment.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Because it has been documented that HNF4 and CBP/p300 form a transcriptionally active complex (36), we verified whether in our experimental conditions this complex was sufficient to achieve the strong cooperation.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	109	 This question was addressed by the use of human HNF1 promoter containing a HNF4 response element but lacking a HNF1 binding site.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Using the same p300/HNF4 expression vector amounts used in Figure 3A and B, cotransfection of p300 failed to strongly enhance the HNF4-mediated activation of transcription (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	111	 It appears therefore that the strong activation of transcription observed in Figure 3A and B requires a ternary complex including HNF1, HNF4 and p300.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	112	View larger version (16K):    Figure 3.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Involvement of p300 in the cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The cooperation was analysed on the HNF1-TATA and ( to 96/+11) LPK promoters, (A) and (B), respectively.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	115	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of promoter plasmids, 10 ng of HNF1, 15 ng of HNF4 or HNF4-AF2mut and 30 ng of p300 expression plasmids, as indicated.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Fold induction refers to the basal activity of the promoter (left column).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Values above bars indicate the enhancement of HNF1- mediated activation of transcription by HNF4 or p300 alone or in cooperation.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	119	 of three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	120	 (C) Effect of the mutations in the AF2 of HNF4 on its interaction with p300 analysed by pull-down assay.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	121	 [35S]Methionine-labelled HNF4 or HNF4-AF2mut were incubated with immobilized GST-p300(340 to 528).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Bound proteins were analysed by SDS to PAGE and PhosphorImager.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	123	 (D) HeLa cells were transiently transfected with expression vector amounts indicated in (A) and 250 ng of the human HNF1 promoter.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Fold induction, calculated from three experiments performed in triplicate refers to the basal activity of the promoter.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	125	  With the aim to investigate the mechanism underlying the p300-mediated enhancement of the cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4, we surveyed the p300 domains involved in interactions with these transcription factors.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Using a double hybrid approach, it was previously shown that the sequences 180 to 662 and 1818 to 2079 of p300 interact with the HNF1 transactivation domain (20).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Using GST pull-down assays, we mapped more precisely the amino-terminal sequence of p300 involved in interaction with full-length HNF1 between residues 340 and 528 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	128	 We also confirmed that full-length HNF1 interacts with the carboxy-terminal region of p300 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	129	 We have previously shown the ability of HNF4 to interact with the amino-terminal domain of p300 (33).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	130	 HNF4 also interacted with the p300 carboxy-terminal region as shown in Figure 4C.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The presence of multiple interaction surfaces between these proteins led us to analyse the effect of HNF4 on the recruitment of the amino- and carboxy-terminal regions of p300 to HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The strategy consisted of determining whether HNF4 affects the cooperation between HNF1 and the amino- or carboxy-terminal fragments of p300 fused to the VP16 activation domain named Np300-VP16 and Cp300-VP16, respectively (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Expression of the VP16 activation domain affected neither the basal activity of the promoter nor its activity in the presence of expression vectors for HNF1 alone or together with HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Expression of Np300-VP16 failed to affect the basal activity of the promoter and the HNF1-mediated activation of this promoter (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Similar results were obtained with expression of Cp300-VP16 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Conversely, in the presence of both HNF1 and HNF4, Np300-VP16 and Cp300-VP16 markedly enhanced the promoter activity (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	137	 These results indicate that, in a cellular context, p300 recruitment by the HNF1 to HNF4 complex can be mediated through both its amino- and carboxy-terminal regions and reinforce data obtained in Figure 3 suggesting that HNF4 improves p300 recruitment to a promoter containing a HNF1 binding site (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	138	View larger version (25K):    Figure 4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	139	 HNF4 enhanced the cooperation between HNF1 and p300 through interactions with both the amino- and carboxy-terminal sequences of the coactivator.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	140	 (A) Schematic representation of p300 fragments fused to either GST or the VP16 activation domain used in interaction studies with HNF1 and HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	141	 (B) Interaction of HNF1 with the amino-terminal domain of p300 analysed by pull-down assays.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	142	 [35S]Methionine-labelled HNF1 was incubated with immobilized GST, GST-p300(1 to 595) or GST-p300(340 to 528).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	143	 (C) Interaction of HNF1 and HNF4 with the carboxy-terminal domain of p300 analysed by pull-down assays.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	144	 [35S]Methionine-labelled HNF1 or HNF4 were incubated with immobilized GST or GST-p300(1572 to 2370).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	145	 In (B) and (C), bound proteins were analysed by SDS to PAGE and PhosphorImager.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	146	 (D) HNF4 potentiates enhancement of HNF1 activity by Np300- and Cp300-VP16.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	147	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of HNF1-TATA promoter, 10 ng of HNF1, 15 ng of HNF4 and 60 ng of VP16 or its empty vector (left), VP16 or Np300-VP16 (middle) and VP16 or Cp300-VP16 (right) expression plasmids.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In each case, the total amount of transfected DNA was kept constant using empty pcDNA3.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Fold induction refers to the basal activity of the promoter (left columns).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	151	 of at least three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	152	 (E) Mechanisms by which HNF4 could enhance HNF1 transcriptional activity.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The amino- and/or carboxy-terminal domains of p300 can be involved in p300-mediated activation of transcription.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	154	 HNF4 could enhance p300 recruitment through direct binding to these p300 fragments and/or through an indirect effect on the HNF1 to p300 interactions.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	155	 HNF4 could also help recruitment of other coactivators to the transcriptional complex.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	156	View larger version (11K):    Figure 5.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Cross-talk between HNF1 and HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The cross-talk involves both expression activation, through binding to promoters (solid lines), and modulation of the transcriptional potential, through protein to protein interactions (dotted lines), of the other HNF transcription factor.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	159	  Interplays between two transcription factors in both activation and repression of transcription have already been documented.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Indeed, cross-talk between HNF6 and HNF3ss, two other liver-enriched transcription factors, also results in opposite effects on the activities of these proteins (38).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	161	Despite their efficient interaction, HNF4 and HNF1 lacking its activation function (HNF1-AD) were unable to cooperate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Such a behaviour is reminiscent of that of CBP and P/CAF with HNF1 (1 to 280) (21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Only the simultaneous overexpression of CBP and P/CAF together with that of the truncated HNF1 could activate transcription (21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	164	 This points to a critical role for the HNF1 activation domain, which could be the recruitment of other required coactivators and/or stabilization of the transcriptional complex recruited by HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	165	Our results indicate that the HNF4 AF2 is involved in interaction with HNF1, but also that other regions of the HNF4 LBD are required for full interaction between these proteins.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Ktistaki and Talianidis previously stated that the HNF4 AF2 is sufficient for interaction with HNF1 (9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The discrepancy between their conclusion and our results is likely explained by the fact that these authors used deletion of a fragment (residues 337 to 368), which includes not only the AF2 but also part of the large helix H10 to H11, the integrity of which has meanwhile been shown to be crucial for the protein conformation (32).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	168	 We observed that two-point mutations in the HNF4 LBD, A223F and E276Q, significantly decreased interaction and cooperation with HNF1 thus demonstrating that the integrity of the HNF4 LBD is required for the synergy with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	169	The similarity of phenotypes exhibited by diabetic patients carrying MODY1 and MODY3 mutations has been ascribed to the mutual control of transcription of HNF1 and HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The ability of HNF4 to serve as an HNF1 coactivator could provide an additional explanation to the closely related phenotypes of these MODY forms of diabetes.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Impairment of interaction and of enhancement of HNF1 transcriptional activity by the HNF4 E276Q mutation may be physiologically relevant since this mutation is correlated with MODY1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Unfortunately, the low transfection efficiency and the presence of large amounts of endogenous HNF4 in pancreatic ss-cells prevented us from analysing the effects of this mutation on the synergy between HNF4 and HNF1 in these cells.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	173	Our results support a model that involves the combined action of HNF4 and the coactivator p300 to achieve the highest rate of transcription mediated by HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Our results also strongly suggest that HNF4 improves p300 recruitment.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The synergy between HNF4 and p300 may be mediated in two ways.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The first involves simultaneous interactions of HNF4 and p300 with HNF1 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	177	 In this case, HNF4 could indirectly improve HNF1 to p300 interaction through induction of a HNF1 conformational change.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Such a mechanism is reminiscent of that of the CBP-mediated improvement of the interaction between HNF1 and P/CAF (21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Similarly, upon docking to PPAR, PGC-1 undergoes a conformational change that permits binding of SRC-1 and p300 (39).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The second involves docking of p300 by HNF4, which is bound to HNF1 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The recruitment of p300 to the HNF1 to HNF4 complex could be mediated by its amino- and/or carboxy-terminal regions, which contain the C/H1 and C/H3 domains, respectively.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	182	 These domains are known to be involved in protein to protein interactions (40).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The presence of multiple interaction surfaces in HNF1, HNF4 and p300 most probably facilitates formation of a ternary complex formed with these proteins (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The remaining synergy between HNF1 and HNF4 after mutations in the HNF4 AF2 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	185	 3) may be accounted for by the ability of p300 to interact and activate the HNF4 AF1 (33,41) and by the fact that the two above mentioned mechanisms may not be mutually exclusive.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	186	In conclusion, our results highlight a new way by which HNF4 can regulate gene expression.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	187	 HNF4 not only directly binds to promoters but also, through interaction with other transcription factors already bound to DNA, can facilitate coactivator recruitment to further enhance transcription.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Recently, it has been shown that HNF4 also serves as coactivator for Sterol Regulatory Element-Binding protein-2 (42).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Furthermore, our results yield insights into a higher complexity of the transcriptional network and on the primordial relationship between HNF1 and HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	190	 In the regulatory loop between HNF1 and HNF4, HNF4 can activate both HNF1 expression and transcriptional activity.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	191	 In contrast to these additive processes, the negative effect of HNF1 on HNF4 transcriptional activity can attenuate the HNF1-mediated activation of expression.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	192	 These regulatory feedback mechanisms will have to be taken into account considering that HNF1 and HNF4 are involved in a large diversity of pathways controlling function of multiple organs, notably liver and endocrine pancreas.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	193	 (1998) Regulation of a transcription factor network required for differentiation and metabolism.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	194	 (2002) A genetic switch in pancreatic beta-cells: implications for differentiation and haploinsufficiency.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	195	 (2001) Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4alpha.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	196	 (eds), Nuclear Receptors and Genetic Disease.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Academic Press, San Francisco, CA, pp.

0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	0	Identification of Critical Residues for Heterodimerization within the Ligand-Binding Domain of Retinoid X Receptor Soo-Kyung Lee, Soon-Young Na, Han-Jong Kim, Jaemog Soh, Hueng-Sik Choi and Jae Woon Lee.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	1	L) Chonnam National University Kwangju 500 to 757, Korea.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	2	Some orphan nuclear receptors bind DNA as homodimers.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	3	 In contrast with the steroid receptor homodimers, orphan receptor homodimers can bind to both palindromic and DR-response elements.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	4	 In particular, the hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) binds as a homodimer to DR1 and is a strong constitutive transcriptional activator (11).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In contrast with HNF4, homodimers of the chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factors (COUP-TFs) such as EAR2, EAR3, and ARP1 are potent dominant repressors of both basal transcription and transactivation by several receptors, including RXR, RAR, VDR, and TR (12).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Repression of these pathways by COUP-TF is believed to be accomplished in part by direct competitive binding and by the presence of a strong carboxy-terminal repressor domain (13).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Interestingly, COUP-TF has an ability to heterodimerize with RXR, thereby titrating RXR into a transcriptionally inactive complex (14).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	8	A dimerization interface has previously been identified within the DNA binding domains (DBDs) of RXRs, RARs, VDR, and TRs that selectively promotes DNA binding to cognate direct repeat HREs (15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	9	 An additional dimerization interface that mediates cooperative binding to DNA, referred to as the I-box, has recently been mapped to a 40-amino acid region within the carboxy-terminal ligand binding domains (LBDs) of RAR, TR, COUP-TF, and RXR (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In contrast to the interface within the DBDs, this dimerization motif promotes cooperative binding with similar efficiency to all three classes of repeats, DR, IR, and ER.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The two dimerization domains appear to work in sequence and led to a two-step hypothesis for binding of heterodimers to DNA (2, 21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Accordingly, the LBD dimerization interface initiates the formation of solution heterodimers that, in turn, acquire the capacity to bind to a number of differently organized repeats.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	13	 However, formation of a second dimer interface within the DBD restricts receptors to bind to DRs.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	14	A dimerization interface referred to as the I-box has recently been mapped to a 40-amino acid region within the carboxy-terminal LBDs of RAR, TR, COUP, and RXR (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The I-box sequences are moderately conserved among a subset of nuclear receptors including the homodimerizing HNF4, leading us to test whether the HNF4 I-box region plays a similar role in the homodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	16	 To this end, we constructed a series of chimeras between HNF4 and RXR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	17	 PCR was used to construct B42/HNF, a chimeric protein consisting of the B42 transactivation domain fused to the entire hinge and LBDs (D, E and F, amino acids 106 to 455) of the rat HNF4 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Chimeric receptors B42/H/X-298/389, B42/H/X-338/429, B42/X-HHH, B42/H-XXX, and B42/X/H-428/339 were similarly constructed (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Western blot analyses were executed to confirm that expression levels for all the mutants constructed were comparable (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	20	 LexA/HNF4 showed some constitutive transcriptional activity in yeast, which was approximately 3.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	21	5-fold higher than that of LexA alone (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	22	 1B, coexpression of B42/HNF led to approximately 5.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	23	5-fold enhancement of this constitutive activity, faithfully reflecting the HNF4-HNF4 homodimeric interactions in this yeast system.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Furthermore, coexpression of B42/H/X-338/429 or B42/X-HHH led to approximately 4- and 7-fold enhancements of the transcriptional activity of LexA/HNF4, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In contrast, the RXR I-box could not substitute the HNF4 I-box for the homodimeric interactions, as shown by inabilities of B42/H/X-298/389, B42/H-XXX, and B42/X/H-428/339 to enhance the transcriptional activity of LexA/HNF4.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	26	 These results demonstrate that the HNF4 I-box is indeed a sufficient and transferable interaction interface for the homodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	27	View larger version (34K):    Figure 1.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The I-box Directs Specificity in Dimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	29	A, Schematic diagrams for chimeric nuclear receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Diagram shows chimeras containing the indicated amino acids derived from RXR (open) and HNF4 (stippled), where the I-box domains are highlighted (dotted in RXR and hatched in HNF4).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Numbers refer to the amino acid boundaries of the receptor fragments consisting of the hinge and ligand binding D/E domains, the I-box domain, and the C-terminal F domain.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	32	 B, Dimerization probed by the yeast two-hybrid system.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Host cells in which ss-galactosidase expression is dependent on the presence of a transcriptional activator with a LexA DBD were transformed with plasmids expressing the indicated LexA or B42 chimeras and grown in liquid culture containing galactose, since expression of the B42 chimeras is under the control of the galactose-inducible GAL1 promoter (22).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	34	 ss-Galactosidase readings were determined and corrected for cell density and for time of development (A415 nm/A600 nm) x 1000/min.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Fold-activations by each B42 chimera are calculated by defining the reporter activity in the presence of B42/- as 1.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The result is the average of at least six different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	37	  As expected, B42/RXR was able to interact with LexA/RAR and LexA/TR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	38	 1B), and similar results were observed with chimeric receptors containing the RXR I-box sequences such as B42/H/X-298/389, B42/H-XXX, and B42/X/H-428/339 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In these interactions, LexA/RAR, which includes a full-length RAR in contrast to LexA/TR and other LexA chimeras consisting of only LBDs, shows higher ss-Gal activities than LexA/TR, probably due to the AF1 activation domain in the RAR A/B domains (25).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Since LexA/TR and LexA/RAR show similar basal activities in yeast, this difference results in higher fold-activations with LexA/RAR than LexA/TR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	41	 For instance, coexpression of B42/RXR conferred approximately 44-fold activation to LexA/RAR and approximately 11-fold activation to LexA/TR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	42	 It is noteworthy that incorporation of only the RXR I-box sequences conferred to the resulting chimera the ability to heterodimerize with RAR and TR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	43	 1B, compare interactions with B42/HNF and B42/H-XXX).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Thus, we conclude that the RXR I-box was indeed a transferable interaction interface for heterodimerization, as reported previously (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	45	Localization of a Critical Region of the RXR I-Box for Heterodimerization As shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	46	 2, there is a high degree of sequence homology between the RXR I-box and the HNF4 I-box sequences.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Nevertheless, the HNF4 I-box directs homodimerization, while the RXR I-box directs heterodimerization (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Thus, we set out to dissect the RXR I-box region to identify sequences critical for heterodimerization by sequentially transferring part of the RXR I-box sequences into corresponding regions of the HNF4, or vice versa.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	49	View larger version (23K):    Figure 2.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Amino Acid Sequences of the I-Box Region.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	51	The I-box regions of USP (amino acids 429 to 468), human RXR (amino acids 389 to 428), and rat HNF4 (amino acids 299 to 338) are shown.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Helix 9 (H9) and helix 10 (H10), which were recently shown to constitute an interaction interface in the crystal structure of the RXR LBD (27), as well as the three most C-terminal (7, 8, 9) of the nine heptad repeats previously shown to be involved in dimerization (30 to 32), are indicated.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Sequence homology determined with the NIH BLAST program is indicated between sequences of two receptors, in which + indicates conservative changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Amino acids that are conserved between USP and RXR but not in HNF4 are shaded.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Three artificial blocks designated to facilitate subsequent chimera constructions are boxed.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	56	  Examination of the I-box sequences reveals a high level of conservation between RXR and its Drosophila counterpart ultraspiracle (USP) (26), which heterodimerizes with many different members of the superfamily.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Therefore, amino acids of the I-box critical for heterodimerization should be conserved between RXR and USP (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	58	 To facilitate analyses, we artificially divided the I-box region into three separate subregions each containing two to four residues that are conserved betwen RXR and USP but not in HNF4 (shaded in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	59	 These subregions were sequentially exchanged between B42/HNF and B42/X/H-428/339, resulting in a series of eight B42-fusion constructs shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Western blot analyses were executed to confirm that expression levels for all the mutants constructed were comparable to each other (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	61	View larger version (39K):    Figure 3.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	62	 An 11-Amino Acid Subregion of the RXR I-Box Directs the Heterodimeric Interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	63	A, Schematic diagrams for chimeric nuclear receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Diagram shows chimeras containing the indicated amino acids derived from RXR (dotted) and HNF4 (hatched).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Three smaller areas (stippled) around the three blocks subjected to exchanges are identical between RXR and HNF4, as shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	66	 B, Dimerization properties of each chimera with LexA/HNF4, LexA/TR, and LexA/RAR were probed by the yeast two-hybrid system, as described in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Fold-activations by each B42 chimera are calculated by defining the reporter activity in the presence of B42/- as 1.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The result is the average of at least six different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	69	 3B, two things were evident from analyses of these chimeric receptors in the yeast two-hybrid system (22, 23, 24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	70	 First, none of the chimeric receptors was able to enhance the constitutive transcriptional activities of the LexA/HNF4, demonstrating that substitution of any of these HNF4 subregions with that of the RXR I-box blocked homodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	71	 This suggests that important residues for the homodimeric interactions are present throughout the entire HNF4 I-box.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Second, the C-terminal 11-amino acid subregion of the RXR I-box was sufficient to direct chimeric receptors to heterodimerize with RARs or TRs; i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	73	 B42/H-HHX, B42/X-HHX, B42/H-XHX, and B42/X-XHX efficiently interacted with LexA/RAR and LexA/TR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	74	Identification of Critical Amino Acids Responsible for Heterodimerization As shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	75	 4, the 11-amino acid subregion of RXR is identical to that of HNF4 with the exception of five residues (RXR A416, K417, R421, A424, and R426).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Among these, RXR K417, A424, and R426 (indicated by arrowheads in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	77	 4) are conserved changes from HNF4: i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	78	 HNF4 has glutamic acid, threonine, and glutamine (HNF4 E327, T334, and Q336) at these positions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	79	 However, RXR A416 and R421 (shaded in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	80	 4) that are conserved in USP are nonconserved changes from HNF4: i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	81	 HNF4 has glycine and leucine (HNF4 G326 and L331) at these positions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	82	 In contrast, COUP-TFs have glycine and arginine, and RARs and TRs have proline and lysine at these positions (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Accordingly, these two residues were identified as primary candidates for determining the heterodimerizing properties of the RXR I-box and subjected to mutational analyses.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	84	View larger version (21K):    Figure 4.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Amino Acid Sequences of the 11-Amino Acid Subregion of Various Receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	86	Rat HNF4 (amino acids 326 to 336), human RXR (amino acids 416 to 426), USP (amino acids 456 to 466), human COUP-TF (amino acids 363 to 373), human RAR (amino acids 375 to 385), and rat TRss (amino acids 419 to 429) are shown.

0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Three amino acids that are conserved changes between RXR and HNF4 are indicated as open arrows.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	89	 5A, we introduced a series of point-mutations into the 11-amino acid subregion in the context of HNF4 resulting in three quadruple mutants (AR-AR, AR-KR, and AR-KA), three triple mutants (AR-K, AR-A, and AR-R), two double mutants (AR and PR), and three single mutants (A326, P326, and R331).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Interactions of these point-mutants with LexA/HNF4 were largely unaffected among single, double, and triple mutants with an exception of AR-K, as shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	91	 All the quadruple mutants were not able to interact with LexA/HNF4 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In contrast, quadruple mutants AR-KA and AR-KR showed relatively strong interactions with LexA/RAR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Quaduple mutant AR-AR, all the triple mutants, double mutant AR, and, most surprisingly, two single mutants (A326 and R331) were also able to interact with LexA/RAR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	94	 These interactions were relatively weak, but highly specific, as these mutants did not show any interactions with LexA/GR either in the presence or absence of its ligand, deoxycortisol (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Addition of the RAR ligands, all-trans-retinoic acid or 9-cis-retinoic acid, did not affect the interactions (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The inherently weaker interactions of LexA/TR with the heterodimerizing chimeras, however, were not evident with these point-mutants.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In contrast, as expected from their RAR-based mutations, P326 and PR that incorporate both P326 and R331 were not able to stimulate ss-galactosidase activities above that of B42/HNF when coexpressed with LexA/RAR (Fig.

0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Equivalent amounts (10  microg) of crude extracts for these samples as well as null extracts were examined using an antibody directed against Flu-tag, as described previously (22).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	111	  To confirm the interactions observed in yeasts, we incubated a glutathione S-transferase (GST) alone, GST-HNF, GST-RXR, GST-H-HHX, GST-AR, GST-A326, or GST-R331 with TR-LBD labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	112	 All the point-mutants were identical to GST-HNF except the indicated amino acid changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	113	 6, TR-LBD bound specifically to GST-RXR and GST-H-HHX, but not to GST-HNF or GST alone, independently confirming the yeast results.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In addition, TR-LBD was able to show relatively week but specific binding to GST-AR, GST-A326, and GST-R331.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	115	 In yeasts, these weak interactions were only evident with LexA/RAR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	116	 5), probably due to the AF1 activation domain in the A/B domains (25).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	117	 As expected, luciferase labeled with [35S]methionine interacted with none of the GST proteins.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Similar results were also obtained with RAR-LBD labeled with [35S]methionine (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Overall, these results, along with the yeast results, indicate that the RXR amino acids A416 and R421 are most critical to determine identity in the heterodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	120	View larger version (35K):    Figure 6.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	121	Luciferase and TR-LBD labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation were incubated with glutathione beads containing GST alone, GST fusions to HNF4-LBD (GST/HNF), RXR-LBD (GST/RXR), H-HHX (GST/H-HHX), A326 (GST-A326), R331 (GST/R331), and AR (GST/AR).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	122	 All the point mutants are identical to HNF4-LBD except the indicated amino acid changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Beads were washed, and specifically bound material was eluted with reduced glutathione and resolved by SDS-PAGE.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	124	The results described here define an 11-amino acid subregion of the I-box as a major determinant of dimerization specificity.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	125	 This is consistent with the fact that this subregion is contained within H10 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	126	 2), a major interface in the recently described crystal structure of the RXR LBD (27) and overlaps with heptad 9 previously shown to be critical for both homo- and heterodimerization of RXR (30, 31, 32).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	127	 We also found that a chimeric RAR construct containing the RXR 11-amino acid subregion readily interacted with RAR, lending further support for the importance of this subregion for the heterodimeric interactions (our unpublished results).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Within this subregion, RXR amino acids A416 and R421 are particularly critical, consistent with the fact that these two residues are conserved between RXR and USP, but not in the homodimerizing HNF4.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	129	 4, HNF4 has glycine and leucine, while COUP-TF has glycine and arginine at these positions, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	130	 In contrast, RAR and TR, heterodimeric partners of RXR, have proline and lysine at these positions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	131	 As expected, mutant HNF4s incorporating only the RXR A416 or R421 heterodimerized with RAR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	132	 However, these and other HNF4 point-mutants we constructed showed distinct interactions with different receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	133	 R331, which resembles COUP-TF at the two target positions, weakly interacted with LexA/RXR (data not shown), consistent with a recent finding in which COUP-TF was shown to have an ability to heterodimerize with RXR (14).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In contrast, PR, which resembles RAR and TR at these positions, did not interact with LexA/RXR (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Similarly, AR with the RXR sequences at these two positions interacted less efficiently with LexA/RAR than single mutants A326 or R331 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Overall, these results suggest that the two residues (RXR A416 and R421) are clearly important for identity in heterodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Finally, it should be noted that changes of these two residues alone were not sufficient to switch specificity in the dimeric interactions (i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	138	 from homodimerization to heterodimerization).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The change of specificity in dimerization was achieved with at least three mutations incorporated, as shown by AR-K, which weakly interacts with LexA/RAR, but not with LexA/HNF (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Similarly, all the quadruple mutants changed specificity in dimerization (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	141	 5B; compare results with LexA/HNF4 and LexA/RAR).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	142	 It is also noteworthy that the effects of substitutions with the corresponding RXR sequences on the heterodimerizing potential of the resulting HNF4 chimeras are largely accumulative: i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	143	 A326, R331, AR, AR-K, AR-A, AR-R, and AR-AR show relatively weak fold-activations with LexA/RAR (3- to 7-fold, as shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	144	 5B), while the quadruple mutants AR-KR and AR-KA, as well as the quintuple mutant B42/H-HHX (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	145	 3B), which incorporates all the five RXR amino acids of the 11-amino acid subregion, showed much stronger fold activations with LexA/RAR (23-, 21-, and 43-fold activations, respectively).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Accordingly, identity seems to be determined in the context of the overall structures in relation to neighboring residues, rather than solely by nature of the two residues.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In addition, it will be interesting to test effects of the identified mutations in the context of full-length receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	148	In conclusion, we have identified an 11-amino acid subregion of the RXR I-box as a critical domain for the heterodimeric interactions and specifically identified two residues in this subregion as determinants of heterodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Recently, we introduced random mutations into these two residues of RXR in an effort to make mutant RXR more selective in the process of heterodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Consistent with the importance of these residues in heterodimerization, we were indeed able to find a series of mutant RXRs with significantly altered specificity (S.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	151	 To understand in detail how these two residues fit into the overall structure of the I-box in each nuclear receptor and how they direct specificity in dimerization, more mutational studies as well as more structural information will be required.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	152	Yeast Cells, Plasmids, and Expressions EGY48 cells [MATleu2-his3-trp1-ura3-LEU2::pLexA-op6 LEU2(UASLEU2)], the lexA-ss-galactosidase reporter construct, and the LexA- and B42-parental vectors were as reported (22).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	153	 LexA or B42 fusions to the full-length RAR and the LBDs of GR, RXR, HNF4, and TR were as previously described (23, 24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Two subsequent PCR steps according to a strategy that has been described (33) were employed for all the following plasmid constructions, by using Vent Polymerase (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA) capable of proofreading to minimize unwanted mutations.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	155	 A forward vector primer (B42 primer; 5'-GCC TCC TAC CCT TAT GAT-3') plus a reverse mutagenic primer (5'-CTT GAT CTT CCC GGG GTC ACT CAG-3') and a forward mutagenic primer (5'-CTG AGT GAC CCC GGG AAG ATC AAG-3') plus a reverse vector primer (ADH primer; 5'-GAC AAG CCG ACA ACC-3') were used to amplify B42/HNF-wild type as a template DNA at annealing temperature of 55 C.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Both PCR products were mixed in an equal molar ratio and amplified using the B42 and ADH vector primers.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Accordingly, B42/HNF includes a SmaI site just upstream of the HNF4 I-box, in which codons for amino acids Pro 296 (CCA) and Gly 297 (GGC) were silently changed to CCC (Pro) and GGG (Gly) to facilitate further subclonings.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	158	 B42/H/X-298/389 encodes rat HNF4 amino acids 106 to 298 followed by human RXR amino acids 389 to 462 to the C terminus.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Similarly, B42/H/X-338/429 encodes HNF4 amino acids 106 to 338 followed by RXR amino acids 429 to 462 to the C-terminus.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	160	 B42/X-HHH is identical to B42/RXR except that RXR amino acids 389 to 428 were replaced by HNF4 amino acids 299 to 338.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	161	 B42/H-XXX is identical to B42/HNF except that HNF4 amino acids 299 to 338 were replaced by RXR amino acids 389 to 428.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	162	 B42/X/H-428/339 encodes RXR amino acids 198 to 428 followed by HNF4 amino acids 339 to 455 to the C terminus.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	163	 B42/H-XHH is identical to B42/HNF except that HNF4 amino acids 299- 308 were replaced by RXR amino acids 389 to 398.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Similarly, B42/H-HXH is identical to B42/HNF except that HNF4 amino acids 312 to 322 were replaced by RXR amino acids 402 to 412, while B42/H-HHX is identical to B42/HNF except that HNF4 amino acids 326 to 336 were replaced by RXR amino acids 416 to 426.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	165	 B42/H-XHX is identical to B42/H-HHX except that HNF4 amino acids 299 to 308 were further replaced by RXR amino acids 389 to 398.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	166	 B42/X-XHH, B42/X-HXH, B42/X-HHX, and B42/X-XHX are identical to B42/H-XHH, B42/H-HXH, B42/H-HHX, and B42/H-XHX, respectively, except that HNF4 amino acids 106 and 299 were replaced by RXR amino acids 198 to 389.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	167	 A326 and P326 are identical to B42/HNF except that amino acid Gly 326 was replaced by Ala and Pro, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	168	 R331 is identical to B42/HNF except that amino acid Leu 331 was replaced by Arg.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	169	 AR and PR are identical to R331 except that amino acid Gly 326 was further replaced by Ala and Pro, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	170	 AR-R, AR-A, and AR-K are identical to AR except that amino acids Gln 336, Thr 334, and Glu 327 were replaced by Arg, Ala, and Lys, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	171	 AR-AR is identical to AR-A except that amino acid Gln 336 was replaced by Arg.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Similarly, AR-KR and AR-KA are identical to AR-K except that amino acid Gln 336 and Thr 334 were further replaced by Arg and Ala, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	173	 All the constructs described here were sequenced to prevent any unwanted PCR mutations.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	174	 In addition, expression levels of all the B42 chimeras were determined using a monoclonal antibody directed against Flu-tagging (gift of Dr.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Kyung-Lim Lee) that resides just upstream of the B42 transactivation domain, as described (22).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	176	 HNF4 sequences from B42/HNF, B42/RXR, B42/H-HHX, A326, R331, and AR were transferred to pGEX4T1 (Pharmacia, Piscataway, NJ) to express GST fusions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Vector for in vitro translation of the TR-LBD was as previously described (24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	178	Yeast ss-Galactosidase Assays The cotransformation and transactivation assays in yeast were performed as described previously (23).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Quantitative liquid ss-galactosidase assays were performed with the following changes as described (23).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The yeast culture was initially diluted to an A600 nm of 0.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	181	05 and plated into 96-well culture dishes with the various concentrations of hormone.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The cultures were then incubated in the dark at 30 C for 16 h.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The A600 nm was determined, and then cells were lysed and substrate was added and A415 nm was read after 10 to 30 min.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The normalized galactosidase values were determined as follows: (A415 nm/A600 nm) x 1000/min developed.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	185	 For each experiment, at least six independently derived colonies expressing chimeric receptors were tested.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	186	Pull-Down Assays GST fusion proteins were produced in Escherichia coli and purified using glutathione-Sepharose affinity chromatography essentially as described (24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	187	 GST proteins were bound to glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads (Pharmacia) in binding buffer (50 mM KPO4, pH 6.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	188	0, 100 mM KCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 10% glycerol, 10 mg/ml E.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Beads were washed once with binding buffer and incubated for 60 min at 4 C in the same buffer with equivalent amounts of various proteins labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Nonbound proteins were removed by three washes with binding buffer without E.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	191	 coli extract, and specifically bound proteins were eluted with 50 mM reduced glutathione in 0.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Eluted proteins were resolved by PAGE and visualized by fluorography.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	193	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Dr.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Kyung-Lim Lee for Flu-antibody and Drs.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Moore for rat HNF4 cDNAs and critical reading of this manuscript.
