0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	0	Orphan Receptors Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor II (COUP-TFII) and Retinoid X Receptor (RXR) Activate and Bind the Rat Cholesterol 7-Hydroxylase Gene (CYP7A)*.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	1	(Received for publication, November 5, 1996, and in revised form, February 4, 1997).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	2	Diane Stroup , Maurizio Crestani and John Y.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	3	The cholesterol 7-hydroxylase gene (CYP7A) is transcriptionally regulated by a number of factors, including hormones, bile acids, and diurnal rhythm.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Previous studies have identified a region from nucleotides (nt) 74 to 55 of the rat CYP7A promoter that enhanced bile acid repression of the SV40 early promoter, as assayed with a luciferase reporter gene in transiently transfected HepG2 cells.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The rat CYP7A promoter/reporter activity was strongly stimulated by cotransfection with an expression plasmid encoding the nuclear hormone receptor chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor II (COUP-TFII) in a dose-dependent manner.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Site-directed mutagenesis in the region of nt 74 to 55 altered this stimulation.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Recombinant COUP-TFII expressed in HepG2 or COS-1 cells were found to bind to nt 74 55 and nt 149 128 probes by electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) and by supershifting the corresponding band with COUP-TFII-specific antibodies.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The region of nt 176 117 was previously mapped as a retinoic acid response region and was found to bind retinoid X receptor (RXR).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	9	 EMSA supershift assays of wild-type and mutant oligomers using antibody against RXR revealed that the sequences between nt 145 and 134 were important for RXR binding.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We conclude that COUP-TFII stimulates the transcriptional activity of the rat CYP7A promoter by binding to the sequences between nt 74 to 54 and nt 149 to 128.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	11	 RXR may stimulate CYP7A gene transcription by binding to a direct repeat of the hormone response element separated by one nucleotide located at nt 146 134.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	12	Cholesterol 7-hydroxylase (EC 1.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	13	17) catalyzes the first and rate-limiting step in a pathway that converts cholesterol to bile acids.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The catabolism of cholesterol to bile acids in the liver is the main mechanism for elimination of cholesterol from the body and thus plays an important role in maintaining cholesterol homeostasis (1).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The gene CYP7A is transcriptionally regulated by a number of factors, including bile acids, cholesterol, hormones, and circadian rhythm (2-6).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	16	The CYP7A promoter structure is typical of a DNA-dependent RNA polymerase II promoter in that, upstream of the TATA box, there are several cis-acting elements that regulate the transcriptional activity of this promoter (7-9).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Transient transfection assay of chimeric CYP7A promoter/luciferase constructs in HepG2 cells revealed that the region from nt 416 to +32 of the rat CYP7A gene contained the promoter and regulatory domains conferring the activation of transcription by dexamethasone and retinoic acid and suppression by bile acids, phorbol esters, and insulin (2, 3, 9, 10).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	18	 We have mapped two footprints that are protected from DNase I digestion using rat liver nuclear extracts (11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Footprint (Fp)1 A is located between nt 81 and 35, and FpB is located between nt 148 and 129.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Nucleotide sequences in these two regions are highly conserved among homologous CYP7A genes of different species.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These footprints contain liver-enriched transcription factors binding sites and hormone response elements.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	22	 A putative bile acid response element (BARE) was mapped to the FpA region, which lead us to propose that a bile acid responsive nuclear receptor may be mediating bile acid response (11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	23	The molecular mechanism of bile acid repression is still unknown.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Determining what factors interact with these BARE sequences is a first step in elucidating the nature of the bile acid response.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	25	 A nuclear protein factor, which was found to bind a repeated sequence -65TCAAGTTCAAG-54 was named direct repeat binding protein (DRBP).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Binding of DRBP to BARE was diminished when liver nuclear extract prepared from rats fed deoxycholate was used in EMSA (11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The sequence from nt 73 to 57 contains an imperfect direct repeat of the hormone response element (HRE, AGGTCA) separated by four nucleotides (DR4).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	28	 According to the 3-4-5 rule for the binding specificity of the steroid/thyroid hormone family of transcription factors (12), a DR4 would be predicted to act as a thyroid hormone response element, hence "7TRE" as the tentative name for this DR4 sequence (11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	29	 However, CYP7A promoter constructs containing these sequences did not respond to thyroid hormones in HepG2 cells (2).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	30	 A number of nuclear factors have affinity for DR4 sequences, including TR, XONR, and LXR that form heterodimers with RXR (13, 14).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	31	 COUP-TFII (or ARP-1) of orphan nuclear receptor family with promiscuous binding specificities also bind a DR4 sequence (15, 16).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	32	 COUP-TFs are believed to influence developmental changes, which is supported by the report that the COUP-TFII promoter responds to differentiation signal, retinoic acid (17).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Recently, we have mapped a complex retinoic acid response region located between 176 and 117 of the rat CYP7A promoter (10).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	34	Using transient transfection assay of CYP7A promoter/reporter activity in HepG2 cells, we have screened a number of known steroid/thyroid hormone nuclear receptors for their effects on gene transcription.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	35	 COUP-TFII produced one of the strongest effects on transcription.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Here, we provide evidence that orphan receptor COUP-TFII activates transcription of rat CYP7A by binding to nt 74 to 54 and to nt 149 to 128 and that an RXR homodimer may bind to a DR1 motif between 146 to 134.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	37	DNA oligomers were synthesized by National Biosciences (Plymouth, MN) or Life Technologies, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	38	 DNA restriction and modifying enzymes, reporter lysis buffer, luciferase assay system, and the reporter vectors pGL2-Basic and pGL2-Promoter were purchased from Promega (Madison, WI).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The radioactive isotopes [-32P]dCTP (3000 Ci/mol) and [-35S]dATP (1200 Ci/mmol) Sequenase sequencing grade were obtained from ICN (Costa Mesa, CA) and DuPont NEN, respectively.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The DNA purification systems used were the GeneClean kit, from BIO 101, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	41	 (La Jolla, CA), and the Qiagen plasmid kit, acquired from Qiagen Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Expression plasmids for the transcription factors were the generous gifts of Dr.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Chen for pLen4S (HNF4) and pL-H3 (HNF3), Dr.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Johnson for pMEXC/EBP (C/EBP) and pMEXCRP2.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Antiserum against COUP-TFII was a kind gift of Dr.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Affinity-purified rabbit polyclonal antibodies against RAR (sc-773; cross-reacts with RAR 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, and 2 isoforms), RXR (sc-774; cross-reacts with RXR , , and  isoforms), C/EBP (sc-61), and c-erbA1 (sc-76) were obtained from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Other reagents were from Sigma.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	48	The human hepatoma cell line (HepG2, ATCC HB8065) and African green monkey kidney cells (COS-1, ATCC CRL1650) were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, MD.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The cells were grown in a 1:1 mixture of Dulbecco's modified Eagles medium and F12, (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	50	) supplemented with 100 units/ml penicillin G-streptomycin sulfate (Celox Corp.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	51	, Hopkins, MN) and 10% (v/v) heat-inactivated fetal calf serum (JRH Biosciences, Lenexa, KS).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	52	The sequences of the CYP7A promoter from nt 200 to +32 were amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using p-416/+32 (3) as the template.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Primers were designed to introduce a 5 KpnI and a 3 XhoI site for cloning into the luciferase reporter vector, pGL2-Basic (Promega) resulting in the plasmid p-200/+32.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The mutations in the sequences from nt 74 to 54 (see Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	55	 1A) were introduced by linking two fragments synthesized by PCR with mutagenic primers containing restriction sites at the 5- or 3-end and using p-416/+32 as a template.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The region from nt 74 to 54 was replaced with a SpeI site () by linking the nt 416/74 (SpeI) and nt 53(SpeI)/+32 fragments to generate p-41674/54 SpeI.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	57	 To delete the SpeI site, p-41674/54 SpeI was digested with SpeI, treated with Mung bean nuclease, and then religated to generate deletion mutant p-41674/54.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	58	 p20074/54 was obtained by PCR using p-41674/54 as a template.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	59	 p-416LSM74/71 (linker-scanning mutation) was constructed by ligating a nt 70 to +32 (SpeI/XhoI) fragment to 416 74/54Spe digested with SpeI and XhoI.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	60	 p-41674/65 was isolated as a spontaneously arising deletion mutant.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	61	 p-416LSM-59/54, p-416LSM70/66, and p-416IM64/63 (insertion mutation) were constructed similarly to p-416LSM74/71.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	62	 All promoter/reporter constructs were cloned into pGL2-Basic vector.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	63	 All constructs were confirmed by sequencing with Sequenase 2.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Effect of overexpressing recombinant COUP-TFII on transcriptional activity of the nt 416 to +32 fragment of the rat CYP7A promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	65	 A, schematic representation of mutations introduced into the region of nt 74 to nt 54 of the rat CYP7A promoter, as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	66	" Wild-type sequence from nt 81 to 48 is diagrammed on top.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	67	 All the clones have the promoter sequences from nt 416 to +32 ligated into pGL2-Basic.

0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The DR4 is overlined, and the direct repeat described in (11) is boxed.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	70	 B, increasing mass of the expression plasmid pTF3A encoding COUP-TFII was cotransfected with CYP7/luciferase reporter plasmids diagrammed in panel A.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The total mass of plasmid was kept constant by the addition of vector without promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Confluent monolayers of HepG2 cells were transfected with 5  microg of the indicated reporter plasmids, various amounts of pTF3A, and 0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	73	5  microg of pCMV- as described under "Experimental Procedures" and then overlaid with DMEM/F12 medium without serum after glycerol shock.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The cells were harvested 40 h after glycerol shock, and the luciferase activity was assayed and corrected for transfection efficiency with the -galactosidase activity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The activation by COUP-TFII of the transcriptional activities were expressed as percentage of corrected luciferase activity without coexpressed COUP-TFII.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The percentage activation differed from wild type p  <  0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	77	01 (p-200/+32 versus p-200-74/54; p-416/+32 versus remainder of the mutants), as determined by Student's t test; error bars omitted for clarity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Data are representative of two individual experiments.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	79	 C, basal transcriptional activities of CYP7A promoter/luciferase reporter plasmids with mutations in the region from nt 74 to 54.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Error bars indicate standard deviation of the triplicate samples for each construct.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	81	 *, indicates statistical significance for difference from wild type p  <  0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	82	 To control for variation in measured activities due to differences in individual plasmid preparations, relative activities of p-416/+32, p-41674/54Spe, p-41674/65, p-41659/54, p-41674/54 CYP7A promoter/luciferase gene constructs were further assayed with three separate plasmid preparations transfected in triplicate in two different experiments as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	83	" The results obtained were essentially the same as those shown in panel C.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	84	 [View Larger Version of this Image (28K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	85	Confluent cultures of HepG2 cells grown in 12-well tissue culture plates were transfected with DNA by calcium phosphate method as described previously (3, 11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Luciferase activities were determined with the luciferase assay kit (Promega) according to manufacturer instructions using a Lumat LB9501 luminometer (Berthold Systems, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Luciferase activities were normalized for transfection efficiencies by dividing relative light units by -galactosidase activity expressed from cotransfected pCMV plasmid (Clontech).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	88	 -Galactosidase activities were determined using O-nitrophenyl--D-galactopyranoside as a substrate (18).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The average of the corrected luciferase activity from cell extracts is given, and error bars indicate the standard deviation of activity from triplicate samples.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	90	 All transfections were repeated at least two times.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Statistical significances were analyzed by Student's t test using Sigma Plot software (Jandel Scientific, San Rafael, CA).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	92	Preparation of Nuclear Extracts.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	93	Nuclei from HepG2 and COS-1 cells were isolated essentially as described (19, 20).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Recombinant COUP-TFII was prepared by transfecting confluent HepG2 or sub-confluent COS-1 cells in 100-mm tissue culture plates with 20  microg of pTF3A and 1  microg of pCMV.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The monolayers were overlaid with DMEM/F12 containing 5 mM butyric acid and 10% fetal calf serum after glycerol shock, and nuclei were harvested 40 h later.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Transfection efficiency was monitored by -galactosidase activity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	97	Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	98	Double-stranded synthetic probes for EMSA were prepared by heating equal molar amounts of complementary synthetic oligomers to 95  degrees C in 2  x  SSC (0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	99	0) and allowing them to cool to room temperature.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The resulting double-stranded fragments were designed with single-stranded 5 overhangs for end-labeling by incorporating [-32P]dCTP (3000 Ci/mol) with the Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Oligonucleotides blunted with non-labeled dNTPs were used as cold competitors in EMSA.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Labeled fragments were isolated from a 15% polyacrylamide gel or purified through two G-50 spin columns.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Binding reactions were initiated with the addition of 2  microg of nuclear extracts to 100,000 cpm of oligomer probe dissolved in 20  microl of buffer containing 12 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	104	9, 50 mM KCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM dithiothreitol, and 15% glycerol, and 2  microg of poly(dI-dC) poly(dI-dC).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	105	 After incubation for the time indicated in the legends to Figs.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	106	 2, 3, 4, 5, samples were run on 4% polyacrylamide gels, dried, and autoradiographed.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	107	 EMSAs were quantitated with IP Lab Gel software (Signal Analytics, Corp.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	108	, Vienna, VA) in conjunction with a PhosphorImager 445Si (Molecular Dynamics, Sunnyvale, CA).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Effect of overexpressing recombinant COUP-TFII on the EMSA pattern of probes based on the sequence from nt 74 to 54.

0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	125	 [View Larger Version of this Image (61K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	126	 EMSA in the presence of RAR-, RXR-, and COUP-TF-specific antibodies using the nt 149 to 128 probe.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	127	 EMSA was performed using nt 149 to 128 as a probe, generated by digesting the double-stranded synthetic oligomer nt 149 to 118 with MspI (diagrammed, top; imperfect HRE half-sites underlined), end-labeling as described under "Experimental Procedures," and gel isolating the nt 149 to 128 fragment.

0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Shown is the wild-type (WT) oligomer probe sequence on top with trinucleotide transversion mutations indicated below.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Numbers over lanes correspond to the nucleotides mutated according to the following rule: A to C, C to A, G to T, and T to G.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	133	 For example, 145/143 corresponds to the nt 149 to 128 probe with nt 145 G changed to T, nt 144 G changed to T, and nt 143 A changed to C.

0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	136	 [View Larger Version of this Image (113K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	137	Activation of CYP7A Promoter Activity by Recombinant COUP-TFII and Identification of a Negative Element.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	138	Cotransfection of the rat CYP7A promoter fragment from nt 416 to +32 fused to the luciferase gene (p416/+32) (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	139	 1A) with a plasmid encoding recombinant COUP-TFII (pTF3A) was found to strongly stimulate reporter activity (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The dose-response curve resulting from cotransfecting with increasing amounts of pTF3A with p-200/+32 was indistinguishable from the stimulation curve of p-416/+32 (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	141	 1B) despite lower overall luciferase reporter activity (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	142	 1C), indicating the COUP-TF activation elements were downstream of position nt 200.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	143	 1A) reduced the stimulatory effect of COUP-TFII (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	144	To define the sequences important for COUP-TFII activation, a number of deletion () and linker scanning mutations (LSM) were introduced into the nt 74 to 54 region.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The dose-dependent stimulation of the promoter activity of the reporter plasmids by COUP-TFII fell into roughly three groups.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In the first group, the wild-type promoter fragments (p-416/+32 and p-200/+32) showed the greatest stimulation of transcriptional activity, and the effect was positive at all points of the curve (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The second group, which includes p-416LSM74/71, p-416LSM70/66, p-41674/65, p-416LSM59/54, p-41674/54, and p20074/54 displayed considerably flatter dose-response curves (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The mutations in this group destroyed one or both of the putative HRE half-sites, AGGTCA, either by completely deleting the sequence (p-41674/65, p-41674/54, and p20074/54) or by replacing the sequence with an SpeI restriction site while preserving the relative spacing of sequences on either side of the mutation (p-416LSM74/71, p-416LSM70/66, and p-416LSM59/54) (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Reporter plasmids with both HRE half-sites deleted (p-41674/54 and p20074/54) retained significant stimulation by COUP-TFII (approximately 3-4 fold), suggesting there may be additional COUP-TFII sites elsewhere in the promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Consistent with the hypothesis that the putative COUP-TFII activation elements were downstream of position nt 200, p-20074/54 was stimulated to approximately the same extent as p-41674/54, which has the same deletion but was 216 base pairs longer (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	151	The third category was represented by an insertion mutant (IM), p-416IM64/63 that displayed an activation intermediate between the first and second groups.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	152	 This plasmid, in which the HRE half-sites were intact but the spacing was increased from 4 to 5 base pairs (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	153	 1A), was strongly activated but to a somewhat lesser extent than the wild type, reaching a maximum of 1740  plus or minus  99% verses 2960  plus or minus  209%, respectively, at a transcription factor plasmid mass to reporter plasmid mass ratio of 0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	154	The various mutations affected the basal activity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Mutant reporter plasmids p-41674/54, p-416LSM74/71, p-416LSM59/54, p-41674/65, and p20074/54 had increased basal promoter activity relative to their parental plasmids (p-416/+32 and p-200/+32), as would be observed if a repressor binding site was mutated.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	156	 With one exception, the basal promoter activity also fell into three groups, corresponding with the COUP-TFII responsiveness of the reporter plasmid (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The promoter/reporter constructs with the lowest response to COUP-TFII had the highest basal activities (p-41674/54 and p-416LSM74/71).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	158	 p-416IM64/63 basal transcriptional activity was not significantly higher than the wild type.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The exception was p-416LSM70/66, which was activated by COUP-TFII to the same extent as p-416LSM59/54 and p-41674/65 but did not display the same transcriptional activation over p-416/+32.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The activation of p-41674/54 over p-416/+32 was not observed in the kidney cell line, COS-1.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	161	Interaction of COUP-TFII with the CYP7A Promoter at nt 74 to 54.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	162	To determine if COUP-TF activates transcriptional activity by directly binding to the sequence between nt 74 and 54, the ability of COUP-TF to interact with the CYP7A sequences in vitro, was measured with the EMSA.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Also, other promoter fragments from nt 200 to 74 were screened to determine if there were additional COUP-TFII binding sites.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	164	Nuclear extracts were prepared from HepG2 cells transfected with pTF3A, an expression plasmid specifically encoding COUP-TFII.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The gel shift patterns of the nt 72 to 59 and nt 65 to 54 oligomers are similar in HepG2 cells, regardless of COUP-TFII overexpression (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Two extra bands were shifted with nt 74 to 53 probe that were enhanced by COUP-TFII overexpression (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The nt 74 to 53 included the putative DR4, which is overlined in Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	168	 2A; the nt 72 to 59 or nt 65 to 54 oligomers do not.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The diffuse nature of these bands was attributed to the low abundance of the nuclear factors.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	170	Recombinant COUP-TFII expressed in the kidney cell line COS-1, bound the nt 74 to 53 (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	171	 2C), indicating the binding of COUP-TF was not dependent on liver-specific factors.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The increased band shift with COS-1 extracts was attributed to the higher activity of the MT2 promoter of pTF3A, which drives transcription of the recombinant gene encoding COUP-TFII, in COS-1 cells relative to HepG2 cells.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	173	 This presumably results in higher levels of expression of recombinant COUP-TFII in this cell line.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Overexpression of COUP-TFII was associated with a reduction in DRBP binding, even in probes unable to be shifted by COUP-TFII (nt 72/59 and 65/54).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The reduction in DRBP binding may be attributed to the reduced proportion of DRBP in the given mass of protein in COS-1 nuclear extracts overexpressed with recombinant COUP-TFII.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Alternatively, if COUP-TFII interacts with DRBP in solution, the overexpressed COUP-TFII may be sequestering the DRBP and forms larger complexes with the probe nt 74/53.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	177	 COUP-TFII did not shift the probes lacking the COUP-TFII binding site (nt 72/59 and 65/54) (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	178	 It is apparent that COUP-TFII interacts with the DR4 of nt 74 to 53 and DRBP interacts with AGTTCAAG sequence (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	179	To further confirm that COUP-TFII binds to this sequence, antiserum raised against COUP-TF was added to an EMSA using the nt 74 to 55 oligomer as a probe of nuclear extract from HepG2 cells.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The band that increased in intensity when shifted by nuclear extracts from HepG2 overexpressing COUP-TFII was supershifted by the anti-COUP-TF antibody (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	181	 3), indicating that COUP-TFII was interacting directly with the region.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Extracts prepared from cells overexpressing recombinant C/EBP, LAP, HNF4, or HNF3 did not produce any changes in the band-shift pattern (data not shown), and antiserum directed against C/EBP (potential binding site at nt 52 to 41) and c-erbA (a homologue of the thyroid receptor that is regulated by phosphorylation events) did not change the gel shift pattern (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Antibody against RAR and RXR did not supershift the nt 74 to 53 probe.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	184	 However, when performed with extracts prepared from HepG2 cells treated with all trans-retinoic acid, the ligand for RAR, the nt 74 to 54 probe was weakly supershifted with anti-RXR (data not shown).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	185	 DRBP, the major nuclear factor that binds to the sequence was not affected by the antibody, indicating that the proteins responsible for that band are distinct from COUP-TFII and RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	186	 These results confirm that the COUP-TFII binds to DR4 motif, which does not bind thyroid hormone receptor.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	187	 C/EBP, LAP, HNF4, and HNF3 do not bind to this region of CYP7A promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	188	Interaction of COUP-TFII and RXR with the CYP7A Promoter at nt 149 to 128.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	189	The probe nt 149 to 128 shifted one band in HepG2 nuclear extracts.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Antibody against COUP-TFII supershifted the oligomer and changed the pattern of bands as if a complex was disrupted (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The amount of probe supershifted was not increased with increasing amounts of antibody, indicating that antibody was in excess.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Antibody against RXR supershifted a band in HepG2 nuclear extract treated with retinoic acid.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The antibody directed against RAR did not supershift the probe even with extract prepared from HepG2 cells treated with all trans-retinoic acid.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Retinoic acid treatment may have increased the expression of endogenous RXR and showed the supershift with anti-RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	195	Once it had been determined that the antibody specific for RXR supershifted the nt 149 to 128 probe, nucleotides important for the binding of RXR were determined by EMSA with mutant oligonucleotides and the antibody against RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides were synthesized in which three bases were changed by transversions.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Trinucleotide mutations in nt 145 to 134 completely abolished or reduced the supershift by antibody against RXR (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Mutations in nt 133/131 did not have any effect on supershift by antibody against RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	199	 These results indicate that RXR was interacting with the DR1 motif located from nt 146 to 134.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	200	Cotransfection assays of COUP-TFII expression plasmid with wild-type and mutant CYP7A proximal promoter constructs and EMSA results indicate that COUP-TFII interacts with nt 74 to 53 and nt 149 to 128 of the rat CYP7A promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The region of nt 146 to 134 was shown by EMSA to bind RXR and contains HRE half-sites separated by one nucleotide (DR1), the preferred binding site for RXR homodimer (14).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The pattern of response of the mutants in nt 74 to 54 suggested that the nt 74 to 54 was the element with the strongest potential for COUP-TF activation of transcription.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The deletion of the sequences from nt 74 to 54 results in the increase of transcriptional activity of CYP7A promoter/reporter plasmids.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	204	 This sequence was previously found to mediate the bile acid response and to interact with DRBP, whose binding was sensitive to deoxycholate feeding in rats.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	205	 6 is a model which shows the binding sites for these transcription factors on the rat CYP7A proximal promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Interactions of transactivators COUP-TFII and RXR with DRBP and their competition for binding to these bile acid response elements may regulate the CYP7A gene transcription by bile acids and hormones.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The CCAAT enhancer binding proteins (C/EBP and C/EBP or LAP) (21) consensus binding site flank the COUP-TFII binding site at nt 74 to 54.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The C/EBP family of transcription factors are temporally regulated and are thus important developmental regulators of gene expression.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	209	 COUP-TFII may recruit C/EBP on to the apolipoprotein A1 promoter (22).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The DBP B-site, which also is the LAP binding site, was located in the nt 149 to 118 region (23).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	211	 However, antibody directed against C/EBP and LAP did not supershift the nt 149/118 probe.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	212	 This is consistent with the lack of effect of these transcription factors on CYP7A promoter activity we observed.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	213	 The juxtaposition of the COUP-TF and C/EBP binding sites at nt 74/54 and nt 149/118 may prevent the weak binding of these factors.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Diagram of CYP7A proximal promoter with DRBP, COUP-TFII, and RXR recognition sites indicated in relation to the transcription start site, D-site binding protein (DBP) and liver activating protein (LAP) binding sites.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	215	 DBP and LAP (C/EBP) binding sites were determined previously (4, 23).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	216	 [View Larger Version of this Image (18K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	217	In light of the well-characterized negative effect of COUP-TFII on gene promoters, removing a COUP-TFII binding site in CYP7A promoter may explain the much higher activity of the deletion mutants (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	218	 However, several recent reports support our finding that COUP-TFII also can function as a transactivator (24-27).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	219	 COUP-TFII binds as a stable homodimer to many variations of GGTCA sequences in direct repeats and interferes with vitamin D3, thyroid hormone, and retinoic acid receptors by competing for the AGGTCA sites, the cognate sequences for the steroid/thyroid hormone receptors (15).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	220	 However, if the negative effect of COUP-TFII is due to interfering with a positive factor, over-expression of COUP-TFII should repress the transcriptional activity of the CYP7A promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	221	 COUP-TFII activated transcription of the CYP7A promoter at all COUP-TFII expression plasmid to reporter plasmid ratios tried.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The deletion of the strong proximal COUP-TFII site at nt 74 to 55 may allow enhancers in the promoter to interact more readily with the transcriptional machinery and resulting in higher transcriptional activity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	223	 COUP-TFII has been reported to interact with TFIIB (28) and to affect the transcriptional activity by interacting with other transcription factors.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	224	 For example, COUP-TFII is required for activation of the apolipoprotein A1 promoter by RXR (22).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	225	 As the COUP-TFII and RXR both recognized the nt 149 to 128 probe, it is possible that COUP-TFII may interact with RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	226	 The heterodimer of COUP-TFII and RXR is known to bind a DR1 motif and transrepress gene transcription (13).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	227	Despite the finding that COUP-TF binds to a region responsive to bile acid repression, the role of COUP-TFII in the bile acid regulation of CYP7A is not clear and requires further study.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The region from nt 65 to 54 can confer the bile acid response to SV40 promoter, but the probe does not bind COUP-TFII in vitro (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	229	 However, the DRBP and COUP-TFII apparently share binding sequence, the 3 COUP-TFII half-site overlaps with the DRBP binding site (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	230	 COUP-TF clearly influences cholesterol metabolism, in that this transcription factor has previously been shown to affect the transcription of the promoters for apolipoprotein AI (16), apolipoprotein AII, apolipoprotein B (29), apolipoprotein CIII (29, 30) and cholesteryl ester transfer protein gene (27).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	231	The physiological role of the sequences from nt 74 to 54 may be to restrain CYP7A expression.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	232	 This down-regulation may be necessary because of the cytotoxicity of bile acids and the need to preserve cholesterol for synthesis of steroid hormones and membrane components.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The exact interactions of the factors involved has yet to be defined; however, the data are consistent with a model in which COUP-TFII, RXR, and DRBP interact with and bind to a negative element in the region between nt 74 and 54 and a positive element from nt 149 to 118 (10) and lead to the regulation of the CYP7A gene transcription in response to signals from bile acids and hormones.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	234	 This work contributes to the increasing body of evidence indicating COUP-TF has a prominent role in transcriptional regulation of lipid metabolism and that factor binding to the nt 74 to 54 and nt 149 to 128 regions are important determinants of CYP7A transcription.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	235	The transcription factor expression plasmids were the generous gifts of Drs.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Johnson (C/EBP and LAP), and M.

0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	268	 270, 29916-29922 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Ing, N.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	269	 267, 17617-17623 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Ladias, J.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	270	 267, 15849-15860 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Mietus-Snyder, M.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	271	 12, 1708-1718 [Abstract]  1997 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	0	Transcriptional Regulation of the Hepatocyte Growth Factor Gene by the Nuclear Receptors Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor and Estrogen Receptor*.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	1	(Received for publication, August 17, 1996, and in revised form, October 22, 1996).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	2	Jie-Gen Jiang , Aaron Bell , Youhua Liu and Reza Zarnegar  .
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	3	Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) is a multifunctional cytokine that controls the growth and differentiation of various tissues.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Previously, we described the existence of a negative cis-acting regulatory element(s) within the 1- to 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	5	7-kilobase pair (kb) portion of the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In the present study, we show that the repressor element is located at position 872 to 860 base pairs and comprises an imperfect estrogen-responsive element 5-AGGTCAGAAAGACCA-3.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We demonstrate that chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF), a nuclear orphan receptor belonging to the steroid/thyroid hormone receptor superfamily, through binding to this site effectively silences the transcriptional activity of the HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	8	 We show that estrogen receptor, on the other hand, relieves the repressive action of COUP-TF, resulting in the induction of the HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Using mice transgenic for either 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	10	7 kb of the HGF promoter region linked to the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase reporter gene, we found that injection of estradiol stimulates HGF promoter activity in tissues such as the mammary gland and ovary of mice harboring 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	11	7 kb of the mouse HGF promoter region.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Potential involvement of the CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein (C/EBP) family of transcription factors in the regulation of HGF gene expression is also discussed.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	13	Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF)1 was originally identified as the major mitogenic component of serum and platelets for normal adult rat hepatocytes (1, 2).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Further investigations revealed that HGF is a multifunctional cytokine with a broad range of target cells (3, 4).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	15	 HGF elicits its biological effects through binding to and activating a specific transmembrane tyrosine kinase (4-6) known as Met (HGF receptor) (7).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	16	 HGF gene expression is tightly regulated at the transcriptional level and is restricted to stromal cells such as fibroblasts, macrophages, leukocytes, and endothelial cells in various tissues.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Numerous studies have shown that this growth factor is involved in the growth and regeneration of several organs (8-10).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In response to tissue loss, such as in the case of partial hepatectomy or hepatotoxin injury, the level of HGF mRNA dramatically increases in the liver as well as in other organs such as the lung and spleen (9, 10).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	19	 HGF mRNA also increases in the remaining kidney or lung after unilateral nephrectomy or pneumonectomy, respectively (9, 10).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Recent investigations in transgenic mice homozygous for a null mutation in the HGF gene (knock-out mice) have proved that HGF is essential for the development of various tissues such as liver, muscle, and placenta (11, 12).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	21	HGF expression is modulated by several cytokines and hormones.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	22	 For example, it has been shown that in MRC-5 fibroblasts and HL-60 cells HGF expression is down-regulated by transforming growth factor 1 and dexamethasone or by coculture with epithelial cells (13-15).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In contrast, phorbol esters, interleukin-1, or tumor necrosis factor  increase HGF mRNA level (16-19).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Overexpression of HGF mRNA in various neoplastic tissues has also been reported.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	25	 To understand the transcriptional regulation of HGF, the sequences of the human, rat, and mouse HGF gene promoters have been determined and the major transcriptional start sites have been mapped (20-23).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Several potential regulatory sites including NF-IL6 (also known as C/EBP) were identified in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF promoter by our laboratory (22) as well as by others (20-24).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	27	 We reported the identification and partial characterization of a transcriptional repressor in the promoter of the mouse HGF gene (25).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We also localized a negative regulatory region in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF promoter residing at position 1 to 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In the current study, we show that COUP-TF binds to an imperfect estrogen response element (ERE) in this region and represses HGF promoter activity.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	30	 We show that high expression of the estrogen receptor counteracts the suppressive action of COUP-TF by competing for the same binding site.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	31	COUP-TF, which belongs to the orphan nuclear receptor family, was originally found through its interaction with a response element in the chicken ovalbumin gene promoter (26, 27) and has been shown to play both positive and negative roles in gene regulation upon binding to its cognate DNA regulatory element (28).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The COUP-TF family (which consists of COUP-TF I and COUP-TF II) binds to the AGGTCA repeat sequence, which also is the DNA half-site for several other nuclear receptors such as the estrogen receptor (ER), vitamin D3 receptor, thyroid hormone receptor, retinoic acid receptors (RAR and RXR), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor, and hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) (28-31).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In previous studies we reported that estrogen stimulates HGF mRNA expression in mouse ovaries (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Our current results implicate COUP-TF as a potent repressor of HGF gene transcription and provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms that regulate HGF gene expression.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	35	4 mouse HGF-CAT (1386 to +29), 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	36	0 mouse HGF-CAT (964 to +29), and 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	37	7 mouse HGF-CAT (699 to +29) constructs were prepared as described (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	38	85 mouse HGF-CAT construct was made by double digesting the 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	39	4 mouse HGF-CAT construct with HindIII/AflII.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	40	85 mouse DHGF-CAT construct harboring an internal deletion was generated by digesting the 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	41	0-kb HGF-CAT construct with AflII and BstXI.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Blunt ends were created by either Klenow polymerase or T4 DNA polymerase, and the corresponding fragments were purified by agarose gel electrophoresis and then ligated.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	43	 For heterologous promoter constructs, synthesized oligonucleotides HERE1 and HERE2 were inserted into the BglII site of the pCAT promoter (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	44	Cell Culture, DNA Transfection, and CAT Assay.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	45	Human endometrial carcinoma RL95-2 cells, human hepatoma HepG2 cells, and mouse fibroblast NIH3T3 cells were obtained from American Type Culture Collection (Rockville, MD) and cultured as described previously (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	46	 For transfection, the recipient cells were cultured in six-well plates for 24 h and then transfected with various mouse HGF promoter/CAT chimeric plasmids and heterologous promoter constructs using the DNA calcium phosphate method according to the instructions of the CellPhect transfection kit (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The -galactosidase reference plasmid pCH110 (Pharmacia) was used as an internal standard for transfection efficiency.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	48	 After cell transfection was carried out for 16 h, the cells were washed twice with serum-free medium.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Complete medium containing 10% fetal calf serum was then added, and the cells were incubated for an additional 24 h before harvesting to test for CAT activity.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	50	For co-transfection experiments of NIH3T3 cells with pHEO, the human estrogen receptor expression plasmid, and pRS-COUP, the human COUP-TF expression plasmid, phenol red-free medium and charcoal-stripped fetal calf serum were used.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The amount of plasmid used in transfection was 5  microg of one chimerical CAT construct, 1  microg of pCH110, and different amounts of estrogen receptor or COUP-TF expression vectors as indicated.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Protein concentration was used as a standard for transfection efficiency in the co-transfection experiments including those with the COUP-TF expression vector.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	53	 CAT activity was determined by a modified assay as described previously (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Transfection experiments were performed at least three separate times with two independent preparations of purified plasmid DNA.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	55	Preparation of Nuclear Extracts.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	56	Human endometrial carcinoma RL95-2 cells, human hepatoma HepG2 cells, and mouse fibroblast NIH3T3 cells were originally obtained from ATCC.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Cells were cultured under conditions described previously (22, 32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The nuclear extracts were prepared as already reported (25).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Briefly, cells growing to about 90% confluence were washed with cold phosphate-buffered saline and dislodged with a rubber policeman into phosphate-buffered saline.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Cells were pelleted by low speed centrifugation, resuspended in 5 volumes of Buffer A containing protease inhibitors (10 mM HEPES (pH 7.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	61	2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	62	5 mM dithiothreitol, plus 1  microg each of leupeptin and chymostatin per ml) and then placed on ice for 10 min.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Immediately after lysis, the solution was transferred to a glass Dounce homogenizer and homogenized with 10 up and down strokes using a type B pestle.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The nuclei were collected by centrifuging for 15 min at 3,300  x  g and resuspended in the same volume of Buffer B as Buffer A.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Buffer B was the same as Buffer A except Nonidet P-40 was omitted.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After the nuclei were recovered by centrifugation, Buffer C (20 mM HEPES (pH 7.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	67	2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	68	5 mM dithiothreitol, plus 1  microg each of leupeptin and chymostatin per ml) was added to resuspend the nuclei.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Nuclear protein was extracted with Buffer D (the same as Buffer C, but substituting 10 mM KCl for 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The extracted nuclei were centrifuged for 45 min at 50,000  x  g at 4  degrees C, and the supernatant was then collected and dialyzed against 60 mM KCl-TGM (10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	71	6), 10% glycerol, 3 mM MgCl2, 3 mM EGTA buffer using a mini-dialysis system (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The insoluble materials were removed by centrifugation, and small aliquots of protein extract were quickly frozen and stored at 80  degrees C after the protein concentration had been determined by protein assay (Bio-Rad).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	73	Rat liver nonparenchymal cells were isolated by differential centrifugation of the collagenase-digested rat liver perfusate (provided by George Michalopoulos, Department of Pathology, University of Pittsburgh).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Cells were washed twice with cold phosphate-buffered saline and then used to make nuclear extracts with the method described above.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	75	The following oligonucleotides were used in gel mobility shift assays: vitellogenin A2 ERE (VitA2ERE), 5-GATCTAGGTCACAGTGACCTA-3 (33); and COUP, 5-GATCTTTCTATGGTGTCAAAGGTCAAACT-3 (30).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The following sequences were derived from the mouse HGF gene promoter (22): HERE1, 5-GATCAAGGTCAGAAAGACCAT-3; HERE2, 5-GATCTGGTCAATCTAACCA-3; AP1, 5-GATCTGCCTTGACTTAGCGAG-3; IL-6RE, 5-GATCAGAGCTGGGATCTG-3; CRE, 5-GATCTTAAGACGTCATTTA-3; NF-IL6, 5-GATCCTTCTGAGGAAAGCTGC-3; GRE, 5-GATCTTCTGGTGCTATTTCTTCTCATT-3; and TIE, 5-GATCGGGCGAATTGGTGTTCTGC-3.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	77	A DNA fragment corresponding to nucleotide position 964 to 812 bp of the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene was isolated from the chimeric 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	78	4 mouse HGF-CAT construct (22) by restriction digestion with AatI/AflII.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The 154-bp fragment was purified and labeled with [-32P]dATP (3,000 Ci/mmol, Amersham Corp.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	80	) by filling in and blunt ending with Klenow enzyme (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The double-stranded oligonucleotides used in gel shift assays were also labeled with 32P by end labeling with T4 kinase.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The labeled probes were then gel purified and used in gel mobility shift assays as described previously (25).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Two micrograms of poly(dI-dC) (Pharmacia) were used as the nonspecific competitor in 10  microl of reaction mixture.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	84	 When antibodies were used in supershift experiments, they (1  microl) were incubated with nuclear extracts for 15 min at room temperature before carrying out DNA binding shift assays.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The binding reactions (20  microl total volume/reaction) were carried out at room temperature for 20 min before loading on 5% nondenaturing polyacrylamide (19:1 acrylamide/bisacrylamide) gels.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The concentration of nuclear protein extracts used in each reaction was 2  microg and that of the labeled probe was between 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	87	 For competition experiments, a 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled DNA fragments or oligonucleotides was included in the reaction mixture.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	88	001 M EDTA) at a constant voltage of 190 V, dried, and autoradiographed using intensifying screens.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	89	Transgenic mice harboring various lengths (2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	90	1 kb) of the HGF promoter region fused to the CAT reporter gene were recently generated and characterized in our laboratory.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	91	2 Two different HGF-CAT transgenic mouse lines were used in the present study to evaluate HGF promoter activity in response to estradiol.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	92	7 HGF-CAT transgenic mouse lines (three different founders) harbor 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	93	7 kb of the HGF promoter that contains the HERE1 element.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	94	7 HGF-CAT transgenic lines (two different founders) carry 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	95	7 kb of the HGF promoter region that lacks the HERE1 element.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Transgenic mice were maintained in animal facilities at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	97	 All animal experiments were conducted in accordance with National Institutes of Health standards established by the "Guidelines for the Care and Use of Experimental Animals.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	98	" Mice were injected subcutaneously with 100 mg of 17-estradiol (Sigma) per kg of body weight in a volume of 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	99	1 ml of buffered saline containing 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	100	 At 24 h after injection, groups of eight animals were killed by cervical dislocation, and the ovary and other organs were dissected and immediately frozen for CAT assays.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	101	Identification of a cis-Acting Repressor in the HGF Promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	102	We previously reported the existence of a negative regulatory region in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene located between nucleotides 964 and 699 bp (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	103	 To further define this region, two additional HGF-CAT chimeric constructs containing a 5 deletion (0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	104	85 HGF-CAT) or an internal deletion (0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	105	85 DHGF-CAT) were generated by using the restriction enzyme AflII (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Four different HGF-CAT chimeric constructs, 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	107	7 HGF-CAT, were subsequently tested for promoter activity by transfection into human endometrial carcinoma RL95-2 cells, human hepatoma HepG2 cells, and mouse fibroblast NIH3T3 cells.

0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	110	 These results suggest that the region between nucleotides 964 and 812 bp contains a negative cis-acting element(s) and that a negative trans-acting factor(s) may interact with this 154-bp DNA fragment to repress HGF gene transcription.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Localization of a cis-acting repressor element in the 5-upstream flanking region of the mouse HGF promoter.

0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Other oligonucleotides found in the mouse HGF promoter corresponding to GRE, TIE, AP1, IL-6RE, NF-IL6, and HERE2 (a mutated version of HERE1) also failed to compete with the 154-bp DNA fragment for binding to the nuclear protein present in NIH3T3 cells (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	127	 We confirmed these results by DNase I footprinting analysis using NIH3T3 cells and mouse liver tissue nuclear protein extracts.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Taken together, these data suggest that the HERE1 (nucleotides 872 to 860, 5-GGTCAGAAAGACC-3) is involved in the formation of the protein-DNA complex.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	129	 This binding sequence is similar to the estrogen response element (5-AGGTCANNNTGACCT-3, see also Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Specific interaction of the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene with a negative regulatory activity in nuclear protein extracts.

0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	144	To assess the functionality of this element, synthetic HERE1 and HERE2 (a mutated version of HERE1, 5-GGTCAATCTAACC-3) oligonucleotides were linked to the heterologous pCAT promoter reporter gene (Promega), which contains the SV40 promoter, and the promoter activity in three different cell lines using transient transfection and CAT assays was determined.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The results are summarized in Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	146	 HERE1 efficiently repressed the SV40 promoter activity in HepG2, RL95-2, and NIH3T3 cells, whereas HERE2 (which failed to specifically bind to the nuclear protein, Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	147	 2, lane 11) did not have any function.

0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	149	 1) but also in the context of a heterologous promoter (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	150	Identification of the Binding Protein(s) as COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	151	To identify the HERE1 binding protein(s), labeled HERE1 was used as a probe in gel mobility shift assays with the nuclear extracts from NIH3T3 and RL95-2 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In NIH3T3 nuclear extract, the specific complex was abolished by unlabeled HERE1, VitA2ERE (wild type ERE), and COUP binding sites (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	153	 4A, lanes 3-5) but not by HERE2 and GRE (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	154	 We used COUP binding site because it is well known that COUP-TF binds to the AGGTCA motif regardless of its configuration (single half-site, direct as well as indirect repeats, and various spacings) (29).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Although RL95-2 cell nuclear extract formed two different bands with the HERE1 probe, these bands were totally abolished by 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled HERE1, VitA2ERE, and COUP oligonucleotides (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	156	 4A, lanes 9-11) but not by HERE2 and GRE (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	157	 It is known that RL95-2 and NIH3T3 cells express small amounts of ER, and that the major function of ER in the transcriptional regulation of target genes is induction (30, 32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Given the fact that COUP-TF mainly exerts repression on its target genes through binding to VitA2ERE (30, 35, 36), we opted to determine if the protein complex formed by HERE1 is COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	159	 To test this possibility, we performed supershift assays using antibody against COUP-TF, estrogen receptor, or nonimmune serum using the labeled HERE1 as probe.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	160	 4, anti-COUP-TF antibody totally abrogated complex formation between the HERE1 probe and nuclear proteins from different sources such as NIH3T3, HepG2, RL95-2 (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	161	 4B), and nonparenchymal liver cells (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	162	 4C) that are known to express the HGF gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The anti-ER antibody and nonimmune control serum did not show any effects (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	164	 These results demonstrate that the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TF binds to the HERE1 site of the HGF promoter region.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	165	 It is of interest to note that HERE1 and HERE2 also bind to the estrogen receptor if this receptor is highly expressed (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	166	 We previously demonstrated this by using extract from RL95-2 cells that were transfected with an ER expression vector (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Taken together, our findings indicate that HERE1, like VitA2ERE, interacts with both ER and COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Identification of the protein(s) binding to the HERE1 element as COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	169	 A, the HERE1 element was labeled with 32P and incubated with nuclear protein extracts from NIH3T3 or RL95-2 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides including self, COUP, VitA2ERE, HERE2, and GRE were added to the reaction mixture to compete for binding as indicated (100 x ).

0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	176	Modulation of HGF Promoter Activity by COUP-TF and ER.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	177	To test whether the estrogen receptor relieves the repression of the HGF promoter activity mediated by COUP-TF, we co-transfected various HGF-CAT chimeric constructs with an estrogen expression vector into NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	178	 5, the promoter activity of the 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	179	0 HGF-CAT constructs that contain HERE1 increased in the presence of ER in a dose-dependent manner.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	180	 However, the activity of the 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	181	7 HGF-CAT constructs were not affected by ER since they do not contain the HERE1 region (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Similar results were obtained when HERE1 was tested for its responsiveness to ER in the context of the SV40 heterologous promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	183	 CAT assays of NIH3T3 cell extracts co-transfected with the chimeric constructs HERE1-SV40-CAT and HERE2-SV40-CAT revealed that addition of increasing amounts of the estrogen receptor expression vector not only overcame the suppressive function conferred to the SV40 promoter by COUP-TF bound to HERE1 but also highly stimulated SV40 promoter activity (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Interestingly, HERE2 did not suppress the SV40 promoter (since it does not bind COUP-TF; see Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	185	 2, lane 11) but it bound ER with low affinity as we reported previously (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Furthermore, overexpression of COUP-TF (pRS-COUP) in NIH3T3 cells counteracted the stimulatory function of ER on HERE1 but had no effect on the HERE2-SV40-CAT construct (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	187	 These results demonstrate that the mouse HGF gene is transcriptionally suppressed by COUP-TF via binding to the HERE1 element at nucleotide 872 bp in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	188	 High expression of ER counteracts the suppressive function of COUP-TF by competing with ER for binding to HERE1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Overexpression of ER relieves the repression of the HGF promoter exerted by COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Four different HGF-CAT constructs (0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	191	0 HGF-CAT) were co-transfected with various concentrations of pHEO, the human estrogen receptor expression vector, as indicated into NIH3T3 cells in the presence of estradiol (107 M).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	192	 CAT activity was normalized by -galactosidase activity, and the relative CAT activities are presented as the averages from three independent experiments performed in duplicate.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	193	 [View Larger Version of this Image (48K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	194	 COUP-TF and estrogen receptor counteract one another's effects through binding to HERE1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	195	 A, chimeric SV40-CAT plasmids containing HERE1 and HERE2 were co-transfected with increasing amounts of ER expression vector into the NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	196	 The estrogen response of the HERE1-SV40-CAT and HERE2-SV40-CAT constructs was then examined by CAT assay.

0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	201	2  microg/well) and various concentrations of pRS-COUP, the COUP-TF expression vector, in NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	202	 CAT activity was normalized against protein concentration, and the relative CAT activities are presented as the averages from at least three independent experiments.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Estradiol concentration was 107 M.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	204	 [View Larger Version of this Image (30K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	205	Stimulation of the Mouse HGF Promoter in Transgenic Mice by Estradiol.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	206	We previously showed that injection of estradiol into mice dramatically stimulated HGF mRNA expression in mouse ovary (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Our present data reveal that the molecular mechanism by which estradiol stimulates the HGF promoter is through the counteraction by ER of COUP-TF, which directly down-regulates the mouse HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Only high levels of ER counteract the suppression caused by COUP-TF bound to HERE1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	209	 To further confirm that HERE1 is functional and responsible for the stimulation of HGF mRNA by estradiol in vivo, we analyzed transgenic mice that harbor 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	210	7 kb of the mouse HGF promoter linked to the CAT reporter gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	211	7 HGF-CAT promoter construct in transgenic mice that carries the HERE1 element was up-regulated in the mammary tissue and ovary after injection of estradiol (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	212	 On the other hand, the activity of the 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	213	7 HGF-CAT construct that does not contain the HERE1 element did not change upon treatment with estradiol (data not shown).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	214	 This result strongly suggests that in vivo high expression of ER counteracts COUP-TF and stimulates HGF mRNA expression.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Estradiol stimulates HGF promoter activity in transgenic mice.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Cell extracts for CAT assays were prepared from mammary gland, adjacent skin, and ovary from 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	217	7 HGF-CAT transgenic mice that harbor 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	218	7 kb of the HGF promoter region and from nontransgenic mice after injection of 17-estradiol (100 mg/kg of body weight) or control saline solution.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Fifty micrograms of total protein extract from each tissue were subjected to CAT assay.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	220	 A graphic representation of relative CAT activity after normalization for protein concentration is shown.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The results presented are the average from at least three groups of mice.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	222	 TG, transgenic mouse; NTG, nontransgenic mouse; AS, adjacent skin of mammary gland; MG, mammary gland; OV, ovary tissue; E2, 17-estradiol.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	223	 [View Larger Version of this Image (16K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	224	Our previous studies have shown that a negative regulatory element is located within 964 to 699 of the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	225	 In this region, an estrogen response element (HERE1) was identified that binds to ER and is responsible for the estradiol stimulation of the mouse HGF promoter in RL95-2 cells co-transfected with an ER expression vector (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	226	 We now show that this same element binds with high affinity to the nuclear orphan receptor COUP-TF, which belongs to the steroid/thyroid receptor superfamily, and silences the activity of the HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	227	 We demonstrate that the estrogen receptor competes with COUP-TF for binding to this site, thereby relieving the repressive action of COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	228	There are two imperfect EREs found in the mouse HGF promoter region that we have called HERE1 and HERE2 (22, 32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	229	 HERE1 is localized in the 5-flanking region and HERE2 is in the first intron of the HGF gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	230	 By using gel mobility band shift and supershift assays, we demonstrated that HERE1 is similar to the ERE found in the vitellogenin (vit) gene (37) and that it binds not only to ER but also to COUP-TF (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Co-transfection of ER or COUP-TF expression vectors in NIH3T3 cells revealed that HERE1 confers the repressive function of COUP-TF to the heterologous SV40 promoter and that not only did ER overcome the suppression of COUP-TF but it also stimulated the SV40 promoter (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	232	 In the homologous mouse HGF promoter, ER only counteracted the negative effects of COUP-TF (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	233	The molecular mechanisms of COUP-TF-mediated transcriptional repression are partially understood.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	234	 COUP-TF acts via several different mechanisms to inhibit target gene transcription including competition with other nuclear receptors for the occupancy of DNA binding sites, active repression of basal transcription, active repression of transactivator-dependent transcription, quenching of transactivator-dependent transcription, transrepression of activated transcription, and titration of the common coregulator RXR (31, 38).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Our data shown here reveal that COUP-TF may down-regulate the mouse HGF promoter by active repression of basal transcription because HERE1 suppresses the basal SV40 promoter and that ER may activate HGF transcriptional activity by replacing COUP-TF and relieving the promoter from repression (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	236	 COUP-TF belongs to the orphan (thus far, no ligand has been found that can bind and directly regulate the activity of this factor) nuclear receptor family and resembles the thyroid hormone receptor/steroid hormone receptor superfamily (31, 36).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The mode by which it represses its target gene involves the binding of COUP-TF to the AGGTCA motif arranged in various configurations (i.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	238	 direct repeats (DR) or inverted repeats (IR) with different numbers of spacers ranging from 0 to 8 nucleotides) (31).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Interestingly, the AGGTCA half-site depending on its configuration forms the response elements for other nuclear receptors such as the estrogen receptor (which binds to IR3), thyroid hormone receptor (which binds to IR0 or DR4), retinoid receptors (RAR, which binds to IR0 and DR2, and RXR, which binds to DR5 and DR1), vitamin D receptor (which binds to DR3), HNF4, and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (31).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	240	 It is believed that COUP-TF directly competes with these receptors for binding to the AGGTCA sequence and thus inhibits their transactivating functions.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Suppression by COUP-TF is also achieved in part through heterodimerization of COUP-TF with RXR (which is the essential transactivating partner for vitamin D3 receptor, thyroid hormone receptor, and RAR), thereby titrating RXR to a transcriptionally inactive complex (31, 38).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	242	 It is tempting to speculate that in addition to ER other members of the nuclear receptor family mentioned above may bind to the COUP-TF binding site in the HGF promoter HERE1 and thus activate HGF transcription in a tissue-specific manner.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	243	 The COUP-TF site in the HGF promoter, however, is composed of an estrogen response element (IR3) and apparently binds only to the estrogen receptor.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	244	Previous observations in our laboratory showed that administration of 17-estradiol to immature female mice caused a significant induction of HGF mRNA in the ovaries (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The tissue- and cell type-specific expression of the mouse HGF gene by estrogen may be due to different amounts of hormone receptors in these tissues, as shown by other studies (37).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Our present studies show that high expression of estrogen receptor in NIH3T3 cells is sufficient to counteract the suppression of COUP-TF on the mouse HGF promoter (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	247	 HGF promoter activity or lack thereof in transgenic mice also supports this hypothesis because estradiol stimulated the HGF promoter in mice carrying the 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	248	7 HGF-CAT construct that contains HERE1, particularly in tissues that have high expression of ER (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In this regard, it is important to understand how HGF gene expression is relieved from COUP-TF repression in other tissues in which ER may not be operational.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The factors that are known to activate HGF expression include cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor  and polypeptide growth factors such as epidermal growth factor.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	251	 These agents do not exert their gene-regulatory function directly through the AGGTCA motif, the DNA binding site for COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Although the molecular mechanisms by which these agents induce their target genes are not fully understood, it is well established that they utilize members of the AP1, C/EBP, nuclear factor B (NFKB), and signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) family of transcription factors.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Indeed, in our previous report (22) we demonstrated that several NF-IL6 (C/EBP) response elements exist in the 5-flanking region of the HGF promoter region and that IL-6 induces HGF promoter activity in a stromal (fibroblast) cell line stably transfected with an HGF-CAT chimeric construct.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	254	 In our very recent investigations using gel shift, supershift, and CAT assays, we have found that functional C/EBP binding sites exist in the HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	255	 We also found that co-transfection of expression vectors encoding C/EBP or C/EBP with HGF-CAT vectors dramatically (more than 20-fold) stimulates the transcriptional activity of various HGF-CAT promoter constructs (even those constructs that do not contain COUP-TF binding sites, thus indicating that promoter activation is not due to interference with COUP-TF binding).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	256	3 These observations provide an explanation for how the HGF promoter is released from repression exerted by negative acting factors such as COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The C/EBP family of transcription factors is known to consist of regulators of important cellular functions ranging from metabolism to cell growth to differentiation.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	258	The physiological significance of the transcriptional regulation of the HGF gene by ER and COUP-TF also remains to be elucidated.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Nevertheless, it has been shown that both HGF and COUP-TF play an important role during embryonic development.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	260	 COUP-TFs are differentially expressed in a restricted manner during organogenesis (40).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Both COUP-TF I and COUP-TF II genes are essential since COUP-TF I mutants die prenatally and COUP-TF II mutants die in utero (41).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Additionally, HGF is believed to be one of the major mediators of stromal-epithelial interactions controlling growth and morphogenesis of various tissues such as breast (39).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Studies on the embryological development of such tissues have revealed that steroid hormone-induced ductal morphogenesis and growth is accomplished via the interactions between the stromal and epithelial compartments of these tissues (34).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Therefore, the functions of COUP-TF and ER during development may be mediated in part by their ability to regulate HGF gene expression.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Our data shown here shed light on the significant interplay among transcription factors such as ER, COUP-TF, and C/EBP and polypeptide growth factors such as HGF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	266	*   This work was supported by Grant CN#55D from the American Cancer Society and Grant R01ES 06109 from the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (to R.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
