0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	0	Critical role of charged residues in helix 7 of the ligand binding domain in Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 dimerisation and transcriptional activity Jerome Eeckhoute, Benedicte Oxombre, Pierre Formstecher, Philippe Lefebvre and Bernard Laine*.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	1	INSERM U459, Faculte de Medecine Henri Warembourg, 1 Place de Verdun, F-59045 Lille Cedex, France.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	2	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Tel: +33 03 20 62 69 51; Fax: +33 03 20 62 68 84; Email: blaine{at}lille.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	4	Received June 18, 2003; Revised August 25, 2003;.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	5	Like other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, HNF4 has a modular structure consisting of functional domains (7).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Two of these domains, the DNA binding domain (DBD) and the ligand binding domain (LBD) are involved in dimerisation of HNF4, which behaves as a homodimer (8).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Dimerisation via the DBD is involved in HNF4 dimerisation on DNA, whereas dimerisation via the LBD is essential for dimerisation in solution and strongly stabilises the HNF4 to DNA complex (9,10).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The LBD is also involved in other functions, including transcriptional activation and interaction with transcriptional partners.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Both domains are well conserved in HNF4 (11).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Crystal structures of the LBDs of HNF4 and HNF4 have recently been resolved (12,13).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These LBDs adopt the canonical fold of -helices (10 helices numbered H1 to H12 to follow the conventional nomenclature) and ss-sheets arranged as an antiparallel -helical  sandwich  in a three-layer structure shared with the LBD of other nuclear receptors (14).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The LBD structures of HNF4 and HNF4 are very similar and closely resemble that of RXR, another member of the nuclear receptor subfamily 2 (NR2).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Indeed, 194 core carbons of the LBD of HNF4 and RXR superimpose with a root mean square deviation (rmsd) of 1.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	14	26 A and 223 core carbons of the LBD of HNF4 and RXR superimpose with a r.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In these structures, the LBD dimerisation interface is made of residues in helices 7 (H7), 9 (H9) and 10 (H10), the major part of the interface being made up of H10.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	16	HNF4 and HNF4, which activate transcription in the absence of exogenous ligands, are considered to be constitutive transcriptional activators (1,11,13,15,16).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Their LBDs are tightly associated with endogenous fatty acids, which do not act as classical ligands but are likely required for the stability of the protein conformation (12,13).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	18	 HNF4 transcriptional activity can be enhanced by other transcription factors, including COUP-TF (17), Smad3 and Smad4 (18), or by coactivators, such as members of the p160 family (19,20), CBP/p300 (20 to 22) and PGC-1 (23).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The HNF4 transcriptional activity can also be repressed by negative transcriptional partners such as SHP (24), p53 (25) and SMRT (26).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	20	In the crystal structure of the RXR LBD, H7 adopts an unusual -helical geometry that forces the glutamic acid residue in position 352 to bulge outward from the H7 axis (27).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	21	 This structure gives rise to the formation of a series of intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonds that improve RXR LBD homodimerisation (27).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In particular, residues E352 and R348 are directly involved in the dimerisation interface by forming charge-driven interactions.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The -helical conformation near E352 in the RXR homodimer and the resulting interactions were also observed in the PPAR/RXR LBD heterodimer (28).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Sequence alignment indicates that a glutamic acid residue and an arginyl residue are also encountered at the equivalent positions in human and rat HNF4 (E262 and R258).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Figure 1 shows that these residues are conserved in remote species such as Drosophila and in the Xenopus HNF4ss and are specifically encountered in members of the NR2 subfamily (27 to 29).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Interestingly, in the crystal structure of the HNF4 LBD, a bulge near E262 was also observed in H7 (12).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	27	 described this glutamate as a single residue E insert in H7 and hypothesised that it may play a crucial role in the function of nuclear receptors belonging to the NR2 subfamily, including HNF4 (27,28).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We investigated the role of the E262 and R258 amino acid residues in HNF4 function using biochemical and mutagenesis studies.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	29	Co-immunoprecipitation assays Wild-type and mutated HNF4 were in vitro synthesised in reticulocyte lysates (Promega).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In co-immunoprecipitation assays performed with an anti-c-myc tag antibody, 5  microl of non-radiolabelled wild-type or mutated c-myc-HNF42 was incubated with 5  microl of [35S]methionine-labelled wild-type or mutated HNF42 for 1 h at room temperature in 30  microl (final volume) of Ip buffer (50 mM Tris to HCl pH 7.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	31	0, 100 mM KCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 0.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	32	5 mM phenylmethylsulphonyl fluoride and 0.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	33	1 mg/ml each of leupeptin, aprotinin and pepstatin).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Then, 2  microg of anti-c-myc tag antibody (clone 9E10; Upstate Biotechnology) was added and incubation was continued for 1 h.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	35	 An aliquot of 150  microl of Ip buffer containing 3 mg of hydrated protein A to Sepharose CL-4B beads (Sigma) was added and samples were incubated under constant agitation for an additional 1 h.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	36	 After extensive washing of the beads with Ip buffer, bound proteins were resolved by SDS to PAGE.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Co-immunoprecipitation assays performed with the 455 antiserum (33) were conducted similarly using 5  microl of non-radiolabelled wild-type or mutated HNF42, 5  microl of [35S]methionine-labelled HNF43 and 0.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Interactions were quantified using ImageQuant software on a PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	39	GST pull-down assays GST pull-down assays were performed as described previously (30) using [35S]methionine-labelled, in vitro synthesised HNF4 and bacterially expressed GST fusion proteins.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Interactions were quantified using ImageQuant software on a PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	41	Electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) EMSA were performed using in vitro synthesised wild-type or mutated HNF42 and 32P-labelled oligonucleotides (0.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	42	2 ng) encompassing the HNF4 response element of the human HNF1 promoter (positions  to 66/ to 48) (1) or a mutated version of this response element (denoted HNF1 and HNF1 mt, respectively) or site B (position  to 67/ to 85) (1) of the human apolipoprotein CIII promoter (denoted CIIIB).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Mutations in the HNF1 mt site are underlined in the following sequence, where half-sites are in upper case: tgaACTCCCaAGTTCAgtc.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Complexes were formed in 20  microl (final volume) of binding buffer (100 mM KCl, 20 mM HEPES pH 7.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	45	1 mM EDTA, 20% glycerol, 1 mM DTT) in the presence of 1.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	46	25  microg of poly(dI dC) to poly(dI dC).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Complexes were resolved by non-denaturing PAGE in 1x TEA.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	48	 DNA binding was quantified using a PhosphorImager.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	49	 In supershift assays, HNF4 proteins were incubated with 0.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	50	25  microl of the 455 HNF4 antiserum (33) for 15 min prior to adding the labelled probe.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	51	Cell culture and transient transfection assays Human embryonic kidney HEK 293 (1.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	52	5 x 105 cells per 24-well dishes), COS-1 (4 x 104 cells per 24-well dishes) and HeLa cells (5.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	53	5 x 104 cells per 24-well dishes) were grown and transfected as in Suaud et al.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	54	 (31) with plasmid amounts indicated in the figure legends.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Luciferase activities were measured using the Bright-Glo Luciferase assay system (Promega).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	56	Western blot assays Aliquots of 2.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	57	3 x 106 HeLa cells were transfected with 2  microg of wild-type or mutated HNF42 expression vector and whole-cell extracts were prepared as in Wang et al.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Western blot assays were carried out as in Suaud et al.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	59	Data analysis Statistical analyses were based on Student s t-test for unpaired data using Prism software.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The statistical significance of differences between values obtained for mutant and wild-type HNF4 (P) is indicated in the legends to the figures.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	61	We analysed whether these mutations affected the ability of labelled HNF42 mutants to form dimers in solution with wild-type HNF42 (HNF42 WT).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Dimerisation was studied by either co-immunoprecipitation assays using c-myc-HNF42 WT or GST pull-down assays using GST-HNF42 WT.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	63	 As expected, HNF42 WT efficiently bound to both c-myc-HNF42 WT (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Conversely, all mutants failed to bind efficiently to c-myc-HNF42 WT (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Next, we analysed the effects of mutations on dimerisation of a given mutant with itself.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	66	 For these assays, we focused on mutants E262A and E262.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	67	 In co-immunoprecipitation assays, no dimer was detectable with either E262A or E262 (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	68	 This result was not due to a lower expression of mutated c-myc-HNF42 (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Impaired dimerisation of mutants was confirmed by pull-down experiments performed in increasingly stringent conditions.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	70	 HNF42 WT dimerisation was unaltered at 300 mM KCl and decreased by only 25% at 600 mM KCl (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	71	 In sharp contrast, dimerisation dropped dramatically at 300 and 600 mM KCl for both mutants (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Thus, removing the carboxylic group at position 262 is sufficient to strongly impair HNF42 dimerisation in solution.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	73	View larger version (31K):    Figure 2.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	74	 E262 and R258 are involved in HNF42 dimerisation in solution.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	75	 (A and B) Analyses by co-immunoprecipitation assays and GST pull-down assays, respectively, of dimerisation between immobilised wild-type HNF42 fused to c-myc or GST (c-myc-HNF42 WT or GST-HNF42 WT) and wild-type or mutated [35S]methionine-labelled HNF42.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Graphs in (A) and (B) indicate means  plus or minus  SE of HNF42 mutant binding relative to that of the wild-type protein from three independent experiments.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Inputs were taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	78	 (C) Dimerisation, analysed by co-immunoprecipitation assays of HNF42 WT, -E262 or -E262A.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For each assay, [35S]methionine-labelled HNF42 was incubated with the same protein fused to the c-myc tag.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Control of synthesis of c-myc-HNF42 WT and mutated proteins is shown in the insert.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	81	 (D) Dimerisation, analysed by GST pull-down assays of HNF42 WT, -E262 and -E262A.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	82	 For each assay, [35S]methionine-labelled HNF42 was incubated with the same protein fused to GST.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Pull-down assays were performed in the indicated ionic strength conditions.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The graph indicates means  plus or minus  SE of HNF4 binding at 300 or 600 mM KCl relative to binding at 100 mM KCl (set to 100%) from three independent experiments.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	85	 (E) Dimerisation, analysed by co-immunoprecipitation assays, between immobilised c-myc-HNF42 WT and [35S]methionine-labelled HNF42 WT or -R258M.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The graph indicates mean  plus or minus  SE of HNF42-R258M binding relative to that of the wild-type protein from four independent experiments.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Inputs were taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	88	  In RXR, R348 is also involved in dimerisation (27,28).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Interestingly, this arginyl residue is specifically conserved in all members of the NR2 subfamily (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	90	 This led us to investigate the role of the corresponding R258 residue of HNF42 in dimerisation.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	91	 When the positive charge of this residue was removed in the R258M mutant, HNF4 dimerisation dropped (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	92	 2E), although less markedly than when elicited by E262 mutations (compare decrease in dimerisation in Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Together, these results show the involvement of the charged groups of residues E262 and R258 in the stabilisation of HNF42 dimerisation in solution.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	94	Mutations of residues E262 and R258 do not impair DNA binding Since HNF4 is known to bind DNA as a homodimer (8), we analysed the effect of E262 and R258 mutations on HNF42 DNA binding.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Surprisingly, none of the mutations altered HNF42 binding to the HNF4 response element of the HNF1 promoter (HNF1 site, Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The specificity of the band shift was ascertained by supershifting it with HNF4 antiserum 455 (33) (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Similar results were obtained on another HNF4 response element, site B of the apoCIII promoter (CIIIB site), which is also a direct repeat 1 (DR1) (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	98	 3E, results in the absence of competitor).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Results obtained with increasing amounts of labelled probe exclude that lack of detection of DNA binding impairment by E262A mutation was due to saturated binding (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Similar results were obtained with other mutants (data not shown).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Mutated and wild-type HNF4 yielded a retarded band of identical intensity and electrophoretic mobility.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	102	 More specifically, we did not observe a band of higher mobility corresponding to a HNF4 monomer bound to DNA as observed for the RAR monomer (15).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	103	 In addition, to rule out the possibility that mutants bound to DNA as two adjacent monomers, we performed EMSA with the HNF1 mt site containing one mutated half-site and obtained no binding of the mutants (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Thus, HNF4 mutants, like wild-type HNF4, bind DNA as homodimers.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	105	 To evidence possibly diminished interactions with DNA, we performed EMSA in less-favorable conditions.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	106	 First, we increased the ionic strength (300 versus 100 mM KCl in Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	107	 3A) in EMSA but found no difference in DNA binding between wild-type and mutated HNF4 (data not shown).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Second, we carried out competition experiments with COUP-TFII, which binds to several HNF4 response elements.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The rationale here was to check whether this nuclear receptor impinges on DNA binding of HNF42-E262A more efficiently than on wild-type HNF42.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	110	 In these assays, the truncated COUP-TFII AB was used to distinguish complexes formed with either HNF42 or COUP-TFII.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	111	 EMSA was performed on the CIIIB site since COUP-TFII does not bind to the HNF1 site (17,30).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	112	 COUP-TFII AB similarly competed for HNF42 WT and -E262A DNA binding (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Also, unlabelled DNA competed equally for DNA binding of both proteins (data not shown).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In addition, we observed that mutations did not alter binding to a direct repeat 2 (DR2), to which HNF4 binds less efficiently than to a DR1 (9) (data not shown).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	115	 It appears therefore that the E262 residue does not play a significant role in HNF42 DNA binding.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	116	View larger version (49K):    Figure 3.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Mutations of E262 and R258 residues do not impair HNF42 DNA binding.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	118	 (A) DNA binding of HNF42 mutants to the 32P-labelled HNF4 response element of the HNF1 promoter (HNF1 site).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Control of in vitro synthesis of wild-type and mutated HNF42, used in EMSA, is shown in the insert (values on the right end indicate molecular size markers).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The graph indicates means  plus or minus  SE of mutated HNF42 DNA binding relative to that of the wild-type protein from three independent experiments.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Unprogrammed reticulocyte lysate (mock) yielded no shifted band.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Supershifting was performed in the presence of the specific 455 HNF4 antiserum.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	123	 (C) EMSA performed with a constant amount of HNF42 WT or HNF42-E262A and increasing amounts of labelled HNF1 probe.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (D) HNF42-E262A did not bind as a monomer to the half-site of the HNF4 response element (HNF1 mt).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	125	 (E) Competition experiments with COUP-TFII AB.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	126	 EMSA were performed on the HNF4 response element of the apoCIII promoter (CIIIB site) using in vitro synthesised HNF42 WT or HNF42-E262A and increasing amounts of the competitor COUP-TFII AB.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The amount of reticulocyte lysate in each lane was held constant by the appropriate addition of unprogrammed lysate.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The positions of HNF42 and COUP-TFII AB homodimers bound to DNA are indicated.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	129	  Differential effects on dimerisation in solution and DNA binding of mutations in H7 and H10 of HNF4 LBD Within the LBD, the I-box has been shown to constitute a dimerisation interface that mediates cooperative binding to DNA of nuclear receptors (35).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The I-box almost perfectly overlaps H9 and H10 that form the major portion of the dimer interface in RXR and HNF4 homodimers (12,13,27,36).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Mutagenesis studies also showed that the HNF4 I-box is an important interaction interface for homodimerisation in solution (37) and is likely involved in DNA binding (15).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	132	 We therefore compared the effects of mutations in H7 and H10 on HNF4 dimerisation in solution and DNA binding.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Until now, the role of the HNF4 I-box has been studied using multiple (double, triple or quadruple) mutations (15,37).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	134	 For example, the K300E-E327K HNF4 double mutant was used to show the involvement of the salt bridge between these residues in the exclusive homodimerisation of HNF4 (15).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	135	 For our comparative study, we chose a single mutation located in H10 E327M.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	136	 In co-immunoprecipitation assays with c-myc-HNF42 WT, we observed that the E327M mutation decreased HNF42 dimerisation in solution by 25% (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The extent of this decrease was similar to that observed for the R258M mutation (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	138	 A similar drop in HNF42 dimerisation in solution with E327M and R258M mutations was also observed in GST pull-down assays (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Note that the impairment of dimerisation by the E262 mutations was stronger, as observed in both co-immunoprecipitation and GST pull-down assays (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The stronger effect of the E262A mutation on HNF42 dimerisation in solution was confirmed by a different co-immunoprecipitation assay, where unlabelled HNF42 WT, -R258M, -E262A or -E327M and the 455 antiserum raised against their common C-terminus were used to co-immunoprecipitate labelled HNF43, which contains a different C-terminus not recognised by this antiserum.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	141	 R258M, E262A and E327M mutations strongly impaired the ability of HNF42 to interact with HNF43 (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	142	 4C), thus confirming the involvement of these three residues in HNF4 dimerisation.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Quantification again indicated that the E262A mutation resulted in the strongest impairment of HNF42 dimerisation in solution (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	144	View larger version (24K):    Figure 4.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Differential effects on dimerisation in solution and DNA binding of mutations in H7 and H10 of the HNF4 LBD.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	146	 (A) Dimerisation, analysed by co-immunoprecipitation assays, between immobilised c-myc-HNF42 WT and [35S]methionine-labelled HNF42 WT or -E327M.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The graph indicates mean  plus or minus  SE of HNF42-E327M binding relative to that of the wild-type protein from three independent experiments.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Inputs were taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	149	 (B) Dimerisation, analysed by GST pull-down assays, between immobilised GST-HNF42 WT and [35S]methionine-labelled HNF42 WT, -R258M and -E327M.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Pull-down assays were performed in various ionic strength conditions as in Figure 2D.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The graph indicates means  plus or minus  SE of mutant binding relative to that of the wild-type HNF4 from three independent experiments.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Inputs were taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	153	 (C) Dimerisation, analysed by co-immunoprecipitation assays using the 455 antiserum, between immobilised HNF42 WT, -R258M, -E262A or -E327M and [35S]methionine-labelled HNF43, which is not recognised by the 455 antiserum.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Control of HNF42 protein synthesis is shown in the insert.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The graph indicates means  plus or minus  SE of HNF43 retention by HNF42 mutants relative to HNF43 retention by HNF42 WT from four independent experiments.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Control of protein synthesis was taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	157	 (D) DNA binding of HNF42-E327M on the HNF1 site, analysed by EMSA performed as in Figure 3A.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Supershifts were obtained in the presence of the 455 HNF4 antiserum as indicated.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Control of protein synthesis is shown in the insert.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The graph indicates mean  plus or minus  SE of HNF42-E327M DNA binding relative to that of the wild-type protein from three independent experiments.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	161	  In contrast to E262A and R258M mutations, the E327M mutation moderately but significantly decreased HNF42 DNA binding to the HNF1 site (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The specificity of the band shift was ascertained by supershifting it with the 455 antiserum (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Interestingly, the intensities of the supershifted bands obtained with wild-type and E327M HNF4 were similar.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	164	 It has previously been shown that the impaired DNA binding of HNF4 mutants (i.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	165	 K300E-E327K and R154X) due to decreased dimerisation could be rescued in the presence of antibodies, which facilitate dimerisation.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	166	 This phenomenon is likely due to the bivalency of antigen recognition by antibodies (15,32).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Conversely, when decreased DNA binding is not due to a loss of dimerisation, DNA binding is not recovered in the presence of antibodies, as observed for the D126Y and D126H HNF4 mutants (38).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Therefore, the decreased DNA binding and impaired dimerisation of the E327M mutant are directly correlated.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	169	 E327M mutation also impaired HNF42 DNA binding to the CIIIB site and to the synthetic DR2 site (data not shown).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Our results not only confirm that H10 and H9 constitute a motif of the LBD dimerisation interface required for efficient DNA binding of HNF4 (15), but also show that another region of the LBD dimerisation interface, namely H7, is not required for strong DNA binding of this protein.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	171	Deletion of the E262 residue dramatically impairs HNF42 transcriptional activity Next we investigated the effects of mutations of E262 and R258 residues on HNF42 transcriptional activity.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The HNF42-mediated activation of the HNF1 promoter was not altered by any of the substitution mutations in HeLa cells (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	173	 However, HNF4 transcriptional activity was abolished by E262 deletion (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	174	 In HEK 293 and COS-1 cells, transcriptional activity was unaffected by substitution mutations but was dramatically impaired by the deletion mutation E262 (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	175	 5B and C, where only data with wild-type, E262A and E262 are shown).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The loss of activation by HNF42-E262 was neither due to a lower protein expression, as controlled by western blotting (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	177	 6D), nor to an unfolding of the protein, as assessed by limited protease mapping assays using chymotrypsin or trypsin (data not shown).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Deletion of the neighbouring residue, D261, also abolished HNF4 transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The dramatic drop in HNF4 transcriptional activity caused by the E262 deletion prompted us to determine whether this mutant exhibits a dominant-negative effect on the wild-type protein.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	180	 However, HNF42-E262 was unable to repress the transcriptional activity of wild-type HNF4 (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	181	View larger version (22K):    Figure 5.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Deletion of E262 strongly affects HNF42 transcriptional activity.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	183	 HeLa (A), HEK 293 (B) and COS-1 cells (C) were transiently transfected with 12.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	184	5 ng of expression vector for wild-type or mutated HNF42 or the corresponding empty vector ( to ) together with 250 ng of HNF1 promoter construct.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Fold induction refers to the activity with no HNF42 derivative ( to ), which was set to 1.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Results are means  plus or minus  SE of three independent experiments performed in triplicate.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	187	0018 for the E262 mutant in (A to C), respectively; ***, P  <  0.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	188	0001 for the D261 mutant in (A).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	189	 (D) Western blotting of HeLa cell extracts.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	190	 (E) HNF4-E262 does not exhibit a dominant-negative activity on wild-type HNF4.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	191	 COS-1 cells were transfected as in (C), except that equal amounts of wild-type HNF4 and HNF4-E262 or control vector ( to ) were co-transfected.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	192	 (F and G) Effects of substitution mutations on the dominant-negative activity of HNF4-AF-2.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	193	 COS-1 cells were transfected as in (C), except that in (F) plasmids expressing wild-type, E262A or E262K HNF4 were co-transfected with an equal amount of vector expressing HNF4-AF-2 or the control vector ( to ), whereas in (G) pcDNA3 HNF42 WT was co-transfected with an equal amount of vectors expressing HNF4-AF-2 or HNF4-AF-2-E262A or the control vector ( to ).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Activation of the HNF1 promoter is expressed relative to that obtained when only full-length proteins were expressed.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Results are means  plus or minus  SE of three independent experiments performed in triplicate.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	196	  View larger version (23K):    Figure 6.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Deletion of E262 markedly decreases recruitment of transcriptional partners.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	198	 (A) GST pull-down assays were performed using GST-SRC-1a (570 to 780), GST-p300 (340 to 528), GST-PGC-1 (36 to 797) or GST-COUP-TFII and [35S]methionine-labelled WT or mutated HNF42.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Inputs correspond to 5 or 2% (for the experiment with GST-SRC-1a) of amounts of labelled proteins used in the assays.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	200	 (B and C) Effects of mutations of the E262 residue on the enhancement of HNF42 transcriptional activity by p300 and COUP-TFII, respectively.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	201	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 12.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	202	5 ng of wild-type or mutated HNF42 expression vector, 250 ng of HNF1 promoter construct and 250 ng of empty control vector (white bars) or expression vectors (black bars) for p300 or COUP-TFII.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Shown are per cent enhancements of wild-type and mutated HNF4 activities.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Results are means  plus or minus  SE of three independent experiments performed in triplicate.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	205	  To gain further insight into the consequences of altered dimerisation of HNF4 by substitution mutations, we took advantage of the fact that a truncated HNF4 lacking the AF-2 activation function module (HNF4-AF-2, left part of Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	206	 5F) exhibits a dominant-negative effect through its ability to dimerise with the wild-type protein (7).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In a first set of experiments, we compared HNF4-AF-2 repression on the transcriptional activities of wild-type HNF4 and of the two mutants E262A and E262K.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The rationale was that the dominant-negative mutant would exhibit a weaker repression on mutant HNF4, with impaired dimerisation, than on wild-type HNF4.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	209	 HNF4-AF-2 reduced the activity of wild-type HNF4 by 50% while it reduced that of E262A and E262K mutants by 29 and 26%, respectively (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Accordingly, compared to HNF4-AF-2, HNF4-AF-2 bearing the E262A mutation (HNF4-AF-2-E262A) exhibited a weaker repressive activity on the wild-type protein.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Indeed, HNF4-AF-2 reduced the wild-type HNF4-mediated activation of transcription by 50% while HNF4-AF-2-E262A reduced it by 30% (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	212	 By demonstrating that substitution mutations of E262 affect repression of HNF4-mediated activation of transcription, our results highlight the importance of this residue for dimerisation in a cell context.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	213	The E262 insert is required for efficient recruitment of coactivators by HNF4 Next, we investigated the effects of the mutations on the physical interaction between HNF42 and its transcriptional coactivators.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	214	 In this study we included interaction with COUP-TFII, which acts as an HNF4 transcriptional partner on the HNF1 promoter (17).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	215	 GST pull-down assays showed that E262 deletion markedly impaired HNF42 interaction with SRC-1a, p300, PGC-1 and COUP-TFII, whereas substitution mutations of E262 did not alter these interactions (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	216	 In line with these data, enhancement of HNF42 transcriptional activity on the HNF1 promoter by p300 or COUP-TFII was not altered by substitution mutations but was abolished by the E262 deletion, as evidenced by transient transfection assays (Fig.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Deletion of the E262 residue also disrupted the functional cooperation between HNF42 and SRC-1a (data not shown).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	218	Like the substitution mutants in H7, several missense HNF4 mutants, including naturally occurring mutants associated with diabetes (6,30,38), also exhibit unaltered or slightly impaired transcriptional activities in transient transfection assays.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Failure to detect a subtle loss of HNF4 function in these assays where the protein is overexpressed does not exclude that these mutations may have greater consequences on HNF4 function when the protein is expressed at normal levels.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Interestingly, a significant effect of substitution mutants in H7 on HNF4 transcriptional activity could be detected by analysing the repression of this activity with an HNF4 mutant exhibiting a dominant-negative activity.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	221	 These results demonstrate the importance of E262 for HNF4 dimerisation in a cell context.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Moreover, it should be kept in mind that the activity of nuclear receptors can be repressed by proteins that prevent their dimerisation (43,44).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	223	 HNF4 is a target of AMP-activated protein kinase, which inhibits HNF4 activity by decreasing its dimerisation (45).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The ability of HNF4 to form a highly stable homodimer in solution (8) is likely crucial in this type of repressive mechanism that does not exclusively occur on DNA.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Other pathways that do not necessarily require DNA binding include cross-regulatory mechanisms in which nuclear receptors are frequently involved.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	226	 In these mechanisms, dimerisation can be of major importance (46).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Since HNF4 is known to interact with numerous other transcription factors, including Smad proteins (18), it likely participates in cross-regulatory pathways.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Therefore, involvement of H7 residues in dimerisation in solution may be crucial in HNF4 biological activities.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	229	Results obtained with the deletion mutant HNF4-E262 indicate that the E insert is required for HNF4 transcriptional activity and recruitment of transcriptional partners.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Note that, probably due in part to its impaired dimerisation, HNF4-E262 did not exhibit a dominant-negative activity.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	231	 None of the MODY1-associated HNF4 mutants can repress wild-type HNF4 activity (6).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Even single or double mutations in the AF-2 module, which is crucial for HNF4 transcriptional activity, do not result in a dominant-negative effect (J.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	233	Eeckhoute, unpublished results).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Interestingly, HNF4-D261, a mutant having a deletion of the neighbouring residue, exhibited an abolished transcriptional activity but an unaltered DNA binding (EMSA data not shown), a behaviour that is very similar to that of the E262 mutant.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	235	 These findings may be explained by the loss of the special conformation (the -helix) in H7, which was hypothesised to result from the presence of an additional residue, the  E insert  (28).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The D261 and E262 deletions most probably modify the orientation of the side chain of residues in H7.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Several residues in H7 point towards the HNF4 ligand binding pocket and probably participate in fatty acid binding, which is required for the stability and function of HNF4 and HNF4 (12,13).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The marked decrease in HNF4 transcriptional activity and recruitment of transcriptional partners caused by the E262 deletion may reflect the alteration in fatty acid binding secondary to the loss of the -helix conformation generated by this glutamate residue.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	239	From a mechanistic point of view, our results unravel distinct contributions of H7, H9 and H10 to HNF4 dimerisation and DNA binding.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	240	 H9 and H10 constitute the core of the LBD dimerisation interface of several non-steroid nuclear receptors (27,36,47,48).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	241	 This core is required for efficient DNA binding (35).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	242	 In HNF4, this core is also involved in dimerisation required for DNA binding, as evidenced using a double mutation in H9 and H10 (15).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	243	 We observed that a single mutation in H10, E327M, was sufficient to alter HNF4 dimerisation and DNA binding.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The role of H7 in nuclear receptors has been less extensively studied and only recent crystallographic data indicate that its contribution to dimerisation varies according to the receptor and, for RXR, with its homodimeric or heterodimeric state (47).
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Concerning HNF4, our results clearly show that H7 has a crucial role in dimerisation in solution but does not contribute to the dimerisation activity required for DNA binding.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	246	In conclusion, our results demonstrate the key role of H7 in HNF4 dimerisation in solution and provide a new concept by which helices of the HNF4 LBD dimerisation interface contribute differently to the dimerisation required for DNA binding: whereas H9 and H10 are required for DNA binding, H7 is involved solely in dimerisation in solution.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Our data also show the key role of the E262 insert that causes a special conformation in H7 observed in both RXR and HNF4.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	248	 The key role of this glutamate is likely shared by other members of the NR2 subfamily, where it is specifically encountered, and most probably the E insert corresponds to a signature of this subfamily.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	249	 (1997) Murine gastrulation requires HNF-4 regulated gene expression in the visceral endoderm: tetraploid rescue of Hnf-4( to / to ) embryos.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	250	 (1998) The embryonic expression of the tissue-specific transcription factor HNF1 alpha in Xenopus: rapid activation by HNF4 and delayed induction by mesoderm inducers.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	251	 (2001) Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4alpha (Nuclear Receptor 2A1) is essential for maintenance of hepatic gene expression and lipid homeostasis.
0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	252	 (2000) HNF4alpha regulates the expression of pancreatic beta-cell genes implicated in glucose metabolism and nutrient-induced insulin secretion.

0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	281	 (1999) The phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase gene glucocorticoid response unit: identification of the functional domains of accessory factors HNF3 beta (hepatic nuclear factor-3 beta) and HNF4 and the necessity of proper alignment of their cognate binding sites.

0.49352923.14602925.html.plaintext.txt	293	 (2000) Mutations in the estrogen receptor ligand binding domain discriminate between hormone-dependent transactivation and transrepression.
